DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 1, or the third day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial regulator bans short selling of stock for two weeks

TEXT.P: Short selling of stocks will be banned for two weeks from Wednesday, the Financial Supervisory Commission announced Tuesday.
Under the new measures, which are designed to boost the local bourse, short sales of stocks, even at prices above the closing prices of the previous trading day, will be banned until Oct. 14.
The drastic measures were decided upon after the bourse took a nosedive for four consecutive business days after a U.S. bailout plan was mired in the House of Representatives and finally rejected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Big flock of sacred ibises observed in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Conservationists observed a flock of over 100 sacred ibises on fallow farmland in the southern county of Tainan Tuesday, after residents reported what they thought was a big group of black-faced spoonbills resting on the land.
Tainan County has a wild bird conservation wetland where the migratory spoonbills, an endangered species of wading bird, spend the winter every year.
Chiu Yen-wu, chairman of the Tainan County Ecology Conservation Society, said they doubted the report because it is too early in the year for the endangered birds to appear in the county.

The first spoonbills usually arrive in Taiwan from the north for wintering between October and November and would never rest on dry land, said Chiu, who added that they were unsurprised, therefore, to find that the birds were in fact a flock of 126 sacred ibises, although the birds are rarely seen in such numbers in Taiwan.
Chiu said it was likely that a huge number of earthworms and insects appearing on the farmland after typhoon rains might be the reason the ibises had arrived in such large numbers.

The sacred ibis is a wading bird of the genus threskiornis, which breeds in sub- Saharan Africa, southeastern Iraq and formerly in Egypt, where in ancient times it was venerated and often mummified as a symbol of the god Thoth.
According to Chiu, the bird was first introduced to Taiwan by a zoo in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, over 10 years ago.
Four of the birds escaped and began to breed in the wild, and the birds are now seen in areas between Hsinchu in the north and Tainan in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: Switch to Hanyu Pinyin will cost NT$216 million: Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government estimates that it will require NT$216 million (US$6.7 million) to convert its public signs to Hanyu Pinyin, the most common standard Mandarin romanization system, an official of the southern port city said Tuesday.

Hsu Li-ming, executive director of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, noted that the city government began in 2004 to romanize all its road signs and signs at tourist spots using the Tongyong Pinyin system which was developed by a Taiwanese and is employed only in Taiwan.

If the city, which is under an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, now decides to adopt the Hanyu Pinyin system in line with central government policy, the price tag will be NT$216 million, Hsu said.

According to the city's Maintenance Office, there are a total of 34,000 road signs in Taiwan's largest southern city. At a cost of NT$1,500 to make one sign, it will require NT$51 million to convert all the city's road signs to a different romanization system, the office said.
Moreover, Hsu noted, road signs are only a fraction of all the public signs that would have to be replaced.
If the central government insists on Kaohsiung City changing its signs, the local government would have to ask the central government to foot the bill, he said.

As part of efforts to bring Taiwan in line with international standards, the Executive Yuan recently decided to standardize the transliteration of Chinese ideograms into the Roman alphabet by replacing the Tongyong Pinyin system with Hanyu Pinyin, which is used by the United Nations and the world community.
Under the new policy, all road signs and other public signs around Taiwan will have to be changed.

However, Kaohsiung City has challenged the policy, with Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP saying that "language should not used as a tool for political expediency, nor should it be given a political purpose."
Chen said that she thinks as long as the language system is convenient to use and can be easily adopted in communication, it is good enough.
Tongyong Pinyin was adopted by the previous pro-independent DPP administration, which was in power for eight years before it lost to the Kuomintang in the March 22 presidential election.

The DPP administration was criticized as selecting the Tongyong Pinyin romanization system for political and ideological reasons and accused of abandoning the universal Hanyu Pinyin system mainly because it originated and is used in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: President confident Taiwan will weather global financial crisis

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that he is confident that Taiwan will be able to weather the current global financial crisis.

Speaking at an award-presentation ceremony for the winners of "Taiwan's Top 20 Global Brands," Ma noted that most people in Taiwan are heavy-hearted about the financial storm in the United States that has also adversely affected Taiwan.

"This is not the first time Taiwan has encountered such difficulties," Ma said, adding that although the global financial environment is unfavorable, he believes that as long as Taiwan braces itself for worse to come, it will ride out the crisis.
The president pointed out that Taiwan survived the first world oil crisis in the 1970s, the second world energy crisis in the 1980s and the Asian financial crisis in the 1990s.
He said he had visited quite a few enterprises in Taiwan recently and found their executives to be confident about the future for Taiwan's economy.
Ma's speech came shortly after the U.S. House of Representatives voted down a US$700 billion plan aimed at bailing out Wall Street.

The rescue package -- a result of hard bargaining between the Bush administration and lawmakers, was rejected by a vote of 228-205 in the House of Representatives, with two-thirds of Republican lawmakers refusing to back the plan.

Reacting to the House decision, Wall Street shares nosedived, sending the benchmark index down by 777 points -- its biggest daily points fall in history. All major stock markets in Europe and Asia also tumbled sharply. Taiwan's stock market shed 210.35 points, with the weighted index closing at 5,719.28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Transparent mechanism needed for sovereign fund: vice premier

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Wednesday that creating a sovereign wealth fund would be helpful for Taiwan's economy but that a transparent mechanism must also be set up to manage it.
Chiu made the comments ahead of a meeting to be held by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) later the same day to discuss the feasibility of creating such a fund.

The CEPD has invited the heads of relevant ministries and agencies, including the Ministry of Finance, the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Central Bank of the Republic of China, as well as leading academics and experts to attend the meeting.
Chiu said that if a "concrete plan" on the creation of a sovereign wealth fund is arrived at during the meeting, the plan will be sent to the Executive Yuan for approval.

Vice President Vincent Siew, who serves as the convener of a new panel of presidential economic advisers, said a day earlier that establishing a sovereign wealth fund could serve as a tool to consolidate relevant resources.

Many countries have in recent years set up sovereign wealth funds -- a state- owned wealth fund composed of financial assets such as stocks, bonds, property, precious metals or other financial instruments -- to help expand their wealth.
Such a fund could initially be financed by using part of Taiwan's US$282 billion in foreign exchange reserves held as of the end of August.

Speaking with reporters, Chiu said that such a fund would be beneficial to the nation's economy but stressed that the most important element would be establishing a transparent system for the fund's management.

On the issue of using the existing National Stabilization Fund, Chiu said that the government is continuing to closely monitor financial markets to decide the most appropriate time to step in to stabilize the situation with an injection of capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-New Zealand mutual fishery check mechanism activated

TEXT.P: A mechanism between Taiwan and New Zealand to help uncover illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing activities (IUU fishing) has been activated recently, the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture reported Wednesday.

The Fisheries Agency said that Taiwanese deep-sea fishing boats operating in the West and Central Pacific Ocean should let New Zealand fishery officials or police board and inspect their vessels -- after establishing that the New Zealand authorities are genuine -- to help crack down on transboundary IUU fishing.
About 1,500 Taiwanese fishing boats are currently operating in the West and Central Pacific Ocean areas, mainly to commercially fish tuna, sharks and sailfish.

Of the total, 100 smaller longline fishing vessels, usually used to fish tuna, that operate in open seas or in other countries' economic zones under contract from those countries are the most likely to be targeted for inspection, the Fisheries Agency said.
An agency official said Taiwanese vessels that don't cooperate with the inspections or are found to have violated regulations could be banned from fishing commercially in those areas.
Taiwanese fishing boats under scrutiny are urged to have relevant documentation and fishing logbooks ready for the inspections.

They should also be properly equipped with fish size measurement gear and monitoring equipment that helps them avoid catching protected sea turtles or sea birds or amassing younger fish they are not allowed to catch.

The Taiwan-New Zealand mutual fishery examination mechanism marked the first time that Taiwan has participated in such inspection efforts aimed at maximizing long term benefits from the Pacific Ocean since the West and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) passed an agreement in December 2006, the official said.
Taiwan is a WCPFC member.

The worldwide value of IUU catches are worth up to US$9.5 billion, a World Commission on Protected Areas' High Seas Task Force study shows. IUU catches make up about 14 percent of the value of the global marine catch, based on figures available for 2001.
Up to 30 percent of IUU fishing occurs beyond national jurisdiction, where there are fewer controls, according to the study.

Sharks and deep sea fish are being caught at an unsustainable rate, and fragile coral reefs, seamounts and sponge beds are in peril from destructive fishing practices such as bottom trawling, according to the study.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan arms sales still under consideration: U.S. official
DOC.DATELINE: Jacksonville, Florida., Sept. 30 (CNA) 10/01/08 14:42:32 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A U.S. State Department official repeated Tuesday that pending weapons sales to Taiwan are still being screened under an internal review process in the executive branch, as a delay in the sales is raising deep concern in Taiwan.
The administration will notify Congress when the interagency process reaches a final decision, said John Norris, acting deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs.
Norris said he would not pay too much attention to when the notification is issued, because the United States maintains close economic and trade relations and civil exchanges with Taiwan.
In addition, there is the Taiwan Relations Act that governs security issues concerning Taiwan, he said.
Norris made the remarks when asked about the matter by Taiwanese media on the sidelines of the 7th U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference held in Jacksonville, Florida.

Taiwan was excluded from the list when the State Department notified Congress of its approval of six arms deals with France, Turkey, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia on Sept. 26 -- the date when Congress was scheduled to adjourn.
The adjournment has been postponed for a week due to a deadlock over a US$700 billion bailout package for Wall Street amid the collapse of venerable financial institutions.

The pending arms deals to Taiwan cover anti-tank missiles, Apache helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, diesel-electric submarines, P3C Orion anti- submarine aircraft, ship-launched Harpoon anti-ship missiles and Black Eagle helicopters.
Taiwan fears that if the deals are not finalized by the end of the year, approval of the sales will be pushed to 2009 and a new U.S. administration.

During his address to the U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference, David Sedney, deputy assistant secretary of defense for East Asia, said the internal review process for the arms sales was far more complicated than imagined and that he did not know if and when notification would be given.

Sedney said, however, that the U.S. government maintains its firm commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act, under which the United States makes available items necessary for Taiwan to maintain a sufficient defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: Annual international photovoltaic forum to begin next week

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum will begin Oct. 7 at the Taipei International Convention Center, with several top executives from prominent companies in the field invited to deliver keynote speeches, organizers said Wednesday.

Organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the forum and the accompanying exhibition of photovoltaic technology and applications have been held annually since 2006.
In 2007, 820 experts and executives attended the event, according to the council.

TAITRA officials said three main topics have been set for this year's event, including "the current status of and trends in the global photovoltaic industry, " "the current status of and trends in the global photovoltaic market," and "solar-grade silicon."
They said experts and executives will share their ideas and insights on these topics during the forum's eight seminars.

According to the schedule, foreign speakers invited include Muramatsu Tetsurou, general manager of Sharp's solar systems group, Erik Thorsen, president and CEO of REC Group, Ernesto Macias Galan, general manager of Isofoton and president of European Photovoltaic Industry Association, and Lei Ting, vice president of Suntech Power Holdings Co.
The event has also invited several executives from Taiwan-based companies, such as Auria Solar Co., Gintech Energy Corp., Lucky Power Technology, and Sino- American Silicon Products Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 44.73 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at 5,764.01.

Rebounding from losses of the previous day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 5,854 and posted a low of 5,727.72. A total of 2.82 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$62.86 billion (US$1.96 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 3.3 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 2.3 percent, foodstuff issues rose 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 0.9 percent, and cement stocks increased 0.6 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues dropping 1.3 percent and banking and financial shares shedding 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,188 to 485, with 373 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$7.27 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaoshiung CDC launches free flu-shot season

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government announced the launch of the free flu-shot season Wednesday, urging all eligible residents of the southern port city to head to the nearest hospital or clinic to receive inoculations against the disease.

Among the top officials attending the press conference were Tsai Lung-chu, deputy director of the Kaohsiung City's Department of Health, and Chang Ching- yun, head of the Kaohsiung City Medical Association, who received flu shots as part of the promotional effort.

Those eligible for free flu shots include children aged six months to three years, elementary students in grades 1 through 4, patients with serious injuries, seniors aged 65 or over, medical workers, disease control personnel, workers in the poultry industry and others at high risk of being infected.
The Cabinet-level Department of Health has distributed a total of 84,000 doses of flu vaccine to 285 clinics and hospitals participating in the program around the city.
The free flu shot period will run through Nov. 30, municipal health officials said, adding that any doses left over will be available to other residents of the city from Dec.1.

Han Yung-kuang, a division chief with Kaohsiung's Department of Health in charge of disease control, said that in the past, the city has achieved a success rate of about 45 percent in terms of inoculating eligible residents, adding that the department hopes to boost that figure to over 50 percent.
Noting that flu vaccine is an inactive vaccine, Han said it produces only mild side effects at worst and that the vaccine is very safe.
A small percentage of those who receive the flu shot suffer from very mild symptoms, such as inflammation, fever or fatigue, but fully recover within one or two days, he continued.

The Formosa Plastics Group is also offering a total of 25,000 doses of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) to Kaohsiung residents over the age of 75. PPV, also known as Pneumovax, is used to prevent pneumococcus bacteria infections, such as pneumonia and septicaemia.
Han said seniors who are examined by a doctor and found not to have a fever or related symptoms can safely receive both the PPV and flu shots at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Data from Taiwan weather satellite benefiting 47 nations: gov't

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-made weather satellite, the Formosat-3/COSMIC, has been transmitting data to 47 nations as of Wednesday, two years after it was first put in space, the National Space Program Office (NSPO) reported.

The Formosat-3/COSMIC mission has so far provided to 842 researchers and institutions from 47 nations near-real time information, including information on the global distribution of air pressure, temperature, and water vapor of the atmosphere, as well as the electron density of the ionosphere, NSPO Director Jiun-jih Miau said.
Data from the satellite help the various countries forecast the weather, including dramatic changes such as typhoons, and help them determine weather patterns and changes in the climate.

The COSMIC (Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate) data has also been integrated into weather forecast systems of the United States, the European Union and major countries in Asia, Miau said at the opening of the 2008 Formosat-3/COSMIC annual science meeting which will last from Oct. 1-3 in Taipei.

In the near future, the space program will strive to conduct an "intense observation period" to perform cross data validation as well as prediction studies of typhoon track, heavy rainfall areas, and rainfall accumulation in the East Asia region, Miau added.

The Formosat-3/COSMIC annual science meeting is the main international forum for scientific discussions and interactions among those involved in the Formosat-3/COSMIC space mission and related sciences.
The meeting was held in conjunction with the fourth Asian Space Conference.
Altogether, 300 scholars and specialist and students from 14 nations and the host Taiwan are taking part in the two related events.

The Formosat-3/COSMIC mission, part of the national science program's satellite project and built in collaboration with the United States, was launched in April 2006 from a U.S. military base in California and is scheduled to be completed in 2016.

Currently, the orbiting satellite FORMOSAT-3, consisting of six mini-satellites, is conducting space-borne GPS radio occultation of atmospheric and ionospheric sounding observations numbering up to 2000 per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola suspends service

TEXT.P: The Maokong Gondola, the city's popular cable car system, suspended operations indefinitely Wednesday afternoon as questions lingered over the system's safety after its foundation may have been weakened by Typhoon Jangmi.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin had assured the public on Monday the system was safe after a landslide occurred near a support tower over the weekend, saying the cable car system's consultants CECI Engineering Consultants, Inc., Taiwan, had assessed the system and vouched for its safety.
But Hau was forced to reverse his position Wednesday and shut down the system pending further assessment.

Taipei City Councilman Chuang Jui-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, his colleagues and city government officials inspected the mountainous area again Wednesday and found an 1.8-meter high opening under the foundation of the No. 16 support tower that had been washed away by the typhoon.
Chuang said he "was shocked" to see the serious erosion.
More than a dozen city councilmen of the ruling Kuomintang then called on Hau to ask him to suspend the cable car system's operations. Hau agreed and shut down the system at 3 p.m.

Taipei city government spokesman Yang Hsiao-tung said that engineering and construction experts have been commissioned to inspect the scene and conduct a safety assessment, with a conclusion expected in one month.
"Before experts complete their assessment, the government will suspend the system's operations," Yang said.

Chen Hsiung-wen, commissioner of the city's Department of Economic Development, said that the city government has appropriated NT$50 million to shore up the slope on which the pillar is located over the next six months.
He said, however, that "it is still uncertain whether the operations of cable system will be suspended during the six months."
Torrential rains brought by Typhoon Jangmi, which hit Taiwan over the weekend, caused a landslide on the slope near the No. 16 support tower that swept to a nearby community on Wanshou Road.
Residents and city councilmen blamed the cable car system for the landslide, which they said was the first ever to have hit the location.

The residents and elected officials have visited the site over the past three days and urged the city government to suspend the cable car's operations, but their appeals had been rejected by the mayor.
Taipei Rapid Transit Corp., which runs the Maokong Gondola, said that over 6.1 million passengers had ridden the system as of Tuesday since its official inauguration July 4, 2007.
Company officials said that those who have bought gondola tickets could call the 24-hour hotline (02) 2181-2345 or 1999 Citizen Hotline for a refund.

DOC.HEADLINE: President: national pension system milestone for social security

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou declared Wednesday, the inauguration day of the new national pension system, that Taiwan's social security system is now more comprehensive, setting a milestone for the country.

At a press conference to launch the system, Ma said that together with the National Health Insurance Program and other insurance programs, the new pension system will consolidate Taiwan's social security network, ensuring that the whole population is covered by insurance.

The national pension system will be open to anyone with household registration in Taiwan aged between 25 and 65 who is not covered by other social welfare insurance such as farmer's health insurance, government employee insurance, insurance for military personnel and labor insurance.

Noting that the country's population is aging, Ma said that "even if there will be fewer people to support elderly citizens in the future, we don't have to worry, since the national system is now established."

According to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , people over 65 are expected to account for 20 percent of the country's population by 2026, and in 2030, every senior citizen will have only three working people to support them, down from the present seven.

"From now on, Taiwan is in an era in which the entire population can be covered by insurance, and the country's social security network is complete, " Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said at the press conference, adding that with the new system, the government has taken a further step in taking care of the underprivileged.
In the first year of the new system's implementation, the monthly premium is decided based on the basic minimum wage, which is NT$17,280 (US$539.5) at present.@@

The premium rate for the insurance is 6.5 percent for the first year, to be increased by 0.5 percent in the third year and thereafter by 0.5 percent every two years until it reaches a limit of 12 percent.
The insured must pay 60 percent of the premium, while the central competent authority will be responsible for the remaining 40 percent.
Under the regulations, an insured person who pays a monthly premium of NT$674 for 40 years will receive NT$8,986 every month from the age of 65 -- the standard retirement threshold -- until death.
In addition, to safeguard women's right, husbands should pay the premiums for their spouses if they are full-time housekeepers, noted Interior Minister Liau Liou-yi.

@According to the National Pension Act, funding for the subsidized premiums and related expenses should be appropriated by the central competent authority. Apart from annual budget, the surplus from the public welfare lottery for the national pension and an increase of business tax by 1 percent could also contribute to the available funds.
@The amendment to the National Pension Act was approved by the Legislative Yuan in July 2008. @@ (By Emmanuelle Tzeng) @

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tightens ban on plant, animal importation

TEXT.P: Taiwan implemented a new measure Wednesday under which inbound travelers can be fined a minimum of NT$3,000 for failing to make an import declaration or quarantine application for animals, animal products, plants, and plant products.
The government has since Jan. 1, 2007 banned inbound travelers from bringing in most plants and animals as well as plant and animal products, but had imposed no penalty until Wednesday.

According to the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) , the importation of all live animals and animal products is forbidden, except for dogs, cats, rabbits and animal products that have cleared quarantine inspection.
In terms of plants, no fresh fruit is allowed, while live plants and other fresh products are also banned, except for those that have cleared quarantine inspection.

BAPHIQ Deputy Director-General Huang Kuo-ching said the new measure was adopted to strengthen the government's effort to block the entry of animals and plants that may carry various diseases or pests, such as foot-and-mouth disease and fruit flies, which can cause serious damage to Taiwan's agriculture sector.

Shen Kuo-san, chief of the BAPHIQ's Hsinchu branch office, noted that it is common practice for Taiwanese travelers to bring home foreign fruit, vegetables, spices, fresh meats and processed meats. The fine was introduced to stop such practices, he said.
Individuals who have questions concerning the importation of animals and plants can visit the BAPHIQ's Web site or contact any of the BAPHIQ's branch offices, Shen said.

Meanwhile, in light of the popular practice of foreign workers bringing to Taiwan animal and plant products from their home countries, the BAPHIQ said it is planning to request the Council of Labor Affairs to help promote the regulations among labor brokers and foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. diplomat pays homage to late American nurse on Penghu

TEXT.P: The director of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) Kaohsiung Office paid homage to late American nurse Marjorie I. Bly in Makong City on the Penghu Islands off southwestern Taiwan, Wednesday, honoring the U.S. citizen's devotion of her life to caring for leprosy patients.
Christian M. Castro laid a bouquet of flowers at a statue of Bly, known locally by her Chinese name of Pai Pao-chu.
In his address, Castro acclaimed Bly for her lifetime devotion to caring for leprosy patients on Penghu, where she lived for 54 years before passing away April 8 this year.
He said the devotion has not only won her the respect of the public but has also inspired people to care for lepers.

He expressed appreciation to the Penghu county government for giving the nurse the assistance she needed to do her job and expressed hope that the spirit of Bly's selflessness will be passed down through the generations.
Bly, born in 1919 to an American missionary family, came to Taiwan at the commission of the Lutheran Church Nov. 17, 1952 to provide care for leprosy patients and families through an outreach clinic.
In 1954, she moved to Penghu, where she continued to care for lepers. She performed follow-up care and treatment for all leprosy patients in the county and advocated their inclusion in society.
Because of her great love for Penghu's residents, Bly was called by the locals "an angel sent by God to Penghu."
In April 2007, she received the country's highest civilian award, the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon, from then-President Chen Shui-bian.
Out of love for the place she called home for 54 years, Bly demanded in her will that her remains should stay on Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH minister vows to enhance control over food ingredient sources

TEXT.P: In the midst of a food safety panic caused by tainted Chinese milk powder, The Department of Health (DOH) announced Wednesday that all imported and local dairy products and food products containing vegetable-based protein food additives will be examined for the toxic chemical melamine.

All imported and local food products, including creamer, milk powder and baby formula, will have to be examined using the liquid chromatography/tandem mass (LC/MS/MS) test, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said at a press conference.
LC/MS/MS is a sensitive analytical instrument used to detect specific chemicals.
"The DOH will also enhance random examinations of such products, especially those from `risky countries,'" said Yeh without naming the countries.

At present, only 5 percent of the food products in each shipment is checked, but 20 percent of imported dairy products and foodstuffs containing vegetable-based protein additives will be examined from now on, Yeh said.

He also noted that with immediate effect, these products should be declared at customs with a report from the exporting country on examination for melamine, the detection limit of which should be noted in the report.
As for Chinese milk power, dairy products and creamer, Yeh reiterated that the government will continue to impose an import ban on these items.

He noted that all tainted ingredients and products in Taiwan have already been either seized or recalled, and he urged the public to have no fear of consuming products found on store shelves, all of which have by now tested negative for melamine.@@
Due to the widespread melamine contamination in many products, food companies and ingredient suppliers have suffered from enormous economic losses and damage to their business images.@@

Addressing the issue of melamine-tainted biscuits imported from Malaysia and sold in the megastore Costco, Yeh said that all the contaminated biscuits had been seized and that the Malaysian food manufacturer is suspected to have used tainted Chinese milk powder.@

China is blamed for the global melamine contamination that has killed at least four babies in China and sickened thousands who have been fed on tainted baby formula. Melamine in sufficient doses can cause kidney stones and lead to kidney failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chief urges China to help mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung asked for assistance from China for Taiwanese businessmen based there, during a meeting with visiting Chinese officials Wednesday, citing increasing difficulties encountered by the island's companies.

Chiang, Taiwan's top negotiator with China, called for Chinese government attention to several major problems that many Taiwan businesses have encountered in China, and urged it to properly address them in a meeting with a visiting group of Chinese Communist Party officials from Suzhou City, in east China's coastal Jiangsu Province.

"The credit crisis which originated in the United States and has swept the whole world is impacting both Taiwan and China, including Taiwanese business people there, " Chiang said. "The crisis and changing investment environments together have stirred up much stronger pressure on Taiwanese enterprises in China."
Many of the pressures Taiwanese companies face are due to a series of austerity measures Beijing imposed in recent years to cool its fast growing economy.

According to Chiang, Taiwanese businessmen operating in China have been hit hard by difficulties in getting bank loans and land as well as problems arising from a new labor contract law enacted by Beijing in January this year to protect workers.
The SEF chairman also asked the Suzhou city government to help Taiwanese businessmen overcome these problems in Suzhou.
Since the 1990s, Suzhou has increasingly become one of the major investment clusters for Taiwanese businessmen in China.

In response, Wang Rong, Suchou City Party Committee secretary, promised to help Taiwanese firms get needed credit loans from the Jiangsu provincial government, pointing out that Beijing has given its approval for local authorities to provide loans to small businesses.

Commenting on the growing difficulties in acquiring land in China, Wang said that Chinese companies are facing the same problem as their Taiwanese counterparts and described the tightening of land management as a "necessary step" in China's economic development.
The Suzhou city government would be willing to help private companies tackle their difficulties in acquiring land for their businesses on a case-by-case basis, Wang said.

The semi-official SEF is responsible for dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.
The SEF and ARATS inked two milestone accords in June in Beijing to step up two- way tourism and transportation services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banning teachers from forming unions unconstitutional: nominees

TEXT.P: All of the five grand justice nominees agreed that banning teachers from organizing their own unions is unconstitutional.
The nominees for grand justices were at a meeting at the Legislative Yuan, where legislators from across the political spectrum were reviewing their nominations by President Ma Ying-jeou.

The five nominees were asked by opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators Kuan Bi-ling and Chen Ting-fei to express their opinions by raising their hands on whether it is unconstitutional if teachers are prohibited from organizing unions to defend their rights and interests.
All the five nominees raised their hands to express that it is unconstitutional if teachers are prohibited from doing so.
Taiwan's current labor union law prohibits teachers from organizing their own unions.

Meanwhile, the five nominees also expressed unanimously that it is not against the Constitution that a referendum screening committee was established by the Executive Yuan to oversee matters pertaining to nationwide referendums and related activities.

On whether they oppose or support the notion that the death penalty should be abolished once and for all in Taiwan and whether same-sex marriages should be legalized, the five nominees gave differing points of view.
DPP lawmaker Kuan said later that the justice nominees are too conservative.
President Ma last month nominated the five legal experts to serve as the country's grand justices.

They are Huang Mao-jung, a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Law; Chen Min, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Law; Yeh Pei-hsiu, a judge at the Supreme Administrative Court; Chen Chun-sheng, dean of the Law School of National Taipei University; and Chen Hsin-min, a researcher with Academia Sinica's preparatory office for the Institute of Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free influenza inoculation program kicks off

TEXT.P: An annual government-funded flu inoculation program targeting high-risk groups began Wednesday, bringing people flocking to the Taipei Municipal Ho Ping Hospital in search of free flu shots.

Inspecting the inoculation set-up at the hospital, Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director-General Lin Ting noted that flu outbreaks normally come to a peak in late November and then gradually tail off after the Lunar New Year holiday, which usually falls in February.
As it takes around two weeks for the vaccine to produce immunity, Lin advised people to get vaccinated before the end of October.

The targets of this year's program include senior citizens aged 65 and older, residents and workers of nursing homes, children between the ages of six months and 3 years, and first through fourth graders.

Patients suffering from rare diseases, major diseases or injuries, disease prevention and control personnel at medical and health institutions, workers in the poultry and livestock industries, and animal disease control and prevention personnel are also among those targeted, according to the CDC.

Lin said the CDC has purchased 3.2 million doses of flu vaccine to meet this year's demand. If there are still doses left over Nov. 30 when the program expires, they will be available to other citizens from Dec. 1, he noted.

In addition to the flu shots, Lin mentioned that those aged over 75 are also entitled this year to a free inoculation of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) , also known as Pneumovax, used to prevent pneumococcus bacteria infections such as pneumonia and septicaemia.

The Formosa Plastics Group, a Taiwanese conglomerate, donated nearly 580,000 doses of PPV through its social welfare charity foundation to protect the elderly from the threat of pneumonia, which struck the group's 91-year-old founder Wang Yung-ching several years ago.
As the immunity offered by PPV can last for five years, those who have been inoculated within the last five years were advised not to get a shot this year.
The shots are available at designated medical institutions, according to the CDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imbalanced life seen as main cause of ill-health: survey

TEXT.P: A survey on people's health knowledge shows that an imbalanced life pattern is believed by most respondents to be the top cause of ill-health, according to the survey results released Wednesday.
Common Health Magazine conducted the survey via telephone among people aged 18 or over Aug. 19-24, receiving 1,087 valid responses.
A similar survey carried out 10 years ago by the same magazine showed that most respondents at that time blamed congenital problems for poor health.

The new survey shows that people have made progress in health knowledge, as the smoking population is smaller, down from 21.4 percent of respondents to 17.76 percent, while more people eat breakfast, up from 64 percent to 77 percent.
In addition, 53.7 percent of respondents exercise at least three times a week, up form the 39 percent in the previous survey, the results show.

However, nearly half of the respondents said they did not know that breakfast is the most important meal of the day, and over 30 percent of them were unaware of their waist size, which is an indicator of one's health condition, according to the report.

Meanwhile, 85.65 percent of respondents said they consider themselves healthy, higher than the previous survey's 73.9 percent. However, cancer remained the biggest worry for respondents, the same as in the previous survey 10 years ago.

More females than males expressed worry about cancer -- 32.41 percent to 22.61 percent -- even though recent medical statistics show that the number of men who died of cancer in 2007 was 1.7 times that of the number of women who died of the disease, the report said.

About 40 percent of the male respondents were unable to describe the location of the prostate gland. Prostate cancer ranked the fifth-most-common form of cancer in men, with 900 people dying of the disease every year on average, higher than the number of women who die of cervical cancer each year on average, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest sex ring in Taipei area smashed

TEXT.P: Taipei City police smashed the largest-ever sex ring in the greater Taipei area Wednesday, arresting nine people, including a chief suspect, accountants, pimps and call girls, a spokesman said.
After lengthy tracking and investigation, Taipei police authorities detained the ring leader surnamed Lee, as well as drivers and prostitutes from China and Indonesia in a raid early Wednesday.
Police also confiscated hundreds of items, such as account books, monthly reports, records of customers' sex deals and PDAs, the spokesman said.
All nine suspects were handed to Taipei prosecutors for further questioning on charges of pandering, he said.

Account books seized by police showed that the ring, which maintained more than 20 brothels and hired over 1,000 local and foreign sex workers -- mostly from China and Southeast Asian countries, made several millions of New Taiwan dollars each week until recently, making the ring the largest of its kind in the greater Taipei area ever smashed by police, the spokesman said.

Taipei policemen also discovered that the ring, in a bid to prevent from being tracked down by law enforcement authorities, had compiled a large number of newspaper files relating to news about sex trade and human trafficking.

To the policemen's surprise, all these news clippings contained detailed information about where, when and by whom criminal suspects in the same line of illegal business were arrested, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most reservoirs in Taiwan full or nearly full after five typhoons

TEXT.P: The five successive typhoons that hit Taiwan between July and September this year have caused 16 deaths and NT$2.89 billion (US$90 million) in damage to agricultural crops, but the upside is that most of Taiwan's reservoirs are full or almost full.

As of the end of September, five of the 15 storms in the western Pacific this year had swept across Taiwan. They were Typhoon Kalmaegi on July 18, Typhoon Fung-Wong on July 28, Typhoon Sinlaku on Sept. 12, Typhoon Hagupit on Sept. 22, and Typhoon Jangmi on Sept. 27-28.

According to a news release from the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, most of Taiwan's reservoirs are more than 90 percent full as a result of the heavy rains brought by the typhoons.

Three of the reservoirs -- Liyutan Reservoir in Miaoli County, Renyitan Reservoir in Chiayi County, and Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan County -- are brimming and are being allowed to overflow naturally, while Lantan Reservoir in the city of Chiayi and Chengkung Reservoir in Penghu, an island west of Taiwan, are almost full.

Seven other reservoirs are more than 90 percent full. They are Feitsui Reservoir, which supplies drinking water to the Taipei area; Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan County; Baoshan reservoir and the Second Baoshan Reservoir in Hsinchu County; Mingte Reservoir in Miaoli County; Tsengwen Reservoir -- Taiwan's largest reservoir -- located in Tainan County; and Wushantou Reservoir, also in Tainan County.

At present, only the Sinshan Reservoir in Keelung, the Techi Reservoir in Taichung County, the Shihgang Dam Reservoir in Taichung County, and the Mudan Reservoir in Pingtung County are still less than 80 percent full.
Taiwan is an island whose short rivers and streams, flowing from steep mountains, can hardly retain the valuable resource. The people of Taiwan rely on abundant rainfall for a secure water supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top financial regulator forecasts rosy outlook starting year's end

TEXT.P: The nation's top financial regulator expressed optimism about the prospects of the country's stock market Wednesday, predicting that the local bourse will regain momentum from late his year through the coming year.

Gordon S. Chen, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) made the remarks while reporting to the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) Central Standing Committee on measures to stabilize and develop the local stock market amid a global financial crisis.

Speaking at the committee's weekly meeting, Chen noted that between May 21 and Sept. 26, Taiwan's bourse fell more sharply than the stock markets in the United States, Japan, South Korea, and China. The KMT came to power on May 20.
But for the period from Jan. 1 to Sept. 26, the drop in shares on the Taiwan market was more moderate than in Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore, he said.
At present, 209 listed companies in Taiwan boast a stock price-earnings (P/E) ratio of less than 10, and 171 others with a stock P/E ratio of between 10 and 15, according to Chen.
These companies account for 60 percent of the listed companies in Taiwan, which indicates that many stock prices have fallen below reasonable levels and are worth buying, Chen said.
In view of the slumping bourse, the Executive Yuan on Sept. 5 unveiled five measure to help boost the market, he added.

Under the plan, the government is seeking to build on the country's sound fundamentals and introduce measures to revive investor confidence; encourage directors and supervisors to buy back their companies' stocks; encourage blue- chip companies to buy back treasury stocks; encourage venture capital companies to solicit equity mutual funds to invest in the local bourse; and encourage investors to buy equity mutual funds.

The Executive Yuan has been following the progress of the five initiatives, and "measures such as encouraging companies to buy back treasury stocks and urging directors and supervisors to buy back their own company stocks have borne fruit," according to Chen.

He also said that the FSC has banned short selling of stocks for two weeks, a move that is also aimed at helping boost the local stock market. Short selling of stocks, even at prices higher than the previous trading day, will be banned until Oct. 14, he added.
Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 44.73 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at 5,764.01.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County hosts indigenous culture museums meeting

TEXT.P: Representatives of 28 museums nationwide that house indigenous cultural artifacts met recently in the central county of Changhua to exchange views on the operation of the museums, Changhua County Deputy Magistrate Chang Jui-pin said Wednesday.

The meeting, joined by over 50 representatives of public and private museums of aboriginal culture, took place at the county's Indigenous Peoples Cultural Artifacts Exhibition Hall Sept. 24, Chang said.

The meeting, organized by the Council of Indigenous Peoples under the Executive Yuan in collaboration with the Changhua County government, was expected to result in a consensus on integrating resources like information, collections, and personnel, in the hope of enhancing the museums' operations.

According to Chang, the aim of the meeting was to allow participants to share their experience in running museums, discuss difficulties they confronted, outline their plans for the future, and come up with new ideas on boosting the cultural industry for aboriginal tribes.
The meeting was the second of its kind. The first meeting was held in Taipei City Aug. 30, and the third will be held in Yilan County Oct. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Saint Kitts and Nevis celebrates 25th anniversary of independence

TEXT.P: Saint Kitts and Nevis, one of Taiwan's allies in the Caribbean, held a function Wednesday in Taipei to celebrate the country's 25th anniversary of independence.

Foreign diplomats and government officials present at the event includedg Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, Vice Foreign Minister Javier Hou, and Nicaraguan Ambassador to the Republic of China William M. Tapia.

Jasmine Huggins, Saint Kitts and Nevis charge d'affaires to Taiwan, began her speech by expressing condolences to the families that lost loved ones during the passage of Typhoon Jangmi. The function was postponed from Monday to Wednesday because of the storm.

Noting that Taiwan was the first country to establish diplomatic relations with the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis 25 years ago, Huggins said the Republic of China on Taiwan has proved a friend to the Caribbean country.

"Over the years, our close collaboration has brought mutual benefit to both our nations. Out relations have grown and strengthened to the point we are today because they are based on the common ideals we share,"said Huggins.
Dennis Merchant, Saint Kitts attorney general and minister of Justice and Legal Affairs, said that his country highly treasures its friendship with Taiwan.

"The opening of our embassy in the Republic of China in January of this year, our first and only embassy in Asia, also signals our commitment to the strengthening of our ties and bonds of friendship," he said.

Ou said that his presence at the function was of extraordinary significance because he was a member of the congratulatory delegations that celebrated the independence of Saint Kitts and Nevis 25 years ago.
"I'm so happy to be here and this indicates the profound and long lasting friendship shared by Taiwan and Saint Kitts and Nevis, " he said.

Taiwan became the first diplomatic ally of Saint Kitts and Nevis after its independence on Sept. 19, 1983 and the two forged diplomatic ties on Oct. 9 that same year. The country is the only one of Taiwan's five Caribbean allies to have established an embassy in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Jangmi rise to NT$1.63 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to Typhoon Jangmi had soared to NT$1.63 billion (US$50.74 million) as of Wednesday noon, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Jangmi, which pummeled Taiwan Sept. 27-28, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in six counties, with Changhua and Taichung counties in central Taiwan being the hardest-hit.
The statistics show that damage to agricultural crops accounted for NT$1.46 billion, as 21 percent of the crops on a total of 42,486 hectares of farmland were lost.
The crops that suffered the heaviest damage included rice, grapes, persimmons, bananas, tangerines, papayas, guavas, maize, shallots and custard apples.
Some NT$5.61 million worth of poultry perished because of flooding caused by the storm, while damage to poultry farm facilities reached NT$22.22 million.
The losses suffered by the aquaculture sector totaled NT$81.89 million, with oyster farming taking the hardest hit.
Damage to farmland and agricultural facilities amounted to NT$52.34 million, and damage to fishery facilities was estimated at NT$4 million.

Changhua County recorded NT$464.14 million in agricultural losses, followed by Taichung County with NT$223.46 million, Chiayi County with NT$222.46 million, Yunglin County with NT$133,4 million, Tainan County with NT$112.15 million, and Miaoli County with NT$16.01 million.
Farmers who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's Lotus Pond ready for 2009 World Games water sports

TEXT.P: Lotus Pond in Zuoying, a district of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, will soon be ready for the water sports events in the 2009 World Games to be held in Taiwan's second largest city next July, after a 10-month dredging project to make the water at least three meters deep.

Officials at the Public Works Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government said Wednesday that they will ask the Kaohsiung Irrigation Association to begin filling the 42-hectare lake from Oct. 5, and that it will take about two weeks for the water to get to least three meters deep, in line with the international standards for water skiing, wakeboarding, canoe polo, and an invitational dragon boat race.
The officials also said that to keep the water in Lotus Pond clean, they will enforce inspections to prevent the discharge of sewage water from adjacent neighborhoods into the lake.

The dredging project, which began in December last year, was completed at a cost of NT$155 million (US$4.83 million). Workers first had to empty the lake and move all fish, turtles, shellfish and other water creatures to aquaculture facilities.
The bottom of the lake was then dredged, excavated and leveled to allow for a depth of least three meters deep for the water sports.

According to the officials, the dredging project will increase the water storage capacity of Lotus Pond by 370,000 cubic meters, and an added benefit will be better flood prevention in the area during the typhoon season.

Lotus Pond, called Lianchihtan in Chinese, is a well-known scenic spot in southern Taiwan. The lake, 1.4 km long and 400 meters wide, is fed by the Gaoping River. It once covered 75 hectares, but has shrunk to 42 hectares. The lake is considered a sacred religious place because it is surrounded by quite a few temples.
Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, has been awarded the right to host the next World Games July 16-26, 2009, which are expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: China sovereign wealth fund not to be allowed on Taiwan market: MAC

TEXT.P: The China government's sovereign wealth fund (SWF) will be excluded from the categories of Chinese capital allowed to enter the Taiwan market due to its special nature, said a senior official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.

MAC Vice Chiarman Fu Dong-cheng made the statement in response to questions from the media following a meeting held by the government earlier in the day to discuss the feasibility of creating such a fund to help bolster Taiwan's bearish stock market and revitalize its economy amid the U.S. financial crisis.

Fu said the government's failure to meet its Sept. 30 deadline for completion of its policy on opening Taiwan's market to Chinese investments was due to the fact that China has not yet put Taiwan on its list of 135 countries and areas eligible for its outbound investments.
It would not be beneficial to Taiwan if it unilaterally opens its market to Chinese capital, he said.
A sovereign wealth fund is a state-owned investment fund composed of financial assets such as stocks, bonds, property, precious metals or other financial assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food scare might be discussed in new cross-strait meeting: official

TEXT.P: Although a date has not yet been fixed for the planned visit to Taiwan by a key Beijing official, issues relating to the toxic milk products imported from China are likely to be discussed in his meeting with Taiwanese officials here, Taiwan's top negotiator with China said Wednesday.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , said the two sides are still working to reach an agreement on the date for a visit to Taiwan by his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

There have been wide speculations that Chen might visit Taiwan in late October in what would be a follow-up to an SEF-ARATS meeting in Beijing in June when the two men clinched two milestone accords to step up two-way tourism and transportation services.

Asked whether he would seek a public apology from Chen and compensation from the culpable Chinese companies for Taiwanese consumers over the melamine-tainted Chinese milk powder and vegetable-based protein food addictives issue, Chiang said that "the two sides will exchange opinions on all topics put forward in the SEF-ARATS talks."
"It has been the government's stance to discuss and settle issues pertaining to cross-Taiwan Strait economic development via the SEF-ARATS platform," he said.

Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes, and joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and crime- fighting, in their next round of negotiations.
"If the two sides reach agreements in these areas, it would greatly upgrade Taiwan's competitive edge, and I believe that this is a development the Taiwan people have long hoped for," Chiang said.

Commenting on the recent scare in Taiwan over imports of melamine-contaminated Chinese milk products and malt extract, Chiang said that a fact-finding delegation composed of Taiwanese experts that visited Beijing last weekend will contribute to future bilateral contacts and cooperation in food safety control. The delegation returned home Monday.

Chiang and Chen met for the first time for the initial round of SEF-ARATS negotiations in June in Beijing, clinching two accords on the opening of direct weekend passenger charter flights and the wider opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's envoy to Japan hopes for friendly ties, mutual trust
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 1 (CNA) 10/01/08 23:21:57 (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Japan John Feng expressed the hope Wednesday that both countries would maintain friendly relations and mutual trust.
Feng made the remarks at a welcome party hosted by Japan's largest pro-Taiwan parliamentary group, Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council.
More than 50 Japanese parliamentarians of the multipartisian group attended the function. Japanese Finance Minister Shoichi Nakagawa and People's New Party leader Tamisuke Watanuki were also present.

Council head Takeo Hiranuma, in his introduction of Feng, said that the envoy studied in Japanese elementary and junior high school for five years as Feng's father was an ROC diplomat stationed in Japan at the time.
Feng is a seasoned diplomat who is trusted by President Ma Ying-jeou, Hiranuma noted.

He further said that there are many issues between Taiwan and Japan that need to be addressed and resolved with the help of the council, and he called for all members to work toward promoting bilateral relations.
In his address, Feng praised the council for the role it plays in promoting bilateral relations.
The boat collision incident in the disputed Tiaoyutai islands in East China Sea earlier this year was "regrettable," Feng said.
He added that President Ma, who attaches great importance to Taiwan-Japan relations, has instructed him to resume and build on Taiwan's friendly relations with Japan.
Taiwan, Japan and China all claim rights to the Tiaoyutai Islands.

The controversy over the sovereignty of the island group reignited in June when a Taiwanese recreation fishing boat sank after it collided with a Japanese patrol vessel on June 10 near the Tiaoyutai Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japanese.
Japan has since apologized to the Taiwanese ship owner over the incident, but talks on compensation to the boat owner have stalled.
Feng expressed the hope that the council will continue to wield its influence to strengthen the ties between Taiwan and Japan.
The council, currently comprised of around 240 members, was established by Japanese Dietmen after the ROC and Japan severed diplomatic ties in 1972.
Feng later attended a dinner party hosted by Interchange Association (Japan) Chairman Reijiro Hattori and the association's President Atsushi Hatakenaka.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH vows to verify ARATS latest report on melamine testing

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will carefully check whether any more melamine- adulterated dairy products had been exported to Taiwan from China, an official of the Cabinet-level agency said Wednesday.

DOH spokesman Wang Tse-chao nade the remarks after China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) informed its Taiwanese counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), earlier in the day that none of the newly published 31 batches of dairy products manufactured by 20 Chinese companies were tested positive for melamine, a toxic chemical usually used to make plastics.

The ARATS stressed in its report that except for a shipment of 25 tons of Sanlu- brand milk powder exported to Taiwan from China that was found in mid-September to have been adulterated with melamine, no other tainted dairy products have been sold to Taiwan. The intermediary body further said most of the tainted products were produced by Sanlu Group -- the largest dairy producer in China, and its affiliates.

Wang said the ARATS report complies with the DOH's initial investigative results. Nevertheless, he added, the DOH will make a further inspection in terms of detailed information provided by the ARATS about corporate name list, shipment numbers and China's examination reports to verify whether any other tainted products have entered Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open little changed

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened little changed Thursday, moving up 0.47 points at 5,764.48 on a turnover of NT$1.63 billion (US$50.89 million).
The weighted price index gained 44.73 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at 5,764.01 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.076 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.047 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Saint Kitts and Nevis celebrates 25th anniversary of independence

TEXT.P: Saint Kitts and Nevis, one of Taiwan's allies in the Caribbean, held a function Wednesday in Taipei to celebrate the country's 25th anniversary of independence.

Foreign diplomats and government officials present at the event includedg Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, Vice Foreign Minister Javier Hou, and Nicaraguan Ambassador to the Republic of China William M. Tapia.

Jasmine Huggins, Saint Kitts and Nevis charge d'affaires to Taiwan, began her speech by expressing condolences to the families that lost loved ones during the passage of Typhoon Jangmi. The function was postponed from Monday to Wednesday because of the storm.

Noting that Taiwan was the first country to establish diplomatic relations with the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis 25 years ago, Huggins said the Republic of China on Taiwan has proved a friend to the Caribbean country.

"Over the years, our close collaboration has brought mutual benefit to both our nations. Out relations have grown and strengthened to the point we are today because they are based on the common ideals we share,"said Huggins.
Dennis Merchant, Saint Kitts attorney general and minister of Justice and Legal Affairs, said that his country highly treasures its friendship with Taiwan.

"The opening of our embassy in the Republic of China in January of this year, our first and only embassy in Asia, also signals our commitment to the strengthening of our ties and bonds of friendship," he said.

Ou said that his presence at the function was of extraordinary significance because he was a member of the congratulatory delegations that celebrated the independence of Saint Kitts and Nevis 25 years ago.
"I'm so happy to be here and this indicates the profound and long lasting friendship shared by Taiwan and Saint Kitts and Nevis, " he said.

Taiwan became the first diplomatic ally of Saint Kitts and Nevis after its independence on Sept. 19, 1983 and the two forged diplomatic ties on Oct. 9 that same year. The country is the only one of Taiwan's five Caribbean allies to have established an embassy in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from Typhoon Jangmi rise to NT$1.63 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to Typhoon Jangmi had soared to NT$1.63 billion (US$50.74 million) as of Wednesday noon, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

The COA said that Jangmi, which pummeled Taiwan Sept. 27-28, caused serious damage to the agricultural sector in six counties, with Changhua and Taichung counties in central Taiwan being the hardest-hit.
The statistics show that damage to agricultural crops accounted for NT$1.46 billion, as 21 percent of the crops on a total of 42,486 hectares of farmland were lost.
The crops that suffered the heaviest damage included rice, grapes, persimmons, bananas, tangerines, papayas, guavas, maize, shallots and custard apples.
Some NT$5.61 million worth of poultry perished because of flooding caused by the storm, while damage to poultry farm facilities reached NT$22.22 million.
The losses suffered by the aquaculture sector totaled NT$81.89 million, with oyster farming taking the hardest hit.
Damage to farmland and agricultural facilities amounted to NT$52.34 million, and damage to fishery facilities was estimated at NT$4 million.

Changhua County recorded NT$464.14 million in agricultural losses, followed by Taichung County with NT$223.46 million, Chiayi County with NT$222.46 million, Yunglin County with NT$133,4 million, Tainan County with NT$112.15 million, and Miaoli County with NT$16.01 million.
Farmers who suffered heavy losses can apply for cash relief or low-interest loans from the government in accordance with the Agricultural Natural Disaster Relief Regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's Lotus Pond ready for 2009 World Games water sports

TEXT.P: Lotus Pond in Zuoying, a district of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, will soon be ready for the water sports events in the 2009 World Games to be held in Taiwan's second largest city next July, after a 10-month dredging project to make the water at least three meters deep.

Officials at the Public Works Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government said Wednesday that they will ask the Kaohsiung Irrigation Association to begin filling the 42-hectare lake from Oct. 5, and that it will take about two weeks for the water to get to least three meters deep, in line with the international standards for water skiing, wakeboarding, canoe polo, and an invitational dragon boat race.
The officials also said that to keep the water in Lotus Pond clean, they will enforce inspections to prevent the discharge of sewage water from adjacent neighborhoods into the lake.

The dredging project, which began in December last year, was completed at a cost of NT$155 million (US$4.83 million). Workers first had to empty the lake and move all fish, turtles, shellfish and other water creatures to aquaculture facilities.
The bottom of the lake was then dredged, excavated and leveled to allow for a depth of least three meters deep for the water sports.

According to the officials, the dredging project will increase the water storage capacity of Lotus Pond by 370,000 cubic meters, and an added benefit will be better flood prevention in the area during the typhoon season.

Lotus Pond, called Lianchihtan in Chinese, is a well-known scenic spot in southern Taiwan. The lake, 1.4 km long and 400 meters wide, is fed by the Gaoping River. It once covered 75 hectares, but has shrunk to 42 hectares. The lake is considered a sacred religious place because it is surrounded by quite a few temples.
Kaohsiung, the second largest city in Taiwan, has been awarded the right to host the next World Games July 16-26, 2009, which are expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: China sovereign wealth fund not to be allowed on Taiwan market: MAC

TEXT.P: The China government's sovereign wealth fund (SWF) will be excluded from the categories of Chinese capital allowed to enter the Taiwan market due to its special nature, said a senior official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.

MAC Vice Chiarman Fu Dong-cheng made the statement in response to questions from the media following a meeting held by the government earlier in the day to discuss the feasibility of creating such a fund to help bolster Taiwan's bearish stock market and revitalize its economy amid the U.S. financial crisis.

Fu said the government's failure to meet its Sept. 30 deadline for completion of its policy on opening Taiwan's market to Chinese investments was due to the fact that China has not yet put Taiwan on its list of 135 countries and areas eligible for its outbound investments.
It would not be beneficial to Taiwan if it unilaterally opens its market to Chinese capital, he said.
A sovereign wealth fund is a state-owned investment fund composed of financial assets such as stocks, bonds, property, precious metals or other financial assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 2, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2001: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime.
2004: Iraqi insurgents shoot down a U.S. military helicopter near Baghdad, killing 36 soldiers and crewmen aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."
