DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan broadens visa waiver program to include more EU countries

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it has decided to extend visa waivers, effective from Oct. 1, to citizens of Poland and Slovakia for a maximum stay of 30 days.

Anne Hung, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, made the announcement at a regular press briefing, adding that holders of passports from Hungary will also be eligible for visa-free entry starting Nov. 1.

Noting that the gross domestic product per capita of Poland, Slovakia and Hungary is US$11,000 US$14,000 and US$20,000, respectively, Hung said that the decision was made with the aim of boosting Taiwan's economy and tourism.
Also, the ministry hopes that the EU will eventually make a reciprocal offer to Taiwan to facilitate travel to Europe by Taiwan citizens, she added.

We would like to show our goodwill first by allowing passport holders from the European Union to travel to our country without visas, " Hung said. "Meanwhile, it is our goal to have our citizens enjoy similar visa exemption when they travel to Europe, and we are working very hard to achieve this."
She said that starting in November, 20 of the EU's 27 member countries will be included in the visa waiver program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign investors urged to use Taiwan as springboard to East Asia

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industry clusters, ideal location and expanding opportunities from the normalization of cross-strait trade relations provide a clear edge for foreign investors looking to strengthen their presence in East Asia, Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said recently.

Urging multinational enterprises to invest in Taiwan, Yiin said, they can capitalize on industry clusters, local talent and the internationalization experience of local businesses to sharpen their competitive edge.
"They could use Taiwan as a stepping stone to make inroads into East Asia, " he said. "After all, East Asia has seen the fastest economic growth in the world."

Yiin made his push for foreign investment less than two weeks before the opening of the three-day Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, which will highlight Taiwan's investment opportunities for visiting world business leaders.
The event will take place at the Taipei International Convention Center from Oct. 6-7. Customized fact-finding trips will be arranged exclusively for potential investors on October 8.

Yiin noted that the conference has received an enthusiastic response so far, with in excess of 1,000 businesspeople from more than 30 countries (including more than 300 overseas Chinese and Taiwanese) registering for the event, according to Department of Investment Services (DOIS) figures.
Among them, around 300 entrepreneurs are from China, showing that Chinese businesses are interested in cooperation with Taiwanese businesses, Yiin said.
When asked about Taiwan's main competitive advantage at a time when the global economy is sluggish, Yiin first cited "our excellent industry clusters."
"Taiwan is the supply chain center of the high-tech industry, " Yiin said. "A lot of IC and IT products and their key parts and components are produced and manufactured in Taiwan."

The strength of that supply chain is one of the main reasons why U.S.-based Business Week featured "Why Taiwan Matters" as its May 16, 2005 cover story. The article asserted that the global economy "couldn't function" without the island.

Given their ambition to compete on the global stage, many businesses in Taiwan also have experience in internationalizing their operations, which has spawned a pool of talent well versed in internationalization and considerable experience in logistics management, Yiin said.

He also touted Taiwan's superb geographical location. "From Taiwan to the major cities in Asia -- be it Tokyo, Seoul, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Singapore, or Sydney -- the distance is the shortest and only a few hours are needed.
"With surging oil prices, the control of transportation costs is especially important, " Yiin said. "Whoever has the best location will get the most opportunities."
The government's policy to ease restrictions on commerce with China also means that cross-strait trade is set to move along a more open and normalized course.

One example cited by Yiin is the government's move to raise the cap on local enterprises' investment in China to up to 60 percent of their net worth, from the previous 40 percent. And those companies headquartered in Taiwan will be exempt from such a restriction.

The easing of restrictions will make it easier for companies to use Taiwan as a springboard to China, Yiin said, and he urged foreign investors to cooperate with Taiwanese enterprises to better harness the opportunities of the Greater China market.

Yiin noted that "we are historically and culturally linked with China and speak the same language. We have more than 100,000 enterprises with investments in China, and they have good connections with those in power there."

The economics minister said the government is still discussing future tax reform initiatives, but stressed that the Statute to Upgrade Industry, under which high-tech companies investing in Taiwan can get five-year tax holidays and various investment incentives, remains valid until the end of 2009.
"Enterprises that invest by the end of next year will still be covered by the statute and able to enjoy the incentives, " he added.
Yiin said that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs to make attracting foreign investment its highest priority.
This year's business alliance conference, he said, hopes to attract more newcomers and not just foreign enterprises that have already invested in Taiwan.

During the conference, President Ma Ying-jeou will present awards to nine foreign businesses that have made big contributions to Taiwan, and the ministry will also sign letters of investment intent with around 14 foreign businesses, Yiin said. More information about the upcoming conference is available at http://www.taiwanalliance.com.tw/2008TBAC/

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 58 points to close at 5,618, with 80,906 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 58 points to finish at 5,598, with 446 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 50 points to close at 5,592, with 39 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 90 points to finish at 5,548, with 14 contract transactions, while June futures were down 69 points to close at 5,545, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,676 for October, 5,656 for November, 5,642 for December, 5,638 for March and 5,614 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 60.29 points to finish at 5,703.72, on turnover of NT$66.46 billion (US$2.07 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

October TE futures fell 4.45 points to close at 229.3, with 4,848 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 4.05 points to finish at 228.45, with 32 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 4.05 points to end at 229.45, with four contracts traded, while March TE futures declined five points to end at 227, with one contract transaction. June TE futures dropped three points to close at 227, with one contract traded.

October TF futures moved up six points to close at 671.8, with 4,894 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures were up 7.6 points to finish at 670.6, with 19 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working to lift study restrictions on expatriate students

TEXT.P: The government is working to lift a restriction that discourages expatriate students from continuing their study in Taiwan, as part of its effort to attract more overseas talent, Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission Minister Wu Ying- yih said Thursday.

Wu made the remark while delivering a report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee. He was referring to a rule that requires overseas compatriots who completed their undergraduate studies in Taiwan to remain abroad for at least two years in order to qualify for further study in Taiwan under the designation of "overseas compatriot students."

Every year, Taiwan universities allocate a certain number of places for "overseas compatriot students" -- a category that is defined as Taiwanese who have lived abroad for at least six years or foreign-born nationals of Chinese ancestry.

However, if students in this group wish to continue on to graduate school after they have earned their bachelor's degrees in Taiwan, they are required to leave the country for at least two years before they can apply for admission under the category of "overseas compatriot students."

If these students intend to remain in the country after undergraduate study, they are allowed to take the entrance exams, as other local students are required to do. However, it has been observed that they tend to be at a disadvantage because their Chinese-language ability is usually not on par with that of other local students.

According to Wu, the regulation discourages outstanding expatriate students from remaining in Taiwan to further their studies and to work. The OCAC is currently coordinating with the Ministry of Education to revise the related regulations to remove this hurdle, he added.

With the international movement of talent becoming a global trend, countries such as New Zealand and Singapore have been offering various incentives in order to recruit outstanding foreign students and to encourage them to work in those countries after graduation, Wu noted.

To encourage more expatriate students to study in Taiwan, the OCAC is planning to enact an expatriate education law to apply the same regulations to "overseas compatriot students" as to foreign students, he said.
Wu pointed out that although most "overseas compatriot students" studying in Taiwan are foreign nationals, the regulations are less favorable to them than to non-ethnic Chinese foreign students.
For example, he said, the scholarship programs for foreign students are better than those for "overseas compatriot students."

OCAC statistics show that a total of 2,009 "overseas compatriot students" have applied to study in Taiwan universities in the 2008-2009 academic year, an increase of 24 percent over the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA thanks allies for speaking up for Taiwan at United Nations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed gratitude to Taiwan's diplomatic allies that spoke in support of the country's bid to join the United Nations at the U.N. General Assembly last month, according to a press statement released by the MOFA Wednesday.

The statement noted that 18 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies in Asia-Pacific, Latin America and Africa voiced support for Taiwan's efforts to seek "meaningful participation" in U.N. specialized agencies, in the General Assembly's annual session which took place in New York from Sept. 23-29.
The United States, the European Union, and Japan also backed Taiwan's U.N. bid this year, the statement said.
In addition, representatives of Singapore and New Zealand said that they were pleased to see improvements in Taiwan-China relations and they encouraged the two sides to continue their dialogue.
According to the MOFA, this level of support shows that Taiwan's bid for meaningful participation in U.N. specialized agencies has gained approval in the international community.
The Taiwan government will continue to strive for greater international participation in the future, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 60.29 points, or 1.04 percent, to close at 5,703.72.
The bourse opened at 5,764.48 and fluctuated between 5,840.09 and 5,672.39. A total of 3.02 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$66.46 billion (US$2.07 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.3 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1 percent, cement stocks rose 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares increased 0.4 percent, and textile stocks grew 0.3 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares declining 1.8 percent and foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both dropping 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 912 to 672, with 401 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$7.29 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traces of malamine found in brand name milk powder from China

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday that six kinds of Nestle milk powder manufactured in China were found to contain the toxic chemical melamine, and said it will request a recall of all 20 Nestle milk products on the market, even though the level of melamine found was too small to pose a health threat.

"The quantity of the chemical was very small, so the products are still safe and will not have any effects on health, but to protect consumers' rights and safety, we have asked the company to pull all its milk powder products from store shelves, " said DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan at a press conference.
@He said that most of the questionable Nestle products can be removed from store shelves within 24 hours.

A random test conducted by local health bureaus found 0.06 ppm (parts per million) to 0.85 ppm of melamine in the milk powder made between February 2007 and June 2008 by the Shuangcheng Nestle company located in Helongjiang province in northern China, Yeh said.
Nestle, which also produces Klim milk power, is one of Taiwan's leading brands of infant and adult milk products.
Yeh said that the milk powder had tested negative for melamine before the DOH decided to employ the most sensitive test -- liquid chromatography/tandem mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS).
@LC/MS/MS is a high-sensitivity analytical technique used to detect and identify specific chemicals, and can detect melamine levels as low as 0.05 ppm.@@

The DOH announced Wednesday that all imported and locally made dairy products and food containing vegetable-based proteins should be tested using LC/MS/MS, and only those that test negative for melamine will be allowed on the market.@@

Nestle milk products were previously classified as safe, as they were tested by means of a less sensitive technique than LC/MS/MS, said Yeh, reiterating that the products will however not cause any damage to people's health.@@

Yeh also said that the DOH will invite experts from Japan, the United States and the European Union to Taiwan to exchange views on the food safety issue before next Sunday, in the hope that local regulations can be brought in line with international standards.@
The whole (made-in-China milk contamination) issue has highlighted the urgent need for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the Word Health Organization," Yeh stressed.

@The Nestle products were allowed on the market in late September, along with the products of other 17 importers from China, after they were tested for melamine. Yeh did not rule out the possibility that the other 17 companies may face a similar problem.
@The DOH had earlier altered the standard for acceptable levels of melamine content in food to 2.5 ppm.

@But the revision caused panic among consumers, who agitated for a "zero content" standard, and led to the resignation of then-DOH Minister Lin Fang-yue last week.@With Taiwan's safety standard for melamine content reset at "undetectable, " products that contain from 0.05 to 2.4 ppm of the industrial chemical may not be allowed on store shelves.

Melamine can cause kidney stones and kidney failure if consumed in sufficient quantity. Baby formula containing the toxic chemical has caused at least four deaths and sickened more than 54,000 in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.131 to close at NT$32.160.
A total of US$1.02 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.029 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.160.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. a model for Taiwan in sustainable construction: PCC

TEXT.P: Taiwan can learn a lot from the United Kingdom in the areas of sustainable architecture and sustainable public construction and hopes to attract the participation of other countries, including the U.K., in its "i-Taiwan 12 projects," Chern Jenn-chuan, vice chairperson of the Executive Yuan's Public Construction Commission (PCC), said Thursday in Taipei.

"Given the fact that the U.K. is well-known in the world for its expertise in sustainable public construction and architecture, it can serve as a model for Taiwan, " Chern said in an international seminar on "U.K. Waterfront Regeneration and Sustainable Construction" held by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) and the PCC.

Chaired by Nigel Peters, the director of British Expertise, the seminar attracted representatives from noted British engineering and development companies such as Arup, Benoy, Fulcrum Consulting, Terry Farrells Group, Paul Davies and Partners, and Mott McDonald.
Chern said attracting the participation of foreign companies in public construction projects, such as the i-Taiwan 12 projects, is one of the major tasks of the government.

"By attracting domestic, foreign and private investment, the government hopes to increase domestic demand in the face of the global economic downturn, " he said, adding that he hopes the companies participating the seminar would try to solicit more interest in the i-Taiwan projects in the U.K. when they return.

Describing the vision and the funding needed for the i-Taiwan projects as "truly ambitious," BTCO Director Michael Reilly said that "development of this scale will require a joint effort from both the public and private sectors. International investors are able to contribute -- we hope they will do so.

Reilly said that Taiwan faces exactly the same opportunities and challenges as the U.K. Despite wanting to make their cities more attractive places to live, neither Taiwan nor the U.K. has the luxury of vast open spaces in which to start from the beginning, he added.
He said developments do not need to be big to work and the U.K. has had some great successes in small-scale regeneration and it is ready to share its experiences with Taiwan -- good and not so good.

The i-Taiwan national construction projects, one of Mas major economic platforms, proposes putting US$120 billion over the next eight years into stimulating the domestic economy and lowering the unemployment rate by creating 120,000 job opportunities each year.

The i-Taiwan 12 projects include an island-wide transportation network, a free trade zone and eco-port in Kaohsiung, a sea and air logistics hub in Taichung, an international air city in Yaoyuan, urban and industrial zone renewal and coastal regeneration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity collects NT$6.18 million to assist the disabled

TEXT.P: A recent cycling event launched by a local charity to raise money to buy walking aids, wheelchairs and buses to give the disabled greater mobility has brought in NT$6.18 million (US$192,667.41).

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin; Chu Chu-hsien, wife of Vice President Vincent Siew; Deputy Minister of the Interior Lai Feng-wei; and Pan Ling-chiao, chief executive officer of the Nan Shan Life Charity Foundation greeted the 50 cyclists as they arrived in Taipei on the final leg of their Taiwan tour Wednesday.
The 12-day, 1,100-km, round-the-island tour was organized by the Eden Social Welfare Foundation.
Most of the cyclists are staffers of the Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. -- a local subsidiary of the American International Group Inc. (AIG), an insurance and financial services enterprise.
Nan Shan Life Insurance donated NT$3.5 million at an event hosted in the square in front of Taipei City Hall Sept. 20 to mark the start of the cycling tour.
During their tour, the cyclists were warmly greeted by local government heads, businesses and individual residents, who also donated money in support of the cause.

The Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Nan Shan Life Charity Foundation, which is affiliated with Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., urged the public to donate more money to help the charity realize its target of collecting NT$10 million by the end of this year.

The funds will be used to buy walking sticks for the visually impaired, wheelchairs for the physically challenged and buses to transport the disabled to hospital, according to Wang Kai-chiang, chairman of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Owners of noise affected residences entitled to subsidy: bill

TEXT.P: A draft amendment to the Noise Control Act was passed preliminarily by a legislative committee Thursday, stipulating that residences that are constantly exposed to noises from nearby public transportation systems are entitled to special governmental subsidies.

Owners of residences and buildings located in close proximity to expressways, freeways, railways, mass rapid transit systems, airports and control towers can apply for government subsidies to install noise-deterrent equipment in their buildings, according to the amendment.

Meanwhile, the proposed amendment also stipulates that vehicles, including cars and motorbikes, may be subject to noise-control examination if they are caught on videotape or reported as making intolerable noises while on the road.

Under the draft bill, factories will be given 90 days to reduce their noise levels after they are reported. Recreation and business locations will be given 30 days, construction sites four days, public address systems 10 minutes to lower their noise levels if they are re ported, according to the bill, which will take effect after clearing the legislative floor.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. scholar to speak in Taiwan on U.S. presidential election

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Thursday that it has invited a political science professor to visit Taiwan next week to give lectures on the 2008 U.S. presidential election.

David Plotke, a professor of political science at the New School, a university in New York City, will visit Taiwan from Oct. 6-9, the AIT said in a press release, adding that he will give lectures and foster discussion in Taiwan on topics related to the 2008 U.S. presidential election.
Dr. Plotke will speak at various universities in Taipei and Kaohsiung, giving talks to students as well as briefings for elite Taiwan scholars," the AIT said.

He will cover themes such as democracy and the U.S. electoral process, voters and public opinion, the U.S. presidential candidates and U.S. foreign policy in the 2008 election and beyond, the AIT added.

Plotke's areas of research include U.S. politics, American political development, national political institutions, political and social movements, American political thought, political theory and sources of democratic continuity, democratic politics and anti-democratic politics.
The AIT said the lectures will be free of charge and open to the public. People interested in attending these events can contact the American Cultural Center at (02)2723-2959 ext. 230.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22 couples get married in Taiwan's famous Alishan mountain resort

TEXT.P: Twenty-two couples got married Thursday at the Alishan Forest Railway station, witnessed by local tourism officials and surrounding high mountains and a sea of clouds.
Men and women made a toast to each other and exchanged a colorful hand-made lucky bracelet in the ceremony, accompanied by a choral of local indigenous school children.
Also present was the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration chief Chung Fu- sung and Chiayi County Tourism Bureau chief Chung Ming-shih.

The Alishan National Scenic Area Administration, the Chiayi county government and the Chiayi Forest District Office jointly organized the special activity, partly to promote tourism in the popular alpine resort area in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County.
To help the newly weds have an unforgettable wedding, a photo session and a two- day tour on the famous Alishan alpine train were also arranged for the couples.
According to Chung Fu-sung, 61 couples have tied the knot in Alishan since the beginning of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan martial artists win six medals in Busan wushu tournament

TEXT.P: Six members of a 50-strong team of martial artists and athletes from Taiwan won two gold, two silver and two bronze medals in the World Wushu Tournament held as part of the fourth World Sport for All Games in Busan, South Korea, which ran from Sept. 26 through Sept. 29.

The athletic meet was sponsored by the Trim and Fitness International Sport for All Association (TAFISA), based in Frankfurt, Germany. In Asia and Oceania, TAFISA is represented by the Asiania Sport for All Association (ASFAA), which has nearly 30 members.

In addition to Taiwan, described officially as Chinese Taipei in the games, competitors also came from China, Macau, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Malaysia, Japan, Indonesia, Myanmar, South Korea, the Philippines, Russia, the United States, Canada, Italy, Iran, Singapore, Ukraine, Netherlands, Cuba, Spain and Israel.

The athletes competed in two categories -- taolu (forms) and sanshou (free sparring). The taolu events consisted of empty-hand forms in the Changquan (long-style boxing), nanquan (southern boxing), and taiji boxing styles, as well as weapon forms in jianshu (swordplay), daoshu (broadsword), nandao (southern broadsword), gunshu (cudgel), qiangshu (spear) and nangun (southern cudgel).
Taiwanese martial artist Chen Ruen-chih captured a gold medal in the men's taiji boxing event, while Li Hung-ying won a gold medal in the speed event in the women's sport climbing competition.
Fan Man-yun received a silver medal in the women's taiji boxing event, and Hsiao Yung-sheng took silver in men's gunshu.
Huang Hsiao-chien earned a bronze in the women's nanquan event, while Lin Wei- liang also received a bronze in the men's changquan event.

During the meet, the ASFAA held its 10th congress and elected a new executive board. Tsai Chen-wei, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, became one of the board members, while China's Feng Jianzhong, vice minister of the General Administration of Sport, was re-elected ASFAA president.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city to rigorously screen factory emissions

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government vowed Thursday to strengthen its screening of factory emissions, amid concerns that a partially state-owned steel company based in the port city may be releasing high volumes of carbon dioxide into the air.

Kaohsiung City Councilor Wu ming-tzu said in a question-and-answer session in the city council that China Steel Corp. emits 21.78 million metric tons of carbon dioxide a year, accounting for 55 percent of air pollutants in the city.
China Steel also emits the toxic chemical dioxin, which he said is a threat to public health.
"China Steel, as one of the leading state-owned enterprises, has not fulfilled its social responsibilities," Wu said.

He said that China Steel records a yearly surplus of NT$60 billion (US$1.875 billion), but only paid NT$385 million in taxes to Kaohsiung. The central government allocated an additional grant of NT$1.51 billion from a tax redistribution fund to Kaohsiung City, and China Steel donated another NT$35 million to the city as a feedback, he added.
"All these figures show that most of the huge profits of the company end up in pockets of its staff and shareholders," Wu said.

He asked the city's Environmental Protection Bureau Director Xiao Yu-zheng to purchase equipment that will be able to detect the level of air pollutants and thus monitor state-owned enterprises such as China Steel and Taiwan Fertilizer. In fact, both companies have been privatized, with government stakes falling below 50 percent.
"Once violations are found, the city government should impose fines on the companies concerned," Wu suggested.
For his part, Xiao said the volume of carbon dioxide emissions in the city is 39.68 million metric tons annually, accounting for around 11 percent of the nation's emissions.
Suspended particles and volatile organic compounds are also released by China Steel, causing deterioration of the air quality in the city's Chiencheng and Xiaokang districts, he added.
Xiao promised to step up its screening of the production process of plants and other facilities to mitigate the pollution effects.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21 injured by turbulence on CAL flight
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/08 20:11:08 (By Lin Ching-ping and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Twenty-one people, including crew members, were injured Thursday by turbulence when a Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) flight was preparing to land at the Bangkok International Airport Thursday from Hong Kong.
Of the 21 injured, four were crew members of CAL flight CI641, two of whom sustained severe but not life-threatening injuries, according to a spokesman for CAL's branch office in Thailand.
None of the 17 passengers were from Taiwan, the spokesman went on, adding that they were from China, Thailand, Hong Kong and various other countries.
The injured were rushed to a nearby hospital for emergency treatment or examination immediately after the aircraft landed.
The crew and some passengers were injured because they had failed to fasten their seat belts while the aircraft was descending and encountered daylight turbulence, the spokesman said.
According to the CAL head office in Taipei at a news conference held later in the day, two Chinese nationals sustained severe injuries because of the turbulence.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC invites expatriates to return for National Day

TEXT.P: Taiwan expatriates are welcome to return home for National Day celebrations, regardless of their political affiliation, Overseas Compatriots Affairs Commission (OCAC) Minister Wu Ying-yih said Thursday.

"The government is inviting all Taiwanese expatriates to participate in the Oct. 10 National Day activities at home, and each of them would be given a subsidy of NT$3,200 (about US$100) as long as he or she joins an OCAC-designated domestic travel tour during the festive period," Wu said.

Wu made the remarks in a legislative question-and-answer session while fielding questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers who claimed that the OCAC, with an additional budget of NT$15 million to serve that end, has invited only pro-Kuomintang (KMT) overseas nationals to return home for National Day activities.

"I would welcome with open arms the return of members of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) to join the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations and would treat them to something special if they are willing to do so," he said.
The FAPA is a pro-Taiwan independence group headquartered in the United States.

Wu estimated that some 10,000 ROC nationals -- double the previous average -- would return to Taiwan for National Day celebrations this year. As in the past, the OCAC will offer them a subsidy if they take any of the OCAC-organized domestic trips during the holiday period, he said.

To encourage more overseas compatriots to travel around Taiwan during their vacation, the OCAC has added visits to local small- and medium-sized companies and health checks at hospitals as new options, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 65% of workers planning to earn master's degree: survey

TEXT.P: More than 65 percent of workers with a bachelor's degree are planning to earn a master's degree to try to advance their career, although a higher academic qualification is not necessarily helpful, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by an online employment broker.

Conducted by 104 Job Bank in cooperation with Global Views Monthly, the survey found that the most common reasons mentioned by the respondents for pursuing a master's degree are: holding the degree will increase their chances for promotion, enhance their professional abilities, and help them get higher pay.
The survey also found that 18.5 percent of the respondents said they are concerned that "holding a bachelor's degree may not guarantee them a good job."
However, the experience of respondents with a master's or doctorate degree show that obtaining an additional diploma does not automatically lead to better employment opportunities.

Slightly more than 41 percent of master's or doctorate degree holders complained that having high academic qualifications has not helped their employment quest, and sometimes has even made it more difficult for them to find a job.

By contrast, 58.8 percent of master's or doctorate degree holders said their academic qualifications have made their job search easier, and 66.3 percent said the qualifications have helped them get higher starting salaries or higher positions.

Also, 38.4 percent of the respondents said the qualifications have increased their chances of being assigned important projects, and 37.8 percent said the qualifications have raised their chances of entering large companies or foreign companies.

The survey found that the most popular fields among the respondents intending to enter a master's program are business and management; engineering; language and humanities; political science, economics, sociology and psychology; and mathematics and computer science.

However, the sectors that businesses think have the highest demand for workers with master's degree holders are those related to business and management, engineering, medical and health care, industrial technology, mathematics, and computer science.

For the year to come, the positions where a master's degree is preferred include engineering research and development personnel, software engineering personnel, finance and insurance agents, server operators, and product or project managers, according to the results.
The survey was conducted Aug. 18-25 among 1,014 businesses and 1,892 workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP mulling street protest over melamine scandal

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday publicly expressed its discontent over the government's handling of the melamine tainted food scandal, and would not rule out the possibility of staging a street protest to demonstrate its dissatisfaction.

In a statement issued Wednesday by the DPP Central Standing Committee and the DPP-governed city and county governments, the party said it will ask supermarkets nationwide to set up special zones for Taiwan-made products to help consumers determine what is safe to buy.

It also said it plans to collaborate with civic groups to label their products "China-Free" in light of a recent food safety scare following the discoveries of melamine-contaminated food imports from China.
The statement was released on the sidelines of the party's Central Standing Committee meeting held in the southernmost county of Pingtung.

To show their support for local industries, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and party members drank domestically produced fresh milk and ate bread during the meeting, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang told reporters after the meeting.

Cheng said the DPP will also help local companies, whose sales were affected by the food scare, put their products through inspections for melamine, the chemical used to make plastics and fertilizer which has been used as a fake protein additive in dairy products originating from China.

Tsai agreed at the meeting to consider DPP Legislator William Lai's suggestion that the party should take to the streets to protest against the government's handling of the tainted milk powder incident regardless of whether Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will visit Taiwan in October, according to Cheng.

The tainted milk scandal has undermined public confidence in the government since government officials flip-flopped on local standards on the maximum amount of melamine allowable in food and failed to guarantee food safety. As a result of the tainted milk incident, Lin Fang-yu has been forced to resign from his position as Department of Health minister.

In its statement, the DPP also blasted the Kuomintang administration for its recent decision to adopt the Hanyu Pinyin system, a Chinese Romanization system developed and adopted by the People's Republic of China in 1979, noting that promoting the use of the system in Taiwan, which uses mostly the Tongyong Pinyin system, would cost the country more than NT$4 billion, or even NT$7 billion, and would create confusion expected to last for five to six years.
The statement said the adoption of Hanyu Pinyin was based on the consideration of ideological issues and the government's attempt to tilt towards China by using the China-developed system.

The administration, however, has said it adopted the system because this would enable Taiwan to enhance the country's international competitiveness and to become better connected with the rest of the world, which uses the Hanyu Pinyin system.

Meanwhile, Tsai said after DPP meeting Wednesday that the party is scheduled to finalize the nominations of its local election candidates for city and county chiefs by the end of this year and the nominations of candidates for township chiefs, city mayors, and city and county councilors by the end of next February.

Touching on former President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at a rally Wednesday in Sanchung City, Taipei County, organized by DPP lawmaker Yu Tian, Tsai said that it's up to individual party members to decide whether to attend such gatherings. She denied the party has tried to distance itself from Chen.

Chen is under investigations for alleged embezzlement of public funds by using other people's receipts to gain reimbursement from his "state affairs fund" and for suspected money laundering by his family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese poachers nabbed off Kinmen

TEXT.P: Kinmen-based coast guard patrol ships launched a crackdown on intruding Chinese fishing boats in waters off Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen Thursday, nabbing four Chinese vessels and 16 people.

During the crackdown -- part of the "Ching Hai" campaign aimed at preventing poaching by Chinese fishing boats in Taiwan's territorial waters and better protecting Taiwan's fishery resources -- 15 other Chinese fishing boats were also chased out of Kinmen waters, the Kinmen operations of the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration said.

In collaboration with the Kinmen county government and the Kinmen Fishermen's Association, the Kinmen coast guard also confiscated some 100 items of fishing gear, including around 3,000 meters of fishing nets, the coast guard said.

The "Ching Hai" campaign is also designed to clear up maritime traffic routes between Kinmen and the Chinese province of Fujian to facilitate the implementation of expanded shipping links between the two sides of the strait, according to the coast guard.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from typhoon Jangmi rise to NT$2.14 billion

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses due to Typhoon Jangmi had risen to NT$2.14 billion (US$66.5 million) as of Thursday, according to statistics released that day by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
Typhoon Jangmi lashed Taiwan last weekend, causing serious damage to the agricultural sector in six conties in central and southern Taiwan.
The affected areas are eligible to receive cash subsidies from the central government to help them get back on their feet.
The statistics show that 22 percent of the crops on a total of 57,187 hectares of farmland were lost.
The crops that suffered the heaviest damage included rice, grapes, persimmons, bananas, oranges, pears, maize, peanuts, papayas, guavas, shallots and bell fruit.

This year's rice production suffered an estimated reduction of 5,000 tons to 10,000 tons due to the typhoon, but those losses will not have an impact on next year's rice price, as the country as a whole has annual production of 1.3 million tons, COA Deputy Minister Huang You-tsai said Thursday.
But he added that the COA will release stored rice if necessary to ensure sufficient supplies to maintain stable prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi hoping for good weather for National Day fireworks show

TEXT.P: The Chiayi city government in southern Taiwan is looking forward to a large influx of visitors to the city for the Oct. 10 National Day official fireworks display sponsored by the central government, but is worried that the capricious weather might not cooperate.
Anxious to see all Double Ten festivities proceed as planned, Chiayi Deputy Mayor Lee Shi-jin led the city government's department heads Thursday to pray for good weather Oct. 10.
They visited four temples in the city -- the Yuhuang Temple, the Chenghuang Temple, the Dizang Temple and the Yuan Fu Temple -- to pay homage by burning joss sticks and praying for fine weather.

Lee told reporters that the fireworks display -- the first official National Day fireworks show to be staged in Chiayi by the central government -- is an extremely important event and that the city cannot afford to see it spoiled by bad weather.

Noting that Oct. 10 is a Friday, Lee estimated that up to 200,000 visitors, including tourists and Taiwanese expatriates from abroad, will flood into Chiayi over the long weekend to attend a series of National Day celebrations, visit spots of interest, and see what life is like in the city.
The city government has selected a farm belonging to the Chiayi Agricultural Station, which is adjacent to Chiayi Park, as the site for the fireworks display.
A giant red balloon with a diameter of five meters has been tethered 100 meters above the farm as a reference point so that visitors can see where the fireworks display will be staged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County police to be briefed on new designer drugs

TEXT.P: In a bid to help police detect new types of illicit drugs, Taipei county policemen have been ordered to gain a better knowledge of them through drug mules detained by law enforcement agents, a spokesman said Thursday.

The prime purpose of the measure is to clamp down on new illicit drugs so as to improve social order, as drugs are closely linked to the growing number of burglaries, robberies and violent crimes in the county, the spokesman said.

Several new illegal drugs such as DOB, BZP and TFMP have been increasingly seized in raids by law enforcement agents on night clubs in Taipei County, northern Taiwan and from passengers entering the country from New Zealand and Australia.

The three drugs, usually presented in colorful coating like candies, are often sold to drug users as the popular club drug ecstasy (the common name for the amphetamine MDMA) or promoted as an ecstasy alternative.
BZP is a synthetic stimulant, TFMP is a hallucinogen and DOB, or Brolamfetamine, is a psychedelic hallucinogen.
"Without the latest relevant knowledge, it is very difficult for police to detect these drugs," the spokesman said.
"Therefore, Taipei county police authorities have told policemen to familiarize themselves with the three new drugs with the assistance of people who know them better," he explained.

BZP and TFMP are listed as first-grade medical drugs in the United States, while DOB is banned. But in Taiwan, the use of BZP and TFMP is unrestricted, while DOB is listed as a second-grade medical drug, possession or sale of which is illegal.
A cocktail of the three drugs, even in low doses, can cause stroke or psychosis, according to drug experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Precursors of summer rainstorms found by meteorologists

TEXT.P: An international meteorological survey has spotted some precursory phenomena of summer rainstorms and by detecting these atmospheric events, a precious lead time of two to three hours can be gained to issue warnings to the public before damaging rainstorms begin, academic sources said Thursday.

However, the meteorologists noted, to identify these precursors requires powerful weather radar that Taiwan lacks at present. Installing a new nationwide rain radar system would take at least two years, while upgrading the four existing weather radar systems would cost some NT$400 million (US$12 million).

During Taiwan's southwest summer monsoon season, rainstorms packed with heavy moisture occur sporadically; these storms bring torrential rainfall that cause landslides and mudslides, as well as inducing lightning that interferes with communication networks and sometimes damages sophisticated equipment.

A project titled "SoWMEX" -- Southwest Monsoon Experiment -- was carried out in southern Taiwan May 15-June 25, as precipitation is usually the heaviest during this period. Sponsored by the Cabinet-level National Science Council, the survey also received assistance from the United States, Canada, the Philippines, Japan and South Korea.

In a press conference to report the survey's initial results, Ben Jong-dao Jou -- the project leader and a meteorology professor at National Taiwan University -- said eddy currents accompanying the southwest monsoons are the main culprits behind the rainstorms.
Enhanced by eddy currents, the monsoons carrying heavy moisture can easily induce mesoscale convective systems, which cause rainstorms to form, said Jou.

"By detecting the existence of eddy currents and the formation of a mesoscale convective system, the weather forecasting agencies can predict the coming of a rainstorm two to three hours before it hits," Jou noted.

However, he went on, the team can precisely spot these weather developments only because some sophisticated, powerful radar has been deployed, including the SPOL radar of the U.S. National Center for Atmospheric Research. SPOL is an S-band polarimetric Doppler radar system and the U.S. is only country in the world that has such complex equipment in this field.

To better predict rainstorms and other atmospheric events, Jou said, the Central Weather Bureau is hoping to upgrade the country's weather radar systems and if the project can begin next year, the overhauled systems can go online three to four years from now.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes for continued development of Taipei-Seoul ties

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed hope Thursday that relations between Taiwan and South Korea will continue to be cordial based on the existing solid friendship.
The president made the remarks when he received outgoing Oh Sang-sik, representative of the Korean Mission in Taipei, at the Presidential Office.

Ma cited trade figures to show the close relations between the two nations, saying that bilateral trade amounted to US$23 billion last year, with South Korea enjoying a trade surplus of more than US$7 billion.
The two countries are each other's fifth-largest trading partners, Ma added.

He noted that since Taiwan and South Korea resumed air links in 2004 after a hiatus of more than a decade, exchanges between the two countries have become even more close, with both countries offering visa-free privileges to each other's citizens.
Taiwan severed diplomatic ties with South Korea in 1992 after the latter switched recognition to Beijing from Taipei.
People from each side paid a total of 680,000 visits to the other country last year, Ma went on.
He also noted that during Wu's tenure, trade talks between Taipei and Seoul resumed after a disruption of more than a decade.

The president said that since his May 20 inauguration, he has dedicated himself to the improvement of cross-Taiwan Strait ties and that the thaw in cross-strait ties has also helped maintain regional peace and stability.
Ma noted that more than 90 South Korean colleges and universities have cooperative relations with Taiwanese universities.
Oh, for his part, said he has enjoyed his stay in Taiwan and has made many good friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: No plan to put off new cross-strait talks: MAC official

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are very likely to hold a new round of negotiations in late October or early November as originally slated, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday.

"Officials from the two quasi-official intermediary bodies still working to set a date for a second meeting in Taiwan between the top negotiators of the two sides, " Liu said, adding, however, that "the date will be not be fixed until as late as the middle of this month."

"There are absolutely no plans to delay the date or shorten the process of the slated meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS)," Liu said.
There has been press speculation that a preparatory meeting between SEF and ARATS officials is expected to be held next week, but Liu did not address the topic.

Commenting on objections concerning Chen visiting Taiwan following the scandal of Chinese adulteration of foodstuffs with the toxic chemical melamine, Liu made it clear that both sides had already agreed to hold systematic negotiations in both Beijing and Taipei.
Chen's planned visit to Taiwan has come at a sensitive time after toxic milk products imported from China were detected in Taiwan in recent weeks, sparking panic among the public.
Some have protested Chen's visit, have demanded that China apologize and that Chinese companies compensate Taiwanese consumers over the melamine-tainted milk products.
Chiang and Chen clinched two milestone accords to step up two-way tourism and transportation services in an ice-breaking meeting in June in Beijing.

Taiwan and China are projected to discuss the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes, joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and crime- fighting in their next round of negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi health officials step up food safety inspections

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Chiayi city government began a large-scale food safety inspection Thursday to ensure that no milk products, non-dairy creamer or vegetable-based protein products from China are being used by food processors in the southern city.

The officials from the Public Health Bureau took the action with the aim of protecting the reputation of 10 delicacies designated by the city government as typical gift items that visitors to Chiayi over the Double Ten National Day holiday will buy to take home, according to a spokesman for the bureau.

Chiayi has been given the right to host this year's National Day fireworks show sponsored by the central government. The city government will also hold a series of other festivities to celebrate National Day, and hopes to attract some 200,000 visitors to the city.

To allay visitors' fears that the city's renowned delicacies might contain melamine-contaminated products from China, the officials stepped up their inspections at food manufacturers in the city to make sure that none of the materials they use have come from China.
"Visitors can feel assured that the 10 recommended gift items they might buy in Chiayi are absolutely safe," the spokesman said.
He said that whenever in doubt about food safety, consumers can phone the bureau on the special service line (03)233-8267.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA respects wishes of directors of state-owned enterprises to quit

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Thursday that he will respect the wishes of board directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises under the jurisdiction of the ministry who decide to resign from their posts rather than make public their assets.
Yiin said that "privacy is involved" and that the ministry will respect their wishes.

He made the remarks amid reports that up to 115 of the 556 board directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises or government-funded, non-profit institutes have tendered their resignations after the enforcement of the amended Act on Property-declaration by Public Servants was put into practice Oct. 1.
Under the new rules, the directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises and government-subsidized institutional organizations, along with their spouses, are required to declare their assets.

Those who are unwilling to declare their assets span the industrial and academic sectors, reports said, citing the examples of BenQ Corp. Chairman Lee Kun-yao, who is a board member of the Industrial Technology Research Institute and former National Science Council Chairman Wei Che-ho, who is a board member of the Institute for Information Industry.
Yiin said that the directors and supervisors who have offered to resign account for more than 20 percent of the total, but added that board meetings "are generally operating normally."
"The ministry will fill the vacancies at the earliest possible time," he added.
He noted that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has said that personnel related to state- owned enterprises and government-funded, non-profit institutes must be competent and must have integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some passengers injured on CAL flight released from hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/02/08 23:39:59 (By Lin Ching-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Some of the passengers injured by turbulence aboard a Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) flight Thursday have already been discharged from a hospital after receiving treatment, a spokesman for the CAL's Bangkok office said later that day.
A total of 21 people -- 16 passengers and five crew members -- were injured by turbulence when the flight from Hong Kong was preparing to land at Bangkok International Airport, the spokesman said.
Two of the injured sustained severe but not life-threatening injuries, the spokesman said.
All of the five injured crew members were Taiwan nationals, but none of the injured passengers were Taiwanese, the spokesman added.

According to a name list released by CAL's Taipei headquarters, nine of the injured were Chinese citizens and four were from Thailand. The remaining three were one each from Hong Kong, the United States and Israel.
Most of those hurt suffered cuts and bruises, and two had spine injuries, hospital sources said.
The CAL spokesman said some passengers were injured because they had failed to fasten their seat belts while the aircraft was descending and hit by turbulence.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd suspect in ex-president's alleged money laundering case detained

TEXT.P: A second suspect in the probe into an alleged money laundering case implicating former President Chen Shui-bian's family was detained Thursday.
Tsai Ming-tse, a younger brother of former first lady Wu Shu-jen's classmate Tsai Mei-li, was taken into custody after the Taipei District Court agreed to prosecutors's request for his detention.

Prosecutors summoned Tsai Mei-li and her two younger brothers -- Tsai Ming-chieh and Tsai Ming-tse -- for questioning again Thursday to determine whether they had assisted in wiring money into overseas accounts owned by members of the former first family.

Prosecutors said they have collected evidence showing that Tsai Ming-tse had played a crucial role in the illegal money transfer over the past years, but Tsai would not divulge any details. Prosecutors then decided to apply for his detention to prevent him from meddling with evidence in the snowballing case.
Besides granting Tsai's detention, the district court also ordered that Tsai be held incommunicado.

Tsai Ming-tse was the second witness-turned-suspect to be detained in the ongoing probe into the alleged money-laundering case after Chen Chen-hui, the former president's most trusted cashier, was taken into custody Sept.25.
The case came to light Aug. 13 when a local weekly reported that the former first family had transferred large sums of money abroad and might be engaged in money laundering.

The former president admitted the following day that his wife had wired family funds abroad without his knowledge, but insisted that all the money was clean. According to Chen Shui-bian, the money was the balance of political contributions for his two mayoral and two presidential bids between 1993 and 2004.

Chen is also under investigation for alleged embezzlement of public funds by using other people's receipts to gain reimbursement from his "state affairs fund." His wife has been indicted in this case.

Chen claimed his innocence, insisting that he didn't use any dime of the discretionary "state affairs fund" to line his own pocket. Prosecutors are investigating whether any portions of the "state affairs fund" had been wired to the overseas bank accounts of his family members during his eight-year presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday, moving down 92.21 points at 5,611.51 on a turnover of NT$3.06 billion (US$95.15 million).
The weighted price index lost 60.29 points, or 1.04 percent, to close at 5,703.72 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.212 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.052 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi health officials step up food safety inspections
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/03/08 10:31:39 (By Han Nai-kuo) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Chiayi city government began a large-scale food safety inspection Thursday to ensure that no milk products, non-dairy creamer or vegetable-based protein products from China are being used by food processors in the southern city.

The officials from the Public Health Bureau took the action with the aim of protecting the reputation of 10 delicacies designated by the city government as typical gift items that visitors to Chiayi over the Double Ten National Day holiday will buy to take home, according to a spokesman for the bureau.

Chiayi has been given the right to host this year's National Day fireworks show sponsored by the central government. The city government will also hold a series of other festivities to celebrate National Day, and hopes to attract some 200,000 visitors to the city.

To allay visitors' fears that the city's renowned delicacies might contain melamine-contaminated products from China, the officials stepped up their inspections at food manufacturers in the city to make sure that none of the materials they use have come from China.
"Visitors can feel assured that the 10 recommended gift items they might buy in Chiayi are absolutely safe," the spokesman said.

He said that whenever in doubt about food safety, consumers can phone the bureau on the special service line (03)233-8267. ENDITEM/J ED5K7104.CEP K71dR MOEA respects wishes of directors of state-owned enterprises to quit

Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Thursday that he will respect the wishes of board directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises under the jurisdiction of the ministry who decide to resign from their posts rather than make public their assets.
Yiin said that "privacy is involved" and that the ministry will respect their wishes.

He made the remarks amid reports that up to 115 of the 556 board directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises or government-funded, non-profit institutes have tendered their resignations after the enforcement of the amended Act on Property-declaration by Public Servants was put into practice Oct. 1.
Under the new rules, the directors and supervisors of state-owned enterprises and government-subsidized institutional organizations, along with their spouses, are required to declare their assets.

Those who are unwilling to declare their assets span the industrial and academic sectors, reports said, citing the examples of BenQ Corp. Chairman Lee Kun-yao, who is a board member of the Industrial Technology Research Institute and former National Science Council Chairman Wei Che-ho, who is a board member of the Institute for Information Industry.
Yiin said that the directors and supervisors who have offered to resign account for more than 20 percent of the total, but added that board meetings "are generally operating normally."
"The ministry will fill the vacancies at the earliest possible time," he added.
He noted that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has said that personnel related to state- owned enterprises and government-funded, non-profit institutes must be competent and must have integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some passengers injured on CAL flight released from hospital
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 2 (CNA) 10/03/08 10:32:54 (By Lin Ching-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Some of the passengers injured by turbulence aboard a Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) flight Thursday have already been discharged from a hospital after receiving treatment, a spokesman for the CAL's Bangkok office said later that day.
A total of 21 people -- 16 passengers and five crew members -- were injured by turbulence when the flight from Hong Kong was preparing to land at Bangkok International Airport, the spokesman said.
Two of the injured sustained severe but not life-threatening injuries, the spokesman said.
All of the five injured crew members were Taiwan nationals, but none of the injured passengers were Taiwanese, the spokesman added.

According to a name list released by CAL's Taipei headquarters, nine of the injured were Chinese citizens and four were from Thailand. The remaining three were one each from Hong Kong, the United States and Israel.
Most of those hurt suffered cuts and bruises, and two had spine injuries, hospital sources said.
The CAL spokesman said some passengers were injured because they had failed to fasten their seat belts while the aircraft was descending and hit by turbulence.
