DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 3, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet- level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Big haul of illicit narcotics seized

TEXT.P: A haul of over 140 kg of ketamine was seized by coast guard officers Friday in northern Taiwan, the Coastal Patrol Directorate General (CPDG) under the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration announced later that day.

In a pre-dawn operation off the coast of Taipei County's Danshuei township, CPDG cutters chased and intercepted a mainland Chinese fishing boat in strong winds. On board, the officers discovered a total of 142.6 kg of the ketamine -- a white crystalline powder used as a general anaesthetic in human and veterinary medicine but used in conjunction with ecstasy by drug abusers.
The confiscated drug, concealed in teabags, has a street value exceeding NT$110 million (US$3.41 million), according to the CPDG.

The skipper, surnamed Zhang, and two other crew members of the Chinese fishing boat, identified as the Minxiayun F730, were later referred to the Shihlin District Prosecutors Office for further questioning.
Meanwhile, the police were tracking down a Taiwanese man suspected of being a connection in cross-Taiwan Strait narcotics smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature approves grand justice nominations

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Friday President Ma Ying-jeou's nominations for five grand justices despite a boycott of the vote by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers.

The nominees were Huang Mao-jung, a law professor at National Taiwan University; Chen Min, a law professor at National Chengchi University; Yeh Pai-hsiu, a judge at the Supreme Administrative Court; Chen Chun-sheng, dean of the Law School of National Taipei University; and Chen Hsin-min, a research fellow with the Academia Sinica's preparatory office for the Institute of Law.
They will replace four grand justices whose terms will soon expire and another one, Peng Feng-chih, who has been tapped to serve as president of the Supreme Administrative Court.
The minority DPP refused to take part in the vote to protest against what they described as a failure of the nominations.

According to DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling, the nominations "failed to impress the public" because none of the nominees -- all of whom are professors at some of the country's most prestigious schools, judges or fellows at Taiwan's highest- level research institute -- "enjoy prestige or a respectful status in the academic sector."
Kuan claimed that their appointments will turn the Constitutional Court into a "conservative, reactionary" institution.
"The DPP refuses such nominations to safeguard the dignity of the Constitution," she said.

According to Lin Shu-fen, another DPP legislator, while the grand justices are supposed to be impartial and independent, the five candidates were nominated to the positions because of their relationship with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) or Ma.
Lin said Chen Hsin-min is a recipient of the KMT-sponsored Sun Yat-sen Scholarship, while Chen Min appeared in a campaign ad for Ma's 2008 presidential bid to endorse his campaign platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: Idaho state governor to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Idaho State Governor C.L. Butch Otter will lead a delegation on a visit to Taiwan Oct. 19 for exchanges on business and economy, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official told CNA Thursday.
Otter will become the first U.S. state governor to visit Taiwan this year, the official said.
The 30-member delegation, including state government officials and representatives of enterprises, will stay in Taiwan for four days before flying to Japan Oct. 22, the official said.

They will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou and Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, as well as visiting the Department of Health and local enterprises that have business relations with Idaho, including those in the meat and glass industries.
The improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations might allow Otter's visit to proceed more smoothly compared with previous planned visits by other U.S. state governors, the official said.

During the past eight years when the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was in power, China invested massive resources in winning over Taiwan's supporters in the United States and blocking relations between U.S. local governments and Taiwan, the official said.

Maryland State Governor Martin O'Malley's and Iowa State Governor Chet Culver's canceled plans to visit Taiwan last September and early May this year, respectively, served as good examples of China's obstruction, the official said.
Under these circumstances, only a few U.S. state head visited Taiwan in some years from 2001 to 2007, the official said.

Six came in 1999 when the Kuomintang was still in power and soared to 12 in the following year, in which Taiwan underwent a political power transfer from the KMT to DPP before tailing off when former President Chen Shui-bian's policies became more apparent, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor visits city's first `made in Taiwan' food section

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu attended the launch Friday of the first "made in Taiwan" section at a hypermarket in the southern port city amid the ongoing Chinese tainted milk product scandal.

The President Group's hypermarket store Dollars established the section in response to the municipal government's call for businesses in the sector to do so as part of the government's efforts to restore consumers' peace of mind regarding the safety of food products.
At the launch, Chen said the government has "a solemn responsibility to ensure the safety of food" on the market.

Recently, consumers in the city "don't know where to turn, " especially families with small children, Chen said, stressing that the government is doing all that it can to ensure food safety and reassure citizens.
The measure of promoting the establishment of "made in Taiwan" sections at hypermarkets is part of those efforts to restore people's peace of mind that they are purchasing safe products, Chen said.

The mayor also expressed the hope that the central government's Council of Agriculture, Department of Health and relevant agencies will establish a food traceability system to further protect citizens and put their minds at ease.

Under the "made in Taiwan" program, all products must first undergo safety testing by the municipal government's Department of Health and Economic Affairs Bureau before being allowed to be displayed in these sections at hypermarkets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor groups call for paid typhoon day leave for laborers

TEXT.P: Labor activist groups urged the government Friday to grant the same opportunity to blue-collar or lower-ranking workers as civil servants to be entitled to paid leave on severe typhoon days that are declared days off by the government.

Members of the Youth Labor Union 95 (YLU 95) and other labor activists groups went to the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to demand that blue- collar and lower-ranking workers be given days off during typhoon days when offices and schools are closed.
"If those workers still have to work during typhoon days, they must be compensated by their employers," the activists said.
It marked the second time that the YLU 95 and other labor activists have petitioned the CLA since Sept. 23, when they made a similar appeal.
The activists renewed their appeal after the CLA told them that the council will leave disputes over working on typhoon days to private negotiations between management and labor.
They blasted the CLA, accusing it of passing a hot potato to the private sector.

Citing as an example a part-time student worker in Taichung who died on his way home after finishing work at a convenience store during a typhoon, the activists said the government should not pass the buck any longer, particularly in the face of Taiwan's unfair work environment, where the rate of labor union organization is pathetically low and laborers have always been at a disadvantage in terms of management-labor relations.

The activists argued that the CLA should make it a rule that blue collar or lower-ranking workers should enjoy same rights as public functionaries and should get paid leave when a typhoon day is announced as a day off.

The government has been procrastinating in making such a rule to avoid causing trouble with business and industrial leaders, who have said that the business and industrial sectors will suffer heavy losses if workers stop working during typhoon days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan members laud progress in Kinmen mine-clearing

TEXT.P: Control Yuan members Huang Huang-hsiung and Liu Hsing-shan visited Kinmen Friday to inspect mine-clearing work on the outlying island, and lauded an Army Engineers Corps demining team's progress.
The team was established in April last year with the task of clearing the more than 70,000 mines on over 150 minefields left on the island. It has vowed to complete its mission before 2013.

Huang and Liu were accompanied by Lt. Gen. Chang Jung-chung of the Kinmen Defense Command and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng on their visit to a minefield in Chinning township that was affected by a major fire last October.
During the visit, the Control Yuan members listened to a briefing by Col. Ku Chien-chien, captain of the demining team.

Ku said that since April 2007, the team has cleared 20 minefields covering about 865,000 square meters. A total of 13,200 mines, or 25.4 percent of the total, were cleared during that period, he added.
Ku said that the team is already 1.75 percent ahead of schedule in achieving its goal of clearing Kinmen of all remaining mines by 2012.

Noting that the remainder of the task, if contracted out to foreign deminning experts, will cost about NT$5.8 billion (US$180.4 million) to complete, Ku said the demining efforts will be beneficial in terms of the outlying islands' development, as well as improving the country's international image.
After listening to the briefing, Huang and Liu both praised the demining team's substantial progress toward achieving its goal.

Chinning township chief Lee Wen-chun and members of the township council were also present to express their hope that the minefields will be handed over to the township's residents for farming after they are cleared.
In response, Huang said he agrees with the idea and that research will be undertaken over the practicability of the military giving up the land.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman has no plans to run for Taipei magistrate

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ruled out Friday the possibility that its chairwoman, Tsai Ing-wen, would run for Taipei County magistrate, despite calls within the party for her to join the race.
Cheng Wen-tsang, who as head of the DPP's Department of Culture and Communications acts as the party's spokesman, said he has never heard of any such idea or plans by Tsai.

Cheng said the DPP realizes that Taipei County -- the country's largest administrative region -- will be a benchmark in next year's elections for city mayors and county magistrates, and the party will muster its wisdom to field the best candidate.

According to the results of a survey released the same day by a group of DPP Taipei County councilwomen, if Tsai were to represent the DPP in the next Taipei County magistrate election, 51.4 percent of voters would vote for her, while only 27.5 percent of voters would support the possible re-election bid of incumbent magistrate Chou Hsi-wei of the Kuomintang.
The results showed that Taipei County residents were split over Chou's performance, with 44.8 percent of residents expressing satisfaction and 41.3 percent voicing dissatisfaction.
Asked to compare Chou with his predecessor Su Tseng-chang from the DPP, 50.5 percent of respondents thought Su performed better than Chou, while 18.7 percent said Chou is better.
The survey was conducted Sept. 27 and Sept. 29 among 1,072 Taipei County residents aged 20 and older via telephone. It had a margin of error of 3 percent.

Councilwomen Liao Hsiao-ching, Chou Ya-lin, Lin Hsiu-huei, Ho Shu-feng and Li Chien-ping said the survey results indicate that Tsai is the DPP's best choice for the the Taipei County race and that they will jointly persuade her to run for the post.
According to the councilwomen, the survey was carried out without Tsai's knowledge. They claimed the results are "highly accurate and objective."

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City to celebrate National Day with cycling activity

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung municipal government held a news conference Friday to announce that the southern port city will celebrate the upcoming Double Ten National Day with a cycling activity.

Attending the news conference were Deputy Mayor Lee Yung-teh, Kaohsiung Bureau of Social Affairs deputy head Huang Chau-huan, and singer Genie Chuo, who welcomed all residents of the city, including Mayor Chen Chu, to take part in the event.
The 6-kilometer cycling activity will kick off at 3 p.m. on Oct. 10 at the Pier 2 Arts District and run along the Cijin Oceanview Bike Path to the ShinKuan Water Park.
Lee said that the holding of a cycling activity to celebrate the National Day is in line with efforts to conserve energy and cut carbon emissions.
The Social Affairs Bureau said that cyclists will be handed special draw tickets at the start of the activity for the opportunity to win one of several prizes on offer, including fold-up bicycles.
The event will also include a special costume contest for participants in the activity, with the top three winners in the competition receiving up to NT$10,000, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seek detention of ex-president's aide

TEXT.P: Prosecutors have asked to detain a close aide of former president Chen Shui-bian after interrogating him over his role in helping Chen and his family in the alleged embezzlement of public funds and overseas money laundering.

After interrogating Lin Teh-hsun, who was Chen's chief secretary from 2005-2008, the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office filed a request with a court for permission to hold Lin incommunicado over fears that he would tamper with evidence related to the case if set free.

Summoned as a potential defendant in the case, Lin was mainly questioned on the nature and destination of expenditures for so-called "top secret missions" that came from the president's discretionary "state affairs fund."

Prosecutors believe Lin is familiar with the former first family's alleged money laundering operations and might be able to provide ironclad evidence against ex- President Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen.
The former president has claimed his innocence, insisting that funds from "state affairs fund" were targeted at six secret diplomatic missions, and that none of the money lined his own pocket.
Prosecutors are investigating whether any portion of the "state affairs fund" had been wired to the overseas bank accounts of his family members during his eight-year presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei share prices buck trend

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, bucking the Dow Industrials' 3.2 percent tumble overnight and a decline in every other major Asian bourse as of 3: 20 p.m. Friday afternoon.
The Taiwan exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, rose 38.51 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 5,742.23.
Rebounding from losses of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 5,611.51 and fluctuated between 5,747.73 and 5,558.35.

A total of 3.17 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$67.12 billion (US$2.08 billion) , the fourth consecutive day turnover failed to exceed NT$70 billion, as investors remain cautious in the face of uncertainty over the outcome of the United States' US$700 billion bailout package for the financial sector.

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.5 percent. Foodstuff issues advanced 2.1 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares gained 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 0.8 percent, and textile stocks grew 0.3 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares declining 1.1 percent and construction issues dropping 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 998 to 617, with 382 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$8.04 million and sold a net NT$26.5 billion in shares for the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government announces nationwide national day festivities

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) announced Friday a series of concerts and festivities, including a parade and a fireworks show, that will be held around the country to mark the 97th national day of the Republic of China (Taiwan) on Oct. 10.

The national day ceremony, over which President Ma Ying-jeou will preside for the first time after taking office on May 20 this year, will begin at 9: 30 a.m. on the square in front of the Presidential Palace in Taipei, according to the GIO.

At the end of the ceremony, there will be a carnival street parade consisting of 17 festooned vehicles that represent different governmental agencies and local authorities. They will promote the government's policies and characteristics of different regions in Taiwan, the GIO said.
In addition, the Presidential Palace will be open to visitors from noon to 4 p.m. that day.
Later on Oct. 10, Chiayi County in southern Taiwan will host a spectacular 50-minute fireworks display, during which 7,813 fireworks will be set off. The show is scheduled to begin at 7 p.m.
A the same time, a pop music concert expected to attract around 20,000-30,000 people, will be held in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien.

In Taichung, the Council for Cultural Affairs under the Executive Yuan plans to entertain central Taiwan residents with the music of the internationally renowned violinist Lin Cho-liang and the 90-member Taiwan Symphony Orchestra.
The southern port city of Kaohsiung City will organize a bicycle-riding carnival in the afternoon the same day.
On National Day, the country commemorates the Oct. 10, 1911 Wuchang uprising in China that led to the collapse of the Qing Dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore establish parliamentary group to boost relations

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Singapore established a parliamentary friendship association Friday, in an attempt to further promote bilateral relations and exchanges between the people of both countries.

With the establishment of the Taiwan-Singapore Parliamentary Friendship Association to serve as a focal point with Singapore, I believe the group will further promote substantial relations between the two countries to bring even closer relations, said Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng at a ceremony to establish the group.
Wang also serves as the honorary chairperson of the group.

Wang saidthe meaning of the friendship association is different from other such relationships Taiwan has, " suggesting it was a further deepening of already strong ties. He noted that interactions between high-level officials of Taiwan and Singapore have long been frequent and close and the two countries share a very good relationship in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Stanley Loh, the trade representative of the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei, said Taiwan and Singapore have long been working together in many areas, such as business, economic and cultural exchanges, and he knows that many Singaporean companies are very interested in doing business in Taiwan, especially the i-Taiwan 12 projects.

The i-Taiwan national construction projects, one of President Ma's major economic platforms, proposes spending US$120 billion over the next eight years to stimulate the domestic economy and lower the unemployment rate by creating 120,000 job opportunities each year.

Speaking at the ceremony, Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia described Taiwan's relationship with Singapore as aspecial friendship, saying that he believes bilateral relations will scale new heights under the efforts of the parliamentary friendship association.

Justin Chou, a ruling Kuomintang legislator and the chairman of the Taiwan- Singapore Parliamentary Friendship Association, said that the group will strive to promote bilateral relations and exchanges between Taiwan and Singapore, and he hopes to lead a delegation to visit Singapore's parliament after the Legislative Yuan goes into recess.
The Taiwan-Singapore Parliamentary Friendship Association is comprised of 57 Taiwanese legislators.
The Singapore Trade Office in Taipei functions as the de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. launches diversity immigrant visa program for 2010

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Friday that the United States Diversity Immigrant Visa (DV) lottery will run from Oct. 3 to Dec. 2, Taiwan time.
Persons born on the islands of Taiwan and Penghu are eligible to participate in the DV program," the AIT stated in a press release.

The only source for complete and authoritative information on eligibility requirements and application procedures is www.dvlottery.state.gov. All applications must be submitted online according to the instructions on this Web site," it added.
The AIT stressed that there is no fee to participate in the DV lottery and that the U.S. government employs no outside consultants or private services to operate the DV program.

"Any intermediaries or others who offer assistance to prepare DV entries do so without the authority or consent of the U.S. government, " the AIT said. "Use of any outside intermediary or assistance to prepare a DV entry is entirely at the entrant's discretion."

Due to anticipated high demand for the online application system, the AIT is encouraging participants to submit applications well before the lottery ends because in the past, system delays caused by extremely heavy demand in the final days of the registration period have resulted in the failure of some applicants to be able to register for the program.
According to the AIT, no entries will be accepted after 1: 00 a.m., Dec. 2 Taiwan time, regardless of whether there are system delays during the registration period.

The AIT functions as a de facto embassy in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the U.S. and its head is also treated as the de facto top U.S. representative to Taiwan. The two countries have maintained substantive ties since the U.S. switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to hold hiking events for high school students

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government will launch a series of hiking events for vocational high school students this weekend to help them learn more about the city after a survey found that they mostly read entertainment and fashion news outside of class.

Wu Ching-shan, director of the city's Department of Education, told a news conference Thursday that the city has mapped out 18 hiking trails featuring natural ecology and cultural and heritage sites that will provide diversified learning environments for vocational high school students.

The hiking program, called "Reading Taipei," was based on the "No Child Left Inside" program launched in the United States, a back-to-nature movement to reconnect children with the outdoors, Wu added.
He said that the goal of the "Reading Taipei" program is to encourage the students to exercise more and experience Taipei's natural beauty and culture rather than play video games.

The program was conceived after a recent survey on the extracurricular reading behavior of vocational high school students in Taipei City revealed that most of them spend a lot of their leisure time reading entertainment news and articles about fashion, according to Wu.
The survey was conducted by the King Car Education Foundation in June among 1,200 students at various vocational high schools around the city, with 1,170 valid questionnaires being collected.
The poll had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus/minus 3 percent.

It showed that over the previous three months before the students were polled, newspapers were their most popular reading material, read by 62.78 of the respondents, followed by novels (58.97 percent) and Internet articles (38.99 percent).

Their preferred extracurricular reading-material topics were movie- and TV- related activities (38.36 percent) , fashion trends (35.4 percent) , travel and leisure (23.9 percent) and sports (22.2 percent), according to the survey.

Their extracurricular reading habits changed only slightly on weekends and holidays. Their preferred topics on those days were movie- and television- related stories (44.3 percent), fashion trends (33.6 percent) sports (26.26 percent) and articles offering tips on improving video game skills (21.4 percent).

As to what type of extracurricular activities they would enjoy, 85 percent of the respondents cited watching audio-visual programs while 58 percent of them said they would enjoy an outdoor guided tour.

The "Reading Taipei" hiking events will be held every weekend from Saturday to Dec. 21 for vocational high school students and their parents. The campaign is expected to attract some 900 people to participate, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County focusing on cleanliness of public washrooms

TEXT.P: Tainan County in southern Taiwan is focusing on the state of its public toilets, as part of efforts to maintain a clean and comfortable environment, an official of the county's Bureau of Environmental Protection said Friday.

Since 2006, the bureau has been carrying out monthly inspections of the 1,054 public toilets that fall under the county government's jurisdiction, including those in parks and at gas stations, sightseeing spots, and bus and train stations, the official said.
Schools toilets under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Education and toilets in private stores are not included, the official added.

The county government offers cash prizes ranging from NT$5,000 to NT$20,000 to units that best manage their restroom facilities, as assessed by the bureau, in a bid to improve public washroom facilities, the official said.
These cleaners who keep these public washrooms clean are also given presents as rewards, the official added.

With the cooperation of all concerned, the program has been showing results, as only two restrooms failed to meet the inspection standards in September, the official said, adding that since then they have made improvements.

In step with its efforts to clean up public toilets, the Tainan County government has been holding an environmental competition among its 31 townships since 2006, and has designated the second Saturday of every month as Cleaning Day in the county, according to the official.

Every Cleaning Day, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih and government staff visit different townships to help with the clean-up work in the hope of drawing wider participation by county residents, the official said.
The county also imposes strict penalties for violations of its environmental rules, such as illegal dumping and pasting of flyers on public property, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei could become regional financial center: City of London chief
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/08 18:45:27 (By Jennifer Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei has the potential to become a regional financial center, the lord mayor of the City of London -- the financial and commercial heart of Britain -- said Thursday, and he offered Taiwan's capital a hand in achieving the goal.

Speaking at a press conference ahead of his planned visit to Asia, City of London Lord Mayor David Lewis said London was a global financial center because of its hundreds of thousands of talented foreign workers and argued that Taipei could become a regional financial stronghold only if it relaxes restrictions on foreign immigration.

Excellent workers are also the reason that Hong Kong and Singapore are globally influential financial cities as they, like Taiwan, lack natural resources, said Lewis, who is scheduled to be in Taiwan Oct. 5-8.
The City of London, known as the world's leading international financial and business center, is willing to share its abundant business opportunities and experience with Taipei, said Lewis.
Located in the eastern part of downtown London, the City of London is also called the "Square Mile" due to its 2.6-square kilometer area.
The lord mayor is elected every year and is commissioned to act during the one- year term as an ambassador for the UK-financial services industry.

According to the City government's statistics, the financial sector generated an export profit of 24 billion pounds (US$42.5 billion) for the UK in 2006. Most financial institutions in Britain are headquartered in the Square Mile.
The October tour will mark the last overseas trip of the 61-year-old Lewis -- born in Hong Kong and raised in Asia -- in his capacity as lord mayor of the City before stepping down in November.
Lewis described the Taipei visit as "very important" amid the global financial storm.
During his stay in Taiwan, Lewis is scheduled to visit President Ma Ying-jeou, Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan and top officials at economic and financial agencies.
He will also deliver two public speeches before leaving Taiwan for other Asian countries including Japan, Brunei and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.027 to close at NT$32.187.
A total of US$922 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.160 and fluctuated between NT$32.125 and NT$32.270.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October rose 25 points to close at 5,645, with 78,624 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November gained 31 points to finish at 5,631, with 590 contracts traded, while December futures rose 17 points to close at 5,609, with 47 contract transactions.
March futures increased 41 points to finish at 5,589, with seven contract transactions, while June futures dropped 28 points to close at 5,517, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,620 for October, 5,600 for November, 5,592 for December, 5,548 for March and 5,545 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 38.51 points to finish at 5,742.23, on turnover of NT$67.12 billion (US$2.08 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
October TE futures rose 3.1 points to close at 232.2, with 5,236 contracts traded, while November TE futures increased 2.8 points to finish at 231.25, with 52 contract transactions.

March TE futures decreased 1.25 points to finish at 225.75, with three contracts traded, while June TE futures decreased 5.05 points to close at 221.95, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for December.
October TF futures decreased 7.4 points to close at 664.4, with 4,098 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures were down six points to finish at 664.6, with 33 contracts traded.

December TF futures moved down 10.8 points to end at 655.6 points, with one contract traded, while March TF futures dropped 11 points to close at 655.8, with one contract transaction. June TF futures declined 7.2 points to finish at 661.2, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oral vaccines for fish win biotech development award

TEXT.P: oral vaccines for fish developed at National Cheng Kung University have won the top prize in the "2008 Crazy Idea" -- a biotech competition organized by the Industrial Development Bureau under Ministry of Economic Affairs, government officials said Friday.
At the award ceremony in Taipei Oct. 15, the research team, led by professor Yang Huey-lang, will receive medals and a cash prize of NT$400,000 (about US$12,000).

The vaccines, which have already gained patents both in Taiwan and the United States, had been under development for years before a breakthrough was achieved early last year, according to the Tainan-based university.

During the three-year experiments on nearly 60,000 cobias, the new vaccines helped raise the survival rate from around 40 percent to more than 80 percent, university officials reported. In optimal circumstances, the vaccines can further boost the survival rate to 86 percent, which is better than the 64 percent achieved by the fish vaccines developed in some European laboratories, they added.

Conventional fish vaccines are delivered by injection, Yang explained, adding that although these vaccines are quite effective, the cost and time increase tremendously when applied to commercial aquaculture because the fish populations are usually very large.
On the other hand, while oral vaccines that are delivered by mixing them into fish food can lower costs and reduce time, they are limited in terms of efficacy, Yang said.

Yang's team employed gene engineering techniques to implant the vaccines into carrier bacteria, then fed planktons with the bacteria. The vaccine-carrying planktons were later fed to fry and adult fish to induce their immunity against certain pathogens.

Compared to other oral vaccines, Yang said, his team's vaccines have greater efficacy because each dose contains much more antigen, and it is much easier to modify the vaccine to induce immunity against new pathogens.

DOC.HEADLINE: 158 kg of semi-finished amphetamine seized in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials have busted an illicit drug plant in Kaohsiung County and seized 158.5 kilograms of semi-finished amphetamine, the CGA's Kaohsiung office announced Friday.

A spokesman for the office said that officers from a CGA mobile unit in Kaohsiung County on Thursday raided the plant, housed in a private home in Fengshan city, and arrested three suspects. The officers also seized the amphetamine -- a grade two drug -- in liquid form, along with the equipment for producing the drug and NT$600,000 in cash.
One of the persons arrested -- the owner of the plant -- was identified by the surname Tsai. His girlfriend surnamed Lien and another accomplice surnamed Chang were also arrested.
The spokesman said that the mobile unit received a tip-off three months ago that Tsai was in the process of producing amphetamine to take advantage of the drug shortage in the Taiwan market.

The CGA mobile unit and criminal investigation police in Kaohsiung County formed a task force to place Tsai under surveillance. Armed with a search warrant issued by the local court, the task force raided the plant Thursday and caught the three suspects red-handed.

In an initial investigation, the task force found that the ephedrine, a precursor chemical used in the production of the illicit drug, came from China. The CGA officials found two large plastic bags labeled in simplified Chinese characters showing that the chemical compound was produced in China's Sichuan province.

According to the spokesman, the task force determined that the manufacturing operation had been going on for about six months, and there are indications that the plant has already delivered finished amphetamine products to its buyers.
The three suspects will be referred to the local prosecutors office to face criminal charges, while the task force will work to catch other suspects involved in the drug network, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister hospitalized after being attacked by lawmakers

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan checked into National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) Friday after he was allegedly attacked by opposition legislators in a scuffle at the Legislative Yuan amid an ongoing public health scare over food contaminated with melamine.
Yeh, who took the post only eight days ago, was suffering from dizziness, flush, cardiopalmus and high blood pressure upon arrival at the hospital, said NTUH spokesman Tan Ching-Ting.
Doctors suggested that Yeh stay in the hospital for further observation, Tan said.

Yeh was sworn in as health minister on Sept. 26 after Lin Fang-yue resigned one day earlier to take responsibility for the government's delayed and inconsistent response to the spiraling crisis on the melamine-spiked dairy foods and drinks containing ingredients imported from China.

According to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chang Shuo-wen, who was with Yeh when the scuffle erupted, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators tried to prevent Yeh from leaving the Legislative Yuan floor after a meeting with bakery owners and lawmakers over disputes pertaining to the government's response to the widening health scare.
"Someone grabbed the minister's neck and he could hardly breathe," Chang said.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan reiterated on Sept. 26 that no melamine as an additive should be allowed in any foodstuffs. Under mounting pressure in recent days, he also agreed to demand an apology and seek compensation from China for the economic losses businesses here suffered.
Government spokeswoman Vanessa Yea-ping Shih on Friday reiterated remarks made by Liu of a zero tolerance for melamine.

The government had surprised and frustrated the public when the Department of Health set on Sept. 24 a new melamine standard which stipulated that products containing 2.5 parts per million (ppm) of melamine would be allowed in foodstuffs sold in Taiwan, a higher amount than the previous standard.
Government officials, however, have said they reached the standard after taking into consideration standards in developed countries.

It was unclear if by referring to zero tolerance of melamine as an additive, Liu and Shih were making a distinction between the deliberate adulteration of milk powder and vegetable-based proteins, as has occurred in China, versus melamine residue that has been known to migrate to foods and beverages from their packaging.

Yeh had overturned the controversial safety standard for melamine set by the health department one hour after taking over the health minister post, saying that all products testing positive for the toxic chemical would be considered "not up to standard."
"We will not stipulate a maximum permissible quantity for melamine. There is only positive and negative, " said Yeh, referring to the principle behind the new test standard.
The DPP blasted Yeh and the administration under President Ma Ying-jeou for its handling of the food crisis.

As of Friday, Taiwan has banned all Chinese dairy imports and ordered those products already imported to be tested for traces of the industrial chemical melamine, a nitrogen-rich industrial chemical used in the production of plastics and glues.

At least four infants have died in China and more than 25,000 others have been sickened by milk powder and other dairy products contaminated by melamine -- which was added by unscrupulous milk middlemen traders and food manufacturers to give the appearance in food tests that the milk has a higher protein content than it actually does.

In Taiwan, the melamine scare has been looming large as the chemical has also been found in non-dairy creamer used in instant coffee, milk tea, puddings, chicken-and-corn soup, ready-to-serve packs of healthy grain drinks, and even in cheese powder packs offered by a local pizza franchise.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGO fights for rights of Vietnamese divorcees and children

TEXT.P: The Catholic Good Shepherd Social Welfare Services urged the government Friday to provide greater legal protection for divorced or abandoned foreign spouses in Taiwanese-Vietnamese marriages and help protect the education rights of their children.
According to the social welfare organization, some Vietnamese women married to Taiwanese men and their children suffer serious consequences when they are divorced or intentionally abandoned.
If they stay in Taiwan, most of the women cannot earn a living as they have to take care of their children at the same time.

If they return to Vietnam, their children, having only Taiwanese nationality, cannot attend public schools there because of local regulations, said the group's head Sister Therese Thong, in the first of a series of hearings on problems faced by new immigrants.
The hearing Friday on cross-border marriages was held by Yang Li-huan, a ruling Kuomintang legislator, at the Legislative Yuan.

"These children are deprived of their right to receive an education, and they might have hatred for Taiwan when growing up, " said Sister Thong, who added that private schools are not affordable for most of the Vietnamese spouses.
She noted that a non-governmental organization tried to open a Chinese-language school for these children two years ago, but the project failed as they were scattered all over the country.
"What we are more worried about is whether the women with trauma can still give decent care to their children, " added Thong.
She argued that the children's education was the responsibility of both countries and demanded that the government find a solution to help people facing such a predicament.

In response, Hsieh Li-kung, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) who also attended the hearing, said the government has a 10-year budget of NT$3 billion to help foreign spouses, and nongovernmental organizations can apply for funding in case of need.
But Hsieh said it was up to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to negotiate with Vietnamese authorities on the education question.
He said there are currently 578 Taiwanese children from failed Taiwanese- Vietnamese marriages in Vietnam, with 260 of them having remained there for more than one year.

He also noted that foreign spouses are already protected by the existing Immigration Law in particular situations, but acknowledged that enforcement rules need to be studied and amended to adapt to the real needs of society.
Legislator Yang also demanded the agency and related departments to better inform foreign spouses of ways in which they can apply for government assistance.
According to the MOI, a total of 408,547 foreign spouses were living in Taiwan as of the end of August, accounting for 1.7 percent of the population. Of the total, 269,871 were from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Design Expo set to open in Tainan County

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Design Expo will open in Tainan County's Soulangh Cultural Park Saturday for a 16-day run until Oct. 19.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih urged people in southern Taiwan Friday to seize the opportunity to go to the expo and see the various creative designs from both Taiwan and abroad, including many award-winning masterpieces.
Su noted that this is the third consecutive year that Tainan County has hosted the annual Taiwan Design Expo.
He said in line with the ongoing campaign to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the Tainan County government has made arrangements to exhibit newly designed bicycles in two of the 13 pavilions.
The event is jointly held by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Tainan County government.

The 13 pavilions include the Taiwan Excellence Pavilion, the International Design Pavilion, the Art Craft and Designer's Pavilion, the Creative Life Pavilion, the Dream Vision Pavilion and the Japan Universal Design Experience Pavilion.
On display will be the latest works by designers from Taiwan, Japan, Singapore, Germany and France, including award-winning pieces that have not been exposed to the market.
During the exhibition, the MOEA, the sponsor of the Taiwan Design Award, will announce award winners and present them with the "Oscars" for Taiwan's design sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 70% of high-tech workers interested in social welfare: survey

TEXT.P: Contrary to the public perception that high-tech personnel are apathetic toward the world around them, more than 73 percent of them said they care about social welfare, according to the results of an online survey released Friday.
The survey on high-tech personnel and social welfare was conducted by the nonprofit World Peace Association and online company Youthwant recently. A total of 1,076 effective samples were collected.
Among them, 25 percent were in the high-tech sector, while others came from different walks of life.

Of those polled, 54 percent said high-tech personnel face tremendous pressure on the job, 46 percent said high-tech personnel attach importance to efficiency and execution, and 42.5 percent said high-tech personnel are less active socially than others.

When asked about participating in social welfare activities, 73.8 percent of the high-tech respondents said they cared about contributing to society, and 57.7 percent said they were willing to partake in charitable services if time permitted.

But since high-tech workers are often confined to their own world, they are unable to participate in public service activities as often as they would like. Some 23.6 percent said activities designed by social welfare groups don't fit into their work schedules.
The World Peace Association called on social welfare groups to design ways for high-tech workers to have the opportunity to do good deeds.

The association, working with Youthwant and a second-hand bookstore, has sponsored a book donation activity, calling for high-tech firms in science parks to donate books to help children from underprivileged families.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plans for Chinese official visit not yet finalized: premier

TEXT.P: Although there has been speculation that Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, would visit Taiwan by the end of this year, Premier Liu Chiao- shiuan said Friday that the plans have not yet been finalized.
"The matter has not yet been settled, as the relevant protocol arrangements have to be discussed and finalized," Liu said.
Liu insisted that Chen must address him as premier, if a meeting between the two of them is to take place. "I will not meet Chen if he refuses to call me 'Premier Liu,'" he said.
Liu made the remarks while answering questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Kuo Wen-cheng in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

Chen's planned visit to Taiwan, in late October or early November, comes at a delicate time when Taiwan is battling a food scare over toxic milk powder and vegetable-based proteins imported from China.

There have been protests in some quarters against Chen's visit, accompanied by demands that China apologize and that the responsible Chinese companies offer compensation to Taiwan consumers or companies over the sale of the melamine- tainted milk products.

Liu's remarks were at odds with a statement the day before by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , whose vice chairman, Liu Te-shun, said that "there are absolutely no plans to delay the date or shorten the process of the slated meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS)."
Taiwan and China are very likely to hold a new round of negotiations in late October or early November as originally planned, the MAC vice chairman said Thursday.

"Officials from the two quasi-official intermediary bodies are still working to set a date for a second meeting in Taiwan between the top negotiators of the two sides," he said, adding, however, that "the date will be not be fixed until around the middle of this month."

Speaking at a news conference earlier Friday, Cheng Wen-tsang, head of the DPP's public relations department, said the party will not pass up any opportunity to protest against China while Chen is in Taiwan.

"The DPP will definitely protest to Chen if he sets foot on Taiwan soil," Cheng said, adding that a DPP panel has been assessing several options on how to stage demonstrations while Chen is in the country.

"Even if Chen does not come, the DPP would consider taking to the streets to protest the importation of Chinese toxic milk and China's continued suppression of Taiwan's independent sovereignty, " Cheng said.

As several pro-independence groups plan to stage a street demonstration on Oct. 25, the DPP will encourage its supporters to join the rally in a concerted move to convey the people's anger to the Kuomintang government, he added.
In an ice-breaking meeting in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen clinched two milestone accords to step up two-way tourism and transportation services.

In their next round of talks, Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes, joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and crime-fighting.

DOC.HEADLINE: New charge added to ex-MJIB head's indictment

TEXT.P: Taipei's prosecutors added Friday yet another charge to the indictment of former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) Director Yeh Sheng-mao over his handling of intelligence regarding suspected money-laundering involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

The latest charge by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office accuses Yeh of leaking the information to Chen. Yeh was charged Aug. 28 with a count of concealing the information from the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

According to the indictment, in a report delivered to the MJIB in January through the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group, the Cayman Islands' financial intelligence unit raised the suspicion that the former first family was laundering money through an account created under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva, Switzerland.

Based on the report, the bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center on Jan. 29 compiled a file intended for delivery to the Supreme Prosecutors Office. Yeh later requested that the file be handed over to him and said he would pass it to State Public Prosecutor General Chen Tsung-ming in person, the indictment stated.

However, instead of giving the file to Chen Tsung-ming, Yeh leaked the content of the file to Chen Shui-bian during a visit to the former president's official residence between Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, the indictment said.

The prosecution said although Yeh repeatedly claimed that he had made an oral report to Chen Tsung-ming about the information, Yeh was inconsistent in his story, which shows that Yeh was likely to have made up the story to try to shun his legal liability.

Besides the money laundering case, Yeh is also accused of leaking a plan by prosecutors and investigators to raid the offices of Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Ker Chien-ming in April over Ker's involvement in an illegal mining operation in the eastern county of Hualien.
The alleged money laundering involving the former first family only came to light in July, when Taiwan received a request by Swiss authorities for assistance in probing the case.

Suspecting that the money wired overseas could be connected to the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating the former president and his wife Wu Shu-jen, prosecutors in August listed the couple, their son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and Wu's brother Wu Ching-mao as suspects in the case of alleged money laundering.
It was found that Huang Jui-ching and Wu Ching-mao are two of the nominal holders of the former first family's overseas bank accounts, and Chen Chih-chung is an authorized proxy on the accounts.

However, Wu Shu-jen, said to be the manager of the family's finances, claimed that the US$21 million deposited overseas had been obtained legally from four sources -- surplus of political contributions for the campaigns of her husband, her husband's practice as a lawyer before he went into politics, her own dowry and her investments.

Wu's statement was consistent with that of Chen Shui-bian, who openly confessed on Aug. 14 that he did not honestly account for his election campaign expenses and that his wife had wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.
Chen claimed that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that he had no idea until early this year that his wife had wired the funds abroad.

The former president denied the money had any connection with the "state affairs fund" case, in which the former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- defender in the case and was probed as soon as he stepped down from the presidency on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic fuel prices move lower

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two oil refiners announced cuts in fuel prices Friday to reflect declining import costs amid drops in crude oil prices in the international market.
Both state-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) , and the private Formosa Petrochemical Corp. said they will lower prices for gasoline by NT$0.6 per liter and for diesel by NT$0.7 per liter.
CPC Corp.'s price cuts were to take effect Friday at midnight, while Formosa's were to go into effect an hour later, at 1 a.m. Saturday.

Following the latest adjustment, the price of 92-octane unleaded gasoline will drop to NT$29.5 per liter, that of 95-octane unleaded will be NT$30.2 per liter and that of 98-octane unleaded will fall to NT$31.7 per liter.
The price of diesel will slide to NT$27 per liter.

The CPC adopted a floating pricing mechanism Aug. 7 that reviews prices on a weekly basis based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students who want to study in Japan urged to obtain visa first

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) on Friday reminded those who want to study in Japan to seek a student visa first before going there or face the possibility of being refused entry.
THe NIA issued the reminder after a recent incident involving a Taiwanese student being rejected entry at Kansai International Airport outside of Osaka.

Immigration officials said that Japan waived its visa requirements for Taiwanese nationals two years ago, and some local residents have mistaken this to mean that they could enter and leave Japan freely.

In fact, the visa-free treatment is given to those who travel to Japan for sightseeing or to visit friends, the officials said, adding that those who want to engage in any other activities are not eligible for the preferential treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SME competitiveness seen growing with high management efficiency

TEXT.P: The global competitiveness of Taiwan's small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) is growing thanks to their increased spending in research and development over the last several years, officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

In the World Competitiveness Yearbook 2008 released in May by the Switzerland- based International Institute for Management and Development (IMD), Taiwan ranked fourth among 55 countries in the evaluation of SME management efficiency.

The ranking marked a 10-notch jump from last year, according to the annual report on the global competitiveness of nations. The CEPD said it regards SMEs as a pillar of Taiwan's economy, based on a Ministry of Economic Affairs White Paper on SMEs in 2008, which showed that there were some 1.23 million such enterprises in Taiwan in 2007, accounting for 97.63 percent of all businesses in the country.
In 2007, over 7.9 million people worked at SMEs throughout Taiwan, accounting for 77.12 percent of the country's entire workforce, the paper stated.
Accumulated SME exports reached NT$160 million (US$4.97 million) in 2007, according to the white paper.
CEPD officials attributed SMEs' growing competitiveness to their high capital efficiency, the formation of industrial clusters, and steep increase in their spending on research and development.

Citing a government survey on the industrial, commercial and services sectors, the officials said that in 2006, Taiwan SMEs offered 62.8 percent of all job vacancies in those sectors and generated an output value of NT$10 trillion.
The survey also found that SME capital productivity posted a rise of 20 percent in 2006 from 2001, while labor productivity grew by 29.5 percent over that five- year period.
In the area of research and development spending, SMEs recorded an increase of 13.78 percent in 2006 from the previous year, higher than the 9.31 percent by large enterprises, the survey showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau chief to promote Taiwan travel in China

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai will head a delegation to China later this month, where it will hold seminars to give potential Chinese visitors a better understanding of Taiwan's tourism environment.

The delegation, to be comprised of 200 Taiwanese travel services representatives, will host seminars in Beijing Oct. 13, in Nanjing Oct. 16 and in Guangzhou Oct. 17 to brief Chinese travel agents and media and 33 Chinese social clubs on Taiwan's tourism culture, Lai said Friday.

Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General Hsieh Wei-chun will separately head a delegation to establish a Taiwan pavilion at a four-day travel fair which is scheduled to open Nov. 20 in Shanghai, according to Lai.
Taiwan and China launched landmark nonstop weekend cross-strait charter flight services July 4 to allow more Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan as part of its efforts to help boost bilateral exchanges.
In a concurrent agreement that formally took effect July 18, up to 3,000 Chinese nationals per day would be allowed to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.

Arrivals of Chinese visitors have fallen far short of the target in the first two months of the program, however, proving a major disappointment to President Ma Ying-jeou's administration, which had touted the greater opening to Chinese tourists as a potential economic boon.
During the July 14-Oct. 3 period, the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan averaged 377 per day, according to the National Immigration Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves shrink for 3rd consecutive month

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves fell in September for the third consecutive month, but the country still retained its status as the world's fifth largest foreign exchange holder, according to statistics released Friday by Taiwan's central bank -- the Taipei-based Central Bank of the Republic of China.
The figures showed that as of the end of September, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$281.13 billion, down US$957 million from the August figure.

Lin Sun-yuan, deputy director-general of the central bank's department of foreign exchange, explained that the decrease was mainly due to September's outflow of foreign funds, which totaled US$4.8 billion in the first 19 days of the month, compared with US$5 billion in August.

Despite a decrease of US$10.27 billion in foreign currency reserves in the past three months, Taiwan still ranked fifth among the world's largest foreign exchange holders, behind China with US$1.8 trillion at the end of June, Japan with US$971.3 billion at the end of August, Russia with US$446.1 billion at the end of August, and India with US$282.8 billion at the end of July.
Other statistics show that South Korea ranked sixth, with its foreign currency reserves totaling US$239.2 billion as of the end of September.
Singapore and Hong Kong -- two of the four Asian "mini dragons" -- recorded foreign exchange reserves of US$172.6 billion and US$153.2 billion, respectively, at the end of August.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chair has no plans to seek top Taipei County post: party offical

TEXT.P: Although Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen enjoys a high level of public support in Taipei County, she has no plans to run for the county magistrate seat, a party official said Friday.

Chen Wen-tsang, head of the DPP's public relations department, made the comments while responding to reporters' questions on a call by a group of DPP councilwomen in the Taipei County Council for Tsai to run for the post.
To back their push for Tsai to throw her hat in the ring, the councilwomen cited the results of a recent survey that they commissioned.

The councilors reported at a news conference at the Taipei County Council that, according to the poll, Tsai has a public support rating of 51.4 percent, well ahead of the 27.5 percent recorded for incumbent Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei of the Kuomintang.
The councilwomen urged Tsai to take up the challenge to install a DPP local government in Taipei County, Taiwan's largest administrative area in terms of population and size.
Due to its large number of voters, Taipei County in northern Taiwan has always been a crucial electoral battleground for the two major parties, the DPP and the KMT.
The DPP lost the presidential election in March this year after eight years in power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese convict departing for home with leniency from Thai king
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Oct. 3 (CNA) 10/03/08 23:16:06 (By Lin Ching-ping and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese drug convict who was originally sentenced to life imprisonment but was later granted a series of commutations by the Thai king was finally released recently and is ready to depart for home, Taiwan's representative office in Bangkok said Friday.
The convict, identified only by his family name Yang, was arrested in December 1992 on charges of narcotics trafficking, the representative office said in a statement.
Yang was first given a life sentence. Thanks to his good behavior behind bars, Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej commuted his sentence to 40 years in prison.

With assistance from the representative office, which issued a letter of guarantee on his behalf, Yang's prison sentence was again reduced by one-third, the statement said, adding that in the following years, Yang received three more rounds of commutations and thus had his prison sentence cut to 15 years and nine months.

According to the statement, Yang, 52, served out his greatly reduced prison term recently. He was jubilant at regaining his freedom, the statement said, adding that the representative office had been busy helping with his paperwork for his return to Taiwan since his release. Yang departed for home Friday evening.
The representative office said another 118 Taiwanese citizens are still serving time in Thai prisons, most of them were convicted of involvement in the narcotics trafficking or drug trade.

Noting that Thailand imposes a stringent ban on narcotics-related crimes, the statement said that any person who is found to be involved in the drug trade or trafficking tends to receive a severe penalty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust human-smuggling ring

TEXT.P: Police busted a human-smuggling ring in the mountains of Hsinchu, northern Taiwan Friday, rescuing 10 illegal workers -- nine men and one woman -- from Thailand.
Police also arrested a suspect, surnamed Huang, who was turned over to the Hsinchu Prosecutors Office on charges of obstruction of freedom and violation of the Employment Services Act.
Police said that they received a recent tip that Huang and an accomplice surnamed Hsieh had been acting as brokers for illegal foreign laborers, finding them odd jobs.
The foreign laborers, whose number rose to more than 50 at one time, were housed in tents erected in the mountainous region of Hsinpu, Hsinchu.
The workers' passports and residence permits were seized by Huang so that he could more easily control them, police said.

Huang demanded NT$800 (US$25) per day from each laborer, which netted him NT$1 million, according to police. He and his accomplice threatened to report the foreign laborers, who were on the run from their legitimate employers, to the authorities if the workers did not comply with their demands, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Third person detained in probe of former first family

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court granted a request by prosecutors to detain a close aide of former President Chen Shui-bian Friday evening over his suspected role in Chen's alleged embezzlement of public funds and overseas money laundering.

Prosecutors sought to detain Lin Teh-hsun, who was director of Chen's office from 2005-2008, after interrogating him earlier the same day. They suspect Lin was involved in embezzlement, committing fraud through the abuse of his position, and destroying evidence.
Lin became the third person to be detained in the probe of the former first family's alleged misconduct.
Chen Chen-hui, the former cashier of the Presidential Office under Chen Shui- bian, was the first to be detained.

Tsai Ming-che, the brother of Tsai Mei-li, a college classmate of former first lady Wu Shu-jen, was also detained for allegedly taking a bribe along with former President Chen from a land developer and providing bank accounts for the former first family to use in laundering money overseas.

The three have been listed as potential defendants in the case, along with former President Chen, former first lady Wu, their son and daughter-in-law, Wu's brother Wu Ching-mao, and Tsai Ming-chieh, another brother of Tsai Mei-li.
Those not in custody have been barred from leaving the country.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said that according to the 2003 rules on operating procedures for use of secret funds from state affairs fund, the fund must be sent to a special account before they can be used and then justified by a formal document reporting on the purpose of the expenditure.

The prosecutors found, however, that while Lin and Chen Chen-hui had claimed secret expenses -- half of the "state affairs fund" available to the Presidential Office each month -- they did not provide documents to explain their purpose.

The prosecutors raided Chen Shui-bian and Chen Chen-hui's residences Aug. 16 and Sept. 25, seizing several disks from Chen Chen-hui's residence in which computer files of the use of each secret fund use was recorded.

Chen Chen-hui reportedly admitted that some secret funds were used by the former first lady for personal use and some of the funds were wired to Wu Ching-mao's overseas bank accounts on Wu Shu-jen's instructions.

Prosecutors said that Lin, while serving as Chen Shui-bian's chief secretary, handled all the claims and expenditures of the secret portion of the "state affairs fund, " and should have first-hand knowledge of Wu Shu-jen's use of the fund.
