The congressional members said they find it unacceptable that the State Department is turning what should be a technical note into a specific policy and demanded a clear explanation from Rice on the decision.
They urged the State Department to remove the new language and restore the original version used prior to 2007.

The letter was signed by Shelley Berkley (D-Nev.), Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), Dan Burton (R-Ind.), Scott Garrett (R-N.J.), Eliot Engel (D-N.Y.), Thaddeus McCotter (R-Mich.), Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) and Linda Sanchez (D-Calif.).
The State Department has outlined various restrictions for dealing with Taiwan since Washington switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

The restrictions include that meetings between U.S. and Taiwanese officials must not take place in State Department buildings, the White House or the Old Executive Office Building; and that executive branch personnel are not permitted to attend functions held at the Washington residence of Taiwan's representative to the United States.

Regarding official references to Taiwan, U.S. executive branch officials are not permitted to refer to Taiwan's government as a "government." Instead, the term "Taiwan authorities" must be used. The guidelines also restrict executive branch personnel from referring to the people of Taiwan as "Taiwanese" but require them instead to refer to the population as the "people on Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taipei marks Confucius anniversary

TEXT.P: The Taipei Confucian Temple held a rite Sunday to mark the 2,558th anniversary of the birth of Confucius (551-479 BC) -- the most revered philosopher and educator in Chinese history.

President Ma Ying-jeou burned incense, delivered a eulogy and presented an inscribed board in praise of Confucius during the rite, marking the first time since Taiwan's retrocession from Japanese rule in 1945 that a head of state has attended a ceremonial ritual at the Confucian Temple to mark the anniversary of the ancient Chinese sage's birth.
The rite, which began at 5 a.m., was presided over by Taipei Mayor Hau lung-bin, with Kung Chuei-chang, the 79th lineal descendant of Confucius, serving as the "sacrificial official" of the rite.

An adapted version of the classic eight-row ceremonial dance, known as the Bayi Dance, was performed by 64 schoolchildren in tribute to the sage. In the past, a smaller-scale six-row ceremonial dance has been held to mark the occasion.
A grandiose feast of 193 courses, including dried peach and prune, bamboo shoots and goose, was offered as a sacrifice at the ritual.

The Taipei city government had postponed the Confucius birthday ritual by one week from Sept. 29 -- which is also Teacher's Day -- to Oct. 5 because of Typhoon Jangmi, which deluged the country on that day.

In 1952, the Republic of China government designated Confucius' birthday as Teachers' Day in recognition of his great achievements as a teacher, and Confucian temples around Taiwan hold sacrificial rituals on this day every year in his honor.

Confucius was born Sept. 28, 551 BC in China's state of Lu -- now Shandong Province. His teachings have become the cornerstone of traditional Chinese philosophy and culture and have greatly influenced some other Asian countries in which the Chinese have had influence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Copyright police swoop on DVD copying factory in northern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Copyright police in the city of Chiayi, southern Taiwan, announced Sunday that they had busted an illegal DVD copying factory in the northern county of Taoyuan and had seized 100,000 pirated discs with an estimated value that represents losses to the legal copyright holders of NT$10 billion (US$310.95 million).

Wu Chuan-hao, leader of the Chiayi unit of the Intellectual Property Protection Brigade under the Taiwan Provincial Police Administration, told a press conference that about six months ago, officers of his unit discovered a Web site offering the pirated products.

The goods offered for sale on the Web site included a wide variety of software systems usually bundled on a single disc under the name "instant noodles," as well as pirated movies and pornographic films.
According to Wu, the unit's investigation identified the mastermind behind the piracy operation as a man surnamed Chen, who had the Web site hosted by a server in China.

Chen would take orders in China through the Internet and then refer the orders, along with the illegally copied software, to his two accomplices in Taiwan -- Tsai Chih-dong and Lin Dong-hua, both aged 27 -- who would copy the ordered DVDs and then use delivery services to send them to customers at prices ranging from NT$100 to NT$300 per disc.
Wu said his unit placed the DVD copying factory under surveillance for nearly six months before deciding it was time to take action.
"With a warrant issued by the Taoyuan Public Prosecutors Office, we searched the factory at Hsinwu township in Taoyuan County and seized 50 DVD burner machines along with the discs," he said.
According to Wu, the Web site has been in operation for three years, with turnover exceeding NT$1 million each month.
The two suspects being questioned will face charges for violation of the Copyright Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan international airports drop in world rankings

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two main international airports experienced drops in world rankings in both passenger and cargo volume in 2007, according to a report released Saturday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport ranked 15th among 877 airports in the world in terms of cargo transport volume in 2007, down two notches from the previous year, the report shows.
In the Asia-Pacific region, the airport ranked 6th among 136 in cargo volume in 2007, the same as 2006, while Kaohsiung International Airport was placed 40th, down one notch from 2006.

In terms of passenger volume in the region, Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport ranked 14th in 2007, slipping one place from 2006, while the Kaohsiung airport ranked 45th in 2007, down eight places from 2006, the report reveals.
The ministry's Institute of Transportation warned in the report that while airports in neighboring countries registered growth in cargo volume in 2007, Taiwan's two main airports suffered a decline.

The institute noted that in 2007, both Beijing Capital International Airport and Shanghai Pudong International Airport saw growth of more than 15 percent in cargo volume, while cargo volume at Seoul's Incheon International Airport increased 9.4 percent.
In contrast, Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport experienced a 5.5 percent dip and Kaohsiung International Airport saw an 8.8 percent drop in cargo volume.
The total volume of cargo handled at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport totalled 1.61 million tons for the year.

The institute suggested that Taiwan's airports should enhance their competitiveness in cargo handling by improving logistics, lowering operating costs, increasing flight destinations and adopting effective logistics strategies.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) attributed the drop in cargo volume to the overall economic situation and the drop in export cargo due to local high-tech companies moving to foreign countries.
It said more cargo shippers also opted to deliver cargo by most cost-efficient sea shipping instead of air transport to cope with surging oil prices.

China's rapidly growing air cargo sector has also had a heavy impact on Taiwan's air cargo industry. Since China signed an agreement on air cargo delivery with the United States in 2004, the number of cargo flights between the two countries has doubled over the past three years, according to the CAA.

To boost the development of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the government is pushing forward a draft "special statute for Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport" that calls for the setting up of an extensive "aviation city" comprising not only the airport but also various economic zones, the CAA noted.
Another report shows that for the first eight months of this year, passenger volume at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport dropped 3.4 percent compared with the same period of last year.

In response, the CAA said it will make it clear whether the decline in passenger traffic is the result of the construction and expansion of airports in the Asia- Pacific region or the expansion of the Chinese air transport market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not open doors to Chinese license-seekers: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that Taiwan will open its doors to Chinese students seeking to pursue advanced studies but will not allow them to sit tests in Taiwan and obtain Taiwanese professional licenses.

Speaking at a national convention on youth policy sponsored by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, Ma said the government's policy of recruiting Chinese students is aimed at making Taiwan's educational environment more liberalized and globalized.
"The policy was espoused 10 years ago by then-Education Minister Wu Jin," Ma noted.
He added that the so-called "opening policy" means that domestic colleges and universities will be allowed to recruit Chinese students but the administration will not push or encourage them to do so.

Noting that China now has over 2,500 colleges and universities, some of which rank among the list of leading universities in the world, Ma said Taiwan will leave itself a "laughing stock" if it continues to close its doors and turn its back on world opinion.
On the viewpoint that such opening will "bring about unlimited business opportunities to the country, " Ma denied that this is the purpose of the government policy.

"The first and foremost purpose of allowing Chinese students to study in Taiwan is to help young men and women from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to better know each other, eventually helping normalize cross-strait relations," Ma said.
"Secondly, it will help Taiwan recruit top-notch Chinese students to spur Taiwan students' competitiveness," he added.

"The other purpose of the opening policy is that it will probably help solve the problems facing privately run colleges and universities because of increasingly declining enrollment rates, " he predicted.

Ma added, however, that the country will not allow Chinese citizens to sit tests in Taiwan for professional licenses on the grounds that only people who are Republic of China nationals are allowed to sit such tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman has no plans to run for Taipei magistrate

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Sunday that she has no plans to run for the post of Taipei County magistrate in late 2009.
Tsai made the remarks while responding to questions from reporters during a beach cleanup along the banks of the Danshui River in Bali township, Taipei County.
The cleanup took place as part of a series of programs to celebrate the DPP's 22nd founding anniversary, which had been postponed for one week because of Typhoon Jangmi.

Tsai, who took over the helm of the DPP in May after the party lost the presidential election and became an opposition party, is considered a rising star and the DPP's best hope. Several DPP councilors on the Taipei County Council have urged Tsai to run for county magistrate next year.

Former Premier Su Tseng-chang, who served as Taipei magistrate for two terms from 1996 to 2004, said he would respect Tsai's wishes but reminded her that, as party chairwoman, she has a responsibility to field heavy hitters from the party for the 2009 mayoral and county magistrate elections.

Asked to comment on former President Chen Shui-bian's speaking tour of Taiwan in which he is claiming innocence over alleged corruption and money laundering charges against himself and his family, Tsai said she can "understand Chen's feelings as a person facing imminent judicial proceedings."
But she added that "although DPP members are still emotionally attached to him, they do know clearly what is right and what is wrong."
On her plans for the party, Tsai said the biggest challenge is finding ways to restore the people's confidence in the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses' work, living rights to be improved gradually

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy planner said Sunday in response to an outcry over the rights of Chinese spouses of Taiwanese people to work and stay in Taiwan that the issue will be tackled step-by-step.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) attaches great importance to the rights and interests of the Chinese spouses of local citizens, whose numbers are close to 300,000, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said during a symposium sponsored by the Cross-Strait Marriage Consultation and Enhancement Association, a private organization.

Lai said the council is taking a three-pronged approach to safeguard the rights and interests of Chinese spouses -- they will be welcome to enter Taiwan if they are genuine and legal; cases involving Chinese women entering Taiwan under the guise of a bogus marriage will be cracked down; and the council will spare no efforts to protect the rights and interests of genuine Taiwanese-Chinese couples.

As for the Chinese spouses' rights to work and the period they are allowed to remain in Taiwan, Lai said any change to the regulations will be up to amendments to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
"It will be tackled step-by-step, as other coping measures will also be needed," she added.

Meanwhile, she went on, the number of new cross-strait marriages registered in Taiwan has declined over the past two years -- down from 39,000 in 2003 to slightly over 10,000 in 2007 and 2006 -- mainly as a result of a crackdown on marriages of convenience and marriage brokers.
Lai forecast that marriages between people who actually know and love each other will be the mainstay of cross-strait marriages in the future.

Chinese spouses are also expected to have different requirements from now, she continued, predicting that the wives of Taiwanese citizens working in China will likely demand long-term multiple entry and exit permits instead of seeking longer periods of leave to remain.

At a meeting with representatives of the Cross-Strait Marriage Consultation and Enhancement Association July 16, Lai said the MAC intended to repeal what it sees as unjust regulations governing Chinese spouses that were put in place over the past four years by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, including a requirement that they provide documented proof of financial solvency when applying for a Taiwan identity card.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expects direct links to make Kaohsiung Harbor boom

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday during a tour of Kaohsiung Harbor that the harbor's competitiveness is expected to be boosted after it is opened for direct sea transport across the Taiwan Strait.
He said that once the direct shipping links are established, international merchant ships will not need to sail via third places, which will help enterprises cut transport costs.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with businessmen to listen to their opinions on enhancing Kaohsiung Harbor's competitiveness in light of the dwindling cargo throughput of the port over the past few years.

Lu Feng-hai, chairman of Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., suggested that the government should build another cross-harbor tunnel to Cijin, a cross-harbor bridge and access roads to the harbor, to relieve traffic between the area and Cijin and enhance the efficiency of cargo delivery at the harbor.
Ma ordered the harbor administration to take Lu's advice into account in its plans.
The president also cited a recent report that Kaohsiung Harbor has slipped to only the world's sixth-busiest container port after Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Busan and Shenzhen.
He added that the harbor's ranking is expected to slide further as it is likely to be overtaken by Dubai and Rotterdam.

Expressing concern over the drop in ranking from third to sixth, Ma expressed hope that the volume of shipping cargo handled at the harbor will substantially increase after direct cross-strait shipping comes into practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Change stated house sizes to reflect reality: consumers' group

TEXT.P: The registered size of houses should be limited to private enclosed areas, a consumers group said Sunday, urging the government to change the registration system to "give consumers better protection."

Lin Wang-gen, an official of the non-profit Consumers' Foundation, told a news conference that nearly 20 percent of the advertised area of apartments sold in 38 building surveyed in Taipei by his foundation was common space, balcony space or covered rooftop space.
This space, which Lin described as "fictitious space, " also includes elevator wells, machinery rooms, public corridors, public recreation halls, water tanks and air conditioner rooms.
"These areas are not living spaces used exclusively by the owners, but are registered on official documents as part of the houses and are sold as such to the buyers." Lin said.

In some of the surveyed buildings, the "fictitious space" accounts for up to 66.01 percent of the advertised space of the houses for sale, meaning that buyers have to pay for more than they can actually use, Lin said.

Almost all of the 38 buildings inspected have balconies and canopies which cannot be used as living space but those two parts made up an average of 19.84 percent of the houses' nominal size, Lin went on.

In addition to warning potential house buyers to watch out for this unusable space, Lin urged the government to crack down on what he described as a "dishonest practice" employed by most house builders by excluding at least balcony and canopies from the registered size of houses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to establish culture, tourism ministry: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou told a youth meeting Sunday that the government is working toward the establishment of a culture and tourism ministry to better promote cultural innovation and tourism.

Ma noted that the government raised the education, science and culture budget to NT$343 billion in its 2009 general budget proposal, representing 18.7 percent of the total budget, which he said is proof that the administration considers the issue to be of great importance.

Saying that the budget allocated to the ministry will also be greater than that allocated to the existing Council for Cultural Affairs, Ma added that promoting domestic tourism is part of the government's flagship plans to spur the development of the country's service industry.

The president pointed out that 3.71 million visitors came to Taiwan last year, while Taiwan tourists made more than 8.67 million overseas visits during the same period. The figures mean that "we still have ample room to improve in this area, " he said.

Adding that granting free-visa privileges is a measure that can be taken into consideration, Ma also said the central government will provide funding for local governments to boost the development of the tourism industry on a step-by- step and longstanding basis.

The government policy "calls for creativity and promotional efforts to increase Taiwan's visibility and attract more tourists, " he went on, adding that cultural and artistic activities are also a principal aspect of Taiwan's tourism industry.
The president also said traditional Taiwanese opera will not fade away as it has taken root in Taiwan, given that many elementary schools provide courses in local theatrical opera.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP leader to be absent from National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will not attend Oct. 10 National Day celebrations to be staged in front of the Presidential Office, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is the leading organizer of the celebrations, said Sunday.
Wang said he had been told by Tsai that she will not attend the celebrations, the first one under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Much as he was disappointment at Tsai's decision, the speaker said, he can understand it in light of the not very amicable atmosphere between the DPP and the KMT.

Wang was referring to a scuffle between the lawmakers of DPP and KMT at the legislature Oct. 3 over health minister Yeh Ching-chuan's option to attend a news conference organized by a KMT lawmaker while turning down the DPP request for him to attend a meeting of its caucus.

The government's ongoing investigation of ex-President Chen Shui-bian's alleged money laundering has also raised the eyebrows of many DPP supporters who considered the probe as a political-motivated scheme.
However, Wang took Tsai's refusal in stride, noting that the chief of KMT didn't bother to attend the National Day celebrations during the DPP's eight-year rule before 2008.
Chen Shui-bian, who was engulfed by the money-laundering scandal, won't attend the celebration, nor would former President Lee Teng-hui, Wang said.

The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Monday, moving down 175.67 points at 5,566.56 on a turnover of NT$2.29 billion (US$71.15 million).
The weighted price index gained 38.51 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 5,742.23 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Monday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.311 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.124 from Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 6, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."
