DOC.HEADLINE: DPP leader to forego National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will not attend the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations to be staged in front of the Presidential Office, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is the chief organizer of the celebrations, said Sunday.
Wang said Tsai has informed him that she will not attend the celebrations, the first to be held under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
Much as he is disappointed at Tsai's decision, the speaker said, it is understandable in light of the not very amicable atmosphere between the DPP and the KMT at this time.

Wang was referring to a scuffle between lawmakers of DPP and KMT at the legislature Oct. 3 over health minister Yeh Ching-chuan's decision to attend a news conference organized by a KMT lawmaker, while turning down a request by the DPP to attend a meeting of its caucus.

The government's ongoing investigation into allegations of money laundering by ex-President Chen Shui-bian has also caused resentment among many DPP supporters who consider the probe a politically motivated scheme.
However, Wang took Tsai's decision in stride, noting that during the DPP's eight years in power the leader of the KMT never bothered to attend National Day celebrations.
Chen Shui-bian, who is engulfed in the money-laundering scandal, will not attend the celebrations, neither will former President Lee Teng-hui, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-chief of Investigation Bureau detained by court

TEXT.P: A former chief of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, Yeh Sheng-mao, was taken into custody Monday by the Taipei District Court, according to the local cable station TVBS.
Yeh was summoned by the court Monday to stand trial for withholding information on the alleged money-laundering activities of ex-President Chen Shui-bian's family.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's largest marine museum set to open Tuesday

TEXT.P: The Evergreen Maritime Museum at the Chang Yung-Fa Foundation Building in Taipei City is set to open to the public Tuesday following nearly a decade of planning.
The Evergreen Maritime Museum is the largest of its kind in Taiwan, covering about 10,500 square meters on five floors and featuring over 400 marine artifacts, paintings and nautical instruments.
One of the main attractions of the new museum is sure to be the 360-degree spherical screen display system featuring near real-time meteorological data.

The display screen system was donated by Weathernews Inc., the world's leading meteorological company, to Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa last year in celebration of his 80th birthday. The establishment of the museum has long been one of Chang's dreams.
Visitors to the museum will be able to view maps of pressure systems, ocean currents, water temperatures, storm positions and much more on the display system's 1.5-meter diameter screen.

Besides meteorological data, the display system, with its use of a position polling system and global position system, will allow visitors see the location of Evergreen Marine Corp.'s 88 ships anywhere in the world.

The new museum features five permanent exhibition galleries, including the History of Ships gallery on the fifth floor, the Modern Ships gallery on the fourth floor, the Maritime Taiwan and Marine Paintings galleries on the third floor, the Navigation and Exploration gallery on the second floor, and the Special Exhibition gallery for events featuring exhibits on loan from other international collections.
Regular admission to the museum will be NT$200, with a discounted price of NT$150 for students and seniors. To celebrate the museum's opening, all prices will be reduced to NT$100 until Oct. 17.
All proceeds from ticket sales will go toward funding the Chang Yung-Fa Foundation's various charitable programs.
The museum will be open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. from Tuesday to Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Rules on Chinese spouses' working rights should be relaxed: CLA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official said Monday that the regulations governing the working rights of Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals should be relaxed if the country is determined to treat this group of people fairly.

Wang Ju-hsuan, minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said that since Chinese spouses of local citizens are daughters-in-law of Taiwanese elders and mothers of Taiwanese children, they should be granted the same rights as people from other countries who are married to Taiwan nationals. This means that Chinese spouses should be able to obtain work permits immediately after they are granted resident status, she said.
Speaking to the media at the Legislative Yuan, Wang said a relaxation of the work restrictions has long been sought by social activits and Chinese spouses.
Under the current regulations, Chinese spouses have to wait at least six years after marriage before they can obtain permission to work in Taiwan.

Noting that any change to the regulations will require amending the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Wang said she believes the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang will support the amendments. She further noted that the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party has not opposed the proposal too strongly.
Wang promised that once the Mainland Affairs Council -- the country's top China policy coordinating body -- approves the amended policy, the CLA will follow.

Addressing concerns that the proposed amendement may have an adverse impact on job opportunities for Taiwan nationals, Wang said she is not particularly worried about that, given that currently only about 20,000-odd Chinese spouses, of the total 300,000, will be qualified to work in Taiwan.

Besides, she added, most of the Chinese spouses currently working in Taiwan are employed as caregivers or in the service sector at businesses such as restaurants -- jobs that most Taiwanese people would not take.

DOC.HEADLINE: Middle-age workers hit by employment crisis: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty-two percent of middle-age workers are concerned about a possible employment crisis as an economic slowdown has led to sluggish business, according to the results of a survey released Monday by an online employment broker.

The survey conducted by 1111 Job Bank found that many workers have started to feel the impact, with 46.21 percent of respondents saying their employers have announced a workforce reduction, 30.68 percent having seen a change in their job content or labor conditions, and 26.45 percent having experienced a cancellation or change in their benefits.

While only 12.15 percent of respondents expressed confidence that it was "absolutely impossible" for them to become a victim of involuntary unemployment, 17.41 percent said it was "very possible, " and 9.47 percent said such a scenario was "imminent."

The problems that middle-age workers worry about most, in the event that they lose their jobs, are their financial status, difficulty finding a new job, and the small number of middle- and high-level positions available.

Conscious of the difficulty middle-age workers find in changing jobs, 36.36 percent of respondents wanted to retain their current positions until retirement. The other two major reasons mentioned by the respondents were satisfaction with their current pay and benefits and fear of change.
The workers who most wish to stay in their currents jobs until retirement age are from the government, education, medical and health care, agricultural, industrial and commercial service sectors.

Meanwhile, 42.11 percent of the businesses surveyed said their inclination to hire workers aged 35-45 has grown following a 2007 amendment to the Employment Services Act that banned employment discrimination based on age.
However, on average, businesses still set an age limit of 38 for candidates applying for non-supervisory positions, with 45.9 percent of businesses setting the ceiling at 35.
On average, workers aged 35-45 accounted for 31.38 percent of the staff of the surveyed businesses, with 55.85 percent of businesses having no more than 30 percent of workers in that age group.
While 48.17 percent of businesses are accepting middle-age workers, 7.31 percent are shutting out this age group completely, according to the survey.

The reasons behind the reluctance to hire middle-age workers include less flexibility among people in this group, the high personnel costs involved, the disinclination among these workers to accept changes, their difficulty fitting into new teams, and their unwillingness to cooperate.

Despite these shortcomings among middle-age workers, many businesses said they recognized that people in this age group have advantages, such as professional experience, low likelihood of quitting and excellent ability to deal with stress.
The survey found that the positions that businesses think are the most suitable for middle-age workers are related to sales, finance, accounting, and production.
The survey was conducted between Sept. 19 and Oct. 2 among 1,235 workers aged 30-45 and 342 business owners and human resources managers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU urged to enhance trade with Taiwan

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) called on the European Union Monday to enhance trade with Taiwan, saying that this would boost not only the EU's export and production, but also its competitiveness in Asia.

The call came after Copenhagen Economics, a highly reputable international consultancy hired in January by the ECCT, released at an EU-Taiwan economic forum in Taipei a report that examines the economic merits of EU-Taiwan trade enhancement measures (TEMs) in the context of the EU Trade Commissioner's strategic objectives in the Asian region.

The EU Trade Commissioner launched a "Global Europe" strategy in 2006 to underline the importance of gaining market access to the growing Asian markets. So far, agreements with the Republic of Korea, India and the Association for Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are on the agenda.

In his opening address at the forum, ECCT Chairman Philippe Pellegrin said the chamber has called on the governments of both Taiwan and the EU to begin talks on TEMs -- similar to free trade agreements (FTAs) -- as they will serve to increase bilateral trade between Taiwan and the EU annually by billions of euros.

Concurring with Pellegrin, Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Executive YuanCouncil of Economic Planning and Development, said that while the ultimate goal in strengthening EU-TW economic relations is the signing of an FTA, "the bilateral trade of the two economies can be enhanced, in the short term, by alternatives such as a mutual recognition arrangement (MRA) or trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA)."
Martin Thelle, a partner at Copenhagen Economics and the author of the report, said in his presentation at the forum that TEMs can greatly benefit the EU and Taiwan.
"The EU should consider saying 'yes' if Taiwan expressed interest in initiating discussions on ambitious TEMs, as the economic impacts of trade enhancement are considerable," Thelle said.

It is estimated that enhancing trade with Taiwan can boost European GDP by up to 2 billion euros per year, expanding the output of European producers and creating more jobs in Europe, according to Thelle. Taiwan's GDP in turn will be increased by an estimated 3.8 billion euros, he added.

"In the longer term, openness to trade with economies like Taiwan and South Korea will give an additional boost to the European economy," Thelle said, adding that Copenhagen Economics assessed that the strategic opportunities for European firms are larger in Taiwan than in Korea.
"The main reason is Taiwan's close economic integration with mainland China," he said. "Taiwan is a bridgehead to China."

Although some may fear that China may react negatively to potential trade enhancement measures between Taiwan and the EU, Thelle said, his analysis shows that China's economy would be, in fact, slightly positively affected by any trade enhancement between the EU and Taiwan.

"Certainly China's exports to Europe will face more direct competition from Taiwan's exporters, but the growth of the Taiwanese economy as a result of trade enhancement measures with the EU will benefit China, and this latter effect will dominate," he said.
In addition, China will benefit significantly from the removal of the Taiwan- imposed restrictions on trade and investment across the Taiwan Strait, according to Thelle.
The forum, held by the ECCT and sponsored by the HSBC, attracted government officials, foreign diplomats and representatives in Taiwan as well as businessmen and academic experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Establishment of sovereign wealth fund would require new law: CBC

TEXT.P: If Taiwan opts for the establishment of a sovereign wealth fund (SWF) , this should be done independent of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) and under new legislation, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said Monday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Perng said the existing Four Major Funds and the National Development Fund run by the administration are all SWFs in nature since they are all state-owned investment funds.
"The best policy here and now is to integrate the Four Major Funds and the National Development Fund into a bigger one, instead of establishing a new SWF," Perng said.
In response to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao's question on whether the CBC favors the way that Singapore established its SWF, Perng said, "the Singaporean model is a good one to emulate."

He added that before establishing its SWF, Singapore first enacted a relevant statute. The Singaporean government then established a SWF with funds raised via the issuance of state bonds and in turn used the SWF to invest overseas, he said.
The CBC governor added that both the establishment of SWFs and overseas investment of the funds should be in line with International Monetary Fund (IMF) regulations.

Perng dismissed as groundless a recent report by the Taipei-based China Times, which alleged that, when asked his opinion on the subject, he categorically ruled out using the country's foreign exchange reserves to establish a new SWF.

DOC.HEADLINE: Failure to act on sexual harassment may incur higher fines

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan completed Monday a preliminary review of a proposed amendment to the Gender Equality in Employment Act that would raise the punishment for employers who fail to take action to prevent or correct sexual harassment in the workplace.

The law requires employers hiring over 30 employees to establish measures for sexual harassment prevention and rules on the handling of complaints about and punishment for sexual harassment. Employers are required to openly display such measures and rules in offices and take immediate and effective correctional and remedial measures when they know of an incidence of sexual harassment.

While the maximum fine for employers who fail to comply is currently set at NT$100,000 (US$3,096) , the bill clearing the Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Labor Committee would raise the ceiling to NT$500,000.

According to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Pan Wei-kang, a lead sponsor of the bill, sexual harassment in the workplace is a form of gender discrimination that undermines the physical safety of women and "other sexual minorities."
However, compared with the punishments for other forms of gender discrimination, the penalties for sexual harassment are much lower, Pan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Honduran vice foreign minister to arrive in Taiwan Tuesday

TEXT.P: Honduran Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Eduardo Rosales is slated to arrive in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Monday.
Rosales is visiting mainly to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations on Oct. 10, according to the ministry.
During his stay, Rosales will receive a medal of honor presented by Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou, the ministry said.
He will also attend a performance staged by Cloud Gate Dance Theatre and is slated to visit the National Palace Museum, the Taipei World Trade Center and the Taipei 101 tower.
Rosales is also scheduled to take the high-speed train to Taichung City to visit several of Taiwan's economic and cultural sites, according to the ministry.
Prior to being appointed vice foreign minister in August of this year, Rosales served in several top diplomatic posts, including minister to Costa Rica and ambassador to Greece.
Honduras is one of 23 countries around the world with which the Republic of China on Taiwan maintains formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many Chinese visitors watch Taiwan political programs: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly 40 percent of mainland Chinese academics and scholars who have visited Taiwan have watched local television political commentary programs, with a large majority of them saying that such programs accommodate the expression of popular sentiments, according to the results of survey released Monday by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

The survey was conducted by the MAC among Chinese citizens visiting Taiwan under cultural and education exchange programs during 2006 and 2007. A total of 926 questionnaires were collected in the survey.

The results showed that 39 percent of visiting Chinese academics have watched television political commentary programs, with 81 percent of that total saying that such programs are an expression of democratic politics and that they are a forum for voicing public opinion.

The survey also found that 77 percent of the visitors have watched Taiwan television news programs, with 87 percent of those who watched saying that the local programs are much livelier than those aired in China.

As for what aspects of Taiwan made the deepest impression on the visitors, matters related to society were most often mentioned, a total of 1,123 times, followed by matters related to the economy, 364 times, and politics, 201 times.
The aspects of Taiwan's society that most impressed the visitors were the people's tolerance and their friendliness as well as the various public welfare organizations, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA contracts with private enterprises aim to achieve 'zero waste'

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has contracted private businesses to recycle all kinds of kitchen waste, including some types not on the current list of recyclables, the agency said in a statement Monday.

The contracts are part of the EPA's efforts to achieve the long-existing goal of "zero kitchen waste, " the statement said. To meet this goal, in 2001, a set of step-by-step measures were formulated, beginning with the collection of kitchen leftovers that can be recycled to feed pigs.

In 2006, the first stage of the recycling program was adopted by all 319 townships around the country. Today, environmental protection units around Taiwan collect approximately 2,000 tons of kitchen waste daily, according to the EPA statement.
That volume is equivalent to the treatment capacity of two 900-ton garbage incinerators, the EPA department of environmental supervision affairs said.
Currently, moist kitchen waste is recycled by being cooked or steamed at high temperatures before being made into fertilizer or animal feed.
According to the EPA department, around 75 percent of recycled waste goes into making hog feed, 24 percent into fertilizers and one percent into dried feed for chickens.

However, there are still many types of organic kitchen leftovers not listed as recyclable, the department said, These include the skins of pomelos, bananas, pineapples and sugar canes, as well as mango seeds, coconut husks, clam shells, lobster shells, meat bones, all kinds of nut shells, weeds, wilted flowers and tree branches, it added.
Currently those types of waste are still being taken to incinerators, along with other garbage.

The Cabinet-level EPA said it has contracted a private company to recycle organic materials. The company is capable of handling around 2,000 tons of organic leftovers from around Taiwan, the press release said.
This contract model will be further expanded to allow the EPA to reach its goal of zero kitchen waste, while recycling the waste into useful resources, the EPA stated.
According to EPA research, household garbage in Taiwan includes between 20 percent and 30 percent of kitchen waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices tumble on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged 4.11 percent Monday as an overnight fall on Wall Street sent Asian stock markets tumbling sharply.
The Taiwan exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell 236.53 points to close at 5,505.7.
Suffering a drop from gains of the previous trading day, the local bourse opened at 5,566.56 and fluctuated between 5,590.52 and 5,505.7.
A total of 2.95 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$60.21 billion (US$1.87 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares declining the most at 6.4 percent. Construction issues lost 5.8 percent, textiles dropped 4.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares declined 4.3 percent, cement stocks dropped 3.1 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 3 percent, plastics and chemical shares were down 2.4 percent, and foodstuff issues lost 2.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,486 to 208, with 280 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$14.33 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Patrol vessel sent to maintain order in high seas: COA

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture has dispatched a patrol vessel manned by Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officers to monitor Taiwanese fishing vessels operating on the high seas in the Western and Central Pacific Ocean, an agency official said Monday.
The vessel, Hsunhu No. 1, carries one agency observer and 10 CGA officers on its 89-day mission, the official said.

In addition to maintaining order among Taiwanese vessels, the vessel will also conduct onboard inspections and send the agency's observer to other designated vessels for scientific observation, the official said.
The dispatch of the vessel is in accordance with management measures of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission, of which Taiwan is a member.

Taiwan's responsibility as a member of the international organization is to promote the deployment of monitoring systems on fishing boats, establish a rapid reporting system, and send observers and patrol vessel for observation and inspections, the official said.
The dispatch of the patrol vessel signifies Taiwan's determination to achieve good management in deep-sea fishing, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Honduras deputy foreign minister to attend national day celebrations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that Honduras will send its Deputy Foreign Minister Eduardo Federico Rosales Ramiraz to attend Taiwan's Oct. 10 Double Ten National Day celebrations.

The MOFA said in a press release that Ramirez, along his wife, will arrive in Taiwan Oct. 7. The Republic of China's National Day celebrations will be attended by other foreign dignitaries and envoys, including Guatemala President Alvaro Colom, who is slated to arrive in Taiwan Oct. 7, the MOFA said.

"Ramirez will attend the Double Ten events on behalf of Honduras President Jose Manuel Zelaya, as Zelaya came to Taiwan for President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration ceremony, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said.

Ramirez is also slated to receive a medal from ROC Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, visit economic infrastructure in Taipei and Taichung and attend a number of cultural events, before leaving Taiwan on Oct. 11, according to the Foreign Ministry.
Ramirez, who once served as Honduras ambassador to Costa Rica and Greece, was appointed as deputy foreign minister by Zelaya in August.
Honduras, one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies, forged diplomatic ties with the country in 1941.

A series of concerts, and other festivities, including a parade and a fireworks show, will be held around Taiwan to mark the 97th National Day of the ROC on Oct. 10. A record-breaking 10,000 Taiwanese expatriates are expected to return to Taiwan for the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.156 to close at NT$32.343.
A total of US$1.101 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.187 and fluctuated between NT$32.140 and NT$32.354.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 256 points to close at 5,387, with 72,476 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 262 points to finish at 5,362, with 728 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 250 points to close at 5,359, with 45 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 244 points to finish at 5,345, with nine contract transactions, while June futures were down 249 points to close at 5,336, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,643 for October, 5,624 for November, 5,609 for December, 5,589 for March and 5,585 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 236.53 points to finish at 5,505.7, on turnover of NT$60.21 billion (US$1.87 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

October TE futures fell 10.9 points to close at 221.35, with 3,858 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 10.55 points to finish at 220.7, with 32 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 9.15 points to end at 221.2, with four contracts traded. June TE futures lost 6.65 points to end at 222.15, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

October TF futures moved down 46.4 points to close at 617.6, with 2,847 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures were down 46.4 points to finish at 618, with 49 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: 87% of voters prefer Saturday as election day: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty-seven percent of voters polled recently support the country's existing practice in which public office elections are held on a Saturday, according to the results of the survey released Monday by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
The results show that only 7.9 percent of respondents think Saturday is not a convenient day to vote.
In addition, 78.6 percent of the respondents said they are in favor of maintaining the polling period between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m., while 12.9 percent of respondents said the period should be extended.
On the idea of changing election days to Sunday, 57.4 percent of the respondents expressed support and 30.6 percent voiced opposition.
Among the reasons for opposing the idea, the largest number of respondents -- 39.6 percent -- said voting on Sunday would affect their plans for outings or family gatherings.

According to the results, 64 percent of the respondents cast their votes in every election held, 17 percent take part in elections "frequently, " 13 percent "seldom" take part and 4.9 percent never vote.

On the reasons for not voting, 26.7 percent said they are disappointed or unfamiliar with the candidates or their platforms, 26.3 percent said they need to work on election days or are too busy to vote, and 17 percent said they have no interest in or are disappointed by politics.
The survey was conducted July 9-10 among 1,124 people by Taiwan Real Survey Co. for the CEC. It had a margin of error of 2.92 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Common cross-strait view on 'direct flights, direct routes'

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Monday that Taiwan and China share a common view on adopting direct routes for the existing nonstop cross-strait weekend charter flights.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Mao said proposals on the adoption of the shortest possible routes for direct cross-strait weekend charter flights have almost been drafted by the two intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

"Once the new rounds of SEF-ARATS talks take place and details on the matter are worked out, agreements on the opening of direct weekend charter flights via direct routes could be signed by the two sides," a confident Mao said.

"Direct flights via direct routes would help reduce the flying time between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Beijing to two hours and 30 minutes and between Taoyuan and Shanghai to just 67 minutes," Mao said.

In response to a question raised by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ken-teh, Mao agreed that direct flights via direct routes would help save energy and reduce carbon dioxide emissions from a global point of view, but added that the issue involves crucial negotiations across the Taiwan Strait.
Mao said he could not disclose the content of the new SEF proposal and that there is no timetable for the signing of agreements by the SEF and ARATS on the opening of such flights.
He pointed out, however, that relevant agencies, including the Ministry of National Defense, have already given the nod to the content of the proposal.
Historic direct cross-strait weekend charter flights were launched in early July after SEF and ARATS negotiators reached unprecedented agreements in talks in Beijing in June.

All the direct cross-strait weekend charter flights, however, have been flown so far with a detour via the Hong Kong Flight Information Region to symbolize the flights' passage via a "third location."

In their planned new round of talks to be held in Taipei at the end of this month, SEF and ARATS negotiators are expected to focus their discussions on the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes, joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and cross-strait crime-fighting.

Of these topics, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes will in fact address the opening of the shortest-possible cross-strait routes, said Lee Long-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
Lee added that in this regard, both sides have tacit understanding that direct flights via direct routes "could be done, but not to be spelled out" prematurely.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust Chinese yuan counterfeiting ring in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Police uncovered a Chinese banknote counterfeiting operation in southern Taiwan Monday and arrested six suspects, the Third Brigade under the National Police Agency's Criminal Investigation Bureau announced later that day.

A spokesman for the brigade said that a task force of criminal investigation police, military police and police officers from Kaohsiung city and county monitored the activities of the counterfeiting ring for four months before raiding its four operational bases in Kaohsiung and the adjacent counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung simultaneously.

According to the spokesman, police officers seized fake Chinese currency totaling 100 million yuan (US$14.61 million) and sheets of uncut paper currency worth 45 million yuan, along with a wide range of equipment.

The criminal ring used a house in a remote mountainous area of Kaohsiung County's Daliao township as its printing factory. In addition to churning out fake Chinese currency, it also counterfeited prepaid toll coupons for Taiwan's freeways, as well as driving licenses.
The task force also seized 3,500 books of fake prepaid freeway toll tickets, each consisting of 100 coupons.

The ringleader and his girlfriend were arrested on the spot. Also arrested were four accomplices, identified as Tsai Chien-shun, Huang Guan-chieh, Hung Ying- tzer and Wang Cheng-hua, the spokesman said.
The six suspects will be charged with offenses relating to currency counterfeiting, as well as offenses relating to the counterfeiting of valuable securities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE: recognition of Chinese diplomas still under review

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng revealed guidelines Monday concerning Chinese students studying for diplomas in Taiwan that say a national quota will be imposed, as well as enrollment ceilings in universities and departments.
As for the recognition of Chinese diplomas, Cheng said the ministry is still making plans on the issue but noted that it might move up its timeframe.

President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that Taiwan will open its doors to Chinese students pursuing advanced studies but will not allow them to take professional license tests. Ma also said earlier this year that Taiwan will recognize Chinese diplomas in the near future.

The new policies raised concerns from some legislators, who argued at a committee session that the moves are a precursor to allowing Chinese students to take tests for local professional licenses, which may have a negative impact on Taiwan's labor market.

Kuan Bi-ling, a legislator of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , questioned how Cheng can forbid Chinese people from taking tests for professional licenses, since the government is planning to recognize Chinese diplomas and accept Chinese students.

She noted that according to the Professional and Technical Examinations Act and Taiwan's commitment made in 2001 when it joined the World Trade Organization, foreigners are permitted to take tests for 64 professional licenses in Taiwan.

In response, Cheng said that Chinese people should not be considered "simple foreigners, " as Taiwan has a very special relationship with China and there are specific regulations in the framework of the Act Governing Relations Between People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
Another DPP legislator, Lin Shu-fen, accused the government of planning to recognize Chinese diplomas, receive Chinese students and then allowing them to take tests for professional licenses.
@"Opening the door to Chinese students to an appropriate degree can promote exchanges between young people of both sides and will be beneficial to Taiwan in the long run," Cheng said.
At present, the MOE is planning to prolong the maximum study period for Chinese students in Taiwan from four months to one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-chief of Investigation Bureau detained by court (update-1)

TEXT.P: A former chief of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, Yeh Sheng-mao, was taken into custody Monday by the Taipei District Court.

At the the third hearing in his trial for withholding information on alleged money-laundering by ex-President Chen Shui-bian's family, Yeh was questioned by a panel of three judges and was ordered detained after the day's court proceedings.

Chief judge Lee Ying-hao told Yeh that by passing the information to Chen Shui- bian, he may have "unduly profited others, " a felony which gives the court the power to detain potential offenders at its discretion.
Citing concerns that Yeh could collude with others to offer false testimony, the judge ordered Yeh's detention, to the surprise of the former Investigation Bureau chief.
Yeh was indicted on Aug. 28 for concealing and not investigated information on overseas bank accounts held by Chen Shui-bian's family members in the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean.
The information was provided to the Investigation Bureau by international anti- money laundering association Egmont Group on Jan. 28. but went missing after being submitted to Yeh.
Yeh admitted on Sept. 2 that he handed the information to Chen in February while Chen was still serving as president.
His confession led prosecutors to bring an extra charge of leaking classified information against him last Friday, paving the way for his detention.

At Monday's trial hearing, the court also heard testimony from two Investigation Bureau officials that the Egmont Group had previously sent a report in Dec. 2006 to the bureau concerning an account held by Chen's daughter-in-law in Jersey in the Channel Islands.

Yeh acknowledged receiving the report and said he provided an outline of its contents to the president, but decided not to investigate further because the intelligence was not concrete enough and the account had been closed in Oct. 2005.
Prosecutors hope to have The investigation into the alleged money laundering of Chen and his family wrapped up by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Arms sales demonstration of U.S. commitment to Taiwan: AIT

TEXT.P: Following the Bush administration's green light to a US$6.4 billion arms sale to Taiwan, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) expressed Monday Washington's support of President Ma Ying-jeou's handling of relations across the Taiwan Strait, as well as bilateral ties between the U.S. and Taiwan.

"This is a significant and tangible demonstration of the commitment of the United States, under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), to provide to Taiwan the defensive weapons that it needs," AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges said in response to reporters' inquires on the Pentagon's recent notification to Congress that it had approved the sales of various defensive weapons systems to Taiwan.
"We appreciate the Ma administration's efforts to reduce tension in the Taiwan Strait and to build on the already excellent ties between the people of Taiwan and the U.S.," he added.

Passed by the U.S. Congress in 1979 after the U.S. switched diplomatic recognition from the Republic of China to the People's Republic of China, the TRA guarantees U.S. defensive arms sales to Taiwan.

The U.S. Defense Department notified Congress Oct. 3 of its approval of a US$6.46 billion arms package, a decision quickly lauded by Ma, who said the announcement "signals an end to the turmoil of the past eight years and the beginning of a new era of safety and peace, as well as of mutual trust between Taiwan and the U.S."

The arms deal includes Apache attack helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, Javelin anti-tank missiles and sea-launched Harpoon missiles, as well as an upgrade of the E-2T aircraft to the Hawkeye 2000 configuration and blank order requisitions for spare parts in support of F-5E/F, C-130H, F-16A/B and Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF) aircraft, along with related support equipment.
However, the approved package does not include the diesel-electric submarines and Black Hawk helicopters that Taiwan is seeking.

In response to the decision, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that rather than hailing the approval of the package as a sign of improved U.S.-Taiwan ties, the Ma administration should be wary of the fact that the package is smaller than expected and be vigilant against the possibility that it is a sign of change in relations between the two countries.

DPP caucus whip Lai Ching-te said the U.S. administration's delay of approval of the arms sale package for so long and only notifying Congress of its decision to give the green light after the regular legislative session had already ended should be viewed as warning signs.
The opposition lawmaker called on Ma's administration not to interpret the approved arms sales package as "a new beginning" but instead as "a new variable" in U.S.-Taiwan ties.

The fact that Hodges' comments -- besides reiterating Washington's commitment under the TRA -- explicitly recognize Ma's efforts in boosting relations with Beijing and Washington, makes it evident that the DPP accusations are unfounded, according to a senior official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lady Mayoress of City of London visits AIDS patients rights group

TEXT.P: Theresa Lewis, lady mayoress of the City of London, visited the Taipei-based Harmony Home Association Monday to express her concern for AIDS patients, the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said in a press release.

Lewis is the wife of City of London Lord Mayor David Lewis, who arrived in Taipei a day earlier to host a seminar titled "Going Global through the Capital Market of the World -London" on Oct. 7 in Taipei.
The lord mayor plays the role of representing, supporting and promoting the businesses, mainly in the financial sector, of the City of London.

Acknowledging the needs of Harmony Home, Lady Mayoress donated two automated beds and one oximeter to the patients of the charity, the BTCO said.She also called on the general public to support Harmony Home and respects the rights of AIDS patients.

The lady mayoress also presented two artworks with her "lotus flower and cherry blossom" design to Harmony Home for auction. The design is painted with special glass paint and then placed in a kiln to fuse the paint onto the glass, the BTCO added.

Accompanying her husband on their trip in Taiwan from Oct. 5-8, the lady mayoress will visit the National Palace Museum and Taipei European School, as well as attend a performance of Taiwan's renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theater.
The BTCO functions as the de facto British embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: No vegetables marketed in Taiwan detected with melamine traces

TEXT.P: No vegetables marketed in Taiwan have been detected to bear traces of melamine contamination, according to the results of recent tests on 112 vegetable samples, Agriculture and Food Agency officials said Monday.
The tests were launched after news reports from China last week said that melamine residue had allegedly been found on some lettuce, tomatoes, mushrooms and potatoes grown in China.
The reports said the residue might have come from the agricultural pesticide cyromazine, which releases melamine as the pesticide naturally dissolves in the soil.
The agency under the Council of Agriculture said in a statement that the test samples ranged from leafy vegetables and cabbages to root vegetables.
In some of the samples, a safe level of cyromazine traces were detected but no traces of melamine, an industrial chemical used to make plastics and fertilizers, the statement said.

The toxic chemical, used by unscrupulous Chinese milk producers to adulterate their baby formula in order to give falsely high protein levels, was blamed last month for the deaths of four infants and the sickening of another 530,000 children in China who were fed with melamine-adulterated infant formula.
The crisis spread to Taiwan and many other countries around the world that import raw materials from China.

It is legal to use cyromazine as a pesticide on vegetables in Taiwan, a local media report said Sunday, citing Fei Wen-chi, deputy director of the Taiwan Agricultural Chemicals and Toxic Substances Research Institute under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Fei said the institute has been taking strict measures to monitor and control the use of the pesticide on local farmland and that based on the institute's regular tests, the level of cyromazine residue has been controlled below between 0.01 ppm (parts per million) and 0.3 ppm -- much lower than the international allowable standard.

The expert urged the public not to worry about the possible natural release of melamine from the pesticide on vegetables, saying such a release is mostly in tiny amounts that can simply washed off by rinsing the vegetables with water.
If consumed, the human body also discharges the chemical through metabolism, she added.
However, she warned that farmers in China might have abused the use of the substance, resulting in unsafe levels of toxic residue.

Meanwhile, the Yunlin County Bureau of Health said Monday that coffee products from the county's Gukeng township -- Taiwan's main coffee-producing area -- were found after testing to be free from melamine.
A total of 45 samples were examined, none of which were found to be contaminated, according to the bureau's report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County promotes bike riding among staffers

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government in southern Taiwan is building shower facilities in its office building for staff members who ride bikes to work, as part of its efforts to promote bicycle riding, Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Monday.

The construction of the shower facilities will be completed by mid-October, and the facilities will provide comfortable spaces for staff members who have sweated all the way to the office to help them start work clean and dry, Su said.
In addition to the shower rooms, the county government will convert parking areas for scooters into 100 spots for people to put their bicycles, Su said.

There will also be another bicycle parking area near the train station in Sinying City, where the county government's offices are located, with land provided for free by a local bus company in support of the county government's efforts, Su noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference opens

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference opened at the Taipei International Convention Center Monday with more than 1,400 industry leaders and business executives from 33 countries participating.

Addressing the conference, President Ma Ying-jeou said now was the best time for local and foreign businesses to invest in Taiwan, as the government is committed to fostering a harmonious domestic society and peaceful exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
He noted that the theme of this year's conference is "new Taiwan, new opportunities" and explained that although Taiwan remains Taiwan, it has a new government.
Since its inauguration May 20, the government has been striving to "steer a new course" for Taiwan's future, the president said.

He said his government has restarted stalled consultations with China and has also eased restrictions on businesses investing in China, raising the investment cap from 40 percent of a company's net worth to 60 percent.
Also, companies that set up their headquarters in Taiwan or subsidiaries of multinational enterprises will not be subject to such restrictions.
The measurers are aimed at creating a better overall investment environment as Taiwan opens up to the rest of the world, he said.
He touted Taiwan's advantage of having a high quality work force, with one quarter of its population receiving college or university educations or above.
Taiwan also enjoys a superb geographic location, as well as close ties with major economies such as the United States, Japan and China.

He said the government has launched a "12 i-Taiwan major infrastructure project" program, with the "i" standing for the Chinese word for "love, " as well as connoting investment in Taiwan, its renowned IT industry, intelligent and international. He added that investors are welcome to invest in these projects.
The president said the government is capable of making Taiwan a global innovation center and of developing a sound, high quality economy.
He later presented the Best Investment Partner Awards to nine foreign companies for their contributions to the local economy.

The nine recipients were Asahi Glass Co., American International Group, Citi Taiwan, Corning Display Technologies Taiwan, Dai Nippon Printing Co., Elpida Memory, Kingston Technology Company, Nissan Motor Co. and Texas Instruments.

In the first forum on Global Investment Perspectives & Taiwan's Emerging Opportunities, Vice President Vincent Siew said Taiwan has weathered many economic difficulties and Asian financial crises and is determined to turn challenges into opportunities and turn the island an "unsinkable ship."

He also highlighted the warmer cross-strait relations and measures to upgrade the nation's competitive edge, including a series of deregulation steps, tax reforms, the 12 major infrastructure projects and the recruitment of talent from abroad to revitalize the economy.

Richard McCormack, vice chairman of Merrill Lynch & Co., gave his views on the global financial crisis, noting that after the 1997 Asian financial crisis, interest rates were kept too low for too long, turning "a good idea into a bad one."
The same thing happened with the current U.S. housing crisis, and the bubble burst again because of extremely low interest rates, he said.
McCormack said there should be enhanced supervision of banks, as well as measures to keep the financial market stable by making it more transparent.
He also urged the public to remain optimistic, quoting Warren Buffet's words, "Be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful."

Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming noted that since 2003 when the first Taiwan Business Alliance Conference was held, it has become an excellent platform for decision makers, industry leaders and venture capital/fund managers to explore Taiwan's investment potential and opportunities.

Now in its sixth year, Yiin said, the conference has more to offer the participants than ever as Taiwan opens its doors to new links and new connections across the Taiwan Strait, adding that the number of this year's participants is greater than in previous years.

This year's conference also has Chinese business leaders taking part for the first time. With the government easing restrictions on trade relations with China, the integration of cross-strait resources and resulting potential trade opportunities have been included in the panel discussions.
More information about the conference is available at http://investintaiwan.nat.gov.tw/en/

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must find ways to capitalize on China's growth: experts

TEXT.P: China will provide opportunities for many countries around the world as it continues to grow, but Taiwan, which stands to gain substantially from the mainland's economic expansion, must determine how to leverage its advantages, a panel of experts said Monday.

Eizo Kobayshi, president and CEO of Japanese firm ITOCHU Corporation, said speculation of a slowdown in China's economy following the end of the 2008 Beijing Olympics will be proven wrong, as the Beijing economy comprises only around 4 percent of China's total GDP.
He and others were speaking at a panel discussion titled "Leveraging Cross- Strait Resources for Global Marketsat the 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, which runs from Oct. 6-8.

In the current global financial and credit crisis, China has offered a sanctuary, as the mainland has emerged to become a large market that's comparable to the European Union and United States markets, with a substantial contribution to global GDP, said Jeffrey Wong, managing partner at McKinsey & Company.

If the Chinese economy continues to grow, it will become a counteracting force in the global economy, said Wong, a Singapore native.We believe as long as the Chinese economy continues to grow, then this will be good news to support the growth of the Asia-Pacific region.

Taiwan stands to gain significantly from Chinas growth, with its proximity to mainland China and its similar language as well as long history, deep involvement and wealth of experience investing in the mainland.
In the next 20 years, there will be 20 megacities developing in China, with annual per capital income in each mega city to eventually reach an estimated US$25,000, Wong said.
In developing itself, however, China will face a shortage of talent, an inadequate health care system and challenges on its environment.
These and more are areas where Taiwan can use its expertise to reap rewards from China's growthVnamely by providing value-added services, Wong and others said.
For example, with more direct flights, Taiwan can serve as a niche market in providing medical services to people in China, experts said.

With all this information, wisdom, expertise and insight, I think Taiwan should continue to contribute to the mainland Chinese economy and it will also help our economy, said Theodore Huang, chairman of the Taiwan-based TECO Group.
But the challenge for Taiwan is deciding what kind of relationship it wants with China, experts said.

Theoretically, it should be easier for us than other countries, but we need to have goals, strategies to come up with (relevant) government measures, said the panel's moderator P.K. Chiang, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, which is responsible for negotiations with China in the absence of government to government relations.

As China becomes more integrated with the global economy and as its system becomes more transparent, however, problems in China will become much more obvious, such as the recent food crisis over poisoned milk powder, according to experts.
This has done a big blow to China's manufacturing interests, said Kobayashi, citing global consumerswariness about Chinese products as a result of the scandal.
Huang said:Looking forward, we believe China, in the process of opening up, will see more and more such issues.
Again, Taiwan can benefit by being of service to China in these areas, as it has also learned from similar problems in the past, according to experts.
Taiwan and China can complement each other very well, Chiang said.
More information about the conference is available at http://investintaiwan.nat.gov.tw/en/

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung's crime rate on the rise: statistics

TEXT.P: Two Kaohsiung City councilors expressed concern Monday over the worsening crime situation in the southern port city and urged police to step up their efforts to curb the trend.

At an interpellation session of the city council, Lien Li-chien, a councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , quoted statistics compiled by the city government's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics as showing that Kaohsiung recorded a crime rate of 239 cases per 100,000 people in August -- the highest since March 2006.
The crime rate for August exceeded July's 207 cases per 100,000 people, as well as the 211 cases for August last year.
In terms of the city's offender rate, 143 out of every 100,000 people committed criminal offenses during August, up 22 percent from July and 16 percent from August last year.

Citing examples to describe the city's worsening public order, Lien said the neighborhood around the rapid transit system's Aozihdi Station in Gushan District alone saw seven criminal cases in the past month, including gold necklaces being snatched from around women's necks and car break-ins.
Another DPP city councilor, Lin Ying-jung, said she had been robbed in the city.

"My car was broken into and my belongings were stolen, but to date the case still remains unresolved," Lin said. "I believe the city's real crime rate could be even higher, because some of the criminal cases were not officially recorded."
Kaohsiung Police Bureau Director-General Tsai Chun-chang said his men had worked hard during the summer to fight all sorts of crimes, including drunken driving, drug pushing and substance abuse.

Tsai admitted that some police officers might have tried to keep the crime statistics down by not recording reported cases properly. He assured the city councilors that any police officers caught doing this will be severely punished.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 southern Taiwan cities, counties opposed to adopting Hanyu Pinyin

TEXT.P: Chiefs of seven local governments in southern Taiwan said Monday they oppose the central government's decision to use Hanyu Pinyin, the world's most common Mandarin romanization system, on all public signs around the country.

Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen and Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen -- all from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- released a joint statement to voice their opposition.

They contended that romanizing Mandarin should follow the principles of simplicity, consistency, and being easy for users to understand, and that any system used should not be chosen for political purposes or have political overtones, the statement said.
The statement also said that the new measure will not only cause confusion over English on signs around the country, but also come at a high price tag.

A preliminary assessment of the total cost for the seven cities and counties to convert their public signs to Hanyu Pinyin found the bill would total NT$500 million (US$15.44 million) , the statement said.
Taiwan's government adopted the Tongyong Pinyin system under the previous Democratic Progressive Party government. It was developed by a Taiwanese and is only employed in the country.

The DPP administration was criticized for selecting the Tongyong Pinyin romanization system for political and ideological reasons and of ignoring the commonly used Hanyu Pinyin system mainly because it originated and his used in China.
The Executive Yuan under the new Ma Ying-Jeou administration recently decided, however, to change the standard to Hanyu Pinyin to bring Taiwan in line with international standards.
The system was developed in China in the late 1950s and was later adopted as the international romanization standard in the late 1970s and early 1980s, leading to its widespread use around the world.

The government's new policy was quickly challenged by the DPP-run Kaohsiung City government, which said it had only recently changed most of town's signage to Tongyong Pinyin and did not want to spend the estimated NT$213 million to convert city signs again, this time to Hanyu Pinyin.

The city administration said it had spent a lot of money over the past two years in making romanization on signs more consistent as part of its efforts to build an international English language environment.

It further argued that the central government's policy will cause confusion among romanization systems around the country at a time when the 2009 World Games, to take place in Kaohsiung next July, are quickly approaching.

Around 5,000 foreign athletes and relevant personnel will come to Taiwan for the games and could face possible chaos caused by the co-existence of the two different romanization systems, city officials said.
Therefore, they said, representatives from the seven cities and counties will attend a planned meeting hosted by the Ministry of Education to voice their opposition to the new policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: September CPI growth lowest in 8 months: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) rose 3.09 percent year-on-year in September, the lowest annualized rise in the the past eight months, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Monday.

September's CPI also fell 0.6 percent from the level in August, thanks to lower prices for fuel cost and food, which decreased by 8.16 percent and 0.57 percent compared to a month earlier, according to DGBAS section chief Wu Chao-ming.
The core CPI, which excludes the prices of energy, fresh vegetables, fruit, and seafood, also fell by 0.13 percent compared to August, Wu said.

The wholesale price index (WPI) for September rose 6.64 percent year-on-year, the lowest annualized growth rate since June, Wu said, adding that the index actually fell 1.42 percent compared to August, another indication that price inflation was easing, Wu said.

Taiwan's monthly CPI, which registered 106.39 in September, hit its peak in July at 106.88, the highest since in October 1994, Wu said. Global inflation also hit its peak in July according to economic forecaster Global Insight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait food safety liaison windows formalized

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have formally established a direct communications mechanism for food safety-related issues, the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Monday in a statement.

Under the mechanism, two major commodity inspection and food safety control agencies on each side have been designated as channels for direct communication and real-time reporting whenever any major food poisoning case is reported, the SEF statement said.

From now on, the statement said, the Bureau of Food Safety under Taiwan's Department of Health will contact the Health Supervision Bureau under China's Ministry of Health in the event of food safety issues of public concern, and vice versa.

Meanwhile, the statement went on, commodity inspection agencies on the two sides -- the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Import and Export Food Safety Bureau under China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine -- will also forge a similar direct dialogue and communications channel for food safety- related information exchanges, mutual assistance and emergency response.

The two sides reached a preliminary consensus on the establishment of a direct cross-strait communications mechanism to deal with emergency food poisoning cases during a working-level meeting in Beijing in late September.

On Monday, the SEF informed its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- of the Taiwan government's decision to pick its food safety and commodity inspection agencies as its designated liaisons with relevant Chinese authorities.

The SEF said it received a response from the ARATS shortly afterward, saying that the Chinese government also chose its health supervision and commodity inspection agencies to serve as liaison agencies with Taiwan.
By now, the SEF statement said, all the formalities have been completed for the installation of a direct communications mechanism for food safety concerns.
The need to craft direct cross-strait dialogue channels to deal with food safety issues arose after the recent melamine scare.
Melamine, a nitrogen-rich chemical used to make plastics and fertilizers, has been widely used in China to spike watered-down milk to mask the resulting protein deficiency and fool quality tests.
Melamine contamination of baby formula has been blamed for the deaths of at least four infants and kidney illnesses in more than 53,000 children in China.

A shipment of 25 tons of milk powder imported into Taiwan from China earlier this year has also caused a stir in the local food market and led to the resignation of Lin Fang-yue as DOH minister late last month.

Through the arrangements of the SEF and the ARATS -- the two quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties -- a Taiwan delegation of health officials and experts visited Beijing Sept.27-29 to discuss the establishment of a direct communciations mechanism to deal with relevant issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition to open

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition, which opens Tuesday in the Taipei International Convention Center, will have 155 companies from around the world taking part to demonstrate their latest products in 300 booths, organizers of the event said Monday.

According to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which is organizing the exhibition with the Taiwan Photovoltaic Industry Association, the 2008 exhibition -- the second ever held in Taiwan -- is twice as large as the exhibition last year.

Among the world-renowned exhibitors are Germany's Q-Cells AG, the world's second-largest manufacturer of solar cells; America's DuPont Co., Despatch Industries, and Spire Solar Co.; Japan's Nisshinbo Industries Inc.; Singapore's ASYS Group; Singmatek of the United Kingdom; and Taiwan's Gintech Energy Corp., Green Energy Technology Inc. and Delta Electronics Inc.

The one-day forum will take place Tuesday at the Taipei International Convention Center. Participants will include world industry leaders, experts, researchers and government officials. They will hold three sessions to discuss the current status and trend of the global and Taiwanese photovoltaic industries, as well as the global market trends.

Statistics show that Taiwan 's solar cell production reached 545 megawatts in 2007 and is expected to increase to 1,148 megawatts in 2008. Taiwan is currently the fourth largest solar cell producer in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22% of university students feel mildly depressed: survey

TEXT.P: More than 20 percent of local college students responding to a recent opinion survey said they experienced various levels of depression, but most of them tended to deal with the phenomena on their own, pollsters said Monday.

The John Tung Foundation, a private organnization dedicated to public health promotion, conducted a survey between May and June to explore the mental and emotional health of students at local universities and colleges.
The foundation distributed 6,840 questionnaires and collected 5,655 valid samples.

Survey results showed that 22 percent of the respondents described themselves as suffering from different degrees of depression, but more than 80 percent of this group of students tended to resolve their emotional problems on their own, declining to seek counseling to help relieve their emotional pressure.
The foundation created a measurement scale to gauge the respondents' emotional health, assessing the students' sources of pressure and how they coped with it.

According to the survey's findings, the top five sources of pressure for local college students were outlook on life, personal economic well-being, academic workload/exam scores, appearance/fitness, and family economic situation or debt problems, in that order.
The five most common ways cited by respondents to relieve their emotional pressure were taking a rest or sleep, seeking advice online, talking with other people, going to movie or watching TV.
For those who confessed to suffering from depression, few cited "talking with other people" as a way to ease their emotional problems, according to the survey.
