DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 7, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. continues to evaluate Taiwan's other weapon requests: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/07/08 11:53:44 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is "faithfully implementing" the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and will continue to evaluate two other pending arms sales to Taiwan, a U.S. State Department official said Monday.

The official from the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was referring to Taiwan's requests to procure diesel- electric submarines and Black Hawk helicopters from the United States.
"Our internal foreign military sales process is continuing. We have turned down nothing," the official told the Central News Agency.

The Bush administration notified Congress Oct. 3 that it had approved sales to Taiwan of 330 Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missiles, 32 sub-launched Harpoon Block II missiles, 30 AH-64D Block III Apache Longbow attack helicopters, 182 Javelin guided anti-tank missile rounds and 20 Javelin command launch units, and system upgrades for four E-2T aircraft.
However, two other items under review -- diesel-electric submarines and Black Hawk helicopters -- were not included on the list.

Asked why the notifications were only sent to Congress on the final day of the congressional session before a scheduled adjournment, the official said Washington's decisions on foreign military sales to Taiwan "are not controlled by a timetable."
"We only recently finished our internal consultations and arrived at this decision on those items," he said.

Washington makes decision regarding weapons sales to Taiwan based on the defense needs of Taiwan and the TRA under which the United States makes available items for Taiwan's self-defense, the official added.
On the Bush administration's position toward Taiwan's request for F-16C/D fighters, the official said "we do not comment on potential weapons systems in the foreign military sales program."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Police arrest 3 in raid on amphetamine plant in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: Police raided an amphetamine production facility in Taoyuan County's Longtan Township Monday night, arresting three suspects and seizing about 400 kilograms of semi-processed amphetamine as well as production equipment, a Taipei City police division announced Tuesday.

The Criminal Investigation Division of the Taipei City Police Department said police received a tip about a possible amphetamine plant in the township two months ago and had been staking out the facility waiting for the opportune time to make the raid.

Despite having a low level of education and no background in chemical production, the three suspects were able to set up a sophisticated amphetamine operation complete with detailed supply and production schedules, police said.
According to police's initial estimates, the amphetamine production operation earned up to NT$6 million (US$ 185,000) per month.
Police said that the suspects will be handed over to Taoyuan prosecutors to deal with according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 81% of Taiwanese support Obama for U.S. president: survey

TEXT.P: As many as 81 percent of Taiwanese support Democratic Party candidate Barack Obama as the next U.S. president, according to results of an international survey released Tuesday by Reader's Digest.
Republican Party candidate John McCain, on the other hand, obtained only 6 percent of support among Taiwanese, the results showed.

The survey was conducted between June and July among 17,000 people from 17 countries, including the United States, Canada, the Netherlands, Germany, Finland, Australia, South Africa, Brazil, Poland, Russia, India and Taiwan.

The results revealed that Obama won overwhelming support in all countries except for the United States, where Obama and McCain are in a neck-and-neck race, with 36 percent and 38 percent support levels, respectively.
The support ratings of the two candidates saw the largest margin in the Netherlands, where Obama is 84 percentage points ahead of McCain.
The narrowest differences outside the United States were recorded in India and Russia, where Obama leads McCain by 35 percentage points.
The support rating of 81 percent for Obama in Taiwan is the third highest among the 17 countries surveyed.

Joanne Chang, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of European and American Studies and Taiwan's former deputy representative to the United States, said the widespread support for Obama overseas is likely related to his personal charisma and the attention that he pays to human rights and environmental issues.
Whoever is elected the next U.S. president, the government of Taiwan is expected to maintain friendly relations with both parties, Chang said.

Tuan Y. Cheng, director of National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations, said U.S. interests will be the top concern of whoever becomes U.S. president, noting that both candidates are paying little attention to the Taiwan issue and have never mentioned Taiwan during their campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October rose 56 points to close at 5,445, with 91,113 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November gained 54 points to finish at 5,421, with 1,825 contracts traded, while December futures rose 49 points to close at 5,408, with 103 contract transactions.
March futures increased 40 points to finish at 5,385, with 17 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 30 points to close at 5,366, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,389 for October, 5,367 for November, 5,359 for December, 5,345 for March and 5,336 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 18.96 points to finish at 5,524.66, on turnover of NT$59.25 billion (US$1.83 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

October TE futures rose 2.7 points to close at 224.6, with 4,875 contracts traded, while November TE futures increased 2.3 points to finish at 223, with 103 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.
October TF futures remained unchanged at 617.6, with 4,536 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures dropped five points to finish at 613, with 50 contracts traded.
December TF futures declined 13.4 points to finish at 596.4 points, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: 171 foreign guests to attend National Day celebrations

TEXT.P: Only one head of state from among Taiwan's 23 allies and half as many foreign guests as last year will attend Double Ten National Day celebrations Oct. 10, numbers the Ministry of Foreign Affairs attributed to the short time span between President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration and Taiwan's national day.

Matthew Lee, chief of MOFAs Department of Protocol, said at a regular press briefing that a total number of 171 foreign guests from diplomatic allies and other countries will attend Taiwans Oct. 10 Double Ten National Day celebrations, compared to 368 people last year.
Guatemala President Alvaro Colom, who is slated to arrive later today, will be the only head of state from Taiwans allies to attend the countrys birthday celebrations, according to Lee.
Colom will receive a military salute Oct. 8 at National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall's Liberty Square.
Explaining the reduced number of foreign dignitaries attending National Day activities, Lee noted that 584 foreign guests attended Ma's May 20 inauguration.
"If we combine the number of foreign guests attending National Day celebrations and the inauguration, it is much more than the total number last year,Lee said.

The MOFA official said five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies will send a total of 31 delegates to Taiwans National Day celebrations, including Colom and parliamentary speakers from Kiribati, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and Gambia, as well as Honduras Vice Foreign Minister Eduardo Federico Rosales Ramirez.

Also, 140 guests from the U.S., Japan, Canada, South Africa, Kuwait and Palestine will attend Double Ten celebrations, according to Lee, of which, a 116-people Japanese group will make up the biggest delegation, led by Takao Fujii, executive director of the pro-Taiwan Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council.

Speaking at the briefing, Harry Tseng, director-general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said that 11 people from the U.S. National Association of Attorneys General will also attend National Day celebrations.
Given that the U.S. presidential election is approaching, there are no congressmen or senators who will come because they are busy helping the candidates,Tseng said.

As to the National Day reception, Lee noted that nostalgia will be the theme of this years Double Ten reception which is slated for the afternoon of Oct. 10 at the Taipei Guest House, featuring a series of Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal cuisines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to act to dissuade teenagers from using cell phones

TEXT.P: A civic group urged the government Tuesday to take action to dissuade children and teenagers from using mobile phones, out of concern over possible electromagnetic radiation hazards.

To back its appeal, the Taiwan Electromagnetic Radiation Hazard Protection and Control Association (TEPCA) presented results of a survey on Taiwanese children and teenagers' use of cellular phones and tests on the levels of electromagnetic radiation among mobile phones marketed in Taiwan.

The survey, conducted between August and October among children and teenagers aged between 6 and 18 around Taiwan, showed that 34.4 percent of polled elementary school students, 67 percent of surveyed junior high school students, and 89.6 percent of surveyed senior high school students are cell phone users.
Based on the survey, the association estimated that around 2.2 million Taiwanese children and teenagers in the 6-18 age group possess mobile phones.

It also concluded that the older the young people are, the longer they talk on the phone, and that 390,000 of them speak on the phone for an average of at least five minutes per call and 170,000 people talk for over 10 minutes per call.

Meanwhile, tests on the electromagnetic radiation levels of 33 types of mobile phones currently marketed in the country showed that more than 60 percent of the handsets release electromagnetic radiation 1 million times higher than the background level.

The association said that although cell phones have become a necessary device in modern life, industrial countries, including Britain, Germany, France, Belgium, Italy and Russia, have all advised children, teenagers and pregnant women, to refrain from using cell phones out of health concerns.

The TEPCA is a nonprofit organization committed to bringing together the victims of electromagnetic radiation hazards, self-relief organizations, nongovernmental organizations, individuals and groups aware of the risk to promote electromagnetic radiation hazard protection and related legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 18.96 points, or 0.34 percent, to close at 5,524.66.

Rebounding from losses the previous day, the local bourse opened at 5,352.9 and fluctuated between 5,539.31 and 5,352.08. A total of 3 billion shares changed hands on continuing weak market turnover of NT$59.25 billion (US$1.83 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.6 percent. Machinery and electronics shares rose 0.8 percent and cement stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both advanced 0.2 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down 2.4 percent. Banking and financial shares declined 1.2 percent, textile stocks dropped 0.9 percent, and paper and pulp issues were down 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 863 to 714, with 397 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.97 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Straighter cross-strait air routes will not compromise security: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) assured the public Tuesday that the government's plan to open straighter air routes across the Taiwan Strait will not undermine Taiwan's security.

According to military spokeswoman Lisa Chi, the MND has contributed its professional assessment to the plan and suggested that the air routes should not involve any direct flights across the imaginary median line in the Taiwan Strait.
Based on this principle, the MND has proposed several possible routes that would not put national security at risk, Chi said.
Also, the MND has worked out the necessary measures to deal with the possible impact of the new air routes on the military's air training programs, she said.

While there are no regular passenger flights between Taiwan and China, the cross-strait weekend and holiday charter flights currently in service are required to make a detour through Hong Kong's or Macau's air space, adding hours to flights between Taiwan and central and northern China.
On Monday, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said that Taiwan and China have reached a high level of consensus on adopting more direct routes for the flights.

An formal agreement on the issue is likely to be signed during the upcoming talks between Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, slated for later this month in Taipei, Mao said.

The new routes, which will dispense with the detours through a third area, are expected to shorten the flying time between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Shanghai from 150 minutes to 67 minutes.
A more direct Taoyuan-Beijing flight would take two and a half hours, 75 minutes less than the current time, and a Taoyuan-Xiamen flight would take one hour, 30 minutes less than it does now.

DOC.HEADLINE: International seminar on melamine to be postponed: DOH

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Tuesday that an international seminar on melamine's toxicity and Taiwan's safety standards related to the chemical will be postponed to Oct. 17.

In principle, the DOH has no plan to change the current safety standard, Yeh said, when asked if the DOH would readjust its strict standard on the level of melamine allowed in dairy products, after a press conference aiming at encouraging people to eat breakfast and do exercise.

He indicated, however, that the current standard may lead to technological and commercial issues and suggested it might be necessary to move in step with international guidelines if the problems became serious.

At present, all food products in Taiwan must test negative for melamine when tested with highly sensitive liquid chromatography/tandem mass (LC/MS/MS) spectrometers, which can detect the presence of as little as 0.05 ppm (parts per million) of melamine.

The main purpose of the seminar, to be attended by experts from the World Health Organization, the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the European Union, Japan, Australia and New Zealand, is to verify if Taiwan's safety standard, which might be the strictest in the world, is appropriate, he said.
The European Union recently stipulated that food containing at least 15 percent or an unknown percentage of dairy products must not contain more than 2.5 ppm of melamine.
In New Zealand, the safety standard for melamine for most food products is 5 ppm, and 1 ppm for baby formula.

As to the United States, the Food and Drug Administration issued a guideline noting that eating 2.5 ppm of melamine would not raise health concerns, even if a person ate melamine-tainted food every day.
But it refused to set any permissable level of melamine in infant formula, saying "there is too much uncertainty to set a level in infant formula and rule out any public health concern."

In addition to discussing safety standards for melamine, Taiwan needs to collect more information at the seminar about the toxicity of the chemical, including the ways in which it pollutes food and harms human health, Yeh noted.
He said currently Taiwan only has data on melamine exposure from animal experiments.
As for the preparation of the international seminar, which was originally scheduled to be held on Oct. 12, DOH spokesman Wang Je-chau said the DOH is still contacting experts.
The safety standard for the toxic chemical melamine has caused confusion for both consumers and the food industry in Taiwan over past few weeks.

The then-DOH minister Lin Fang-yue announced in late September that food products containing up to 2.5 ppm (parts per million) would be qualified for sale and were safe to eat, taking into consideration different sensitivities of test instruments and the possibility that melamine accidentally came into contact with food.

But Lin's decision, although later validated by European and U.S. guidelines on melamine standards, ignited an uproar among consumers and opposition politicians, who believed that the agency had loosenedthe safety standard, putting their health at risk.
Lin later resigned over the decision.
After taking office, Yeh announced that all products testing positive for melamine would not be permitted for sale in order to ease consumersworries.
He also said that food products should be examined with the most sensitive instrument in Taiwan, the LC/MS/MS spectrometer, which can detect as little as 0.05 ppm of melamine.
Melamine, normally used in industrial applications, was added to diluted milk to mask lower protein levels.
Adulterated infant formula has led to widespread kidney disease among children in China, with four dying and 53,000 others left ill.
Many countries have recalled or banned imported Chinese food products containing dairy ingredients and vegetable-based proteins.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to guarantee deposits up to NT$3 million

TEXT.P: The government will guarantee larger bank deposits than previously to ease fears that the financial crisis sweeping U.S. and European banks will not overwhelm local financial institutions.

The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) announced Monday night that the government would guarantee bank deposits of up to NT$3 million per depositor per bank, up from the existing NT$1.5 million cap.

Local financial authorities took the move after observing a shift in recent weeks of ten of billions of Taiwan dollars in deposited funds from smaller private banks to accounts in government-controlled institutions, such as Bank of Taiwan and the post office.

The new policy will only cover savings accounts, time deposits, checking accounts and personal retirement pension accounts, while foreign currency accounts and structured notes will not be included, the FSC said.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, speaking at a legislative interpellation session Tuesday morning, urged citizens not to be too pessimistic about the current financial climate, noting that confidence is important and that the government "will protect the people's assets by guaranteeing all deposits at domestic banks."
Liu further said that the government will strictly supervise domestic banks to make sure that they meet capital adequacy requirements.

The premier added that he has already instructed the FSC, the central bank, and the Ministry of Finance to closely monitor the situation and make adequate preparations to maintain stability in financial markets.
He also called for depositors to "trust the government" and for "everyone to work together to get through this difficult situation."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan photovoltaic industry production to hit NT$100b

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yeh-hsiang said Tuesday that the production value of Taiwan's photovoltaic industry is expected to break the NT$100 billion mark for this year and reach NT$400 billion by 2015.

Speaking at the opening of the 2008 Taiwan International Photovoltaic Forum and Exhibition being held at the Taiwan World Trade Center Exhibition Hall 1, Shih said that the domestic photovoltaic industry has been growing at a rapid pace of over 35 percent per year since 1998.

Claiming that the domestic photovoltaic industry's production value could quadruple by 2015, Shih said that Taiwan will likely become an important global base for photovoltaic production by that time.

Currently in the photovoltaic industry, Taiwan is most competitive in the area of solar cell production, enjoying a 7 percent share of the global market in 2006 and a 12.7 percent share last year, according to Shih.

Shih said the government has been actively assisting in the development of Taiwan's photovoltaic industry through tax incentives, loans, assistance in the establishment of facilities, and other measures. He added that a renewable energy development bill, which has already been sent to the Legislative Yuan, will also help in this respect.

Shih said that based on Taiwan's successful experience in developing its semiconductor and flat panel display industries, he is confident that the country will also become an important international player in the emerging photovoltaic industry in the years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV most popular source of news: poll

TEXT.P: Television is the most popular source of news and the medium to which most people in Taiwan are exposed, followed by newspapers and the Internet, according to a survey released Monday by Shih Hsin University.

TV ranked as the most heavily used type of media for the fifth consecutive year in the university's fifth survey on media use patterns and media exposure, said Hsiung Jie, director of the College of Journalism and Communications at the university, which conducted the survey.

The survey, conducted in 22 cities and counties around the country to produce indicative rankings of newspapers, magazines, radio broadcasting, TV stations and Internet services, indicates people's heavily reliance on television, Hsiung said.

The survey found that Formosa TV, TVBS, HBO and SET-TV had the highest viewership, while Da Ai (Great Love) TV had "the greatest influence on individuals, " "the greatest influence in the society, " and "the best quality".

TVBS and Unique Business News cable channels ranked as having the best news coverage, while the Discovery and Travel & Living channels were picked as the top providers of educational, cultural, leisure and entertainment content, the survey revealed.
Although the impartiality of TV news reporting in Taiwan is often questioned, the respondents in the survey gave TV news coverage the highest credibility rating among all the media, Hsiung said.

The survey found that the Apple Daily was the most frequently read newspaper, favored by 44.2 of the respondents, followed by the Liberty Times (34.1 percent), the United Daily (25.1 percent) , and the China Times (20.5 percent).

The Apple Daily was also cited as the paper that provides the "the most detailed reports, " "the most diversified content" and "the best quality". It was also picked by 18.5 percent of the respondents as the most individually influential newspaper and, according to the survey, is the most influential newspaper in the society.
The most frequently read magazines are Next Magazine, Business Weekly, China Times Weekly and CommonWealth Magazine, the poll found.

The Broadcasting Corporation of China's (BCC's) Pop Network and News Network were selected by the respondents as their favorite radio broadcasting networks. BCC's News Network and UFO Network tied for top ranking as the most influential radio stations in the society.
YahooKimo is the most visited Web site, followed by Google, MSN and PCHome Online, according to the survey.

The survey was conducted between May and June through face-to-face interviews with 1,100 people aged 15 to 64. It had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County holds marine pollution drill

TEXT.P: Hualien County in eastern Taiwan held a drill Tuesday that simulated marine pollution from a damaged ship off its coastline, according to Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan.

The county government mobilized 34 units, including firefighters, and personnel in environmental protection, public health, marine patrol and township offices, with a total of 191 people participating in the drill, Hsieh said.
The scenario envisaged an accident in which a cargo ship strikes a rock and is crippled at the mouth of the Meilun River.
Marine pollution prevention and control is an important task for Hualien County, which has 175 km of coastline, the longest along any city or county in Taiwan.
Tuesday's drill covered emergency reporting, inspection, oil spill cleanup, and evidence collection, said Hsieh, who was the commander of the exercise.
Hsieh said the participants displayed skill in all aspects of the drill and reacted swiftly, which he said boded well in the event of an emergency, as a quick response can help to minimize damage.
Hualien County has had several marine pollution incidents in the past, and quick responses and mobilization by the relevant authorities were crucial in dealing with these crises, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier insists on parity in possible meeting with Beijing official

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chiao-shuan said Tuesday that he will insist on parity and dignity in a possible meeting with a key Beijing official who is slated to visit Taiwan soon.
"Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , must address me as 'premier' if the meeting is to take place," Liu said.

"Arrangements will have to be made in advance, and I will not meet Chen if the two sides fail to reach an agreement on this matter, " he said. "Reciprocality and dignity must be fully observed during the meeting with Chen."

The premier also gave the assurance that in addition to Chen, he will demand an apology from the Chinese government and companies over China's toxic milk powder and other questionable dairy products sold to Taiwan, and promised to help Taiwan's private sector seek compensation from the Chinese side.

Chen serves as China's top negotiator in systematic two-way talks with Taiwan. His planned visit to Taiwan, originally slated for late October or early November, has drawn objection from the DPP and its supporters, particularly as it was found last month that milk powder and other food products imported from China were tainted with a toxic industrial chemical melamine.

Meanwhile, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chiang Pin-kung, Chen's Taiwanese counterpart, said the SEF and ARATS are still arranging the details of Chen's visit to Taiwan, projected for late October.

"The date of Chen's Taiwan visit will not be changed once it has been fixed, despite objections from some quarters, " Chiang said later Tuesday during a speech at the opening of a cross-Taiwan Strait electronics show sponsored by the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association.
"In their next round of negotiations, the two sides hope to wrap up talks on establishing direct cross-strait air and sea links," he reiterated.
Meanwhile, the DPP and several pro-independence groups have vowed to take to the streets in protest against China while Chen is in the country.

In the next round of SEF-ARATS talks in Taipei, Taiwan and China are scheduled to discuss the opening of straighter cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the establishment of new passenger charter flight routes, joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and crime-fighting.
In an ice-breaking meeting in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen clinched two milestone accords to step up two-way tourism and passenger transportation services on weekends.

Speaking during a legislative interpellation session earlier Tuesday, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said issues relating to Chen's projected visit later this month are being discussed as slated. But, she added, a pair of pandas offered by China to Taiwan as gifts are not expected to be brought to Taiwan on Chen's flight.

"China's gift of two giant pandas will not arrive in Taiwan at the same time as Chen, as quarantine issues remain unsettled, " Lai said, asserting that the two endangered animals will eventually be brought to Taiwan when the necessary quarantine measures are put in place.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.007 to close at NT$32.350.
A total of US$1.614 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.343 and reached a high of NT$32.512.

DOC.HEADLINE: City of London chief: Taiwan can weather global financial crisis

TEXT.P: Given the fact that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are very healthy, the country stands a better chance than some others of weathering the global financial crisis, the lord mayor of the City of London -- the financial and commercial heart of Britain -- said Tuesday in Taipei.

"Fundamentally, your economy is in very good shape, " Lord Mayor David Lewis said at a news conference at the end of his four-day visit to Taiwan. He said Taiwan has good GDP, good export volume, low inflation rates and healthy foreign currency reserves.
"I think you stand a better chance of weathering the storm than some other countries, " Lewis said. "You should more optimistic about the situation."

The lord mayor also applauded President Ma Ying-jeou's economic policy toward China, which includes initiatives such as direct cross-strait flights and relaxation of the investment ceiling. This "is a very good thing, both for Taiwan and China and for the rest of the world," he said.
"Dialogue is the only way you can solve economic and political problems, so I endorse what he has done," he added.
Regarding Taiwan's efforts to become a regional financial center, Lewis said Taiwan has a lot to do, as there is a lot of "red tape" involved in starting a business in Taiwan.
Also, Taiwan has to encourage more foreign investors to list on the Taiwan stock market and encourage more Taiwanese businesses to come back to invest at home, he added.
Turning his attention to the current global financial crisis, Lewis suggested that global action is needed to solve the problem.
"Fundamentally, it has to do with lack of confidence and lack of trust, " Lewis said. "Because it is a global problem, only a global solution will deal with it."

He said it is essential that governments, regulators, and central banks across the world get together and agree on a course of action to restore the confidence and trust that everyone had in the system and also, just as importantly, to prevent similar financial crises from happening again in the future.

The lord mayor argued that it is quite understandable and sensible to see the consolidation of financial institutions around the world, because while there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the businesses, the problem lies in bank liquidity.
He said such consolidation should apply to Taiwan as well because the country has too many banks for a population of only 23 million.
"You need small banks to be merged or taken over by larger banks, which will then become more stable and stronger, and that would result in more confidence in the system," Lewis said.
The 61-year-old Lewis will leave Taiwan Oct. 8 and travel to Japan, Brunei and Singapore from Oct.9-16 to discuss investment opportunities that the City of London has to offer.
Located in the eastern part of downtown London, the City of London is also called the "Square Mile" because it is 2.6 square kilometers in area.
The lord mayor is elected every year and is commissioned to act during the one- year term as an ambassador for the UK-financial sector industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Native Taiwanese chicken popular choice amid economic slump

TEXT.P: Consumers in Taiwan now have the option of buying native Taiwanese chicken whose prices have dropped from its peak a month ago amid the current economic volatility.

At the "2008 chicken broth of happiness" fair in Taipei Tuesday, the organizer, the Poultry Association of the Republic of China, drew attention to the fact that the market price of local chicken fell from over NT$80 (US$2.47) per kilogram in September to around NT$53 per kg in early October.

Ho Yu-chen, an association executive responsible for the sale of locally raised chicken, said that between 1.8 million and 2 million chickens were sold per week during the long summer break -- a volume that she said was about normal for that time of year.
However, in the cooler autumn season, sales were expected to rise to between 2 million and 2.2 million whole chickens per week, but they fell short of that projection this year, Ho said.

This is because local poultry farmers had overstocks of between 400,000 and 500,000 units during the Mid-Autumn Festival, a traditional high season for chicken, one of the main ingredients of local cuisine and of a health broth that includes Chinese herbal medicine, Ho added.
The association has therefore organized a series of promotional activities around the island in the hope of pumping up the sluggish sale of locally grown chicken, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's infrastructure plan offers ample investment opportunities

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference entered its second day Tuesday with four panel discussions in the morning, including one presenting Taiwan's NT$3.99 trillion infrastructure development plan.

Hwang Wang-hsiang, vice chairman of the nation's top economic planning agency, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, introduced the i-Taiwan 12 projects as "the new economic development blueprint for Taiwan."
Investment in the projects is expected to hit NT$3.99 trillion (US$123.2 billion) over eight years, with NT$2.65 trillion coming from the government and NT$1.34 trillion from the private sector.

Among the 12 projects will be the extension of Taiwan's transportation network, encompassing three programs: a fast and convenient islandwide transportation network, Kaohsiung port-city regeneration, and the development of a Taoyuan international aviation city.

Another project, to stimulate industrial development, will focus on building a new central region high-tech industrial clusters program, an industrial innovation corridors programs, and an intelligent Taiwan.
Two major programs will be emphasized in the project related to urban and rural development: urban and industrial park regeneration, and farm village regeneration.
The project related to environmental protection will feature four main components: coastal regeneration, green forestation, flood prevention and water management, and sewer construction.

The government's preliminary budget for the 12 projects in 2009, pending legislative approval, is NT$170.226 billion. Of that, 38.89 percent, or NT$65.349 billion, will be earmarked for the building of a fast and convenient islandwide transportation network.
The programs developing an intelligent Taiwan and industrial innovation corridors will account for 20.02 percent, or NT$34.07 billion, of the 2009 budget.

Jennifer Yuh-jen Wu, deputy director of the Institute of Transportation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that the fast transportation network aims at allowing residents of villages and townships with populations greater than 50,000 to reach a freeway or expressway within 30 minutes and reach regional centers in one hour.

In another panel discussion on biotechnology, National Health Research Institutes Secretary-General C.M. Liang said Taiwan's diverse advantages offered attractive opportunities in biotech development.

While worldwide revenues in the bio- pharmaceutical industry now total US$800 billion annually, Taiwan's annual revenues currently stand at only US$6 billion, Liang said, indicating the sector's considerable potential for growth in the country.

Liang noted that Taiwan's biotechnology industry enjoys many advantages, including a reservoir of high-quality talent to help discover and develop new drugs and its powerful electronics industry, which can help design better medical monitoring devices.
Taiwan's knowledge of traditional Chinese medicine will also help as more people around the world stress health maintenance, a potentially crucial trend for the bio-pharm sector, Liang suggested.

He observed that as baby boomers age, biotechnology will be geared as much to enhancing health care and quality of life as it is to preventing disease, a trend that will cater to Taiwan's competitive advantages.

He also said that nurturing and retaining biotech talent is an urgent priority in the research and development of new drugs, and noted that the key areas in the development of bio-pharm will be small molecule drugs, DNA & RNA drugs and protein drugs.

In the panel discussion on micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) , Shyu Jyuo- min, chairman of the Nanotechnology and Micro Systems Association, noted that Taiwan's semiconductor industry has good supply chain integration.
That strong supply chain is seen as a major advantage, Shyu said, as it enables many ODM factories, foundries, and fabless companies to advance their MEMS component technologies.
Taiwan also has a sound high-tech infrastructure with northern, central and southern Taiwan industrial parks, making it very suitable to develop MEMS applications, he said.

Yee Kuo-chung, vice president of the R&D Center of the Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Group (ASE) , said there were growing opportunities in Taiwan's MEMS sector as 4C functions are being merged into handsets and demand is growing for the technology in sensors and related equipment.
Yee said the key factors in winning MEMS business included standardization & diversification, cost effectiveness, market size, supply chain integration and chip-package-system know-how.

In the panel discussion on Taiwan's LED Industry, Taiwan was introduced as the world's second largest LED manufacturer in terms of output, after Japan, with applications in cellular phones, small- and middle-size panel backlights and digital photo frames being the backbone of the industry.

Panel participants noted that considering the huge commercial opportunities in large backlights, residential and commercial lighting and automobile LED applications, upstream epitaxial wafer and chip production is seen as an ideal niche for foreign investment.
The output value of the LED industry in Taiwan was US$1.423 billion in 2007, accounting for a 21.6 percent share of the world market.
Following the panel discussions, Charles H.C. Kao, the chairman of the Institute of Knowledge Economy and Management, discussed Taiwan's investment climate in front of a luncheon audience.

Kao said he was fundamentally optimistic about Taiwan's economic future, and lauded the government's attempt to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations to solidify Taiwan as a key hub between the West and China.
But he also urged the administration to address the country's tax structure, streamline regulations and maintain policy consistency to strengthen the local investment environment.
More information on the conference is available at http://investintaiwan.nat.gov.tw/en/

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan eyeing position as regional financial center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/08 20:10:15 (By Sofia Wu) (Ninth in a 10-part series)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will capitalize on its strength in manufacturing industries to turn itself into a regional niche-oriented financial center, a senior official said Tuesday at an annual international business conference.

Bill Chang, a Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) commissioner, made the remarks while moderating a panel discussion on finance and insurance industry development held as part of the 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference.
Chang said the FSC has singled out developing Taiwan into a regional financial center as a long-term goal for the coming four to eight years.

As Taiwan is working hard to improve relations with China and ease restrictions on trade and economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said, Taiwan stands a good chance of realizing its ambitious goal of becoming a regional financial center, given its cultural and language advantages and having the greater China area as its market.
In becoming a regional financial market, Chang went on, Taiwan must seek to become a regional financial service center, fund raising center and wealth/asset management center for Asia.

While Hong Kong is outstanding in market opening and financial liberalization and Singapore is good at integrating financial services under its efficient government leadership, Chang said Taiwan has many advantages that cannot be easily replaced, such as a rich talent pool, an enormous demand for capital and financial services by a large array of overseas Taiwanese companies, and a well- developed chain of high-tech manufacturing industries.

If Taiwan can leverage its strengths in these fields, such as its upstream companies' demand for financing, its midstream companies' demand for securities management and its downstream companies' demand for commodity distribution, Chang said, Taiwan can emerge as a regional financial center.

At another panel discussion on investment opportunities based on cross-strait deregulation, both local and foreign business executives said Taiwan's government should come up with a comprehensive policy on trade and economic relations with China in order to create more jobs and business opportunities through further opening to Chinese capital.

Randall Hall, CEO-China of Savills Property Services (Shanghai) Co., said Taiwan should develop a well-rounded cross-strait economic policy and greatly ease restrictions on two-way investment across the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan's real estate, tourism and hotel industries will all benefit from such reforms, Hall said during the panel discussion on investment opportunities based on cross-strait deregulation.

Forecasting that both the commercial property and housing markets in Taiwan will benefit from deregulation, Hall said he is very confident of Taiwan's property market prospects once Taiwan opens its doors wider to Chinese investors.

He further suggested that Taiwan accelerate its pace of opening up to China by allowing direct shipping links and direct cross-strait flights on a daily basis and permitting Chinese citizens to invest in Taiwanese industries and property.

Fred P.C. Huang, chairman of the Taiwan Association of Machinery Industry, concurred with Hall's views, saying that as China has gradually evolved from a "global factory" to a "global market, " Taiwan's business community should step up efforts to tap its neighbor's vast domestic market and consider how to cooperate with its Chinese counterpart to cope with changing global economic trends and financial volatility.

In its formulation of cross-strait economic policy, Huang said, the government should take into account Taiwan's leverage, the feasibility of cross-strait cooperation in industrial development, and China's willingness to engage in such cooperation.

Yasushi Hata, general manager of Japan's Mitsui & Co.'s overseas department in charge of corporate planning and strategy, said Taiwanese and Japanese companies would stand a better chance of gaining a solid foothold in the Chinese domestic market if they pool their resources and cooperate closely, given the fact that Taiwan has advantages in the areas of management, cost control and market distribution in China, while Japan excels in the areas of branding and technical know-how.
Meanwhile, in a panel discussion on the tourism and hospitality industry, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said now is the best time for investment in Taiwan's tourism industry.

Noting that many international news media outlets have run articles on Taiwan's tourism resources, Lai said the government has also spared no efforts in an international publicity campaign in order to attract more tourists.

Over the past few years, Lai said, the government has consistently set aside a large portion of its annual budget for the renovation of tourist facilities and infrastructure construction. Moreover, she added, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have come to terms on mutual tourist exchanges, ushering in a new era for Taiwan's tourism development.

Stanley C. Yen, honorary chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association and group president of Landis Hotels and Resorts, said Taiwan has potential to become a regional travel and recreational center if it can carve out unique tourist attractions by leveraging on its generous hospitality and abundant religious and cultural heritage.

On the development of the logistics industry, Bobby Yu, chairman of Taiwan Air Cargo Terminal, said that thanks to Taiwan's thriving information technology industry and booming cross-strait transport services, the combined air cargo volumes of Taiwan's two major carriers -- China Airlines and Eva Airways -- have put Taiwan at the top of the world air cargo service map.

Other domestic logistics industry operators have also used online services and forged cooperative ties with foreign air carriers to expand their reach in the global transport service market, Yu added.

Henk Meijboom, executive board member for shipping and logistics divisions of the Netherlands Broekman Group, shared Yu's views on Taiwan's advantages in the logistics industry, saying that Taiwan occupies a favorable geographic location, enjoys continued economic growth and boasts a strong IT industry.

Nevertheless, Meijboom continued, Taiwan also faces many challenges in sustaining its niches in this field. To reap even more gains, he said, Taiwan's logistics industry operators should step up their exploration of Chinese market- related logistics services by using its geographic proximity to that country.

With its robust manufacturing sector, Meijboom said, Taiwan should capitalize on the daily demand of its world-renowned companies such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., Acer and Chimei, for delivery of their goods worldwide every day to beef up its logistics service network.
A total of 1,500 business people attended the 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, in which two forums and eight panel sessions were held. The event concluded Tuesday. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 foreign companies pledge to invest up to US$200 million in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/07/08 20:11:57 (By Cindy Sui) (10th in a 10-part series)

TEXT.P: Fifteen companies with diverse businesses and headquartered in different parts on the world on Tuesday pledged to invest an estimated US$150 million to US$200 million in Taiwan, citing the islands skilled workforce, strong government support and honest business environment as reasons why they want to put their money here.

The companies signed letters of intent at a ceremony on the sidelines of the 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference, an event that is held for the fifth time in Taiwan this year, attracting 1,500 business people this time. The conference concluded Tuesday.

There are different reasons why these companies made their commitments, with some planning to make Taiwan their regional headquarters. The reasons include Taiwans strong talent, location and the improvement in cross-strait relations, said Yiin Chii-ming, Taiwans Minister of Economic Affairs.

Of the companies that signed the letters of intent, 10 will expand or increase their investments here. These include companies that have been investing in Taiwan for nearly 20 years or more, including Bayer, 3M, Corning, and Siemens.
For Bayer, the letter of intent is the first the company has signed with the government in 10 years.
We see Taiwan as a key market in our strategic positioning in Asia, especially in research and development of functional films, said Tim Bielfeldt, head of Bayer Material Science A.G.

We are especially encouraged by recent commitments by Mr. Yiin and his team that they are supporting private sector investment in environmental protection, especially investments in green products, Bielfeldt said at the signing ceremony.
Another five companies will make their initial investments in Taiwan.

One of them, Matla Solar Energy (Pty) Ltd., which is based in Africa, plans to invest US$25.2 million in opening a photovoltaic cell manufacturing facility in Taiwan and another US$8.1 million into a Taiwan-based research incubation company.

Thats very unusual for an African country, underdeveloped, to be investing heavily in a developed country. We do that for strategic reasons and because we embrace the people of Taiwan because of their warmth and expertise, said Zwelakhe Sisulu, chairman of the company s parent company, The Matla Group.
Six of the companies will set up R&D centers in Taiwan.
They said the business environment and attitude of the government and people makes Taiwan anexcellent choiceas a regional base for their companies in the Asia Pacific region.

We speak about trust, loyalty and honesty and its not always easy to find these words in China, but we have these in Taiwan,said Johan Stjernberg, president and CEO of Swedish firm, the STEGIA Company, which makes electrical, mechanical, telecom and automotive devices.
Yiin said his ministry is committed to further improving Taiwan s investment environment to attract foreign direct investment more efficiently.

Taiwan is strategically located in East Asia.KWe believe cross-strait deregulation and cooperation as well as new domestic infrastructure development will lead to more investments in Taiwan, Yiin said at the ceremony.

Yiin said later that he did not know whether the amount pledged at the conference was greater than investment commitments made in previous conferences, but that regardless of the amount, with the financial challenges currently faced around the world, the ministry willneed to work harder to attract foreign investment. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO announces Mansion House scholarship winners

TEXT.P: The British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) announced Tuesday the two winners of this year's Mansion House Scholarship, who will embark on financial training and courses in the United Kingdom.

The two winners -- Chang Hsiao-ping and Wang Wei-kai -- were awarded at a joint chamber luncheon earlier in the day by Alderman David Lewis, the lord mayor of the City of London -- the financial and commercial heart of Britain.
"I wish both the winners of the scholarship a fruitful financial experience in the City of London, " Lewis was quoted as saying by the BTCO in a press release.

Thirty-four-year-old Chang, who has a master's degree in banking and finance from the University of Stirling, has worked as a specialist at the Financial Supervisory Commission's Division of International Banks since 2001, according to the BTCO.
She intends to undertake a short-term position at Switzerland-based UBS London headquarters to learn about the wealth management business, the BTCO added.

Wang, a 30-year-old economics graduate who has worked for the Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China since 2006, is planning to take either a masters in finance at the London Business School or an MSc in investment management at Cass Business School.

The Mansion House Scholarship Scheme targets overseas students wishing to take masters-level degree courses at British universities and young business executives or officials wishing to undertake training or work experience in the financial services sector or in related business activities in the U.K.

The scheme was established by the lord mayor of London in 1997 to help build links between London's City -- one of the world's leading financial centers -- and other financial centers, including Taiwan.

The scheme provides an excellent opportunity to gain a better insight into British business life and underlying cultural perceptions. Awards vary in size but are usually in the region of 5,000-7,500 British pounds (NT$282,500 to NT$423,500.)
The process and selection of the successful applicants are made by the lord mayor's office on the advice of the BTCO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Security chief apologizes over `slip of tongue' on SARS remarks

TEXT.P: National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Tsai Chao-ming apologized Tuesday for what he described as a "slip of the tongue" he made a day earlier at the legislature when he called the 2003 severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak a result of "China's biological warfare."

The apology was made through a news release issued by the NSB. Unlike a previous news release a day earlier that flatly denied that Tsai made any remarks to that effect, the Tuesday news release said Tsai's "slip of the tongue" occurred because of the limited time he had to answer questions from a legislative committee.

SARS originated in southern China and went on to kill about 745 people around the world, including 350 in China, 299 in Hong Kong and 83 in Taiwan. It dealt a heavy blow to Asia's tourism and air industries.
Tsai's remarks about SARS being a biochemical agent of China were
made in response to questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Twu Shiing-jer, who was the head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) during the SARS outbreak.
Asked to comment on whether the SARS virus could be used as a biological weapon, Yeh Chin-chuan, who took over as minister of the DOH 10 days ago, said the possibility is "very slim."

"I am not a weapons expert, but the SARS virus is something that can be controlled. If it occurs, we are capable of stopping it," said Yeh, who earned the reputation as Taipei's "SARS-fighting hero" in 2003 when he led the quarantined Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital in the fight against the outbreak as director of the city's health bureau.
Although Tsai offered an apology for his remarks, the controversy appeared to be still developing, with legislators of both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the DPP bent on pursuing the issue.

The DPP legislative caucus urged Tsai to reveal all information his bureau has about a SARS conspiracy theory that the virus was "probably produced in a Chinese laboratory" in order that Taiwan can ask the international community to join an investigation into the issue.
The KMT legislative caucus also said that if Tsai cannot back his remarks with concrete proof, he should step down from his post as the nation's top security chief.

Answering questions from opposition DPP legislators at an interpellation session, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan voiced his support for the KMT legislators, saying that the NSB has an obligation to clarify the issue.

On whether he agreed with the KMT legislative caucus' view that Tsai should resign, the premier said he would relay the suggestion to President Ma Ying-jeou and that it is up to the president to decide what, if any, further steps should be taken.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for Taiwan-U.S. extradition treaty

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Tuesday for the signing of an extradition treaty between Taiwan and the United States so that Taiwan criminals, especially economic criminals who have fled to the United States, could be brought back to face justice.
Ma made the remarks while receiving a delegation from the U.S. National Association of Attorneys General.

Ma expressed the hope that the delegation would help in this regard when they return to the United States, so that the U.S. Congress could formulate the relevant legislation to turn a new page in bilateral judicial cooperation.
He said that although the two countries have not signed an extradition treaty, Taiwan has worked with the U.S. to turn over U.S. suspects who had fled to Taiwan.

This relatively unbalanced situation has existed for a long time, the president said, expressing the hope that the signing of a bilateral extradition treaty will serve to repatriate Taiwan fugitives in the U.S.

Ma said that Taiwan has cooperated well with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency in a "controlled delivery" approach, noting that drug mules traveling from Southeast Asia to the United States sometimes go via Taiwan or Japan.

When such drug traffickers are spotted passing through Taiwan's ports, the Taiwan police usually take no action, but instead allow the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency to make the arrests and seize the drugs when the suspects arrive on the U.S. West coast, the president said.
The process has to be kept top secret and requires full cooperation, he added.
Taiwan has worked with the United States in this way for a long time, Ma said, adding that it would be even better if both sides signed an extradition treaty.

DOC.HEADLINE: English service cabs to hit roads in Taipei County

TEXT.P: Taxis with English-speaking drivers are expected to soon hit the streets in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, as part of the county government's efforts to build a foreigner-friendly environment in the local transportation network, a county official said Tuesday.

The Taipei county tourism bureau sponsored a seminar to explain the aim and design of the program, and a local taxi driver was invited to share his English- learning experience with other taxi drivers who are keen to join the program.

Under the program, the Taipei county government will offer free English conversation courses to taxi drivers through virtual reality learning, and those who qualify will be certified and recruited into the English-speaking service network.
In the future, foreign visitors and local passengers will be able to call an English-language taxi service through the county government's certification system, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14th case of enterovirus fatality reported this year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) reported Tuesday the 14th fatality from enterovirus this year, confirming the death of an eight-month-old boy affected by enterovirus 71 (EV71), which can cause severe neurological damage.
Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said the patient became ill on May 30, and was taken to a local clinic for medical treatment the next day.

Without showing signs of getting well, the boy was transferred to a medical center on June 1, where he was admitted to an intensive-care ward. The following day, he was put on the extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ecmo) life support system.
The system was removed on June 5, but the boy remained in critical condition, Lin said.

The patient, suffering from damage to the central nervous system of the brain, was transferred to a health care center on July 4, where he succumbed to the disease, passing away on Sept. 21, Lin noted.
With rising public awareness about the outbreaks of the epidemic this year, only 13 suspected cases were reported as of Tuesday since Sept. 1, five of which were confirmed, according to Lin.
The accumulated volume of confirmed severe enterovirus infection cases reached 396 so far this year, Lin added.
Lin reminded the public that asking their children to wash their hands frequently and maintaining good hygiene are the best ways to protect children from the disease.
Parents and teachers are also advised to be on guard if children under 5 have the typical symptoms of a serious case of enterovirus -- fever, foot-and-mouth disease, twittering and drowsiness.
Enterovirus is the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and can lead to serious illness, especially in infants and the immunocompromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourists favor quota control on visitors to Orchid Island: poll

TEXT.P: A vast majority of tourists who have visited Orchid Island support the idea of imposing a quota system to control the number of visitors to the small island off the coast of Taitung County in southeastern Taiwan, a tourism organization said Tuesday.
The Taitung Sustainable Development Association made the statement based on the results of a public opinion survey that it conducted recently under commission by the Taitung County government.

Citing the poll results, association officials reported that as many as 62.5 percent of the respondents favored the idea of establishing a "quota control" mechanism to limit the number of tourists to the Orchid Island, while 58.9 percent supported setting up a "conservation area" on the island -- both to help preserve its natural resources.
These are strong indications that visitors are increasingly aware of the importance of environmental protection on the island, said association officials.
According to the results of the survey, most tourists to the Orchid Island are young men and women with higher education who visit the island at least once.

To this type of tourist, Orchid Island's "landscape" and "diversified ecological system" are the prime attractions, the survey found. About 92.1 percent said they would like to visit the island again with their families or friends.

But about 90 percent of the respondents said they are deeply concerned that the many motorcycles on the island would destroy its tranquil environment, while many tourists said they were most dissatisfied with what they described as the island's unclear "road signs" and "explanation boards" at the tourist spots.
The 45 square-kilometer Orchid Island is located some 80 km southeast of Taitung County. It is home to some 5,000 indigenous people of the Tao tribe. Most of the residents are farmers and fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature urged to provide live broadcasts of sessions

TEXT.P: The Citizen Congress Watch (CCW) , a civic group that monitors the Legislative Yuan, has urged the legislature to provide live broadcasts of its sessions via the video-on-demand (VOD) system, CCW Chairman Ku Chung-hwa said at a news conference Tuesday.

Ku said the legislature has spent six months working on providing the service, efforts that have included sending a delegation to America in July to learn from its experience. However, he went on, no progress has been made since then.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng vowed in July that the legislature would put the service into practice in September, but has failed to keep his promise, Ku said.

Wang said at the beginning of October that the legislature is working toward allowing public access to live session broadcasts and will hold a cross-party meeting Oct. 13 to reach consensus on the many problems involved.

However, CCW Executive Director Ho Tsung-hsun said the issue of technical problems should be excluded in that meeting, pointing out that eight local government councils -- Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Keelung City, Yilan County, Hualien County, Chiayi County, Chiayi City and Taichung City -- have already put broadcasts of their sessions on their Web sites.
Among them, the Kaohsiung City Council started providing the service in 2001, while Taipei City launched its one in September after just two months of preparation, Ho said.

Financial support will not be a problem, either, Ho said, pointing out that Chiayi City's operating expenses in this regard amount to about NT$50,000 (US$1,543) per year, while those of Hualien County cost only NT$10,000 for one year.
Ho said he does not understand why the legislature has been so ineffective in providing the service, given that it enjoys more resources than local councils.
He expressed hope that the Oct. 13 meeting will come up with resolutions that meet the public's expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taichung Jazz Festival to challenge Guinness record

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taichung Jazz Festival is scheduled to open in the central city next Saturday, with 20 to 30 well-known saxophonists and saxophone ensembles from home and abroad performing, an official said Tuesday.
The nine-day festival, which is held annually, is in its sixth year.

At the opening of the festival sponsored by the city's Cultural Affairs Bureau, 1,000 musicians are expected to team up to perform popular songs on saxophone at the bustling City Square in the city's West District, said Mark K. Huang, the bureau's director-general.

They will be attempting to break the British-based Guinness Book of World Records for the most sax players performing at once, which currently stands at 900, a record set in Toronto, Canada March 30, 2004, Huang said.
At present, more than 500 musicians have applied to take part in the Taichung saxophone performance, Huang said.

With less than two weeks left before the scheduled assault on the record, Huang said the bureau will do more to publicize the record-breaking attempt and try to encourage city government staffers and city residents who have taken saxophone lessons to participate in the performance.
Even those just interested in learning to play the instrument are welcome, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP proposes bill to compensate importers harmed by melamine scandal

TEXT.P: An opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) @legislator proposed a draft bill Tuesday to compensate Taiwanese import firms that have suffered financial losses as a result of their importing of melamine-contaminated products from China.
Wang Sing-nan, a DPP caucus whip, submitted the bill to the legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee, which agreed to report it to a meeting of the whole legislature for discussion Oct. 14.
The bill has won the endorsement from the legislative caucuses of both the DPP and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Legislator William Lai, another DPP legislative caucus whip, said the government should first compensate the affected importers for their losses and then try to get the money back from the Chinese authorities.
KMT caucus whip Lin Yi-shih said the KMT caucus supports the bill in principle but will need to communicate with the Cabinet to thrash out some differences.

In addition to granting such importers business tax exemption for September, the bill would allow cash compensation to be paid for melamine-related losses to import firms according to their annual business revenues.

For example, a firm whose revenues totaled between NT$3 million and NT$4 million last year could get NT$500,000@ (US$15,420) in compensation, while a smaller firm with revenues of less than NT$1.2 million could receive just NT$50,000.

Taiwan has been engulfed in a food scare since the food and beverage products of several noted companies were recently found to contain melamine. The contamination occurred because milk power and non-dairy creamer imported from China were used as ingredients in the Taiwanese companies' food and beverage products.

Twenty-two dairy companies in China were found to have added melamine -- a toxic chemical used to make plastics and fertilizers -- to milk powder and non-dairy products to give them artificially high protein levels.

Taiwan discovered last month that 25 tons of Sanlu-brand milk powder imported from China in June was contaminated with melamine. The milk powder was sold mainly to bakeries and beverage companies as a baking ingredient and creamer.

According to statistics released by the Chinese authorities, six babies have died and some 53,000 children have fallen ill -- including 6,200 infants diagnosed with kidney stones -- after consuming melamine-tainted infant formula.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police confiscate 1,000 counterfeit DVDs in northern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The leader of the copyright police in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, said Tuesday that officers from his unit seized more than 1,000 pirated DVDs a day earlier at a night market in Taoyuan County.

Chen Fu-chien, leader of the Taoyuan unit of the Intellectual Property Protection Brigade under the National Police Agency, said his men discovered a junior high school student selling discs containing a wide rage of illegally copied movies.
"We were surprised to see such recent titles as `Cape No. 7' and `Paris' among the titles," Chen said.

Cape No. 7 is a Taiwanese film that is still being screened around the island, with box office takings surpassing NT$300 million already, while Paris is a French romance not scheduled to be shown in Taiwan until December.

The student claimed that he was not the owner of the pirated films but was merely paid NT$1,000 to look after the stand. Police officers were trying to follow leads to track down the counterfeit ring that produced the discs, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-first lady's brother detained in money laundering probe

TEXT.P: Former first lady Wu Shi-jen's older brother was detained Tuesday on charges of violating the anti-money laundering act, making him the fifth person to be held incommunicado in the ongoing probe into alleged money laundering involving the former first family.

Wu Ching-mao was taken into custody after being questioned for several hours earlier in the day. Prosecutors sought Wu's detention as they believed he had offended against the anti-money laundering act by helping his older sister wire more than NT$60 million abroad using figurehead accounts.
Prosecutors also feared that Wu might tamper with evidence or collude with other suspects to commit perjury if allowed to remain at large.

The Taipei District Court granted the request for detention after reviewing the case and ordered that he be held incommunicado. The court said in its ruling that the money wired abroad by Wu might be connected with public funds; otherwise, he had not to have used many figurehead accounts to evade scrutiny.

Wu's detention came a day after former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau Director-General Yeh Sheng-mao was detained by the Taipei District Court for his role in the former first family's alleged money laundering case.

Yeh was indicted Aug. 28 for concealing and failing to investigate information about overseas bank accounts held by members of former President Chen Shui- bian's family in the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean. Yeh was the first to be indicted in the case.
The district court will hold a hearing on Yeh's case Wednesday, during which Yeh is expected to hold cross-debate with Chen.

Two of the former president's most trusted aides -- Chen Chen-hui, a former cashier of the Presidential Office, and Lin Teh-hsun, director of Chen's office from 2005-2008 -- have also been taken into custody for their suspected roles in the case.
Also detained was Tsai Ming-tse, a brother of Tsai Mei-li, a college classmate of former first lady Wu Shu-jen.

In addition to being implicated in the money laundering case, Chen is also under investigation for alleged embezzlement of public funds by using other people's spending receipts to gain reimbursements from a special "state affairs fund" set aside for his discretionary use for official purposes. His wife has been indicted in this case.
Prosecutors are now investigating whether any portion of the "state affairs fund" had been wired to the overseas bank accounts of Chen's family members during his eight-year presidency.

According to Chen Shui-bian, the money in the overseas bank accounts was the balance of political contributions for his two mayoral and two presidential bids between 1993 and 2004. Chen claimed his innocence, insisting that he didn't use any penny of the "state affairs fund" to line his own pocket.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Wednesday, moving down 150.39 points at 5,374.27 on a turnover of NT$2.2 billion (US$67.87 million).
The weighted price index gain 18.96 points, or 0.34 percent, to close at 5,524.66 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.417 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.067 from Tuesday.
