Also detained was Tsai Ming-tse, a brother of Tsai Mei-li, a college classmate of former first lady Wu Shu-jen.

In addition to being implicated in the money laundering case, Chen is also under investigation for alleged embezzlement of public funds by using other people's spending receipts to gain reimbursements from a special "state affairs fund" set aside for his discretionary use for official purposes. His wife has been indicted in this case.
Prosecutors are now investigating whether any portion of the "state affairs fund" had been wired to the overseas bank accounts of Chen's family members during his eight-year presidency.

According to Chen Shui-bian, the money in the overseas bank accounts was the balance of political contributions for his two mayoral and two presidential bids between 1993 and 2004. Chen claimed his innocence, insisting that he didn't use any penny of the "state affairs fund" to line his own pocket.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 8, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. should stand by Taiwanese people: presidential candidate
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/08 12:32:09 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: America should continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan in the future and stand by Taiwan's people, U.S. Republican presidential candidate John McCain said Tuesday.

"I welcome reports indicating that the sale of defensive arms to Taiwan -- a package that has been on hold for too long -- will now move forward, " McCain said in a statement issued Tuesday by his campaign headquarters in Arlington, Va.
The administration is taking a step in the right direction by notifying Congress of its intent to provide weapons aimed at bolstering Taiwan's self defense, he said in the statement.

"I have long supported such sales in order to strengthen deterrence in the Taiwan Strait and to help preserve the peace. American interests in Asia are well-served through faithful implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act, and if I am fortunate enough to be elected President, I will continue the longstanding and close ties between our peoples," McCain said.

The Pentagon's Defense Cooperation Security Agency on Oct. 3 notified Congress that it had approved the sale of a package of weapons to Taiwan, including 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 advanced capability Patriot (PAC-3) missiles, 32 Harpoon sub-launched missiles, 182 guided Javelin missile rounds, and four E-2T system upgrades.

But the U.S. did not approve Taiwan's requests for 64 Black Hawk helicopters and 8 diesel-electric submarines, nor did it accept a letter asking the U.S. to sell Taiwan advanced F-16C/D fighters, a decision McCain disagreed with.
"I urge the administration to reconsider this decision, in light of its previous commitment to provide submarines and America's previous sales of F-16s," the statement said.

"These sales -- which could translate into tens of thousands of jobs here at home -- would help retain America's edge in the production of advanced weaponry and represent a positive sign in these difficult economic times."

While McCain did not discount the importance of seeking cooperative and productive relations with China, he argued promoting the improvement of cross- strait relations meant bolstering Taiwan's defense capabilities.
"We should understand that the possibility of productive ties between Taiwan and China are enhanced, not diminished, when Taipei speaks from a position of strength," McCain said in the statement.

"I believe that America should continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan in the future, in accordance with its security requirements, and stand by this remarkable free and democratic people," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Arms sales in accordance with Taiwan Relations Act: spokesmen
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) 10/08/08 14:20:54 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: In an attempt to defuse China's anger over its decision to sell advanced weapons to Taiwan, the United States insisted Tuesday that the sale was approved in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, which permits the selling of defensive systems to the island.

China has canceled a series of military-to-military contacts with the U.S. and China's ambassador to the United States, Zhou Wenzhong, lodged a protest at the State Department after the Bush administration notified Congress Oct. 3 that it had approved sales of US$6.46 billion worth of weapons to Taiwan.

The package included 330 Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) missiles, 32 sub- launched Harpoon Block II missiles, 30 AH-64D Block III Apache Longbow attack helicopters, 182 Javelin guided anti-tank missile rounds and 20 Javelin command launch units, and system upgrades for four E-2T aircraft.
Department of State deputy spokesman Robert Wood said at a regular news briefing Tuesday that China's reaction to the sale was unfortunate.

"It's an unfortunate decision that the Chinese have taken. We've explained to them that what we've done is very much in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act in terms of selling defensive systems to the Taiwanese and we'll continue to work with the Chinese on a whole range of issues where we have mutual interests, " Wood told reporters.
Wood said China has basically informed the State Department that some U.S.-Chinese bilateral exchanges may be affected, but would not elaborate on which activities would suffer.

Meanwhile, Department of Defense spokesman Stewart Upton said Tuesday in response to Taiwanese reporters' questions that the People's Republic of China canceled or postponed several upcoming military-to-military exchanges due to the arms sales to Taiwan.

"Bilateral events affected involve senior level visits and humanitarian assistance and disaster relief exchanges that were scheduled to occur between now and the end of November. We are not going to go into further detail on the affected programs at this time, " Upton said.

"There has been no change in U.S. government policy and we have faithfully carried out the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act under which the U.S. makes available items necessary for Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self defense," he said.
"The Chinese reaction is unfortunate and results in missed opportunities," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to guarantee all deposits without limit

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) announced Tuesday night that the government will guarantee all deposits at private and public banks without limit.

The blanket guarantee will cover all types of deposits, including savings accounts, time deposits, checking accounts, foreign currency accounts, negotiable certificates of deposit, and interbank call loans, the FSC said.
Deposits at credit cooperatives, fishermen's and farmer's credit associations, and other financial institutions will also be covered by the guarantee.

The FSC's announcement came just one day after it announced that the Central Deposit Insurance Corp. would increase the maximum amount of deposits to be guaranteed from NT$1.5 million to NT$3 million through Dec. 31, 2009.

The period of the blanket guarantee will be decided over the next day or two, with the decision then being sent to the Executive Yuan for approval, FSC Vice Chairwoman Lee Jih-chu said at Tuesday's press conference.
Lee said the blanket guarantee is a preventive measure to restore confidence and alleviate depositors' concerns about current financial conditions.

Also speaking at the news conference, Chang Ming-daw, head of the FSC's banking bureau, said that the government's revenue from business tax and the Central Deposit Insurance Corp.'s premiums, totaled about NT$24.5 billion a year, will be sufficient to bail out any banks that might default.

Earlier on Tuesday at a legislative interpellation session, Premier Liu Chao- shiuan announced the full guarantee for deposits in Taiwan's banking system and urged citizens not to be too pessimistic about the current financial climate.
He noted that confidence is important and that the government "will protect the people's assets" by guaranteeing all deposits at domestic banks.
Liu further said that the government will strictly supervise domestic banks to make sure that they meet capital adequacy requirements.
He also called for depositors to "trust the government" and for "everyone to work together to get through this difficult situation."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City council speaker released on NT$5 million bail

TEXT.P: Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien, suspected of influence peddling on behalf of pachinko parlor operators, was released Wednesday on bail of NT$5 million (US$153,000) instead of being detained as prosecutors had urged.

The Taichung District Court rejected a request by prosecutors early Wednesday morning to detain Chang, after he was questioned overnight on allegations that he received NT$20 million to help pachinko parlor owners get business licenses.
The court stipulated, however, that Chang is not allowed to change his residence or leave the country.
Chang claimed his innocence after being set free on bail, denying that he used his influence to help pachinko operators acquire operating permits.
Chang contended that he was only "concerned" about the matter because the government had imposed "very strict" restrictions on issuing licenses for such gaming businesses.

The council speaker insisted that he had not accepted any "illegal money" from pachinko operators to get business licenses from relevant authorities and claimed that the pachinko business owner involved in the case was simply a friend of nearly 20 years.
The Taichung city councilor and several his aides were summoned by prosecutors Tuesday for questioning over the allegations.
Prosecutors then asked the local district court for approval to detain Chang because of the seriousness of the case and to prevent him from tampering with evidence, but their request was denied.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 330 points to close at 5,112, with 105,393 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 332 points to finish at 5,086, with 2,516 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 326 points to close at 5,080, with 75 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 207 points to finish at 5,178, with three contract transactions, while June futures were down 301 points to close at 5,065, with 19 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,442 for October, 5,418 for November, 5,406 for December, 5,385 for March and 5,366 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 318.26 points to finish at 5,206.4, on turnover of NT$66.76 billion (US$2.06 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures fell 12.8 points to close at 211.9, with 5,534 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 12.5 points to finish at 210.5, with 89 contract transactions.
March TE futures lost 11.3 points to end at 211, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December and June.
October TF futures moved down 43.2 six points to close at 574.2, with 4,375 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures were down 42.8 points to finish at 570.2, with 121 contracts traded.
December TF futures dropped 42.8 points to end at 569.8, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC president meets Guatemalan counterpart in Taipei

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou presided over a formal welcoming ceremony Wednesday complete with full military honors, including a 21-gun salute, in honor of visiting Guatemalan President Alvaro Colom.

Addressing the ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza, Ma said that Guatemala and the Republic of China have maintained close and cordial bilateral ties since the two countries established formal diplomatic relations in 1935.

He said the ROC values its deep-rooted friendship with Guatemala and will continue to bolster bilateral exchanges, including cooperation in business and trade and exchanges of visits by personnel from the two sides, to deepen the partnership between the two countries.
"The ROC is more than willing to share its development experiences with Guatemala, particularly at a time when the world situation is changing fast," Ma noted.
He said Colom's "extraordinary leadership" is "greatly respected and adored" by the Guatemalan people.
Ma gave Colom a hearty welcome to Taiwan as the first president from a foreign country to arrive to attend the Double Ten National Day celebrations slated for Friday since Ma took office May 20.
For his part, Colom offered his most sincere gratitude to the ROC for its staunch support for and cooperation with Guatemala.
Noting that Taiwanese people are known around the world for their great diligence in work, Colom said the ROC is a role model for Guatemala.

"There are great number of friends of Guatemala in Taiwan, among them Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou, " Colom went on, adding that these people will help increase the cooperation between the two countries.

Colom expressed hope that with their close ties, Taiwan and Guatemala can fight shoulder to shoulder and fare well in the face of mounting global challenges in energy resources, environmental protection, climate change and other critical issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen to hold mountain-climbing activity to celebrate national day

TEXT.P: The outlying island of Kinmen will hold a mountain-climbing activity Friday to celebrate the Republic of China Double Ten National Day.
The Kinmen County government invited all county residents and soldiers stationed on the island to take part in the activity at Taiwu Mountain.
The mountain-climbing event is being held to promote healthy leisure sports and encourage more people to take part in outdoor activities, the government said.
All participants in the activity will receive gifts, free drinks and raffle tickets for a draw to be held at the square outside Haiyin Temple on Taiwu Mountain.
The prizes include 32-inch and 37-inch LCD televisions, a notebook computer, a washing machine and other home appliances.
The activity is scheduled to kick off at 8 a.m. on Yuchang Road at the foot of the mountain.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH defends rejection of heavy-ion cancer therapy project

TEXT.P: Taiwan's level of cancer treatment has kept pace with other countries and will remain among the leaders with proton radiation therapy, Taiwan's health chief said Wednesday, after the Department of Health (DOH) nixed a private foundation's plan to introduce heavy-ion therapy to Taiwan last month.

"Taiwan can already be considered among the leading countries (in the area of cancer treatment), " said DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan at a committee hearing in the Legislative Yuan, when asked by legislators if Taiwan was in immediate need of the heavy-ion therapy to cure cancer.

Yeh said that at present, proton radiation therapy is more proven than heavy-ion therapy, and noted that Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou donated NT$15 billion last year to National Taiwan University Hospital to build Taiwan's first proton therapy center.

The questions were raised after Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa angrily denounced the DOH Monday for rejecting his private foundation's proposal to build a cancer center equipped with a heavy-ion treatment facility.
Dissatisfied with the government's response, Chang said his foundation had abandoned the project and that he would dismiss the team responsible for making related preparations.
Advocates of the relatively untested heavy-ion radiotherapy believe it is more effective at killing tumors than proton therapy while damaging less healthy tissue in the process.
The DOH refused to approve the NT$6-10 billion project, however, because it considered the high radiation heavy-ion therapy dangerous and insisted that it first pass human clinical tests.

Shih Chung-liang, director of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs, also said that clinical tests could only be conducted in conjunction with a teaching hospital, and thus the foundation was not eligible to introduce the equipment on its own.
Suggesting that Chang's foundation could cooperate with a teaching hospital, Yeh stressed that he was willing to communicate with the foundation and help realize the project.

He added that studies and proof of the safety and curative powers of the technology should be presented before it is introduced to Taiwan. If there is insufficient evidence or its efficacy varies with different ethnic groups, human tests are needed to verify its safety.

There are currently only three heavy-ion treatment facilities in the world -- two in Japan and one in Germany -- while 29 proton treatment facilities are functioning in 13 countries in the world, according to the DOH.
Cancer ranks first among causes of death in Taiwan for about two decades. It claimed more than 40,000 lives last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices tumble on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged 318.26 points, or 5.76 percent, Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, to close at 5,206.4.
Suffering a drop from gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 5,374.27 and fluctuated between 5,411.72 and 5,206.4.
A total of 3.21 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$66.76 billion (US$2.06 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 6.7 percent. Cement stocks and construction issues both declined 6.2 percent, textile stocks lost 5.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 5.7 percent, paper and pulp issues dropped 4.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were down 4.7 percent and foodstuff issues declined 4.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,541 to 137, with 238 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$9.49 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung commission promises to up number of polling booths

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Election Commission (KEC) promised Wednesday to increase the number of polling booths from the originally planned 145 to 203 for an upcoming referendum on reducing class sizes at elementary and junior high schools in the southern port city.
The referendum, to be held Nov. 15 on cutting class sizes from 35 to 25 students, is the first city-wide referendum to be staged since the amendment of the country's Referendum Act.

Chen Bao-te, deputy secretary-general of the KEC, made the promise to increase the number of polling booths in response to a petition filed that same day during a rally by more than 100 teachers led by Kaohsiung Teachers' Association (KTA) President Yu Chu-cheng.
The teachers held the rally to express their concerns about the fact that the low number of polling booths could affect voter turnout.

Cheng Ming-shan, a member of the association's board of directors, said the city government was "acting out of tune" with the wishes of the people, noting that more than 57,470 residents of the city had signed the petition on applying to hold the referendum.

Several city councilors joined the teachers in the rally to give their moral support and express the hope that the referendum will be passed for the sake of improving the quality of the city's education system.
Chen said the KEC will announce the locations of the additional polling stations by Oct. 20 and that the total cost of the operation is estimated at about NT$11.5 million.

The KTA has been holding large-scale campaigns recently to drum up support for the referendum, although many city officials have been arguing against it, pointing out that the government will have to shell out an additional NT$32 million per year for extra teaching staff and classrooms if the referendum is passed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.098 to close at NT$32.448.
A total of US$1.32 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.350 and reached a high of NT$32.500.

DOC.HEADLINE: Various local elections could be integrated by 2014

TEXT.P: A legislative committee preliminarily passed a draft amendment Wednesday which stipulates that seven categories of local elections in the country should be integrated into one in six years, to save costs.

The amendment, passed by the Legislative Yuan's Internal Administration Committee, stipulates that beginning in 2014, elections of mayors of special municipalities -- namely Taipei City and Kaohsiung City; council members of special municipalities; mayors and magistrates of counties; counties' council members; borough chiefs; township chiefs; and representatives of township councils will be held simultaneously in one election.
The purpose of the amendment, authored by ruling Kuomintang legislators Hsieh Kuo-liang, Wu Yu-sheng and Lee Chia-chin, is to save taxpayers' money on running too many elections.

Welcoming the proposed amendment, Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang said that in the past, the country had squandered immeasurable amounts of money, time and resources on various and frequent elections.
These elections also included nationwide presidential and legislative elections.

"If the draft amendment is passed into law, the nation will see its expenditures from national coffers and expenditures for political mobilization by local communities on elections reduced remarkably, " Chien said.
The draft amendment will have to clear the legislative floor, in a second and third reading, before it can be passed into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to build up image to help fruit exports to China

TEXT.P: Taiwan has to build up a brand image for its fruit and establish connections with big distributors in China to market its produce in an orderly and stable way, Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said Wednesday.
Chen was addressing concerns by legislators at a legislative committee meeting about Taiwanese fruit and flower exports to the world.

The lawmakers urged the government to formulate a quality agriculture development statute to help fruit and flower exports and enhance competitiveness. For instance, they said, Taiwan should upgrade competitive edge in butterfly orchid trade as the Netherlands' output is twice that of Taiwan and its production value is three times Taiwan's.
In response, Chen said exporting fruit to China has been listed as a goal of the council for next year.
"The COA will work toward anything that is beneficial to farmers or will help tap the market," he added.
He noted that the first thing needed is to establish an image for Taiwanese fruit, which must be marked with quality assurance labels to differentiate them from fruit from China or other countries.
Taiwan also needs to establish connections with "big and credible" distributors, he added.

On Chinese visitors buying fruit in Taiwan, Chen said that the policy of "taking orders in Taiwan and making deliveries in China" remains unchanged and that the sites for taking orders will be increased in addition to one near the Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan, one of the biggest attractions for Chinese tourists.
The COA has also initially planned to set up delivery sites in Beijing and Shanghai, Chen added.
Legislator Chiu Ching-chun of the ruling Kuomintang suggested that the COA set up fruit parlors in rest areas along the freeways, and treat Chinese tourists to Taiwanese fruit in hotel rooms.
On the sidelines of the committee meeting, meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan and China will donate animals to each other as a "reciprocal" gesture.

Chen's remarks came one day after Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said China and Taiwan will donate animals to each other, suggesting that long-awaited Chinese pandas will come to Taiwan soon.

Chen said the "mutual donation is a reciprocal gesture, " adding that Taiwan will also present animals listed under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) to China. Taiwan has previously donated animals to both China and Japan.
As for the exporting and importing references on the documents, Chen said this will be decided by the Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's highest China policy coordinating agency.
l

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP will stage large demonstration against China: spokesman

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is poised to stage a large demonstration against China in late October or early November when a high- ranking Beijing official is slated to come for a visit, a party spokesman said Wednesday.

"The DPP will stage a large-scale protest against China to express the people's strong desire to protect and underline Taiwan's independent sovereignty around the time when Chen Yunlin, president of the semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), visits Taiwan," DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang told a news conference.
Chen serves as China's top negotiator with Taiwan in the absence of government- to-government contacts between the two sides.

The DPP has set October as "a month of civic activities" and will organize a series of events to highlight its cause, he noted, adding that the party will keep a close watch on the government to see how it responds while Chen is visiting.

Cheng accused President Ma Ying-jeou of falling short of safeguarding Taiwan's independent sovereignty in the face of continued suppression by China and said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will not attend the Oct. 10 National Day celebrations held by the Presidential Office if Ma fails to "correct" his rhetoric concerning Taiwan-China relations.
Ma recently described cross-Taiwan Strait ties as "not links between two states."

"It is pointless to celebrate the Oct. 10 National Day should Taiwan's popularly elected president not dare to recognize that the country is an independent sovereignty. In such a case, how the president could build up the people's fidelity to the nation, " Cheng said.
This is why Tsai has urged Ma to uphold a firm stance toward China regarding Taiwan's sovereign status, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka awards begin accepting applications

TEXT.P: The Council for Hakka Affairs has started soliciting applications for next year's Hakka Contributions Awards, which honor people who have made contributions to promoting Hakka culture, according to a statement released by the council Wednesday.
Local residents and foreigners are welcome to submit applications for the awards. There are no restrictions based on ethnic groups and gender, the statement said.

There are two categories of awards: the Award for Life-time Contributions to Hakkas and the Award for Outstanding Contributions to Hakkas. The latter includes contributions in language, history, literature, art, public affairs, overseas promotion, and youth participation.
Candidates for the life-time contributions award have to have at least 25 years of dedication to Hakka affairs, and society's recognition of their dedication is a must.

Applicants for this award have to be recommended by other individuals or nominated by groups. A maximum of two winners will be selected annually and each will receive a prize of NT$1 million (US$30,810).

Meanwhile, applicants for the outstanding contributions award are encouraged to recommend themselves. They have to be under the age of 35. There will be one winner under each of the award's seven categories, and each winner will receive NT$200,000 of prize money, the statement said.
Jurors may decide to hold awards if candidates do not meet qualifications, the statement said.
The submission period will run through Nov. 30, and detailed information can be accessed at the council's Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports post first decline in 6.5 years

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports dropped 1.6 percent year-on-year to US$21.85 billion in September, the first negative growth since April 2002, due to falling demand from major trade partners amid the global economic volatility, the Ministry of Finance reported Tuesday.

While the value of exports declined, that of imports grew 10.4 percent to US$21.04 billion during the same period, registering a trade surplus of US$810 million, according to customs statistics released by the ministry.

Lin Lee-jen, director of the ministry's statistics department, attributed the drop in exports to the impact of the U.S. financial crisis and weaker global demand for electronic and machinery products, as well as plastic raw materials.

Shipments to China and Hong Kong, the main destinations of Taiwan's exports, in September plunged 16.3 percent year-on-year, the first drop since January 2002, Lin noted, adding that this is the main reason for Taiwan's lackluster performance in exports in September.

A 4.4 percent decline in exports in the same month to six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries - Singapore, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam - also took a toll on Taiwan's exports, Lin added.
In response, the Bureau of Foreign Trade suggested that the government should intensify marketing and promotional efforts to boost shipments.

The value of exports for the first nine months of this year totaled US$204.48 billion, a 14.5 percent growth year-on-year, while that of imports was US$196.01 billion, an increase of 21.6 percent over the same period last year, the statistics showed.

The figures translated into a trade surplus of US$8.47 billion for the first nine months, very close to the goal of US$10 billion originally set for the whole year, said the bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The bureau added that despite the global economic slowdown, the goal is expected to be achieved thanks to a high amount of export orders received by traditional industries, such as textile, petrochemcial and machinery industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-border marriage rate continues to decline: MOI

TEXT.P: Statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) show that the cross- border marriage rate has significantly declined in the past four years, a result of a stricter immigration interview system implemented by the National Immigration Agency, a ministry official said Wednesday.

According to the MOI, the cross-border marriage rate had climbed from 15.69 percent in 1998 to 31.86 percent by 2003, and thereafter declined to 18.29 percent last year, when 24,700 Taiwanese married foreign spouses, of which 14,721 were from China.

"The considerable reduction results from the immigration interview system implemented in late 2003 in an effort to prevent fraudulent marriages, " said an MOI official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The Immigration Agency began to conduct immigration interviews for Chinese spouses applying for entry permits in order to prevent them from using bogus marriages as a ruse to gain entry to Taiwan to work or engage in other illegal activities.
For spouses from other countries, the system was implemented in 2005 and is carried out by Taiwan's representative offices in the respective countries.
"When marriage brokerage companies are prohibited from introducing foreign spouses to Taiwan, the number will probably decrease even further," he went on.

The official was referring to an amendment of the Immigration Law approved by the Legislative Yuan in late 2007 stipulating that only non-profit organizations, rather than commercial businesses, can provide marriage broker services.
The regulation is expected to go into effect by the end of 2008.
MOI data shows that 399,000 foreigners were married to Taiwanese people as of the end of 2007, including 262,000 from China, accounting for 65.76 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's competitiveness continues to slide: WEF report

TEXT.P: Taiwan's competitiveness has been losing ground for five straight years, and this year it has dropped another three places to the 17th among 134 countries in the latest global ranking, according to a just-released report on world competitiveness.

The Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) Wednesday released the authoritative "The Global Competitiveness Report 2008-2009, " an important tool for policy- makers and business leaders in formulating economic policies, and institutional reforms.

Although the report indicated that Asian economies like Taiwan, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, and South Korea performed strongly, it is clear that Taiwan has gone down a sliding path, with eroding competitiveness compared to other countries in the region.

Taiwan's competitiveness sank to 17th place this year from 4th position five years ago, and ranked last among the so-called "four Asian tigers," with the other tigers - Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea - ranking 5th, 11th and 13rd, respectively.
Of the three major sub-indexes - basic requirements, efficiency enhancers, and innovation and sophistication factors - Taiwan scored 20th, 18th and 8th places, respectively.
In terms of education and innovation, Taiwan is doing relatively well, according to the report.

"Taiwan has high enrollment rates at all levels, and the educational system gets good marks for quality," said the WEF, adding that "companies provide a high level of continuing on-the-job training, ensuring that the workforce can adapt to the rapidly changing economy."

In terms of innovations, the report said, Taiwan has a large pool of scientists and engineers, and it benefits from high company spending on R&D and strong collaboration between research institutes and the business sector.
The report indicated that Taiwan led the world on "utility patents" and "state of cluster development" and ranked 4th on "tertiary enrollment."

But the WEF said that Taiwan's financial markets "represent a comparative weakness", and expressed concerns about the "soundness of banks (ranked 117th) and the restriction of capital flows (78th)." It added that public institutions could be further strengthened.

Of the 12 "pillar indexes, " financial market sophistication, ranked 58th and is the weakest link in Taiwan's total competitiveness, while its 7th position in innovation is the island's strongest performance.
The United States tops the overall ranking and Switzerland is in second place followed by Denmark, Sweden and Singapore.

The global competitiveness rankings are calculated from both publicly available data and the Executive Opinion Survey, a comprehensive annual survey conducted by the WEF together with its network of partner institutes. This year, over 12,000 business leaders were polled in a record 134 global economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Nestle, Klim dairy products found to contain melamine

TEXT.P: Health officials in Taipei have examined 39 Nestle and Klim milk powder products and found that 16 of them contained tiny amounts of melamine -- a harmful industrial chemical that has caused a global food safety scare -- the Taipei city government's department of health announced Wednesday.
Nestle, which also produces Klim milk power, is one of the leading brands of infant and adult milk products in Taiwan.

Chiang Yu-mei, head of the department, said the 16 products were found to contain 0.123 parts per million (ppm) to 2.02 ppm of melamine, and that these products must be removed from the city's store shelves.

According to Chiang, the 16 products included the six certified by the Cabinet- level Department of Health on Oct. 2 as containing small amounts of melamine. Among the six products that had already been removed from Taiwan's store shelves were Klim Instant Full Cream Milk Powder and the Neslac Growing Up series, produced in China's Heilongjiang province.

The other 10 products included two Klim Superkid milk powder brands -- respectively for children who are 3 to 5 years old and children who are 6 or older -- two types of Klim milk powder for people aged 50 or over, Nestle Neslac Gold 1+ Growing Up Milk Powder, Neslac Gold 3+ Growing Up Milk Powder, and two products in the Nespray series.
All these milk powder products were produced by Shuangcheng Nestle Co. in Heilonjiang province.
Taiwan has adopted a zero tolerance standard for melamine content in food products, although its newly imported test equipment can only detect melamine levels as low as 0.05 ppm.
Nestle milk products were previously declared as safe because the equipment employed to test them was less sensitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fashion designer's creations on display in Paris
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 6 (CNA) 10/08/08 20:25:19 (By Tsai Hsiao-ying and Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Sophie Hong, a noted Taiwanese fashion designer, is exhibiting her latest creations at the Atmosphere d'Ete fashion show in Paris.
The Oct.5-8 Atmosphere d'Ete show mainly features women's ready-to-wear and accessories collections.
Jean-Pierre Mocho, president of the French Women's Ready-to-Wear Federation, and Republic of China Representative to France Michel C. L. Lu visited Hong's booth at the show Monday.
Mocho, in conversation with Lu, said that more of Taiwan's skilled fashion designers should participate in international fashion shows to promote their work.

Mocho said that he really likes Hong's creations because they exhibit the designer's ability to make clothing so amazing that few Western designers can match her creative use of fabric and design patterns.
"That is why I have invited Hong every year for the past 12 years to take part in the fashion show," Mocho said.
Hong's creations for this year feature a modern collection in a range of colors that include peacock green and they incorporate elements of art and lifestyle in Taiwan.

Hong expressed hope that the ROC government can do more to recommend outstanding fashion designers to participate in fashion shows in Europe so that Europeans can learn more about Taiwan's culture and fashion industry.

Born in Taiwan, Hong in 1997 entered the Taipei-based Shih Chien College -- a higher education institution famous for its department of fashion design. She later went on to study at the Fashion and Creation Department of Dunka Fashion College in Tokyo, Japan.

Hong, one of Taiwan's top fashion designers, has designed costumes for choirs, theater groups and dance companies. Her designs have been displayed at the Musee Galliera de la Mode et du Costume -- a well-known fashion museum in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu faces challenge of preserving old temples
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/08/08 20:55:24 (By Kao Mao-hsiung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The island county of Penghu boasts more than 200 temples that serve as a source of comfort for the island residents who make their living on the seas.

While the 127-sq-km county, consisted of 90 islets off southwestern Taiwan, has the highest concentration of temples in all of Taiwan, most of them are old or have been destroyed because the residents pay scant attention to the preservation of historic relics, conservationists said.

Wang Kuo-yu, a county official responsible for museum affairs, said Wednesday that Penghu residents believe that the bigger and more ostentatious the temple, the greater the honor for their neighborhood.

With this attitude, the residents have often moved to tear down an old temple in order to build a new and bigger one, Wang said. Some construction contractors, in their own interests, have also encouraged and persuaded temple owners to embark on restoration or reconstruction work.
As a result, many valuable historical temples have simply vanished, Wang lamented.
Over the years, many of Penghu's temples that were old but not old enough to be categorized as national historic heritage sites, have undergone renovation -- with disastrous results, Wang said.

Recalling the most notorious example -- the reconstruction of the "Chou Wang Temple" in Makong City in 2001 -- Wang said it was heartbreaking to see an excavator tearing down and destroying most of precious folk art by famous Taiwanese ceramic figurine master Wang Pao-yuan and painter Pan Li-shuei.
"I risked my life to save a few pieces of the masters' works," he said.

Wang Wen-liang, a Penghu resident who specializes in history and culture, recalled that in Penghu, only two temples -- the Chou Wang Temple and Yung An Temple -- owned Wang Pao-yuan's works, most of which were destroyed during the renovation of the temples.

Wang Wen-liang said that temple architecture in Taiwan flourished in the 1960s and 1970s. Many famous artists in different disciplines were invited at the time to help build temples around the country.
Unfortunately, he went on, local governments cannot apply for nation heritage protection for those temples because they are not old enough.

A 2007 documentary film by director Tzeng Chi-hsien featured the life and art of Wang Pao-yuan, 79, who has been involved in the construction of many temples in southern Taiwan over the past six decades.

In the Shichuan district in suburban Makong, Chen Fu-chi, a native folk artist devoted to the preservation of old temples, has drawn criticism because of the means he chose to rescue some works of art and artistic aspects of dismantled temples.
Chen used the pillars and doors of old temples to built a tea house named "Chun Chiao" and decorated the wooden building with ceramic figurines and other small objects from dismantled temples.
Critics accused Chen of having destroyed the antiques rather than attempting to preserve them.

In response, Chen explained that he had stored the collections in a warehouse, but given his limited financial resources, he was unable to properly protect them and some of them rotted or were damaged by insects.
He has no choice but use the antiques "in a pragmatic manner, " Chen said in an interview with CNA.
"If I did not use them to build the Chun Chiao Tea House, there would be nothing to see now," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to imprint agricultural, fishery equipment to prevent theft

TEXT.P: In view of the high rate of theft of agricultural and fishery equipment in the first eight months of this year, the government is considering adopting an imprint method to help prevent stealing, an official said Wednesday.

Chen Yung-fong, chief secretary of the Government Information Office, said that to reduce the theft rate, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi has come up with a method patterned on the hot stamping of motorcycles.

Chen said the Interior Ministry has reached an agreement with the Council of Agriculture (COA) on the matter, and the imprinting of equipment will be launched in major agricultural counties on a trial basis and later expanded to other areas.
Chen made the remarks after Premier Liu Chao-shiuan presided over a meeting at which National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Wang Cho-chun reported on social law and order.

According to Wang's report, in the first eight months of this year, the number of criminal cases, violent crimes and burglaries dropped from the same period last year, while the rate of solving such crimes increased, Chen said.
Overall, social law and order was improving, but the theft of agricultural and fishery equipment was markedly increasing, according to Wang.

NPA statistics showed that in the first eight months of the year, the number of reported thefts of agricultural and fishery equipment was 1,096 -- an increase of 428 cases, or 64 percent, from the same period last year.
This practice is most prevalent in the counties of Changhua, Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Taichung and Yunlin, according to the NPA.
Wang explained that due to the soaring price of metal worldwide, small electric devices and machinery have become attractive to thieves.
Moreover, most of the equipment is usually located in isolated areas such as fields, mountainous regions and along the seashore, which makes it easy for them to be stolen, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Creative glasswork exhibition opens in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: A joint exhibition of creative glassworks by more than 200 glass companies opened Wednesday in the central Taiwan county for a two-month run until Dec. 7

The venue of the exhibition is the Taiwan Glass Hall in the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park in Lugang township. Many of the companies taking part in the exhibition are located in a special zone assigned to the glass industry in the industrial park.
The event is being held by the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Changhua County government, and the Lugang township administration.
Guests of honor invited to the opening ceremony included Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, Lugang township head Wang Mei-hui and economics officials.

Speaking at the ceremony, Cho noted that the Taiwan Glass Hall has attracted 1.2 million visitors since its inception two years ago, making it one of the most popular places of interest in Changhua County.
The Taiwan Glass Hall used to be a demonstration venue for one of the glass manufacturers in the industrial park -- Taiwan Mirror Glass Enterprise Ltd.

Lin Zhao-sui, general manager of Taiwan Mirror who designed the hall, said he hopes that other glass companies will join him in making the hall a world-class attraction by expanding it to make it the largest glass exhibition hall in the world.
The exhibition, under the theme "Taiwan's Beauty, " features creative works on various aspects of life in Taiwan, including its sceneries and natural ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parents found selling kids' identity to human trafficking ring

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) recently cracked down on a Taiwanese human trafficking ring that was smuggling children from China into the United States on Taiwan passports purchased from Taiwanese parents.

The NIA's Border Affairs Corps said in a statement Wednesday that information provided by the U.S. showed that the illegal Chinese immigrants who were arrested in the case had U.S. visas in passports supplied by a Taiwanese human trafficking ring, which was headed by a man surnamed Lin.
In its investigation, the agency discovered that the crime ring had bought the identity of Taiwanese children from parents who were in financial straits.

Using the Taiwan IDs, the human traffickers acquired Republic of China passports by means of a legal loophole that allows a representative to apply for a Taiwan passport and a U.S. visa for Taiwan citizens under the age of 14.
The statement said that 20 Taiwan citizens, including 10 parents from the greater Kaohsiung area in southern Taiwan, were found to have provided IDs to the human trafficking ring.
The parents sold their children's IDs at a price of NT$90,000 (US$2,780) each, the agency said.
The investigators further found that the crime ring employed the strategy seven times in the first half of this year to smuggle 18 children into the U.S.
The agency said it was the largest human trafficking ring it had ever busted.
It said it has taken action to fix the loophole, and it urged local parents not to risk their children's future for small sums of money.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman endorses Taiwanese coffee

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and high- ranking party officials hailed coffee produced in Yunlin County Wednesday and urged the public to buy local products amid a public scare over tainted Chinese foodstuff.

Tsai and members of the DPP's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) each drank a cup of coffee produced in the county's Gukeng township at a news conference ahead of a weekly CSC meeting, in a gesture to help promote local foodstuffs after China-made milk powder and non-dairy creamers sold in Taiwan were found to contain melamine -- a toxic chemical used by Chinese milk producers to give falsely high protein levels in tests.
The DPP chairwoman urged the public to buy locally made products "for the sake of Taiwan's economic development, " as consumer spending has rapidly stagnated over the melamine scandal.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, one of the party's CSC members, also gave a "thumbs-up" to Gukeng coffee.
Gukeng township in Yunlin County in central-southern Taiwan is one of the very few places in the country where coffee is grown commercially.
Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen praised the Gukeng coffee as the world's safest because samples of 45 local coffee brands sent by Yunlin makers for lab examinations all tested melamine-free.

"The 45 companies voluntarily removed their coffee from store shelves and sent their products to be examined after questionable milk powder from China was first detected in Taiwan Sept. 25, " said Su.

According to a spokesman for a Yunlin resort tourism association, local companies had always used coffee creamer imported from Holland and New Zealand until last year, when they began importing cheaper products from China to cut production costs.

"Yunlin coffee companies have sustained combined losses of more than NT$10 million (about US$300,000) in recent weeks after widespread fear over melamine broke out among Taiwanese consumers, " the spokesman pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indonesian maid indicted for allegedly poisoning employer

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutors Office indicted an Indonesian domestic worker Wednesday on charges of causing injury, after she allegedly poisoned the family of her employer with mercury.
Prosecutor Chang An-chen said the worker, known by the name Sukini, is currently being held at a detention center in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, pending a trial.
The alleged victims -- Chang, his wife, and their two children -- are recovering after being treated in hospital and having the heavy metal residues removed from their bodies, Chang said.
The prosecutors said Sukini was employed with the Chang family in the Sungshan district, Taipei City, between June 2006 and March 2007.
Possibly due to discontent, Sukini allegedly broke several thermometers and put the mercury into the family's food.
Chang and his wife later developed symptoms that included hair loss, mouth ulcers and impairment of vision, which are all indicative of mercury poisoning, the prosecutors said.

The two children in the family, aged 3 and 5, were constantly falling because they lacked physical coordination, the prosecutors added. It was found that the mercury concentration in their bodies was respectively 10.42 times and 23.33 times the normal level.

After Sukini ran away from the family, Chang's wife found several broken mercury thermometers in the house, which led her to suspect that the family had been poisoned, and she sought medical treatment, the prosecutors disclosed.

Although Sukini denied any wrongdoing, the prosecutors, based on the fact that she was employed in the Chang home and on the evidence of the broken thermometers, indicted her on charges of causing injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: Double Ten brings good business to hotels in Hualien area

TEXT.P: Hotel rooms in the Hualien area are fully booked for the period Oct. 10 through 12 -- the three-day weekend that begins with the Double Ten National Day on Friday -- hotel owners said Wednesday.

They noted that even private tourist accommodations in the city and county of Hualien are fully booked for the weekend, mainly because many people from around Taiwan want to attend the Double Ten gala night, to be held Friday at Hualien Stadium, and go sightseeing during the two following days.

The hotel owners said that the influx of visitors has caused one inconvenience -- all train tickets to and from Hualien between Oct. 10 and 12 have been sold out, leaving many of their guests without transportation means to go to Hualien or return home on Oct. 12.

Entry to the Double Ten festivities is free, with the public allowed to enter the stadium from 4: 30 p.m. The lineup of performers includes television entertainment program hosts, well-known singers and dancers.
The aboriginal tribes in Hualien will also present their traditional dancing and singing at the event. The gala night will culminate with a fireworks display over the stadium.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Made-in-Taiwan foodstuff' zone enjoys booming sales

TEXT.P: A hypermart chain store in the southern port city of Kaohsiung has seen its sales triple since it established an exclusive "made-in-Taiwan foodstuff" retailing zone earlier this month amid a melamine scare, market sources said Wednesday.

The Dollar hypermart's Mintsu store cooperated with the Kaohsiung city government to create the special zone for the exclusive sale of Taiwan-made foodstuffs after reports of imports of a shipment of melamine-adulterated milk powder from China caused panic among local consumers.
With consumers' confidence undermined by Chinese food suppliers' unscrupulous business practices, foodstuff sales at local stores were being seriously affected, according to market sources.

The Kaohsiung city government then offered to help food retailers set up special zones for melamine-free made-in-Taiwan foodstuffs. Store operators are required to produce documents showing that none of their food ingredients came from China and to send samples of their products for food safety testing.

The Dollar hypernmart's Mintsu store was the first to respond to the city government's call for cooperation in setting up an exclusive Taiwan foodstuff zone to more easily attract health-conscious consumers.

The store sent 60-plus items for testing and more than 30 proved to be melamine- free. Since the melamine-free products were put on sale in the special "made-in- Taiwan foodstuff" zone, sales of those products have increased threefold on average, a store spokesman said.
Many other supermarket and hypermarket chains and bakeries in the city are expected to follow suit in the near future, a city official said.
Melamine, a nitrogen-rich chemical used to make plastics and fertilizers, has been widely used in China to spike watered-down milk to mask the resulting protein deficiency and fool quality tests.
Melamine contamination of baby formula has been blamed for the deaths of at least four infants and kidney illnesses in more than 53,000 children in China.

A shipment of 25 tons of milk powder imported into Taiwan from China earlier this year has also caused a stir in the local food market and led to the resignation of Lin Fang-yue as DOH minister late last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 9, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self- respect."
