DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's central bank cuts key interest rates

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) announced Thursday an emergency measure to cut the country's key interest rates by 0.25 percentage points, in reaction to the International Monetary Fund's (IMF's) call for coordinated policies by economies worldwide to help reverse the global economic downturn.
The step is the second of its kind in two weeks, after the rates were reduced by 0.125 percentage points on Sept. 25.

The latest reduction marked the discount rate further down to 3.25 percent, the rate on accommodations with collateral to 3.625 percent and the rate on accommodations without collateral to 5.50 percent.

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said while weakening overseas demand led to negative growth in Taiwan's exports in September, the ongoing global financial crisis is undermining consumption and investment among Taiwanese, raising the risk of slower economic growth in the country.

Following the relief of inflationary pressure thanks to the fall in oil and commodities prices in recent months, the cut in key interest rates is expected to help stimulate domestic demand to push the country's economic growth, Perng said.
On Wednesday, the IMF warned that the world economy is experiencing a major downturn in the face of "the most dangerous financial shock in mature markets since the 1930s."
The IMF's latest World Economic Outlook (WEO) projects global growth to slow substantially in the latter part of 2008, revising the projected growth rate downward to 3.9 percent for the year.

The WEO has forecast that growth in advanced countries will be close to zero until at least mid-2009, while growth in emerging and developing countries will slow to substantially lower rates than in the recent past.
In Taiwan, growth is likely to reach 3.8 percent in 2008 and drop to 2.5 percent in 2009, according to the WEO.

In an effort to boost confidence in the world financial system, major central banks, including the U.S. Federal Reserve, Bank of England, European Central Bank, Bank of Canada, Bank of Sweden, and Swiss National Bank, cut their key interest rates by a half-percentage point Wednesday.
Meanwhile, the People's Bank of China dropped its key interest rates by 0.27 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. presidential candidate welcomes arms sales to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) 10/09/08 15:20:49 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator and Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama said Wednesday he welcomes the Bush administration's decision to notify Congress of a package of weapon systems for Taiwan.

In a statement issued by his national security spokesperson Wendy Morigi, Obama said he looks forward to fully reviewing the notifications and the accompanying justification of the Department of Defense.
"This package represents an important response to Taiwan's defense needs. This action is fully consistent with U.S. obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act," Obama said.

The Pentagon's Defense Cooperation Security Agency on Oct. 3 notified Congress that it had approved the sale of a package of weapons to Taiwan, including 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 advanced capability Patriot (PAC-3) missiles, 32 Harpoon sub-launched missiles, 182 guided Javelin missile rounds, and four E-2T system upgrades.
The move drew strong protest from China, which has suspended military-to- military exchanges and nonproliferation talks with the United States.
Expressing regret over China's decision, Obama said the discussions should be resumed because they are in the interest of both sides.
Obama said he strongly supports the reduction of tensions between China and Taiwan and he commended Chinese President Hu Jintao and Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou for their efforts in that regard.
"A strengthening of Taiwan's defenses will not undermine the process of reduction of tensions and can actually promote it, " the statement read.
Obama's statement came one day after his Republican opponent, Senator John McCain, said that U.S. White House did not go far enough when it agreed to the items in the arms package.

"The package will not include submarines or new F-16 aircraft, McCain said. "I urge the administration to reconsider this decision, in light of its previous commitment to provide submarines and America's previous sales of F-16s."
Also in his statement, McCain said the U.S. government should continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan in the future and stand by the Taiwan people.

"American interests in Asia are well-served through faithful implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act, and if I am fortunate enough to be elected president, I will continue the longstanding and close ties between our peoples," McCain said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices drop further on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday,
with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 75.69 points, or 1.45 percent, to close at 5,130.71.
Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 5,183.43 and fluctuated between 5,295.05 and 5,130.71.
A total of 3.8 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$74.82 billion (US$2.31 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 3.9 percent. Construction issues declined 3.8 percent, cement stocks dropped 2.5 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 2 percent, banking and financial shares and machinery and electronics shares both shed 1.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares fell 0.9 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,133 to 432, with 349 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.29 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 54 points to close at 5,062, with 110,499 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 64 points to finish at 5,024, with 8,404 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 86 points to close at 4,994, with 115 contract transactions.
March futures increased 98 points to finish at 5,159, with 23 contract transactions, while June futures were up 43 points to close at 5,108, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,116 for October, 5,088 for November, 5,080 for December, 5,061 for March and 5,065 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 75.69 points to finish at 5,130.71, on turnover of NT$74.82 billion (US$2.31 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
October TE futures fell 3.4 points to close at 208.3, with 4,958 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 3.9 points to finish at 206.6, with 254 contract transactions.

December TE futures lost 0.75 points to end at 210.25, with four contract traded, while March TE moved up 0.15 points to end at 211.15, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.
October TF futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 567.4, with 6,041 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures were down 11 points to finish at 559.2, with 354 contracts traded.

December TF futures gained nine points to end at 578.8, with 11 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 6.2 points to finish 561, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abused children could ask for change of surname: amendment

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan preliminarily passed a draft amendment to the Civil Code Thursday which would allow children who have been sexually or physically abused by parents to change their family names to either their maternal or paternal surnames.
The amendment, proposed by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) , stipulates that the option applies to children who have suffered constant parental abuse.

Noting that abusive parents have been grossly negligent in their responsibility to protect their children and give them a proper upbringing, MOJ officials said abused children could file an application for a name change with a district court.
The purpose of the amendment is to champion gender equality and better protect the rights of children, MOJ officials said.

Meanwhile, the amendment also states that when parents are divided on whether a child, born in or out of wedlock, should take the father's or the mother's surname, the parents can settle the matter in a draw at a household registration office.
The draft amendment has to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for screening and approval before it can be put into effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's approval ratings will be published regularly: official

TEXT.P: The approval ratings of President Ma Ying-jeou, as determined in government polls, will be published at specific intervals, the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Thursday.
Commission Minister Jiang Yi-huah made the remarks at a legislative committee in response to inquiries by legislators about the latest approval rating of Ma's performance.

Jiang said the RDEC polls are to be published at intervals of one month, three months, six months and one year after Ma's May 20 inauguration and that the results of the RDEC's latest poll on Ma's performance were released Aug. 19.
In the August poll, Ma received an approval rating of 47 percent, while 36.3 percent of the respondents said they were displeased with his performance.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan received an approval rating of 41.9 percent and a disapproval rating of 37.9 percent in the same poll.
Legislator Liao Cheng-ching of the ruling Kuomintang asked Jiang to analyze the reasons for the decline in Ma's approval ratings in recent media polls.

Jiang said the polls are based on political assessment rather than scientific analysis, but he admitted that the president's sliding approval rating is closely linked to media criticism of gaffes and policy flip-flops by ranking government officials, as well as to lack of clear explanations or strong defense of government policies, and poor communication with the legislature and the media.

Jiang also said that President Ma's campaign promises "will not vanish into thin air, " and that the commission will keep track of their progress. If the government "cannot deliver on Ma's campaign platform, we will have to explain why to the voters," he added.
"In mid-October, the respective government agencies will submit progress reports on their implementation of the president's campaign promises in his first three months in office," Jiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.011 to close at NT$32.437.
A total of US$1.187 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.448 and fluctuated between NT$32.401 and NT$32.508.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC reports new case of dengue fever

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health announced Thursday an imported case of dengue fever that was reported to the CDC by the patient himself.
The man came down with fever and joint and muscle pain soon after his return from a trip to Vietnam on Oct. 3, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting.

Suspecting that he may have contracted dengue fever, the man informed the CDC of his symptoms through the CDC's online self-notification system on Oct. 7 and tests confirmed his suspicions were true, Lin said.
The man will be awarded NT$2,500 as part of the center's measures to encourage individuals to report their disease cases to the center, which helps prevent the spread of diseases, the CDC said.
CDC statistics show that 375 cases of dengue fever have been recorded in Taiwan so far this year, 209 of which are indigenous cases and 166 are imported cases.
Of the total 375 cases, 185 have occurred since the start of summer, according to the CDC.
Dengue is transmitted by the bites of mosquitoes infected with the dengue viruses, according to the World Health Organization.

Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, vomiting and bleeding. The disease is potentially deadly, affecting mainly children, who have weaker immune systems. Early diagnosis increases the survival of patients, the WHO said.
To prevent transmission of the disease, people are urged to clear sources that help breed mosquitoes, such as standing water, including uncovered buckets or drains.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA sees no easing of diplomats visa restrictions in Venezuela

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it sees no signs of Venezuela easing its restrictions on Taiwanese diplomats' visas, but will continue to communicate with the Venezuelan government to find a solution.
Diego Chou, sub-director-general of MOFAs Department of South American Affairs, made the remarks at a regular press briefing in response to reporters' inquiries.
Chou indicated that the visa restrictions announced last year might have been a gesture by Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, who is known for his anti-U.S. attitude, to show solidarity with China.

Venezuela not only canceled the 90-day visa-on-arrival for Republic of China passport holders last March as part of Chavez's scheme to strengthenone China policy, " the South American country also keeps shortening the courtesy visa status for Taiwans officials stationed there, Chou said.

According to the Foreign Ministry, officials of the ministry, the Government Information Office and the Ministry of Economic Affairs posted in Caracas have to renew their visa every two to three months, whereas their visas used to be valid for the duration of their stay.
The Venezuelan government has also imposed a lot of restrictions on the activities of the Taiwan representative office in Caracas, the ministry said.
Of course this serves as an indicator -- an indication of their unfriendly gesture toward us,Chou said.

Nevertheless, the Foreign Ministry is still trying to communicate with the Venezuelan government on the basis of Taiwan's intention to strengthen economic, trade and cultural relations with the country, despite the absence of diplomatic ties, Chou added.
Asked if there is a possibility that Taiwans officials stationed in Venezuela might be expelled, Chou said:I believe they will not go that far.

It is not that they cannot do so, but I guess he (Chavez) does not think it is necessary, given the fact that Taiwan and Venezuela have many substantial relations, he said, citing as an example cooperation in oil fields.

According to a senior official of the MOFA who spoke on the condition of anonymity, the ministry is trying to communicate with the Venezuelan government on the visa issue since relations between Taiwan and China have been improving after President Ma Ying-jeou took office.
The official stressed that the Venezuelan government should take notice of Masmodus vivendidiplomatic strategy and realize that cross-Taiwan Strait relations are now much more reconciliatory.

Ma has been touting amodus vivendidiplomatic strategy to seek more international space for Taiwan and to end the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China for allies. Under this approach, Taiwan will focus on consolidating diplomatic relations with its few existing allies while continuing to build relations with other countries with which it does not have formal diplomatic ties.

In March 2007, Venezuela repealed a 90-day visa exemption for Taiwanese tourists and in June 2007, the Venezuelan government decided not to renew visas for five members of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Caracas. The MOFA reached an agreement with the Venezuelan government in July this year in order to avoid the closure of the Taiwanese representative office there.

However, travel to Venezuela remains difficult since a visa is required to go to the South American country, especially as Venezuela has no representative office in Taiwan. All applications have to be translated into Spanish and be notarized by both Taiwans and Venezuelas representative offices in Hong Kong before being handled by the Venezuelan government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese gains fame for writing articles about Taiwan

TEXT.P: Articles highlighting the beauty of Taiwan by a Japanese graduate student studying at I-Shou University in the southern county of Kaohsiung have drawn great attention among a number of Japanese readers after they were posted on the Website of an overseas Japanese reporters club.

Since moving to Taiwan with her husband 10 years ago, Meiko Fukuoka, a freelance writer and a graduate student of the university's Institute of Applied Japanese, has written numerous articles online describing what she saw and heard in the country.

Her online stories have made a splash in the Japanese community and have also become the main source of topics for Japanese journalists reporting on Taiwan. Due to her writings' popularity, Fukuoka has been hired by several Japanese magazines to write stories introducing Taiwan.
The Japanese writer said she has fallen in love with Taiwan since she and her family moved here 10 years ago when her husband, a construction engineer was dispatched to the island for work.

Fukuoka said that unlike people in other countries, Taiwanese people are very friendly to foreigners and quite conversable. They are not xenophobic, she added, but happy to help people from other countries.
In her view, Fukuoka said, Taiwan's people attach great importance to communication among family members and value the virtue of filial piety and the concept of respect for the elders.

Citing the homegrown blockbuster "Cape No. 7", Fukuoka said it was a rare experience for her to see Taiwan's youngsters and senior citizens jointly stage a performance and share music together as shown in the film, a scene she said is not common at all in Japan's society.

As she has been working to cover news events and write stories based on various topics as requested by various Japanese journals, Fukuoka said she has had tremendous opportunities to get a better understanding of various aspects of Taiwan.

"From the perspective of a Japanese, it is interesting to see many things in Taiwan, " Fukuoka added, citing as an example an interview with indigenous people in Shandimen in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan during which she was impressed by their passion and easy-going attitude, and fascinated by their daily appliances which are splendid, rich in color, and full of aboriginal folk style.
Other things worthy of mention in Taiwan are delicacies, aboriginal dance and festivals, Fukuoka added.
Fukuoka currently lives in Taipei City and commutes between the city and Kaohsiung County to study every week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to lure more tourists from neighboring countries: MOTC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is committed to attracting more tourists from neighboring countries, apart from China, and in particular Japan and South Korea, Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.

"The number of tourist arrivals from Japan, South Korea and other Asian countries has grown this year by more than 20 percent, " Mao said, in response to questions by lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the government's tourism expansion efforts during a legislative committee meeting.

Although Taiwan in July established direct cross-strait weekend passenger charter flights and opened its doors wider to more Chinese tourists, the economic effect of the two measures has been limited, as the number of Chinese traveling to Taiwan remains low, the lawmakers said.

"The government is aiming not just at the Chinese market, but is also eyeing other markets like Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and other Southeast Asian countries, " Mao said. The government has spent over NT$100 million (US$3 million) in tourism promotion campaigns to court visitors from Japan and South Korea, he disclosed.
He expressed confidence that the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan would also increase rapidly in the future.

Touching on the issue of Taiwan and China considering straighter routes for nonstop charter flights between the two sides, he asserted that the Ministry of National Defense strongly supports the relevant plans put forward by the MOTC.
Nevertheless, Mao stressed that safeguarding Taiwan's national security and dignity is the highest priority in the negotiations with China on bilateral transportation links.

The transportation minister told a legislative session Monday that Taiwan and China have reached a high degree of consensus on the projection of new flight routes and that relevant details would be finalized in the two-way talks slated for late October or early November in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Open, eased policies help spur economic growth: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that open, relaxed government policies help spur the country's economic growth, which has been affected by battered global economies over the past several months.

Speaking at a rally held to mark Double Ten National Day, which falls on Friday, Ma said that in the face of the economic sluggishness caused in part by the global economic volatility, the administration has adopted a series of rescue measures to help the public as well as the private sector to weather the economic difficulties, Ma said.

In the meantime, he added, the administration has also taken long-term measures, including relaxing restrictions and adopting more open policies in terms of investment and trade exchanges with China, in an attempt to rev up Taiwan's economy.

Thousands of overseas Taiwanese who had returned to the country to celebrate Double Ten National Day attended the rally, held at the stadium of National Taiwan Sport University in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to watch out for pink eye disease

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan were urged Thursday to be on the alert for a possible outbreak of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis -- commonly known as pink eye disease -- which in recent months has hit nearby Hong Kong.

Given that the number of reported cases of pink eye disease in Hong Kong has risen this year by five folds of that recorded in the area last year, Taiwan's doctors have expressed concern that people in Taiwan, particularly school children, could also be affected this season.

Wei Li-chen, an ophthalmologist with central Taiwan's Taichung Veterans General Hospital, said the island witnessed an outbreak of pink eye disease last October, with school children and junior high school students from Taipei, Yunlin and Chiayi areas being affected the most.

As her clinic has received increased cases of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis in recent days, Wei advised those who have not been infected with the disease to avoid sharing towels, hand-to-eye contact, and eye medicine, and to wash their hands thoroughly before and after contact with their eyes.

For those who have already been infected, Wei suggested that they avoid shaking hands with other people and students should temporarily stop going to school to avoid spreading the disease to their classmates.

Conjunctivitis is caused by an infection or inflammation of the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid and exposed surface of the eyeball. Pink eye usually is brought about by either bacterial, viral, or numerous allergic factors.

Although pink eye is not a serious eye disease, the bacterial causes need to be treated because the symptoms do not go away without proper treatment and this variant of conjunctivitis can be passed on to other people just by coming into contact with the contaminated items.
Conjunctivitis usually looks bad on first diagnosis as the eye can turn bright red, but the worst part is usually the irritation and itchiness.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is characterized by a sudden onset of painful, swollen, red eyes, with hemorrhaging of the conjunctiva, and excessive tearing. Cases of the disease have been detected throughout tropical regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to submit draft law on indoor air quality to legislature

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Thursday approved a draft law on indoor air quality management and will submit to the legislature the bill, which if passed into law could require businesses and public facilities to improve the air people breathe.

Chiau Wen-yan, deputy minister of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , told a press conference that most people in Taiwan spend about 90 percent of their time indoors every day, and that the air quality in an indoor environment has a direct effect on people's health.

After the bill becomes law, titled the Indoor Air Quality Management Act, several central government departments will be authorized to publicize indoor air quality standards based on consideration of the volume of people in a given environment and the health risks involved, Chiau said.

Indoor environments include office buildings, schools, hospitals, factories, banks, movie theaters, department stores, hypermarkets, restaurants, railway stations and transportation vehicles, including aircraft, boats and buses, Chiau said.

After the draft bill becomes law, it will not be enforced until one year later. First offenders will not be penalized, but will be given a warning and a time period to correct the problems. Those who fail to do so could be fined between NT$50,000 and NT$250,000 (US$7,727).

Meanwhile, the EPA's Environmental Analysis Laboratory and National Cheng Kung University's Department of Medical Technology have developed a new biochip that can simultaneously detect up to 10 kinds of airborne disease-causing microorganisms, including four kinds of dangerous fungi: Aspergillus versicolor, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, and Stachybotrys chartarum.
This technological innovation can shorten the time required to test air quality from one month to just a few days.
According to EPA officials, once the legislature passes the legislation, this technology will be ready for use immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bayer to establish two new R&D centers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Germany-based Bayer Group has decided to invest more than US$5 million over the next three years to establish two new research and development centers in Taiwan, its Taiwan operations announced Thursday.

One of the centers will focus on the R&D and industrial application of functional films, which are widely used in the areas of flexible electronics and printed electronics, said Bayer Taiwan's President Steffan Huber.
Huber said that the center will be fully operational by the end of 2009 and that Bayer is expected to funnel 900,000 euros (UD$123,800) annually into the operation during its first three years.
According to Bayer Taiwan, the center will also seek to expand cooperation with local universities in an effort to upgrade its R&D capabilities.
Meanwhile, Huber said, the other center will concentrate on the application of thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) in sports and recreational products.

In 2007, Bayer relocated its TPU headquarters from Germany to Hong Kong and merged with Taiwan Ure-tech Co. -- the largest TPU supplier in Asia-Pacific region -- to become the largest TPU supplier in the world.
With another TPU R&D center in Taiwan, company officials said, the group will have a better chance of maintaining its edge in the region.

Huber told the CNA that he is optimistic about Taiwan's business environment. If direct sea and air links across the Taiwan Strait can be realized, the industrial players surely will be able to further reduce time and costs in maintaining their operations, he said.

Based on its experience of operating in Taiwan for 50 years, Bayer Taiwan urged the government to set up a "single window" -- a one-stop service -- for multinational companies, so that potential foreign investors can more easily enter the Taiwan market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to adjust economic growth for next year: minister

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Thursday that the ministry's estimated economic growth of 5.08 percent for next year will be revised amid the global financial crisis.
Yiin made the remarks when questioned by legislators of a legislative committee about the impact of the world financial crisis on Taiwan.
Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party accused Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's Cabinet of "making up the figures to cheat the people."
"The Cabinet needs to know where the problems are before it can solve them, " Chang said, urging the government "to come up with the right economic measures to tackle the problems."
Rebutting Chang's accusation, Yiin pointed out that the government set the figure before the financial crisis exploded and said the figure will be adjusted downward.

He also said that while the global economy is not in good shape and some developed countries might not see economic growth, the emerging economies could still see growth, citing China as an example in that it might still be able to maintain growth of about 8 percent.
He admitted, however, that Taiwan still has to work hard to overcome the challenges.

Legislator Lee Ching-hua of the ruling Kuomintang asked Yiin how long the hard days will continue, to which Yiin responded that experts have estimated that it will take more than a year for the world economy to bottom out, adding that Taiwan, as an open economy, is definitely affected by global economic trends.

DOC.HEADLINE: First phase of government restructuring decided

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will give priority to the establishment of a Ministry of Culture and Tourism, or will at least complete its organic legislation by May 20 next year, along with that of another five government units in the coming four years, as the first phase of a plan to streamline the government administration, an official said Thursday.

The reform plan, proposed by the former administration, was also part of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign platform when he was running for president in the March election, according to Jiang Yi-huah, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

To better cope with contemporary social changes, the government plans to restructure its executive branch by cutting the number of agencies under the Executive Yuan from 39 to 26, which would include 14 ministries, seven councils, and another five independent organizations.

Besides the Ministry of Culture and Tourism, five other units to be established in the first phase of the plan are: the agriculture ministry, marine affairs ministry, environmental resources ministry, social welfare ministry, and gender equality commission.
Jiang said the plan's preparation committee, consisting of government officials and experts in management, decided at a meeting Wednesday that the plan will be carried out in different phases.
The meeting was convened by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung, Jiang added.
More measures will be discussed in future meetings of the joint committee, including the number of government personnel which each of the new government units will have, Jiang said.
He added that the joint committee will hold a meeting every month as the initial reform requires intensive coordination among government organizations.
To strive for faster legislation, Jiang's commission will propose a draft amendment to allow the administrative overhaul to happen, Jiang said.

He said the new amendment will not be very different from the previous one, and the government will hold public hearings and seminars in the future to introduce measures to the public on how the reform plan will be implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five cities, counties kick off carpooling network

TEXT.P: Five cities and counties in northern Taiwan launched a carpooling system Thursday in an effort to reduce pollution and improve traffic congestion.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu, Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua and Keelung Mayor Chang Tung-jung presided over the formal launch ceremony for the network -- the first of its kind in Taiwan -- at the Taipei county government headquarters.
The five local government chiefs urged the public to take part in the carpooling system through http://intranet.tpepb.gov.tw/carpool.
The idea of setting up the carpool was initiated by the Taipei county magistrate and received the support of the other four local government chiefs.

Although the system is mainly aimed at commuters in the greater Taipei area, residents from the rest of the country are welcome to use the network, with 671 routes and 19 stops for pick-ups and drop-offs.

Nearly 70 routes have been established since the network began operating in late August, and the organizers have estimated that some 26,400 liters of gasoline could be saved and 57,200 kg of carbon dioxide emissions could be cut each year thanks to the practice.
According to Chou, 2,863 people have become members of the carpool network.

Hau said Taipei City will benefit the most from the carpool system because it has 1.8 million registered vehicles, including around 650,000 private cars and a large number of motorcycles -- causing serious pollution.

Chu for his part noted that more than 10,000 school children in the Taoyuan area are ferried to and from school by carpoolers, and both Lu and Chang described the service as a modern society convenience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan targets 4 million foreign tourists in 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan still hopes to attract 4 million tourists from abroad for the whole of 2008, the country's top official in charge of tourism said Thursday.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that despite the fact that global economic volatility has affected the growth in the number of tourist arrivals, the Tourism Bureau will stick to its plan to help attract some 4 million tourists this year.

"We will strive to achieve that goal whatever it takes," Lai said during a ceremony held at the ministry, where the winners of a "most tourist-friendly cities and counties in Taiwan" competition were cited and awarded.
Lai said the 3 millionth tourist this year is likely to arrive Oct. 14.

The eastern county of Hualien won the championship in the category of natural environment as it is home to the Taroko Gorge National Park, an impressive 19-km canyon of marble and granite, and is situated on the east coast facing the Pacific Ocean nestled among mountains as high as 3,800 meters.

The capital city of Taipei was the champion in the category of humanities and history as it is home to National Palace Museum -- which is considered the world's leading museum of ancient Chinese artifacts.
Both Hualien County and Taipei City were awarded cash prizes of NT$600,000 (US$18,519).

The southern county of Chiayi, home to the famous Alishan, and the central landlocked county of Nantou, which is the location of the beautiful Sun Moon Lake, were placed second and third, respectively, in the natural environment category.

Kinmen Island and the central county of Changhua won the second and third places in the category of humanities and history -- with the historic Chukuang Building and the Lukang historic site, respectively.

Some cities and counties were rated as "unfriendly to tourists" because of factors ranging from jumbled, disordered, unprofessional shop layouts and unclear road signs to unhandled garbage, disordered parking lots and sloppily dressed shopkeepers and store clerks, according to the judges of the competition, which was sponsored by the Tourism Bureau and Global View Magazine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural biotechnology program bears fruit: officials

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has successfully helped 42 local companies develop new products and has inspired them to invest a total of NT$1.11 billion (US$34 million) in research and development funds under a national R&D promotional program, officials said Thursday.
The MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) offered assistance to those program under the National Science and Technology Program for Agricultural Biotechnology, the officials said.
Under the program, selected companies were offered R&D subsidies and the IDB also helped them seek technology transfers from domestic research institutes, said the officials.
Among these companies, they said, Farming IntelliGene Tech. Corp. and Fwusow Industry Co. are the two that have produced the most promising results.

According to the bureau, Farming IntelliGene -- a company specializing in viral detection and prevention technologies for aquaculture -- has developed a dozen detection systems, while one -- for white spot syndrome in shrimps dubbed " IQ2000 WSSV Detection and Prevention System" -- was accredited by the World Organization for Animal Health in May.

Bureau officials said that the systems have all been developed with an R&D platform invented by Farming IntelliGene, which has decided to invest an additional NT$500 million to further expand its R&D and manufacturing capacity, as well as develop more viral detection and prevention systems.
For Fwusow, the officials said, its latest product -- a biopesticide -- will be on the market in early 2009 and is expected to generate revenues of NT$3 million.
The biopesticide has been developed based on the E9-11 strain of bacillus thuringiensis and has proved effective against the moths and butterflies that tend to feed on vegetables, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPM plans to establish incubation center for creative industry

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM) is working to obtain a piece of land in the suburbs of Taipei City to build an incubation center for the cultural and creative industry in Taiwan, according to museum curator Chou Kung-shin.

Chou made the announcement during a tea party to mark the 83rd founding anniversary of the museum -- a classical Chinese imperial court-like complex established in the city's Shihlin district in 1964.

The NPM now boasts more than 654,500 works of art, featuring the world's best collection of Chinese historical artifacts and antiquities, including books, documents, paintings, ceramics and calligraphy. The museum, with a main exhibition gallery that covers 15,118.2 square meters, is one of the country's chief attractions for tourists.

The museum management intends to acquire a 5.4 hectare plot of idle land, formerly occupied by a sanitary service school affiliated to the Ministry of National Defense, for the purpose of establishing an innovation and incubation center for the cultural and creative industry in Taiwan, Chou said.
The land, which is now jointly owned by the National Security Bureau and the Taipei city government, is located near the NPM.
The museum's aspiration to build the center is aimed at developing cultural and creative design talent, Chou said.

Exchange exhibitions on innovative works by local and foreign gurus from cultural and creative industries around the world will be held at the center when it is completed, Chou said. It will also host a series of lectures by masters on their unique creative design experiences.

The NPM, which plans to make the center a flagship dedicated to boosting the visibility of Taiwan's creative products in the international community, will also do its utmost to develop the center as a hub for creative industries worldwide, according to Chou.

The center will be a modern garden complex with a multifunctional architectural structure that features aspects of classical Chinese style, Chou said, adding that it will include underground parking lots, restaurants, coffee shops, tea houses and hostels.
Chou expressed hope that the center would also become an international tourist attraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Special forces retirees in battle of a different sort

TEXT.P: A group of retired Army Air Special Services Commando members will climb a mountain in eastern Taiwan Friday to use their highly trained military skills in a different kind of battle - ridding the island's precious mountains of garbage.

As part of a project that began in 2005, the former soldiers -with an average age of around 50, will carry not guns, but digging tools and garbage bags, with their enemy being waste littered by mountain climbers and tourists in the precipitous mountain.

About 20 members of the Special Air Services Commandos Retiree Association and several other soldiers serving in the same special services, will climb Cilai Mountain in Taiwan's scenic Taroko National Park in Hualien County for a three- day clean up mission.

The mountain, also called "Black Cilai, " is located within the northern section of the Central Mountain Range's main ridge and is the source of the Jhuoshuei River that flows over central and southern Taiwan and the Liwu River that passes through eastern Taiwan to the sea.

A big name among Taiwan's mountain climbers, Cilai is well known for beautiful mountain views that come from its magnificent topography constituted by the undulating contours of the Central Mountain Range and the two rivers.
Statistics by the Taroko National Park Administration Center showed 3,971 climbers visited the mountain last year and since January, more than 2,000 people have stepped foot on the mountain.

The retired special forces members will go up by the mountain's main ridge at the north, starting from Cilai's entrance at the Songhseu Lodge, which is 3,200 meters above sea level. They will march toward the direction of the Cilai North Peak at 3,560 meters above sea level.

All participants, including the oldest who is 64 years old, have to meet certain requirements for this mission, such as experience in climbing Cilai and spending nights in high mountains, according to mission coordinator Huang Hsi-jung.

To prepare for the journey, the retirees, who are volunteers, practiced jogging at 5,000-meter stretches, mountain hiking carrying gears weighing 20 kg for 8 kilometers, and bike riding for 30 kilometers every week.
They also meet regularly at Yushan Forward Peak for group training, taking advantage of that mountain's similar geology with Cilai Mountain's, according to Huang.

Many people have joined mountain clean-up activities and have contributed a lot to improving the mountain's environment, but only the special forces retirees can reach the most difficult and least visited areas, according to the national park administration center.
The group will be divided into three teams, with one team consisting of seven members with the best skills trying to climb as far as they can to remove garbage in the most dangerous areas.
A 10-member team will collect garbage along the crest line.

Another 11 members will travel among different sites to carry the garbage out of the mountain, Huang said, emphasizing that the waste has to be carried by labor, instead of by machines, due to the mountain's special topography.
The most difficult part of the climb is an up-slope which has a 400-meter gap of height on the return trip near the mountain's entrance, Huang said.

Most climbers find it difficult to finish that section after two days' difficult climb, thus some of them would dump their stuff there, turning a valley down the slope into what looks almost like a garbage landfill, Huang said.
Huang believes the park administration center's efforts to raise public awareness about the need to keep the mountain clean, has reduced the amount of garbage dumped by climbers.
"I have to say that we have seen less and less newly added garbage each time we visit the mountain, " Huang said.
The association launches a garbage pick-up mission to the mountain twice a year. The last clean-up drive was carried out in the same place in April.
They also helped clean up other mountains like Hehuan Mountain and Jade Mountain, the highest mountain in Taiwan.

In previous campaigns, they found all kinds of garbage on mountains, such as PE bottles, plastic bags, food leftovers, and climbing tools like steel bars and batteries that can cause heavy metal contamination, Huang said.

The team spent five months preparing for this mission. But even with good preparation and confidence gained from continuos training, whether they will succeed remains unknown, because of the hard-to-predict weather.
Changeable weather, as well as unexpected river runoffs and steep drops in the mountain areas pose threat to the participants, despite good preparations and optimistic views about garbage volume.

Directions of dried stream paths on sunny days in the mountain areas could be altered as water runoffs come out after heavy rains, which could force climbers to find alternative paths in unfamiliar territory, according to the Taroko National Park Administration Center.
"Loss of body temperature often happens after rains in the mountain, " said coordinator Huang, who has many years of experience climbing the mountain.
In order to have better control and more correct forecast of the weather, a section chief of the Central Weather Bureau involved in weather radar monitoring will join the team to ensure their safety.

"Tornado, " the section chief's nickname on the campaign's online forum, is also a retiree from the Special Forces. He said the weather for the next three days in the Cilai mountain area will be fine.
But he added that the possibility for rain still exist.
Even Tornado is not sure how the mission will turn out.
"We don't know how far we can reach and how much we can do this time. We'll just try to do our best," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Special task force to be formed for Beijing official's visit

TEXT.P: The government will form a cross-agency task force to take charge of a planned visit to Taiwan by a key Beijing official, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Thursday.

The MAC will be responsible for organizing and convening the panel, which will be composed of officials from relevant government agencies and will take charge of the itinerary of Chen Yunlin -- president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- in Taiwan.

Liu did not disclose other details about which government agencies will be involved or whether the task force will be a Cabinet-level panel or an ad hoc arrangement under the National Security Council.
He also played down concerns over street protests against China to be staged by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and several pro- independence groups when Chen visits.

Chen, who serves as China's top negotiator with Taiwan, is slated to visit in late October or early November to hold talks with his Taiwan counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

In their coming round of talks, Chiang and Chen are expected to discuss the establishment of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and shipping links, the opening of new passenger charter flight routes, joint oil exploration in the Taiwan Strait and cross-strait crime-fighting.
In an ice-breaking meeting in June in Beijing, the two men inked two milestone accords to step up two-way tourism and opening of weekend direct passenger charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schoolgirls in Taiwan demand right to wear pants

TEXT.P: Girls in Taiwan's high schools have begun to challenge their schools' nearly 60 -year-old dress codes that ban them from wearing pants, and under pressure from civil rights groups, education authorities have agreed to review the dress code policy.

Lai You-mei, secretary-general of the Taiwan Gender Equity Education Association, told a press conference at the Legislative Yuan Thursday that a recent letter to a newspaper editor from students at the Taipei First Girls Senior High School about their school's gender-based dress restrictions is not an isolated case.

She said that since early September, civil rights groups have received more than a dozen complaints from schoolgirls who contend that prohibiting girls from wearing pants as an alternative to skirts at school amounts to sex discrimination.
"These schoolgirls are very brave and apparently understand the Gender Equity Education Act," Lai said, adding that any school dress codes based on gender are "plain sex stereotyping and bias."

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue-ying pointed out at the press conference that girls who wear pants instead of skirts are either not allowed to enter their schools or are subjected to various forms of punishment, including reprimands, being forced to stand in the corner, being given a recorded warning, or being made to do laboring work.
"Why can't girls have the option of wearing pants in school? Are the uniforms meant to place them under control?" she asked.
Huang and Lai urged the education authorities to remind all schools by written notice that enforcing gender-based dress codes might contradict the Gender Equity Education Act.
They also told the Ministry of Education (MOE) to review the "outdated" dress code policy within one month.

Fu Mu-lung, a section director from the MOE's Student Affairs Committee who was also present the press conference, promised that the MOE's Committee for Gender Equity Education will hold a meeting within one month to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Six people arrested for baseball rigging

TEXT.P: The Banciao District Court in Taipei County granted a request by public prosecutors Thursday to detain six suspects involved in professional baseball game rigging.

The six detainees are Wu Chao-hui, coach of the T-Rex baseball team owned by the dmedia Corp.; Kuo Teh-chih, spokesman for the team; and four members of a gambling ring headed by Lin Bin-wen, who is also the head of the group that owns the team.

The Banciao Public Prosecutors Office pointed out that their offenses are related to fraud, breach of trust and organized crime and that it was necessary to detain them to prevent them from colluding among themselves.

According to the prosecutors, Lin and Wu would give instructions to the pitcher and the other players on how to play in order to produce game results according to their plans, so that the ring could net huge winnings from their bets.
A day earlier, prosecutors raided 22 locations linked to the suspects and took them in for questioning.
The dmedia T-Rex team was formerly called the Macoto Cobras, but was renamed in February this year after being bought by dmedia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL urged to `consider feelings' of air passengers

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) called on air carriers to think of the feelings of their passengers lest they "lose big by focusing on trivial things."

CAA Director-General Lee Lung-wen made the remarks amid reports that China Airlines (CAL), the nation's biggest airliner, is planning to charge an extra NT$500 from Oct. 16 for passengers who choose front row or aisle seats.
Lee noted that only CAL is planning to charge the extra fees while other carriers are adopting a wait-and-see attitude.

He reminded those who plan to charge extra fees that while they might be able to rake in between NT$3 million and NT$5 million a month, they must not overlook the fury of passengers, which could cause them to actually lose more than they make.

Lee said that civil aviation law and related regulations do not ban airlines from charging extra money and that the CAA will "respect the approach of each air carrier and will only ask them to report to the CAA on the method and content of the extra charges to the passengers."

Lee said that with the era of high fuel prices and the increasingly unfavorable environment faced by the aviation industry, domestic and foreign carriers have adopted various ways to cope with the difficulties.
He noted that these contingency measures include charging extra money for more than one luggage, or even charging passengers who ask for a blanket on long-haul fights.
Carriers might someday even stop supplying food during long-haul flights, Lee said.
If the plight of carriers worsens further, the "user pays" method might become more of a trend, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tour group visits for sightseeing, health checkups

TEXT.P: A 17-member Chinese tour group from Shanghai experienced high-quality health checkups in Taipei Thursday and many of its members praised local medical personnel service attitudes and professionalism.

The tour group was organized by Cathay Financial Group's Shanghai operations and the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council as part of the government's efforts to promote medical tourism.

Members are mostly Cathay Group's life insurance policy buyers, with ages ranging between 30 and 60. Two of them are operators of medical institutions in China and many of them are senior executives of private corporations in the Shanghai area.

Tseng Hsiao-chi, a section chief in charge of health management at Cathay General Hospital, a Cathay Group affiliate, said the Cathay Life Insurance's Shanghai operation hopes the success of the group's trip will serve as a catalyst to attract more Chinese citizens to come to Taiwan for sightseeing and health checkups.

According to Tseng, many of the tour group members told hospital staff that they had undergone similar checkups, including heart and cancer examinations, in Shanghai and found that Shanghai's facilities are generally on a par with those in Taipei.
"However, they said Taipei excels in terms of heath check procedural arrangements, service attitudes and overall levels of medical attention," Tseng said.
Each of the tour group members paid NT$20,000 for their checkup, according to Tseng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma to reaffirm resolve to defend sovereignty in National Day speech

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will reaffirm his resolve to defend the Republic of China's sovereignty and Taiwan people's dignity in the face of division with China in his Double Ten National Day speech, the Presidential Office said Thursday in a statement.
Ma will preside over a ceremony inside the Presidential Office at 9 a.m. Friday to mark the country's Double Ten National Day and receive felicitations from foreign dignitaries.
Later on, Ma will deliver a National Day address at a mass rally in front of the Presidential Office to celebrate the country's birthday.

In his speech, the Presidential Office statement said, President Ma will reassure the public of the government's commitment to carry through its duty of improving their livelihood and mitigate their hardships amid the current global economic volatility.

Ma will also reiterate the government's determination to continue seeking greater presence in the international community and closer exchanges with China even though such links could expose Taiwan to risks as evidenced in the recent global financial crisis and China's melamine scare.

On relations across the Taiwan Strait, Ma will renew his call for the two sides to shelve disputes on political issues with wisdom and gradually expand cross- strait reconciliation so that the two sides will no longer confront each other in the world arenas.
While pursuing cross-strait rapprochement, Ma will also stress the need for the country to beef up its defense capabilities in order to safeguard national security, sovereignty, peace and prosperity.
Friday will be the first Double Ten National Day since Ma assumed presidency May 20.
