DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 10, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announced on Sept. 28 that Oct. 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chungkuo Kuomintang (KMT), also known as the Nationalist Party.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extra-territoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC air force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by U.S. President Richard Nixon to be vice president, resigns before appearing at a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.
1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the ROC armed forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries joining in the celebration.
1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniversary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F-5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.
1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urges his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.
2001: A Republic of China Double Ten National Day parade is held at Yokohama's Chinatown, with more than 300 pro-Republic of China overseas Chinese residents and friendly Japanese people participating.
2001: Steven Newman, the Guinness world record holder for the most number of countries traversed on foot completes his 27th conquest when he arrives at the southern-most tip of Taiwan.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says in his National Day message that the ROC government has not only strongly condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man never upholds a man because of what he says, nor does he discard what a man says because of the speaker's character."

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma Ying-jeou's National Day address

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of President Ma Ying-jeou's National Day address.
Vice President Siew, Presidents of the Five Yuans, Ministers, Distinguished Guests, Ladies and Gentlemen: Good morning!

Today, the 97th National Day of the Republic of China, we celebrate the founding of our nation with joyful hearts. At the same time, we must also be prepared to resolutely face the formidable challenges posed by global economic events and set long-term goals for our nation's development. Only then can we fashion a vision for our future.

Over the past 97 years, our nation has undergone many severe trials. We have traversed an era of national partition, have been buffeted by the whirlwinds of two world wars, and have suffered pain and hardship during the Chinese Civil War. On Taiwan, however, we have steadfastly upheld the ideals of our nation's founding father, Dr. Sun Yat-sen, engaging in democratic reform at every governmental level nationwide. In March of this year, Taiwan accomplished its second change of government, enabling our democracy to evolve in the direction of greater maturity and stability. Intolerance for corruption and insistence on clean government have become our common values. The country has become not only a model for democracy in Asia, but also a beacon of democracy for Chinese people everywhere. This is the historic achievement of all of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Since taking office in May, this administration has been keenly aware of the desire of our citizenry for good governance. Four months on, gaps yet remain between measures adopted and the expectations of our people. To fulfill their hopes, we must remain humble and engage in self-reflection, while continuing to expedite reform, enhance competitiveness, revitalize the economy, and rebuild confidence.

First of all, we need to come to grips with the fact that Taiwan is now facing unprecedented economic challenges. The current financial crisis is one of those that, in the words of former US Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, comes once in a century. In this age of globalization, it is impossible for Taiwan to avoid coming under its influence. To help the private sector get through these difficult times, this government is exploring all possible avenues.

After taking office, this administration immediately launched programs to stimulate the economy through boosting domestic demand, assisting low-income groups, and other approaches. We have also taken forceful measures to conserve energy and reduce carbon-dioxide emissions. In the span of just these few months, our fuel consumption has fallen by one-fifth. More crucial, however, is the imperative to carry out forward-looking, long-term reform.

Just as past oil crises presented Taiwan with opportunities for transformation and development, so too must we meet today's global challenges by initiating large-scale infrastructure projects and revamping our industries to buttress our national strength and reinvent our economy. In response to global changes, we have adopted apolicy of liberalization and deregulation, whereby people and capital can flow into and out of the country more freely, and enterprises can deploy around the globe more boldly.

Concerning basic infrastructure, this government aims to invest vigorously in construction projects that will improve Taiwan's living environment. These include working on river engineering projects, rebuilding roads and bridges, integrating public transportation networks, and rejuvenating local industries. These and other projects are clearly outlined in the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects." We will invest an increasing amount of resources to complete these projects in stages so as to lay a solid foundation for the next cycle of robust economic development.

With regard to reinventing our economy, this government will create a sound investment environment for the private sector. Besides the construction of essential infrastructure, this entails the creation of mechanisms for cultivating talents and the introduction of government policies to encourage private-sector development. We will support the transformation of certain key types of enterprises such as those concerned with conserving energy and reducing carbon-dioxide emissions, those in the cultural and creative industries, high-tech businesses, the biotechnology industry, and the tourism sector. The government will also strive to revitalize traditional industries by providing them with resources and services in a timely manner.

These efforts to spur transformation and long-term development cannot produce results overnight. Yet, just like the Ten Major Construction Projects of three decades ago that laid the groundwork for Taiwan's "economic miracle, " this administration's policy direction and vision are crystal clear: building a future for generations to come and laying a solid foundation for Taiwan's prosperity in the 21st century.

The new administration has taken heed of the public's grievance over corruption in the past. We not only will be law-abiding, but also will hold ourselves to a higher standard, in order to restore the core values of incorruptibility, integrity, honesty, and trustworthiness. Already, we have begun to implement a set of Code of Ethics for Civil Servants to strictly regulate public servants' conduct with respect to social gatherings and the giving and receiving of gifts. To ensure the proper functioning of the five branches of the central government in accordance with the ROC Constitution, after this administration took office, it quickly reactivated the operations of the Control Yuan, thus enabling this independent organ to once again exercise its oversight mandate.

To safeguard social justice and take care of disadvantaged families, this government has implemented the annuitized labor pension system, which covers 8.8 million workers. Further, a number of other programs have either been launched or are in the works, such as the national pension system; a program to benefit low-income people; a plan to work with community and charity groups to help the disadvantaged; benefits for first-time home buyers; support for people who cannot afford National Health Insurance premiums; and the expanded subsidization of lunches for schoolchildren. In short, this government is determined to take care of all socially disadvantaged groups and make Taiwan a beautiful home in which everybody can enjoy security, stability, and peace of mind.

Concerning relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait have resumed consultations on the basis of the "1992 Consensus" after a hiatus of ten years. Our efforts to alleviate cross-strait confrontation, create a new dynamic for peace, and enhance stability in East Asia have won the international community' s affirmation. Holding fast to the principle of "putting Taiwan first for the benefit of the people, " and guided by a policy of liberalization and deregulation, we have pushed forward with direct cross-strait charter flights, visits by tour groups from mainland China, expansion of the "mini-three- links, " and encouragement of Taiwan's businesspeople overseas to list their companies on Taiwan's stock markets. The aim of these initiatives is to create a more open, stable environment for cross-strait interaction.

In the realm of foreign relations, we have replaced the previous confrontational foreign policy style with a diplomacy of the possible as the core of our foreign policy. Our aim has been to defend the sovereignty of the Republic of China, strengthen ties with our diplomatic allies, and improve our substantive relationships with friendly nations-in particular, to re-establish mutual trust and promote bilateral security cooperation between Taiwan and the United States. Further, we handled the recent Diaoyutai Archipelago incident in an appropriate manner, ensuring justice and dignity for the people of Taiwan, while laying a foundation for nurturing a " special partnership" between Taiwan and Japan. At the same time, we have gradually developed our foreign relations and participated with flexibility in more international organizations and activities, thereby expanding our international space. Regarding national defense, we adhere to the principle of "resolute defense and effective deterrence." We are working to strengthen our modern defense capabilities, move forward with the creation of an all-volunteer force, reinforce a sense of honor among our soldiers, and instill in the men and women of our armed forces a firm faith in the meaningfulness of their service in protection of the nation.

We have unshakeable confidence in Taiwan. Taiwan's Olympic taekwondo competitor Su Li-wen is one reason among many. Her persistence enabled her to pick herself up even after her 11th fall. Courage is what inspired Cape No. 7 movie director Wei Te-shen to realize his cinematic dream. It is passion that has driven Ming Hwa Yuan to bring Taiwanese Opera to stages around the world. And then there are the idealism and creativity of countless other talented people that push them to strive for a better future for Taiwan. All are manifestations of the determination and bravery that constitute the " Taiwan Spirit." This spirit is our most precious asset and the wellspring of our collective strength. We are blessed with a very industrious, pragmatic people and with dynamic entrepreneurs eager to do business all over the globe. Our economic fundamentals are strong, our industrial base solid, our fighting spirit unbreakable. We have confidence to revitalize our economy and bring prosperity back to Taiwan again.

The courageous see crises as challenges and opportunities for transformation. Over its 97-year history, the Republic of China has prevailed against difficulties much more formidable than the ones we face today, yet here we stand tall, having created an economic miracle in Asia and established a model democracy. Today, we find ourselves at a turning point in history. Let us, then, strive as one, with unbounded courage and wisdom, to meet challenges, ride out storms, and together ensure better lives for our descendents and peace for all.
In closing, let me wish our nation great success and prosperity!
And may all of us be blessed with health, peace, and happiness!
Thank you!

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwanese representative to Panama to boost bilateral ties
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 9 (CNA) 10/10/08 13:36:46 (By Ramon Huang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Simon Ko said Thursday that he will maintain and continue to strengthen relations between Taiwan and the Central American country.

Ko made the comments while receiving Taiwan expatriate community leaders, diplomatic staff and Panamanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials at the ROC embassy after presenting his diplomatic credentials to Panamanian President Martin Torrijos earlier the same day.
Speaking with CNA, Ko said that during his time in office, Taiwan will continue to fulfill its promises to Panama under various cooperative projects between the two countries.

On launching new projects in the future, Ko said he will consult with the Panamanian government, adding that because Panama is such an important ally of Taiwan, he hopes relations between the two countries will continue to strengthen.
He further noted that he has extended invitations to Torrijos as well as to Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Lewis Navarro to visit Taiwan.
Ko, who was appointed as the new ambassador last month, arrived in Panama City Sunday to assume his post. He presented duplicates of his credentials to Navarro Tuesday.
Prior to assuming his new post, Ko served as director-general of the Department of Central and South American Affairs. He has served in diplomatic posts overseas for more than a decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President pledges to speed up economic reforms

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Friday to speed up economic reforms to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness and rebuild the public's confidence in the country's economy.

Raising the issue while presiding over a National Day ceremony at the Presidential Office, Ma admitted that the policies implemented by his administration over the past four months since his inauguration have failed to meet the public's expectations.

While Ma said his administration will humbly reflect on its failure, he called the people's attention to the fact that the country is undergoing "unprecedented economic challenges" as a result of the global financial crisis.

"In this age of globalization, it is impossible for Taiwan to avoid coming under its influence. To help the private sector get through these difficult times, this government is exploring all possible avenues," Ma said.

Despite the difficult situation, the president said, he has "unshakeable confidence" in Taiwan because the country has a wealth of talent such as Olympic taekwondo competitor Su Li-wen, Cape No. 7 movie director Wei Te-shen, and Taiwanese opera impressario Ming Hua Yuan who is passionately bringing Taiwanese opera to stages around the world.
"All are manifestations of the determination and bravery that constitute the `Taiwan Spirit.' This spirit is our most precious asset and the wellspring of our collective strength, " Ma said.

Ma said he believes the industrious people of Taiwan, combined with its globally minded businesses, strong economic fundamentals and solid industrial base, will together revitalize the country's economy and bring prosperity back to Taiwan.

On Wednesday, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that the world economy is experiencing a major downturn in the face of "the most dangerous financial shock in mature markets since the 1930s."
The IMF's latest World Economic Outlook (WEO) has projected global growth to slow substantially in the latter part of 2008, revising the projected growth rate downward to 3.9 percent for the year.

The WEO has forecast that growth in advanced countries will be close to zero until at least mid-2009, while growth in emerging and developing countries will slow to substantially lower rates than in the recent past.
In Taiwan, growth is likely to reach 3.8 percent in 2008 and drop to 2.5 percent in 2009, according to the WEO.
Due to a drop in the public's confidence in the economic situation, Taiwan's stock index has decreased almost by half from 9,068.89 at Ma's inauguration May 20 to 5,130.71 Oct. 9.
Likewise, Ma's approval rating has also been falling.

According to the results of the latest survey released Aug. 19 by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, Ma received an approval rating of just 47 percent, with 36.3 percent of the respondents expressing dissatisfaction with his performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deregulation, liberalization policy remains unchanged: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that in response to global changes, the administration has adopted a policy of liberalization and deregulation, while the government will be given stronger teeth to bolster safety control and crisis management.

"While our policies of deregulation and liberalization will remain unchanged, this government will make every effort to minimize social risks by strengthening safety controls and crisis-management mechanisms, " Ma said in his speech delivered to the Double Tenth Day rally in front of the Presidential Office.
Ma said that in this age of globalization, it is impossible for Taiwan to avoid coming under its influence.

"Given the growing interdependence among nations in this era of globalization, however, crises related to epidemics, pollution, or finance can spread around the world overnight. The recent global financial troubles and the danger posed by tainted milk from mainland China are two striking examples of such crises, which have heightened our vigilance against potential hazards of integrating ourselves with the rest of the world, including mainland China.
"This is not to say that we must give up eating simply for fear of choking. Rather, we should turn crises into opportunities, " he said.
Invigorating the domestic economy is the administration's top priority, Ma went on, adding that challenges to the country's economy present golden opportunities for reform.
"Currently, we are pressing forward with deregulation in order to expedite economic growth and we are renovating infrastructure to fortify the constitution of our economy," he continued.

"With deregulation, our businesses can bring their competitive advantages into full play, enabling them to become more firmly rooted in Taiwan, while integrating with the Asia-Pacific region and deploying worldwide.

"With comprehensive retooling of infrastructure hardware and software, our businesses will have enhanced power to attract investment and talent from all over the world. Moreover, with our implementation of diverse programs to promote social security and ensure the welfare of disadvantaged groups, Taiwan's society will become fairer, more compassionate and more harmonious," he said.

"To safeguard social justice and take care of disadvantaged families, the government has implemented the labor pension system and a number of other programs to take care of all socially disadvantaged groups and make Taiwan a beautiful home in which everybody can enjoy security, stability and peace of mind, " the president continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers weigh in on president's planned meeting with ARATS chief

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling and opposition parties weighed in Friday on revelations the previous day that President Ma Ying-jeou will meet China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, during Chen's planned visit.

P.K. Chiang, head of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), told Reuters Thursday that Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Chairman Chen Yunlin will meet with Ma when he visits Taiwan later this month or at the beginning of next month.
During the visit, the two sides will sign deals on regular cross-strait flights and direct cargo shipments, according to Chiang.

In response to the news, Chang Sho-wen, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus, said the planned meeting is part of the protocol of foreign relations and is "not inappropriate."

On opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) plans to mobilize supporters to stage a protest during Chen's visit, Chang said that "if the DPP wants Taiwan to be a country, it should not try to obstruct visits by Chinese representatives."
"Taiwan should treat Chen with a magnificent welcome based on the principles of etiquette and should not welcome him with protests and resistance," he added.
According to KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang, the planned meeting represents "a breakthrough in cross-strait relations" and demonstrates Ma's self- confidence in negotiating with China.
Lin further said he expects cross-strait relations to normalize, adding that Taiwan "will still have a voice on the international stage in the future."

Noting that China is Taiwan's largest export market but also its main military threat, Lin said Taiwan needs to keep lines of communication open with China, which includes visits to Taiwan by Chinese representatives.
DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai said that the main issue is not Ma's meeting with Chen during his visit.
"What the public objects to is that President Ma doesn't dare to insist on his status as president and doesn't dare to insist that Taiwan is a country," Lai said.
He added that the people are opposed to Ma "sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty and disregarding the Taiwanese people's rights and interests" in his dealings with China.
As for lawmakers of the ruling party, Lai claimed, they have been embellishing the benefits to Taiwan of cross-strait negotiations and "pretending that all is going well."
"They should remember their responsibility to speak on behalf of the Taiwanese people," he added.

Chen's visit will be the highest level visit by a Chinese official to Taiwan. It will also mark the first face-to-face meeting between the heads of the SEF and ARATS since they signed deals on direct cross-strait weekend charter flights and a further opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists in a landmark meeting in Beijing in June this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved cross-strait ties cannot be based on wishful thinking: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations is the shared aspiration of the people of Taiwan, but he added that the administration cannot do so based on wishful thinking.

"In the course of exchanges between Taiwan and China, this administration will surely uphold the principle of `putting Taiwan first for the benefit of the people, '" Ma said in a speech delivered in front of the Presidential Office to mark Double Ten National Day.
"Taiwan's interests cannot be compromised and the dignity of its people must be staunchly defended," Ma went on.
He said that under the guidance of public opinion, the administration has sought since it took office May 20 to resume cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue after a hiatus of 10 years.
"The resumption has substantially alleviated cross-strait tension and enhanced stability in East Asia -- efforts that have won the international community' s affirmation," he said.

Ma said that while differences still exist between Taiwan and China over sovereignty issues, "we hope that the two sides can apply wisdom to shelve disputes and chart courses to steadily extend the political reconciliation achieved in cross-strait relations to the international arena."

"We hope to thereby eliminate unnecessary conflict and confrontation between the two sides in the international community, and create a mutually beneficial situation for Taiwan, China and the world community."

"At the same time, we must maintain a solid national defense so that we can promote peace across the strait without having our security compromised. Let us join together to safeguard our country's sovereignty and our precious island home," Ma said.

Improving cross-strait relations within the framework of the Constitution and through a policy of no unification talks with China, no creation of an independent Taiwan republic and no use of force to settle sovereignty issues is the shared hope of the people of Taiwan. Doing so, however, cannot be based on wishful thinking, he added.

Meanwhile, he said, although his administration has been hard at work, the country's citizenry expects more from the government. "We feel deeply the pain of our people caused by the economic downturn."

"This administration will shoulder the responsibility to end suffering for as long as it exists. We must therefore accelerate the pace of reform and, with firm commitment, unite our forces as a nation to break through economic roadblocks," Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival kicks off in Yilan

TEXT.P: The 2008 Asia-Pacific Traditional Arts Festival kicked off Friday in Yilan City in the eastern county of Yilan with the theme of "Wow, Philippines."

Five Philippine song and dance troupes, including the Bayanihan National Folk Dance Company, Banda Kawayan and MSU-IIT Kalimulan Cultural Dance Troupe, as well as four noted handicraft artists have been invited to take part in this year's festival.

During the festival, which will run through Oct. 19, two Taiwan troupes -- namely the Taipei Physical Education College Dance Troupe and the Lan Yang Dancers -- will perform with the visiting Philippine groups in the spirit of enhancing cultural exchanges, the organizer said.
The festival, being held at the National Center of Traditional Arts in Yilan, will also feature the screening of various films showcasing the beauty of the Philippines' diverse cultures.
In addition, an exhibition of traditional music instruments from Taiwan and neighboring countries -- including the Philippines, Thailand, Myanmar and Vietnam -- will be held through Oct. 11.

This marks the seventh year that the festival has been held since its launch in 2000. More than 20 countries in the Asia-Pacific region have participated in the festival over the years, enhancing exchanges in the areas of traditional arts and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU, UN-affiliated organization to cooperate on rice research

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) on Thursday became Taiwan's first academic institution to sign a research cooperation agreement with the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) , a partnership aimed at conducting rice-related research to boost global rice production.
The agreement, signed by NTU President Lee Si-chen and Robert S. Zeigler, a representative of the IRRI, comes at a time when global rice stocks are at their lowest levels in a quarter of a century.

Many countries in the world have been faced with severe food shortages because rice production has fallen as a result of global climate change and the extensive use of land for biofuel production, Lee said.
The problem is particularly serious, he noted, because rice is the main staple of more than half the world's population.

The United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization warned in a 2007 report that with global rice stocks falling to a 25-year low because of global warming, world rice prices are expected to be high over the next few years.
The IRRI has also asserted that only if world rice production grows 1.2 percent annually by 2015 can global rice supply keep up with demand.

Lee said that NTU, as a leading institute in rice research, is keen to contribute its knowledge and expertise in developing new rice varieties and improving rice cultivation skills to help boost world rice yields and address food shortages.

Bao-ji Chen, the dean of NTU's College of Bioresources and Agriculture, indicated that the IRRI began to conduct exchanges with NTU on rice research a little over a year ago when an exhibition of a new rice species was staged on the university campus.
Chen said the IRRI selected NTU as a partner because Taiwan is situated in a sub-tropical region that is suitable for rice cultivation, and the grain is the main staple of the country.

Under the accord, NTU will serve as an intermediary platform between the IRRI and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the Agricultural Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture, and other academic institutions specializing in rice research, to help promote bilateral cooperation and exchanges, Chen added.
The IRRI, a UN-affiliated organization dedicated to rice research, has maintained cooperative relations with many institutions worldwide.

NTU became the first university in Taiwan to sign a collaborative pact with the international organization, according to Chen, who expressed hopes that through the cooperation, Taiwan's achievements in rice research will be presented in the global arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: People want actions, execution: DPP chairwoman

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairwoman described President Ma Ying-jeou's National Day speech as a "compilation of previous empty rhetoric, " saying that what the people wanted were "actions and execution" that could turn governmental policies into reality.

Tsai Ing-wen made the comment at a summit meeting in Kaohsiung of DPP administrators of seven cities and counties in southern Taiwan. She did not participate in the National Day celebration that took place earlier in the day in front of the Presidential Office.
At the Kaohsiung event, Tsai said that although many people focused on whether she and DPP legislators would attend National Day festivities, she believed the issue was relatively unimportant.

The most important issue is "whether President Ma has the ability to rule the country, whether he is determined to safeguard his own country, and whether he recognizes Taiwan as an independent sovereign country," she said.

She argued that people believe the Ma administration, in its pursuit of closer and more frequent exchanges between Taiwan and China, had gone against the rising Taiwan-centric consciousness developed throught the considerable efforts of the previous DPP government, which ran Taiwan from 2000 to 2008.
She also denounced the current government for failing to advocate Taiwan's sovereignty and accused it of being incompetent and unaware of the people's suffering.

Judging from Ma's 2008 National Day speech, Tsai said she thinks the president is too distant from the people's feeling and reminded Ma that the current "one China" policy was doing serious harm to Taiwan rather than serving as a magic cure for its problems.
Ma admitted in his speech that the policies implemented by his administration over the past four months since his inauguration May 20 have failed to meet the public's expectations.

While saying his administration will humbly reflect on its failure, the president called the people's attention to the fact that the country is undergoing "unprecedented economic challenges" as a result of the global financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 local students gain admission to prestigious French school

TEXT.P: Ten Taiwanese senior high school students have recently gained admission to the preparatory school of France's prestigious "Grandes Ecoles, " the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Friday.

The 10 students, including Lo Lun-si from Taipei Municipal Chien Kuo High School, Lai Yen-ling from National Chiayi High School in southern Taiwan and Huang Chih-kang from Taichung First High School in central Taiwan, will be able to attend the two-year "Classes Preparatoires aux Grandes Ecoles" beginning in early 2009, according to an MOE official.

The 10 students gained admission after passing an examination sponsored by the French Ministry of Education to select outstanding senior high school students from Taiwan for studies at the preparatory school.
The French government will fund the two-year tuition for the 10 students while the MOE will provide them with round-trip plane tickets, the official said.

If the students gain admission to one of the Grandes Ecoles after they finish the preparatory courses, 90 percent of their tuition for the three years of advanced studies will be financed by the French government, the official said.
They will be awarded with master's degrees if they make it through one of the Grandes Ecoles, which produce many of France's top civil servants, politicians and businesspeople.

Four Taiwanese senior high school students gained admission to the Grandes Ecoles preparatory school in 2006 when the French government began to offer free tuition for Taiwan students to study at the school under an academic exchange program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City organizes free health clinic for foreign workers

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Department of Labor will organize a free one-day clinic to provide health checks and medical consultancy services to foreign workers in Taiwan, the department said in a statement Friday.
The clinic will be held from 1: 30 p.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday at the Taipei Railway Station, in a joint effort between the city government and the Tzu Chi International Medical Association (TIMA).

The city department and the non-profit organization, founded by a group of healthcare professionals under the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, will recruit local physicians who speak the languages of Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam to volunteer at the clinic, the statement said.
The services provided will include normal health checks and basic medical treatment for those suffering from depression, eye, skin and teeth problems, and gynecological and internal diseases.

City officials responsible for organizing the service said that as most foreign workers in Taiwan do not speak Mandarin or any of the local dialects, they are usually reluctant to go to a local clinic or hospital when they are ill.
It is the fourth time this year that the city government is organizing a free health clinic for foreign workers.

According to Council of Labor Affairs statistics, as of August, there were more than 373,336 foreign laborers in Taiwan, 125,330 of whom were from Indonesia, 85,639 from the Philippines, 82,643 from Thailand and 79,703 from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business operators hustle to revive MRT underground shopping area

TEXT.P: The people who crowded into the Zhongshan underground shopping mall on National Day may have been surprised to learn that much of the commercial strip had been little more than a ghost town for most of the year.

Now, after a renovation that lasted from the end of 2007 to its grand re-opening Oct. 4, at least one section of the 2-kilometer mall that connects Taipei Main Station to Shuanglian Station to the north is hoping to thrive in today's difficult retail environment.

A total of 81 shops occupy the mall, which first opened in 2000. Since then, it has faced its ups and downs, and with business weak through much of 2007, the city had trouble finding new private contractors this year to operate the shopping area's different sections after contracts with previous management companies ran out.

According to Tsai Jing-cheng, the vice president of the private contractor that re-opened one of the mall's three sections Oct. 4, the underground street was mostly populated in recent months by homeless people who would lie on benches until midnight.
That same stretch now is home to shiny new storefronts, with all 35 booths in the section managed by Tsai's company rented out, although some booths in other areas are still vacant.

To make the contract signed with the city government to operate the mall section pay, Tsai needs to help his tenants generate revenue by capitalizing on the heavy MRT and railway passenger traffic that passes through the Taipei station.
That means focusing on inexpensive goods and fast services that are more likely to compel metro passengers to stop and spend, Tsai said.
The need for speed and convenience is reflected in the choices shoppers have, from clothes, cafes, and home furnishings to video game booths, massage services and barber shops.

To celebrate the Oct. 10 National Day, for example, a barber shop was running a two-day promotion, offering already relatively cheap NT$100 haircuts for NT$10 (US$0.31) , to publicize its fast haircut service.
But consumers should not expect anything more than a simple cut, because the shop does not wash or style hair or offer more time-consuming services.
Next to the barber shop is a massage parlor offering quick relaxation breaks from blind masseurs. Passengers in a hurry who need a bit of pampering can enjoy a 10-minute massage for NT$100.
In addition, several book stores in the area provide 15 to 25 percent discounts on many kinds of publications.

Chris, an American tourist from Los Angeles who strolled through the underground street, told the Central News Agency that the underground shopping area was a good idea, and was just beginning to be adopted in his hometown.
Having bought several T-shirts in the shopping street, he was also happy with the prices, which are considerably lower than those in department stores.

Joe Teltser, who arrived in Taiwan from New York two weeks ago, said he liked the idea even if he initially found it odd after coming from a city where subway stations are not connected as they are in Taipei.
"(The idea of the shopping area) is fine; (the space) is not narrow, and it's shielded from the weather," Teltser said.

According to Tsai, however, generating sales is not always easy, not only because of the tough economic environment but also because of the many restrictions on advertising and promotional events imposed by the city.

"We can't do all the promotional activities we want because of the metro company's regulations, " Tsai said, complaining that stores are not allowed to use loud-speakers or hold events that are "too exciting."
At best, they can only distribute leaflets in front of their stores, which Tsai described as "meaningless."
To attract more shoppers, Tsai plans to enhance the diversity of the stores in addition to insisting on low prices as his main business strategies. His newest idea?
"I'm thinking about introduce a pet shop here in the near future, if the metro company allows it."

DOC.HEADLINE: 20% of herbal medicine samples contain Western drugs

TEXT.P: Eleven out of 54 herbal medicine samples that the Consumers' Foundation had tested recently were found to have been adulterated with Western medicines, a spokesman for the nonprofit organization said Thursday.
At the request of local consumers, the foundation sent the samples for testing to determine whether any of them contained Western medicines, said Hsieh Tien- jen, the foundation's acting chairman.
Laboratory tests showed that 11 of the samples, or 20 percent of the total, were adulterated with Western medicines, Hsieh said.

Four of the samples testing positive for Western medicines originated in China, and one of those even contained excessive amounts of lead. In Taiwan, the permissible lead content is set at 100 ppm (parts per million).

Noting that excessive lead intake can cause renal failure or brain damage, Hsieh called on the public to take medicine prescribed only by licensed doctors instead of purchasing drugs of unknown origin.

According to Hsieh, the remaining seven of the 11 samples that tested positive were all purchased domestically, including three bought from traditional martial art studios, two bought from friends, one bought from a herbal shop and the other bought from a Western medicine store.
All of them contained either painkillers or diuretics that could also damage the kidneys.

Founded in Taipei in 1980, the foundation is an independent, nonprofit organization that aspires to safeguard the rights of consumers, provide legal assistance for consumers pursuing lawsuits, address public consumer protection issues and conduct product testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rare land crab spotted in Kenting

TEXT.P: A species of rare land crab has been spotted in southern Taiwan's Kenting National Park, marking only the third time in history that this type of species has been observed by scientists, sources at the park administration said Friday.

The park's biologists said that the sesarmid crab, named labuanium trapezoideum, was first spotted in Andaman Island, Indonesia in 1837 and biologists did not find another such crab until 166 years later.

In 2003, a group of biologists found several labuanium trapezoideum crabs in Taiwan's eastern county of Taitung and made detailed records of their biological and behavioral characteristics, which was later published in the science journal Crustaceana.

According to the report, the crabs live in a hilly area five kilometers from the sea, and only come close to the seashore during breeding season. The young crabs return to land habitat when they are two to three months old.
The park biologists said that since 2003, however, no other habitats of labuanium trapezoideum crabs had been found in Taiwan.
In mid-September this year, however, an amateur ecologist at the park reported seeing and photographed a "strange" crab, which was later identified as a labuanium trapezoideum crab.
Park biologists noted that the finding indicates not only that the species still exists, but that there may be a new habitat inside the national park.

DOC.HEADLINE: China describes milk contamination as 'accidental' at WTO

TEXT.P: China has insisted at a World Trade Organization (WTO) meeting that the widespread melamine contamination of infant formula in the country was "accidental, " an apparent attempt to play down the latest Chinese food safety furor that has raised health concerns around the world.

At the WTO Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures Committee meeting held from Oct. 8 to 9, a Chinese official acknowledged widespread concern about recent discoveries of melamine in milk powder and other products, according to a WTO official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The WTO official quoted a Chinese official as saying that the contamination was "accidental" and that the Chinese government was also concerned about the issue and making enormous efforts to deal with problem.
Information has been provided directly to consumers, through the World Health Organization's (WHO) Web site and diplomatic channels, the Chinese official was quoted as saying.

Since Sept. 10, tighter controls have been introduced for milk and no contamination has been discovered, with a similar result for milk products after controls tightened on Sept. 20, China claimed, according to the WTO official.

Noting that several countries have introduced import bans, China urged them to base their measures on science, risk assessment and information from the WHO, to avoid escalating the restrictions, and to notify the WTO and its members of the measures, the WTO official said.

Melamine, normally used in industrial applications, was added to diluted milk to mask lower protein levels. Adulterated infant formula led to the deaths of four children from renal failure and sickened more than 54,000 others in China.
Taiwan and many other countries have recalled or banned imported Chinese food products containing dairy ingredients and vegetable-based proteins.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Games to kick off in Kaohsiung as warm-up to World Games

TEXT.P: The 2008 National Games will begin Oct. 25 in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, with the city government promoting the event as a warm-up to the 2009 World Games slated for July 16-26 in the port city.
The two separate sporting events are closely related to each other, said the city's Bureau of Education, the organizer of the National Games, in a statement Friday.
It explained that in the two Games there will be 16 common categories of competitions, and that all of the events are non-Olympics and non-Asian Games sports.
More than 8,830 athletes will compete in 24 categories in the National Games, which will run through Oct. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chair meets seven local government chiefs in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Seven opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) - held cities and counties will jointly sponsor a special agricultural fair to promote high-end locally produced goods, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Friday.
Tsai made the announcement following a meeting with the heads of the seven local governments in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen and Pingtung County Deputy Magistrate Chung Jia-pin attended the meeting.

According to Tsai, the seven local government heads hope that the central government would set up a food safety certification system to help the public select safe agricultural and farm products at a time when the Taiwan people are deeply concerned about substandard products imported from China.
DPP lawmakers have submitted to the Legislative Yuan a law amendment proposal aimed at mandating tighter inspection of Chinese foodstuff and ingredients, Tsai said.
The local government chiefs are pushing the DPP lawmakers to make the bill a priority on the legislative agenda, she added.
The Taiwan people have strong doubts about the resolve of President Ma Ying- jeou's administration to uphold the country's sovereignty during the upcoming visit by a key Beijing official, she said.

They are also skeptical of the government's capability to handle cross-Taiwan Strait dealings, including the consequences of importing from China melamine- tainted milk powder and other products containing the toxic chemical, according to Tsai.
Melamine is a toxic industrial chemical that produces falsely high results in tests for protein levels in food.

Instead of attending National Day celebrations, Tsai visited a Kaohsiung City hypermart earlier the same day to help promote a special zone, the second of its kind in the city, that has been set up in the mart to sell high quality and safe local agricultural goods.

"It is pointless to celebrate National Day at a time when the country's sovereignty, the economy and the people's livelihood are being hit hard, " Tsai said. "It is much more meaningful to take the opportunity to encourage the public to use locally produced goods."
Tsai was accompanied on the tour of the center by Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Tainan Deputy Mayor Hung Cheng-chung and several DPP lawmakers.

Chen said the central government has a responsibility to rebuild consumer confidence in the wake of the melamine scare, and called for a speedy legislation to institute a standard mechanism to strengthen food safety control for the sake of the public's health.
In view of the enthusiastic public response to the Taiwanese product center, Chen Ming-wen said he would consider a similar plan in Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU calls for universal abolition of death penalty

TEXT.P: On the occasion of the World and European Day against the Death Penalty, which falls on Taiwans Double Ten National Day, the European Union Friday called on Taiwan, along with the rest of the world, to take measures to abolish the death penalty.

Benita Ferrero-Waldner, commissioner for External Relations and European Neighborhood Policy, said in a press release promulgated by the Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) that although over half of the countries in the world have abolished the death penalty in law or practice, the global figures for its use remain much too high.

I fully recognize the plight of victims of violent crime, but the death penalty is not the solution,Ferrero-Waldner said, adding thaton the Contrary, it only serves to aggravate a culture of violence and retribution.
The Commission is determined to work towards the universal abolition of the death penalty through all available diplomatic channels and as a leading donor in this field,she added.

The EU encourages public debate, strengthening public opposition and putting pressure on retentionist countries to eliminate the death penalty, or at least introduce a moratorium as a first step, the press release said.

It added that the EU also acts against the death penalty in multilateral fora, such as the United Nations; a culmination of this effort was the resolution on the moratorium on the use of the death penalty, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on Dec. 18, 2007.
EETO Director Guy Ledoux, told CNA that he hopes Taiwan would continue its "de facto moratorium" on the death penalty since the last execution three year ago.
Some very good progress has been seen in Taiwan and we hope that it will continue the moratorium on the death penalty, if abolishment cannot be achieved in the short term,Ledoux said.

Launched by the World coalition Against the Death Penalty on Oct. 10, 2003, the first World Day Against the Death Penalty gathers annually international non- governmental organizations, bar associations, unions and local governments from all over the world to lobby for the abolition of the death penalty.

While a total of 137 countries have abolished the death penalty in law or practice since 2005, the number of government-condoned death penalty sentences and executions around the world sill remain high.

During 2007, at least 1,252 people were executed in 24 countries and at least 3,347 people were sentenced to death in 51 countries, the EU said, adding that 88 percent of all known executions took place in five countries: China, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grounded navy missile boat off southern Taiwan towed into port

TEXT.P: A salvage team of the Republic of China Navy on Friday successfully towed a 150-ton fast-attack missile boat that had been grounded off the coast of Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, into the county's Budai harbor.

Navy Fleet Command spokesman Liu Chih-chien told reporters that the team used two giant cranes to pull the Kuang Hua No. 6 Missile Speedboat out of shallow waters, and that the boat is now berthed at one of the wharves in Budai harbor.
Liu said the hull of the boat is generally in a satisfactory condition, although Navy frogmen who inspected the damage below water discovered five holes in the bottom of the boat.
"The Navy is confident in its ability to repair the boat," Liu said, adding that after a preliminary welding job in Budai harbor, the boat will be towed back to Kaohsiung Port for an overhaul.

The missile boat is a prototype designed by the Navy under its Kuang Hua No. 6 Missile Speedboat Plan to phase out the 50-ton Seagull-Class missile boats. It is 34 meters long and 7.6 meters wide, with a top speed of 34 knots.
The boat ran aground Sept. 25 in bad weather while taking part in the Han Kuang 24 Military Exercise. The 14 crewmen on board were rescued shortly after the mishap.
In the following days, rescue workers from the Navy removed the four Hsiung Feng anti-ship missiles, the navigation system and other important equipment from the vessel.

Under the Kuang Hua No. 6 plan, 30 boats will be built at a cost of about NT$400 million (US$12.29 million) each. The state-run Kaohsiung-based CSBC Corp. Taiwan -- the nation's largest shipbuilder -- began building the boats in November 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic fuel prices lowered by over NT$2 per liter

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic fuel prices were lowered by approximately 7 percent Friday, with the prices for gasoline falling NT$2.3 per liter and diesel prices dropping NT$2.5 per liter.
The price cuts came amid falling international crude oil costs that are now approaching US$80 per barrel, down from a record-high of US$147 per barrel in July.

State-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC), and the private Formosa Petrochemical Corp. both announced the adjustment earlier in the day, with CPC's price cuts to take effect Friday at midnight and Formosa's to go into effect an hour later, at 1 a.m. Saturday.

Following the latest adjustment, the price of 92-octane unleaded gasoline will fall to NT$27.2 per liter, that of 95-octane unleaded will be NT$27.9 per liter and that of 98-octane unleaded will fall to NT$29.4 per liter.
It was the first time that prices for 95-octane and 98-octane gasoline fell below the NT$30 barrier since CPC Corp. adopted a floating pricing mechanism Aug. 7 that reviews prices on a weekly basis.
Price adjustments are made based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urged to uphold dignity with Chinese official
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Oct. 10 (CNA) 10/10/08 22:07:03 (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen urged senior ruling Kuomintang (KMT) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party officials and President Ma Ying-jeou to respect national dignity and the feelings of Taiwan's people when they meet Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan.

"The form of the meeting and other arrangements must pay attention to the issue of the dignity of Taiwan's 23 million people. President Ma was elected by Taiwan's people, and their feelings should be respected, " Tsai said in Kaohsiung City after meeting with the heads of DPP-held cities and counties in southern Taiwan.
"Taiwan's independent sovereignty and Taiwan-centric consciousness are very important and cannot be shunned," she added.

A foreign wire service report said a day earlier that Ma will meet Chen Yunlin, the president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), during Chen's expected visit to Taiwan at the end of October or early November.
The report cited as its source Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , who is Chen's Taiwanese counterpart.
Commenting on the Reuters report, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lian acknowledged Thursday that the SEF and the ARATS were arranging a Ma- Chen meeting.

"As Chiang also met Chinese President and Communist Party General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing in June, a meeting between President Ma and Chen is certainly under consideration and being arranged, " Kao explained.
But he added that the matter will not be finalized before the two intermediary bodies have concluded ongoing talks on the issue.
Chen would be the highest-ranking official from the People's Republic of China ever to visit Taiwan.

The planned Chiang-Chen meeting in Taipei would be a follow-up to a landmark meeting between the two men in June in Beijing, in which two accords on weekend charter flights and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists were clinched.

Should they meet, Chiang and Chen are expected to hold talks on cross-Taiwan Strait transportation services, including the establishment of regular cargo charter flights and regular passenger flights, financial supervisory cooperation and crime-fighting, among other things.
The DPP and several pro-independence groups have decided to hold large-scale protests against China if Chen goes through with the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar marks down Taiwan's projected GDP growth

TEXT.P: Taiwan is unlikely to achieve an economic growth rate of 5.08 percent for 2009 as projected by the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, an academic said Friday.

Noting that Taiwan's economy is heavily dependent on export trade, Wu Chung-shu, dean of the College of Management at National Dong Hwa University in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, said the pace of world economic recovery will determine whether Taiwan's gross domestic product could realize a growth rate of 4 percent for 2009.

"The global financial market seriously underestimated the impact of the American sub-loan crisis," Wu said, adding that the current global financial crisis will further delay world economic recovery and that the public should exercise discretion and remain conservative in making personal financial plans.

"It is too early to predict when the current global financial crisis will be over. Most governments are trying to cope with the problems, although there is not much they can do. People need to be more careful and conservative," he said.

Quoting statistics from the International Monetary Fund's world economic outlook report released earlier this week, Wu said the global growth rate for 2008 was revised downward from the July projection of 4.1 percent to 3.9 percent, and that the previous forecast of 3.9 percent growth for 2009 was also slashed to 3 percent -- the lowest since 2002.

The IMF defined growth of 3 percent as implying a "global recession" and warned that the world economy is entering a major downturn in the face of the most dangerous financial shock in mature financial markets since the 1930s.

Like other major stock markets in North America, Asia and Europe, Taiwan's stock market has also suffered continuous setbacks. Despite a series of government measures to attempt to prop up investor confidence, the Taiwan stock index fell nearly 2,000 points, from 7,046 in early September to 5,130 on Oct. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5,000 guests attend ROCs 97th National Day Reception

TEXT.P: Amid what diplomats described as the most exciting atmosphere in recent years, around 5,000 local and foreign dignitaries and guests joined the Republic of China in celebrating its 97th National Day at a reception Friday.

Hosted by Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou and his wife, the reception was graced by the presence of President Ma Ying-jeou and first lady Chow Mei-ching, who arrived at around 5: 05 p.m. at the Taipei Guest House where the function was held.
Chow wore a purple V-neck evening dress that flattered her slender figure, but sticking to her usual austere style, she did not wear any accessories.

Other guests included Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Guatemala President Alvaro Colom, Gambian Parliamentary Speaker Fatoumata Jahumpa-Ceesay, Saint Kitts and Nevis Parliamentary Speaker Curtis Martin and Honduras Deputy Foreign Minister Eduardo Federico Rosales Ramirez, as well as other foreign guest and members of the diplomatic corps.

"I am so impressed by the grandeur of this years National Day Reception," Nicaraguan Ambassador to Taipei William Tapia told CNA, adding that it was much bigger than the previous year when he attended the function as a member of a special mission to Taiwan.

Hans-Peter Fitze, deputy director of the Taipei-based Trade Office of Swiss Industries, said that this year's reception was the best compared to the previous two he attended, and he made special mention of the traditional Taiwanese and aboriginal cuisine.

With the Baroque-style Taipei Guest House as the backdrop, the world-renowned Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Company entertained the guests, performing on a lotus-shaped stage erected above the pond in the center of the garden.

As nostalgia was the theme of this year's reception, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs invited folk art performers to showcase their talent, which featured flour miniature, paper cutting, calligraphy and art works from Taiwan's aboriginal tribes.
The cuisine at the reception included Taiwanese, Hakkanese and aboriginal dishes, which symbolized the richness and harmony of Taiwan's culture and society.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH tracking flow of residue-tainted dragon fruit from Vietnam

TEXT.P: A shipment of dragon fruit imported from Vietnam earlier this month had been found to contain pesticide residues, but about 18,000 kilograms of the affected fruit have already been sold, food safety inspection officials said Friday.

Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director of the Bureau of Food Safety under the Cabinet- level Department of Health, said samples of the fruit, imported by Kieunga Import-Export Trading Co., were found to contain 0.27 ppm (parts per million) of prochloraz, a pesticide used in the cultivation of a variety of crops such as small berries, mushrooms and rice.
According to Hsieh, prochloraz is not highly toxic and the testing standard for small berries is set at below 1 ppm, but no prochloraz residue is permitted in dragon fruit.

The Pingtung-based trading company in southern Taiwan had sold a large portion of the affected shipment before the test results were confirmed, but officials from the DOH and the local health bureau confiscated the remaining 34 cases of the fruit, each of 9.5 kg.
The company has been required to produce a detailed customer list to facilitate tracking and recall of the tainted dragon fruit, also known as pitaya, Hsieh said.

The company will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$40,000 (about US$1,238) and NT$200,000. In addition, Hsieh said, it may be deprived of the right for six months to take delivery of imported goods before residue testing results are available as an administrative penalty.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Day fireworks show brightens southern city's night sky

TEXT.P: A 50-minute fireworks show, during which 7,813 fireworks were set off, brightened the night sky of southern Taiwan's Chiayi City Friday as part of Double Ten National Day celebrations.

It marked the first time in history that the annual National Day fireworks show was held in the southern city, attracting a huge crowd of spectators, many of whom came from neighboring cities and counties.

The dazzling fireworks presented images of "Double Ten" and plum blossoms -- the Republic of China's national flower -- to celebrate the country's birthday. Also featured in the show were images of the Chiayi City flower known as the Hong Kong orchid.

The fireworks, mainly gold and silver, also formed many distinguishable shapes, such as numbers, geometrical patterns like trapezoids and pyramids, and glittering paths, during the display, enthralling spectators and winning acclaim.
People began to gather at the event's venue -- the city's main stadium -- at noon, even though the show was not to begin until 7 p.m.

Chiayi-born Vice President Vincent Siew presided over the opening of the event. In his brief speech, he urged the public to remain confident in the country's bright future despite the current global financial crisis, given Taiwan's relatively sound economic fundamentals.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Chiayi City Mayor Huang Min-hui and many other local politicians also attended the ceremony to admire the eye-catching display.
The colorful show was followed by a pop concert, which brought the National Day celebrations in the city to another climax.

Meanwhile, President Ma Ying-jeou attended an evening party in the eastern county of Hualien to celebrate National Day. Ma praised Hualien as a mecca for Taiwan's democratic development because its first-ever direct local elections took place in the county which boasts beautiful natural scenery.
In 1950, Ma recalled that Hualien residents first elected county councilors and then elected their magistrate. Both elections proceeded smoothly and successfully, according to Ma.

After more than five decades of development, Ma went on, Taiwan's democracy has matured and evolved into a steady growth period as evidenced in the second transition of power in the wake of the March 22 presidential election. Ma won a landslide in the poll, paving the way for his party, the Kuomintang, to regain power after an eight-year hiatus.
"While celebrating our country's birthday, we should feel grateful for Hualien 's contribution to Taiwan's democratic transformation, "he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct.11, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma receiving John Hambre, head of Washington-based think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies. Date and Time: 11:00 a.m., Saturday, Oct. 11, 2008. Place: Presidential Office. Press Contact: Tel.2311-3731. Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 11, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through Hong Kong merchants.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons, beginning his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain during World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War," and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for literature.
1939: U.S. scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin D. Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration by the government and the Chinese communists announces that an agreement between the two sides has been reached after six weeks of negotiations and that unsolved problems are to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7, carrying U.S. astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle and Walter Cunningham, is launched.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1975: A two-day national conference on "Building a New Asia Through Moral Rearmament" opens in Taipei.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup after Mao's death.
1978: The 1978 World Women's Football Invitational Tournament opens at the Taipei Municipal Stadium with 13 teams from Asia, Australia, Europe, the Americas and the Pacific competing.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhabited islets, located in the East China Sea, is also claimed by Japan and Communist China.
1991: Direct air service between Australia and the Republic of China begins.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique on expanding bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.
1999: Some 7,000 people gather at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei to mourn the death of 2,321 people in the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Chang Yu-hern confirms that Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic have agreed to exchange "temporary aviation rights" with the ROC to facilitate bilateral visits.
2001: Chang Siao-yueh, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs says that the ROC government supports the U.S.-launched war against terrorism and has taken steps to prevent terrorists from laundering money in Taiwan.
2001: The results of the first stage of a nationwide English evaluation examination for people with a junior high school education background are unveiled. The tests are part of a government drive to urge people to improve their English-language ability levels in order to better compete in a rapidly globalizing economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he in this world who is possessed of absolute truth that can order and adjust the great relations of human society, fix the fundamental principles of morality, and understand the laws of creation of the Universe."
