DOC.HEADLINE: Performance of cross-strait charters barely satisfactory: CAA

TEXT.P: The performance of the weekend cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, marred by a decreased number of flight destinations, is "barely satisfactory, " Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Long-wen said Monday.

Over the past 14 weeks since the charter flight services were launched, combined passenger trips on Taiwanese and Chinese air carriers have reached approximately 200,000, with the passenger load factor averaging 84.8 percent, Lee said.
However, he admitted, one of the contributing factors is that Taiwanese carriers are now operating flights from only two Taiwan destinations.
Lee made the remarks when asked about the issue by a lawmaker at ameeting of the Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chao-shun said she believes the performance of the weekend cross-strait charter flights deserves arating of only 25 on a 100-point scale, due to the reduction in the number of flight destinations.
Refusing to rate the performance of the service, Deputy Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver F.L. Yu said the current performance is "acceptable" because it meets market demand.
Flight operations will break even on a passenger load factor of 65 percent and the average passenger load factor of the weekend charter flights obviously has exceeded that level, Yu noted.

Under an agreement reached between Taiwan and China in June in Beijing, five Chinese cities and eight Taiwanese destinations were opened to the nonstop weekend cross-strait charter flight services that were launched on July 4.
The cities were Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Xiamen and Nanjing in China, and Taoyuan, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Taipei, Penghu, Hualien, Kinmen and Taitung in Taiwan.

While five Taiwanese airlines companies provided flights from Taipei, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Penghu and Hualien during the first month, the destinations have been limited to Taipei and Kaohsiung since August.

During further negotiations set to take place between late October and early November in Taipei, the two sides are expected to discuss the issue of opening more Chinese destinations to the services. The suggested locations on the list include Chengdu, Chongqing, Hangzhou, Dalian, Guilin and Shenzhen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Not time yet to halt bourse trading: Executive Yuan

TEXT.P: It is not the time yet for the government to announce a halt to trading in the domestic stock market despite the panic selling that has overtaken world stock markets over the past week, Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Hsieh Hsiang-chuan said Monday.
Although the Taiwan bourse also lost ground last week, it fared relatively better than its U.S. and European counterparts, Hsieh said.

"All we need now is more confidence, " Hsieh said. "The administration is taking every possible measure to stabilize the domestic bourse and calm the investors in the face of disastrous stock nose dives that have sent shudders around the globe.
"I appeal to the country to face the problems courageously and to concertedly work out solutions," he urged.

In a contingency move, the government on Sunday temporarily narrowed the daily limit on share price declines and extended a ban on short selling on the Taiwan Stock Exchange in an attempt to avoid the panic selling that has overtaken world stock markets since last week.

Local shares, which normally are not allowed to rise or fall by more than 7 percent in any trading session, will be limited to declines of 3.5 percent starting Monday, the Financial Supervisory Commission announced Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traffic death toll down in Taipei City

TEXT.P: Traffic conditions in Taipei City have improved markedly, as the number of traffic accidents and traffic deaths have dropped since the beginning of this year, the Taipei City Police Department said Monday.

Forty-four citizens lost their lives in 43 traffic accidents in the first nine months of this year, noticeably down from 70 people in 61 cases for the same period last year, Taipei City police statistics showed.

Of the 44 killed people, 16 were pedestrians, with 14 of them being over the age of 65 years, the tallies indicated. Most of the pedestrians were fatally struck by vehicles -- 12 cars and 4 large trucks -- rushing through the streets in violation of traffic rules.
Taipei in northern Taiwan is the country's largest city and has a population of more than 2.5 million residents. Traffic congestion is common in its busy commercial and business districts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city councilors call for testing of schools' fire extinguishers

TEXT.P: Two Taipei city councilors of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Monday for comprehensive testing of all fire extinguishers at the city's schools.
Hung Chien-yi and Yen Sheng-kuan held a news conference to express their concerns that many fire extinguishers at schools around the city are not up to standard.

In making their appeal, Hung and Yen displayed pictures of fire extinguishers at Lishan Elementary School that posed safety concerns, including missing safety pins from some of the extinguishers' triggers and serious corrosion of several of the canisters.
The councilors expressed doubts about whether the fire extinguishers were merely "serving a decorative function," and they urged the Taipei Education Department to carry out city-wide testing.
Also attending the news conference was Wu Huei-lin, principal of Lishan Elementary School, who said that the manufacturer conducts regular inspections of the fire extinguishers every two months.
Wu said that the school replaces any fire extinguishers that the manufacturer decides are a safety problem.

In response to the city councilors' calls, Wu Wen-chi, a division chief at the Education Department, said that it will ask schools to carry out testing of all their fire extinguishers within the next week.
The Taipei City Fire Department made the same call and asked that the results of the tests be sent to the department, which will then proceed with any necessary follow-up supervisory measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to revise 2009 economic forecast downward

TEXT.P: The Cabinet is expected in November to revise downward the economic growth forecast for 2009, in light of the impact of the global financial crisis, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Tain-jy said Monday.

Addressing the issue during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee, Chen admitted that the original projection of 5.08 percent will be "difficult to achieve" and "probably unattainable."
Chen predicted that the financial crisis will be over by the end of the year, but its substantive impact on Taiwan and the rest of the world is likely to last for some time.
If describing the crisis with weather terminology, Chen said the "typhoon's eye" is looming over Taiwan.
"It is our top priority to secure our financial system to protect houses from collapsing," he said.

Asked by legislators about the verity of a media report that the Cabinet is planning to buy shares of private-owned banks with the National Development Fund, Chen dismissed the report as mere speculation.
Chen said the Cabinet will not take such a measure into consideration because it is unnecessary, as Taiwanese financial institutions are not as leveraged as those in other countries.

The CEPD chairman also indicated that the temporary move to halve the maximum allowable daily drop in local shares from 7 percent to 3.5 percent for one week starting Monday is not suitable to be carried out on a long-term basis because it reduces capital mobility.
He said, however, that the Cabinet has not ruled out the possibility of extending the measure when its run expires at the end of the week.
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned last week that the world economy is experiencing a major downturn in the face of "the most dangerous financial shock in mature markets since the 1930s."

The IMF's latest World Economic Outlook (WEO) has forecast that economic growth in advanced countries will be close to zero until at least mid-2009, while growth in emerging and developing countries will slow to substantially lower rates than in the recent past.
In Taiwan, growth is likely to reach 3.8 percent in 2008 and drop to 2.5 percent in 2009, according to the WEO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer-stricken official halfway to completing dream

TEXT.P: A Tainan County Environmental Protection Bureau official who has been fighting stage 3 colon cancer the past three years was halfway to fulfilling his dream of circling Taiwan by bicycle after arriving in Taipei City Monday.

Hou Chun-yen, the bureau's deputy director, and fellow cyclists who left Tainan Oct. 10 paid a visit to the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and were met by EPA Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen.
Hou and other cyclists joined Shen in the signing of a declaration to push efforts to save energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions in Taiwan.

After their stop in Taipei, Hou and his fellow cyclists hit the road again for the northeastern county of Yilan, where they will start their ride down Taiwan's eastern coastline to the south before returing to Tainan Oct. 17 if everything goes as scheduled.
Hou chose cycling as his primary form of exercise and recuperation after being diagnosed with stage 3 colon cancer three years ago.
To fulfill his dream of cycling around the island before succumbing to the disease, Hou said he began intensive training six months ago to prepare himself physically and mentally.
"Now I found myself even stronger than I was three years ago and I'm more confident in fighting cancer," Hou said.
Hou and his group departed from Tainan at 5 a.m. Oct. 10 and cycled along a northbound roadway and reached the coastal Danshuei township in the northern county of Taipei in less than three days.
Among Hou's fellow cyclists from Tainan County were two elementary school students -- fourth grader Hu Teng-jen and sixth grader Lin Yu-hung.

The two have not complained about their arduous journey on the road over the past three days, and Lin, who noted he has learned a lot on the trip, said completing the round-the-island tour would be an ideal graduation gift for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stocks close lower despite new measures to shore up market

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened lower before regaining some ground with the weighted index losing 110.27 points, or 2.146 percent, to close at 5,020.44 at the Taipei Stock Exchange Monday.

Despite new measures to shore up stock market announced by the government the previous day, including halving the daily decline limit from the normal 7 percent to 3.5 percent, the stock market opened by falling below 5,000 points with all eight categories of stocks dropping.
The local bourse opened at 4,996.06, fluctuating between 5,025.73 and 4,971,36.

A total of 2.2 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$44.88 billion (US$1.39 billion), compared with the previous session last Thursday which saw a total of 3.8 billion shares change hands on market turnover of NT$74.82 billion.
Paper and pulp issues lost the most ground at 3.4 percent, followed by financial and insurance stocks at 3.3 percent, and cement and textile stocks, both at 3.1 percent.
Construction issues fell by 2.8 percent, while mechanical and electronics issues shed 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks fell by 1.4 percent, and foodstuff shares fell by 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,357 to 226, with 252 issues remaining unchanged.

Analysts said that the government's new measures to half the daily decline limit for a week, extend the short-selling ban until the end of the year and coordinate the National Stabilization Fund to intervene may curb the sliding trend, but it will not be favorable to foreign investors who want to unload their shares and ease selling pressure.
A turnaround of Taiwan's stocks will have to wait for investors to regain confidence after panic selling amid the global financial crisis, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing official's visit better before APEC summit: NSC official

TEXT.P: Although the date of a key Beijing official's visit to Taiwan has yet to be set, National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi said Monday it would be best if the visit could take place before this year's APEC summit slated for Nov. 22-23 in Lima, Peru.

Su made the remarks while fielding questions from lawmakers about the planned visit by Chen Yunlin, China's top liaison with Taiwan and president of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Speaking during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, Su said that the issue of whether President Ma Ying-jeou would meet Chen is being arranged by the NSC, the Mainland Affairs Council and ARATS' counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), following past precedents.
Su noted that Chiang Pin-kung, Chen's Taiwanese counterpart in his capacity as SEF chairman, met Chinese President Hu Jintao during a visit to Beijing in June.
Addressing some lawmakers' concerns over the protocol arrangements for a possible Ma-Chen meeting, Su asserted that Ma will certainly uphold dignity and parity when meeting with Chen.

But Su did not disclose whether Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , would attend the annual informal leadership summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on Ma's behalf.

According to Su, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been working on a list of possible representatives for Taiwan to the leadership summit. But Su said he was not in a position to make the list public.

Chen is slated to visit Taiwan in late October or early November, and will hold talks with Chiang in a follow-up to a landmark meeting between the two men in Beijing in June, in which the two sides clinched two accords on weekend charter flights and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists.

Issues regarding cross-Taiwan Strait transportation services, including the establishment of regular cargo charter flights and expansion of weekend passenger charter flights, as well as financial supervisory cooperation and crime-fighting, will be high on the agenda of the second round of talks.
Chen would be the highest-ranking official from the People's Republic of China ever to visit Taiwan.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party and several pro-independence groups have announced that they will jointly organize a large demonstration on Nov. 2 to voice their anger about President Ma's policies of building closer relations with China, and what they consider to be his administration's poor performance since taking office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't seeking tax reduction for the middle class

TEXT.P: As part of efforts to reduce the tax burden for middle-class taxpayers at a time when the economy is in decline, the government is seeking to raise the amount of allowable deductions for personal income taxes, Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Monday.

According to Lee, the government is considering a plan which calls for raising the standard deduction amount for single taxpayers to NT$60,000 (US$1,852) from the current level of NT$46,000 and the standard deduction amount for married couples to NT$120,000 from the current level of NT$92,000.
Deductions for education expenses will be raised from the current NT$25,000 per household to NT$25,000 per person per household.

Meanwhile, both the salary deduction amount and deduction amounts for physically and mentally challenged taxpayers will be raised to NT$100,000, from the current level of NT$78,000 and NT$77,000, respectively, according to a source of the Taxation Reform Committee.

Lee said the plan to increase the amount tax payers can deduct from their taxes will be discussed Tuesday at the Taxation Reform Committee, an ad hoc group established by the government administration to streamline the country's taxation system.
Once the plan is passed by the committee, it will be referred to the Executive Yuan as part of an amendment to the existing laws governing taxation and relevant regulations, Lee said.

Many people are hoping that the amendment can be passed into law before this current legislative session wraps up at the end of this year, so the law could be implemented hopefully by May 2010 at the earliest, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT caucus denies pushing for Cabinet reshuffle

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) denied Monday a media report that some of its members are banding together to push for a Cabinet reshuffle before the end of this year.
Legislator Yang Chiung-ying, also a KMT legislative whip, rebutted the report as sheer speculation, arguing that the KMT caucus fully supports the Cabinet.

According to the media report, Taiwan's five-month-old Cabinet, plagued by low approval ratings amid global financial turmoil, is facing increasing calls for a reshuffle from opposition lawmakers and even some from the KMT itself.

Commenting on the report, another KMT legislator, Hung Hsiu-chu, said some KMT lawmakers might be unsatisfied with the performance of some individual Cabinet members. But none of them are banding together to force a Cabinet reshuffle, Hung said, adding that the KMT caucus would like to see the government stand firm amid the current global financial turmoil.

Meanwhile, KMT lawmakers, including Lu Shiow-yen, Lo Shu-lei, Chen Chieh and Hung Hsiu-chu, raised issues about the reported replacement of Cabinet members during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan Monday.

According to media reports, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der was among those fingered by the lawmakers because of more than 40 percent decline of the local bourse's benchmark index since the new Cabinet took over May 20 and fell below 5,000 Monday for the first time since July 2003.

The embattled Lee, who had served in government finance agencies for three decades before being appointed to his current post, said he has done whatever he could to save the country from the impact of the global financial storm.
Describing his performance as "not bad, " Lee said that although he had not necessarily met the people's expectations, he would continue to humbly face up to the challenge.
Aside from Lee, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan were also blamed for failing to save the plummeting stock market.
In trading Monday, local shares fell below the psychological barrier of 5,000 points before finishing 110.27 points lower at 5,020.44. The decline came despite the intervention of government funds.
Meanwhile, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, a heavyweight KMT member who enjoys high public satisfaction ratings, also expressed his support for the under-fire Cabinet and called for internal party unity.
Hu said it was most important now to pursue political stability and to assist the government in helping pull the country through the current financial turmoil.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.049 to close at NT$32.388.
A total of US$1.393 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.437 and fluctuated between NT$32.343 and NT$32.470.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices nosedive on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market plunged Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for October fell 117 points to close at 4,945, with 62,516 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 129 points to finish at 4,892, with 15,376 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 126 points to close at 4,870, with 106 contract transactions.
March futures lost 138 points to finish at 4,850, with 25 contract transactions, while June futures moved down 148 points to close at 4,835, with 16 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,062 for October, 5,021 for November, 4,996 for December, 4,988 for March and 4,983 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 110.27 points, or 2.15 percent, to close at 5,020.44 on turnover of NT$44.88 billion (US$1.39 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, finished lower.
October TE futures fell 2.75 points to close at 205.3, with 3,943 contracts traded, while November TE futures decreased 4.9 points to finish at 201.6, with 1,199 contract transactions.
December TE futures lost 5.45 points to end at 199, with 14 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures fell 19.8 points to close at 548.8, with 1,198 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures fell by 19.4 points, the daily limit, to finish at 539.8, with 322 contracts traded.

No transactions were recorded for December. March TF futures lost 19.2 points to finish at 529.8, with 21 contracts transacted, while June TF futures fell 19.6 points to finish at 540.6, with five contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP split over former president leads to scuffle

TEXT.P: The split within the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over whether to support or distance itself from scandal-plagued former President Chen Shui- bian surfaced Monday when local and central party officials scuffled with each other over the issue.

Huang Ching-lin, director of the DPP's Taipei City chapter, and a group of the former president's supporters went to DPP headquarters to demand that DPP Secretary-General Wang Tuoh apologize and resign for remarks made two days ago that were critical of Chen.

Wang said Saturday that "emotional and moral support seems to have become a fad" within the DPP, so that many DPP members have neglected the more important issue of what is really right and what is really wrong.
As Wang was not in the office Monday, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Hung Yao-fu received the group.

When Hung addressed the group, however, he bluntly reminded Chen's supporters that "Huang was the first person who called on the DPP to strip Chen Shui-bian's party membership" soon after the former president and his family were hit with allegations of corruption.
Unhappy with Hung's remarks, Huang pushed and then grabbed him, causing the situation to spiral out of control, as supporters from both sides joined in the fray.

Huang later said he had never asked the party to expel the former president and that the Taipei chapter of the DPP had only discussed whether the party should strip the DPP membership of Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, and their son and daughter- in-law.
Claiming that Hung's remarks "smeared my character," Huang said he would not rule out the possibility of suing Hung for defamation.
Hung refused to apologize to Huang over his remarks, however, insisting that he told the truth and that DPP legislative caucus convener Ker Chien-ming could vouch for his statement.

While agreeing that party members at a local DPP chapter have the right to express themselves and hold different views from the party leadership, Hung said they should not lead a group of activists to the party's head office to stage a protest.
"The party central must maintain authority and discipline," he said.
Later in the day, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen expressed regret over the fracas, which she compared to an "accidental blowup."

In an attempt to prevent the party split from getting worse, she asked all workers at the DPP head office not to join any activities that are either in support of or against the former president, and at the same time refrain from expressing personal views on issues related to him.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP caucus calls for redrawing of 2008 budget bill

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus demanded Monday that the 2008 budget bill be sent back to the Executive Yuan to be re- worked.

Speaking at a press conference, DPP legislative whip Lai Ching-te, accompanied by other members of the caucus, said that the projected revenue in the current budget bill is excessive and that the spending plan is not efficient.
Lai explained that the projected revenue amount is not realistic as it is based on forecast economic growth of 5.08 percent, when actual growth is likely to reach just 2.5 percent.
DPP lawmaker Pan Meng-an said that the budget bill's projected tax revenues are NT$40 billion higher than could be expected based on the lower growth forecast.
He added that the projected revenue includes NT$22 billion in the planned sale of shares in Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. which has not been approved by the Legislative Yuan.

In response, KMT caucus deputy whip Wong Chung-chun said that the budget was worked out in May and June and has already been sent to the various legislative committees for review and that it will not be sent back to the Executive Yuan.
Noting that the projected revenue cannot be calculated exactly due to changing economic conditions, Wong said that adjustments can be made to make up for shortfalls in revenue.

He stressed that the budget bill will not be sent back to the Executive Yuan as doing so would affect the process of legislative review which must be completed within a specific time period according to the law.

As for the planned sale of Taiwan Tobacco shares, Wong noted that the KMT caucus is also opposed to it, assuring that the legislative committees will closely review the planned spending in the budget and make cuts as necessary.
He added that if adjustments fail to balance the budget, the government will borrow money to cover the difference.

DOC.HEADLINE: President has no plan to change Cabinet lineup: aide

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has no plans to reshuffle the Cabinet at present, a presidential aide said Monday in response to media speculation that lawmakers in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) are pushing for a new ministerial lineup.

Responding to lawmakers' questions on the issue in a legislative committee hearing, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said the president is not thinking of a Cabinet overhaul at this time.

Out of his concern for people's livelihoods in the face of volatile conditions at home and abroad, the president has encouraged the Cabinet to quickly put policies in place that respond to the challenges and stabilize the local financial environment, Chan said.

Local media has reported in recent days that a group of maverick KMT lawmakers have demanded that the president make changes in the Cabinet in view of the administration's plunging approval ratings since Ma took office in May.

According to the reports, the KMT lawmakers also prepared a list of what they called "failing Cabinet members" that reportedly includes Premier Liu Chao- hsiuan, Finance Minister Lee Sush-der, and Cabinet Secretary-General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC denies brewing plan for Fubon-Taishin merger

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), Taiwan's top financial regulator, denied Monday that it was planning to have Taishin Financial Holding Co. merge with Fubon Financial Holding Co.

FSC Chairman Gordon S. Chen made the denial when asked to clarify media reports that he had met with Fubon Financial Chairman Daniel Tsai in secret on Oct. 9 to find out whether his group might consider a merger with Taishin Holdings.

Fitch Ratings revised its outlook on the group from "stable" to "negative" on Oct. 9, citing its declining profitability and inadequate reserves against unsecured consumer lending. It also suffered from the recent collapse of Lehman Brothers -- one of Wall Street's most prestigious players.
Chen said that he knew nothing about the merger plan, and that he would respect the mechanisms of the financial market.
He added, however, that the FSC would "gladly expect" financial institutions in Taiwan to consolidate through mergers.
Fubon Financial also denied Monday that its executives had ever discussed any merger plan with either the FSC head or Taishin Holdings executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Even with training center, Taichung faces local caregiver shortage

TEXT.P: The Taichung Home Care Services Association, the first group of its kind in Taichung to train and find employment for local caregivers, said Monday it is straining to meet strong demand for full-time help in the central city.

The organization, which trains local residents for the profession and then helps them find employment upon graduation, books jobs for about 80 percent of the 30 graduates it prepares per quarter, said Association Chairman Huang Kuo-ta.
Those who do not get jobs, Huang said, usually decided not to become caregivers after completing their training.

Despite Taiwan's rising unemployment rate, the city's home care service sector still faces a shortage of local manpower amid rising demand, Huang said, leaving many individuals needing full-time care without the help they require.

Those applying to the association for a local caregiver have to wait in a line behind other applicants, much like a 76-year-old ailing grandmother surnamed Chung who has applied for help but has yet to receive it after a 30-day wait.

The lower half of Chung's body was paralyzed three years ago after a traffic accident. Despite having a son and two daughters, none of them can provide the full-time care she needs because of their jobs.

Chung previously employed a foreign caregiver, but eventually fired the employee because of bad communications caused by a language barrier, Huang said, leaving her at the mercy of the local caregiver shortage in the city.

Association Director Chang Chi-fang said most of the applicants are senior citizens like Chung whose family members cannot stay with them. She urged local middle-aged women to join the 90-hour training program that comes with an employment guarantee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy minister to become presidential aide

TEXT.P: Deputy Interior Minister Lai Feng-wei has been tapped to serve as deputy secretary-general to the president, a senior Presidential Office official confirmed Monday.
Kao Lang, another deputy secretary-general to President Ma Ying-jeou, confirmed the appointment during a Legislative Yuan committee hearing.

According to Kao, Lai, a former magistrate of the outlying island county of Penghu, will fill the position left vacant by Yeh Ching-chuan, who replaced Lin Fang-yue as minister of the Department of Health late last month amid a melamine scare.
Kao said Lai's appointment will be formally announced soon.

Lai, 55, has a doctoral degree in industrial engineering and management from the University of Missouri. He has been a section chief at the Atomic Energy Council and headed the ruling Kuomintang's Penghu chapter.
He is known to be versed in grassroots politics and community affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to take to streets to call for safeguarding sovereignty

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that it has decided to hold a protest march on Oct. 25, the nation's Retrocession Day, in Taipei to call for safeguarding national sovereignty and improving the economy.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks after the party held a coordination meeting on major issues during which the party discussed on how to deal with the planned visit by China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , reportedly will visit Taiwan in late October or early November.

"The march is targeted at the government and this is why the DPP will not overly tie the march to Chen's planned visit, " Tsai said, adding that the date of the march was moved ahead one week from the originally scheduled date in late October or early November.

On former President Chen Shui-bian's possible participation in the protest march, Tsai said "anyone who identifies with the call of the march will be welcome to take part, regardless of party affiliation."
On whether Chen's participation in the march will blur its focus, Tsai said she was confident that it wouldn't be the case, citing the Aug. 30 protest march as an example.

That march, called "The People's Outcry, " was organized by the pro-independence Taiwan Society to highlight its call for the protection of Taiwan's sovereignty, improvement of the economy and the enactment of sunshine laws, drawing tens of thousands participants.
Chen Shui-bian, who along with his family members, is facing corruption and money-laundering allegations, said recently that he would take part in the march if he had not been detained.
Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said Monday that the protest march will end at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
After Chen Yunlin's visit, the DPP will hold a "Taiwan-centric" evening rally, tentatively set to be staged in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Cheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75 groups of street buskers accredited in Taipei County

TEXT.P: The Taipei County government on Monday presented 75 groups of street performers with certificates of accreditation, allowing them to stage performances at designated public places in the county.
Officials at the county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau said members of the public are encouraged to tip these street performers generously after watching their performances.

According to the officials, 152 groups of street artists applied for accreditation, but only 75 groups passed muster, a success rate of 54 percent. Their specialties covered a wide variety of skills, including music, acrobatics, juggling, comedy, magic and painting.

The oldest of the accredited street artists is over 80, and the youngest is 17. They will be allowed to perform at Fishermen's Wharf in Danshuei, in plazas outside Taipei County museums, and other designated places of interest.

The officials disclosed that their bureau will hold a carnival on Oct. 18 at Taipei County's Citizen Plaza for the county's first batch of accredited street artists, and that the public is welcome to enjoy their performances and provide them with encouragement.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chairwoman announces her withdrawal from TSU

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan announced Monday that she was leaving the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) after the pro- independence party demanded that she resign from her government post within three days.
Lai said in a statement that she had discussed her withdrawal from the party with former President Lee Teng-hui, who is regarded by the TSU as its "spiritual leader," and received his understanding.

The TSU's Central Executive Committee threatened earlier in the day to strip her of her party membership if she did not resign from the MAC in protest over what it believes is the Ma Ying-jeou administration's excessive tilt toward China.

It also objected to Lai, in her capacity as a TSU member, hosting Chen Yunlin, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), during his visit to Taiwan in late October or early November.
Lai said she was surprised by the TSU decision and felt bewildered.

Since taking office May 20, Lai said she has spared no effort to safeguard Taiwan's interests and mitigate any possible impact and damage to the country's interests when outlining measures to liberalize cross-strait exchanges.

As a Cabinet member, however, she had to respect the law, and before policies delivered tangible results, she "could only do, not speak, " she said. The situation, Lai added, had led to misunderstandings, which she regretted.

In the statement, Lai said she understands that as an opposition party, the TSU must monitor the government, helping democracy become more deeply rooted in Taiwan. She therefore decided to withdraw from the party and concentrate her efforts on public affairs.

Lai also noted that she will not join any other existing political party after leaving the TSU, but will maintain her "center left" leanings and continue her efforts to protect the long-term interests of Taiwan's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to attract 20,000 Chinese tourists per month: official
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 13 (CNA) 10/13/08 23:35:04 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan looks forward to doubling the number of Chinese visitor arrivals to 20,000 per month by the end of this year, the country's tourism chief said Monday upon her arrival in Beijing to promote travel in Taiwan.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said she will introduce to Chinese travel agents and ordinary citizens Taiwan's tourist attractions during her five-day visit, which will also take her to Nanjing.
Traveling with executives of more than 100 travel agencies from around Taiwan, Lai is visiting China in her capacity as chairwoman of the nonprofit Taiwan Tourism Association.
Lai said she believed increasing the number of nonstop cross-Taiwan Strait charters on weekends would support higher arrival numbers.

Since Chinese nationals began visiting Taiwan on July 18 under an agreement expanding cross-Taiwan Strait tourism reached in mid-June, 85 percent of Chinese tourists to Taiwan have come from provinces or cities where the nonstop flights are available.

Lai said she keenly hoped that Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan in his capacity as president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), could wield his influence to push for increases in both the number of such flights and Chinese destinations after his planned visit to Taiwan later this year.

Chen is scheduled to visit Taiwan in late October or early November for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, on a range of issues.

The two are expected to discuss new cross-strait flight routes and destinations as well as the opening of direct shipping links and direct cargo charter flights as well as cross-strait cooperation in fighting crime.

If the number and destinations of the existing weekend direct flights can be increased, Lai said she believes that the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan will increase from the current 10,000 per month to 20,000 by year's end.
During her current visit, Lai said she will do her utmost to convince Chinese tour operators and ordinary citizens of the joy of sightseeing in Taiwan.

A series of workshops will be organized to have direct contact with Chinese travel agents and prospective travelersr and introduce to them various short- stay tour packgages that could be attractive to Chinese salaried workers looking for a quick getaway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls for faith in nation's economic outlook

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Monday that Taiwan has ample foreign reserves and a high savings rate and urged the public not to lose faith in the nation's economic outlook.
Liu made the remarks to shore up public confidence as share prices continued to fall in the local bourse despite rebounds Monday from Friday's precipitous declines in most other world markets.
The premier, speaking at an architecture award presentation ceremony, said the financial crisis was essentially triggered by excessive money manipulations, resulting in a widespread credit crunch.

But he pointed out that Taiwan enjoys a number of advantages, such as its ample foreign reserves. As of the end of September, Taiwan had foreign reserves of US$281.13 billion, ranking fifth in the world behind China, Japan, Russia and India.
"This, coupled with Taiwan's high private savings rate of 20 percent, means that Taiwan has no capital liquidity problem, " he said.
In addition, Taiwan's banking system is yet to be fully internationalized, leaving it insulated from the financial crisis like a sort of a firewall.
"The fallout of global stock market meltdown will not spill over to Taiwan immediately," the premier said.

He also praised Taiwan's manufacturing sector as a bedrock of the nation's economy, saying it has laid a solid foundation for the country, and said the problems of inflation and high fuel prices have gradually come under control.

Noting that the government has already channeled funding starting this year to stimulate the economy and strengthen its support of underprivileged families, he urged the public not to lose faith in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy minister to become presidential aide

TEXT.P: Deputy Interior Minister Lai Feng-wei has been tapped to serve as deputy secretary-general to the president, a senior Presidential Office official confirmed Monday.
Kao Lang, another deputy secretary-general to President Ma Ying-jeou, confirmed the appointment during a Legislative Yuan committee hearing.

According to Kao, Lai, a former magistrate of the outlying island county of Penghu, will fill the position left vacant by Yeh Ching-chuan, who replaced Lin Fang-yue as minister of the Department of Health late last month amid a melamine scare.
Kao said Lai's appointment will be formally announced soon.

Lai, 55, has a doctoral degree in industrial engineering and management from the University of Missouri. He has been a section chief at the Atomic Energy Council and headed the ruling Kuomintang's Penghu chapter.
He is known to be versed in grassroots politics and community affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 14, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's groups call for boycott of Chinese products

TEXT.P: Members of several local women's rights groups staged a demonstration in Taipei Tuesday demanding that the Department of Health reject all Chinese products or mandate stricter inspection of these products.

During their demonstration outside the DOH's office, the protesters also demanded that China take responsibility for the export of melamine-adulterated food products to Taiwan. They requested that DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan raise the issue directly with Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, who is expected to visit Taiwan between late October and early November.

The protesters claimed that the way the DOH has dealt with melamine-tainted food scare shows that the government is incapable of handling problems related to low-quality Chinese imports. They urged consumers to boycott all Chinese products such as clothing, shoes and food and buy only Taiwan-made products.

Taiwan has been engulfed in a food scare since the beverage products of a number of Taiwanese companies were recently found to contain melamine. The contamination occurred because milk power or non-dairy creamer imported from China was used as an ingredient.

However, some of the products were allowed to remain on store shelves last month for a period when the DOH altered the standard for acceptable levels of melamine content in food to 2.5 ppm. The policy, which obviously failed to meet consumers' expectations for "zero content," led to the resignation of then-DOH Minister Lin Fang-yue.

The DOH has since reset its standard for melamine content at "undetectable" using the most sensitive test -- liquid chromatography/tandem mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS) -- which can detect melamine levels as low as 0.05 ppm.

The change has resulted in the recall of a number of milk powder products by the leading manufacturer Nestle earlier this month. The products, which were made in China, were previously declared as melamine-free because the equipment employed to test them was less sensitive.

Melamine, an industrial chemical, can cause kidney stones and kidney failure if consumed in sufficient quantity. Baby formula containing the toxic chemical has caused at least six deaths and sickened more than 53,000 children in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices rise sharply on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Buoyed by the Dow Jones Industrial Average's biggest single-day points increase in history, Taiwan's share prices surged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 271.12 points, or 5.4 percent, to close at 5,291.56.

Rebounding from losses the previous day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 5,321.25 and hit a low of 5,277.3. A total of 3.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$67.49 billion (US$2.08 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 6.7 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 6.5 percent, cement stocks, foodstuff issues and textile stocks all rose 6.4 percent, paper and pulp issues increased 6.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares gained 5.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares were up 5.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,511 to 198, with 251 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.26 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food scare highlights need for Taiwan's entry to WHO: ministry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that the World Health Organization (WHO) took notice of Taiwan's protests against the WHO's handling of the Chinese tainted milk scandal and that the importance of Taiwan's participation in the world body is manifested in the incident.

"The international community understands more clearly how important and necessary it is for Taiwan to participate in the WHO, " said Paul Chang, director-general of MOFAs Department of International Organizations, at a regular press briefing.
His statement came in response to a reporter's question on whether Taiwan's protests against the world health body's handling of the matter were in vain.

The MOFA protested after the WHO, in requesting information from Taiwan authorities on the effects of China-produced melamine-adulterated dairy products, sent an e-mail to China and copied it to Taiwan, referring to Taiwan as "Taiwan, China."

Chang said the foreign ministry made contact three times with the WHO through its representative office in Geneva to protest against the WHO's failure to contact Taiwan directly on the food contamination issue and against the WHO's downgrading of Taiwan's status in dealing with the matter.
Former Department of Health Minister Lin Fang-yue also wrote to WHO Director- General Margaret Chan on Sept. 26 to sternly express Taiwan's objections, he added.

Chang, however, refused to confirm whether the scheduled Sept. 30 meeting between Taiwan's Representative to Geneva Shen Lyu-shun and the WHO took place. Shen has regular and direct contact with WHO officials, but in keeping with an understanding between Taipei and Geneva, the details of those contacts cannot be disclosed, Chang added.
The WHO took notice of our position, " Chang said. "But frankly speaking, Taiwan's participation in the WHO would require a comprehensive solution."
Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) voluntarily reported to the WHO by e-mail on Sept. 16 that some Taiwan products containing toxic dairy ingredients from China had been sold to Hong Kong.

Taiwan -- though not a member of the WHO and excluded from the International Health Regulations (IHR) framework due to pressure from China -- decided in 2005 to nonetheless voluntarily adhere to the IHR, and designated the CDC to handle its contacts with the WHO.
Taiwan has been trying to gain entry to the World Health Assembly -- the WHOs decision-making body -- as an observer, but its efforts have been obstructed by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kaohsiung County recalls octopus balls imported from China

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing ordered Tuesday the immediate recall of frozen octopus balls imported from China, instructing that retailers remove them from store shelves and send them to the relevant government authorities for melamine testing.

Yang gave the directive after officials of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) inspected a trading company Monday in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, which was found to have imported the Japanese-style snack from China's Shangdong Province.

Yang demanded that local vendors send any questionable China-made octopus balls to the county public health authorities or the DOH for examination, as frozen octopus balls imported by a trading company in Japan from China's Fujian Province were found to contain the toxic chemical melamine.
Melamine is an industrial chemical used by some Chinese food makers to produce a falsely high level of protein in a wide variety of foodstuff.

According to the DOH officials, the Kaohsiung County trading company by late July had already sold the 7,377 kilograms of frozen octopus balls in 900 boxes that it imported from Shangdong to a local distributor.

Acting on information provided by the Kaohsiung County, the Kaohsiung City's health bureau confirmed later Tuesday that the Kaohsuing County distributor has sold all the product to a retailer in central Taiwan's Taichung area. No octopus balls of the shipment was sold to Kaohsiung City.
Meanwhile, the Kaohsiung County's health bureau has informed its Taichung County counterpart of the incident and sought a joint cooperation to detect the questionable imports.
In August, panic arose among Taiwan consumers after it was found that shipments of 25 tons of milk powder imported from China contained melamine.
The government has asked for compensation for Taiwanese consumers from the culpable Chinese companies.
The food scare over China-made products has become a sensitive issue in bilateral relations at a time when a key Beijing official is preparing to visit Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, China's top liaison with Taiwan in his capacity as the president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), is slated to visit Taiwan late this month or early November and hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung -- on two-way exchanges.

Issues regarding cross-Taiwan Strait transportation services, including the establishment of regular cargo charter flights and expansion of weekend passenger charter flights, as well as financial supervisory cooperation and crime-fighting, will be high on the agenda of the second round of talks.
Chen would be the highest ranking official of the People's Republic of China to visit Taiwan.
Chiang and Chen clinched two accords on weekend charter flights and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists in a historical ice-breaking meeting in June in Beijing.
