DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China officials discuss cross-strait issues in Beijing

TEXT.P: Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang met with China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Wang Yi in Beijing Monday to discuss cross-strait issues and the global economic crisis.

Shih and Wang agreed that cooperation is essential to the future development and survival of industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, said Tsai Lien-sheng, secretary-general of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, speaking to the Central News Agency by phone from Beijing.
The two men also exchanged views on the impact of the current global credit crisis on the world economy, he indicated.
Tsai said Shih was in Beijing in the capacity of an adviser to a delegation from the Chinese National Federation of Industries led by its chairman, Preston Chen.

Shih's trip is expected to help pave the way for a visit to Taiwan in late October or early November by Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , a quasi-official body authorized to deal with Taiwan.
The delegation also met with several Taiwan businessmen based in Beijing and encouraged them to reinvest in their home country.
The group is slated to visit Shanghai and Kunshan in central China in the coming days.
The Chinese National Federation of Industries is an association of Taiwan businesses that seeks to promote industrial and trade growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to press retailers to cut product prices

TEXT.P: The government should demand that domestic retailers of bulk commodities adjust their prices downward to reflect falling global prices, the Consumers' Group suggested Monday.

Although the global prices of bulk commodities, such as wheat, soybeans, rice and corn, dropped sharply recently, local consumers did not benefit from the price drop as retailers did not lower their prices accordingly, said Hsieh Tien- jen, acting chairman of the group.
For example, Hsieh said, despite the fact that world flour prices fell significantly recently, the domestic prices of bread and noodles remained high.

In addition, most of the special zones set up by six supermarket and hypermarket chains around the country for fair-price goods have not provided sufficient information and have covered only a few product items, he noted.

In response, the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau said that the factory price of flour dropped to NT$499.26 per 22-kilogram package in mid-September from NT$584.04 per package in April. But as the sale price of flour products are linked to the purchasing behavior of wholesalers and pricing strategy of retailers, it is not appropriate for the government to interfere in the market economy, it added.
The bureau also said that it will ask the Consumer Protection Commission under the Executive Yuan to closely scrutinize the operations of the fair-price special zones.

However, Liu Ching-fang, an official of the commission, rebutted that the special zones were set up in accordance with the administrative guidelines, which are not based on any specific provisions in the law, therefore the establishment of such zones is not mandatory and not subject to regulations.
Liu added that with the current sluggish domestic economy, there is a need to maintain the special zones.
She acknowledged that the space for the special zones had been squeezed to make room for promotional campaigns during the Mid-Autumn Festival and the Chung Yuan ghost festival.

She added that the commission will provide the latest issue of Consumer Reports Magazine, which carries related reports, to the six supermarket and hypermarket chains in the hope that they will stick to their commitment to help consumers cope with surging product prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gender equality official weighs in on high school uniform controversy

TEXT.P: An education official said Tuesday that schools should not penalize students for not conforming to school uniform regulations that discriminate based on the sex of the student.
Chen Chiao-mei, a member of the Committee for Gender Equality Education under the Ministry of the Education, said that schools must respect students and their right to "pluralistic choice."

Chen was referring to a recent controversy that arose when students at Taipei First Girls' High School sent to a letter to a local media outlet complaining about the school's regulations prohibited them from entering or exiting the school campus wearing shorts.
The school's formal uniform is a green shirt and black skirt.

Although the Teacher's Act authorizes schools in the country to implement regulations to manage and guide their students, Chen said, students have the right through a democratic process to initiate and implement rules regarding the school uniform.

In response to the letter sent by the Taipei First Girls' High School students, the Ministry of Education stated that schools' rigid rules requiring students to wear skirts or pants are in violation of the Gender Equality Education Law.
The ministry also said students' right to choose should be respected and that they should not be punished for uniform violations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students invent wind-powered bicycle headlights

TEXT.P: A group of students from Kaohsiung National First University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan won an award Tuesday for creative application at the 2008 National Wind Power Invention Contest with their entry of a wind- powered bicycle headlight.

Given the spiraling price of gasoline this year, which has fueled inflation, cutting energy costs has been a major concern for many consumers. Harnessing wind power is considered one of the possible solutions.

The wind-powered bicycle headlight utilizes head-on wind, while the bike is in motion, to generate electricity as a source of energy for the headlight. The electricity is saved in rechargeable batteries and may be used to power a small fan when the cyclist stops at traffic lights.

This particular invention has drawn several enquiries from businessmen who are interested in purchasing the patent from the students. The commercial application of the invention is perceived to have great market potential.

The National Wind Power Invention Contest was held at Southern Taiwan University in Tainan County's Yongkang City in early October. The purpose of the contest is to encourage the use of wind power as an alternative source of energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar remains unchanged on Taipei Forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday to close at NT$32.388.
A total of US$1.197 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.388 and fluctuated between NT$32.190 and NT$32.440.

DOC.HEADLINE: British opera singer to make debut in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Budding British opera singer Paul Potts, who achieved instant fame after an appearance on a television singing competition, was to open the Taiwan leg of his world tour Tuesday night.
Potts, visiting Taiwan for the first time, will sing in Taichung, Taipei and Tainan on Oct. 14, Oct. 16 and Oct. 18, respectively.

Described by one blogger as "failure, hope, futility, perseverance, and victory personified, " Potts rose from obscurity when he stunned an audience and the judges on the UK talent search show "Britain's Got Talent" with his rendition of the operatic aria Nessun Dorma from the final act of Puccini's Turandot.

Following that performance, which was aired on June 9, 2007, the tenor eventually won the competition and almost immediately released an album called "One Chance" in mid-July 2007 that had sold 2 million copies by the end of the year.
Potts will be joined during his swing through Taiwan by a top-notch Filipino soprano. Potts will sing the melody while the soprano harmonizes, according to organizers.

Potts said he became addicted to operas at the age of 16 when he began listening to opera music performed by Spanish tenor Jose Carreras, who gained fame with a wider audience as one of the Three Tenors along with tenors Placido Domingo and the late Luciano Pavarotti, who died in 2007, in a series of mass concerts that began in 1990 and last until 2003.
But he also regularly listens to other forms of music and enjoys English rock band Queen and Swedish pop group Roxette.
Potts said he especially liked "Chasing Cars" -- the third single from the fourth album by Snow Patrol, a Northern Irish/Scottish alternative rock band.
The tenor reaffirmed, however, that he will concentrate on singing opera in the future and will not consider performing pop or rock songs.
Potts said that although he does not intend to sing Chinese songs on this tour of Taiwan, he will consider adding some to his repertoire if he has a chance to perform in Taiwan again in the future.
Potts spent his 38th birthday with his wife during a party at a Taipei hotel Monday and made a wish that he could perform in Taiwan as often as possible.
Potts was a mobile phone salesman aspiring to be an opera singer before he achieved fame on "Britain's Got Talent."

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC to offer discounts to I-Pass holders using MRT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) said Tuesday that it will offer discounted prices to I-Pass holders using the southern port city's MRT, starting Oct. 22.

That is the date when regular fares will be applied to the two lines in the system. During the first week of the Orange line's operations since Sept. 14, passengers were able to ride for free, while prices were set at just NT$15 for the Sept. 22 - Oct. 21 period on both the Red and Orange Lines.
The KRTC said that the level of discount for I-Pass holders has not yet been determined, although it had earlier planned to offer a 75-percent discount.

Huang Yi-chung, director of the KRTC's Public Affairs Department, said that as the percentage of Kaohsiung residents using the MRT is relatively low, the company has had trouble boosting daily passenger numbers.
Ridership on the system has remained at between 100,000 and 200,000 per day, with the number rising to around 250,000 on holidays, Huang said.
These figures show that most Kaohsiung residents view the MRT as "a tourist and leisure train," Huang claimed.
The KRTC's main task at present is to try to encourage people to change their commuting habits and switch to using the MRT to get to and from work, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president defends administration cross-strait policy

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew clarified Tuesday that the government's liberalization policy toward China did not constitute being "pro-China" or "tilting toward China, " as he rejected criticism that the administration's approach was sacrificing the country's sovereignty.
Siew argued that easing the restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait economic activities is a "necessary" step to promote Taiwan's economic development.

He also contended that the Chinese market is one that Taiwan should pursue, because compared with other non-Chinese speaking countries, Taiwan enjoys an edge in terms of language and social customs while doing business in China.

The recent improvement in relations between Taiwan and China has presented many opportunities to foreign businesses, as foreign companies can base their operations and recruit talent in Taiwan, making Taiwan their springboard to China, he said.

Siew said cross-strait transportation will become more convenient if the two sides reach an agreement on the opening of more direct nonstop cross-strait air routes during upcoming negotiations expected to take place between late October and early November in Taipei.
The development would put Taiwan in a more advantageous position, he indicated.
The vice president made the remarks while delivering a speech at a Rotary Club meeting held in Taipei.

In the months since the Kuomintang's Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated as president on May 20, Taiwan has adopted a series of liberalization measures toward China, including launching nonstop cross-strait charter flights on weekends, expanding the admission of Chinese tourists to Taiwan, allowing cross-strait currency trading, and raising the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent of their net worth to 60 percent.
Other measures under planning include opening Taiwan to Chinese investors and relaxing restrictions on China-bound investment by Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturers.

In protest over what it believes is the Ma administration's excessive tilt toward China, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union on Monday (TSU) threatened to strip Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan of her party membership unless she resigned from the government post within three days.
In response, Lai chose to relinquish her TSU membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung opens speciality food center catering to Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: A specialty food center, opened on Oct. 1 for trial operations by the Kaohsiung city government in a large- scale shopping mall, is slated to be formally inaugurated on Oct. 25, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu said Tuesday.

"The prime aim of the center is to provide a convenient and comfortable place where Chinese tourists can pick up high-end, typical, locally-produced food or other items," Chen told reporters following a municipal meeting.

Although the number of Chinese tourists coming to the port city has been low since the central government opened up Taiwan to more mainland tourists in July with various incentive measures, Chen said the city has attracted many foreign tourists from other countries, such as Japan.
The center, featuring fine local products in a space of 826 square meters, is located in the first-floor basement of the city's largest shopping center - the Dream Mall.
Liu Hsin-cheng, head of te city's Economic Affairs Bureau, said that Japanese tourists have made up the bulk of visitors to the center since it began trial operations on Oct. 1.
Citing bureau statistics, Liu said that some 130,000 Japanese tourists have visited Kaohsiung City this year to date, up from the previous year's level of 110,000.
"I am confident that the number of Japanese visitors to Kaohsiung will exceed 200,000 by the end of this year," Liu said.
Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan is the country's second-largest city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flexible display, three other devices forecast to emerge fast

TEXT.P: In the next several years, the global market for display equipment will increasingly concentrate on four "emerging" technologies -- flexible display, touch screen, public information display, and three-dimensional display, according to a survey by market analyst Displaybank.

Displaybank's Taiwan chapter forecast in a statement that the market for all four of these technologies will expand fast in the next decade, achieving annual growth rates in output value ranging from 28 percent to 143 percent.

For individual product lines, the market research showed that the mainstream thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) will reach its production peak in the next two to three years, and after that, the organic light-emitting diode (OLED) will phase in to seize an increasingly larger market share.
After OLED, flexible display will become the next mainstream product when related manufacturing technologies mature, according to Displaybank's analysts.

Meanwhile, the annual average composite growth rates for flexible display will be as high as 126 percent for 2008-2017, while the flexible display products will account for 25 percent of the production output of all display devices in 2017, the analysts said.
3D display, they said, will also see strong growth in the next four years, and before 2012, its annual average composite growth rate will reach 143 percent.

As for public information display, the annual average composite growth rates is likely to reach 28 percent for 2008-2012; while the annual average composite growth rate of touch screen displays will be between 31 percent to 35 percent, depending on the size of screen, according to the forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA introduces new toxicity testing method using insect

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) recently introduced a new method to test for water or mud toxicity using a small insect, the Hyalella azteca, significantly reducing the time and cost of toxicity testing, the agency said Tuesday.

According to the Environmental Analysis Laboratory under the EPA, the Hyalella azteca, an amphipod of about 5 millimeters long that is common in aquatic systems, has already been used for toxicity testing by the United States' Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Geological Survey.

"The insect adapts easily to environments of a wide range of temperatures, from 10 to 35 degrees Celsius. Their individual differences are imperceptible, and they are sensitive to toxic materials, such as pesticides and heavy metals, " Yang Hsi-nan, a researcher of the laboratory said at a press conference, speaking about advantages of using the insect.
In addition, Yang said it only takes about 10 days for scientists to see how toxic the water or mud being tested is, based on the effects that any toxic chemicals would have on the insects.
The insects are also very easy to reproduce in laboratories, according to Yang.
It only takes seven days to raise the Hyalella azteca before it can be used for testing purposes, while traditional tests with Cyprinus carpio--a kind of fish, take one to two months, Yang added.
He said that several tests on riverbed mud toxicity with the Hyalella azteca are already underway.

The new method was introduced to Taiwan by a group of experts of the laboratory who were sent to the Columbia Environmental Research Center in the United States to study biological toxicity testing technology.
Biological toxicity testing is a method of using live insects or animals to examine the toxic level of a body of water or river bed mud.
Insects that are frequently used for toxicity testing are the Cyprinus carpio, Neocaridina denticulata --a shrimp-- and Daphnia similis--a water flea.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 APEC nations attend agriculture seminar in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Twelve APEC nations are attending a seminar launched in Taiwan Tuesday aimed at looking at the latest developments in agronomy, according to the Council of Agriculture, which organized the conference.

The APEC-ATCWG Workshop on Capacity Building for Development and Implementation of Risk Management Systems on Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture is a four-day seminar that is being held in Taichung City in central Taiwan from Oct. 14 to 17.
According to the COA, the aim of the seminar is to increase the capability of participating nations in the area of food provision and agriculture management.
The countries which are participating in the seminar include Canada, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Indonesia, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea and Taiwan.

Participating countries belong to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's Agriculture Technology Cooperation Working Group. Participants to the seminar will visit Taiwan's Livestock Research Institute to examine the latest progress in vegetable cultivation and fish farming as well as farm products genetic resources preservation.
The COA hopes to enhance the understanding of APEC nations on Taiwan's progress in these areas.
Experts from Norway, Canada and Taiwan are invited to address the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passers-by slightly wounded by pepper spray at Taipei intersection

TEXT.P: A chemical floating in the air at an intersection in Taipei, which caused discomfort to passers-by on Tuesday, has been confirmed to be an ingredient of pepper spray, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said.
The incident occurred around 11 a.m. Tuesday at the intersection of Zhonghua road and Guangzhou street, where a bottle of pepper spray was broken and the irritating powder spread into air.
Forty-three motorcyclists and pedestrians passing by felt discomfort, suffering symptoms of respiratory tracts burns, eye inflammation and throat irritation.
According to the EPA, the yellow powdery chemical is an ingredient of pepper spray, which can irritate the eyes and respiratory tracts.

But brief exposures to the chemical poses low risk (to health) , Yuan Shaw-ying, director-general of the EPAs department of environmental sanitation and toxic substance management, told a news conference.
The incident caused public concern in the afternoon, as some media reported that the chemical was chloroacetaldehyde, an ingredient of tear gas.
A group sent by the EPA later confirmed it was not a tear gas ingredient but a pepper spray ingredient instead, Yuan said.
EPA staff have cleaned up the chemical from the area, Yuan added.
According to the EPA, apart from 20 people who are still in hospitals for further examinations, all the other victims have been released from hospitals after being treated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sovereign wealth fund would be used to develop local economy: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday that a sovereign wealth fund run by Taiwan would integrate government capital and be used to launch construction projects, develop new industries, and provide temporary assistance to local businesses.

Revisiting an issue that sparked controversy when first suggested by the government on Oct. 1 as a way to stimulate the economy, Siew said at a Rotary International gathering that if a fund were launched by Taiwan, it would differ from those run by other countries.

Taiwan's fund, as described by Siew, would focus more on domestic development while funds run by other countries tend to emphasize strategic investments around the globe to promote their national or economic interests.
Siew acknowledged that the present global financial turmoil would inevitably affect Taiwan, but insisted the country did not face serious capital liquidity problems.

He believed, however, that if the government's various assets, such as equities, land, capital from public-run companies and foreign exchange reserves could be integrated, the government would have more chips at its disposal to boost the economy.

The fund, he said, would serve as an expanded national development fund that could invest in developing new industries, carrying out public construction projects or assisting soundly-structured companies in tiding over temporary financial difficulties.
In fact, Siew said, it would not even have to be called a "sovereign wealth fund."
During his speech, Siew also proposed a reduction in the inheritance and gift taxes as incentives to draw more overseas capital back to Taiwan.
That would generate more job opportunities and improved business prospects, leading to increases in tax revenues and growth in domestic economic development.

Siew said that with the government's short-term provisional measures to combat the current financial crisis and its long-term package of systemic reforms, he was cautiously optimistic about Taiwan's economic future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposed bridge linking Kinmen, Xiamen should consider security: MAC

TEXT.P: The proposed construction of a bridge linking Taiwan-held Kinmen island and the city of Xiamen in southeastern China should take into consideration national security, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.
MAC Deputy Chairman Fu Don-cheng made the remarks at a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan on withdrawing stationed troops in Kinmen and Matsu and building the Kin-Xia bridge.
The Taiwan Competitiveness Forum, a Taiwan think tank, sponsored the hearing on the bridge, which would span 8.6-11.4 kilometers depending on which of the three proposed designs was chosen.

"Other factors to be considered in the construction of the bridge include a review of the development of cross-strait relations, the construction cost and its efficiency, and the willingness and cooperation of China," Fu said.

Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, who is keen to build the bridge to boost the local economy, said President Ma Ying-jeou on a recent visit to Kinmen had been open to its construction and instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to assess the project.
"But the issue was stalled because of the reservations of the Ministry of National Defense and other government agencies, " Lee said.
MND officials said recently that an overall assessment of Kinmen's strategic status needed to be conducted before considering building the bridge.

CEPD Deputy Minister San Gee said that whether or not to withdraw troops from Kinmen and Matsu, once the front lines of Taiwan's defenses against China, or build a bridge linking Kinmen and Xiamen will have to take into account the future direction of Kinmen's development.

San suggested other economic initiatives to revive the local economy could include launching gambling in the island county, opening Kinmen educational institutions to Chinese students, using battlefield resources to develop tourism, and setting up a medical industry and cross-strait free trade zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Golden Rain Trees in Taitung County present natural wonder

TEXT.P: Autumn is the best time to observe one of nature's wonders in Taitung County in eastern Taiwan, where Taiwan Golden Rain Trees are splashing a lovely bright yellow before their blossoms on the top of the canopy fall like golden showers to make way for a sea of pink seed pods.

Experts in the local travel industry said Tuesday that the best locations to admire the colorful foliage change in Taitung County include the mountainous areas along the route linking the townships of Jinfong, Daren and Dawu, areas along Taiwan provincial road No. 11, the East Rift Valley near the Luye tea farm, and areas along County Road No. 197.

The Golden Rain Tree is a medium-sized deciduous tree with a dense round crown composed of ascending branches. It grows to about 15 meters tall. During the cooler season of autumn, its flowering panicles burst into a yellow shower of blossoms on the top of the canopy.

Shortly after the clusters of flowers reach their peak and fall, another beautiful stage occurs when the trees go into their seed pod cycle, with the delicate pink lantern-like capsules creating another colorful transformation by turning pink, red and then brown.
The Golden Rain Tree found in Taiwan is an indigenous subspecies called the Koelreuteria elegans formosana and said to be more beautiful than the variety found in other countries.
The subtropical trees can also be found in Taiwan's major cities, including Taipei and Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County's river patrol team safeguards water quality

TEXT.P: A volunteer river patrol team in Tainan County, armed with the authority to collect evidence of environmental crime, has successfully uncovered water polluters and helped bring them to justice, a local government official said Tuesday.

According to the official from the county government's Bureau of Environmental Protection, the patrol team consisting of about 200 volunteers from various walks of life had reported 87 suspected cases between January and September.
Of those cases, 34 were confirmed with evidence gathered by the team, the official said. Most of the confirmed cases were major violations, resulting in fines totaling NT$3.8 million.

Like river patrol teams in other cities and counties, the group in Tainan County was originally only authorized to report suspected cases to the local government, which would then be pursued by the local environmental protection bureau.

Their efforts were often wasted. Prosecutors gave little weight to the unofficial group's reports, and the trail of evidence had often disappeared when government investigators decided to pursue their tips.

Facing a shortage of manpower to handle environmental probes, the Tainan County government decided in December 2006 to authorize the volunteer team to gather evidence of wrongdoing, a decision that has led to more efficient monitoring of the county's rivers, which are often used as wastewater receptacles.
Empowered to gather evidence, the volunteers could collect wastewater discharged by factories during the five minutes it took to disappear into once clean rivers.

"Waiting futilely during the five minutes for government authorities to do the same task was not smart because it allowed the best time to collect persuasive powerful evidence to go by, " the county government official said.
"Most of the team members are local residents, who know how to trace wastewater movements and where to find sources of pollution, " he added.
The evidence gathering authority allows them to examine pollution sources, request related data from operators of suspected sources, collect samples, and take photos and video recordings.

The team receives subsidies from the central government to buy the necessary devices and equipment to hunt down polluters, such as ice buckets, sample bottles, PH level paper strips, and video cameras.
The Tainan County government has encouraged local residents to join the team, but members have to be trained by the bureau before they can participate in the team's missions.
The training helps them obtain professional knowledge, such as how to identify contaminated water and collect samples from suspicious sources, the official said.
Group members also learn how to open drainage covers on the road to inspect water quality and how to avoid threats posed by suspected firms during the evidence gathering process, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to convene international forum on melamine

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will convene an international forum this week focusing on melamine's risk to health, as well as measures to prevent contamination of the toxic chemical in food, the agency announced Tuesday.

International experts from the European Union, Australia and New Zealand are confirmed to attend the forum to be held on Thursday and Friday, said Wang Je- chau, the DOH's spokesman, adding however that his agency is still confirming the name list.

In addition, a two-hour web conference with officials and experts from the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) will be held on Thursday to discuss how to assess the risk of melamine in food and methods to analyze the chemical in foods.
A roundtable on policy and cooperative strategies to prevent melamine- adulterated food in international trade will also be held Friday morning, the DOH stated.
The forum will take place from Oct. 16 afternoon to Oct. 17 , at the Howard Plaza Hotel in Taipei.
The proceedings of the meeting will be conducted in English and will be broadcast live in a hall in the hotel opened to the public, the DOH said.

The toxic chemical melamine, normally used to make plastics and fertilizers, was found to have been added by milk collection stations into diluted milk in order to give the appearance of high protein in tests.
Four infants who consumed baby formula made with melamine-tainted milk have died in China, with 54,000 others sickened and more than 10,000 still hospitalized.

Food made with ingredients containing melamine-tainted milk powder and vegetable-based protein were also found in many countries in the world. Imports of Chinese milk powder and food products have been banned or recalled in more than a dozen countries, including the European Union, Malaysia, Singapore and Taiwan.
In Taiwan, the chemical seemed to be ubiquitous in food products, as it is found in instant beverages, cakes, breads and chocolate, and has caused general panic among consumers.
Taiwan's former DOH minister Lin Fang-yue recently stepped down for not being able to ease consumers' worries, after only four months in office.
No official from the World Health Organization (WHO) will attend the forum even though the WHO was invited, according to the premilinary name list of participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese octopus balls seized in Taichung for melamine testing

TEXT.P: Seventeen boxes of frozen octopus balls imported from China and suspected of containing melamine -- a harmful industrial chemical -- were seized at a local company in central Taiwan Tuesday, officials said.

Acting on information from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), health officials in Taichung County rushed to a company in the county's Tatu township and confiscated the questionable octopus balls, county officials told reporters.

It will take two or three days for test results to be made available to reveal whether the food products -- made of diced octopus and usually served with noodles or as barbecue skewers -- actually contain melamine, a Taichung county official said.
The items were imported in July by a trading company in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County and later sold to a Taichung distributor.

Authorities conducting the raid Tuesday were able to seize only 17 boxes, out of a total shipment of 900 boxes, because the rest of the products had already been sold by the Taichung distributor to local vendors, Taichung county officials said.

Meanwhile, Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety, advised the public Tuesday not to panic because the shipment does not necessarily contain melamine, even though some China-made octopus dumplings imported to Japan from the southeastern Fujian province were recently found to contain the chemical residue.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing earlier the same day ordered an immediate recall of frozen octopus balls imported from China and demanded that retailers in Kaohsiung remove them from store shelves and send them to relevant government authorities for melamine testing.
Yang gave the directive after DOH officials searched the premises of the Kaohsiung trading company, which imported the snacks from China's Shandong Province.
According to the DOH officials, the Kaohsiung County trading company by late July had already sold the 7,377 kilograms of frozen octopus balls that it imported, to a local distributor.
Kaohsiung county officials confirmed later Tuesday that the Kaohsuing County distributor had sold all the products to the Taichung distributor.
Melamine is an industrial chemical used by some Chinese food makers to produce a falsely high level of protein in a wide variety of foodstuff. The chemical is used to make plastics.
In August, a shipment of 25 tons of China-made milk powder containing melamine were found to have been sold in Taiwan, causing panic among Taiwanese consumers.

So far, no cases of deaths from melamine contamination have been reported in Taiwan. But media reports said a four-year-old daughter of aTaiwanese businessman and his Chinese wife who reside in Fujian province part of the time was diagnosed in Taiwan to have kidney stones after drinking the melamine- contaminated milk powder.
In China, food tainted with melamine were found to have killed four infants and sickened more than 50,000 others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most fines imposed on Kaohsiung MRT passengers for eating in trains

TEXT.P: Some 860 passengers riding the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit system have been fined since it opened in March this year, with most of them guilty of violating food consumption rules, according to statistics released by the city's Mass Rapid Transit Bureau Tuesday.

Bureau official Li Kuo-pao said that between April 7, when the MRT's rules began being enforced after a one-month grace period, to Oct. 13, 860 passengers were fined a total of NT$1.13 million, of which NT$735,250 has been collected.

Li estimated that up to 90 percent of the fines were imposed on passengers who were caught eating on the trains, with other infringements including carrying non-caged pets into the trains' compartments and the irregular switching-on of alarms and other devices.
Although more than 27 million passengers have taken the MRT's two lines as of Oct. 13, riders are still breaking the rules because they remain unfamiliar with them, Li said.
Eating in Kaohsiung MRT stations and on trains is prohibited, with violators fined NT$1,500.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU expels MAC chairwoman from party

TEXT.P: The head of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Tuesday that although Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan had announced her withdrawal from the party a day earlier, the TSU would still follow the decision of its Central Executive Committee to expel her.
TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei told reporters that the decision was made because Lai could not fulfill the originally intended purpose of having her accept the post in the Kuomintang government.
Huang explained that TSU supporters are worried that President Ma Ying-jeou's policies have tilted too much toward China, and believe Lai has been unable to do anything about it.

"The TSU has observed her for five months, and yet the situation has not improved. Therefore, the Central Executive Committee demanded yesterday that Lai must resign from her MAC post within three days or the TSU would strip her of her party membership," he said.

In a statement announcing her withdrawal from the TSU a day earlier, Lai said that in handling cross-Taiwan Strait relations, many things can be done but not publicized prematurely, and that as a Cabinet member, she must respect the law.
She pledged that she will continue her efforts to serve the interests of Taiwan's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low salaries top headache for young wage earners: CLA survey

TEXT.P: Low wages are the number one job problem facing young wage earners while declining physical strength is the biggest worry for those nearing retirement age, according to the results of a survey released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Tuesday.
The Cabinet-level CLA conducted the survey in September to gain a better understanding of the living and job conditions of local wage earners, with 4,040 valid samples collected.

Asked about job-related problems, 39 percent of the respondents in the 15-24 age group cited "low wages" as their top headache and 30.7 percent listed "lack of professional skills or expertise" as their biggest hurdle.
For prime working age individuals in the 25-44 age group, the top two concerns were low wages (28.6 percent) and difficulties in balancing family life and their jobs.

To those aged between 45-64, the three major concerns were falling physical vigor (34.4 percent) , worries over being laid off (22.6 percent) and worries about being unable to receive their pensions (20.5 percent).

Analyzing the poll results, CLA officials said young and prime working age wage earners tended to feel they are having a hard time making ends meet and that young workers are particularly concerned about their lack of professional skills.
The poll findings also showed that the older the wage earners, the more they worry about job security and retirement benefits.
The survey also found that the intention to change jobs is highest among young workers at 41.4 percent and the lowest among those in the 45-64 age group.
Up to 74.5 percent of the overall respondents said they have no intention to change jobs or change to other professions.

Among those intending to change jobs, 40.6 percent said they hope to move to different professions and 30.9 percent said they look forward to being transferred to departments where their potential can be better developed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Port's container handling volume unchanged from 2007

TEXT.P: The number of containers handled at Kaohsiung harbor in southern Taiwan during the first eight months of this year showed no growth from the same period of 2007, prompting worries that the port might not maintain its status as one of the top 10 container ports in the world.

Officials at the Department of Aviation and Navigation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications pointed out that Kaohsiung port handled 6.72 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) between January and August -- the same level as during the corresponding period in 2007.
Previously released official statistics showed that for the January-August period of 2007, Kaohsiung harbor recorded an increase of 4.4 percent, or 283,380 TEUs, over the same period of 2006.
For all of 2007, the port handled 10.25 million TEUs, setting a new record and representing an increase of 4.9 percent over the previous year.

Kaohsiung was the world's third-largest container port in 2000, but its ranking has slipped in recent years. It retained its status as the sixth-largest container port in the world in 2006, but it slipped two places to become No. 8 in 2007.
The stagnant growth in container handling volume in the first eight months has triggered concern among officials about whether Kaohsiung port might be removed from the top 10 list this year.

Kaohsiung is currently lagging behind the five ports that ranked from first to fifth last year: Singapore, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Shenzhen, and Busan. It is also behind China's Ningbo and Guangzhou ports, which placed 11th and 12th, respectively, last year.

Because the other three ports -- Dubai, Rotterdam and Hamburg -- that ranked sixth, seventh and ninth, respectively, last year still have not publicized updated container volume statistics, it is unclear whether Kaohsiung can remain among the top 10 container ports in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Income tax deductions to be increased from 2009: officials

TEXT.P: Income tax deductions will be largely increased from 2009, government officials announced Tuesday after a meeting of the Executive Yuan's Tax Reform Commission (TRC).
According to the officials, TRC commissioners reached a consensus during the meeting that the amounts of various tax deductions will be increased from next year to ease wage earners' tax burdens.

In terms of the consensus, the standard deduction for single persons will be raised to NT$60,000 per person from the current NT$46,000 and will be increased for married couples filing together to NT$120,000 from NT$92,000 at present.

The standard salary deduction will also be raised to NT$100,000 from the present NT$78,000; deductions for education expenses will be increased to NT$25,000 per person from the current NT$25,000 per household; and deductions for the disabled will be raised to NT$100,000 from NT$77,000.

If the tax deduction increase proposal is passed by the Legislative Yuan, the officials said, local taxpayers will be able to enjoy such benefits when they file their tax returns for their 2009 incomes in 2010.
The deduction increase plan, if passed, will cost national coffers an estimated NT$15.3 billion, the officials said.
As to whether the income tax rates will be adjusted downward, the officials said, it needs further discussion. Probably, they said, new income tax rates could be adopted in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Investigation Bureau chief retracts accusation against ex-boss

TEXT.P: Yeh Sheng-mao, former chief of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, openly admitted for the first time Tuesday that he did not inform his superior of the ex-first family's possible involvement in money-laundering, backtracking on a previous charge.

When Yeh's potential involvement in concealing information related to the money- laundering allegations surfaced in August, he indicated that he had informed his superior, State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming, of the information obtained from abroad, in a meeting in early February.

But at Tuesday's trial hearing, Yeh admitted that he had not advised his boss of the contents of reports from the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering organization, on the first family's overseas bank accounts.
He apologized to Chen Tsung-ming in court, saying "I was wrong" several times during the trial hearing at the Taipei District Court.
Yeh was indicted on Aug. 28 for concealing and not investigating information on overseas bank accounts held by Chen Shui-bian's family members in the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean.
Yeh admitted on Sept. 2 that he handed the information to Chen Shui-bian in February while Chen was still serving as president.
His confession led prosecutors to bring an extra charge of leaking classified information against him, paving the way for his detention on Oct. 6.
Meanwhile, Yeh also testified Tuesday that he passed on information on alleged money-laundering activities of the former first family to former President Chen Shui-bian as early as December 2006.
He said that an anti-money laundering center at the Investigation Bureau received information from Jersey in the Channel Islands in December 2006 on overseas funds deposited there by Chen's family.

Yeh said he called Lin Teh-hsun, then director of the president's office, two or three days later to tell him he had received a report, without mentioning its contents, but later passed the information on to Chen.
Chen admitted in mid-August that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he had received as campaign contributions.

Chen confessed that he had not been faithful in reporting the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 but claimed that he was unaware that the surplus funds were wired abroad by his wife until early this year.
Yeh said he also received information On Dec. 12, 2007 from the Cayman Islands inquiring about Chen, his son, his daughter-in-law and the daughter-in-law's father, through the Egmont Group.
Yeh said he again called Lin in mid-December and late December about receiving inquiries from the Cayman Islands, and passed on the compiled information to Chen in early February this year.

The former Investigation Bureau chief said that Chen, after being informed of related information or letters, would tell him that a lot of the funds were used on diplomatic missions and that he would handle the matter.
Yeh said that in view of Chen's "stature and dignity, " he had believed that the former president would handle the matter properly.
In addition, as the chief of the Investigation Bureau, Yeh said, "I could not doubt his words" and "had a duty to respect and obey him."

Yeh said that he had soul-searched since Chen's alleged money-laundering scandal came to light in August, especially while being detained over the past week. He felt remorseful for being "careless and foolish."

Judge Tseng Cheng-lung said based on Yeh's position, it would be hard to believe that he truly felt the information he passed on to Chen was unrelated to criminal activity, and that the court would consider Yeh's attitude when meting out punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11,000 grey-faced buzzards pass Kenting, setting single-day record

TEXT.P: More than 11,000 grey-faced buzzards passed Kenting National Park in southeastern Taiwan Tuesday, setting a single-day record, a park administration specialist said.

Tsai Yi-jung said that since the administration began the systematic investigation of the number of the birds passing Kenting, the previous one-day high was 8,300 on Oct. 11, 2005, while the largest number for a season was 35,800 in 2006.
Tsai noted that as of Tuesday, more than 24,000 grey-faced buzzards had passed Kenting.
The birds usually fly through Taiwan between Oct. 1 and Oct. 20, with the largest numbers of migrating birds seen one or two days after Oct. 10.
This year, the massive movement started Oct. 9, with more than 3,000 flying toward sea Oct. 10. Since then, the number has averaged between 1,000 and 3,000 per day.

The grey-faced Buzzard is an Asian bird of prey. It is typically between 41-46 cm in length, making it a medium-sized raptor. It breeds in eastern Russia, northern China, Korea, and Japan, and winters in Southeast Asia.

Lee Chin-hung, a Ph. D. candidate at National Normal Taiwan University who has helped the National Geographic Channel film a documentary of the birds' migration over the past year, said that he found the migratory route of the birds was not always fixed and that some were actually wintering in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 15, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander in chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and new elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single Republic of China air force Saber jet, piloted by Capt. Sun Szu- wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese Communist MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried in a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y.T. Wong, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the ROC army headquarters and also the ROC navy headquarters.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, an Academia Sinica member, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo would send a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for democracy in South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
2000: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, urges the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
2001: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih arrive in Shanghai to attend a series of ministerial meetings under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for Oct. 15-18.
2001: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai- shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, dies in Hawaii at the age of 101.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Low salaries top headache for young wage earners: CLA survey

TEXT.P: Low wages are the number one job problem facing young wage earners while declining physical strength is the biggest worry for those nearing retirement age, according to the results of a survey released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Tuesday.
The Cabinet-level CLA conducted the survey in September to gain a better understanding of the living and job conditions of local wage earners, with 4,040 valid samples collected.

Asked about job-related problems, 39 percent of the respondents in the 15-24 age group cited "low wages" as their top headache and 30.7 percent listed "lack of professional skills or expertise" as their biggest hurdle.
For prime working age individuals in the 25-44 age group, the top two concerns were low wages (28.6 percent) and difficulties in balancing family life and their jobs.

To those aged between 45-64, the three major concerns were falling physical vigor (34.4 percent) , worries over being laid off (22.6 percent) and worries about being unable to receive their pensions (20.5 percent).

Analyzing the poll results, CLA officials said young and prime working age wage earners tended to feel they are having a hard time making ends meet and that young workers are particularly concerned about their lack of professional skills.
The poll findings also showed that the older the wage earners, the more they worry about job security and retirement benefits.
The survey also found that the intention to change jobs is highest among young workers at 41.4 percent and the lowest among those in the 45-64 age group.
Up to 74.5 percent of the overall respondents said they have no intention to change jobs or change to other professions.

Among those intending to change jobs, 40.6 percent said they hope to move to different professions and 30.9 percent said they look forward to being transferred to departments where their potential can be better developed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Port's container handling volume unchanged from 2007

TEXT.P: The number of containers handled at Kaohsiung harbor in southern Taiwan during the first eight months of this year showed no growth from the same period of 2007, prompting worries that the port might not maintain its status as one of the top 10 container ports in the world.

Officials at the Department of Aviation and Navigation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications pointed out that Kaohsiung port handled 6.72 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) between January and August -- the same level as during the corresponding period in 2007.
Previously released official statistics showed that for the January-August period of 2007, Kaohsiung harbor recorded an increase of 4.4 percent, or 283,380 TEUs, over the same period of 2006.
For all of 2007, the port handled 10.25 million TEUs, setting a new record and representing an increase of 4.9 percent over the previous year.

Kaohsiung was the world's third-largest container port in 2000, but its ranking has slipped in recent years. It retained its status as the sixth-largest container port in the world in 2006, but it slipped two places to become No. 8 in 2007.
The stagnant growth in container handling volume in the first eight months has triggered concern among officials about whether Kaohsiung port might be removed from the top 10 list this year.

Kaohsiung is currently lagging behind the five ports that ranked from first to fifth last year: Singapore, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Shenzhen, and Busan. It is also behind China's Ningbo and Guangzhou ports, which placed 11th and 12th, respectively, last year.

Because the other three ports -- Dubai, Rotterdam and Hamburg -- that ranked sixth, seventh and ninth, respectively, last year still have not publicized updated container volume statistics, it is unclear whether Kaohsiung can remain among the top 10 container ports in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Income tax deductions to be increased from 2009: officials

TEXT.P: Income tax deductions will be largely increased from 2009, government officials announced Tuesday after a meeting of the Executive Yuan's Tax Reform Commission (TRC).
According to the officials, TRC commissioners reached a consensus during the meeting that the amounts of various tax deductions will be increased from next year to ease wage earners' tax burdens.
Up to 3.6 million households, or roughly 70 percent of the total, will benefit from the proposed increases of the four deductions, officials said.

In terms of the consensus, the standard deduction for single persons will be raised to NT$60,000 per person from the current NT$46,000 and will be increased for married couples filing together to NT$120,000 from NT$92,000 at present.

The standard salary deduction will also be raised to NT$100,000 from the present NT$78,000; deduction for education expenses will be increased to NT$25,000 per person from the current NT$25,000 per household; and deduction for the disabled will be raised to NT$100,000 from NT$77,000.

If the tax deduction increase proposal is passed by the Legislative Yuan, the officials said, local taxpayers will be able to enjoy such benefits when they file their tax returns for their 2009 incomes in 2010.

The deduction increase plan, if passed, will cost national coffers an estimated NT$15.3 billion, the officials said, adding that salaried people will benefit from the increased salary deduction. Salaries have traditionally accounted for 75 percent of total income tax revenues.

As to whether the income tax rates will be adjusted downward, the officials said, it needs further discussion. Probably, they said, new income tax rates could be adopted in 2010. If so, new tax rates will be used in 2011 when taxpayers file reports on their 2010 incomes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Estate, gift tax rates may be lowered to 10%: finance minister

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance may opt to cut the maximum inheritance and gift tax rates to 10 percent to lure funds back to Taiwan and buoy the domestic economy, Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Wednesday.

The Executive Yuan's Tax Reform Commission has already drawn up five versions of an estate and gift tax reduction plan, but Lee said at a Legislative Yuan Finance Committee hearing that his agency is leaning toward the Council for Economic Planning and Development's proposal to lower the maximum rates to 10 percent.
At present, the maximum marginal inheritance tax and gift tax rates are both 50 percent, a rate many economists believe compels wealthy Taiwanese to send their money abroad to avoid paying taxes.

"The Finance Ministry's stance is that it hopes inheritance and gift tax rates can be lowered as much as possible. That would lure capital back to Taiwan and bring greater vitality to the economy, " Lee said.
The tax reduction plan, however, will have to submitted to Premier Liu Chao- shiuan for approval, Lee said. Any tax reform plan has to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for final approval.
Lee said the new, lower estate and gift tax rates, if approved, will cost national coffers an estimated NT$20 billion a year.
According to the Finance Minitry, the inheritance and gift taxes are among the least significant of the government's revenue sources, accounting for NT$28 billion in revenues in 2007.
Lee has argued, however, that those receipts could be easily replaced by increased tax revenues from brisker economic activity.
In addition, according to Finance Ministry officials, only a small number of people who have potential tax liabilities actually pay the taxes under existing legal provisions.
Only 4,900 of the 100,000 people with potential inheritance tax liabilities and only 40,000 of the 200,000 with potential gift tax liabilities actually paid the taxes in 2007, the officials said.

In addition, most of the 4,900 paying inheritance tax were from the middle class rather than wealthy individuals with over NT$100 million in tax liabilities, who would be the main targets of the lower tax rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25% of trees in Taipei City public spaces toxic

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government, under pressure from city councilors, acknowledged Tuesday that a number of trees and plants in Taipei's parks have toxic fruit or leaves and promised not to plant such trees in the future.
At a Taipei City Council hearing Tuesday, Kuomintang (KMT) Councilor Ou Yang Long asserted that of the more than 800,000 trees and plants in Taipei, 25 percent have toxic fruit or leaves.
Those who come into contact with the leaves or eat the fruit may contract allergies or develop symptoms such as dizziness and vomiting, Ou Yang said.
Chen Jia-chin, the director of Taipei City's Parks and Street Lights Office, acknowledged that 68 kinds of trees planted in city parks and along sidewalks have toxic elements.
The Odollam erberus tree, the Pagoda tree, the Chinese tallow tree and the paperbark were among those identified by Chen as being potentially hazardous.
Chen stressed that people should not touch the leaves or eat the fruit from these trees and plants but said his office had no plans to remove them.
He promised, however, that no more trees and plants that might pose a health hazard would be planted and that the city would post warning signs near trees with toxic characteristics.
The Parks and Street Lights Office is responsible for the planning, construction, and management of parks, greens and streetlights of Taipei City.
The trees considered to have toxic fruit or leaves can be found on the office's Chinese language Web site at http://pkl.taipei.gov.tw/cgi- bin/SM_theme?page=437c8a5a.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
WTO clarifies Chinese wording on milk contamination incident

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization clarified Tuesday that a Chinese official at a WTO committee meeting referred to the widespread adulteration of milk with the toxic chemical melamine as an "incident," rather than as an "accident" as previously reported.

The WTO correction is an indication of the Chinese government's sensitivity to the international community's reaction to the latest in a string of Chinese food safety debacles that have raised concerns around the world.
The Chinese description of the issue as an "accident" was seen by the news media as an attempt by Chinese authorities to play down the issue.

In the original summary of the Sanitary and Phytosanitary committe meeting, a WTO official quoted a Chinese official as saying that the contamination was an "accident, " but apparently the Chinese delegation did not mean to use the word "accident" as understood in English.
"They merely wanted to refer to it as an 'incident, '" a WTO official told the Central News Agency.

Melamine, normally used in industrial applications, was added to diluted milk to mask lower protein levels. Four children died in China and tens of thousands of children were sickened after drinking the adulterated milk.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Nobel laureate to be named honorary Academia Sinica academician

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica would be pleased to name U.S. biochemist Roger Y. Tsien, a winner of the 2008 Nobel Prize in chemistry, as an honorary academician and invite him to visit Taiwan, the head of Taiwan's top research institution said Wednesday.

Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong seconded ruling Kuomintang Legislator Liao Cheng-ching's suggestion at a Legislative Yuan Education and Culture Committee hearing that Academia Sinica name Tsien as an honorary academician and invite him to visit Taiwan.

Tsien, a professor with the University of California, San Diego, won the Nobel Prize in chemistry with Osamu Shimomura and Martin Chalfie last week for the discovery and development of the green fluorescent protein, which can be used as a tool to monitor the movement of cells and their affiliated proteins.

Tsien, who has lived his entire life in the United States and was born to parents from China, was previously rejected as an academician by Academia Sinica academicians. Wong said the "honorary academician" title was more suitable.

"Given that Tsien grew up in the United States, does not speak Mandarin and was not educated in Taiwan, nominating him to become an 'honorary academician' would be more feasible, " the Academia Sinica president said.
Wong, also a biochemist, added that he was well acquainted with Tsien and had known for sure that Tsien would some day become a Nobel laureate.
"I will meet Tsien at international workshops or symposiums this year and I'd like to extend an invitation to him then to visit Taiwan whenever it's convenient for him, " Wong said.
According to Academia Sinica regulations, signatures of endorsement from 10 academicians are required to enable a nominee to become an honorary academician.

The Convocation of Academia Sinica consists of more than 240 academicians, including 6 Nobel laureates. Unlike regular academicians, honorary academicians do not necessarily perform research or attend meetings at the Academia Sinica campus.
This year, the institution selected eight people as honorary academicians, most of them Nobel laureates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temporary bridge for collapsed Jiasian Bridge opens to traffic

TEXT.P: A temporary bridge constructed to replace Kaohsiung County's Jiasian Bridge which collapsed when Typhoon Sinlaku hit Taiwan last month opened to traffic Wednesday.
The 100-meter temporary bridge and feeder road were constructed by the Third Maintenance Office of the Directorate General of Highways under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The bridge and road, upon which construction began shortly after Sinlaku swept across the island, were washed out during Typhoon Jangmi which came right on the heels of Sinlaku.
The maintenance office said that as special supports were used for the temporary bridge to allow river waters to flow smoothly underneath, a maximum load restriction of 20 tons has been imposed.
As for the new Jiasian Bridge, the office said that it is currently in the planning stages and that construction work will be contracted out before the end of this year.
Construction of the new bridge will take about two years to complete, during which time the temporary bridge and feeder road will remain in operation, the office said.
It added that the bridge and road will be closed during the flood season and during typhoons for safety reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices weaker on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Wednesday, hit by an overnight fall on Wall Street, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 45.3 points, or 0.85 percent, to close at 5,246.26.
Unable to sustain its gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 5,225.05 and fluctuated between 5,246.26 and 5,178.68.
A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$53.35 billion (US$1.65 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.3 percent. Textile stocks rose 1 percent.

Cement issues dropped the most at 2.8 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks and paper and pulp shares falling 1.4 percent. Machinery and electronics shares as well as financial and insurance stocks both lost 1 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares fell 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,090 to 466, with 325 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$1.18 billion, the first time foreign investors bought a higher value of shares than they sold in a single session since Sept. 22.
