DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers find method to extract DHA from algae

TEXT.P: Researchers at the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) have invented a new way to extract pollution-free docosa hexaenoic acid (DHA) from an indigenous species of algae that could revolutionize the way the supplement is produced commercially, academic sources said Wednesday.

Team members said DHA is normally derived from fish and shellfish, but minute quantity of toxins -- such as methyl mercury or dioxins -- may migrate from the fish to the DHA, a common nutritional additive used in food or animal feeds.

Chen I-min, an NCKU assistant professor and the co-leader of the project, said this contamination led the team to search for new avenues to extract DHA, and it decided to further investigate the possibility of deriving DHA from algae.
The researchers first selected an alga species as the subject of their experiment and then induced fermentation among algae to observe their DHA productivity, Chen said.

Yang Huey-lang, a professor at NCKU's Institute of Biotechnology, noted that the results proved the algae can produce DHA in quantity and without man-made pollutants, indicating its potential as a food ingredient.
Yang said several Taiwan-based biotech companies have showed interest in the process and its related technologies and in applying the method to mass production.
DHA is a highly touted food supplement that is said to help reduce the risk of heart disease or mitigate DHA deficiences that may lead to diseases such as Alzheimer's.

Meanwhile, after presenting the results to the 2008 annual meeting of the European Aquaculture Society, the team's achievements were highly praised and an award in the "Best Poster" section was given to the team, according to the university.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwan nationals arrested at Hong Kong electronics show
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/08 17:11:12 (By Lo Kin-fai and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan citizens were arrested Tuesday at an electronics fair at the AsiaWorld-Expo in Hong Kong for selling tasers, pepper spray and other security items without authorization.
A Hong Kong police spokeswoman confirmed to the Central News Agency Wednesday that a 46-year-old man surnamed Fu and a 47-year-old man surnamed Liu were arrested the previous day.

According to the spokeswoman, police received a tip at 3 p.m. Tuesday that vendors at the fair were selling banned items. After a search of the venue, the police discovered hidden taser guns and pepper spray at Fu's booth and proceeded to arrest him.
Shortly thereafter, they uncovered tasers, handcuffs and ammo cartridges at Liu's booth and also took him into custody.
The two men were charged with possessing banned weapons and ammunition and appeared in court for a hearing Wednesday, the spokeswoman said.
According to Hong Kong law, anyone who wants to import tasers or sell them in the special administrative region must first apply at customs for police approval.
Violators can face a maximum fine of 10,000 Hong Kong dollars (US$1,290) and up to three years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.012 to close at NT$32.400.
A total of US$1.012 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.388 and fluctuated between NT$32.359 and NT$32.465.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ceremony previews Taichung-Penghu ferry service

TEXT.P: A high-speed ferry was officially launched at Taichung Harbor Wednesday, paving the way for the opening of regular passenger and cargo ferry services between Taichung and Makong on Penghu Island later this month.

A host of honorary guests, including Vice President Vincent Siew's wife, Chu Chu-hsien, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, attended a ribbon cutting ceremony for the high-speed OceanLaLa, owned by Excalibur International Marine Corp.

The guests were able to board and tour the vessel but did not get a chance to set out to sea, because Excalibur International opted against testing waves estimated by the Central Weather Bureau at between three and four meters high.

The Taichung-Penghu ferry services will begin later in October if trial runs of the OceanLaLa in coming days are successful and the Taichung Harbor Bureau grants permission for the service to begin, said Excalibur International founder Chiao Jen-ho, formerly a vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.

If everything goes smoothly, Chiao said, the Singapore-built OceanLaLa will also sail between Penghu and China's southeastern coastal city of Xiamen beginning at the end of October, in addition to the Taichung-Penghu route.

The OceanLaLa is expected to offer visitors from Taiwan to China a new travel option under the expanded "mini three links" formula, using Penghu -- about 41 kilometers off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper -- as a transit stop, Chiao said.
The 2,300-ton OceanLaLa will sail the Taichung-Penghu route at a speed up to 35 knots, covering the distance in two and a half hours, said Lu Chu-chun, an Excalibur International spokesman.
It would depart Taichung Harbor at 8 a.m. each day and return from Makong at 7 p.m. the same day.
The ferry service will be priced competitively, Lu said, with a one-way ticket costing NT$1,300 (US$40), compared to NT$1,610 (US$50) for an airplane ticket.
The OceanLaLa can accommodate up to 536 passengers, along with 54 cars and six tourist buses. An extra charge of NT$3,000 (US$95) will be collected per car aboard.

The Taichung Harbor Bureau looks forward to seeing tourism grow in central Taiwan after the launch of the OceanLaLa -- the first passenger ferry service to use the harbor since it was opened in 1976, harbor officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK announces policies to foster relations with Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hong Kong on Wednesday announced a series of policies aimed at fostering the territory's relations with Taiwan.
The policies are carried in the government's 2008-09 Policy Address, which was given by Chief Executive Donald Tsang in the Legislative Council Wednesday morning.
Speaking about regional integration, Mr. Tsang said that the semi-official Hong Kong Trade Development Council (TDC) will set up an office in Taipei.
"The preparatory work is now at the final stage," he said.
The aim is to strengthen exchanges and co-operation with Taiwan, he said.

Mr. Tsang also said that the government is encouraging local industrial and business leaders, as well as Taiwanese businessmen in Hong Kong, to form a Hong Kong-Taiwan Business Co-operation Committee.
"The committee will facilitate direct communications between enterprises from both places and foster closer co-operation in areas such as trade, investment and tourism," he said.
According to Tsang, the Immigration Department will also introduce two new measures in January 2009 to provide greater convenience for frequent business visitors and tourists from Taiwan.
The two new measures include:
-Removing the restriction that limits a person to two iPermit applications--- applications for visa through the Internet--- within each 30-day period;
-Extending the limit of stay in Hong Kong from 14 days to 30 days for holders of iPermits and multiple-entry permits.

Mr. Tsang also revealed that the government has set up an inter-departmental steering committee to examine and co-ordinate the overall strategy and plans on closer economic and trade ties with Taiwan.
The committee is being led by the financial secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: State-run sugar company expands organic farming

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation (TSC) has decided to expand the scale of its organic farming operations in response to strong public demand, a press released issued by the company said Wednesday.
The public enterprise will expand the land area devoted to cultivating organic rice from the current 25 hectares to 113 hectares, which is expected to increase annual output to 450 metric tons.

At the same time, TSC will also extend its organic fruit and vegetable cultivation to several townships in the Kaohsiung and Yunlin areas, through which it hopes to expand its output to 300 metric tons of produce each year, the press release said.

Currently, the company maintains organic fruit and vegetable farms totaling 3.4 hectares of land in Huwei township in Yunlin County, Shanhua township in Tainan County and Nanzih district in Kaohsiung City.

Due to a recent public scare over China-made foodstuffs after it was found that milk powder tainted with melamine from China had been imported to and sold in Taiwan, local demand for safe food had surged in recent weeks, pushing Taisugar to step up its organic farming.
Taisugar began its small-scale organic plantation of rice and vegetables in 2000, and its produce was only sold at its chain of convenience stores in limited supplies, according to the press release.

At present, the organic produce grown by TSC can be found at over 40 convenience stores of the Matsusei chain and exclusive organic product stores in the Tainan, Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taoyuan areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwanese students badly beaten in Xiamen

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese students have been severely beaten by several faculty members and students from Xiamen University in southeast China's Fujian province, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.
The two young men, Hsueh An-cheng and Liao He-jun, - both students at Xiamen University - were beaten Monday night. They were immediately taken to Chung Shan Hospital in Xiamen.

According to the SEF, Hsueh suffered a broken nose and was released from the hospital after medical treatment. Liao sustained more wounds and received 40 stitches to the face and 100 stitches to the body.
Liao remains in hospital in stable condition, a SEF official told CNA.

The SEF cited witnesses as saying that the two Taiwanese students were eating at a restaurant just outside the campus when they were beaten. Witnesses said that the two students were being very noisy. This led to people at a nearby table becoming very upset, to the extent of beating the two Taiwanese students.
Upon receiving information about the incident, the SEF immediately made a telephone call and then sent a formal letter to ARATS, asking for assistance.
The SEF requested that the ARATS provide medical attention to the students, investigate the actual cause of the incident, punish those involved and assist in matters of compensation.

According to the SEF, the ARATS has designated Xiamen police to investigate the incident. The SEF has also asked the Taiwan Businessmen Association in Xiamen to send personnel to the hospital to look after the two students.
The SEF expressed regret over this incident and warned Taiwanese students in China to be cautious and to be aware of their safety.
In addition, the SEF is reminding Taiwanese people in China to call their 24-hour hotline at 886-2712-9292 whenever they face problems.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations that are responsible for handling cross-strait affairs in the absence of formal government relations.
Xiamen City is a port city in mainland China where many Taiwan businessmen and students reside.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese director ready to begin shooting of Louvre 'face'
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 15 (CNA) 10/15/08 19:17:30 (by Tsai Hsiao-ying and Jian Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese director Tsai Ming-liang was personally received Tuesday by the director of the Louvre Museum in Paris, less than a month before shooting begins at the famous museum for Tsai's latest film called "Visages."

The director, along with leading actress Laetitia Casta and actor Lee Kang- sheng, were welcomed by Henri Loyrett, the museum's director, and they gathered in front of Leonardo da Vinci's painting "St. John the Baptist," the face, or "visage" of Tsai's new endeavor.

The movie, a tribute to French New Wave cinema, will be a film within a film. It tells the story of a Chinese filmmaker who heads to the Louvre to shoot a film that revolves around the myth of Salome and her request to her father Herod that St. John the Baptist be beheaded.

Tsai said during the planning of the film that he was willing to shoot any painting except for da Vinci's Mona Lisa, and when reminded of Tsai's comment Tuesday, Loyrett laughed and agreed with the sentiment.
Tsai also asked Loyrett if the painting of St. John the Baptist could be exhibited in Taiwan when the film appears in movie theaters.
"It is possible for you to film wherever you want or borrow any painting, but you absolutely cannot borrow Mona Lisa, " Loyrett replied.
"Visages" is the museum's latest collaboration with filmmakers to create thematic productions based on its collection.

The release in 2006 of "The Da Vinci Code, " which showcased the museum in a number of its scenes, boosted the museum's popularity, with a record-breaking 84 million visitors setting foot in the Louvre in 2007.

"Visages, " a French-Taiwanese production, will also be another cross-cultural collaboration of different artistic elements, Loyrett noted, following the architectural cooperation with I. M. Pei in 1983 to construct the Louvre Pyramid, now a Paris landmark.
Loyrett went on to express his hope that the Louvre's significance would transcend borders through Tsai's creation.
Meanwhile, Tsai said he felt very proud and happy that a Taiwanese work would be chosen to feature the museum.

He believed that the Louvre wanted to show that cultural value could be preserved in movies, and said this Taiwanese production with French assistance would redefine art and show that movies are a type of culture as well.
After three years of preparation and NT$200 million in investment from Taiwan, France, the Netherlands and Belgium, shooting of the film is expected to begin Nov. 10.
Tsai will spend two and a half months in France and then shoot the remaining scenes in Taipei early next year.
The production has already been tapped as a possible hit at next year's Cannes International Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police ready for key Beijing negotiator's visit: NPA chief

TEXT.P: Police authorities have made adequate security arrangements for a visit to Taiwan by a top Beijing negotiator to ensure his safety, National Police Agency (NPC) Director-General Wang Cho-chiun said Wednesday.

Although it is the National Security Bureau that is primarily responsible for security during the Beijing official's visit, the police are well prepared to protect his safety at his place of accommodation and while he is attending activities in Taiwan, Wang said.

Wang made the remarks while answering questions by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chia-chin, who urged police authorities to get ready for the upcoming visit by Chen Yun-lin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , which is slated for late October or early November.
"However, it remains unclear which hotel Chen will stay at and what activities he will engage in while in Taiwan," Wang said.

Chen is slated to hold talks in Taipei with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, on cross-strait transportation issues, including the establishment of regular cargo charter flights and expansion of weekend passenger charter flights, and on cross-strait cooperation in the areas of financial supervision and crime fighting.

The Chiang-Chen meeting in Taipei will be a follow-up to a landmark meeting between the two men in Beijing in June, in which they clinched two accords on weekend charter flights and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists.

In light of Chen's highly sensitive status as China's top liaison with Taiwan in the absence of contact between the two governments, Lee called for the highest degree of protection of Chen's personal safety while the official is in Taiwan, in order to avoid any possible complications in bilateral relations.
Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said it will stage a large-scale anti-China demonstration Oct. 25 in Taipei.

Chen Cheng-wen, head of the DPP's Kaohsiung City committee, said the response among supporters has been enthusiastic. He estimated that 165 fully loaded tour buses will transport people from Kaohsiung to Taipei to join the protest.
To achieve the DPP's target of 1 million protestors, Kaohsiung city councilors and DPP members have been assigned to mobilize supporters and have each been allotted a quota, Chen Cheng-wen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children, teenagers suffer after parents affected by cancer

TEXT.P: Children whose father or mother have cancer can be tormented by the experience, a survey has revealed, with most children feeling financial woes but some also suffering severe emotional disturbances.

According to a survey released Wednesday by the Taipei-based Hope Society for Cancer Care, 88 percent of 323 respondent cancer families -- defined as families with children in elementary or junior high school whose father, mother or both parents are afflicted with cancer -- said the most obvious impact of cancer on their home life was the financial strain brought by the disease.
The survey found that 20 percent of the cancer patients who responded said they still must work to maintain their livelihood.
Only 30 percent of the polled cancer families obtained financial aid through social welfare organizations while 10 percent of the families said they relied on relief from relatives and friends.

Chien Huei-lan, an executive member of the society, said that although the national health insurance system covers part of cancer patients' medical treatment costs, it does not pay for new and expensive targeted medication.
And medication is only part of the high expenses a cancer patient has to face, which also include spending on caregivers and special nutrition, she said.
Some patients were also faced with the challenge of a declining income because they needed to take work leaves to seek medical treatment.

In his study in the survey, Lu Chun-hung, a lecturer at Soochow University's Department of Social Work, said 80 percent of the children will experience negative emotional disturbances such as sorrow, anxiety, and anger after learning their parents have been diagnosed with the disease.
But he also found that 53 percent of the children in cancer families became more clever and learned how to handle situations.

In coping of their parent's affliction, some children take it on themselves to replace the parent and mature prematurely while others suffer behavioral degeneration and emotional blocks that holds them back in school and in their relationships with friends, Lu said.

Chien concluded that economically-challenged cancer families not only need more support from the national health insurance system and social welfare policies, the children also need assistance that will help them surmount the dark clouds hovering over their family.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cape No. 7 wins Best Narrative Film Award at Hawaii Festival

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-produced box office hit, Cape No. 7, won the Best Narrative Film Award at the 2008 Louis Vuitton Hawaii International Film Festival Tuesday.

According to information posted on the festival's Web site, an international jury screened 150 entries from 36 countries based on the Hawaii film festival's mandate "to entertain, enlighten and empower."

Other awards were presented for the best documentary, the best short film, the best film in Hawaii, achievement in acting, plus a Viewers Choice Award, a Maverick Award, and an award from the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema.

Vanessa Shih, minister of the Government Information Office (GIO), has extended congratulations on behalf of the government to the film's director Wei Te-sheng, who was present at the festival, according to officials at the GIO's Department of Motion Picture Affairs.
The officials said that in addition to receiving a cash award of NT$100,000, Wei will be entitled to a government subsidy to cover 20 percent of the movie's NT$50 million (US$1.54 million) budget.

The Hawaii film festival award was the third in row for Cape No. 7, which also captured the first prize at the fourth Asian Marine Film Festival in Makuhari, Japan, in September, as well as three awards -- the Grand Prize, the Best Music and Best Cinematography awards -- at the 2008 Taipei Film Festival in June before the film was released commercially.

Cape No. 7 is a romantic comedy and Wei's first full-length motion picture. It is still being screened in movie theaters around Taiwan, with box office takings already surpassing NT$400 million (US$12.34 million) -- the second highest in Taiwan, next to the NT$775 million for the Hollywood blockbuster Titanic.

The film tells two interrelated stories. One is a love story about a Japanese man leaving his Taiwanese girlfriend in what is now Pingtung County in southern Taiwan when Japan gave up its colonial rule of the island. The other is about the dreams of a group of young, amateur Taiwanese musicians.
In her congratulatory message to Wei, Shih wished him further success with his next feature film, Seediq Bale, on which shooting is scheduled to begin in autumn next year.

Seediq Bale is a story about the Wushe Incident of 1930, in which Seediq warrior Mona Rudao led the aboriginal people from his tribe in an armed rebellion against the Japanese occupiers in Nantou County.

They killed 125 Japanese and wounded more than 200 others. In retaliation, the Japanese colonial government deployed 2,000 soldiers and police officers who placed the Seediq tribe under siege for months. Mona, along with some 300 of his warriors, refused to surrender and killed themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 61 percent of employees afraid of losing jobs: poll

TEXT.P: More than 61 percent of Taiwan's white- collar workers are afraid they would be laid off amid the sluggish economic situation in the country, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

Some 25.7 percent of the respondents said their companies were seemingly prepared to streamline the work force, while 8.8 percent said their companies had already cut the number of employees, the survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank showed.

A little more than 16 percent of the employees polled said their enterprises had not filled the vacancies left by departing workers, while 45.7 percent said they were not aware of any job-cutting plans by their employers.
Around 6.5 percent of the respondents said they thought they would "very probably" be laid off, in contrast to 55.1 percent who said that they "could" face that fate.
Twenty-two of the white-collar workers polled said they were confident that they would not be fired, while 16.5 percent said they were fully convinced they would be laid off, the survey found.

Regarding bonuses, 29.3 percent were apprehensive that their year-end bonuses or cash rewards would be adversely affected by sagging business, while 28.9 percent said that their benefits had been cut.
Some 8.6 percent complained of a salary cut due to their companies' operating losses, but 3.4 percent of the white-collar workers said they had received a pay raise.

In view of the financial crisis that has swept many countries across the globe, 32 percent of the office workers polled contended that the bio-medical sector would not be affected but instead would score a brilliant performance.

Industries related to astrological readings, foodstuff, gas and electricity, and telecommunications were cited by most of the respondents as sectors less vulneralbe to the effects of sluggish economy.

On the other hand, construction, tourism, auto manufacturing, financial insurance, and department stores are the businesses most likely to come under strong pressure as a result of the present economic recession, according to the poll.
The public opinion survey was conducted from Sept. 30 to Oct. 4. It collected 3,919 valid questionnaires and had a margin of error of 1.57 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Textile show opens at World Trade Center

TEXT.P: A textile exhibition featuring healthy, bio-friendly and hi-tech fibers opened at the World Trade Center in Taipei Wednesday, according to the organizer.

The 2008 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) attracted some 250 exhibitors, including companies from India, Japan and China, that are showcasing their latest innovative products at 500 booths, said the organizer, the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF).

TTF secretary-general Huang Wei-ji said that the TTF collaborated for the first time with certified manufacturers such as Far Eastern Textile and Control Union to plan a special organic cotton section that would serve as a showpiece for "green industry opportunities."
Huang also noted that several Taiwanese manufacturers have unveiled new products that use bio-friendly materials such as natural bamboo, charcoal and corn fibers.

Innovative products are even more important in light of the economic downturn, said Huang Hua-de, chairman of TEXMA International Co., a local manufacturer that has developed fabrics with the use of recycled plastic bottles. TEXMA's export orders are expected to increase sharply this year, he said.
TITAS is being held with the support of the National Cotton Council of America and several textile-related domestic corporations such as Nan Ya Plastics and Formosa Chemicals & Fiber.
The show will end on October 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seek detention of former minister

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Prosecutors Office sought to detain Yu Chen-shien, a former minister of the interior, Wednesday on charges connected to a case of alleged bribery.

Yu was intercepted by law-enforcement personnel at Kaohsiung International Airport Wednesday while he was attempting to leave the country after being listed as a potential suspect in the case of alleged bribery in connection with the construction of an exhibition hall in the Taipei suburban district of Nangang in 2003.
Yu was then taken to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office where he was questioned about his role in the case.

Lin Chin-tsun, deputy chief prosecutor of the office, said after the questioning that the prosecutor in charge of the case filed for a court order to detain Yu after the investigator found that Yu was possibly involved in leaking confidential government information, profiteering, and colluding with witnesses in the case.
Lin said Yu was barred from leaving the country before the prosecutors office summoned him on Oct. 7 to report to the office Thursday as a potential suspect.
Earlier Wednesday the prosecutor sent another summons asking Yu to report to the office that day after it was learned that the suspect was preparing to leave the country, Lin said.

According to the prosecutors office, Yu is suspected of leaking the names of members of a committee that was responsible for screening the bids for the costly construction of the Nangang Exhibition Hall.
Yu made the name list available to the company that eventually won the bid, during his tenure as minister of the interior in the period 2002-2004, the prosecutor charged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official makes pitch in support of direct postal links with China

TEXT.P: Direct postal links between Taiwan and China would reduce the delivery time and save costs to the benefit of both sides, an official familiar with the postal industry said Wednesday.

The official, who requested anonymity, made the statement after Yang Yi, a spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said earlier in the day in Beijing that the launch of direct postal links will be on the agenda of the cross-strait negotiations to be held late this month or early November in Taipei.

The lack of postal links resulted partly from the fact that there were no direct cross-strait air links prior to the weekend direct charter flights that were launched on July 4, the official explained.

Currently, all China-bound mail distributed either by the state-run Chunghwa Postal Co., Ltd. or private express delivery companies are sent to China via a transit point and are handled by one or more forwarding agents, the official said.
In the best case scenario, which means minimum time between the air transfers, it takes one day for express mail from Taiwan to arrive at the delivery point in China, the official said.
But more often it takes three days, the official said, adding that direct postal links would ensure one-day delivery.
However, this would not apply to ordinary post which would take one week to twelve days to deliver, according to the official.

Furthermore, there is no postal clearance mechanism between Taiwan and China at this time, which means each side is responsible for compensation to the sender if registered post is lost by the other side.
This puts Taiwan at an advantage, in light of the fact that the volume of mail from Taiwan to China is much more than that sent from China to Taiwan, said the official.
The official welcomed China's decision to include the issue in the forthcoming talks, and said he looked forward to seeing the nagging problem settled once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Income subsidy for 'near poor' has no legal foundation: lawmakers

TEXT.P: Two legislators told Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi Wednesday that the government's income subsidy plan implemented from October to help "near poor" people cope with price hikes lacks legal foundation.

Wu Yu-sheng, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang, said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Internal Administration Committee that the subsidy plan is a matter of urgency because many low-income families need help.

Wu said that although he supports the NT$20.2 billion (US$ 623.46 million) allocation requested by the government to implement the plan in 2009, the interior minister must first provide a legal basis to justify the planned budget.

Chiu Yi-ying, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, claimed that the NT$5.7 billion to be spent by the government on the plan in the final quarter of 2008 and the NT$20.2 billion it has requested for 2009 are both "unlawful."
She said she and other DPP legislators will introduce a resolution to freeze the budget request.
In response, the interior minister acknowledged there were some errors in formulating the subsidy plan. He said he will consult with budget experts on how to straighten out the proposal.
The income subsidy plan is intended to help 1.35 million people in 450,000 families that are at risk of falling into poverty because of continuous hikes in commodity prices during the past months.

Under the plan, one employed member in each family whose annual income is below NT$300,000 and whose assets are worth less than NT$3.9 million would be entitled to between NT$3,000 and NT$6,000 per month for six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former minister detained by prosecutors on bribery charges

TEXT.P: Former Minister of the Interior Yu Chen-shien was detained Wednesday on charges connected to a case of alleged bribery.

The Taipei District Court granted prosecutors' request for Yu's detention on grounds that he was possibly involved in leaking confidential government information and profiteering, and may have colluded with witnesses in the case.

Yu was intercepted by law-enforcement personnel at Kaohsiung International Airport Wednesday while he was attempting to leave the country after being listed as a potential suspect in the case of alleged bribery on a construction project for an exhibition hall in the Taipei suburban district of Nangang in 2003.
Yu was taken to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office where he was questioned about his role in the case.
Lin Chin-tsun, deputy chief prosecutor of the office, said after the questioning that the prosecutor in charge of the case had filed for a court order to detain Yu.
Lin said Yu was barred from leaving the country before the prosecutors office summoned him on Oct. 7 to report to the office Thursday as a potential suspect.
Earlier Wednesday the prosecutor sent another summons asking Yu to report to the office that day after it was learned that the suspect was preparing to leave the country, Lin said.

According to the prosecutors office, Yu is suspected of leaking the names of members of a committee that was responsible for screening the bids for the costly construction of the Nangang Exhibition Hall.
Yu made the name list available to the company that eventually won the bid, during his tenure as minister of the interior in the period 2002-2004, the prosecutor charged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 16, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County to hold joint athletic meet for farmers, fishermen

TEXT.P: Hualien County in eastern Taiwan will hold a joint athletic meet for farmers and fishermen Oct. 18, after a 15-year suspension of the annual county event.

Du Li-hua, director of the Hualien County government's Bureau of Agriculture, said Wednesday that county Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan decided to resume the event after accepting the suggestions from local farmers and fishermen's associations.
She said that about 2,000 members of 10 farmers and fishermen's associations in Hualien County will take part in the athletic meet in Hualien Stadium.
In addition to sports competitions, the event will include various fun contests and farming and fishery-related games.

DOC.HEADLINE: 64% of public approve of China negotiator's visit to Taiwan: poll

TEXT.P: Sixty-four percent of the people in Taiwan approve of a visit to the country by a top China negotiator for high-level talks, according to the results of a poll released by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.

But 52 percent of the respondents also said that China should first apologize for selling its toxic dairy products to Taiwan, before Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, can visit Taiwan to hold talks with his counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.

Liu Te-hsun, MAC spokesman and vice chairman, urged China to address the mainstream concern of the Taiwan people so as to lay a solid foundation for the development of harmonious relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The survey showed that 64.29 percent of the respondents support the Chiang-Chen meeting, which is expected to take place in Taiwan later this month or early November.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to hold a demonstration Oct. 25 to protest what it called the incompetence of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and to drive home its call for the safeguarding of Taiwan's sovereignty. The party also aims to highlight what is said is the inappropriate timing of Chen's visit amid a public scare over imports of toxic milk products from China.

The scheduled Chiang-Chen meeting will be a follow-up to a landmark meeting in Beijing between the two in mid-June during which both sides reached an agreement on weekend cross-strait charter flights and the expansion of the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

According to the poll results, 64.29 percent of the Taiwan public support the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting, with 55.51 percent saying that they do not think Chen's visit would undermine national dignity or interests.

The survey also showed that 64.85 percent of those polled think the Chinese government is unfriendly toward Taiwan government and 45.98 percent think that the Chinese government is unfriendly toward the Taiwan people.
Commenting on the results of the survey, National Chengchi University professor Chao Chien-min said that "there is no need to worry about that issue."
He pointed out that in previous polls, the ratio of people who thought that China was friendly toward Taiwan never surpassed 2 percent.
But in the latest survey, those who think China is friendly toward the Taiwan government and the Taiwan people accounted for 24 and 39 percent of the respondents, respectively, he noted.
"This shows that the recent improvement in cross-strait relations has more or less changed the Taiwan people's stereotypical impression of China," he concluded.

The survey, commissioned by the MAC and conducted by the Taiwan-based China Credit Information Service between Oct. 10 and 12, collected a total of 1.081 effective samples and had a margin of error of 2.98 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes 3 millionth tourist

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomed its 3 millionth visitor this year -- a South Korean -- with fanfare Wednesday.

Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General Steven T. Y. Kuo Su presided over a welcome ceremony at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport for Kim In-Tae, and presented him with an NT$300,000 (US$9,260) debit card to spend in Taiwan, locally produced millet liquor, necklaces and other gifts.
Kuo Su expressed the hope that more foreign visitors will come to Taiwan for sightseeing, and that Taiwan will be able "to welcome its 4 millionth visitor by the end of the year."
Kim, who traveled to Taiwan with his family members for a scheduled four-day visit, said "it was indeed a pleasant surprise" to learn that he was the 3 millionth visitor.
He was also happy to be showered with so many gifts and to be given NT$300,000 to spend in Taiwan, he said.
Kim said that when he returns to South Korea, he will encourage his friends and relatives to visit Taiwan and he hopes that one of them will be the lucky 4 millionth visitor.

Tourism Bureau officials said that they had invited more than 400 foreign journalists and 600 travel agents to visit Taiwan between January and September, in the hope that these professionals would promote Taiwan's fun travel and rich tourism resources.
The Tourism Bureau is also working with the media, PR companies and air carriers in Asia and major countries in Europe and the Americas to promote Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009.

Tourism officials said that these measures are aimed at developing new emerging markets, attracting new visitors, and tapping into the Japanese market more heavily. Japan has traditionally been the largest source of foreign visitors to Taiwan.

The officials said that they also have various promotion programs in place in Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, Malaysia and other Asian countries, with the aim of reaching the 4 millionth visitor mark by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosa Plastics Group founder dies

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group founder Wang Yung-ching died of myocardia infarction at his U.S. residence in New Jersey, Wednesday. He was 92.
