DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 16, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti- revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six- Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
2001: Taiwan atmospheric scientists successfully obtains vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.
2001: A Taipei delegation leaves for Indonesia to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival in Jakarta.
2001: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. invests US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan welcomes 3 millionth tourist

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomed its 3 millionth visitor this year -- a South Korean -- with fanfare Wednesday.

Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-General Steven T. Y. Kuo Su presided over a welcome ceremony at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport for Kim In-Tae, and presented him with an NT$300,000 (US$9,260) debit card to spend in Taiwan, locally produced millet liquor, necklaces and other gifts.
Kuo Su expressed the hope that more foreign visitors will come to Taiwan for sightseeing, and that Taiwan will be able "to welcome its 4 millionth visitor by the end of the year."
Kim, who traveled to Taiwan with his family members for a scheduled four-day visit, said "it was indeed a pleasant surprise" to learn that he was the 3 millionth visitor.
He was also happy to be showered with so many gifts and to be given NT$300,000 to spend in Taiwan, he said.
Kim said that when he returns to South Korea, he will encourage his friends and relatives to visit Taiwan and he hopes that one of them will be the lucky 4 millionth visitor.

Tourism Bureau officials said that they had invited more than 400 foreign journalists and 600 travel agents to visit Taiwan between January and September, in the hope that these professionals would promote Taiwan's fun travel and rich tourism resources.
The Tourism Bureau is also working with the media, PR companies and air carriers in Asia and major countries in Europe and the Americas to promote Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009.

Tourism officials said that these measures are aimed at developing new emerging markets, attracting new visitors, and tapping into the Japanese market more heavily. Japan has traditionally been the largest source of foreign visitors to Taiwan.

The officials said that they also have various promotion programs in place in Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, Malaysia and other Asian countries, with the aim of reaching the 4 millionth visitor mark by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Income subsidy for 'near poor' has no legal foundation: lawmakers

TEXT.P: Two legislators told Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi Wednesday that the government's income subsidy plan implemented from October to help "near poor" people cope with price hikes lacks legal foundation.

Wu Yu-sheng, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang, said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Internal Administration Committee that the subsidy plan is a matter of urgency because many low-income families need help.

Wu said that although he supports the NT$20.2 billion (US$ 623.46 million) allocation requested by the government to implement the plan in 2009, the interior minister must first provide a legal basis to justify the planned budget.

Chiu Yi-ying, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, claimed that the NT$5.7 billion to be spent by the government on the plan in the final quarter of 2008 and the NT$20.2 billion it has requested for 2009 are both "unlawful."
She said she and other DPP legislators will introduce a resolution to freeze the budget request.
In response, the interior minister acknowledged there were some errors in formulating the subsidy plan. He said he will consult with budget experts on how to straighten out the proposal.
The income subsidy plan is intended to help 1.35 million people in 450,000 families that are at risk of falling into poverty because of continuous hikes in commodity prices during the past months.

Under the plan, one employed member in each family whose annual income is below NT$300,000 and whose assets are worth less than NT$3.9 million would be entitled to between NT$3,000 and NT$6,000 per month for six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former minister detained by prosecutors on bribery charges

TEXT.P: Former Minister of the Interior Yu Chen-shien was detained Wednesday on charges connected to a case of alleged bribery.

The Taipei District Court granted prosecutors' request for Yu's detention on grounds that he was possibly involved in leaking confidential government information and profiteering, and may have colluded with witnesses in the case.

Yu was intercepted by law-enforcement personnel at Kaohsiung International Airport Wednesday while he was attempting to leave the country after being listed as a potential suspect in the case of alleged bribery on a construction project for an exhibition hall in the Taipei suburban district of Nangang in 2003.
Yu was taken to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office where he was questioned about his role in the case.
Lin Chin-tsun, deputy chief prosecutor of the office, said after the questioning that the prosecutor in charge of the case had filed for a court order to detain Yu.
Lin said Yu was barred from leaving the country before the prosecutors office summoned him on Oct. 7 to report to the office Thursday as a potential suspect.
Earlier Wednesday the prosecutor sent another summons asking Yu to report to the office that day after it was learned that the suspect was preparing to leave the country, Lin said.

According to the prosecutors office, Yu is suspected of leaking the names of members of a committee that was responsible for screening the bids for the costly construction of the Nangang Exhibition Hall.
Yu made the name list available to the company that eventually won the bid, during his tenure as minister of the interior in the period 2002-2004, the prosecutor charged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 64% of public approve of China negotiator's visit to Taiwan: poll

TEXT.P: Sixty-four percent of the people in Taiwan approve of a visit to the country by a top China negotiator for high-level talks, according to the results of a poll released by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday.

But 52 percent of the respondents also said that China should first apologize for selling its toxic dairy products to Taiwan, before Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, can visit Taiwan to hold talks with his counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.

Liu Te-hsun, MAC spokesman and vice chairman, urged China to address the mainstream concern of the Taiwan people so as to lay a solid foundation for the development of harmonious relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The survey showed that 64.29 percent of the respondents support the Chiang-Chen meeting, which is expected to take place in Taiwan later this month or early November.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to hold a demonstration Oct. 25 to protest what it called the incompetence of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and to drive home its call for the safeguarding of Taiwan's sovereignty. The party also aims to highlight what is said is the inappropriate timing of Chen's visit amid a public scare over imports of toxic milk products from China.

The scheduled Chiang-Chen meeting will be a follow-up to a landmark meeting in Beijing between the two in mid-June during which both sides reached an agreement on weekend cross-strait charter flights and the expansion of the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

According to the poll results, 64.29 percent of the Taiwan public support the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting, with 55.51 percent saying that they do not think Chen's visit would undermine national dignity or interests.

The survey also showed that 64.85 percent of those polled think the Chinese government is unfriendly toward Taiwan government and 45.98 percent think that the Chinese government is unfriendly toward the Taiwan people.
Commenting on the results of the survey, National Chengchi University professor Chao Chien-min said that "there is no need to worry about that issue."
He pointed out that in previous polls, the ratio of people who thought that China was friendly toward Taiwan never surpassed 2 percent.
But in the latest survey, those who think China is friendly toward the Taiwan government and the Taiwan people accounted for 24 and 39 percent of the respondents, respectively, he noted.
"This shows that the recent improvement in cross-strait relations has more or less changed the Taiwan people's stereotypical impression of China," he concluded.

The survey, commissioned by the MAC and conducted by the Taiwan-based China Credit Information Service between Oct. 10 and 12, collected a total of 1.081 effective samples and had a margin of error of 2.98 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Textile show opens at World Trade Center

TEXT.P: A textile exhibition featuring healthy, bio-friendly and hi-tech fibers opened at the World Trade Center in Taipei Wednesday, according to the organizer.

The 2008 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) attracted some 250 exhibitors, including companies from India, Japan and China, that are showcasing their latest innovative products at 500 booths, said the organizer, the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF).

TTF secretary-general Huang Wei-ji said that the TTF collaborated for the first time with certified manufacturers such as Far Eastern Textile and Control Union to plan a special organic cotton section that would serve as a showpiece for "green industry opportunities."
Huang also noted that several Taiwanese manufacturers have unveiled new products that use bio-friendly materials such as natural bamboo, charcoal and corn fibers.

Innovative products are even more important in light of the economic downturn, said Huang Hua-de, chairman of TEXMA International Co., a local manufacturer that has developed fabrics with the use of recycled plastic bottles. TEXMA's export orders are expected to increase sharply this year, he said.
TITAS is being held with the support of the National Cotton Council of America and several textile-related domestic corporations such as Nan Ya Plastics and Formosa Chemicals & Fiber.
The show will end on October 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA offers assistance to family of deceased business tycoon

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Ministry (MOFA) said Thursday that the ministry's representative office has certified the death certificate issued for Taiwan's second richest man, Wang Yung-ching, who passed away in New York Wednesday morning, and that it will provide all necessary help to Wang's family.
Wang, founder of Formosa Plastics Group, died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 92, according to media reports.
"The certification for Wang's death certificate has been completed, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said at a regular press briefing.
"Besides expressing our condolences, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is willing to provide all necessary assistance to his family," he added.

Noting that the MOFA's representative office in New York was informed on Wednesday afternoon of Wang's death, Chen said the ministry only certified the authenticity of the death certificate rather the contents of the document, refusing to reveal the cause of Wang's death. However, it is believed that the cause of his death was myocardial infarction-caused cardiorespiratory failure.

Wang was an influential entrepreneur who founded a large business empire in Taiwan. According to the 2008 Forbes survey, he was the 178th richest person in the world with an estimated net worth of US$5.5 billion.
He was born in Hsintien township, Taiwan. Despite lacking any formal schooling beyond elementary school, he is currently ranked second on the Forbes list of Taiwan's Richest.
Wang's group is the parent company of several major publicly traded companies, including Formosa Plastic Corp., Nan Ya Plastics Corp. and Formosa Petrochemical.

In June 2006, after he stepped down from his position as the day-to-day head of the company and handed over the business empire to his brother and daughters, Wang remained chairman of the boards of Nan Ya Plastics, Formosa Chemistry & Fiber Corp. and Cyma Plywood & Lumber Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves inheritance, gift tax rate cuts to 10%

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Thursday an inheritance and gift tax rate reform proposal submitted by the Ministry of Finance which cuts the maximum marginal rate to a uniform 10 percent.
The inheritance tax deduction will be increased to NT$12 million (US$369,230) from the current NT$7.79 million, while the gift tax reductions will be raised to NT$2.2 million from NT$1.1 million.
At present, the maximum marginal inheritance tax and gift tax rates are both 50 percent -- a rate many economists believe compels wealthy Taiwanese to send their money abroad to avoid paying taxes.
Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said a day earlier that the new estate and gift tax rates will cost the government an estimated NT$20 billion a year.
However, he added that those losses could easily be made up by increased tax revenues from brisker economic activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former prosecutors impeached for entering improper realms

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan has decided to impeach several former prosecutors and court police officers in the northern county of Miaoli for misconduct, the country's supreme watchdog body said Thursday in a statement.

Those impeached include former county prosecutors Dai Ruei-chi and Liao Chi- Tsuen, as well as Tsai Chia-hong, former deputy court police chief of Miaoli's prosecutor's office, and former court police officer Tseng Te-yuan.

The four have been impeached for harming the Ministry of Justice's image by wining and dining guests with questionable characters in an inappropriate manner, including the use of escort girls, in March 2006.
The Ministry of Justice suspended the four men and sent the case to the Control Yuan for review in July 2006.
Following the Control Yuan's decision Wednesday, the case will now be sent to the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Public Functionaries to mete out punishment to the four men.
The Control Yuan is the branch of ROC government that is mainly responsible for reviewing the conduct of civil servants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grand Hotel plans to trim personnel by 10%

TEXT.P: The Grand Hotel has announced a plan to reduce its staff by 10 percent as part of its efforts to prevent the enterprise's financial situation from worsening, but the hotel's labor union has protested the management's move, insisting on its members' right to work.
"Employees should perform services well, but it is the responsibility of management to make a profit, " Lee Huan-yang, the union's spokesman, said Thursday.

In an interview with CNA Wednesday, Johnson Chiang, the hotel's president, said that the hotel has been operating in the red for five consecutive years and that its losses for this year alone amounted to NT$150 million (US$4.63 million) as of the end of September.
The only exception, he added, was the surplus of NT$28,000 in 2007 from income from non-operating revenues such as stock investment.
Chiang pointed out that the hotel's operating expenses are roughly double those of its competitors, adding that he can only improve the business' finances by shutting down unprofitable departments.

For example, the hotel will lay off five employees at the Li Bai Lounge by the end of this month, and 87 more at the Yuan Shan Club of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, with the date yet to be determined.
Apart from these layoffs, Chiang said he will also make adjustments to the hotel's workforce according to seasonal needs and demand.

Meanwhile, Chiang explained that the hotel's contract with the labor union obligates the hotel to pay staff triple their salary on national and typhoon holidays, making it harder for the hotel to make ends meet in light of the present economic slowdown.
He added that the hotel has expressed a desire to renegotiate the contract but that the labor union has refused.

DOC.HEADLINE: Body of Taiwanese tycoon to be flown back Friday

TEXT.P: The body of Taiwan's second richest man, Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) founder Wang Yung-ching, who died Wednesday in New Jersey at 92, will be flown back from New York to Taiwan Friday morning, the FPG said in a statement Thursday.
The statement said EVA Air plane carrying Wang's body will arrive at Taiwan's Taoyuan International Airport at 5:15 a.m. Friday.

According to the statement, Wang and his wife traveled to the United States on Oct. 11 for an inspection of the assembly lines of the company's factories there, and had originally intended to stay seven to 10 days.
However, Wang, who had followed healthy life style and kept the habit of jogging until his late years, died in his sleep, the statement said.

The FPG's seven-member policy-decision team held an urgent meeting Thursday in the wake of Wang's death, during which the team decided to follow the spirit of the founder of diligence, trustworthiness and sustainable operation to lead the group steadily forward, the statement said.
Forbes Magazine identified Wang as Taiwan's second richest man in its most recent study.

Wang, known as "god of management," founded the Formosa Plastics Group in 1954. Since then, his businesses have expanded to the realms of medical, biotech, thermo power station, automobile, electronics, silicon wafer and kitchen waste recycling and reuse.
He had also dedicated himself to funding charities.
Wang also advocated direct trade and transportation links with China in his later years.
According to the 2007 data of the Taiwan-based China Credit Information Service, the FPG group had 95,538 employees, with a total revenue of NT$1.967 trillion and total assets of NT$2.462 trillion.
The FPG was the most profitable enterprise in Taiwan last year, achieving after- tax net profits of NT$219.077 billion.
Wang served as the chairman of the Group's Formosa Plastics Corp., one of the largest plastic manufacturers in the world, until June 2006, when he stepped down at the age of 89.

He remained chairman of the boards of Nan Ya Plastics Corporation, Formosa Chemistry & Fibre Corporation, and Cyma Plywood & Lumber Co. Ltd, but indicated he would gradually resign from these positions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 170.29 points, or 3.24 percent, to close at 5,075.97.
Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 5,069.07 and rose as high as 5,085.97 during trading.
A total of 1.69 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$28.65 billion (US$884.26 million).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 3.4 percent. Foodstuff issues, plastics and chemicals shares and machinery and electronics shares all declined 3.3 percent, while cement stocks dropped 3.2 percent, textile stocks and pulp and paper issues both slipped 3.1 percent, and construction issues declined 1.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,401 to 181, with 246 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$3.69 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November fell 180 points to close at 4,978, with 2,305 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 179 points to finish at 4,949, with 91 contracts traded, while March futures moved down 178 points to close at 4,912, with 243 contract transactions.
June futures decreased 177 points to finish at 4,905, with 619 contract transactions, while September futures were down 173 points to close at 4,793, with 126 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,158 for November, 5,128 for December, 5,090 for March, 5,082 for June and 4,966 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 170.29 points to finish at 5,075.97, on turnover of NT$28.65 billion (US$884.26 million).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

November TE futures fell 7.35 points to close at 204, with 118 contracts traded, while December TE futures decreased 7.3 points to finish at 202.2, with 22 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures moved down 19.8 points to close at 550, with 69 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were down 19.8 points to finish at 546.2, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to announce details Friday of planned protest march

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will make public Friday details about its planned Oct. 25 march, including the estimated number of participants, aimed at calling for the safeguarding of Taiwan's national sovereignty, according to a party official.

DPP Information and Culture Department Director Cheng Wen-tsan said Wednesday after a weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee that the rally will highlight three appeals: "protesting the one-China market, " "opposing the incompetent government" and "opposing the hollowing out of Taiwan's sovereignty."
To realize the goals, the DPP is working hard to encourage citizens from all walks of life to join the event to demonstrate their resolve to uphold Taiwan's sovereignty, Cheng noted.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen also urged everyone who supports the rally's aims to join the event, regardless of their political affiliation.

Cheng said the rally will be held to protest the upcoming visit by Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin, Beijing's top negotiator on Taiwan-related issues, who is slated to make his first trip to the island at the end of October or early November for talks with his Taiwanese counterpart Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

Also on Wednesday, the DPP issued a statement under the title of "boycott Chinese substandard goods and protect Taiwan" which said that the DPP, in conjunction with all sectors of society, will launch a series of activities from the end of this month to express the Taiwan people's discontent with the government, their attitude toward China, and their desire to make their voices heard in the international community.

Another focus of discussion during the meeting was DPP Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai's offer to resign amid criticism over his taking part in an event several days ago to show support for former President Chen Shui-bian, who is being investigated on allegations of corruption and money laundering.
Agreeing with committee member Chai Trong-rong's proposal to retain Chen for his outstanding performance, the DPP chairwoman said that she would not approve his resignation, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not sign CEPA with China: MAC chair

TEXT.P: Taiwan definitely will not sign a Closer Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) with China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday.

"A CEPA was clinched between Hong Kong and China, but Taiwan is not Hong Kong, and Taiwan certainly will not ink a similar pact with China," Lai stressed while answering questions from lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during a legislative committee meeting.

"The MAC has not, nor will it, authorize the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to negotiate with China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) on that issue, " Lai asserted.
Hong Kong and China inked a CEPA in June 2003, helping to open up a huge market for Hong Kong goods and services and effectively improving Hong Kong's economy.
DPP lawmakers voiced concern that if Taiwan signed a CEPA with China it would harm Taiwan's national dignity and its independent status.

The DPP and other pro-independence groups are very disgruntled over a planned visit to Taiwan in late October or early November by ARATS President Chen Yunlin who serves as China's top negotiator with Taiwan -- fearing that it might lead to Taiwan tilting further toward China.
Although the date of Chen's visit has yet to be fixed, the DPP is planning to hold a large anti-China protest in Taipei Oct. 25.

Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, for the first time for talks in a historical meeting in June in Beijing, in which two accords on weekend charter flights and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists were clinched.

Issues regarding cross-Taiwan Strait transportation services, including the establishment of regular cargo charter flights and expansion of weekend passenger charter flights, as well as financial supervisory cooperation and crime-fighting, will be high on the agenda of their second round of talks in Taipei.
Chen would be the highest-ranking official from the People's Republic of China ever to visit Taiwan.

The major opposition party and other pro-independence groups will also jointly stage a large demonstration Nov. 2 to protest the government's polices to build close links with China since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Average family income in Kaohsiung reached NT$1.18 million in 2007

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City's annual household income averaged NT$1.18 million (US$36,310) in 2007, with average disposable income reaching NT$980,000, according to city statistics released Thursday.

The southern Taiwanese city's 2007 average family income was up by 1.23 percent compared to the 2006 average of NT$1.17 million, according to data compiled by the city's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics based on results of a survey of 1,500 local households.
Of the NT$1.18 million average family income, wages which on average reached NT$698,931 made up the bulk of the income, with the rest coming from earnings incurred from other assets.
The southern Taiwanese port city's 2007 average family discretionary income also marked a rise of 1.06 percent over the previous year's level of NT$970,062, the same tallies indicated.
In terms of savings, households in Kaohsiung City had an average cash deposit of NT$240,754 in banks, representing a drop of 1 percentage points in its savings rate from the previous year's level.
More than 90 percent of the city's families had cell phones, while more than 70 percent had computers at home, with 93 precent of those having access to the Internet, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.137 to close at NT$32.537.
A total of US$1.437 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.400 and reached a high of NT$32.602.

DOC.HEADLINE: President salutes Taiwan's 'God of Business'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou saluted Thursday the extraordinary contributions that Taiwan's "God of Business, " Wang Yung-ching, made to the country. Wang, founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, died in New York earlier in the day at the age of 92.

"The president was sad upon learning of Wang's death and he offered his highest respects to the man who made unprecedentedly outstanding contributions to Taiwan's economic development, " Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said at a news conference.
Ma made a phone call to the late Wang's family to express his condolences immediately upon learning of his death, the spokesman said.
The president and the late Formosa Plastics Group founder were more than just acquaintances -- they ran, debated and ate the traditional Taiwanese delicacy oyster noodles together, Wang Yu-chi said.
Ma, who is almost a professional runner, ran the 5,000-meter race with Wang Yung-ching more than 10 times over the past two decades at the Formosa Plastics Group's annual corporate games.

The president said the late Wang -- a rags-to-riches model who showed lifelong diligence in his work and who lived a simple and frugal life despite his position as founder of the most financially successful business group in Taiwan -- represented the core values of Taiwan, according to the spokesman.
The president particularly mentioned his respect for Wang Yung-ching's resolute leadership in efforts to promote environmental protection and sustainable growth, Wang Yu-chi said.

A man of far-reaching vision, Wang Yung-ching began contributing to educational and medical development on the Chinese mainland more than 10 years ago, despite tight regulations imposed by the Taiwan authorities.

One of the most renowned examples of the tycoon's philanthropy in China was the launch of his "Engineering of Hope" project under which some 10,000 elementary schools were built across the Chinese mainland.

Meanwhile, Vice President Vincent Siew also paid tribute to the the Formosa Plastics Group's founder, saying he will never be forgotten by the people of Taiwan because of his lifestyle and his contributions to the country.

Siew, who once served as minister of economic affairs and head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said he had maintained a friendship of more than 30 years with Wang Yung-ching and could be the one official who knows best how instrumental Wang was to the successful take-off of Taiwan's economy in the 1960s.

"Wang Yung-ching's establishment of the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant helped lay a solid foundation for Taiwan's petrochemical industry, which in turn fueled the development of the plastics manufacturing industry and many other related industries, " Siew related.

Siew added that long before the late Wang spent a fortune to build schools in China, he had established many colleges, universities and vocational schools around Taiwan to provide free career education to youths from disadvantaged and aboriginal families to enable them to pull their own weight after they graduated.

"Wang Yung-ching even directed the Formosa Plastics Group to build housing units in Guatemala -- a country with which his group had no business relations -- to help house the poor and the homeless there," Siew added.

Wang Yung-ching, born in the era of subsistence when Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule, came from humble beginnings that saw him working at the age of 15 as a rice shop apprentice in the southern city of Chiayi. Although he did not always earn money, he was a hard-working youth, carrying the rice sacks on his back to deliver them to the homes of the shop customers. Whenever he had spare time, he visited the customers to check whether their rice bins were running low or were empty.
The "God of Business" grew from that rice shop apprentice who worked hard and became a shrewd businessman by the time he reached his early 20s.

One of the major business conglomerates in Taiwan, the Formosa Plastics Group is the most efficient corporate group in the country in terms of profit-making, with its business turnovers topping NT$1.97 trillion (US$60.7 billion) in 2007 and countable assets valued at more than NT$2.46 trillion.
Wang Yung-ching's daughter Wang Juei-hua said that her father often said to his children that "what your hands can hold is limited, but once you open your hands, the whole world is yours."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan forms women's rights alliance to report to the U.N.

TEXT.P: A new alliance of women's groups in Taiwan was formed on Thursday with the primary goal of writing a report to the United Nations about the status of women's rights in the country.
Taiwan's Committee on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women, or CEDAW, aims to complete the report by the year 2010, members told reporters Thursday.

Jih Huey-rong, one of the officials on the Committee, said that in the past two decades, 185 nations have joined the U.N.'s CEDAW. However, due to political reasons, Taiwan has not been able to join this organization.

China, which considers Taiwan one of its provinces, strongly opposes Taiwan joining any international organization reserved for nations, including the U.N. and U.N. groups, such as the World Health Organization. In 2007, Taiwan's application to formally enter the committee was rejected by the U.N. Secretary General.

Since Taiwan is not a member of the U.N. or the U.N.'s CEDAW, its report will be sent via non-governmental organizations to the U.N. in hopes that Taiwan may eventually be allowed to join the U.N. Committee.

Jih, who is the chairperson of one of the groups on Taiwan's Committee, said on Thursday that Taiwan's report on Taiwanese women's rights will look at issues including sexual discrimination in work places, as well as violence against women.

A total of eleven woman's groups in Taiwan have joined the local committee. They include: the Garden of Hope Foundation, Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism (ECPAT) , Modern Women's Foundation, Young Women's Christian Association, Taiwan Coalition Against Violence, Zonta International District 31, Hope Workers' Center, National Union of Taiwan Women's Association (NATWA) , College of Humanities and Social Science of Soochow University and the Rerum Novarum Center.

The U.N.'s Committee is an expert body established in 1982 and composed of 23 experts on women's issues from around the world. The Committee's mandate is to watch over the progress of women's rights around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation promotes child adoption program

TEXT.P: The Child Welfare League Foundation is urging people to enthusiastically adopt abandoned children and take care of them, a foundation spokesman said Thursday.
The spokesman made the remarks during a news conference at the Children's Recreation Center in Taipei.

Some parents abandon their children because of financial problems, some because the children are suffering from serious diseases, and others because they are in prison and cannot look after their children, the spokesman said.
Recent government statistics show that the number of local families willing to adopt children has dwindled over the past few years, the spokesman said.
The country's sluggish economy is one of the main reasons behind the drop in the number of families willing to adopt children, according to the spokesman.
To make matters worse, some families that have adopted children plan to give up the children because of financial woes, he said.
The spokesman also called on the general public to donate money to help fund the foundation's child adoption program.

"Philanthropic ambassador" Patty Tsai, wife of EasyCard Corp. Chairman Sean Lien, during the press conference urged the public to do more to help abandoned children by donating more funds to the child adoption program.
Lien is the son of ruling Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.
Founded in Taipei in 1991, the foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting child welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time for Taiwan to strengthen relations with ASEAN: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew declared Thursday that now is the right time for Taiwan to strengthen relations with countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) as the group of countries is undergoing transformations and is improving cross-strait relations.

Why now? Because with the improvement of Taiwan-China relations, obstructions in the exchanges between Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries are decreasing, Siew said, adding that the strong presence of Taiwanese businesses in the region can help Taiwan strengthen ties with ASEAN countries.

Siew made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFAs) working meeting for the Southeast Asian region and the first coordination meeting of the ministry's newly formed task force on relations with ASEAN.

The meeting was carried out under the instruction of President Ma Ying-jeou to have Taiwan actively participate in the integration of the Asia Pacific region and ASEAN. It is the first such meeting after the MOFA established the ASEAN task force -- a strategic inter-agency group aimed at strengthening relations with the region and preventing Taiwan from being marginalized.

Noting that Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries are closely related in economy given the substantial volumes of trade and investment between the two sides, as well as exchanges in foreign labors, education, culture and tourism, Siew said Taiwan has great leverage in strengthening ties with ASEAN countries.
These all serve as very good bargaining chips in the interaction with Southeast Asia,the vice president said.

Siew contended that -- as the ASEAN will become a single market next year after the ASEAN Charter goes into effect -- the government should seize the opportunity in the expansion of ASEAN Plus One, ASEAN Plus Three or ASEAN Plus Six, and start drawing on collective wisdom and absorb all useful ideas to let the Republic of China become a partner of the ASEAN countries.

I know this is not an easy task but if we can do so, I believe we will play a more constructive role in this region given Taiwans participation and contribution in the economies of ASEAN countries over the years,Siew said.

Established in Thailand in 1967, ASEAN is made up of 10 member countries -- Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. Its objectives, apart from promoting regional peace, include the acceleration of economic growth, social progress and cultural development among its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum to hold exhibition in Chiayi County

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum will hold a special exhibition from Oct. 24 to Jan. 4, 2009 to herald the establishment of the museum's southern Taiwan branch in Chiayi County, scheduled for completion in 2011.

The exhibition, titled "Exploring Asia: Episode One of the National Palace Museum's Southern Branch," will take place at the Chiayi Performing Arts Center. It will display 117 items featuring six themes -- Buddhist sculptures, Asian scriptures, fabrics and textiles in Asia, blue and white porcelains from Asia, Asian tea cultures and traditions, and Western trends in Asian culture.
The exhibition is intended to help visitors understand the patterns of cultural transmission, dissemination and evolution in Asia.

Fung Ming-chu, deputy director of the museum, and Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen opened the boxes containing the exhibits at a press conference Thursday and allowed media workers to see some of the highly treasured items.
The most conspicuous among the items was the Dragon Sutra manuscript, which was completed in A.D. 1669 under the reign of Qing Dynasty Emperor Kangxi.

The sutra was written in gilt standard Tibetan script on both sides of celadon blue stationery, with each page measuring 87.5 cm. by 33 cm. The manuscript has 108 sets in all, comprising 100,000 pages. The sutra contains the Kangyur -- the Tibetan translation of the teachings of Sakyamuni Buddha.
The text of the sutra is accompanied by more than 700 colorful images of Buddhas, bodhisattvas, dharmapalas, patriarchs and arhats.
Fung said that an ornamental Koran will be on display in the same room as the Dragon Sutra manuscript.
"Each of the exhibits is a treasured masterpiece," she said, pointing to a 15th century blue and white vase from Vietnam featuring a motif of phoenix with a peony flower design.
Other masterpieces on display will include Gandharan style stone-carved Buddha statues, Indian embroideries, and Chinese tea sets, she added.
According to Fung, the exhibition will be the first of a series of thematic presentations by the museum in the lead-up to the launch of its southern Taiwan branch in Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for stronger consumer spending to boost economy

TEXT.P: President Ying-jeou endorsed Thursday a proposal to stimulate consumer spending and boost investment, promising that he will take the lead at the proper time to achieve those goals.

"Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain healthy and I am very confident that the country will weather the current financial storm," Ma said in response to the proposal put forward by a group of trade association leaders during a meeting at the Presidential Office.

Ma urged the public to maintain cautious optimism despite the current economic downturn in Taiwan and the rest of the world, arguing that Taiwan's enterprises are still vigorous and competitive amid robust foreign competition.

Citing a recent USA Business Week report on the world's top 100 information technology companies, Ma said that Taiwan had the second highest number of companies on the list, after the United States. Eighteen Taiwanese companies were listed, he said.

In light of the global credit squeeze and economic crisis, the government has also adopted a series of countermeasures, including lowering the gift and inheritance tax rate from 50 percent to 10 percent and reducing several other taxation rates and the stock transaction rate, to help re-build public confidence and reinvigorate Taiwan's economy, the president said.
He pledged that the government will do its best to increase investment in public construction projects to offset the negative growth over the past eight years and help boost local demand.

If the Legislative Yuan approves the budget for the government's 12 mega-project program by the end of this year, this would mean that more capital would be injected into the economy starting January next year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over half of Taiwan's workplaces enforce smoking ban: BHP

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan's workplaces have enforced a non-smoking policy, in keeping with government regulations that will take effect next year, the results of a recent survey indicated.

Some 55.8 percent of Taiwan's corporations have declared their premises smoke- free, according to a survey released by the Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health.
Another 17.7 percent have designated indoor smoking areas, while 25.5 percent maintain no restrictions on smoking, the survey showed.
The survey also found that 63.6 percent of the respondents were aware of the government's new initiative, with 17 percent of that number knowing the exact implementation date.
The government adopted a package of amendments to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention and Control Act on July 11 to impose stricter anti-smoking regulations starting Jan.11 next year.

The regulation prohibits smoking in indoor workplaces that are occupied by more than three people, as well as in all public areas within a workplace, such as stairwells and hallways, which are often used as "smoking zones."
Workplaces caught breaking the rule will be fined between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000, and individual violators will be subject to fines of NT$2,000 to NT$10,000.

Meanwhile, the survey showed that since 2003 when a smoke-free project was launched, the rate of smoking at worksites in Taiwan has dropped from 24.2 percent to 20 percent this year. Alongside that drop, the rate of people quitting smoking has risen from 5.8 percent in 2003 to 11 percent this year, according to the poll.
The figures demonstrate a higher level of public awareness of the dangers of smoking and breathing second-hand smoke, and greater sensitivity to the issue, the survey indicated.
The highest rate of smoking was recorded among construction workers and those in the transportation and storage industry, at 39.5 percent and 34 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice plant in Tainan County promoting 'duck farming' technique

TEXT.P: A rice production plant in southern Taiwan's Tainan County is trying to promote a farming technique that replaces pesticides with ducks, plant owner Huang Li- chin said Thursday.
Huang said the method of cultivation allows rice fields to be playgrounds for ducks, which eat insects and apple snails that harm rice crops and whose excrement can be used as organic fertilizer.

But since Fangjung Rice Plant launched the program to use ducks in rice farming in 2006, only six farmers have participated in it, with the total farmland using this method reaching only three hectares, Huang said.

Hoping that more farmers and consumers will support this unique organic farming technique, Huang said she is trying to get produce generated under the program certified as organic produce. She said she is confident this can be achieved within one year.
Huang explained that three years is the minimum time it takes for a farm's produce to pass organic examinations.
Contract farmers have to abide by certain regulations. They have to grow the strain selected by the rice production plant and cannot use any pesticides or chemical fertilizers, Huang said.

Persuading farmers to switch from the pursuit of production volume to quality is the most difficult part of promoting the farming technique, even though farmers know that it is a good technique passed down by their ancestors, Huang said.
She is the fourth-generation owner of the plant that was founded in 1926.

The six contract farmers currently using this method raise ducks beside their rice farms. Three farmers who cultivate a 1.68-hectare plot of land together have had to raise about 500 ducks to help them with their organic efforts, Huang said.
"We experimented with creatures like frogs and chicken in carrying out the mission, but found that ducks are the most effective, " Huang said.
All produce grown on farmland using this special technique have passed pesticide tests, she emphasized.

Huang noted that while ducks eat rice too when there are not many bugs around, they are still beneficial to farmland. She added that having ducks in rice fields is also a good way to attract tourists to the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical researchers develop new tool to test for skin diseases

TEXT.P: Scientists at three universities in Taiwan have developed a new non-invasive diagnostic tool which combines the functions of virtual biopsy and molecular imaging and can significantly improve clinical diagnosis of skin diseases, researchers said Thursday.

Experiments conducted on laboratory animals using the new tool have been successfully completed and the results show that the tool can effectively detect indications of oral cancer on hamsters, team members said.
They added that they are looking forward to conducting human testing.

The team -- led by Shieh Dar-bin of National Cheng-Kung University, Sun Chi- kuang of National Taiwan University, and Lin Kuan-jiuh of National Chung-Hsing University -- has already presented its findings in several scientific papers in the journals Optics Express and Advanced Materials.

Shieh, who is also an oral surgeon, said that in his past experience, it is very difficult to determine whether a patient has developed oral cancer because it is neither easy to spot the cancer nidus nor to carry out biopsy inside the mouth.

But with the help of the tool -- dubbed "backward-propagating, multi-harmonic optical tomography," Shieh said, the surgeons can more easily determine the location of the cancer nidus without any invasive measures.

Shieh noted that since the experiments on animals have shown some promising signs, they hope medical equipment manufacturers will become interested in funding the project to refine the system and to produce the prototypes for commercial use.
Once the prototypes are made, Shieh indicated, the team can apply for permission to carry out human testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: International conference in Taipei discusses melamine issue

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) convened a conference Thursday at which international experts discussed policy and control measures for the prevention of melamine contamination of food and shared their experience in this area with local health authorities and food safety personnel.
Experts from Australia, New Zealand, France and Belgium are attending the two- day forum, while a web conference is expected to be held with the United States Food and Drug Administration.
DOH Deputy Minister Sung Yen-jen said at the opening of the conference that his agency expects to learn from the experiences of other countries in containing melamine contamination.
He said that he and DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan will however not attend the conference to avoid political interference.

At the conference, Slava Zeman, manager of the export food policy section of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, said that Australia has a comprehensive food safety system with robust controls in the whole chain, including measures to prevent fraud.
She noted that the most effective measures of controlling melamine and other types of contamination of food are based on the food safety systems in the producing or exporting countries.
"Regulatory actions should target levels of concern, not the absence of melamine," she stressed.
According to another participant, the problem has to be tackled before it reaches the consumer.

If the authorities cannot avoid some isolated cases of fraud, they have to try to detect the problem upstream and solve it before it causes harm to people, said Emmanuel Foex, who works at the French Embassy in Beijing, China.

The question of acceptable levels of melamine in food was also raised by the Taiwan participants who asked why most countries had set the safety standard at 2.5 ppm without knowing the exact level of contamination from sources such as the manufacturing process and packaging.

In response, Emmanuelle Moons, an expert from Federal Agency For the Safety of the Food Chain in Belgium, said that in Europe, the standard of 2.5 ppm was set because it was considered a reasonable level to distinguish adulteration from background contamination, and that the European Union took into consideration the standards in other countries.

Discussing Taiwan's experience, Chen Shu-kong, director-general of the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH, said that only some brands of milk powder imported to Taiwan were tainted with the toxic chemical and that the source of the contamination was possibly the manufacturing process and packaging materials.

However, Kuo Hsu-sung, director of Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control, presented the case study of Taiwan's leading food company which used a toxic non dairy-creamer, imported from the Shandong Duqing company in China, as an ingredient in its pre-mixed beverages.
The chemical melamine is added to milk by some Chinese dairy farmers and milk producers to produce a falsely high test result for protein content.
In China, melamine contamination is believed to have caused at least four deaths and sickened thousands of children who drank tainted infant formula.
The problem has spread to other countries that import food products from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'God of Management' helped change Taiwan's medical map

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "God of Management, " whose enterprises stretched from plastics, petrochemicals and high technology to automobiles, gas stations and biomedical technology, was also instrumental in reshaping the country's medical map.

Wang Yung-ching, founder of the Formosa Plastics Group -- the most financially successful business group in Taiwan -- and a rags-to-riches model, died in New York Thursday at the age of 92. Wang founded the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taipei City in 1976 with the aim of providing care for Taiwan's middle-class and less-privileged citizens, who had no access to cheap but good medical attention prior to the 1970s.

The Chang Gung Memorial Hospital was Taiwan's first general hospital for the ordinary people and the first teaching hospital at which doctors did not accept "red envelops" from the relatives of their patients.
In establishing Chang Gung hospital, Wang spared no funds -- earned from his business operations -- to hire top-notch medical professionals and management personnel from home and abroad.
At the same time, he also established a medical university and a nursing college to train medical professionals.

In less than 30 years, Chang Gung Memorial Hospital -- which now has branches in Linko, Taipei County, Keelung City, Kaohsiung County and Xiamen in China -- has become the largest hospital in Taiwan in terms of the number of beds and doctors, and is considered the best medical institution in Taiwan in terms of business management.

Inspired by Chang Gung's successful business management model, other privately run and owned hospitals have been established around Taiwan over the past 10 years, a development that has reshaped Taiwan's medical map. In the 1970s the ratio of public to private hospitals was 8:2, but that figure has since been reversed and is now 2:8.

As the biggest hospital chain in Taiwan, Chang Gung hospitals now have the largest number of National Health Insurance Program (NHIP) holders, commanding 8-9 percent of NHIP expenditure, which averages around NT$450 billion (US$13.88 billion) a year.
The Chang Gung business model has inspired National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) -- Taiwan's top public teaching hospital -- to change its style of management.
Emulating Chang Gung, NTUH began several years ago to expand its operations and now has many branches scattered around the country.

In his bid to make Chang Gung a first-class medical institution, Wang Yung-ching was instrumental in installing the most advanced equipment and facilities in the hospitals. The facilities included an operating theater and ward exclusively for patients with congenital heart disease; an operating theater and ward exclusively for children with craniofacial defects; and a clinic for the implant of electronic ears for children with acoustic nerve defects.
Wang, who was a victim of streptococcus pneumoniae, donated NT$500 million earlier this year to allow citizens over the age of 75 to receive free streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine.

Over the past year, Chang Gung invested billions of New Taiwan dollars in the construction of Taiwan's first cyclotron for proton beam radiation therapy for cancer treatment. The expensive cutting-edge facility -- which exists only in Japan and the United States -- is expected to be installed in a Chang Gung hospital by 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan completes phase II clinical testing of new cancer drug

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese subproject of a phase II clinical test for a cancer drug ADI-PEG 20 has been successfully completed and the drug should be on the market some time next year following the phase III clinical testing, researchers at the National Health Research Institute said Thursday.

ADI-PEG 20 was first developed by the U.S.-based Polaris Pharmaceuticals several years ago. A subsidiary of the Taiwan-based Hsin Tung Yang group later acquired exclusive distribution rights for the drug in Taiwan and China. The group also invested in Polaris to gain the right to conduct clinical testing in Taiwan, which will shorten the required time for review of a new drug in the country.

Financed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and commissioned by the pharmaceutical companies, the phase II clinical tests were started late last year by the National Health Research Institute, researchers said.
According to researchers, ADI-PEG 20 is a protein drug that can break down the arginine in human blood to inhibit the development of cancer cells.
Arginine, an alpha-amino acid, plays a vital role in cell division, wound healing, ammonia removal, immune functions, and the release of hormones.

Once the arginine in blood is removed, cancer cells will lose their most important source of nutrition, which then leads to their death, the researchers said. Normal cells will survive the condition of arginine deprivation because they can synthesize arginine within themselves, the scientists added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved cross-strait relations do not hamper ties with allies: Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the improvement in cross-Taiwan Strait relations since he took office in May this year does not affect Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies.

"The efforts to improve relations with China are aimed at achieving stability and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait," Ma told a group of senior military officers from the Republic of China's diplomatic allies who are in Taiwan for a training session.
Ma assured the foreign military officers that Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies will not be compromised in its efforts to improve bilateral relations with the Chinese mainland.
"Instead, cooperative programs between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies will be increased in the future based on the needs of those countries," Ma told the visiting foreign military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president sues political pundit for defamation

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian filed a slander lawsuit Thursday against a political pundit who claimed in a television program earlier this week that Chen has a stash of money in Japan amounting to NT$30 billion (US$920.78 million).

Chen's office said in a news release that he is suing Yao Li-ming, associate professor at the Department of Administrative Management of Chinese Culture University, for "aggravated defamation" because of Yao's allegation on ETtoday's satellite cable TV news channel Oct. 13 that Chen has deposited NT$30 billion in cash in Japan.
"As a university professor, Yao should have been more careful with his words and about his behavior," Chen's office said. It dismissed Yao's allegation as "completely groundless."
The "untruthful allegation" was subsequently quoted by other TV commentators and newspaper reporters, causing serious damage to the former president's reputation, the office stated.
Asked about his reaction to the lawsuit, Yao said he has a witness to back up his claim, which he insisted was not unfounded, because the information was obtained via an "official" channel in Japan.
Yao added that the lawsuit will provide an opportunity for him to expose in court everything he knows about the matter.
Chen and his family are being investigated on suspicion of embezzlement, bribery and money laundering during Chen's two terms as president.

Prosecutors of the Special Investigation Unit have detained Chen's former treasurer Chen Cheng-hui and former Presidential Office director Lin Teh-hsun, as well as several others allegedly involved in the scandals, to prevent possible collusion among them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing vows to pave way for more Chinese tourists to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, China, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/08 23:38:28 (By Kuo Ping-ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's top tourism official has promised to help pave the way for more Chinese citizens to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing, a visiting Taiwan official said Thursday.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, made the remarks on the sidelines of a presentation in Nanjing on Taiwan's tourist attractions and resources.
Lai is heading a 150-member delegation on a tourism promotion visit to China, which already took her to Beijing.

According to Lai, Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, told a Beijing workshop hosted by the Taiwanese delegation Tuesday that Chinese authorities are studying measures to allow or encourage more Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.

The two sides of the Taiwan Strait signed two landmark agreements in mid-June on the opening of direct cross-strait weekend charter flights and further opening of Taiwan to more Chinese tourists with effect from July 4.
Under the agreements, Taiwan allows the entry of up to 3,000 Chinese tourists per day, but the number of actual arrivals has so far fallen far short of expectations.
Lai said Taiwan is looking forward to doubling the monthly Chinese tourist arrivals to 20,000 by the end of this year.
According to Lai, expansions of the direct flight services will be high on agenda of a new round of cross-strait talks scheduled for late this month or early November.
On Thursday, Lai paid a call on Zhou Naixiang, director of Jiansu Province's tourism bureau, to exchange views on the promotion of bilateral tourist and cultural exchanges.

More than 100 Chinese travel agents in Nanjing, capital of Jiangsu Province, and its surrounding areas, attended the Taiwan tourism presentation to get first- hand information about resources and the latest developments in Taiwan's tourism industry.

A similar event in Beijing was also very successful, attracting more than 400 travel service executives or tour operators, Lai said, adding that the Taiwanese delegation has been offering various tour packages, including short-stay ones that could be attractive to Chinese salaried workers looking for a quick getaway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong to set up first official office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/16/08 23:41:53 (By Mandy Wong and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has given permission for the Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) to set up an office in Taipei, which will be the special administrative region's first official organization in Taiwan, HKTDC spokesman William Cheung told the CNA Thursday.

The council applied to the relevant authorities in Taiwan earlier this year to establish an office in Taipei, and the approval was received Thursday, Cheung said, adding that the HKTDC welcomed the decision.
The council was established in 1966 as the international marketing arm of Hong Kong and now has 40 offices around the world, according to Cheung.
The council has rented an office in Taipei, and will send one staff member from Hong Kong, while other personnel will be recruited in Taiwan, Cheung said.

The Taipei office is being established to enhance bilateral trade relations and promote Hong Kong's services industry, with financial services, logistics, and real estate being the focus, Cheung said. The Taipei office will also help to boost cooperation between the two sides in technology development and the entertainment industry, he added.
Taiwan is Hong Kong's fourth largest trade partner in terms of volume, with the bilateral trade volume standing at US$33.25 billion for last year, Cheung said, citing HKTDC statistics.

The bilateral trade volume for the period January to August this year was US$22 billion, up by 2.4 percent from the year-earlier level, he noted. The breakdown is US$17 billion from Taiwan's export volume to Hong Kong and US$5 billion from Hong Kong export volume to Taiwan, Cheung said.
He forecast that the Taiwan market will offer more business opportunities for Hong Kong with the continued improvement of relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 17, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Safety standard for melamine key issue at international conference

TEXT.P: The safety standard for melamine levels in food was one of the key issues at an international conference held Thursday in Taipei, with most foreign experts agreeing that 2.5 ppm of melamine would be an appropriate safety level.

However, Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) stipulates that foods containing dairy ingredients, creamers and vegetable-based proteins are allowed on the market only if they test negative for the toxic chemical using the sensitive LC- MS/MS technique.
LC-MS/MS, liquid chromatography/tandem mass, is a technique with a detection limit for melamine of 0.05 ppm, according to the DOH.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration uses LC-MS/MS methods that are capable of determining melamine at levels of 0.25 ppm (parts per million) in powdered infant formula, for which there is a stricter standard, and other dairy- containing food products or ingredients.
We're not encouraging people to close the level down as low as they can impossibly go," said an FDA expert, adding that there are no safety concerns with 2.5 ppm of melamine in foods.
Experts invited by the DOH to attend the conference said earlier that a maximum level of 2.5 ppm of melamine in food is acceptable, but that background contamination levels need to be determined.

Bonnie Sun Pan, a professor at the Department of Food Science, National Taiwan Ocean University, told reporters that the international experts did not discuss whether Taiwan's safety standard for melamine was too strict.
But Sung Yen-jen, DOH deputy minister, said earlier that his agency had no immediate plans to change the standard.

Taiwan's safety standard for melamine levels in food caused controversy in late September when then-DOH Minister Lin Fang-yue raised it to 2.5 ppm amid a food scare over contaminated milk products imported from China. Lin later resigned, mainly because of the public outcry over his decision.

The current DOH minister, Yeh Ching-chuan, immediately after taking office, decided that food products containing dairy and non- dairy ingredients must test negative for melamine using the LC-MS/MS technique if they are to be allowed on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday, moving down 82.18 points at 4,993.79 on a turnover of NT$4.06 billion (US$124.78 million).
The weighted price index lost 170.29 points, or 3.24 percent, to close at 5,075.97 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.574 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.037 from Thursday.

According to another participant, the problem has to be tackled before it reaches the consumer.

If the authorities cannot avoid some isolated cases of fraud, they have to try to detect the problem upstream and solve it before it causes harm to people, said Emmanuel Foex, who works at the French Embassy in Beijing, China.

The question of acceptable levels of melamine in food was also raised by the Taiwan participants who asked why most countries had set the safety standard at 2.5 ppm without knowing the exact level of contamination from sources such as the manufacturing process and packaging.

In response, Emmanuelle Moons, an expert from Federal Agency For the Safety of the Food Chain in Belgium, said that in Europe, the standard of 2.5 ppm was set because it was considered a reasonable level to distinguish adulteration from background contamination, and that the European Union took into consideration the standards in other countries.

Discussing Taiwan's experience, Chen Shu-kong, director-general of the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH, said that only some brands of milk powder imported to Taiwan were tainted with the toxic chemical and that the source of the contamination was possibly the manufacturing process and packaging materials.

However, Kuo Hsu-sung, director of Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control, presented the case study of Taiwan's leading food company which used a toxic non dairy-creamer, imported from the Shandong Duqing company in China, as an ingredient in its pre-mixed beverages.
The chemical melamine is added to milk by some Chinese dairy farmers and milk producers to produce a falsely high test result for protein content.
In China, melamine contamination is believed to have caused at least four deaths and sickened thousands of children who drank tainted infant formula.
The problem has spread to other countries that import food products from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan completes phase II clinical testing of new cancer drug

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese subproject of a phase II clinical test for a cancer drug ADI-PEG 20 has been successfully completed and the drug should be on the market some time next year following the phase III clinical testing, researchers at the National Health Research Institute said Thursday.

ADI-PEG 20 was first developed by the U.S.-based Polaris Pharmaceuticals several years ago. A subsidiary of the Taiwan-based Hsin Tung Yang group later acquired exclusive distribution rights for the drug in Taiwan and China. The group also invested in Polaris to gain the right to conduct clinical testing in Taiwan, which will shorten the required time for review of a new drug in the country.

Financed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and commissioned by the pharmaceutical companies, the phase II clinical tests were started late last year by the National Health Research Institute, researchers said.
According to researchers, ADI-PEG 20 is a protein drug that can break down the arginine in human blood to inhibit the development of cancer cells.
Arginine, an alpha-amino acid, plays a vital role in cell division, wound healing, ammonia removal, immune functions, and the release of hormones.

Once the arginine in blood is removed, cancer cells will lose their most important source of nutrition, which then leads to their death, the researchers said. Normal cells will survive the condition of arginine deprivation because they can synthesize arginine within themselves, the scientists added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing vows to pave way for more Chinese tourists to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, China, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/08 11:01:46 (By Kuo Ping-ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's top tourism official has promised to help pave the way for more Chinese citizens to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing, a visiting Taiwan official said Thursday.

Janice Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, made the remarks on the sidelines of a presentation in Nanjing on Taiwan's tourist attractions and resources.
Lai is heading a 150-member delegation on a tourism promotion visit to China, which already took her to Beijing.

According to Lai, Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, told a Beijing workshop hosted by the Taiwanese delegation Tuesday that Chinese authorities are studying measures to allow or encourage more Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.

The two sides of the Taiwan Strait signed two landmark agreements in mid-June on the opening of direct cross-strait weekend charter flights and further opening of Taiwan to more Chinese tourists with effect from July 4.
Under the agreements, Taiwan allows the entry of up to 3,000 Chinese tourists per day, but the number of actual arrivals has so far fallen far short of expectations.
Lai said Taiwan is looking forward to doubling the monthly Chinese tourist arrivals to 20,000 by the end of this year.
According to Lai, expansions of the direct flight services will be high on agenda of a new round of cross-strait talks scheduled for late this month or early November.
On Thursday, Lai paid a call on Zhou Naixiang, director of Jiansu Province's tourism bureau, to exchange views on the promotion of bilateral tourist and cultural exchanges.

More than 100 Chinese travel agents in Nanjing, capital of Jiangsu Province, and its surrounding areas, attended the Taiwan tourism presentation to get first- hand information about resources and the latest developments in Taiwan's tourism industry.

A similar event in Beijing was also very successful, attracting more than 400 travel service executives or tour operators, Lai said, adding that the Taiwanese delegation has been offering various tour packages, including short-stay ones that could be attractive to Chinese salaried workers looking for a quick getaway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong to set up first official office in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 16 (CNA) 10/17/08 11:05:41 (By Mandy Wong and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has given permission for the Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) to set up an office in Taipei, which will be the special administrative region's first official organization in Taiwan, HKTDC spokesman William Cheung told the CNA Thursday.

The council applied to the relevant authorities in Taiwan earlier this year to establish an office in Taipei, and the approval was received Thursday, Cheung said, adding that the HKTDC welcomed the decision.
The council was established in 1966 as the international marketing arm of Hong Kong and now has 40 offices around the world, according to Cheung.
The council has rented an office in Taipei, and will send one staff member from Hong Kong, while other personnel will be recruited in Taiwan, Cheung said.

The Taipei office is being established to enhance bilateral trade relations and promote Hong Kong's services industry, with financial services, logistics, and real estate being the focus, Cheung said. The Taipei office will also help to boost cooperation between the two sides in technology development and the entertainment industry, he added.
Taiwan is Hong Kong's fourth largest trade partner in terms of volume, with the bilateral trade volume standing at US$33.25 billion for last year, Cheung said, citing HKTDC statistics.

The bilateral trade volume for the period January to August this year was US$22 billion, up by 2.4 percent from the year-earlier level, he noted. The breakdown is US$17 billion from Taiwan's export volume to Hong Kong and US$5 billion from Hong Kong export volume to Taiwan, Cheung said.
He forecast that the Taiwan market will offer more business opportunities for Hong Kong with the continued improvement of relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 17, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
