1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: Body of Formosa Group founder arrives in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The body of Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) founder Wang Yung-ching, who died Wednesday in the United States, was delivered back to Taiwan early Friday morning.
The late tycoon's body was received at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport by his family and later moved to Chang Gung University, which Wang had established in Taoyuan County.
Visitation will take place at the university starting Saturday.
Wang died at the age of 92 in his sleep in Livingston, New Jersey Wednesday. He had traveled there with his wife to inspect the company's U.S. assembly lines.

Wang, known as the "god of management, " founded the FPG in 1954. His businesses have since expanded to the realms of medical care, biotechnology, thermal power stations, automobiles, electronics, silicon wafers, and kitchen waste recycling and reuse.
Forbes Magazine identified Wang as Taiwan's second richest man in its most recent survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Right turn on red light will be opened conditionally

TEXT.P: Automobiles on roads in Taiwan may soon be allowed to make right turns on red lights, the National Police Agency (NPA) said Friday.
Currently, right turns are only permitted on red lights when there is a right turn signal.
The NPA said this will change if the Ministry of Transportation and Communications passes the new regulation allowing right turns at all intersections unless stated otherwise by a traffic sign.
Under the new regulation, motorists will be required to come to a complete stop and check that the way is clear before making a right turn on a red light, the NPA said.
The regulation has been introduced as a petrol saving and pollution emission cutting measure by reducing the number of automobiles idling at intersections, the NPA said.
The NPA has notified police departments under all local governments around the country to assess the feasibility of implementing the new regulation, including examining safety issues.
Right turns on red lights are legal in most states in the United States and most provinces in Canada. They are illegal in Britain and allowed under certain conditions in Germany.
China, South Korea and Myanmar are a few of the countries in Asia where right turns on red lights are legal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to hold public debate on CEPA with China

TEXT.P: Several non-government organizations urged the government Friday to hold public discussions or even a referendum on the issue of whether to sign a "closer economic partnership arrangement" (CEPA) with China, which they claimed will have a serious impact on Taiwan's economy, society and sovereignty.
They made the appeal at a seminar titled "The Impact on Taiwan of Signing a CEPA with China" held by the Policy Committee of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Describing Hong Kong's economy after signing a CEPA with China as a "bubble economy, " Taiwan Labor Front President Ngou Giok-siong said that the Taiwan government should take Hong Kong's example as a warning, "as China is always the biggest winner in the game."

"The government should have public discussions on whether to sign such a major agreement with China or even hold a referendum on the issue, " Ngou said. "If the government just goes ahead without considering the consequences, Taiwan will end up as another Hong Kong."

His expressed concerns came after Jiang Zengwei, deputy minister of China's Department of Commerce, said on Sept. 8 that in order to promote economic and trade normalization between China and Taiwan, the two sides can sign a CEPA like the one China has with Hong Kong and Macau.
Hong Kong and China inked a CEPA in June 2003, helping to open up a huge market for Hong Kong goods and services and effectively improving Hong Kong's economy.

These NGOs also expressed concerns that a CEPA-like economic agreement will be included on the agenda during the visit of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Chairman Chen Yunlin slated for late October or early November, despite Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan saying Thursday that Taiwan definitely will not sign such an agreement with China.

"What China is doing is trying to secure political power through the support of the business community and speed up reunification by economic means," said Chen Po-chih, chairman of the pro-independence non-government Taiwan Thinktank.

Chen argued that an economic agreement like a CEPA will not only compromise Taiwan's economic strength but will also eventually jeopardize the country's sovereignty because "when Taiwan becomes more and more dependent on China, Beijing can use the economy as means of political coercion."

DPP Legislator Twu Shiing-jer said that from the public health and food safety point of view, a CEPA will put the Taiwan people's health in great danger, citing the recent melamine-tainted milk products scandal as example.

He pointed out the differences between Taiwan and China in food standards, quality of medical services and public health, as well as people's way of thinking and doing businesses, saying that a CEPA "is not what Taiwan needs.
"Taiwanese are not Chinese; Taiwan does not belong to China; and Taiwan is better than China," Twu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese creamer maker confirms presence of its product in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Staff of the Chinese company which had supplied non-dairy creamer to Taiwan's beverage maker King Car have confirmed after visiting King Car's warehouse that the supplies were from the company, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Friday.

After visiting King Car's production facility and warehouse in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan Thursday, three staff members from Duqing Co. in Heze City, Shandong Province confirmed that the non-dairy creamer was supplied by their company, Yeh said at the Legislative Yuan.
The Duqing men also admitted that none of the creamer supplied by Duqing and stored in King Car's warehouse had been adulterated intentionally, according to Yeh.
Duqing contracted an international firm to choose randomly four samples of the creamer bought by King Car for melamine tests Thursday.

Two samples, examined by King Car and DOH National Laboratories of Foods and Drugs, respectively, were found to be tainted with melamine. Two other samples were sent back to China for tests to be conducted respectively by Duqing and an international firm commissioned by the company, Yeh said.
The health minister told legislators that Duqing is now conducting its own melamine tests in China.
"If Duqing is to blame for King Car's losses due to the melamine contamination, then Duqing will apologize and the government will help King Car file a claim for compensation," Yeh stressed.

The King Car Group reported on Sept. 21 that eight of its products, made with a non-dairy creamer from China, contained melamine, and the company blamed the presence of the toxic chemical on ingredients imported from China.
However, Li Weiyi, spokesman of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said on Sept. 24 that Chinese laboratories did not find any traces of the chemical in the Shandong-based company's products.@@
Duqing manager Li Hailing echoed the Chinese government spokesman's statement, saying tests on products exported to Taiwan showed they were not contaminated with melamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
TSU becomes co-organizer of 'safeguard Taiwan' rally

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) accepted Friday an offer by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the party to become a co- organizer of a "safeguard Taiwan" rally scheduled for Oct. 25.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen extended the invitation in person during a visit to TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei.
At a news conference held after the meeting, Huang said the TSU will take an active part in the event because the demonstration's theme is one of the party's longstanding goals.

On the DPP's invitation for the TSU's spiritual leader -- former President Lee Teng-hui -- to take part in the demonstration, Huang said the 85-year-old Lee seldom takes part in public rallies. However, Huang said he will help pass on the message to Lee.
The demonstration is being organized to protest the upcoming Taiwan visit by Chen Yunlin, president of China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

During his stay in Taiwan in early November, Chen will hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung of the Straits Exchange Foundation, to discuss issues including the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights and direct shipping links and the establishment of more direct cross-strait air routes.
According to the DPP, the main objectives of the demonstration will be to reject the "one China market, " a downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty and an incompetent government.

The opposition has accused the Kuomintang administration led by President Ma Ying-jeou of "tilting excessively toward China" and sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty in adopting a series of liberalization measures toward China since Ma's inauguration on May 20.

These measures include launching nonstop cross-strait charter flights on weekends, opening Taiwan up to more Chinese tourists, allowing cross-strait currency trading, and raising the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent of their net worth to 60 percent.

Other measures under planning include opening Taiwan to Chinese investment, relaxing restrictions on China-bound investment by Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturers, and recognizing Chinese academic degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI wins R&D 100 Award with One-Chip AC LED technology

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), with its One-Chip AC LED (alternating current light-emitting diode) technology, has been selected a winner of the 2008 R&D 100 Awards competition sponsored by the U.S.-based R&D Magazine.

Receiving the honor on behalf of the ITRI at a gala awards banquet in Chicago Thursday evening, Dr. Jon Hsu, deputy general director of ITRI's Electronics & Optoelectronics Research Laboratories, said that the technology innovation was the result of efforts of an ITRI research unit over the past four years.

According to Hsu, Taiwan is the world leader in LED production in terms of volume, while Japan is taking the lead in production value. The ITRI has recognized the importance of technology innovation in order to develop LED products of higher value.

A LED is a semiconductor device that emits light under a direct current (DC) power source of the right polarity and voltage. Currently, LEDs can only be directly powered in an AC environment with AC-DC converter sub-assemblies.

Hsu said that the ITRI research unit started the project to develop an AC LED module four years ago and that after numerous experiments achieved a breakthrough and developed much smaller and more energy efficient AC LED models. Compared to DC LEDs, AC LEDs can reduce energy consumption by 15 percent to 30 percent.
Recognizing the great commercial potential of the One-Chip AC LED, the ITRI has applied for national as well as international patents, with 70 patents already having been granted, according to Hsu.

Hsu said that the institute has formed an alliance with 19 electronics and optoelectronics manufacturers in Taiwan, including Epistar Corp., Lite-On Technology Corp., Tyntek Corp. and Forward Electronics, to apply the technology to the development of commercial products.
With patent protection, ITRI is confident that Taiwan will remain a world leader in One-Chip AC LED technology, with production value expected to reach NT$7.4 billion in two years, Hsu said.
The R&D Magazine initiated the R&D 100 Awards competition in 1963 by selecting 100 research teams of technological products or processes expected to enhance quality of life and efficiency.

This year's winners include the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, National Energy Technology Laboratory of the U.S., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, NASA Glenn Research Center, Langley Research Center and Goddard Space Flight Center, as well as universities and corporations around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November fell 174 points to close at 4,804, with 72,057 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 173 points to finish at 4,776, with 271 contracts traded, while March futures moved down 171 points to close at 4,741, with 392 contract transactions.
June futures decreased 171 points to finish at 4,734, with 47 contract transactions, while September futures were down 167 points to close at 4,626, with 37 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,978 for November, 4,949 for December, 4,912 for March, 4,905 for June and 4,793 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 115.57 points to finish at 4,960.4, on turnover of NT$55.32 billion (US$1.69 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower, with November and December TE and TF all falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent.

November TE futures fell 7.1 points to close at 196.9, with 3,700 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 7.05 points to finish at 195.15, with 16 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures were down 19.2 points, also limit down, to close at 530.8, with 813 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were down 19 points to finish at 527.2, with 13 contracts traded.
September TF futures lost 11.8 points to end at 517.8, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 2009 economic growth likely to register around 3%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth for 2009 is expected to register around 3 percent due to the impact of the global economic downturn, Central Bank of the Republic of China Governor Perng Fai-nan said Friday.
Perng told the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee that the forecast has been made based on information collected from various international sources.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecast in August that the country would post economic growth of 5.08 percent for 2009.
On Monday, however, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Tain-jy admitted that the projection will be "difficult to achieve" and "probably unattainable."
Chen said the Cabinet is expected in November to revise the forecast downward.
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned last week that the world economy is experiencing a major downturn in the face of "the most dangerous financial shock in mature markets since the 1930s."

The IMF's latest World Economic Outlook (WEO) has forecast that economic growth in advanced countries will be close to zero until at least mid-2009, while growth in emerging and developing countries will slow to substantially lower rates than in the recent past.
In Taiwan, growth is likely to reach 3.8 percent in 2008 and drop to 2.5 percent in 2009, according to the WEO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pingtung police bust amphetamine plant

TEXT.P: Police raided an amphetamine production facility in Pingtung County's Chaojhou township Thursday night, arresting two suspects and seizing nearly 55 kilograms of semi-processed amphetamine and production equipment.
Chaojhou township police said Friday that the semi-processed amphetamine has an estimated street value of about NT$100 million (US$3.07 million).
Arrested were a 26-year-old man surnamed Chou and a 20-year-old surnamed Wang, both of whom are from the southern county of Pingtung, according to the Chaojhou police department.
After receiving a tip, police staked out the suspected amphetamine production facility in Chaojhou for 20 days before carrying out the raid Thursday night.
Police said that the two men rented the place last year and began producing amphetamines at the site about two months ago.

The suspects told police that a man nicknamed "Black Wheel" left the amphetamine-making equipment and ingredients to them after he died and that they decided to start up the illicit operation because they were broke.
Police said they were following up on the suspects' testimony and indicated that initial investigations have not revealed any other accomplices in the illicit operation.
They said that the semi-processed amphetamine was less than a week from being ready for sale on the street.
The case will now be turned over to prosecutors to handle, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 115.57 points, or 2.27 percent, to close at 4,960.4.

Finishing lower for the third consecutive day despite a rally late in Thursday's session on Wall Street, the local bourse opened at 4,993.79 and fluctuated between 5,024.43 and 4,924.73 during trading.
A total of 3.06 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$55.32 billion (US$1.69 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 2.9 percent. Machinery and electronics shares declined 2.7 percent, cement stocks dropped 2.6 percent, construction issues fell 2.5 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 2.3 percent, textile stocks shed 2.1 percent, foodstuff issues fell 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares were down 0.5 percent
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,079 to 365, with 401 stocks remaining unchanged. Another 284 shares finished limit down while 33 closed limit up.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange normally allows shares to rise or fall by a maximum 7 percent in any one session, but the government has limited share price declines this week to 3.5 percent to try and limit the impact of global market volatility on local stocks.

Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$10.98 billion, making them net sellers of NT$21.34 billion in shares for the week and of NT$71.50 billion in shares for the month of October to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local sponsor buys yurt for Mongolian recipient

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese who sponsors a Mongolian child has bought a yurt to shelter her and her family from severe weather in the landlocked country, the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families said Friday.

Wang Ming-jen, executive-director of the fund, said the donor, Chien Hsiu-chih, who is the principal of Fongming Elementary School in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, began sponsoring a sixth-grade girl named Erdenetuya in Mongolia two years ago via the fund.

Erdenetuya lived with her mother and younger brother in a rented yurt in Ulan Bator. Her mother does odd-jobs on the street for a living, but had to stop working for several months due to the wintry climate in Mongolia, where it started to snow in September, leaving the family in a precarious position, according to Wang.

Chien and her family decided to buy a yurt for Erdenetuya's family after observing from her photos that the rented dwelling was not strong enough to help them cope with sandstorms and freezing winds of minus 30 degree Celsius during the winter months.
Chien spent NT$30,000 (US$920) buying the yurt and another NT$3,000 purchasing mattresses for Erdenetuya and her brother, Wang said.

The yurt that Chien bought was the first donated by a Taiwan national after the fund built a dwelling village in Ulan Bator last year for disadvantaged Mongolian children, according to Lin Li-wen, an executive of the fund involved in sponsoring affairs in Mongolia.

The village's 20 Mongolian yurts were all donated by Taiwan citizens, and each yurt has the donor's name on it, Lin said, adding that the fund plans to expand the village in the future to benefit more Mongolian children in need.
Currently, a total of 2,844 Taiwanese are sponsoring 3,957 Mongolian children via the fund, Lin noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imported Shandong octopus balls found to be free of melamine

TEXT.P: Taichung County's Public Health Bureau said Friday that samples from a recent shipment of octopus balls from Shandong province in China were found to be free of melamine.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) in recent days ordered the importer to halt sales of the octopus balls -- a popular round dumpling -- as a precautionary measure after trace amounts of melamine were discovered in similar products tested in Japan.

The DOH asked Kaohsiung County to check the octopus balls, which were imported by a company registered in the county, but county officials found they had already been sold to a distributor in Taichung County.
Nonetheless, Kaohsiung County ordered the removal of octopus balls from local supermarket shelves for melamine testing.

Chu Nien-feng, director of Taichung County's health bureau, said Friday that samples of the shipment in question were sent to the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis for testing and were found not to contain the toxic industrial chemical used in plastics and fertilizers.
He added that the shipment was safe for sale on the local market.
The imported shipment came from a different supplier than those found to have problems in Japan, which originated from Fujian province in southeastern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inter-agency meeting held to prepare for potentially heavy layoffs

TEXT.P: The government has decided to set up an unemployment pre-warning system and strengthen standard procedures to deal with labor-management disputes in anticipation of heavy layoffs at local companies, which are being hurt by the global economic downturn, an official said Friday.

Those and other measures were agreed upon at an inter-agency meeting convened by the Executive Yuan's Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Thursday to address issues related to protecting workers' rights, the official said.

The meeting, attended by representatives from the Ministry of Justice and various central and local government agencies in charge of labor affairs, was aimed at strengthening exchanges among those agencies, according to the CLA official.

Aside from setting up a pre-warning system and improving standard operating procedures used to handle labor-management conflicts, the government also decided to establish a single window to facilitate information exchange among government agencies and set up a Web site to deal with labor-management disputes.

Those at the meeting also decided to hold cross-agency coordination meetings regularly to enable labor affairs officials to stay on top of changes in early warning indicators of unemployment and help them effectively settle industrial disputes, the labor council official said.

CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said that to ease public worries over potentially heavy layoffs in the face of the global economic downturn, the government should stand on the side of workers and give priority to protecting their working rights, the council official said.

Wang also advised employers facing operating difficulties to try and adjust their management strategies to protect the interests of their employees before they move to negotiate a layoff agreement with their staff.
The minister added that the council is more than willing to help enterprises hold dialogue with their employees to pursue better approaches to solve their problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 2010 Int'l Horticulture Expo expecting 6 million visitors

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition is expected to attract exhibitors from 30 countries and some 6 million visitors, the Taipei city government said Friday.

Taiwan is considered one of the world's major flower producers and exporters and the expo, which will begin in the month of September in 2010, will be the first time the island will be hosting a major international horticulture event.
The expo, projected to feature 15 exhibition halls in four separate locations, is expected to take place over a period of eight months.

The exhibition space will include a Global Garden Area, where exhibitors from up to 30 countries are expected to show off their flagship gardening and horticultural products and technology, said Chen Hsiung-wen, director of the city government's Department of Economic Development.

The organization of the expo is authorized by the Hague-headquartered International Association of Horticultural Producers, a prestigious international group in gardening and horticulture comprised of 33 members from 25 countries, Chen said.
The Taipei city government is planning to grant NT$2.5 million (US$77,160) as subsidy to each foreign country that organizes a group to take part in the expo, he added.
A soft opening is slated for Sept. 6, 2010, although the expo is officially scheduled between Nov. 6, 2010 and April 25, 2011, Chen said.

With an investment of NT$7.8 billion (US$240.74 million) , the expo will be held at venues stretching from the Yuanshan Park, Fine Arts Park to the nearby Xinsheng Park and the Dajia Riverside Park in Dazhi, Chen added.

Championing a 3-R motto (reduce, reuse and recycle), all the 15 exhibition halls will be powered by green energy, including solar and wind power, and built with environmentally friendly building materials, Chen said.

As the exhibition will be open daily from 9 a.m. till 10 p.m., there will be "Blue Highway" boats sailing along the Dajia River for visitors to go from one area of the expo to another and a "light sculpture" shows during the evening for entertainment, Chen said.

Admission will be NT$300 per ticket. Preferential tickets, including group tickets and nighttime tickets, will also be available, Chen said, adding that if visitors purchase a NT$2,500 open ticket, they can visit any hall of the expo anytime throughout its eight-month duration.

DOC.HEADLINE: No problems were found in usage of the Nangang Exhibition Hall

TEXT.P: Although bidding for construction of the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall is alleged to have involved corruption, there have been no problems regarding the use of the premises, Huang Hsiao-kuan, the hall's director said Friday.
Huang said that the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall has hosted six large-scale international exhibitions since opening on March 13 of this year.
Many of the participants in these exhibitions have expressed satisfaction with the hall, he said.

However, Huang pointed out that due to differences of opinion between the construction company and the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior regarding the exhibition hall construction's completion date, the builder may face fines.

Huang also pointed out that although the bidding process for the construction contract may have involved corruption, there have not been any major problems with the exhibition hall itself, except for minor leakage in the pipelines.
No major faults in terms of construction quality have been found whatsoever, he added.

The Nangang Exhibition Hall took more than 10 years to plan and construct. It was built because the increasing number of large-scale international exhibitions had overwhelmed the Taipei World Trade Center in the Xinyi District of Taipei City.
Former Minister of the Interior Yu Chen-shien was detained Wednesday on charges connected to the case of alleged bribery in the bidding process.
According to the prosecutor's office, Yu is suspected of leaking the names of members of a committee that was responsible for screening the bids for the costly construction of the hall.
Yu allegedly made the name list available to the company that eventually won the bid during his tenure as interior minister between 2002-2004, the office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT co-hosts conference on new nanotechnology dental implants

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Friday that its Commercial Section will co-host a conference on dental implants at the Taiwan Medical University to introduce Taiwanese dentists to new U.S. nanotechnology that dramatically decreases the patient recovery time for dental implant surgery, while increasing its success rate.
Renowned American dentist Dr. Alan Meltzer will deliver the keynote address to over 200 local dentists on how to incorporate this new technology into their practices, the AIT said in a press release.

Patients often request shorter treatment time so that they can minimize inconveniences in life,Meltzer was quoted as saying in the AIT press release.Even if patientsconditions are not ideal, we can still shorten surgery recovery time by using nanotechnology implants.

Taiwans official data shows that 47 percent of Taiwans population aged 12 and older is missing at least one tooth. If left untreated, missing teeth can cause a variety of health issues such as periodontal disease, loss of natural facial contours, and even digestive problems, the AIT press release said, adding that however, many people are hesitant to seek treatment fearing that it will take too long.

The length of treatment required for an implant is determined by the time it takes for the implant to bond with the human bone, known as osseointegration. The latest dental implants employing state-of-the-art nanotechnology can substantially reduce the time for osseointegration.

Dr. Cheng Kuo-ching, a graduate of the Boston University School of Dental Medicine, said in the AIT press release that as implant dentistry becomes popular, patients demand better quality and a faster healing process.
It is therefore essential to enhance bone bonding and improve stability, Cheng said.Implants using nanotechnology can effectively expedite bone growth.
The conference on the nanotechnology dental implants is slated to be held at the Taipei Medical University on Oct. 19 at 9 a.m. A cocktail party is planned for 15:30 p.m.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.550.
A total of US$672 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.525 and fluctuated between NT$32.491 and NT$32.588.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist numbers to Taiwan far below agreed upon limits

TEXT.P: The number of sightseeing trips to Taiwan by Chinese citizens has been far lower than expected since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached an agreement in mid-June on opening Taiwan up to more Chinese tourists, a Shanghai daily reported on its Web site Friday .

According to the Workers' Daily, just over 21,000 Chinese tourists have visited Taiwan since the agreement, signed by the heads of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, formally took effect on July 18.

The figure represents only 28 percent of the maximum number of Chinese tourists allowed to visit Taiwan under the agreement -- which the paper said established a quota of 1,000 tourists per day in its initial stages.

In fact, however, the deal allowed up to 3,000 tourists per day, and it was unclear if the newspaper simply made a mistake or was reflecting an official decision by Beijing to limit visits to Taiwan by its citizens in the months following the agreement.
The lower tourist numbers have been a disappointment to President Ma Ying-jeou's administration, which had hoped more arrivals from China could provide a spark to the stagnant local tourism sector.
The report provided some insight to why tourist numbers have fallen below expectations.

In Shanghai the three travel agents authorized to offer tours to Taiwan under the agreement have handled just over 3,700 Chinese tourists since the launch of the agreement, well below their allowable limit of 900 tourists per month each, according to the daily.
A travel agent in Shanghai told the newspaper that the high costs and many restrictions have discouraged many Chinese citizens from choosing tours to Taiwan.
He said that the price of a tour to Taiwan is as high as 12,000 yuan (US$1,760), which is comparable to taking a trip to Europe.
The fact that the cheapest tour to Taiwan costs an average of about US$80 per day has led many Chinese citizens to opt against choosing the island as a travel destination, he added.

Another travel industry source, however, expressed the hope that the announcement before the end of this year of the next group of travel agents authorized to offer tours to Taiwan will give a boost to the number of Chinese tourists visiting the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record high number of grey-faced buzzards pass through Kenting

TEXT.P: The number of grey-faced buzzards passing through Kenting National Park in the southernmost tip of Taiwan this year reached 39,300 as of Friday, breaking its 2006 record of 35,800, a park administration specialist said.
More than 11,000 of the rare birds passed the Kenting National Park Tuesday, setting a single-day record, Tsai Yi-jung said.

The birds breed in eastern Russia, northern China, Korea, and Japan, and winter in Southeast Asia. They usually fly through Taiwan between Oct. 1 and 20 on their southward migration, with the largest numbers of migrating birds usually seen one or two days after Oct. 10.

Since the Kenting park administration began its systematic investigation of the number of the birds passing Kenting, the previous one-day high was 8,300 on Oct. 11, 2005, while the largest number for a season was 35,800 in 2006, according to Tsai.

More than 5,000 birds passed Kenting Friday, pushing the number of the birds passing Kenting this season over 39,000, Tsai said, adding that the number will exceed 40,000 Saturday if only 650 fly over.
This year, the massive movement started on Oct. 9, with more than 3,000 flying toward the sea on Oct. 10. Since then, the number has averaged between 1,000 and 3,000 per day.

Tsai attributed the higher-than-average daily number of grey-faced buzzards passing Kenting this year mainly to the fact that the weather has been good in countries that the birds had passed through before arriving in Taiwan.
The grey-faced buzzard is an Asian bird of prey. It is typically between 41-46 cm in length, making it a medium-sized raptor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to protect ROC's sovereignty

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan promised Friday that the government will make sure the sovereignty of the Republic of China is protected in its handling of the upcoming visit to Taiwan by Beijing's top negotiator.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will be in Taipei to meet with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung.
They are expected to discuss issues ranging from the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights and direct shipping links to the establishment of more direct cross-strait air routes.
Asked during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan if he has any plans to receive Chen, Liu said if he is to receive Chen, he will definitely do so in his capacity as premier of the ROC.

Also, Liu said the ROC flag and the portrait of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen will not be removed from the government offices where possible meetings between ROC government officials and Chen take place.
As Beijing does not recognize Taiwan's government, Chinese officials visiting Taiwan have always avoided official meetings with government officials in Taiwan.
There have also been cases in which mainland officials demanded that the ROC flag not be displayed at venues where they visited.
But Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said during the session that ARATS has not made any such requests for Chen's visit, which has been set for early November.

On the opposition's demand that Beijing apologize to Taiwan over the scare over melamine-tainted food before Chen visits, Premier Liu said the government has formally asked for an apology from the mainland, but that he could not decide on Beijing's behalf as to when the apology is to be offered.
Lai noted that the government first raised the apology issue on Sept. 14 following the discovery of melamine in a shipment of Sanlu-brand milk powder imported into Taiwan.

While Premier Liu reiterated the position during a legislative interpellation session Sept. 30, the government later also passed on the message to Beijing through the communication channels existing between the two sides, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation raises funds for abandoned children

TEXT.P: The Child Welfare Foundation plans to raise NT$15 million (US$460,603) before the end of this year to care for abandoned children, whose numbers reached a three-and-a-half-year high in the first half of 2008.

The foundation needs the funds to cover the costs of housing and caring for the abandoned children at its nursing homes across Taiwan to give them good environments before they are entrusted to adoptive families.
The foundation announced its plans at a news conference held at the Children's Recreation Center in Taipei Thursday, where it also delivered a report on the current scale of the problem in Taiwan.

A foundation representative urged the general public to donate money to help fund the program, and said those interested in making a contribution could call a hot line at (02) 2550-5959 or visit the foundation's Web site for more information.

A total of 525 children, or approximately 43 each month, were abandoned in the country last year, said Alicia Wang, the foundation's executive director, citing statistics recently released by the Ministry of the Interior.

A total of 315 children have been abandoned in Taiwan during the first half of this year, marking an increase of 23 percent over the same period of last year and representing the highest level in three and a half years, Wang said.
Parents also made a total of 425 calls to the foundation during the January-June period, expressing their desire to have their children adopted, as they are short of money to raise them, Wang added.

While financial problems are the main reason for the phenomenon, the foundation said, children are also often abandoned because their parents are in jail and cannot take care of them or because of the strain of caring for children with serious diseases.

Making the foundation's job more challenging is that local families interested in adopting abandoned children generally reject children who are sick, older, foreign or of aboriginal descent, while scores of families decline taking in children whose parents are drug addicts or have criminal records.

At the same time, recent government statistics show that the number of local families willing to adopt children has dwindled over the past few years because of the country's sluggish economy during that time.
To make matters worse, some families that have adopted children plan to give them up because of financial woes, the foundation indicated.

Also on hand at the press event was "philanthropic ambassador" Patty Tsai, wife of EasyCard Corp. Chairman Sean Lien, and officials of the program's sponsors -- including Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., one of the country's major cell phone service providers.
Founded in Taipei in 1991, the foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting child welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwanese win awards with essays at APEC event about water

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese young adults received top prizes for their research papers on the country's water culture at an APEC camp, the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) said in a statement Friday.

The two winners, a male and a female, who are in their 20s, won the awards at the 2008 APEC Youth Camp, an event held under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Peru from Oct.1-6.
The theme of the camp was "caring for the sustainable development in the Asia- Pacific region."

Among the four-member Taiwan delegation, Cheng Yu-hsung's thesis on renovation of the Love River in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan garnered the Best Essay Award, while Wang Chih-hua walked away with the Most Interesting Essay on application of coastal water resources in Chiayi County in southwestern Taiwan.
Some 36 delegates from 21 APEC member economies participated in the camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local chemists invent shortest intermetallic quintuple bonds

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese chemists have invented the shortest artificial metal-metal quintuple bonds to date, which holds two chromium atoms at the distance of only 1.74 angstroms (0.174 nanometers), academic sources said Friday.

Tsai Yi-chou, a chemistry professor at the National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu, explained that the scientists have for long devoted themselves to discovering or inventing high-order inter-atomic bonds, such as quadruple, quintuple, or even sextuple bonds.
"The higher the order, the stronger the binding power, and wider the range of application," added Tsai.

A chemical bond is the attractive interactions between atoms or molecules. When employing artificial bonds, scientist will be able to create novel compounds that can be used in commercial products or other equipment.
An American chemist, Frank Albert Cotton, first invented quadruple bonds in 1964; while the first man-made quintuple bonds did not come into existence until as late as 2005, according to Tsai.
Even though some scientists have claimed to produce sextuple bonds, it is very difficult to reproduce the results, not to mention determine their genuine bond orders, noted Tsai.
To date, the shortest distance between two quintuple-bonded atoms is recorded at 1.80 angstroms.

The Taiwanese team -- joined by scientists from National Tsing Hua University, National Chiao Tung University, National Taiwan University, and National Taiwan Normal University -- first produced a pair of quintuple-bonded chromium atoms with an intermetallic distance of 1.82 angstroms.
They later replaced the bond with potassium graphite, which further shortens the interatomic distance to 1.74 angstrom, said Tsai.

According to the online report of Nature Chemistry, a separate team in Germany reported that they made a similar breakthrough in producing quintuple bonds at almost the same time when Tsai's team reported their finding; however, the German team's quintuple bonds are slightly longer, 1.75 angstroms, and the re- evaluation suggested abond order of only 4.2.
For future applications, Tsai said that for example, their findings can be used to refine the catalysts employed in the manufacturing process of polyethylene (PE) or polypropylene (PP).
Such an improvement can lower the temperatures and pressure needed to produce PE and PP, so that the production safety can be increased, added Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts see 2.5 ppm for melamine as appropriate safety standard

TEXT.P: International experts reached a consensus at a conference in Taipei Friday that the standard of 2.5 ppm of melamine in food is adequate to ensure human health and stressed that cooperation between importing and exporting countries should be enhanced.

Despite the consensus, however, Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) had no immediate plans to modify its own more restrictive standard for melamine in food, said agency spokesman Wang Je-chau, who said the forum was simply a platform for experts to share their opinions.
Debate has raged over the standard since late September, when consumers panicked after a shipment of melamine-adulterated milk powder from China was found to have entered Taiwan.

Then DOH Minister Lin Fang-yue was forced to resign after setting a safety standard of 2.5 ppm (parts per million) of the chemical in most foods and 1 ppm for infant formula, as opposition politicians charged the standard was "loose" and would put local consumers at risk.

To appease consumer fears, the DOH now stipulates that processed foods and ingredients will be allowed for sale only if they test negative for melamine using highly sensitive LC-MS/MS (liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry), which can detect as little as 0.05 ppm of the chemical in food.

That has led to disputes with local food suppliers, who have complained that products that would be found acceptable in the European Union, the United States and elsewhere were judged unacceptable in Taiwan.

At Friday's conference on control measures for melamine presence in food, most experts agreed that the 2.5 ppm standard was an "action level" to prevent fraud, meaning that it was an appropriate level to distinguish adulteration from background contamination.
The experts also echoed previous international advisories on the issue that melamine, although toxic, is of low toxicity and thus poses low risk to human health.

Bill Jolly, deputy director of export standards of New Zealand's Food Safety Authority, described trying to set standards for melamine at levels below 2.5 ppm as "more academic than practical, " arguing that only items containing melamine in traces above that level needed to be dealt with for public health purposes.

New Zealand's standard for melamine is 5 ppm for food ingredients, 2.5 ppm for foods in their final form and 1 ppm for infant formula, according to a media release issued by the country's Food Safety Authority Sept. 29.

Kang Jaw-jou, a professor in National Taiwan University's Institute of Toxicology, appeared to take issue with the DOH's standard, arguing that while all chemicals are toxic, and only the level of use and how they are used can determine its toxicity.
We cannot chase after zero detection or zero tolerance, which is impossible. What we need is a standard based on risk assessment, not on numbers,Kang said.
A number of the experts also argued that more attention needed to be placed on prevention measures than testing methods,

Slava Zeman, manager of the export food policy section of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, stressed the importance of control and management measures at the source of food production.

The most meaningful and almost the only way to really prevent the presence of melamine in food is to look at the production controls and at the whole food safety framework during production, Zeman said.

She further suggested that cooperation between the authorities of exporting and importing countries should be enhanced to ensure that necessary measures are adopted during food production, including fraud prevention.
Zeman feared that if people use extremely expensive testing methods, it would raised the price of products to a level that nobody could afford.

According to Chen Shu-kong, director-general of the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH, a LC-MS/MS spectrometer costs about NT$9 million (US$276,180), while a GC/MS machine, which is less sensitive but generally used by other countries to test for melamine in foods, costs from NT$3 million to NT$ 5 million.

Experts also said that integrated control between trading countries should be improved. They praised Taiwans food safety system, but believed it could still further enhance relationships with its trading partners, including China.
In addition, they suggested better random and risk-based testing to verify imported productssafety at ports of entry.

Bonnie Sun Pan, a professor in the Department of Food Science at National Taiwan Ocean University, said that risk communication in Taiwan needs to be enhanced between food suppliers, consumers and government agencies, in order to ease people's worries about tainted food.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to set up a think tank to promote relations with ASEAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) decided Friday to establish a think tank to provide strategies to promote relations with countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
The decision was made after a two-day coordination meeting of the ministry's newly formed task force on relations with ASEAN.

The meeting -- attended by eight representatives of Taiwan in the Southeast Asian countries and 15 agencies under the Executive Yuan -- was held to follow through on President Ma Ying-jeou's directive to have Taiwan actively participate in the integration of the Asia Pacific region and ASEAN.

It was the first such meeting after the MOFA established the ASEAN task force, a strategic inter-agency group aimed at strengthening relations with the region and preventing Taiwan from being marginalized.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said the think tank, which will be comprised of senior diplomats and experts well-experienced in relations with ASEAN countries, will advise the task force on its strategies and direction.
This serves as a proof that we are not just paying lip service to the issue, but really taking action (to improve relations with the ASEAN),Chen said.
While Chen would not reveal more details related to the think tank, he said the unit should be establishedthe sooner the better."
The meeting provides a good beginning to the integration of agencies on the establishment of a working network toward ASEAN,the MOFA said in a press release.

The ministry added that improved relations across the Taiwan Strait provides Taiwan with more latitude to work with ASEAN countries, and said it will work with related agencies to seize the opportunity and integrate resources to continue to expand and consolidate relations with Southeast Asia.
The MOFA will also promote Taiwan's entry into the ASEAN mechanism to benefit Taiwan's sustainability and development, the foreign ministry added.

Taiwan fears its trade-dependent economy could be marginalized if it is not included in a regional free trade zone under negotiation that would include the ASEAN countries and China, South Korea and Japan.
Established in Thailand in 1967, ASEAN is made up of 10 member countries -- Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.
Its objectives, apart from promoting regional peace, include the acceleration of economic growth, social progress and cultural development among its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students to get free lunches by 2010 at the earliest: MOE

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng said Friday that the ministry hopes to be able to provide free lunches to all elementary and junior high school students in Taiwan by 2010 at the earliest.

Cheng made the remarks at a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan during which the issue of children from underprivileged families who are unable to afford the lunch fees at schools was raised.

Legislator Tsai Chin-lung of the ruling Kuomintang noted that the government has appropriated NT$700 million this year to subsidize students from low-income households, but "there are still many children who have not been included and cannot afford to pay for lunch fees."

Tsai said that the government has been generous in funding top-notched universities, and that it should also fund the lunch program in all elementary and junior high schools, adding that doing so "would only cost NT$19 billion (US$179.88 million) a year."
Providing students with free lunches is "a step in the right direction", Cheng said, but he noted that "local governments should also shoulder responsibility in financing the project."
At present, in addition to the central government, a few local governments -- Hsinchu city and county, as well as Kinmen and Matsu -- are also funding their lunch program, according to Cheng.
"If the Ministry of Education has to shoulder all the expenses, it will have financial problems," Cheng said.
Pressed by Tsai on when the free lunch will be possible, Cheng
said the budget for next year has already been appropriated, but
he is eying for 2010.
"The ministry will coordinate with other government agencies and
local governments, in hopes that the goal can be achieved in
2010," he said.
Lunches offered in elementary and junior high schools cost between NT$35 to NT$50, and a student has to pay between NT$770-1,100 per month if a school month is counted by 22 school days.
According to government statistics, around 140,000 students, accounting for 5.6 percent of the elementary and junior high school student population, cannot afford to pay for school lunches.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Design Award seeking new name

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is inviting the public to give the Taiwan Design Award -- considered the "Oscars" for Taiwan's design sector -- a new shorter but more powerful name.

According to the IDB, the idea came from President Ma Ying-jeou, who suggested that the annual event could use a shorter, more creative name along the lines of renowned design awards in other countries, such as Germany's iF Design Award and Red Dot Award, America's IDEA (Industrial Design Excellence Award) awards, and Japan's G-mark Award.

The 2008 Taiwan Design Award winners were announced in early October. The president presented the awards to the winners on Oct. 4 at the opening of the 2008 Taiwan Design Expo, which is being held in Tainan County's Soulangh Cultural Park for a 16-day run until Oct. 19.
The Taiwan Design Center, which is entrusted by the IDB as the organizer of the Taiwan Design Award, has decided to invite the public to submit entries to get a new name for the award.

Interested individuals can access http: //www.boco.com.tw to download a form and fill it out with recommended names in both Chinese and English and give a brief description of their significance before submitting their entries online.

An online vote will select the top five winners from among all entries, with the first place entry entitled to a cash award of NT$20,000, the second place entry NT$10,000 and the third to fifth place entries each receiving NT$5,000. If any of the five suggested names is adopted as the formal name of the award, it will be presented with an extra cash award of NT$50,000.

Meanwhile, the organizer will also ask a panel of experts to come up with five additional names, which, along with the five winning entries submitted by members of the public, will enter the final screening stage, with the winner selected through an online vote from Nov. 5 through Nov. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: No injuries after coach catches fire in Hsuehshan Tunnel

TEXT.P: A coach carrying 28 passengers caught fire while traveling northbound in the Hsuehshan Tunnel early Friday, but firemen rushed to the scene quickly and put out the blaze.
No one was harmed in the accident.

According to the National Highway Traffic Control Center, the fire that occurred at 10:25 a.m. may have been sparked by the coach's overheated engine, but the true cause of the blaze has yet to be established.
The center temporarily stopped both northbound and southbound traffic to allow fire trucks to reach the scene, which was close to the tunnel's exit on the Taipei County side.

The 28 passengers were students and faculty members of National Ilan University who were on their way to Kaohsiung to take part in a national robotics competition. They were evacuated to a rest area to wait for a replacement bus.
The traffic in the tunnel returned to normal at around noon after the demobilized bus was towed away.

This was the second fire in the 12.9-kilometer tunnel since the second longest road tunnel in Asia was inaugurated in June 2006. On Aug. 3 this year, a northbound sedan also caught fire when it was 5.5 km into the tunnel, but firemen rushed to the scene within 10 minutes to extinguish the blaze.
No one was injured, and fire experts later determined the blaze was caused by spontaneous combustion.
The tunnel's self-defense fire brigade, as well as the fire brigades near both ends of the tunnel in Taipei and Yilan counties, hold fire drills regularly to keep their men in top firefighting form.

The tunnel is the centerpiece of the 55-km No. 5 Freeway linking Taipei with Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan. It has cut travel time between the two areas from more than two hours to about 30 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic fuel prices drop further amid falling crude prices

TEXT.P: Domestic fuel prices will drop further amid declining crude oil prices in the international market, with Taiwan's two gasoline suppliers announcing price cuts Friday.
Both state-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) and the private Formosa Petrochemical Corp. will lower their prices for gasoline by NT$2 per liter and prices for diesel by NT$2.2 per liter.
CPC's price cuts will take effect Friday at midnight and Formosa's will go into force at 1 a.m., Saturday.

Following the latest adjustment, the price of 92-octane unleaded gasoline will fall to NT$25.2 per liter, that of 95-octane unleaded will be NT$25.9 per liter and that of 98-octane unleaded will fall to NT$27.4 per liter. The price of diesel will fall to NT$22.3 per liter.

This week's cuts follow gasoline and diesel price reductions last Friday of NT$2.3 and NT$2.5 per liter, respectively, the highest drops since CPC Corp. adopted a floating pricing mechanism Aug. 7 that reviews prices on a weekly basis.
With international crude oil costs continuing to slide this week, falling to below US$70 per barrel on Thursday, CPC Corp. decided to lower its product prices accordingly, a company executive said.
Price adjustments are made based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information, the executive added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEC's R & D center will boost Taiwan's economy: President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Japanese firm NEC Corp.'s plan to set up a research and development center in Taiwan will help promote and develop the country's WiMax industries.
Ma made the remarks while receiving NEC President Kaoru Yano, who announced the investment plan during his visit to Taiwan.

The company's decision to establish a WiMax R & D center in Taiwan is significant, Ma said, because nearly 90 percent of the parts and components needed for production for the industry are manufactured on the island.
Ma suggested that the corporation use Taiwan as the base to make inroads into the global market on information technology.
Yano said that Taiwan's products have always been in the lead in international markets, and that he expects to see Taiwan's IT industry notched up.
Meanwhile, Ma said NEC's previous trade deals with Taiwanese companies have contributed to Taiwan's economy.
NEC purchases of Taiwan's products in recent years are valued at over US$3 billion, ranking it among the top 10 of the country's overseas electronics products buyers, according to Ma.
The firm has been a leading company in the IT industries, with net sales last fiscal year amounting to US$45.78 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: European offices to hold conferences on abolition of death penalty

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty (TAEDP) and three European offices in Taiwan will organize a series of activities in early November to encourage the abolition of the death penalty and help advance the debate on the issue in Taiwan, the alliance said Friday.
One of the centerpiece events will be a seminar Nov. 6-7 called "New Perspectives on Abolishing the Death Penalty, " organized by the TAEDP and the German Institute in Taipei.
German scholars will discuss the issue from different perspectives, such as the relationship between the abolition of the death penalty and social safety, victim protection and prison reform.

"The objective of Taiwan's Criminal Code is to re-educate and reform prisoners, not to kill them, " said a TAEDP worker, who expected that the events will help promote human rights and encourage debate on the issue.

The worker, who only gave her surname Chiu because she only volunteers for the organization, also suggested that Taiwan should learn from Germany's experience, which includes considerable achievements in prisoner re-education.

According to the TAEDP, no individual has been executed in Taiwan since 2005, but there are still 31 convicts who have been sentenced to death, including one who was sentenced on the Double Ten national holiday, which is also the World Day Against the Death Penalty.

In addition to the above seminar, the French office will hold a conference on Nov. 3 on "How Taiwan can move toward abolishing the death penalty, " in partnership with National Taipei University and the Taiwan Law Society, with the support of the European Economic and Trade Office.

Two French experts, Sylvie Bukhari de Pontual, a lawyer and member of the Bar of Paris, and Michel Forst, general secretary of the French National Consultative Commission for Human Rights, will talk about the need of criminal code reform regarding abolition of the death penalty and on the death penalty in the context of international law, according to the office.

A film featuring Robert Badinter, senator and former French Minister of Justice, who is renowned for his activism in support of abolishing capital punishment in France, will also be screened at the conference.
British experts will also exchange their experiences with Taiwan on Nov. 13 and 14. They will discuss how to advance the process of getting rid of the death penalty in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs open policies to retain, attract talent: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 17 (CNA) 10/17/08 21:32:52 (By Charles Kang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government should come up with more open policies to prevent a brain drain and to attract foreign talent amid a global competition for human resources, Johnsee Lee, president of Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), suggested Friday.

Speaking to CNA during a telephone interview, Lee said Taiwan fell behind many countries and places like Singapore, Hong Kong, China, and Malaysia in terms of keeping and attracting professional talent.
Many of Taiwan's technology talents, including researchers in the ITRI, have been recruited to work in Singapore, said Lee, who is currently visiting Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
What Taiwan lacks are favorable government measures to retain and attract talent, Lee said.

In addition to local research institutes' efforts to provide a better environment to ease and prevent a brain drain, Lee said, Taiwan's government should offer more assistance, which could include a more open attitude towards allowing foreigners to work here, and favorable regulations related to talent acquisition, including loosening guidelines on the kind of jobs foreigners are allowed to do here and providing easier access to residency rights.

Lee cited Singapore as an example Taiwan can learn from. Singapore recruited leaders of and teams of research institutes in the United States and Europe with high salaries. It also simplified the process for foreign professionals to acquire work permits, residency, and naturalization.
Lee pointed out that Taiwan's ITRI has made a lot of efforts in improving teamwork and creating a good entrepreneurship environment to keep its talented staff.
The institute allows researchers to spend 10 percent of their work time to research innovative topics that they are interested in, Lee said.

ITRI also provides development capital to employees for profitable innovations created during that part of their work time and researchers can receive 25 percent of the technology transfer fees on their inventions, Lee said.
ITRI's staff are also free to give suggestions and criticism about the institute's operations on its employee intranet, in the hope of inviting ideas for the institute's improvement, Lee said.

The ITRI also encourages researchers to study ways to develop innovations beneficial to disadvantaged groups, energy saving, and health care, in order to keep them in the institute by satisfying their need to make contributions to society, Lee said.
Lee is in Malaysia for the Frost and Sullivan 4th Annual Growth Innovation and Leadership Summit, which was organized by the U.S. -based growth consulting company Frost and Sullivan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to freeze Lehman Brothers' funds in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) urged the government Friday to immediately freeze the NT$5.71 billion (US$175.29 million) kept by the bankrupt Lehman Brothers in two accounts of Polaris MF Global Futures Co. as good faith deposits.

KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said at a press conference that some 51,000 Taiwanese investors who bought structured notes from Lehman Brothers suffered losses totaling NT$40 billion, and that the government should follow the examples of Japan and South Korea by freezing the funds of Lehman Brothers to protect the rights of domestic investors.
Wu also called for a thorough check to find out if the collapsed Wall Street investment bank still has other funds and assets in Taiwan.
He lashed out at Securities and Futures Investors Protection Center Chairwoman Chan Tsai-hung for remaining silent on the issue.
"Did Chan know that Lehman Brothers still has NT$5.71 billion in cash in Taiwan? If she didn't, she should step down. If she knew it but took no action, she should all the more step down," Wu said.

In response, Chan said her center has already sent a written notice to the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission about the matter, and that the center and the commission are actively pursuing the issue.
Meanwhile, Ted Ho. chairman of Polaris MF Global Futures, confirmed that Lehman Brothers still has NT$5.71 billion in two accounts with his company, and that no one is allowed to touch the funds.

Ho said that although the trustee in the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy had requested a takeover of the funds, his company had replied that the company had to consult with related government authorities in Taipei on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Mega Holdings chief listed as suspect in money laundering probe

TEXT.P: Former Mega Financial Holding Co. Chairman Cheng Shen-chih was listed as a suspect Friday in a probe into a snowballing case involving alleged money- laundering by former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said prosecutors decided to change Cheng's status from a witness to a potential defendant after discovering while questioning him earlier in the day that he had shady financial dealings with other suspects in the money laundering case.
Cheng was released after being questioned.

Also Friday, prosecutors investigating the high-profile money laundering case raided offices of three of Taiwan's largest financial holding groups in search of evidence of their involvement in the case.

According to Chen Yun-nan, prosecutors discovered that subsidiaries of the three business groups -- Mega Holdings, Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and China Development Financial Holding Corp. -- had suspicious money dealings with bank accounts held by suspects in the money laundering case.
To avoid affecting the bearish local bourse, prosecutors did not start the massive search until after the market closed. The raid was still going on as of press time.

Chen Yun-nan said all relevant personnel were very cooperative in the course of operations. In addition to offices, residences of certain major shareholders of the three financial groups were also searched.
According to media reports, prosecutors suspect that some of Chen Shui-bian's family's overseas funds might have come from companies in connection with financial reforms during his presidential term.

But Chen Yun-nan said Friday's operations had nothing to do with the so-called controversial "second fianncial reforms" launched during Chen Shui-bian's tenure in which local banks were encouraged to merge to expand their market shares.
The former president, his wife, son, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law and four others have all been named as potential defendants in the case.

Two of Chen Shui-bian's trusted aides -- Chen Chen-hui and Lin Teh-hsun -- as well as the former first lady's older brother Wu Ching-mao and Tsai Ming-tseh, a brother of one of Wu's college classmates, are being detained for their suspected roles in the case.

Swiss authorities informed Taiwanese authorities that a sum of US$21 million was wired to Swiss bank accounts belonging to Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching in 2007. The funds have since been frozen.

Chen Shui-bian admitted Aug. 14 that his wife Wu shu-jen wired US$20 million abroad from his past campaign funds but said she did so without his knowledge. He denied that members of his family were laundering money.

The former president, who stepped down May 20 after eight years in office, is already being investigated for allegedly embezzling NT$14.8 million from a "state affairs fund" set aside for his discretionary use for official purposes while he was head of state.
His wife is on trial in the same embezzlement case.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC hopes rules can be eased to facilitate infrastructure plan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) expressed the hope Friday that regulations governing the introduction of foreign laborers in free trade zones could be eased for one of the government's 12 major infrastructure projects.
The Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) reaffirmed, however, its stance that any move to bring in more foreign laborers could not undermine the job opportunities of local people.

An MOTC official was referring to the Taoyuan International Air City, which will include a free trade zone (FTZ) . The ministry is hoping to ease current regulations governing the FTZ to make it more attractive to foreign investors.

The ministry hoped that existing labor regulations in local free trade zones, such as paying the minimum wage and requirements that foreign laborers be limited to 40 percent of a company's workforce and that Indigenous Peoples make up at least 5 percent of a company's workforce, not apply to the air city.
The official said that the ministry has sent two versions of a draft statute governing the development of Taoyuan International Airport Park to the Executive Yuan for approval.
The first one follows existing regulations and would enforce the 40 percent cap on foreign workers and payment of a minimum wage.

The second version states that in special cases, companies seeking to invest in the air city could apply for exemptions from the 40 percent cap and minimum wage standards, and their applications would be jointly screened by the MOTC and the Council of Labor Affairs.
The MOTC also hopes to lower the ratio of Indigenous employees the minimum 5 percent to 1 percent, the official said.

The official acknowledged, however, that "no company in a free trade zone has a workforce where 40 percent of its workers are foreign laborers. It is not certain which sectors in the air city would need a lot of foreign laborers."
He said the ministry only put forth the second version because it does not want potential investors to have any misgivings about hiring foreign laborers if they had the need.
Meanwhile, CLA spokesman Pan Shih-wei stressed that industrial development will not rely on opening Taiwan to foreign workers, saying that they should be complementary in nature.

"The premise of opening up to foreign workers is that it should not affect the working rights of local people," Pan said, adding that those jobs that are made available to foreign laborers should be ones in which local people are not interested and where labor shortages exist.
He said that the CLA currently allows foreign laborers to work in households and in the manufacturing, construction, and social welfare sectors.
The logistics industry has in recent years hoped to introduce foreign laborers, but the CLA said logistics companies are part of the service sector, which is not facing a labor shortage.
CLA statistics showed that there are more than 370,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan, and the ratio of foreign laborers employed in various sectors depends on their respective conditions.
In the construction sector, for example, only major construction projects are allowed to introduce foreign laborers.
Some sectors have in recent years asked the CLA to exempt them from paying foreign laborers the minimum wage, but the requests have been rejected by the CLA to protect the workers' human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC to announce Sunday whether to extend limit on share price decline

TEXT.P: The government will announce Sunday evening whether the measure to narrow the limit on share price declines will continue, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Gordon S. Chen said Friday.
Chen made the announcement after financial officials failed to make a decision on whether to extend the new measure.
"We will continue to monitor the financial situation at home and overseas closely in the next two days before making a decision," Chen said.
Local shares, which normally are not allowed to rise or fall by more than 7 percent in any trading session, have been limited to declines of 3.5 percent since Oct. 13.
The 7 percent limit-up remains unchanged.
The measure has not prevented local share prices from tumbling along with world markets. The benchmark Taiex index fell 3.3 percent for the week, including 2.27 percent on Friday to close at 4,960.4.
The FSC hinted on Thursday that it might not extend the measure, but felt on Friday that it needed more time to decide because of continuing volatility on world markets.
