DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist still missing after disappearing from Taipei hotel

TEXT.P: A member of the first Chinese tour group allowed to travel to Taipei via the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen disappeared from a Taipei hotel shortly after his arrival and has since remained at large, the Tourism Bureau said in a statement Friday.

Lin Guobin arrived in Taipei via a flight from Kinmen Sept. 30 -- the inaugual day of the new cross-Taiwan Strait travel formula -- after reaching the island on a ferry from Xiamen in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian earlier that day along with a tour group.
Lin was nowhere to be found when the Chinese tour group leader conducted a roll call the following morning. He remained missing on the group's scheduled departing date Oct. 8.
After an intensive search over the past 10 days failed, the National Immigration Agency put Lin on the "wanted" list Friday, the Tourism Bureau statement said.

Meanwhile, the statement said, the Tourism Bureau decided to deduct NT$200,000 (US$6,153.8) from the travel agency's NT$1 million deposit as a fine. All local travel agencies intending to host Chinese tour groups are required to deposit NT$1 million as a guarantee.
According to Lin's entry permit application form, he was a staff member of a ready-to-wear garment factory.

Travel sources said all members of the first tour group to travel to Taiwan via Kinmen had been carefully screened and selected. It was hard to understand why Lin, known as the boss of a garment factory in China, would abscond, the sources said.
As part of its efforts to attract more Chinese tourist arrivals, Taiwan began to allow Chinese holidaymakers to fly to Taiwan via Kinmen Sept. 30.
Oliver F.L. Yu, deputy minister of transportation and communications, said the issue should be addressed in terms of the motivations of those who have absonded and the frequency of such cases.
Since Taiwan opened its door wider to Chinese tourists July 4, three absconding cases have been reported, including Lin's case.

The remaining two cases involved Chinese citizens traveling to Taiwan via a third place or country. On July 9, three Chinese women left the hotel their tour group was staying without informing their group leader. Two of them came forward to a local police office the following day, but the third one, identified as Guan Xiaoyin, has remained at large.
On July 14, a man disappeared from the hotel after arriving with a tour group from a third place, but he was located the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 18, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty- three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Number of active Internet users in Taiwan totals 10.14 million

TEXT.P: The number of active Internet users in Taiwan totaled 10.14 million at the end of June 2008, which translates into 44 Internet users per 100 population, an industry report has revealed.

The number represents a slight increase from the end of December 2007, when there were 10.03 million active Internet users, according to the report released recently by the Foreseeing Innovative New Digiservices (FIND), a Web site run by the Institute for Information Industry to provide professional information on Internet demographics and trends.

At the end of June 2008, broadband subscriptions totaled 4.7 million, up 40,000 quarter-on-quarter, and mobile Internet subscriptions reached 13.38 million, up 920,000 quarter-on-quarter. Meanwhile, dial-up subscriptions stood at 690,000.

Mobile Internet subscriptions accounted for the largest portion of commercial subscriptions at 71 percent, followed by digital subscriber line (xDSL) subscriptions at 18 percent, fiber-to-the-home/business (FTTH/B) subscriptions at 4 percent, dial-up subscriptions at 4 percent, and cable modem subscriptions at 3 percent.

Of the 13.38 million mobile Internet subscriptions, 8.55 million were through 3G data service, increasing 990,000 from the previous quarter and accounting for 64 percent of all mobile Internet subscriptions.
Meanwhile, 3.32 million subscribers were using the general packet radio services (GPRS) , dropping 70,000 quarter-on-quarter and accounting for 25 percent of all mobile Internet subscriptions.

Those using the personal handy-phone system (PHS) totaled 1.49 million, up 10,000 quarter-on-quarter and accounting for 11 percent of all mobile Internet subscriptions. Only 20,000 subscribers were using the wireless application protocol (WAP) network.

Among broadband subscriptions, xDSL users totaled 3.42 million at the end of June 2008, declining 3.7 percent quarter-on-quarter and accounting for 73 percent of all broadband users. The number of cable modem users stood at 480,000, up 5 percent quarter-on-quarter.

The FTTH/B service, which provides faster transmission speed and better quality than the xDSL, recorded 800,000 subscriptions at the end of June 2008, up 23 percent quarter-on-quarter and accounting for 17 percent of all broadband subscriptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang Chien-ming tosses in bullpen for first time since injury
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 17 (CNA) 10/18/08 14:49:58 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born New York Yankees starter Wang Chien-ming took a major step forward Friday in his rehabilitation from a season-ending injury in mid-June.

Wang, who suffered a right foot injury while rounding third base in an inter- league game against the Houston Astros on June 15, entered the bullpen for the first time since the injury to throw some warm up pitches in Tampa Bay, Florida.

Known as "the pride of Taiwan" for his stellar 19-win seasons in 2006 and 2007, Wang began the new season with an 8-2 record and an ERA of 4.07 before being sidelined for the remainder of the year with a torn Lisfranc ligament of the right foot.
Although the injury did not require surgery, Wang was restricted to a foot cast which was only removed on July 28.
On Friday, Wang began cautiously by throwing some 20 pitches on a mound half the height of a regular mound to warm up before entering the bullpen where he threw about 25 pitches.
"It's better. It's good," Wang told members of the U.S. media afterwards.

Although Wang has not yet recovered 100 percent, the U.S. media already see him as one of the five starters in the Yankees' rotation for next year, which is the pride of Taiwan's ultimate goal after months of rigorous rehabilitation.

The Yankees are also hoping that Wang will be back in top form for the start of next season after they failed to make the post-season for the first time since 1993 because of a string of injuries to key players during the course of the regular season.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier goes on shopping spree to encourage consumer spending

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan went on a shopping spree in Taipei City Saturday afternoon in an attempt to encourage more consumer spending to help boost the domestic economy.
Liu spent more than NT$10,000 (US$307) on his shopping trip which took him to the Pin-chiang Market and Sogo Department Store.

The premier's move came on the heels of President Ma Ying-jeou's highly publicized visit to a local market to purchase two pairs of sneakers Wednesday with the express aim of setting an example for Taiwan consumers to head out and shop.
At the Pin-chiang Market, Liu bought a variety of locally grown fruits, including papayas, grapefruit, persimmons and dragon fruit, saying that "Taiwan- grown dragon fruit is the sweetest."

Liu then headed to Sogo Department Store, where he purchased three shirts for more than NT$6,000 as well as a new DVD player for NT$1,490. He said he decided to make the purchase after his wife had told him earlier the same morning that their old player was on the fritz.

The premier also purchased a few CDs to round out his shopping trip, including one by folk singer Kimbo, another by pianist Li Yun-di, and one by pop singer Jay Chou, whom he called "a brilliant musician."

Liu told reporters after his shopping spree that he randomly chose the market and department store and that most of the products he purchased were Taiwan made. He expressed the hope that his gesture would be helpful toward boosting production at domestic businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH imposes ban on China-made leavening agent

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) imposed a ban Saturday on a leavening agent imported from China, which it said is contaminated with the toxic chemical melamine, adding another item to the list of banned Chinese food products.

The leavening agent, ammonium bicarbonate, was found to contain between 70 and 300 ppm (parts per million) of melamine in a regular random examination conducted by a local bureau of health, said Deputy DOH Minister Cheng Shou-hsia at a press conference.
Cheng announced a ban on all imports of ammonium bicarbonate from China, adding it to list of food imports from China already banned -- milk powder, creamers and vegetable-based proteins.
Ammonium bicarbonate is a legal food additive used to lighten and soften bread and biscuits.
Cheng said that only one company in Taiwan, Sesoda Corp., has imported the tainted leavening agent from two chemical companies in China.
But volume of the import is still under investigation, he said, adding that the tainted ingredient was shipped to 12 regions in Taiwan.
He however declined to name the 12 regions, saying only that local health bureaus have begun to seize the tainted ingredient.
"The leavening agent was tainted, but as the quantity added to food is usually very small, products on store shelves are still safe to eat," he stressed.
Nonetheless, the DOH has asked food companies in Taiwan to use other leavening agents, such as baking soda and baking powder.
Cheng said he did not know why the chemical had shown up in the leavening agent.

"Melamine is not a food additive, so we have no way of knowing in what products it will show up, " he said, adding that instituting controls at the food production source is the most important food safety measure.
An inter-agency meeting will be convened before next Monday to discuss measures to deal with the issue of melamine contamination of food, Cheng said.
He disclosed that the DOH has informed the International Food Safety Authorities Network under the World Health Organization about the latest case of melamine contamination.
In the past weeks, melamine has been found in imports of dairy products, creamers and vegetable-based proteins from China.
Under the DOH's current regulations, foods testing positive for melamine with the use of the LC-MS/MS technique (liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry) are not allowed on the market.

Melamine, a toxic industrial chemical, was added by Chinese food producers to milk to produce a falsely high result in tests for protein levels that measure nitrogen content. This was done in cases where water was added to raw milk to increase its volume. The addition of melamine increases the nitrogen content of milk and therefore its apparent protein level.

Thousands of children in China who were fed baby formula contaminated with the chemical were found to have kidney stones, while four infants have died as a result of consuming the tainted milk products.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP expects 1 million participants in 'safeguard Taiwan' rally

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) forecast Saturday that one million people will take part in its "safeguard Taiwan" demonstration to be held Oct. 25 in Taipei.
According to Lai Ching-te, a DPP legislative caucus whip, the event has spurred the interest of "more people than any other demonstrations held in the past."
For example, Lai said, in his Tainan constituency office alone 200 people have signed up for the rally over the past two days.
Lai said the widespread responses reflect the deep public resentment against the Kuomintang (KMT) administration.
"Everybody wants to take to the streets, regardless of political affiliation or class," he said.
Pan Meng-an, a deputy whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said crowds of protesters are expected to converge on Taipei in at least 100 charter buses from Pingtung County alone.
According to DPP Legislator Chen Ting-fei, the rally will definitely trigger "an unprecedented uproar" because the KMT administration's "tilt toward China" has damaged Taiwan's sovereignty.
The main objective of the planned demonstration is to reject the "one China market, the downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty and an incompetent government, " the DPP said.

The protest is being organized in cooperation with the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union amid plans for a visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, president of China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

Chen is expected to visit Taipei to hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung of the Straits Exchange Foundation, to discuss issues that include the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights and direct shipping links and the establishment of more direct cross-strait air routes.

The opposition has accused President Ma Ying-jeou of sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty by adopting a "modus vivendi" approach that advocates a"diplomatic truce" with China and introducing a series of cross-strait liberalization measures since his May 20 inauguration.

These measures include launching nonstop cross-strait charter flights on weekends, opening up Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, allowing cross-strait currency trading, and raising the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent to 60 percent of their net worth.

The opposition is also unsatisfied with what it alleges is the Ma administration's failure to take a tough stance toward China in dealing with the scare over melamine-tainted food imported from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business delegation to seek buyers in China

TEXT.P: A business delegation comprised of government and local food firm representatives will travel to northern China Sunday to seek potential buyers, in the first stage of a plan to grow exports, according to a statement released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The delegation, consisting of 38 representatives of 23 local food companies, will be led by Chiang Shih-huang, deputy director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, and will visit Beijing, Tianjin, and Qingdao cities from Oct. 19-25, the statement said.

The trip is part of the government's plan, which has a budget of NT$1.5 billion (US$46 million), to increase export by 10 percent for the second half of the year. The markets of China, Russia, Brazil, the Middle East, Indonesia, and ASEAN member countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia and Malaysia are the focus of the plan.

After visiting the three Chinese cities, the delegation will travel to China's Sichuan Province to participate in the annual Western China International Economy and Trade Fair from Oct. 27-30, the official said.
The trade fair, which is the largest of its kind in western China, is the first international business show to be held there since the Sichuan earthquake occurred in May.
The statement noted that the province has had two-digit growth in import volume every year since 2002.
While in China, the delegation will hold news conferences to raise the visibility of Taiwan's products and will arrange meetings between Chinese and Taiwanese food firms.
The delegation will also visit high-end food outlets like Jusco, MyKal, and Walmart, to learn about their purchasing policies, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's Nangang district celebrates Sweet Olive Blossom Festival

TEXT.P: The southeastern Taipei City district of Nangang celebrated the blossoming of sweet olive flowers with a carnival-like festival Saturday that featured musical performances and a fun fair.

It was the sixth year that the Nangang District Office was holding the "Guihua Festival, " which revolves around the blossoming of the sweet olive -- a plant known for the special fragrance of its flowers, called guihua in Chinese.

The 2008 Guihua Festival and Musical Carnival began at Jiuzhuang Elementary School with a singing contest and a musical concert. Visitors to the one-day festival also had the opportunity to sample traditional guihua cakes and guihua- scented Chinese tea, according to the organizer.
Sweet Olive, or osmanthus fragrans, is an evergreen shrub species of osmanthus native to Asia. It is found in the Himalayas, eastward to southern China, Taiwan, and southern Japan.

The plantation of sweet olive trees began more than a century ago, when local tea farmers came up with the idea of using guihua to improve the fragrance of their original green tea, known as Paochung Tea.
The Nangang District Office began this year to encourage residents to grow more guihua trees in an effort to promote the district's tourism.
At present, there are 10,000 sweet olive trees in Nangang.
District administrator Chiang Ching-hui said that the trees began blossoming last week and the fragrance is growing increasingly stronger as more flowers bloom.

This year, it is expected that there will more blossoms than ever before, creating the most magnificent sight in history, and the delightful fragrance will last until the beginning of 2009, according to Chiang.

Chiang particularly mentioned 12 guihua trees, about 50 years old, in the Jiuzhuang Elementary School compound, saying they are in full bloom. He encouraged people to visit Nangang to enjoy the natural autumn fragrance.
Visitors can travel to Nangang via the Taipei metro to Kunyang station and then transfer to the Small 5 city bus to the elementary school.

DOC.HEADLINE: 51.7% Japanese firms in Taiwan satisfied with current operations

TEXT.P: Some 51.7 percent of the Japanese enterprises in Taiwan are satisfied with their current operations in the country, according to the results of survey released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) late Thursday.

The survey, commissioned by the MOEA and conducted by the Taipei branch of Japan's Nomura Research Institute, was aimed at learning more about how Japanese enterprises view the Taiwan market and their means of coping with the country's changing investment environment.

Japanese firms invest in Taiwan mainly because of the market, the respondents indicated, with about 65 percent of those in research and development saying that Taiwan was their target market for product development, and 68 percent of those in production indicating that they wanted to be close to the market.

About 32 percent of respondents think one of the advantages of operating in Taiwan is that they are well positioned to develop products for other Asian markets including China, and 25 percent of the respondents in the field of marketing and selling think Taiwan functions as a test market before they look at other countries, the poll showed.

In terms of coping with the shrinking Taiwan market, 50 percent of the respondents said they chose to invest in high value-added products and services, while 47.3 percent said they will expand to other markets.

Some 19.1 percent of the respondents that sell their products in Taiwan think the Taiwan market will expand in the future, while 45.5 percent think the situation will remain the same, according to the poll.
Among the respondents, 78.1 percent have operated in Taiwan for more than 10 years, and 48.1 percent for longer than 20 years.

The respondents were drawn from a wide range of business operations, with 68.9 percent in marketing and selling, 53.8 percent in purchasing, 51.8 in after-sale service, and 32.7 percent in research and development, and product planning and design.
The survey obtained 251 valid samples in June from Japanese firms in both the manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rotary club bike tour aims to raise funds for rare disorder patients

TEXT.P: Several members of the Rotary Club's Taipei Yenping branch set off Saturday morning on a round-Taiwan bicycle tour to raise funds for the treatment of rare disorders.
King Liu, chairman of Taiwan's flagship bicycle maker Giant, was one of the many people on hand to see the 21 cyclists off at Dadaocheng Wharf in Taipei City at just after 7 a.m.
Liu, whose son-in-law is one of the group members, joined the cyclists on the first stretch of their journey to give them encouragement.

The cyclists hope to complete their 1,010-km journey in 11 days and raise at least NT$5 million (US$153,500) for the cause as the Rotary Clob has promised to donate NT$1 for every kilometer they ride.

The Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders (TFRD) and the Department of Health have listed 171 rare disorders in Taiwan -- 80 percent of which are either incurable or can only be treated with drugs that are costly and not readily available.
The cost of treating such diseases is extremely high and well beyond the means of patients whose disorders are not covered by the national health insurance system, according to the TFRD.

The foundation expressed its appreciation to the Rotary Club for its show of concern for people with rare disorders and expressed the hope that it can serve as an example for all sectors of society in Taiwan.
The Rotary Club cyclists plan to arrive in the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Oct. 21, where they will visit a patient with a rare genetic skin disorder called epidermolysis bullosa.
The cyclists will solicit donations during stops along their journey which is slated to conclude back at Dadaocheng Wharf on Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity calls for end to abuse of domestic animals in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A non-profit animal protection organization in Taipei called Saturday for an end to the abuse and torture of domestic animals in Taiwan by providing them with a safe and caring environment.

The founder of AnimalsTaiwan (AT), Sean McCormack from the United Kingdom, said at a press conference that neutering, rather than killing, of animals is a more effective method of dealing with the stray pet problem in the country.
"My hope is to achieve the goal of caring for and protecting domestic animals by educating school children and the wider public on the issue, with the help of media," he said.
He suggested that "by protecting animals and showing love for them, Taiwan can enhance its image in the international community.".
AnimalsTaiwan was founded four years ago with the aim of helping to stop cruelty to domestic animals, McCormack said.
It started out by rescuing dogs on the street and has since grown into an officially recognized charity organization that attracts volunteers and advocates animal welfare through education, he added.
Currently, AT, at its rescue center in Beitou District, Taipei, provides shelter and care for around 60 dogs and more than 10 cats.
Report of animals in distress may directed to the organization's hotline at 02-2833-8820, while more information about AnimalsTaiwan is available at its Web site at www.animalstaiwan.org.
The organization said it welcomes the adoption of animals and contributions to help fund its work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jan-Aug fire incidents drop 18% year-on-year

TEXT.P: A total of 1,903 fire incidents were recorded in Taiwan during the first eight months of 2008, down 18 percent compared with the same period last year, according to statistics released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior.
There were 1.3 casualties per 100,000 persons between January and August 2008 as a result of fires -- a decrease of 0.4 percent ----- from the year-earlier level, the figures showed.
Building fires were the most common among all the different types of fire incidents, accounting for 66 percent of the incidents reported during the eight- month period.
In terms of the causes, 36 percent of the fires were attributed to short circuiting of electrical equipment, while 12 percent were cases of arson, and 8 percent were caused by cigarette butts.

By region, the highest fire incidence rate was recorded in Lienchiang County, with 6.1 incidents per 10,000 persons. Taitung County had the second-highest fire incidence rate, with 4.7 incidents per 10,000 persons, followed by Penghu County, with 3 incidents per 10,000 persons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carnival parade brings color to Taipei streets

TEXT.P: Some main streets in Taipei were crowded with colorful floats and musical bands Saturday afternoon, drawing throngs of people to participate in the cultural event, the "Dream Parade."

The parade, held by the Dream Community Foundation, is reportedly the largest carnival in Asia. This year it attracted the participation of more than 5,000 people from 150 groups, including schools, civic groups and community associations, which used recycled materials to make the costumes and decorations.

The parade, featuring floats, musical bands, acrobats and folk dance groups, started from Liberty Square and ended on Ketagalan Boulevard. A party was scheduled to be held on the boulevard until 9 p.m., according to the foundation.
The annual event usually attracts not only local people but also foreign artists.
Klaus, a German keyboarder who has been in Taiwan for five years, told the Central News Agency that he has participated in the carnival for three consecutive years and he really enjoyed it.
He and his five-member music band, the Bopomofo Blues, made a float from recycled paper, which depicted a New Orleans style jazz band with real music instruments.
Describing the cultural atmosphere in Taipei as "nice", Klaus, however, said he expected much more diversity.
"(Taipei) could be more open to international things and not just concentrate on Taiwan or Japan," he said.

A young Brazilian woman, who has been learning Chinese and teaching samba in Taiwan for a year and a half, said while Taiwan has a rich culture, its people sometimes have a conservative attitude toward other cultures.
"For example, Taiwanese girls would hesitate to wear this kind of costume, " she said in standing in front of an orange and yellow colors float on which characteristic samba costumes were displayed.
The first Dream Carnival was organized in 2002 by the foundation in order to "reignite people's passion for life."

DOC.HEADLINE: Illegal radio stations mushrooming despite clampdown

TEXT.P: The National Communication Commission (NCC) has recently stepped up clampdown on unlicensed radio stations around the country, but admitted this would only serve to temporarily reduce the number of such stations.

Chen Chuan-ping, director of the NCC Northern Regional Regulatory Department, said Saturday that the crackdown has resulted in halving the number of illegal radio stations in Taiwan to around 50. However, based on past experience, the number would soon bounce back to 100, he added.

Unlicensed radio has existed in Taiwan for years, with many stations being accused of disrupting frequency assignment, airing exaggerated commercials for so-called medical cures and making false claims about a cure-all drug.

According to NCC statistics, the government has cracked down on 330 underground radio stations over the past two years. However, some of them have set up again in other locations, therefore, the number has remained at around 100, NCC officials said.

Chen said it takes two to three weeks to prepare for a raid on an underground radio station. First, the transmitter must be located, then it must be determined what the station is broadcasting, before a search warrant can be sought, he explained. The whole process takes even longer if the station is in a remote area, he said.

Under the Telecommunications Act, persons found operating unlicensed radio stations that cause interference may be subject to fines of up to NT$600,000 (US$18,400) and imprisonment of up to two years.
In a raid, the equipment and devices used by an underground station are also confiscated, Chen said.
He added that increased raids on such stations are only part of efforts to root out underground radio broadcasting, and that the measures include assisting illegal operators to become legal.
In order to address this problem, the NCC has decided to open a new bandwidth to accommodate more than 40 private stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 918 saxophone players perform together in bid for world record

TEXT.P: The central Taiwan city of Taichung tried Saturday to set a new Guinness World Record by gathering 918 saxophone players to give a grand musical performance.
The challenge was part of the 2008 Taichung Jazz Festival, being held from Oct. 18-26 under the sponsorship of the city government.

According to the organizers, the number of saxophone players they gathered for the challenge surpassed the current world record of 900 maintained by the Canadian city of Toronto. As a result, Taichung City will register the new record with the Guinness World Records management group and ask for its certification, the city government said.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said he believes the city will be more famous thanks to the potential new world record.

The 918 saxophone players performed three songs -- "Spring Breeze, " "The Moon Represents My Heart" and "You Are My Sunshine." Although the organizers failed to gather 1,000 musicians as planned, the resonant music of the 918 saxophone players rocked the audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei expected to name envoy to APEC summit before end of October

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco Ou said Saturday that he hopes President Ma Ying-jeou would name the country's envoy to the informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum before the end of the October.

Noting that Peru which is to host the summit at its capital Lima on Nov. 22 has urged Taipei to inform it of its envoy's name, " the decision should not made after Chen Yun-ling's Taipei trip." Ou said.
Chen is China's top negotiator with Taiwan and is expected to visit Taipei late this month or early November for talks with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin- kung on issues of mutual interests.
Taiwan's leader has been prevented from the APEC summit ever since it was admitted to the forum in 1991 because of Beijing's opposition.
The country has to name an economics official or a business leader to attend the summit in place of its leader.
Local political analysts said Ou urged Ma to name the envoy before Chen's visit in order to shield President Ma from possible criticism that he wants to seek Beijing approval on his choice.

Ou said his ministry has already provided a list of candidates to President Ma to choose the envoy. Given the fact that leading powers in the world are concerned about the development between Taiwan and China, Ou said Taipei will have its representatives to the United States, Japan and European Union to brief their host countries on talks between Chen and Chiang afterward.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA Daybook for Oct. 19, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 19, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin- yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei expected to name envoy to APEC summit before end of October

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco Ou said Saturday that he hopes President Ma Ying-jeou would name the country's envoy to the informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum before the end of this month.

Noting that Peru which is to host the summit at its capital Lima on Nov. 22 has urged Taipei to inform it of its envoy's name, " the decision should not made after Chen Yun-ling's Taipei trip." Ou said.
Chen is China's top negotiator with Taiwan and is expected to visit Taipei late this month or early November for talks with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin- kung on issues of mutual interests.
Taiwan's leader has been prevented from the APEC summit ever since it was admitted to the forum in 1991 because of Beijing's opposition.
The country has to name an economics official or a business leader to attend the summit in place of its leader.
Local political analysts said Ou urged Ma to name the envoy before Chen's visit in order to shield President Ma from possible criticism that he wants to seek Beijing approval on his choice.

Ou said his ministry has already provided a list of candidates to President Ma to choose the envoy.
