DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
ARATS vice president to attend cross-strait symposium in Tainan

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese academics, including Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , are scheduled to take part in an academic symposium slated to open in the southern county of Tainan Monday.

Zhang, who was a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council before becoming the deputy head of the ARATS in 2006, is leading a 21-member Chinese academic group to attend the 2008 Cross-Strait Academic Symposium on Mass Communications and Image Arts to be held Monday at Tainan National University of the Arts (TNUA) located in Guantian township, Tainan County.
Zhang is taking part in the academic symposium in his capacity as dean of Xiamen University's School of Journalism and Communication.

"The symposium, which is titled Globalization and Reflection on Values, is aimed at examining the cultural assets and unique values in Taiwan and China, respectively, in the face of increasing globalization and the development of homogeneity in modern societies," said Chen Ling-hui, director of the TNUA College of Sound and Image Arts, one of the sponsors of the symposium.
Zhang and other Chinese scholars will deliver speeches and share their research papers with their Taiwanese counterparts during the one-day symposium, which is the seventh of its kind, Chen said.
They are also scheduled to make field trips to other universities in southern Taiwan Tuesday to "hear in person more local voices from Taiwan," Chen added.

On reports that some supporters of the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party will launch protest against Zhang at TNUA as ARATS President Chen Yunlin is due to visit Taiwan at the end of this month or in early November, Chen Ling-hui said Zhang's visit is for purely academic purposes and has nothing to do with politics.

"TNUA respects the freedom of speech of all members of Taiwan society, but the school hopes that the protesters will look rationally at the reality and not interrupt the symposium, " the director said.

DOC.HEADLINE: American expatriates in Taiwan keep close tabs on U.S.election

TEXT.P: As the U.S. presidential election campaign enters the final stretch, American expatriates in Taiwan are paying close attention to the race between the Democratic candidate Senator Barack Obama and the Republican candidate Senator John McCain, as the outcome could change the future course of the U.S.
Many Americans living outside their country plan to have their say in the election by casting absentee ballots.
In the U.S., an absentee ballot is defined as a ballot marked and mailed by the voter in advance of the election, away from the place where he or she is registered.

American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokesman Thomas Hodges told the CNA that although the AIT is not directly involved in the voting process, it thinks that the estimated 40,000 to 50,000 Americans in Taiwan are keeping their fingers on the pulse of the Nov. 4 presidential election.
"Indeed, the AIT has received many inquiries recently from (U.S.) citizens in Taiwan, and from this communication we can say that interest here in the upcoming election is very high," Hodges said.

Hodges noted that elections in the U.S. are fully conducted by the country's 50 states and its territories -- the Federal Government does not print ballots or count votes. Therefore, Americans wishing to vote must register with the local officials in the U.S. jurisdiction -- usually a county -- where they most recently resided, he explained.

Even if overseas Americans are already registered in a particular locality, they still need to periodically let the county know where to mail the absentee ballot and there is no requirement that they have to go through the AIT, according to Hodges.
"However, the AIT takes seriously its responsibility to assist," he said.

In a press release on Sept. 10, the AIT stated that it "strongly encourages all U.S.citizens on Taiwan to vote in all U.S.elections in which they are eligible. Advanced planning is crucial for overseas voters and now is the time to act."
The overseas voting process is completed in four steps -- registering, requesting a ballot, receiving a ballot, and mailing the marked ballot, the AIT added.

It also outlined various options for mailing the completed ballots from Taiwan, directing American expatriates to the Web site http: //www.ait.org.tw/en/uscitizens/MailingOptions.asp. It said Americans in Taiwan may also submit specific questions to the AIT via the email address VoteTaipei@state.gov.

Eligible voters can also find all the relevant information on absentee voting at www.FVAP.GOV, the official Web site of the Federal Voters Assistance Program, a Federal organization that is charged with assisting overseas and military U.S. voters, the AIT said.
Mainly because of the Internet, it is now very easy for overseas citizens to get the information they need and to obtain their ballots without the AIT's involvement," Hodges said.

Under U.S. regulations, a voter must request an absentee ballot at least a week before the election. Each state's secretary of state or director of elections is in charge of the election process, including voter registration and absentee ballot requests.

After completing the registration and absentee ballot request form, the voter is required to return it to the election official in his or her county, who will approve the registration and request and then mail the ballot to the voter. After completion, the ballot has to be returned to the election official to be counted.
The regulations on absentee voting vary in different states. For example, in Hawaii, the deadline for registration of absentee voters was Oct. 6, and for ballot requests it is Oct. 28.

Most states count absentee ballots on Election Day, although the process can continue for several days after. In Washington D.C. and Florida the counting of absentee ballots must be completed within 10 days after Election Day.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S.embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington. 971019

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers have mixed responses to president's peace accord plan

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and its counterpart of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reacted differently Sunday to comments in an Indian quarterly by President Ma Ying-jeou on the subject of a cross-Taiwan Strait peace accord.

While KMT lawmakers keenly supported Ma's initiative to ink a peace accord with China during his term in office, DPP lawmakers were highly skeptical of such an agreement, expressing fears that it would undermine Taiwan's independent status.

In an interview published in the Oct. 18 issue of the India and Global Affairs quarterly, Ma said he hoped to pursue a peace pact with China during his term in office, in response to a question on whether he would see the more than 1,000 missiles targeted by Beijing on Taiwan removed during his presidency.

KMT Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang endorsed the president's efforts to make peace with China, saying that signing a cross-strait peace agreement is the right thing to do. But he cautioned that Ma still needs to overcome many challenges ahead.
Lu called for the legislation of a cross-strait bill and improved understanding with China to pave the way for the clinching of the proposed peace accord.

Another KMT lawmaker, Lin Yu-fang, said that signing a cross-strait peace agreement would mean a normalization of bilateral relations. If that happens, Taiwan would enjoy greater international space and the prospects of peace in the strait and the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world would be better guaranteed, he added.
Lin highly praised Ma for putting forward what he called a politically far- reaching proposal.

But DPP lawmaker Kuan Bi-ling opposed the idea of a cross-strait peace pact on grounds that it would make Taiwan into an appendage of China and push Taiwan to embark on a path of unification with China.
Kuan suggested that a referendum must be held to decide whether the president should sign such a peace accord with China, if Ma insists on doing so.

Kuan's DPP fellow lawmaker, Huang Wei-cher, painted Ma's proposal as pandering to China, at a time when Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan in his capacity as president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is slated to visit Taiwan later this year.

Huang accused Ma of preparing a big gift for Chen at the cost of Taiwan people's interests by raising the proposal without setting any pre-conditions. "This would put the Taiwan people at great risk, " he said.
Meanwhile, Chen is projected to visit Taiwan in late October or early November.

He will hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, on issues that include the establishment of cross- strait regular air and sea links, crime fighting and financial supervisory cooperation.

The Chiang-Chen meeting in Taiwan would be a follow-up to their historical meeting in Beijing in June this year, in which two accords on weekend passenger charter flights and Taiwan's broader opening to Chinese tourists were signed.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP undecided on whether to let ex-president join protest rally

TEXT.P: Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Sunday that the DPP is still considering whether to let ex-president Chen Shui-bian participate in its Oct. 25 anti-government rally.

Before attending a promotion news conference for the scheduled "safeguard Taiwan" march, Tsai said that the DPP will accommodate all the different opinions on the issue, which she said is still under discussion.
Chen and his family have been under investigation on allegations of corruption and money laundering during his presidency.
"The question is not whether he should attend or not, but rather how we can make the best arrangements," Tsai said.

"I believe that all the parties concerned would be willing to sit down and discuss this matter," she added, avoiding a direct answer to reporters' questions on whether the DPP planned to send its pro-independence party heavyweights to talk Chen out of attending the event.
Asked whether she would personally communicate with Chen on the matter, Tsai said "it depends on the situation."

Meanwhile, Lin Chih-chia, secretary-general of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said that "the TSU cannot walk with Chen and I hope the DPP will communicate with him properly so that the focus of the event will not be diverted."

As to whether former President Lee Teng-hui will take part in the demonstration, Lin said the TSU has invited Lee and he is considering the invitation but no decision has yet been made, as Lee is scheduled to give a keynote speech at a forum organized by the non-government Taiwan Advocates.

The Oct. 25 protest is being organized by the DPP in cooperation with the TSU and pro-independence groups such as Taiwan Society and Taiwan Professors Association, amid plans for a visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, president of China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
The main objective of the planned demonstration is to reject the "one-China market, the downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty and an incompetent government," according to the organizers.
Tsai said the enormous insecurity of Taiwan's people comes from Ma's handling of issues such as sovereignty, the economy, the public's livelihood and food safety.
It is time for the general public to take to the streets and express their deep discontent and resentment over the government's policies, as the DPPs warnings have all fallen on deaf ears, she added.

The opposition has been accusing Ma of sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty by adopting a "modus vivendi" approach that advocates a "diplomatic truce" with China and introducing a series of cross-strait liberalization measures such as direct weekend air links and raising the cap on China-bound investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: People do not trust president on peace accord with China: DPP chair

TEXT.P: There will be huge controversy in the country if President Ma Ying-jeou proceeds with talks on a peace accord with China, given that people in Taiwan have very little confidence in him, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen warned Sunday.

"Many people in Taiwan have little confidence in Ma's handling of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, and if he is takes the lead to sign a peace accord with China, I believe there will be great controversy in the society," Tsai said, as she prepared to attend a promotion event for the DPP's planned Oct. 25 anti- government march.

In an interview published in the Oct. 18 edition of the Indian quarterly India and Global Affairs, Ma said that he hoped to ink a cross-Taiwan Strait peace accord with China during his term of office.
He stressed, however, that there is no timetable for setting up a mechanism on military confidence-building or signing a peace agreement between Taipei and Beijing.

Ma, who took office May 20, said in the August interview that weekend chartered flight services and allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan were the top priorities for his administration and that they were achieved in July.
The next step is to push for direct air and sea links, comprehensive normalization of cross-strait economic relations and then Taiwan's international participation and a peace agreement, he added.
Tsai contended that a peace accord between Taiwan and China should be dealt with by someone who has the people's trust.

Negotiating or signing any peace accord will definitely involve the questions of sovereignty and national security, Tsai said. "If these two questions cannot be properly addressed, a peace accord will harm the country."
Tsai said the government's handling of issues such as sovereignty, the economy, the public's livelihood and food safety indicates that Ma's administration "is not resolute and lacks ability."
She urged the general public to participate in the Oct. 25 rally to express their discontent with the government.

The opposition has accused Ma of sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty by adopting a "modus vivendi" approach that advocates a "diplomatic truce" with China and introducing a series of cross-strait liberalization measures.

These measures include launching nonstop cross-strait charter flights on weekends, opening up Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, allowing cross-strait currency trading, and raising the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent to 60 percent of their net worth.
The opposition is also unsatisfied with what it alleges is the Ma administration's failure to take a tough stance toward China in dealing with the issue of melamine-tainted food imported from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Politics will be absent from upcoming SEF-ARATS talks: MAC

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official ruled out Sunday the possibility of top negotiators from across the Taiwan Strait talking about the prospects of signing a peace accord between Taiwan and China, during their upcoming meeting in Taipei.

"It has been decided that no political issues will be raised during the upcoming meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based quasi-official intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), or among members of their respective organizations," said Fu Don-cheng, a MAC vice chairman.
Fu made the statement to the media after speaking at a workshop organized by Minchuan University in Taipei City.
The workshop, held at the National Taiwan University Alumni Association building, focused on the development of cross-strait relations and the implications of Chen Yunlin's planned visit to Taiwan.
Chen Yunlin and his group are expected to visit Taiwan at the end of this month or in early November for the SEF-ARATS meeting

The scheduled Chiang-Chen meeting will be a follow-up to a landmark meeting in Beijing between the two in mid-June during which both sides reached an agreement on weekend cross-strait charter flights and the expansion of the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

President Ma Ying-jeou said recently during an interview with India and Global Affairs, an English-language strategic and academic periodical in India, that he will try his utmost to achieve the goal of signing a peace accord with Beijing within his tenure to improve cross-strait relations.
Ma said he will also seek to strengthen Taiwan's bilateral ties with Japan and the United States to enhance peace and stability in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese sponsored senior center opens in Panama
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/19/08 18:46:29 (By Ramon Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A senior citizens center built with a fund of US$200,000 provided by Simply Help, a foundation formed by Taiwanese expatriates in the United States, opened in Panama Saturday with a grand ceremony.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Panamanian first lady Vivian Fernandez de Torrijos expressed her gratitude to the foundation and the Embassy of the Republic of China in Panama for their help with the construction of the center, which has been named Hogar de San Antonio.

Tina Bow, founder of the California-based foundation, said the construction project was initiated last January after the foundation discovered during a visit to Panama that there was a severe shortage of senior nursing homes in the country.

Almost at the same time, Panamanian Archbishop Jose Dimas Cedeno expressed the wish to donate to the government a plot of land belonging to his church in Los Santos City in Las Tablas Province and asked that the land be used for the well- being of the public, Bow related.
Bow attributed the completion of the project partly to the donation of US$200,000 by Lee Chin-fu, a member of the Simply Help foundation.

The senior center, occupying an area of 9,000 square meters, is equipped with a kitchen, fitness rooms and suites. It currently has the capacity to accommodate 30 elderly people and so far there are five already in place.

Bow said only the first stage of the project has been completed and she called for Taiwanese expatriates and businessmen in the Central American country to continue making donations to help with the next phase of the work so that the center would be able to accommodate more senior citizens.

The archbishop described the accomplishment as a "miracle," while the first lady echoed his view saying that the inauguration of the center helped to realize the dream of many elderly people to have a place to live for the rest of their lives.

Mrs. Torrijios said that the then-ROC ambassador to Panama, Hou Ping-fu, told her that the foundation had originally planned to donate the US$200,000 to purchase computers for impoverished people in Panama or to build homes for the elderly.
The Panamanian government later decided to use the money to build asenior citizens home, in view of the inadequate care of the elderly in the country's remote and impoverished areas.

During the ceremony, the Simply Help foundation also donated an additional US$65,000 to the senior citizens center, which was accepted by Domingo Dominguez, head of the center, to help fund its expansion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan puppet show impresses audience in Germany
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 18 (CNA) 10/19/08 18:49:31 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Taiyuan Puppet Theater Company, led by puppet master Chen Xi-huang, staged a show at the Folklore Museum in Hamburg, Germany Saturday, drawing a big crowd and the attention of the media, according to a Taiwanese official posted in the city.

Building on the success of its previous performances at an international festival of puppet theaters in Hannover, the troupe on Saturday attracted a number of German parliamentarians, including Hamburg Parliament President Berndt Roder, and several diplomatic officials from Panama, Iceland and India stationed in Hamburg, said Chang Hsiao-nee, head of the Hamburg office of the Taipei Representative Office in Germany.
The Hamburger Abendblatt -- the city's largest newspaper -- and local TV station Hamburg 1 also covered the performance, Chang added.

After the show, the 78-year-old Chen, who has more than 60 years' experience in hand puppetry and the theatrical arts, demonstrated to the audience how to manipulate a puppet so that it combs its hair and blows smoke from its mouth.

The puppet master, who is considered as a "national treasure" in Taiwan also answered questions from members of the audience about the history and evolution of puppetry and posed for photos with them.

At a party after the performance, "a member of the audience made a 90-degree bow to show his reverence for Chen, " according to Chang. The troupe was presented with a medal by the museum in recognition of its impressive performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Producers reportedly investigating contamination of leavening agent
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/08 19:17:05 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Hebei Province-based chemical company that exported a melamine-tainted baking ingredient to Taiwan said Sunday that it has begun investigating how the leavening agent came to be contaminated with the toxic industrial chemical.

A sales manager of the Xinji Huaer Chemical Co. in Xinji township of Hebei Province's Shijiazhuang City, identified as Ding Qinyan, was summoned to the Xinji town hall Sunday afternoon to brief "the people upstairs" on the matter, according to a Huaer staff member.

The shock wave reached Huaer Saturday after Taiwan's Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) convened a news conference earlier in the day, saying that ammonium bicarbonate imported by Taiwan's Sesoda Corp. from Xinji Huaer Chemical Co. and the Fuzhou City-based Yaolong Chemical Industry Group, was found to be tainted with melamine.

Deputy DOH Minister Cheng Shou-hsia said at the news conference that the melamine content in the ammonium bicarbonate, used as leavening agent in the food industry, was as high as 70 parts per million (ppm) to 300 ppm.
Cheng said the DOH has halted the distribution of the tainted product around Taiwan and will soon seize all ammonium bicarbonate imported from the Chinese company.
The DOH has also passed this information on to the World Health Organization's International Food Safety Authorities Network, Cheng added.

The DOH announced Friday night a ban on all imports of ammonium bicarbonate from China, adding it to the list of food imports from China already banned -- milk powder, creamers and vegetable-based proteins.

Meanwhile, the DOH also alerted the local health and food safety authorities in the 12 Taiwanese cities and counties where the tainted leavening agent had been distributed, and ordered a thorough investigation and seizure of the product.

Ammonium bicarbonate is listed as a legal food additive in the Standard Regulating Scope and Application of Food Additives, Cheng said, adding that it is commonly used to lighten and soften bread, cookies, biscuits, cream puffs and Chinese fried bread sticks.
"Although it is allowed as an additive in food products, adding harmful substances to it is prohibited," Cheng stressed.

"Melamine is not a food additive, so we have no way of knowing in what products it will show up," he said, adding that instituting controls at the food production source is the most important food safety measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF-ARATS talks will not compromise Taiwan's sovereignty: MAC

TEXT.P: The second round of negotiations between the intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will proceed on an equal footing and with no compromise of Taiwan's sovereignty, a senior official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Sunday.

Fu Don-cheng, a MAC vice chairman, made the remarks at a workshop held by Minchuan University to discuss the implications of an upcoming meeting in Taipei between Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , and his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung.

Fu said that the meeting symbolizes the equal status of the two sides, with Taiwan and China both facing up to the political reality that the other exists and adopting a non-negating attitude on the issue.
On this basis, he emphasized, Taiwan's national dignity and security "will not be damaged" during the meeting.
The meeting will also mark a new era of pragmatic cross-strait negotiations, Fu added.
The talks will ensure the functioning of institutional negotiation mechanisms between the both sides, which is important in light of the enhanced two-way exchanges in many spheres, he said.
Any disputes that occur during cross-strait exchanges can be better addressed within such a framework, Fu said.

He further expressed the view that the normalization of relations between the two sides will enhance the prospects of cross-strait peace, which in turn would contribute to regional security and stability.

In their scheduled talks in Taipei in late October or early November, Chiang and Chen are expected to discuss issues that would include the establishment of direct cargo charter flights and shipping links, expansion of weekend passenger charter flights and food security.

However, Chen's visit has given rise to concerns in some quarters, with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and pro-independence groups planning a demonstration Oct. 25 to protest against President Ma Ying-jeou's China policies and what they called the government's poor performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president vows not to steal the show at Oct.25 protest

TEXT.P: Responding to the controversy over his planned appearance at an anti-China protest march to be held by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , former President Chen Shui-bian promised Sunday that he will not give any speeches at the rally and will fully adhere to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's directives on the matter.

Although his plan to take part in the DPP-sponsored demonstration Oct. 25 in Taipei has drawn objections from some participants, Chen gave the organizers the assurance that he will not steal the show or try to shift the focus of the protest by making any speeches at the event.
Chen made the comments while addressing a meeting in Taipei with his supporters from his home county of Tainan in southern Taiwan.

Two opposition parties -- the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) as well as several pro-Taiwan independence groups have decided to jointly organize the protest to demonstrate their anger over harmful substandard food imports from China and President Ma Ying-jeou's China-leaning policies, ahead of a visit to Taiwan in a few weeks by China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

The former president's decision to join the Oct. 25 anti-China protest march has met with opposition because he and his family members are being investigated on suspicion of corruption and money-laundering while he was in office.
Tsai said earlier the same day that all opinions will be considered before a decision is made on whether Chen should attend the protest.

"Chen's attendance is still being arranged and the opinions of the party's senior members and supporters will be taken into account, " Tsai told a news conference that was also attended by several senior DPP members such as former Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and TSU Secretary-General Lin Jih-jia.
Lin was opposed to Chen's appearance in the protest march, while Yao argued that the former president's participation is unlikely to blur the focus of the protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3.5%-limit on share prices decline to remain valid until Oct.24

TEXT.P: The measure to restrict share prices from falling more than 3.5 percent during a single trading session on the local stock exchange will remain in place until Oct. 24, the Finance Supervisory Commission (FSC) announced Sunday.

In an effort to mitigate volatility on the local bourse amid the current global financial crisis, the FSC announced a decision last Sunday to halve local share prices' daily drop limit -- from 7 percent to 3.5 percent -- for one week starting Oct. 13.

The measure was to have expired Oct. 17. As the global stock markets remained highly volatile over the past week, the FSC said Friday it would decide Sunday whether to extend the 3.5 percent floor limit for another week.

Lee Chi-hsien, director-general of the Securities and Futures Bureau under the FSC, told CNA Sunday that if no major events occur in the coming week and if the New York Stock Exchange stops fluctuating drastically and gradually stabilizes, the temporary limit-down trimming measure will not be extended again.
Local shares normally are not allowed to rise or fall by more than 7 percent in any trading session. The 7 percent limit up has remained unchanged amid the current financial volatility.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP delays nomination of candidates for mayoral elections

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has decided to postpone its nomination of candidates for next year's local government elections, from late October to November, to deal with the impact of an imminent visit to Taiwan by a Beijing official, a DPP official said Sunday.

Su Jia-chyuan, a former DPP lawmaker and former interior minister in the previous DPP administration, made the remarks in his capacity as head of the party's strategic task force responsible for the city and county chief elections slated for late next year.

"The DPP has decided to postpone the nomination of the first batch of its candidates for the elections in view of the upcoming visit by Chen Yunlin, and will set a date, depending on the consequences of Chen's visit," Su said.
Chen is president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and serves as China's top liaison with Taiwan.

He is expected to visit Taiwan in late October or early November for talks with his Taiwanese counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin- kung -- in a second round of negotiations on two-way exchanges as a follow-up to their historic first meeting in June in Beijing.

This time around, the DPP will field its candidates for the 2009 local government chief elections through internal consultations instead of a primary vote within the party, in a bid to maximize its chances of victory in the polls.

The main opposition party is trying hard to regain it footing at the local government level as a first step toward recapturing the central government, after its humiliating defeat in the presidential election in March this year.

The DPP and several pro-independence groups will stage a protest march Oct. 25 in Taipei in a concerted move to voice their anger against China and what they called pro-China policies adopted by the administration of President Ma Ying- jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shin Kong Mitsukoshi supports breastfeeding in public

TEXT.P: Shin Kong Mitsukoshi, the largest department store chain in Taiwan, announced Sunday that four of its stores have established a breastfeeding area for mothers who wish to nurse their babies.
The announcement was made at a news conference organized by the Breastfeeding Association of Taiwan as part of efforts to promote breastfeeding in public places.

In support of the drive, Shin Kong Mitsukoshi said that mothers are welcome to breastfeed their babies at public areas inside the designated four stores. It has also instructed its employees to render any necessary assistance and avoid disturbing women who are breastfeeding their babies in its stores.

During the news conference, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hsu Shao-ping urged the Department of Health (DOH) to draft a bill that would give mothers the legal right to breastfeed their babies in public places, and submit the draft to the Legislative Yuan for review.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tien Chiu-chin also called on the government to formulate a policy to prevent dismissal of and discrimination against breastfeeding women in the workplace. Currently, it is very difficult for many women to return to work while they are still breastfeeding, Tien added.

Citing an incident that occurred three years ago when a woman who was breastfeeing her baby was expelled from the Taipei Story House, an arts exhibition hall in the city, Chen Yi-chun, director of the association, said that since then the group has been pushing for the passage of legislation to protect the right of women to breastfeed in public.

In central and southern Taiwan, it is more common to see women breastfeeding their babies in public, as people in these areas generally take that right for granted, compared with those in northern Taiwan, a DOH official, Huang Wei-kang, said, citing a recent survey.

A breastfeeding mother, Pan Juo-lin, said that it is normal for a mother to feed her baby whenever he is hungry, adding that the government should create a more friendly environment for breastfeeding mothers and babies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor visits Hong Kong to woo tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 19 (CNA) 10/19/08 22:29:23 (By Lo Kin-fai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu arrived in Hong Kong Sunday to promote tourism in the southern Taiwan port city.
Chen, a heavyweight of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , was accorded courteous treatment upon her arrival at Hong Kong International Airports.
It was Chen's first visit to Hong Kong since she assumed mayorship of Taiwan's second largest city after capital Taipei.
Chen will host a news conference Monday to introduce Kaohsiung's major tourist attractions and a number of preferential tour packages especially designed to cater to Hong Kong holidaymakers' needs.

The Kaohsiung city government is collaborating with China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, and the Kaohsiung Visitors Association in organizing the promotional program to attract Hong Kong tourists.

Chen's visit was seen as yet another sign of improvements in Taiwan's relations with Hong Kong and Beijing as well. When the DPP was in power, key figures from the pro-independence party were barred from visiting Hong Kong because of its soured ties with Beijing over sovereignty issues.

With cross-strait tension subsiding following the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration in May, the Hong Kong government has decided to open an official representative office in Taipei soon.
Chen will conclude her Hong Kong visit and return to Kaohsiung Monday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200-plus tons of tainted baking ingredient from China already sold

TEXT.P: More than 200 tons of a melamine-tainted leavening agent imported from China had been sold in the domestic market, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.

DOH spokesman Wang Je-chau told a news conference that Taiwan's Sesoda Corp. imported a total of 469 tons of ammonium bicarbonate from two Chinese companies which were found to contain melamine, an industrial chemical banned from being used as a food additive, and more than 200 tons of the baking ingredient had been sold to local distributors.

According to information provided by Sesoda Corp., only a small portion of the melamine-tainted leavening agent had been sold to food processors. But Wang said the DOH is still checking the verity of Sesoda's information.

One of the food processors who had purchased ammonium bicarbonate from Sesoda was identified as Hunya Foods Co.. Wang said Hunya was known to have bought 700 kilograms of the tainted leavening agent and 670 kg. had been used and the remaining 30 kg had been sealed off.

Moreover, Wang went on, it has become clear that the melamine Kaohsiung health officials found in two flavors of Hunya-made biscuits last week could be traced to the tainted baking ingredient supplied by Sesoda Corp. All of those substandard baked products have since been pulled from store shelves, Wang added.

Ammonium bicarbonate is listed as a legal food additive in the Standard Regulating Scope and Application of Food Additives. It is commonly used to lighten and soften bread, cookies, biscuits, cream puffs and Chinese fried bread sticks.

The DOH has banned imports of ammonium bicarbonate from China after laboratory tests showed that the leavening agent imported by Sesoda from China contained 70 to 300 parts per million (ppm) of melamine, a chemical used to make plastics or fertilizers that should never be used as a food additive.
Taiwan already banned milk powder, non-dairy creamers and vegetable-based proteins from China after samples of food products using those ingredients were found to contain traces of melamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC defends decision to continue restricting share prices decline

TEXT.P: The measure to restrict share prices from falling more than 3.5 percent during a single trading session on the local stock exchange has proved to be effective to stabilize investor confidence amid the global financial turmoil, a senior official said Sunday.

Finance Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Gordon Chen made the remarks after the Executive Yuan decided earlier in the day that the temporary limit-down trimming measure for share prices will remain in place until Oct. 24.

In an effort to mitigate volatility on the local bourse amid the global financial crisis, the FSC announced a decision last Sunday to halve local share prices' daily drop limit -- from 7 percent to 3.5 percent -- for one week starting Oct. 13.

The measure was to have expired Oct. 17. As the global stock markets remained highly volatile over the past week, the FSC said Friday it would decide Sunday whether to extend the 3.5 percent floor limit for another week.
Over the past week, Chen said, the weighted Taiwan stock index dropped only 3.3 percent, far smaller than declines in neighboring Asian countries.

For instance, Singapore stocks plunged 10.6 percent between Oct.10 and Oct.17, compared to South Korea's 8.82 percent decline, Hong Kong's 8.7 percent fall, Shanghai's 6.9 percent slide and Japan's 5.06 percent dive.
"The figures indicated that our limit-down trimming measure has helped stabilize investor confidence and maintain market stability," Chen explained.
As the U.S. stock exchanges remained highly volatile last Friday, Chen said the Executive Yuan decided to extend the trimming measures for another week.
When the one-week extension expires Oct. 24, Chen said, the FSC has been authorized to decide on its own whether to stop or continue such a discretionary measure.
As to whether the measure had adversely affected stock trading volume or market fluidity, Chen said the FSC will keep a close watch on market developments.

Meanwhile, Lee Chi-hsien, director-general of the Securities and Futures Bureau under the FSC, told CNA Sunday that if no major events occur in the coming week and if the New York Stock Exchange stops fluctuating drastically and gradually stabilizes, the temporary limit-down trimming measure will not be extended again.
Local shares normally are not allowed to rise or fall by more than 7 percent in any trading session. The 7 percent limit up has remained unchanged amid the current financial volatility.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS deputy head arrives to attend cross-strait academic seminar

TEXT.P: The deputy head of China's quasi-official intermediary body with Taiwan arrived in the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan Sunday to attend a symposium on mass communications aimed at promoting bilateral academic exchanges.

Zhang Mingqing, vice chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , maintained a low profile and refrained from answering sensitive issues posed by local journalists after his arrival at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan. He just said this is his third visit to the island.

Zhang, accompanied by more than 20 Chinese media experts and scholars, will attend the 2008 Cross-Strait Academic Symposium on Mass Communications and Image Arts to be held Monday at Tainan National University of the Arts (TNUA) located in Guantian township, Tainan County.

According to TNUA sources, Zhang is visiting Taiwan in his capacity as dean of Xiamen University's School of Journalism and Communication in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian which lies close to Taiwan.
Zhang and his delegation were greeted only by representatives of TNUA and a local travel association. No Taiwanese officials showed up to greet them at the airport.

Airport security was tight as pro-independence activists had threatened to demonstrate against China's exports of substandard dairy products and food ingredients to Taiwan and its relentless suppression of Taiwan in the international community.
But pro-independence activists didn't show up at the airport. They instead gathered in front of a hotel in Tainan City where Zhang and other Chinese visitors will stay during their visit.

To shield the Chinese guests from encountering the protesters, organizers of the symposium arranged for them to change their itinerary several times after their arrival. The protesters, led by Wang Ting-yu, a Tainan city councilor, suspended their demonstration after failing to see their protest target at several of the delegation's originally picked stopover venues.

Wang said they will not be daunted by Sunday's failure to meet Zhang and that they will continue to try to let Zhang understand during his stay that Taiwan is not part of China and that the Beijing leadership should apologize for Chinese companies' sales of tainted or substandard foodstuffs, such as melamine-tainted milk powder, to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA Daybook for Oct. 20, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

Chen, a heavyweight of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , was accorded courteous treatment upon her arrival at Hong Kong International Airports.
It was Chen's first visit to Hong Kong since she assumed mayorship of Taiwan's second largest city after capital Taipei.
Chen will host a news conference Monday to introduce Kaohsiung's major tourist attractions and a number of preferential tour packages especially designed to cater to Hong Kong holidaymakers' needs.

The Kaohsiung city government is collaborating with China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, and the Kaohsiung Visitors Association in organizing the promotional program to attract Hong Kong tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan jet fighter disappears

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Air Force indigenous defense fighter (IDF) based in Chinchuankang Airbase in Taichung county disappeared from radar screens while on a training mission over the Taiwan Strait Monday morning, according to local TV cable station TVBS.
