Over the past week, Chen said, the weighted Taiwan stock index dropped only 3.3 percent, far smaller than declines in neighboring Asian countries.

For instance, Singapore stocks plunged 10.6 percent between Oct.10 and Oct.17, compared to South Korea's 8.82 percent decline, Hong Kong's 8.7 percent fall, Shanghai's 6.9 percent slide and Japan's 5.06 percent dive.
"The figures indicated that our limit-down trimming measure has helped stabilize investor confidence and maintain market stability," Chen explained.
As the U.S. stock exchanges remained highly volatile last Friday, Chen said the Executive Yuan decided to extend the trimming measures for another week.
When the one-week extension expires Oct. 24, Chen said, the FSC has been authorized to decide on its own whether to stop or continue such a discretionary measure.
As to whether the measure had adversely affected stock trading volume or market fluidity, Chen said the FSC will keep a close watch on market developments.

Meanwhile, Lee Chi-hsien, director-general of the Securities and Futures Bureau under the FSC, told CNA Sunday that if no major events occur in the coming week and if the New York Stock Exchange stops fluctuating drastically and gradually stabilizes, the temporary limit-down trimming measure will not be extended again.
Local shares normally are not allowed to rise or fall by more than 7 percent in any trading session. The 7 percent limit up has remained unchanged amid the current financial volatility.

DOC.HEADLINE: People protest ARATS deputy head's visit

TEXT.P: A group of activists from the southern city of Tainan lodged a protest Monday against a visit to Taiwan by Zhang Mingqing, vice president of Beijing's intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), who arrived in the country the day before to attend an academic symposium.

Scores of people, led by Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu, demonstrated at Tainan National University of the Arts (TNUA) located in Guantian township, Tainan County, where Zhang and 20 other Chinese media experts and scholars are attending the 2008 Cross-Strait Academic Symposium on Mass Communications and Image Arts organized by TNUA.

The pro-independence Tainan protesters demanded that Zhang apologize to the Taiwan people for China's export to Taiwan of substandard dairy products and food ingredients that were tainted with the toxic industrial chemical melamine.
They demanded that the ARATS deputy head either meet with them to apologize and hear the voices of the Taiwanese people, or cancel all his activities in Taiwan.
"We'll follow him and protest wherever he goes during his stay in Taiwan if our demands are not met," the activists threatened.

In response to the protesters, TNUA chief secretary Tseng Hsu-cheng said that Zhang is attending the symposium in his capacity as dean of Xiamen University's School of Journalism and Communication in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian, and the seminar, a purely academic gathering, has nothing to do with politics.
After discussions, the TNUA authorities decided to cancel all the public appearances by Zhang in Taiwan in the next two days.
The other Chinese experts and scholars, however, maintained their schedule at the symposium. They are slated to make field trips to other universities in southern Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200-plus tons of tainted baking ingredient from China already sold

TEXT.P: More than 200 tons of a melamine-tainted leavening agent imported from China had been sold in the domestic market, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.

DOH spokesman Wang Je-chau told a news conference that Taiwan's Sesoda Corp. imported a total of 469 tons of ammonium bicarbonate from two Chinese companies which were found to contain melamine, an industrial chemical banned from being used as a food additive, and more than 200 tons of the baking ingredient had been sold to local distributors.

According to information provided by Sesoda Corp., only a small portion of the melamine-tainted leavening agent had been sold to food processors. But Wang said the DOH is still checking the verity of Sesoda's information.

One of the food processors who had purchased ammonium bicarbonate from Sesoda was identified as Hunya Foods Co.. Wang said Hunya was known to have bought 700 kilograms of the tainted leavening agent and 670 kg. had been used and the remaining 30 kg had been sealed off.

Moreover, Wang went on, it has become clear that the melamine Kaohsiung health officials found in two flavors of Hunya-made biscuits last week could be traced to the tainted baking ingredient supplied by Sesoda Corp. All of those substandard baked products have since been pulled from store shelves, Wang added.

Ammonium bicarbonate is listed as a legal food additive in the Standard Regulating Scope and Application of Food Additives. It is commonly used to lighten and soften bread, cookies, biscuits, cream puffs and Chinese fried bread sticks.

The DOH has banned imports of ammonium bicarbonate from China after laboratory tests showed that the leavening agent imported by Sesoda from China contained 70 to 300 parts per million (ppm) of melamine, a chemical used to make plastics or fertilizers that should never be used as a food additive.
Taiwan already banned milk powder, non-dairy creamers and vegetable-based proteins from China after samples of food products using those ingredients were found to contain traces of melamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 20, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino- Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Delegation of Hong Kong businessmen to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Dr. Leung Chun Ying, convener of the Non-official Members of the Executive Council of Hong Kong and chairman of the Hong Kong Coalition of Professional Services (HKCPS) said Monday that a delegation of Hong Kong businessmen will make a historic visit to Taiwan on Oct. 22.

It will be the first large-scale business delegation to visit Taiwan in recent years, according to Leung. The delegation will comprise of members from the Coalition of Professional Services, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, Hong Kong Trade Development Council and the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre.
The delegation is scheduled to call on Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council, Leung said.
Noting that the warm-up of cross strait ties has brought about new opportunities, he suggested that Hong Kong should not stand idly by and waste the chance to advance business and trade with Taiwan.

Leung also said that Hong Kong will be able to provide professional services in the areas of trade and arbitration for Taiwan businessmen. Through cooperation, a win-win situation may be achieved for both Hong Kong and Taiwan, he added.

Officially established Nov. 22, 2001, the HKCPS is a non-profit organization founded to promote the common interests of Hong Kong professionals, and to promote and gain recognition for the contribution of those professionals to the social and economic development of Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan jet fighter disappears (update-1)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Air Force indigenous defense fighter (IDF) stationed at Chingchuankang Airbase in Taichung county disappeared from radar screens while on a training mission over the island county of Penghu in the Taiwan Strait Monday morning.

The IDF, No. 1615, took off from Chingchuangkang at 9: 15 for a bombing training mission over Penghu and disappeared 30 minutes later near Huayu island in Penghu county, according to an Air Force statement.
The two officers onboard the plane, pilot Capt. Gu Zhih-bing and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian-ting, were unaccounted for, according to the statement.
An air and sea search conducted by two Air Force planes and five boats from the Penghu Coast Guard office began immediately after the plane went missing, the statement disclosed.

The IDFs, developed by Taiwan in the 1990s with assistance from the U.S., is one of four types of second generation Air Force jet fighters stationed mainly on airbases in the western areas of the country, across the Taiwan Strait from China, because of their quick takeoff time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taipei Zoo holds postcard design contest to welcome pandas

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo said Monday that it will hold a "panda conservation" postcard design competition as part of activities to mark the upcoming arrival of two giant pandas presented by Beijing as a gift to Taiwan.
Entries, which will be accepted between Nov. 1-14, should encompass the theme of conservation of pandas and Taiwan's indigenous animals, according to the zoo.

Jason Yeh, director of the zoo, said that the competition is being held with the aim of helping the Taiwan public better understand "the significance of conservation" which underlies the pandas' arrival.

"The time contestants spend on designing their postcards and promoting the concept of conservation through their creations will allow them to gain a better sense of the mutual dependence of humans and animals," Yeh explained.
The contest has been divided into three categories -- for middle school students, high school students, and members of the general public -- with contestants restricted to one entry, the zoo said.
Entries will be based on several criteria, with 50 percent of the overall score awarded for creativity, 20 percent for aesthetics, 20 percent for composition, and 10 percent for artistic layout.

Interested persons can send their entries by post to Chen Hsiang-yin at No. 30 XinGuang Road, section 2, Taipei City, or visit the Taipei Zoo's Web site at www.zoo.gov.tw for more information on the contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manila envoy seeks clemency for Filipina sentenced to death in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei has appealed to Taiwan judicial authorities clemency for a Philippine woman who was sentenced to death by the Kaohsiung District Court Oct. 1.

The court sentenced Nemencia Armia to death for the stabbing her job broker to death in September last year. Armia was caught on closed circuit television disposing of the broker's body in a garbage bag. She also made several withdrawals to the tune of over NT$660,000 (US$20,200) using the broker's ATM card.

Antonio Basilio, managing director of the MECO, the Philippines' de facto embassy in Taiwan, in a statement expressed his regret over the ruling and the hope that the courts would overturn the ruling or reduce the sentence.

The Philippine representative said that his office has regularly dispatched personnel to visit Armia in jail to comfort her and has cooperated closely with her lawyers to ensure that her legal rights are protected.
Armia's lawyers have filed an appeal with the Taiwan High Court.
The MECO is also helping Armia's family members to obtain visas to visit Taiwan, and her brother and sister-in-law are slated to arrive sometime this week, according tothe statement.
The Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs had said in Manila earlier that because of the government's one-China policy, it had no way of assisting in the case.

The Philippines, a predominantly Catholic country, abolished the death penalty in 2006. Its representative offices have actively assisted Philippine nationals on death row in countries around the world, with President Gloria Arroyo even stepping in on several occasions to appeal for clemency.
The efforts have born fruit, with many Philippine citizens on death row having their sentences reduced.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food company recalls products containing China-made leavening agent

TEXT.P: Hunya Foods Co. announced Friday that it has recalled all its products containing the leavening agent ammonium bicarbonate imported by Sesoda Corp.

The announcement came after the Department of Health (DOH) revealed at a news conference Saturday that ammonium bicarbonate imported by Sesoda from the Hebei Province-based Huaer Chemical Co. was found to be tainted with melamine.
The department said that it had stopped the distribution of the contaminated product around Taiwan and would soon seize all ammonium bicarbonate imported from the mainland Chinese company.
Kuo Cheng-er, a spokesman for Hunya, one of Taiwan's leading food manufacturers, said that the products have been removed from store shelves and will be destroyed in line with the DOH's decision.

Noting that ammonium bicarbonate has been used in the baked goods industry in Taiwan for years with the DOH's consent, Kuo said that this case is "not a problem related to the ingredient itself, but instead the source of the ingredient."

Kuo said that as melamine -- an industrial chemical used in the manufacture of plastic products -- is much more expensive than ammonium bicarbonate, it would not make sense for food manufacturers to add it as a way of illicitly cutting costs.

The ammonium bicarbonate in question was therefore probably inadvertently contaminated during the production process, he said, adding that the Chinese company is now investigating the source of the contamination.

Kuo said that following the recall, Hunya will revise the formula for making the products in question before restocking store shelves, in order to allay people's concerns. This is expected to cost the company between NT$20 million (US$615,000) and NT$30 million (per year), he added.
The spokesman stressed that the company views food safety as being of the highest importance, noting that it has received FGMP, HACCP, ISO9001 and ISO14001 certifications from the government.

According to Kuo, the unfolding melamine scandal has led regulators, businesses and the general public to re-evaluate food safety testing and standards, and he expressed the hope that this will be a positive development for the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November rose 19 points to close at 4,823, with 85,947 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December gained 14 points to finish at 4,790, with 496 contracts traded, while March futures fell 11 points to close at 4,730, with 189 contract transactions.
June futures decreased 11 points to finish at 4,723, with 42 contract transactions, while September futures fell 71 points to close at 4,555, with 67 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,804 for November, 4,776 for December, 4,741 for March, 4,734 for June, and 4,626 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 28.56 points to finish at 4,931.84, on turnover of NT$41.03 billion (US$1.26 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

November TE futures rose 2.2 points to close at 199.1, with 3,969 contracts traded, while December TE futures increased 1.9 points to finish at 197.05, with 21 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
November TF futures lost 15.6 points to finish at 515.2, with 3,121 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures lost 15.2 points to finish at 512, with 19 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS deputy head heckled by protesters but keeps his cool

TEXT.P: The visiting deputy head of China's quasi-official negotiating body with Taiwan described angry, banner-waving protesters who told him to "get lost" and "go back to China on Monday as greeting him in an "especially warm way."

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), has been followed and heckled by pro-independence activists since his arrival at Kaohsiung International Airport Sunday evening.
Zhang, attending an academic seminar at the Guantian, Tainan County-based Tainan National University of the Arts (TNUA) , was met with protests in front of the university Monday morning.
He also faced two National Cheng Kung University students at the seminar, who shouted at him, "Taiwan is independent and not a part of China" and displayed a related banner.
The two were then removed from the seminar by security personnel.

Before delivering his speech to the seminar in his capacity as dean of the School of Journalism and Communication of Xiamen University in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian, Zhang described the protesters as "especially warm people" who "greeted me in an especially warm way."
"I learned a lot from these people, " Zhang said of the protesters, who were led by Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Asked by the Central News Agency how he felt about the demonstrators "following him like a shadow and protesting" wherever he goes during his stay in Taiwan, Zhang replied, "Tagore once said, 'I may disagree with your views, but I will lay down my life to defend your right to express your views, " referring to early 20th century Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore.
In the wake of the protests, university authorities decided Monday to cancel all the public appearances by Zhang in Taiwan over the next two days.
Although Zhang was in Taiwan for the seminar, he was inevitably asked about the planned and much-talked about visit to Taiwan by ARATS President Chen Yunlin.
Zhang said negotiations are still needed between ARATS and its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , to work out a concrete timetable for the visit.

Pundits and opposition politicians have opposed Chen's planned visit or expanded contacts with China in part because of a recent food safety scare over melamine- contaminated milk powder and other ingredients imported from China.
They have also strongly criticized President Ma Ying-jeou's overtures to China as not being reciprocated by Beijing and as compromising Taiwan's sovereignty.
Meanwhile, Zhang spoke at Monday's seminar on the development of the media and mass communications industry across the Taiwan Strait.

He said that after the two sides relaxed restrictions on cross-strait exchanges, it has become easier for Taiwan journalists to cover news in China, but the Chinese reporters have faced "restrictions after restrictions" to do so.
"There was an absence of equality across the strait in terms of journalism environment of the two sides," he claimed.

Zhang is heading a delegation of 20 Chinese media experts and academics in Tainan to attend the 2008 Cross-Strait Academic Symposium on Mass Communications and Image Arts organized by TNUA slated for Monday and Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: New landmark hotel planned for Fishermen's Wharf in Danshuei

TEXT.P: An international tourist hotel will be built at Fishermen's Wharf in Danshuei to further enhance the appeal of the port, which is already one of the top tourist attractions in Taiwan.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei signed a contract with Lih Pao Construction Co., Ltd. Chairman Wu Pao-tien Monday under which the conglomerate will construct and manage the hotel on a BOT (build-operate-transfer) basis.

Lih Pao will invest some NT$2 billion (US$61.54 million) in the property, to be called the Danshuei Fishermen's Wharf Hotel, which will feature 169 rooms, a banquet hall, several restaurants, a 100-meter tall tower and a street of arts shops, Wu said.
"If the group gets the building licenses next year, the Danshuei Fishermen's Wharf Hotel is expected to be completed by 2012 at the earliest," Wu said.

According to Chen Chih-hung, a Lih Pao Construction manager, the tourist tower, which carries a price tag of NT$100 million on its own, will provide tourists with a 360-degree panorama view of the Danshuei Port and the nearby sea and mountains.
The Danshuei Fishermen's Wharf Hotel will likely be the highest end property operated by Lih Pao, with room prices starting from NT$7,000 per night, Chen said.
Lih Pao currently runs a chain of five hotels around Taiwan through affiliate Fullon Hotels & Resorts, with another seven properties planned for completion over the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to help people request compensation from China: Vice Premier

TEXT.P: The government will help those who have suffered health problems because of tainted food imports from China request compensation from Beijing through the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung pledged Monday.

Chiu said at a committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan that the Cabinet-level Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) will make the appeals for compensation through the SEF and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

"At present, the Consumer Protection Commission has received 80 inquiries and is handling three cases of people with kidney stones (caused by China-made tainted dairy products) for compensation from China, " Chiu noted.
He said the SEF may address the issue of compensation with ARATS President Chen Yunlin, during his upcoming visit to Taiwan.
In recent weeks, the toxic chemical melamine has been found in imported dairy products, creamers and vegetable-based proteins from China, causing a general panic among consumers.

Over the weekend, the DOH announced that leavening agent ammonium bicarbonate imported from China, used to soften and lighten doughs, was also found to contain 70 to 300 ppm (parts per million) of melamine.

The agency indicated that a local company had imported a total of 469 tons of the contaminated ammonium bicarbonate since the beginning of the year, of which local health authorities have seized about 210 tons.

The DOH is still investigating the whereabouts of the remaining ammonium bicarbonate, and didn't rule out the possibility that some of it has already been consumed as part of processed foods, such as cookies and breads.
Chiu tried to ease consumers' worries, however, saying, "ammonium bicarbonate is a legal food additive, and the quantity added into foods is very small."

According to DOH Deputy Minister Cheng Shou-hsia, a number of products examined thus far that might contain the contaminated leavening agent, including 80 kinds of cookies and 23 breads, have tested negative for melamine.

Only two fried dough sticks examined by the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH were found to contain a very small amount of the toxic chemical, and Cheng said the sale of tainted fried dough sticks had been prohibited.
Cheng added that his agency has demanded local health bureaus to help bakeries and restaurants use other leavening agents, such as baking powder and baking soda, instead of ammonium bicarbonate.
"We still do not know how melamine came to be in the leavening agent. We have demanded China to investigate, " said Cheng at a press conference.

The DOH announced a ban on all imports of ammonium bicarbonate from China last week, adding it to list of food imports from China already banned, including milk powder, creamers and vegetable-based proteins.

With the recent spate of imported Chinese food ingredients testing positive for melamine, some legislators have advocated having the countries of origin of all of a processed food's ingredients listed on its package.

Chiu said he will refer the suggestion to the Ministry of Economic Affairs, but noted that under current world trade regulations, most products are only required to label the country where the finished product was made.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head welcomes ex-president's plan to join protest march

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that former President Chen Shui-bien is welcome to join its protest march on Oct. 25, after Chen promised not to make any public speeches, according to DPP sources.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, in a meeting with DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming and Huang Ching-lin, chief of the DPP Taipei City chapter office, reportedly did not object to Chen taking part in the demonstration.

According to sources who were also present at the meeting, Tsai said that she welcomes everyone's participation in the upcoming protest, whether they are from the "pan-blue alliance" of the ruling Kuomintang and its ally the People's First Party, or from any other party.

The meeting was held after Ker and Huang paid a call on Chen earlier in the day amid concerns among some party members that the former president, who is being investigated on suspicion of corruption while in office, could prove to be a distraction from the main purpose of the protest.

Ker, the chief convener of the DPP legislative caucus, said he and Huang talked with Chen about the upcoming demonstration, which will be held under the theme "Anti-Black Heart; Protecting Taiwan's Sovereignty."

Chen, who is embroiled in a money-laundering scandal, said publicly the previous day that he wants to join the protest against China's shipment of substandard goods to Taiwan and its suppression of Taiwan in the international community.
Ker said Chen will join the demonstration at the Dinghao commercial circle on the Zhongxiao East Road, from where he will walk toward Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

Chen assured Ker and Huang that he will not stray from the parade, neither will he give any public addresses or talk about his current problems. Chen said he will follow the organizers' guidelines and will protest against President Ma Ying-jeou and China, Ker related.
Ker said he believes Chen's participation may serve to encourage more people to join the protest march.

The Oct. 25 protest was jointly organized by the opposition parties, including the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and several pro-Taiwan independence groups to demonstrate their anger over harmful substandard food imports from China and what they called President Ma's China-leaning policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90 percent of office workers suffer investment losses: survey

TEXT.P: Almost 90 percent of office workers in Taiwan have lost money in financial markets over the last six months due to the collapse of global share prices, the results of a recent survey indicated.

According to a survey released Monday by 1111 Job Bank, an online employment broker, 60 percent of the respondents held various types of financial investment assets in the past six months, with roughly 89 percent of that number reporting losses.
An average loss of NT$262,000 (US$7,900) was incurred during the period, which amounted to 31 percent of their total investment, the survey found.
Among the types of investments, mutual funds and stocks accounted for the biggest shares, at 42.83 percent and 30.26 percent, respectively.
The poll also showed that some 45 percent of those who suffered losses have shifted to a more conservative investment strategy.

The shrinking of assets among investors is due to the volatile global investment environment aggravated by the recent bankruptcy of major American financial institutions, said Ryan Wu, the operating chief of the job bank.
Meanwhile, 84 percent of office workers said they feel dejected in the face of the financial storm and fear that the business climate might worsen, according to the survey.

Adding to employees' financial woes, salary or bonus cuts were recorded among 26 percent of the respondents, while another 19 percent face possible layoffs and dismissals or have already lost their jobs, the poll showed.
A total of 1,577 valid responses were collected in the Oct. 3-16 survey, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC reports first influenza death this year

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Monday that the first death from influenza this year was reported last week in southern Taiwan, and it urged people at high risk to get free flu vaccines before the end of Nov.
According to CDC Deputy Minister Lin Ting, the patient was a 75-year-old woman who fell ill on Oct. 13 and died three days later of influenza with the complication of pneumonia.
"It is a pity that the woman did not get a free flu shot, " said Lin, noting that the first influenza death occurred this year much earlier than in previous years.
Lin said that the flu epidemic generally begins in October, and peaks around the Christmas holidays, before receding in February.

"Vaccination is still the most efficient way to prevent influenza," said Lin in a telephone interview. He urged people to get inoculated as soon as possible, as it takes two weeks for the vaccine to become effective.

The CDC this year provided 3.2 million free doses of flu vaccine for citizens over the age of 65 years, children between six months and three years old, and first to fourth grade elementary school students.

In addition, residents and workers at nursing homes, patients suffering from rare diseases or injuries, disease prevention and control personnel, workers in the poultry and livestock industries, and animal disease control and prevention personnel are also entitled to receive the vaccine free of cost.
Since Oct. 1 when the free inoculation program began, 1.21 million people have been vaccinated, Lin said.
If there are any doses left over after Nov. 30 when the program expires, they will be made available to other citizens, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.03 to close at NT$32.580.
A total of US$556 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.550 and fluctuated between NT$32.541 and NT$32.600.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares edge lower in light trading

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 28.56 points, or 0.57 percent, to close at the day's high of 4,931.84.

While markets around Asia were generally higher Monday, the local bourse had trouble finding momentum to push it into positive territory. Share prices opened at 4845.31 and fluctuated between 4,931.84 and 4,805.68.

A total of 2.20 billion shares changed hands on relatively weak market turnover of NT$41.03 billion (US$1.26 billion) . Buying interest remained constrained as the government extended its restriction on share prices from falling more than 3.5 percent during a single trading session to Oct. 24.

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp shares moving down the most at 2.1 percent. Cement issues dropped 1.8 percent, financial and insurance stocks lost 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues lost 0.7 percent, construction issues fell 0.6 percent, textile issues and machinery and electronics shares both lost 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares fell 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 863 to 561, with 389 stocks remaining unchanged and 155 fell to their lower limit.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Diplomatic truceis effective: KMT deputy secretary-general

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ability to hold on to at least two of its 23 diplomatic allies before and after President Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration could serve as an indication that hisdiplomatic truce" approach is effective, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) official said Monday.

"As far as we know, the 'diplomatic truce' has been effective, " Chang Jung-kung said.If we continued the old (scorched-earth) diplomatic measure, we would have immediately lost two allies or had to put in more resources (to keep them).

Chang made the remarks in a consultation meeting on the effect of the 'diplomatic truceon promoting international diplomacy from the cross-Taiwan Strait relations prospective, held by Control Yuan members Ger Yeong-kuang and Hung Chao-nan.
Chang contended that based on past experience, with Taiwan's diplomatic and international space continuing to shrink, the diplomatic truce was an approach that needed to be adopted.
Chang would not identify, however, the two allies that he felt were successfully prevented from switching diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China by Ma's government.
It has been widely speculated that Paraguay, Taiwan's only ally in South America, called off its plan to establish formal relations with China, in large part due to Ma's diplomatic truce approach.

Although our highest goals might not be achieved through the results of our negotiations with China, it will still be better than the current situation and win Taiwan more international support, " Chang said.
He cited as examples U.S. President George W. Bush's open praise on July 30, Aug. 7 and Aug. 10 for the improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations between Taiwan and China since Ma took office.
Since assuming the presidency May 20, Ma has pursued amodus vivendidiplomatic strategy, which is trying to set aside Taipei's differences with Beijing to find a mutually beneficial equilibrium.
He has also sought adiplomatic truceto end a longstanding tug-of-war with China over each other's allies and carve out a greater international presence for Taiwan.
The lack of a tangible response to the strategy from Beijing, however, has sparked criticism and suspicions that Ma's diplomatic approach is merely wishful thinking.

Lai I-chung, former director of the Democratic Progressive Party's Department of Chinese Affairs, argued that other than the number of diplomatic allies, relations with countries without diplomatic relations, the level and designation of Taiwan in international organizations, and security cooperation are all important indicators for whether a "diplomatic truce" will work.
He said he was uncertain whether the diplomatic truce was a means to push ahead with cross-strait reconciliation or a result that would emerge only after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reconcile?

If the importance of cross-strait relations were magnified to the extreme, it would greatly hinder the cooperation between Taiwan and other countries in areas that do not involve the two sides of the Taiwan Strait,Lai believed.
In that case, he said, Taiwan would be encouraging countries to evaluate their relations with Taiwan through Taipei's relations with Beijing rather than from a parallel point of view.

Chang Ling-chen, professor emeritus in National Taiwan University's Department of Political Science, said the diplomatic truce was a practical approach that needed to be taken in view of the situation in the real world.

A diplomatic truce can prevent Taiwan's plight from getting worse, Chang said, adding that continuing scorched-earth diplomacy would not serve Taiwan's interests given that Taiwan and China's relative economic and political strength have greatly changed over the years.
This is a strategy that Taiwan has no choice but to take, " she added, suggesting that the country could only negotiate from a relatively weak position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan jet fighter disappears (update-2)

TEXT.P: Debris from an Air Force jet fighter that apparently crashed on a training mission over the island county of Penghu has been collected from waters near an uninhabited islet of the county Monday afternoon, a spokesman for the Chingchuankang Airbase in Taichung said.
The debris, including a safety jacket, a flight helmet and fragments of cockpit seats, were fished out of the sea near Maoyu, or "Cat Islet, " Col. Chang Chao- kui said.
These items have been identified by Air Force personnel as originating from the missing indigenous defense fighter (IDF).

The Air Force said earlier Monday that IDF No. 1615, stationed at Chingchuankang Airbase in Taichung County, disappeared from radar screens while on a training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait Monday morning.

The jet fighter took off from Chingchuangkang at 9: 15 a.m. for a bombing training mission over Penghu and disappeared 30 minutes later near Huayu island in Penghu County, according to an Air Force statement.
The two officers onboard the plane, pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian-ting, have not been unaccounted for, according to the statement.
An extensive air and sea search conducted by Air Force planes and boats from the Penghu Coast Guard office began immediately after the plane went missing, the statement said.
The IDF, developed by Taiwan in the 1980s with assistance from the U.S., is one of four types of second generation Air Force jet fighters.
Taiwan has 130 IDFs, which are stationed mainly on airbases in the western areas of the country, across the Taiwan Strait from China, because of their quick takeoff time.
Monday's apparent accident was the fifth mishap to befell an IDF fighter since the model was introduced to Taiwan's Air Force in 1988.

DOC.HEADLINE: Retired teacher donates life savings to help poor students

TEXT.P: A retired elementary school teacher donated his life savings -- NT$12.16 million (US$372,600) -- Monday to his alma mater, which is also the school where he had taught for 46 years, in hopes of helping students living in poverty.

Tsai Sheng-chih, 81, studied at Gangshan Elementary School in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung county during the Japanese occupation era in 1895-1945. His late wife Chang Heng had also attended the school.
Tsai said the donation was inspired by his beloved wife's spirit of being happy in helping people. Chang passed away on Jan. 16, before the couple's 60th wedding anniversary on Feb. 1.

To accomplish his wife's last wish, Tsai said he donated NT$10.16 million for the school to establish a scholarship for poor students who have excellent academic performance. He also donated another NT$2 million for the school to improve equipment for teaching and to purchase more books.
Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin presented Tsai earlier in the day a certificate to express the county's gratitude for Tsai's good deed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Popular Games to open in Kaohsiung Oct. 25

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Popular Games will open Oct. 25 in Kaohsiung -- the second largest city in Taiwan -- for six days of competition in 24 sports.

The opening ceremony will take place at Kaohsiung Arena, and the guests of honor invited to the occasion will include Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Tai Hsia-ling, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council.

The Taiwan Popular Games will be the first national athletic meet held in Kaohsiung in 13 years and will be seen as a warm-up for the 2009 World Games to be hosted by Kaohsiung July 16-26 next year that are expected to draw 4,600 athletes from some 100 countries.

According to the Kaohsiung City government, the organizer of the event, the sports being contested in the competition will include powerlifting, tug of war, rollerblading, canoe polo, flying disc, fin swimming, water life saving, jujitsu, and petanque.

Kaohsiung Mayor Cheng Chu told reporters that the port city is well-prepared to greet the participants in both athletic meets. She pointed out that Kaohsiung now has a well-developed transportation network, with its mass rapid transit system linked with bus services.

The Taiwan Popular Games is a biennial event. In 1999, the government divided the Taiwan Area Games -- an annual athletic meet that had been held for 25 years -- into the National Games and the Popular Games, each of which would be alternatively held every two years.
The competition categories in the National Games are limited to those at the Asian and Olympic Games, while the Popular Games can include non-Olympic sports and folk athletic contests.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to look into beauty competition's belittling of Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that it is investigating whether Taiwan's representative in the Miss International beauty pageant was belittled by the competition's Japanese organizer.

The Foreign Ministry's representative office in Japan is trying to figure out what happened, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told the Central News Agency. "If there is any unreasonable arrangement or downgrading of Taiwan, the representative office will protest to the organizer and ask for a correction.

According to local daily Liberty Times, Taiwan's representative in the 2008 Miss International Ting Yen-yu was given two sashes, reading "Taiwan" and "Chinese Taipei" by the Japanese organizer and was toldto wear either of them depending on where you are.

The Taiwanese contestant apparently interpreted the move to mean that she could wear the "Taiwan" sash while performing competition-related duties in Japan but would have to wear the "Chinese Taipei" sash during the actual competition being held in Macau.
The candidates from 68 countries are in Tokyo to conduct a series of charity events before competing in the final of Miss International Beauty Pageant 2008 slated to be held in Macau on Nov. 8.
Ting's instructor Chang Ming-chu criticized the organizer for disrespecting the candidate.
The judges will be confused by different sashes as they do not know which country she (Ting) represents,Chang was quoted as saying by the news report.
Also, questioning our candidate this and that is not only discrimination but also a blow to her confidence,she added.
Ting was cited as saying that she will wear the "Taiwan" sash in Macau and see what happens.

The MOFA's Chen said Taiwan's representatives usually use the designation "Chinese Taipei, " "Taiwan" or "Republic of China, " depending on which name Taiwan uses to join the related international organizing body for the event.

Since the Japanese organizer gave Ting the "Taiwan" sash, it means that the organizer agrees to the candidate using "Taiwan," Chen said, adding that the MOFA will fight for the rights of Taiwan's representative in the competition.
The contest organizers do not seem to have a standard used for the country's name.
On their Web site, the 2006 Taiwan representative Liu Tzu-hsuan was listed under the name "Taiwan, " while the 2007 Taiwan representative, Hung Tzu-wei, was listed under the name "Chinese Taipei."

Created in Long Beach, California in 1960, Miss International is the largest beauty pageant in the world next to Miss Universe and Miss World. Since 1972, it has been held in Japan and from that time, Miss International has attained the status of a quasi-national event garnering a reputation as theOlympics of Beauty.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers demand pressure on China over toxic milk powder issue

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday demanded the government seek compensation from China for Taiwanese consumers and companies who fell victim to melamine-tainted Chinese milk products.

The government should ask Chen Yunlin, China's top liaison with Taiwan, to apologize over the issue and pay compensation to Taiwanese victims, on behalf of the Chinese government, during his imminent visit to Taiwan, DPP legislators said.

Chen, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is expected to visit Taiwan in late October or early November. He will be the highest ranking Chinese envoy to visit the island since the two sides began a dialogue in 1992.

Legislators argued that if Chen refuses to apologize or agree to pay compensation, President Ma Ying-jeou should raise the demand directly to the Chinese authorities, now that Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao has reportedly acknowledged in a recent interview with an international media outlet that the Chinese government has a responsibility to deal with the negative effects of melamine-tainted milk powder, which has been sold overseas, including to Taiwan.
The group of DPP lawmakers, led by the party's caucus whip Lai Ching-te, issued the request at a Legislative Yuan news conference.

According to DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin, more than 200 brands of questionable foodstuff and other products containing melamine were removed from local store shelves after the Chinese toxic milk powder scandal broke out in mid-September in Taiwan. The incident has caused a combined loss of more than NT$ 4 billion (US$123 million) to Taiwanese companies and consumers, she said.
"The large amounts of harmful Chinese food imports really make Taiwan's consumers gravely concerned over their health," she added.
DPP lawmaker Chen Chi-yu contended that the government should put stronger pressure on the Chinese government to force it to take responsibility for compensation.
Chen Chi-yu asked the DPP central to consider launching a larger protest if Chen Yunlin fails to issue a public apology while in Taiwan.

The DPP, in conjunction with the Taiwan Solidarity Union and several pro- independence groups, have decided to stage a protest march in Taipei on Oct. 25, ahead of Chen Yunlin's visit. They have vowed to gather 1 million protesters.

Chen Yunlin is slated to hold talks to further two-way exchanges with his Taiwanese counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung -- as a follow-up to their landmark meeting in June in Beijing.

In response to implications arising from China's toxic milk powder and Chen Yunlin's visit to Taiwan, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said while giving a report earlier Monday at a legislative committee that the SEF is authorized to ask China for compensation through negotiations with the ARATS during Chen's visit.

Chiu, who doubles as Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) chairman, said the CPC has so far received three complaints filed by Taiwanese people who appeared to have suffered kidney stones after they drank melamine-tainted Chinese milk powder.
The CPC's hotline "1950" has to date received a total of 1,639 inquiries about melamine-tainted food, CPC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor touts city in Hong Kong
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 20 (CNA) 10/20/08 21:14:01 (By Manday Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu promoted tourism in the southern Taiwan port city Monday at a news conference in Hong Kong co-sponsored by the Kaohsiung city government and Taiwan's largest carrier China Airlines (CAL).

"Kaohsiung City aims to attract more tourists from Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan through a series of especially designed activities for 2008 -- the year designated by the city to promote tourism," Chen told the news conference.

The city government is collaborating with CAL and the Kaohsiung Visitors Association in hosting the promotional program to attract tourists from Hong Kong, effective immediately through the end of the year.
Chen expressed the hope that more Hong Kong people could take time to visit Kaohsiung in depth and enjoy its delicious food and historic and cultural sites.
She said Hong Kong people are particularly welcome to spend weekends in Kaohsiung City due to the relatively short distance between the two cities.
Currently, Hong Kong is the second largest source of tourists to Taiwan, she noted.
At the head of a 22-member group of city officials and private business representatives, Chen was visiting Hong Kong in her capacity as mayor for the first time.
She praised Hong Kong's impressive progress and transformation in recent years and called for more frequent two-way exchanges.
The Kaohsiung mayor was slated to return to Taiwan later Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's endorsement in Tainan County race sparks backlash

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's endorsement of a former aide to represent the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the race for Tainan County magistrate next year could disrupt the party's nominating process and performance at the polls, a DPP lawmaker said Monday.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, DPP lawmaker Lee Chun-yee, who has his sights set on running for the post, expressed his regret that Chen publicly backed former Presidential Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen in the race.

Lee said the former president's endorsement would split party opinion and result in chaos in its fielding of a candidate, and he urged party chairwoman, Tsai Ing-wen, to address the matter to quell the shockwaves created inside the party by the former president's announcement.

Lee wondered if the party really wanted new blood or if it wanted Tan Sun Chen, who served as Tainan County magistrate from 1993-2001, and he said Tsai needed to move quickly and bring the party together to unify support and prevent it from disintegrating.

Meanwhile, another DPP legislator, Yeh Yi-jin, who is also likely to seek the party's nomination, said that everyone is entitled to support their ideal candidate, and that Tainan County voters would ultimately decide the issue.
She said the party should only take into consideration who has the best chance for electoral success in the process and should have its own methods of determining the final nominee.
The former president threw his backing behind Tan Sun Chen at a Tainan County association meeting Saturday, saying that his former aide was leading in a private poll conducted by the DPP.
DPP officials denied, however, that the party had conducted such a poll.
Tainan County, where Chen Shui-bian is from, has long been considered a DPP stronghold.
Five people have currently expressed their interest in running for county magistrate, including the incumbent vice county magistrate, and one former lawmaker as well as Lee, Yeh, and Tan Sun Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon pays US$600 million to buy life insurance unit of ING

TEXT.P: Fubon Financial Holding Co. announced Monday it will buy ING Group's Taiwan life insurance unit in a deal worth NT$19.5 billion (US$600 million), the biggest merger in the local life insurance industry in five years.

The acquisition, expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2009, will increase Fubon's customer base by 2.2 million customers, or more than a third, to 8.7 million and boost its total life insurance assets to NT$1 trillion, propelling the group's ranking in the local insurance market to fourth.
The purchase will also vault Fubon Financial past Mega Financial Holdings to make it Taiwan's second-largest financial holding company in terms of assets, trailing only Cathay Financial Holdings.
ING said it will hold a 5 percent Fubon stake and the company's bonds once the deal is concluded.
The merger will also solidify the total premium and first-year premium market share of Fubon's life insurance unit.
Fubon's total premium market share will nearly double to 13.9 percent from the 7 percent it held at the end of September to rise to second from fourth.
Its share of first-year premium will grow to 17.8 percent from the current 13 percent, solidifying its hold on second place in the category.
Cathay Life Insurance topped the industry with 23.3 percent of Taiwan's total premium market and 25.2 percent of the first-year premium market.

Fubon Financial Vice Chairman Richard Tsai said Fubon and ING's sales channels and product structure complement each other. Fubon's line, he said, is more weighted toward interest-sensitive products while ING's line favors traditional and investment-sensitive policies.
The deal, subject to the approval from Fubon shareholders and regulators, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2009.

Fubon Financial President Victor Kung said Fubon had talked to ING about a possible deal for two years before signing the accord Saturday. The length of the discussions, he said, was a key factor in the "very reasonable" price.
On a day when most other financial and insurance stocks nosedived, Fubon Financial shares rose Monday, finishing 5.7 percent higher to close at NT$19.05 per share.

Financial analysts said that in addition to Fubon Financial, ING also contacted Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and Mega Holdings in a bid to strike a deal. They said Fubon was able to clinch the deal at a bargain price because of its abundant cash reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei, Idaho sign joint statement to bolster relations

TEXT.P: The signing of a joint statement between a Taipei business organization and the state government of Idaho of the United States not only signify but also renew the close relations between the two countries, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Monday.

The joint statement just signed serves as a milestone in the mutually beneficial relations between Idaho and Taiwan and sets the course of our future bilateral cooperation, Ou said at a dinner reception he hosted for the Idaho Governor C. L. "Butch" Otter.
Otter led a 28-member economic and trade delegation consisting of Idaho state government officials and representatives from Idaho businesses and academic institutions to Taiwan from Oct. 19-22.

Ou added that the passage this year by Idaho's Senate and House of Representatives of a resolution in support of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreementdemonstrated the deep friendship between the two of us.
Speaking at the same occasion, Otter said he was honored to revisit Taiwan and witness the progress of a partnership that he helped bring about a decade ago.
Ten years ago, I sat at the desk and had the opportunity to sign thebirth certificateof a great friendship and great relations that continue yet today,Otter said.

We should remember that all that's happened in the past is only the promise for tomorrow, he said. "You are all witnesses to the renewal of the vows, partnership and trade agreements and continuing success.

Signed by Huang Chun-kuo, secretary-general of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei and representatives from Idaho's Department of Agriculture and Commerce, the joint statement aims to strengthen mutual understanding and bilateral cooperation in the areas of trade, culture and education between Taiwan and the western state.

While close relations have existed between Idaho and Taiwan since 1984, Idaho's exports to Taiwan totaled US$304 million in 2007, an increase of 76.8 percent over the previous year, making Taiwan Idaho's sixth largest export market.

Whereas Taiwan has become the primary market for Idaho's high-tech goods, foods, wheat, wood and building materials, Idaho has become a top export destination for Taiwan's electronic equipment and machinery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan Tsou people to celebrate Fona Festival from Nov. 1

TEXT.P: Chiayi County's chief promoted on Monday a unique festival prepared by the indigenous Tsou tribe from Alishan that marks the spirit of "fona, " meaning "bean of life" in their language.

Chen Ming-wen, serving as the spokesman for the festival, invited people to join the two-week event -- to begin on Nov. 1 -- in which they will have chance to witness the Tsou's cultural essence by attending a traditional wedding ceremony.
Introducing the fona bean, Chen said the vine normally blossoms and bears bean pods every November.
While serving as one of tribe's traditional food ingredients, the fona bean is also regarded as a symbol of vitality and fertility because it can grow well on barren soil and in adverse conditions.

Thus, the plant has served as an important offering during the Tsou's traditional wedding ceremonies to help the younger generation grow up with the same strong vitality as that of the bean, Chen said.
The Fona Festival will take place on Nov. 1-16 at the Leyie Tsou tribe cultural park, which is located at the 61.5-kilometer mark on the Alishan Highway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team receives IAVI funding for HIV vaccine research

TEXT.P: A research team led by the head of Taiwan's top research institute has received a cash award from the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI) for its innovation in the development of a defense against the disease, academic sources said Monday.

The IAVI, a global organization working to speed up the development of a vaccine against HIV/AIDS, will offer more than NT$19.92 million (US$612,923) in financial aid over three years beginning in 2008 for the AIDS vaccine research team headed by Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong, the sources said.

"This is very practical and morale-boosting encouragement, " Wong said, adding that the aid from the prominent organization is expected to inspire more attention and engagement in the development of an AIDS vaccine.
Wang, a world-renowned biochemist, said he is convinced that over the next few years substantial progress will be made in AIDS vaccine research and development.
According to Wong, the IAVI funding will be paid in six installments or once every six months. "The installment for the second half of 2008, totaling NT$3.32 million has been received," he added.

Wong's team has devised a new compound proven effective in stopping HIV- infection in animals at an early stage, raising hopes it can also be used to develop effective anti HIV-medications and the long-awaited HIV vaccine for humans.

HIV or human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, is capable of evading the body's virus detection system by locking itself to the virus detecting dendritic cell. The goal of Wong's project was to inhibit the HIV from doing so.
Wong's team has created a new substance called "glycodendron" in accordance with the chemical characteristics of the HIV-oligomannose glycan combination.

The new substance has been proven effective in preventing HIV from latching onto dentritic cells and prompted the immune system to produce antibodies destructive to the virus during experiments on rodents, Wong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yuanta Financial Holdings being probed over suspected bribery

TEXT.P: An anti-corruption unit is investigating whether the US$180,000 in cash given by two board directors of Yuanta Financial Holding Co. to former first lady Wu Shu- jen in 2005 as a gift for her son's wedding was in fact a bribe, a spokesman for the unit said Monday.

Prosecutor Chen Yun-nan, director of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said members of the division were still trying to find out whether the money, given by Yuanta President Victor Ma and Vice President Michael Ma in the form of traveler's checks in June 2005, was related to the Yuanta Group's being allowed to take over the management of Fuhwa Financial Holding Co. at about the same time.
Fuhwa Financial subsequently merged with the Yuanta Group and became Yuanta Financial Holdings.

A day earlier, prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division raided Yuanta Financial Holdings and summoned the Ma brothers and their financial adviser Lin Ming-yi for questioning in connection with the money-laundering case involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

The trio were asked to explain why the US$180,000 had been remitted to several overseas accounts of Tsai Ming-tse, Wu Shu-jen's special assistant. They were released after more than four hours of interrogation.
Tsai, who has been held in custody as a potential defendant in the money laundering case, had apparently admitted to prosecutors earlier that the US$180,000 from Yuanta was for Wu.
Yen Ching-chang, chairman of Yuanta Financial Holdings, told reporters Monday that the money came from the Ma brothers' personal accounts and had nothing to do with the Yuanta Group.

According to Yen, although the former president claimed publicly in June 2005 that his family would not accept any cash gifts from well-wishers for their son's wedding, the Ma brothers, after consulting with "well-acquainted people," still decided to send US$180,000 as a gift.

In addition to Yuanta Group, the prosecutors have also searched other financial institutions in the past few days, including Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and Mega Financial Holding Co. in connection with their investigation of the former first family's money laundering case.

DOC.HEADLINE: President said to declare: no war in Taiwan Strait in next 4 years

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will tell the nation's top brass Tuesday that there will be no war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the next four years, informed sources in the Presidential Office disclosed Monday.

The sources, who declined to be identified, said that during an address before top military leaders at National Defense University, the president will make major policy statements regarding national defense policy, weapons procurement, and relations between Taiwan and China.

"The president will declare that there will be no war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the next four years," the sources said, adding that based on this premise, Ma will encourage the military leaders to use their expertise to help the government formulate new defense strategies.
Ma is identified with a policy to promote peace between Taiwan and China, which considers Taiwan a renegade province.
In an interview published in the Oct. 18 issue of the India and Global Affairs quarterly, Ma said he would like to sign a peace agreement with China during his term in office.
He promised, however, that he would not consider such an accord if China refuses to destroy its nearly 1,000 missiles targeting at Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fertilizer price reduction under consideration: COA chief

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said Monday that local urea prices might be reduced thanks to steep falls in oil prices in the world market.

"Although the government promised that fertilizer prices would be maintained through the end of the year after it imposed a price hike in late May, the COA will study the possibility of adjusting prices downward as a result of continued declines in international oil prices, " Chen said at a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee.
According to Chen, a COA fertilizer price screening panel and the state-run Taiwan Fertilizer Co., will jointly work on the feasibilities of a price reduction based on future oil price trends.
"The panel might devise a 'long-term pricing mechanism' to transparently reflect fertilizer production costs and take better care of farmers," he added.
Urea is being targeted because it is the only chemical fertilizer derived from petroleum, he noted.

The COA minister announced on May 28 a price hike for a 40-kilogram bag of urea, lifting its price from NT$360-NT$370 per bag to over NT$800 a bag from May 30 to reflect the soaring costs of raw materials.

As part of the government's efforts to help minimize the financial burden of the hike on farmers, it pushed Taiwan Fertilizer to absorb nearly 70 percent of the price increase, leaving farmers to pay NT$520-NT$530 per bag.
The price hike stirred up widespread discontent among farmers.

Chen Wen-teh, director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, confirmed later the same day that the COA panel will assess a possible cut in fertilizer prices in conjunction with Taiwan Fertilizer officials, although it will take some time for the declining prices of crude oil to have an impact on petrochemical products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan thrashes out two-stage plan to promote employment

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan thrashed out a two-stage plan Monday to promote employment in government agencies in a bid to help the jobless tide over difficulties.

"To actively supply job opportunities is a right direction, and all government agencies have to think seriously about how to hire additional hands, " said Chen Yung-feng, chief secretary of the Government Information Office, citing Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

Convening his first meeting with the heads of government agencies on measures to promote employment, the premier instructed that the measures be made in two stages, with the first stage dedicated to the hiring of short-term work in November and December and the second stage to hire people for all of next year.

The premier asked all agencies to submit a list of the number of people they can hire and the required funds they would need to the Council for Economic Planning and Development for an overall review before the Executive Yuan holds a meeting for discussion next week.
Chen said the jobs offered by the government could include serving as guides in scenic spots.
The Ministry of National Defense has also agreed to accelerate the pace of draftees entering military service to make sure they are not idle too long.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration agency sets criteria to deter bogus marriages

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Monday that it has developed criteria to help it determine whether foreigners have committed decency offenses during their stay in Taiwan to crack down on marriages of convenience.
NIA officials said that those who are deemed to have committed the offenses will be expelled from Taiwan and barred from re-entry from three to five years.

Those who have been found guilty by a court of violating decency regulations under the criminal code or have been ruled by the police or court to have committed decency offenses under the Social Order Maintenance Act will be expelled.

The officials said that it set the criteria, which took effect Oct. 3, in the hope of deterring marriages of convenience and prevent foreigners from using "marriage" to enter Taiwan and engage in "indecent" jobs.
Those who serve as hostesses in pubs, restaurants or other public places and receive payment for their services will also be deemed to have committed decency offenses.
The officials expressed the hope that through the enforcement of the criteria, the number of marriages of convenience will be sharply reduced.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDF jet fighters to undergo special inspection

TEXT.P: The locally developed Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) will undergo special inspections after one of them apparently crashed on a training mission over the island county of Penghu Monday, Air Force authorities said in a statement.
The special inspections will be completed in the shortest period of time, said the statement, issued by Chingchuankang Airbase in the central county of Taichung.

Debris from IDF jet fighter No. 1615, including a safety jacket, a flight helmet, a seat and a piece of the fighter's fuselage, was recovered from waters near Maoyu, or Cat Islet -- an uninhabited isle of the Penghu island group, the statement said.

Air Force Commanding General Peng Sheng-chu rushed to Chingchuankang Airbase Monday afternoon to console the family of the two pilots aboard the plane, the statement said, adding that Peng assured their family members that the military will make every possible effort to search for the pilots.
"We'll never give up so long as there is a glimmer of hope," Peng was quoted as having said.

The airbase has set up a special project control center responsible for the search and rescue mission, the statement said, addign that many naval and coast guard ships and aerial rescue forces have been mobilized for the mission. The all-out search was still going on as of press time.
The IDF fighter disappeared from radar screens while on a training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait Monday morning.
The jet fighter took off from Chingchuangkang at 9: 15 a.m. for a bombing training mission and disappeared 30 minutes later near Huayu island in Penghu County, Air Force authorities said.
The two officers onboard the plane, pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian-ting, have since remained unaccounted for.
IDFs, developed by Taiwan in the 1980s with assistance from the U.S., together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the mainstay of Taiwan's second generation Air Force fleet.
Taiwan has 130 IDFs, which are stationed mainly on airbases in the western areas of the country, across the Taiwan Strait from China, because of their quick takeoff time.

Monday's apparent accident was the fifth mishap to befall an IDF fighter since the model was introduced to Taiwan's Air Force in 1988. According to military authorities, IDFs have the best availability in the country's air force fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA Daybook for Oct. 21, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday, moving up 57.01 points at 4,988.85 on a turnover of NT$3.55 billion (US$108.96 million).
The weighted price index lost 28.56 points, or 0.57 percent, to close at 4,931.84 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.587 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.007 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 21, or the 23rd ay of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
2001: Asia-Pacific leaders pledge to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit in Shanghai.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Fubon pays US$600 million to buy life insurance unit of ING

TEXT.P: Fubon Financial Holding Co. announced Monday it will buy ING Group's Taiwan life insurance unit in a deal worth NT$19.5 billion (US$600 million), the biggest merger in the local life insurance industry in five years.

The acquisition, expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2009, will increase Fubon's customer base by 2.2 million customers, or more than a third, to 8.7 million and boost its total life insurance assets to NT$1 trillion, propelling the group's ranking in the local insurance market to fourth.
The purchase will also vault Fubon Financial past Mega Financial Holdings to make it Taiwan's second-largest financial holding company in terms of assets, trailing only Cathay Financial Holdings.
ING said it will hold a 5 percent Fubon stake and the company's bonds once the deal is concluded.
The merger will also solidify the total premium and first-year premium market share of Fubon's life insurance unit.
Fubon's total premium market share will nearly double to 13.9 percent from the 7 percent it held at the end of September to rise to second from fourth.
Its share of first-year premium will grow to 17.8 percent from the current 13 percent, solidifying its hold on second place in the category.
Cathay Life Insurance topped the industry with 23.3 percent of Taiwan's total premium market and 25.2 percent of the first-year premium market.

Fubon Financial Vice Chairman Richard Tsai said Fubon and ING's sales channels and product structure complement each other. Fubon's line, he said, is more weighted toward interest-sensitive products while ING's line favors traditional and investment-sensitive policies.
The deal, subject to the approval from Fubon shareholders and regulators, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2009.

Fubon Financial President Victor Kung said Fubon had talked to ING about a possible deal for two years before signing the accord Saturday. The length of the discussions, he said, was a key factor in the "very reasonable" price.
On a day when most other financial and insurance stocks nosedived, Fubon Financial shares rose Monday, finishing 5.7 percent higher to close at NT$19.05 per share.

Financial analysts said that in addition to Fubon Financial, ING also contacted Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and Mega Holdings in a bid to strike a deal. They said Fubon was able to clinch the deal at a bargain price because of its abundant cash reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDF jet fighters to undergo special inspection
