TEXT.P: The locally developed Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) will undergo special inspections after one of them apparently crashed on a training mission over the island county of Penghu Monday, Air Force authorities said in a statement.
The special inspections will be completed in the shortest period of time, said the statement, issued by Chingchuankang Airbase in the central county of Taichung.

Debris from IDF jet fighter No. 1615, including a safety jacket, a flight helmet, a seat and a piece of the fighter's fuselage, was recovered from waters near Maoyu, or Cat Islet -- an uninhabited isle of the Penghu island group, the statement said.

Air Force Commanding General Peng Sheng-chu rushed to Chingchuankang Airbase Monday afternoon to console the family of the two pilots aboard the plane, the statement said, adding that Peng assured their family members that the military will make every possible effort to search for the pilots.
"We'll never give up so long as there is a glimmer of hope," Peng was quoted as having said.

The airbase has set up a special project control center responsible for the search and rescue mission, the statement said, addign that many naval and coast guard ships and aerial rescue forces have been mobilized for the mission. The all-out search was still going on as of press time.
The IDF fighter disappeared from radar screens while on a training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait Monday morning.
The jet fighter took off from Chingchuangkang at 9: 15 a.m. for a bombing training mission and disappeared 30 minutes later near Huayu island in Penghu County, Air Force authorities said.
The two officers onboard the plane, pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian-ting, have since remained unaccounted for.
IDFs, developed by Taiwan in the 1980s with assistance from the U.S., together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the mainstay of Taiwan's second generation Air Force fleet.
Taiwan has 130 IDFs, which are stationed mainly on airbases in the western areas of the country, across the Taiwan Strait from China, because of their quick takeoff time.

Monday's apparent accident was the fifth mishap to befall an IDF fighter since the model was introduced to Taiwan's Air Force in 1988. According to military authorities, IDFs have the best availability in the country's air force fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fertilizer price reduction under consideration: COA chief

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said Monday that local urea prices might be reduced thanks to steep falls in oil prices in the world market.

"Although the government promised that fertilizer prices would be maintained through the end of the year after it imposed a price hike in late May, the COA will study the possibility of adjusting prices downward as a result of continued declines in international oil prices, " Chen said at a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee.
According to Chen, a COA fertilizer price screening panel and the state-run Taiwan Fertilizer Co., will jointly work on the feasibilities of a price reduction based on future oil price trends.
"The panel might devise a 'long-term pricing mechanism' to transparently reflect fertilizer production costs and take better care of farmers," he added.
Urea is being targeted because it is the only chemical fertilizer derived from petroleum, he noted.

The COA minister announced on May 28 a price hike for a 40-kilogram bag of urea, lifting its price from NT$360-NT$370 per bag to over NT$800 a bag from May 30 to reflect the soaring costs of raw materials.

As part of the government's efforts to help minimize the financial burden of the hike on farmers, it pushed Taiwan Fertilizer to absorb nearly 70 percent of the price increase, leaving farmers to pay NT$520-NT$530 per bag.
The price hike stirred up widespread discontent among farmers.

Chen Wen-teh, director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, confirmed later the same day that the COA panel will assess a possible cut in fertilizer prices in conjunction with Taiwan Fertilizer officials, although it will take some time for the declining prices of crude oil to have an impact on petrochemical products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yuanta Financial Holdings being probed over suspected bribery

TEXT.P: An anti-corruption unit is investigating whether the US$180,000 in cash given by two board directors of Yuanta Financial Holding Co. to former first lady Wu Shu- jen in 2005 as a gift for her son's wedding was in fact a bribe, a spokesman for the unit said Monday.

Prosecutor Chen Yun-nan, director of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said members of the division were still trying to find out whether the money, given by Yuanta President Victor Ma and Vice President Michael Ma in the form of traveler's checks in June 2005, was related to the Yuanta Group's being allowed to take over the management of Fuhwa Financial Holding Co. at about the same time.
Fuhwa Financial subsequently merged with the Yuanta Group and became Yuanta Financial Holdings.

A day earlier, prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division raided Yuanta Financial Holdings and summoned the Ma brothers and their financial adviser Lin Ming-yi for questioning in connection with the money-laundering case involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

The trio were asked to explain why the US$180,000 had been remitted to several overseas accounts of Tsai Ming-tse, Wu Shu-jen's special assistant. They were released after more than four hours of interrogation.
Tsai, who has been held in custody as a potential defendant in the money laundering case, had apparently admitted to prosecutors earlier that the US$180,000 from Yuanta was for Wu.
Yen Ching-chang, chairman of Yuanta Financial Holdings, told reporters Monday that the money came from the Ma brothers' personal accounts and had nothing to do with the Yuanta Group.

According to Yen, although the former president claimed publicly in June 2005 that his family would not accept any cash gifts from well-wishers for their son's wedding, the Ma brothers, after consulting with "well-acquainted people," still decided to send US$180,000 as a gift.

In addition to Yuanta Group, the prosecutors have also searched other financial institutions in the past few days, including Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. and Mega Financial Holding Co. in connection with their investigation of the former first family's money laundering case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team receives IAVI funding for HIV vaccine research

TEXT.P: A research team led by the head of Taiwan's top research institute has received a cash award from the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI) for its innovation in the development of a defense against the disease, academic sources said Monday.

The IAVI, a global organization working to speed up the development of a vaccine against HIV/AIDS, will offer more than NT$19.92 million (US$612,923) in financial aid over three years beginning in 2008 for the AIDS vaccine research team headed by Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong, the sources said.

"This is very practical and morale-boosting encouragement, " Wong said, adding that the aid from the prominent organization is expected to inspire more attention and engagement in the development of an AIDS vaccine.
Wang, a world-renowned biochemist, said he is convinced that over the next few years substantial progress will be made in AIDS vaccine research and development.
According to Wong, the IAVI funding will be paid in six installments or once every six months. "The installment for the second half of 2008, totaling NT$3.32 million has been received," he added.

Wong's team has devised a new compound proven effective in stopping HIV- infection in animals at an early stage, raising hopes it can also be used to develop effective anti HIV-medications and the long-awaited HIV vaccine for humans.

HIV or human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, is capable of evading the body's virus detection system by locking itself to the virus detecting dendritic cell. The goal of Wong's project was to inhibit the HIV from doing so.
Wong's team has created a new substance called "glycodendron" in accordance with the chemical characteristics of the HIV-oligomannose glycan combination.

The new substance has been proven effective in preventing HIV from latching onto dentritic cells and prompted the immune system to produce antibodies destructive to the virus during experiments on rodents, Wong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan thrashes out two-stage plan to promote employment

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan thrashed out a two-stage plan Monday to promote employment in government agencies in a bid to help the jobless tide over difficulties.

"To actively supply job opportunities is a right direction, and all government agencies have to think seriously about how to hire additional hands, " said Chen Yung-feng, chief secretary of the Government Information Office, citing Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

Convening his first meeting with the heads of government agencies on measures to promote employment, the premier instructed that the measures be made in two stages, with the first stage dedicated to the hiring of short-term work in November and December and the second stage to hire people for all of next year.

The premier asked all agencies to submit a list of the number of people they can hire and the required funds they would need to the Council for Economic Planning and Development for an overall review before the Executive Yuan holds a meeting for discussion next week.
Chen said the jobs offered by the government could include serving as guides in scenic spots.
The Ministry of National Defense has also agreed to accelerate the pace of draftees entering military service to make sure they are not idle too long.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% oppose street protests during top China liaison's visit: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of respondents to a recent government opinion survey said they oppose the opposition parties' plan to take to the streets during a top Chinese liaison officer's visit to Taiwan, a Cabinet-level agency said Tuesday.

The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said it conducted the telephone poll Oct. 14-15 to explore local people's views on an upcoming visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan in his capacity as president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
According to the poll results, 73 percent of the respondents were aware that Chen will visit Taiwan in late October or early November.
Up to 54 percent said they did not think that Chen should defer his travel plans because of the recent controversy over melamine contaminated food products from China.
Meanwhile, 67 percent said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should sign a cooperative agreement during Chen's visit to ensure quality and safety of food imports from China.

Asked about their opinions on the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) plan to stage a large-scale march and mass rallies during Chen's stay to protest China's exports of melamine-tainted milk powder and food ingredients to Taiwan, 59 percent said they disagreed with such a plan, while 26 percent gave a thumbs-up to the proposal.
The poll also found that 49 percent of the respondents believe Chen's visit would bring about more benefits than detriments, but 22 percent said they think otherwise.

In addition, 50 percent said they believe Chen's visit would contribute to further development of cross-strait trade and economic cooperation; 50 percent said Chen's visit would help Chinese people better understand Taiwan's democratic experience; and nearly 47 percent said Chen's visit could help ease cross-strait confrontation on diplomatic and military fronts.
A total of 1,085 valid replies were collected in the survey among randomly chosen adults residing in various parts of the country, with a margin of error of 2.9 percentage points.

Although Chen's itinerary has yet to be announced, the DPP and major pro- independence groups have decided to mount a march in downtown Taipei this Saturday to voice their anger at China's shipment of substandard and even toxic foodstuffs to Taiwan and what they call the current Kuomintang government's China-leaning policy and its inability to revitalize the bearish stock market and slumping economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: No war in Taiwan Strait in next four years: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reassured the nation Tuesday of his strong commitment to preserving peace across the Taiwan Strait during his term, even as he pledged to beef up the country's defenses against mainland China's military threats.

"There will be no war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the next four years. I put forth this vision during my presidential campaign and am more confident about it now," Ma said in an address to a group of top military leaders at National Defense University in Taoyuan County.
Ma, however, stressed that Taiwan must maintain a strong defense even if the country has no desire to go to war with the mainland.

He noted that developments taking place across the strait over the past several decades, such as the removal of a ban on China visits by Taiwanese, the inflows of Taiwanese investment into China, and the economic boom in China, have led to a structural change in relations between the two sides, while China's rapid military buildup and modernization has also posed a serious threat to Taiwan's security.
According to Ma, to Taiwan, China is both an opportunity and a threat. As the president, it is his responsibility to maximize the opportunity and minimize the threat, he said.
"And the military's responsibility is to deter any risky actions across the strait through strong preparedness," Ma said.

Renewing his promise to maintain Taiwan's status quo under the framework of the Republic of China Constitution, Ma said his administration is working toward that goal by following the strategy of "no unification, no independence and no use of force" to try to create a peaceful cross-strait environment.

The president said the work of the military is to protect the ROC Constitution, safeguard the ROC sovereignty and maintain the dignity and peaceful life of the country's 23 million people. In order to preserve cross-strait and regional peace, Taiwan needs to maintain a strong defense capability, he added.

Citing the famous quote "Let us never negotiate out of fear, but let us never fear to negotiate" by the late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, Ma argued that the stronger Taiwan becomes the more leverage it will enjoy in cross-strait negotiations, because maintaining a military balance is necessary to achieve peace.
The president pledged that to attain that goal, his administration will earmark sufficient funds over the next few years to meet the country's defense needs.

Ma has put forth a "modus vivendi" approach for dealing with China, which advocates a cross-strait "truce" in the diplomatic arena and the opening of cross-strait negotiations for the establishment of a peace accord.
Ma, however, has requested that China remove its more than 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan as the precondition to such peace talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official's visit will harm Taiwan: DPP chair

TEXT.P: An upcoming visit to Taiwan by a top Chinese liaison official Chen Yunlin will greatly harm Taiwan, the chairperson of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said Monday.

Speaking at press conference, Tsai Ing-wen stressed that by agreeing to the visit, President Ma Ying-jeou was severely undermining the rights of the Taiwan people and greatly damaging Taiwan's status as a sovereign nation.

Chen, who is president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), is slated to make a historic visit to Taiwan late this month or early next month to meet with his Taiwan counterpart Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung. It will be the second meeting between ARATS and SEF heads since Ma took office in May. The two will discuss a wide range of issues, including direct cross-strait flights, shipping and trade.

Tsai said that the official stance of the Democratic Progressive Party on the issue of cross-strait relations is that Taiwan is a sovereign state. She stressed that the rights of the Taiwan people should be protected at all costs and should not be undermined in any way by Ma, nor should the country's sovereignty be compromised for economic gains.
Tsai also disparaged Ma's statement that there will be no war across the Taiwan Strait in the next four year, saying that the president "would surrender Taiwan to Beijing without a fight."

At second press conference, Tsai also took Ma to task over his comment that Taiwan is a region rather than a sovereign nation, calling it a ridiculous statement that indicates Ma is an incompetent president.
The Democratic Progressive Party has organized a rally to be held on Oct. 25 in protest against Ma administration's handling of cross strait affairs.
The DPP said it is not ruling out the possibility of camping out overnight to prolong the rally, but did not give any details on how long the camp could last.
Tsai and other DPP members did not disclose what form of a protest they planned for the arrival of Chen in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS vice chief falls while being mobbed by protestors

TEXT.P: Visiting Vice President Zhang Mingqing of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was allegedly knocked over by pro-Taiwan independence supporters while on a private tour to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City Tuesday.

Zhang was chased and pushed by a group of protesters mobilized by a Tainan city councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and was allegedly knocked over by some emotional demonstrators while he was at the temple.
Dozens of pro-Taiwan independence supporters chanted anti-China slogans, shouted at Zhang and asked him to "get lost and roll back to China" when they saw Zhang walking alone.

One protester jumped onto the top of Zhang's car and fiercely stamped on it as Zhang was being escorted from the site by a local official and a tour guide. Zhang was later taken to a hotel in Tainan City to rest.
The Tainan area is a stronghold of pro-independence forces.
None of the protesters were detained by local police authorities, but Tainan City Police Bureau Commissioner Chen Fu-hsiang has ordered an investigation into the case.
The incident might have a negative impact on a planned visit to Taiwan by ARATS President Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, slated for late October or early November, analysts said

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in an academic seminar at the Tainan National University of the Arts in Tainan County in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November fell four points to close at 4,817, with 117,258 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 12 points to finish at 4,775, with 544 contracts traded, while March futures moved up one point to close at 4,731, with 70 contract transactions.
June futures decreased 15 points to finish at 4,706, with 35 contract transactions, while September futures were down 12 points to close at 4,543, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,821 for November, 4,787 for December, 4,730 for March, 4,721 for June and 4,555 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index moved up 10.88 points to finish at 4,942.72, on turnover of NT$67.41 billion (US$2.06 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

November TE futures fell 2.3 points to close at 196.65, with 5,004 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 1.6 points to finish at 195.45, with 46 contract transactions. September TE futures declined 6.6 points to end at 188, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

November TF futures rose four points to close at 519.8, with 4,032 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were up three points to finish at 515, with 26 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military school plans to begin accepting females next year

TEXT.P: The Chung Cheng Armed Forces Preparatory School said Tuesday that it expects to begin accepting female students from next year.
The school said it has presented the proposal to the Ministry of National Defense and received initial support for the plan.
Two female military officers are slated to report to the school in November to help with its plan to accept up to 20 female students beginning next year, according to a spokesman for the school.

The Chung Cheng Armed Forces Preparatory School was established by the ministry in Fongshang City, Kaohsiung County in 1976 with the aim of recruiting exceptional talent to help meet Taiwan's national defense needs and raise the quality of the country's military officers.
The school, which offers free tuition, has accepted only male students since its inception.
A Junior High Department was added in 1991, but it stopped enrolling new students in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former President Lee will not attend DPP-sponsored rally

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will not take part in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party-sponsored protest rally slated for Saturday in Taipei City, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei said Tuesday.
The rally, being co-sponsored by the Taiwan-centric TSU, will target "the one China market, the downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty and an incompetent government."
Speaking with reporters after a DPP news conference to promote the rally, Huang said that Lee, who is the spiritual leader of the TSU, is advanced in age and will not attend the event.

Lee will voice his views on President Ma Ying-jeou's China policy as well as the upcoming visit by Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits Chairman Chen Yunlin, Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan, at a forum on "Taiwan's sovereignty and security" to be held by the think tank Taiwan Advocates on the day of the rally.
The former president serves as the chairman of the think tank.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not dispense with defense force: premier

TEXT.P: Even if Taiwan signs a peace pact with China amid easing of tensions across the Taiwan Strait, the country should still maintain a strong national defense force, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday.

Liu made the comment while answering questions at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan on President Ma Ying-jeou's statement a few days ago that he will seek to forge a peace accord with China during his term in office.

Legislator Hsueh Ling of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked why the Ministry of National Defense (MND) had budgeted over NT$300 billion (US$9.18 billion) for arms procurement, if a peace pact would ensure that there would be no war in the Taiwan Strait.
"Why not just dismantle all Taiwan's military and defense forces?" Hsueh asked.

In response, Liu said that currently the two sides are moving toward peace. However, Taiwan must still have defense budgets and a certain degree of self- defense capability, which means maintaining an adequate defense force, he added.

Meanwhile, in response to an incident in which Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), was allegedly knocked over by anti-China protesters in Tainan earlier in the day, Liu said the Executive Yuan denounced any acts of violence.

With the incident triggering concerns over the safety of ARATS President Chen Yunlin when he visits Taiwan in late November or early December, Liu gave the assurance that the Executive Yuan will do its best to ensure Chen's safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices edge higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging up 10.88 points to close at 4,942.72.
Rebounding from losses the previous day and a rally on Wall Street overnight, the local bourse opened at 4,988.85 and quickly reached the day's high of 5,045.45.

But the market could not sustain the brief rally and fell to the day's low of 4,890.32 just after noon before heading higher. A total of 3.49 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$67.41 billion (US$2.06 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.3 percent. Textile stocks advanced 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares increased 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues were up 0.5 percent, and banking and financial shares rose 0.1 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks declining 0.7 percent and machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 839 to 598, with 421 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.44 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Obama did not object to selling Taiwan F-16s: campaign adviser

TEXT.P: U.S. Democratic presidential hopeful Barack Obama never said he objects to selling Taiwan F-16 C/D fighter jets, an Obama campaign adviser said Tuesday as he tried to negate a previous statement by the campaign that said it made no sense to sell the fighters to Taiwan.

It is incorrect that Senator Obama opposes the sale of F-16s. We are not closing the door on any U.S. military sales to Taiwan, " said Evan Medeiros, a member of the Obama campaign's Asia policy team, at a video conference on the 2008 U.S. presidential candidates' policies related to Asia.
The Obama campaign team was not asked to comment and therefore did not comment on the F-16 issue simply because the fighters were not on the table, Medeiros contended.

He added that if Obama were elected president, he would take appropriate measures if China started to use military force or threats and coercion to try to force or intimidate Taiwan into changing the status quo against its will.

Obama's diplomatic adviser David Lampton reportedly said in a policy debate in Washington last week that it made no sense to sell the most advanced fighter jets to Taiwan, given that Taipei and Beijing just recently reopened long- stalled dialogue.
The selling of F-16s to Taiwan did not meet the strategic interests of the U.S. or the interests of regional security and certainly not the interests of Taiwan, Lampton was cited as saying.

The U.S. Defense Department notified Congress Oct. 3 that it had approved the sale of a US$6.46 billion package of weapons to Taiwan, which President Ma Ying- jeou lauded assignaling an end to the turmoil of the past eight years and marking the beginning of a new era of safety and peace, as well as of mutual trust between Taiwan and the U.S.

The arms package includes 30 Apache attack helicopters, 330 Patriot PAC-3 missiles, 182 Javelin middle-range anti-tank missiles, 32 sea-launched Harpoon missiles, four E-2T aircraft system upgrades and assorted spare parts.
The sales were made under the auspices of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), which authorizes the U.S. to sell defensive weapons needed by Taiwan to maintain a sound defense.
The U.S. did not, however, approve diesel-electric submarines and Black Hawk helicopters that Taiwan had sought.
The Bush administration has also declined to process a separate request from Taiwan for F-16 C/D fighter jets.

While both Obama and McCain said they welcomed the arms package, only McCain urged the Bush administration to reconsider its decision not to approve the sale of the submarines or entertain the F-16 request.

Representing Republican presidential candidate John McCain at the forum, which was held by the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) American Cultural Center, Randall Schriver said McCain values the promises outlined in the TRA and will sell more defensive weapons to Taiwan if elected.
A deal is a deal, " Schriver said. "We will be judged by others if we made commitments and don't follow through with them."

If the military balance across the Taiwan Strait became unfavorable to Taiwan, it would raise the possibility that Beijing could coerce a settlement, even without the use of a military strike but through intimidation and coercion, the former deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs said.
People of Taiwan would then feel they have no other choice but to accept some sort of accommodation with Beijing, he added.
This is really about preserving Taiwan's latitude for maneuver, preserving the ability of the people of Taiwan to make choices about their future,Schriver said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for more consumer spending

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged local residents and overseas Chinese Tuesday to increase their personal spending in Taiwan to boost the country's economy, which is feeling the pinch of the global financial crisis.

Addressing a celebration marking Overseas Chinese Day, Ma noted that while foreign trade contributed greatly to Taiwan's economic growth in the past, the country now needed to turn to domestic investment and consumption for support in the face of a global economic downturn.
On its part, the government will increase its investment in public works in 2009 by NT$100 billion, Ma said.
People with purchasing power were also encouraged to spend as much as possible, he added.
"The best way for overseas expatriates to help the government is to increase your investment in the country and shop and spend more during your stay in Taiwan," Ma said.
The president said that although Taiwan has experienced a period of sluggishness over the past several months, the country's economic fundamentals remain sound.
For example, Taiwan has the world's fifth highest level of foreign exchange reserves, and its foreign reserves per capita of US$12,000 is the third highest worldwide, he said.
In addition, Taiwan's high saving rate is rare for a country with per capita income of US$19,000, he continued.
Standing at 29 percent this year, the country's saving rate is likely to top 30 percent in 2009, with approximately 9 percent representing excess savings, he said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's inflation rate is the second lowest after Japan among Asian countries, indicating that the government has effectively brought the inflation situation under control through efforts made by Taiwan's central bank, he said.
The global financial crisis that has toppled banks in the United States and Europe has not spared Taiwan, but the country's banking system has so far remained sound, according to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: China official says mobbing of his deputy may dent cross strait ties

TEXT.P: President of China's Association Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Chen Yunlin expressed concern Tuesday that the mobbing of his deputy Zhang Mingqing in Tainan City may have a negative effect on future cross-strait relations, according to Chen's counterpart in Taiwan.
However, Chiang Pin-Kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), stressed that this will not affect the plans for a visit to Taiwan in the next few weeks by Chen.

Chiang said that he called Chen immediately after the incident in which Zhang fell amid a crush of anti-China protesters during a visit to Confucius Temple in Tainan City, southern Taiwan Tuesday. It was not clear whether Zhang tripped or was pushed.

In response, Chen expressed concern that the incident may put a dent in future cross-strait relations and he reiterated that Zhang's visit was purely for academic purposes -- not for cross strait negotiations, according to Chiang.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan strongly condemned incident, saying it was no way to treat a guest to Taiwan. Lai also called for tighter security for Chen when he visits Taiwan later this month or next month for talks with Chiang on a range of cross-strait issues.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and the Presidential Office also condemned the mobbing of Zhang, with Liu agreeing that security should be enhanced for Chen's visit.
Ruling party Kuomintang lawmakers called for an apology by opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen over the incident, as they said DPP supporters were to be held responsible.
Tsai condemned the protestors' actions and called on her party's supporters to exercise restraint.

Zhang, the deputy head of China's quasi-official negotiating body with Taiwan, is in Taiwan for an academic seminar, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University in Xiamen, Fujian Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: McCain not worried about speed, range of Taiwan-China links: aide

TEXT.P: Republican presidential candidate John McCain is not concerned that relations between Taiwan and China are moving too fast, a senior advisor in the McCain campaign on Asia policy said Tuesday.

Asked whether Taiwan is moving too fast or going too far in improving relations with China, Randall Schriver, a member of the McCain campaign team and former deputy assistant secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said "Senator McCain and certainly the campaign have great confidence in the people of Taiwan. If this is going too quickly, it will come from the 23 million people of Taiwan."
"At the end of the day, the administration is pursuing a course that is popular in Taiwan, that is supported in Taiwan, and the U.S. will support those endeavors," he added.

Schriver made the remarks in Washington D.C. at a digital video conference on Asia policies among policy advisors of the 2008 U.S. presidential candidates and scholars, which was held by the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) American Cultural Center. The event was joined by Evan Medeiros, member of the Democrat presidential candidate Barack Obama campaign team, Schriver, and scholars from Taiwan.

Since assuming the presidency on May 20, President Ma Ying-jeou has been touting a "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy, which attempts to set aside Taipei's differences with Beijing to find a mutually beneficial equilibrium. He is also seeking a "diplomatic truce" to end a longstanding tug-of-war with China over each other's allies and carve out a greater international presence for Taiwan.

In addition, Ma introduced a series of cross-strait liberalization measures, including the launch of nonstop direct weekend charter flights, opening up Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, allowing cross-strait currency trading, and raising the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent to 60 percent of their net worth.

The opposition, however, accuses Ma of sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty by leaning too much toward China, which they claimed displeased the U.S. to the point that Washington dragged its feet on the approval of a US$6.46 billion arms sale to Taiwan.

Both campaign teams agree that the U.S. should continue to provide the necessary defensive weapons to Taiwan to give the island additional bargaining chips and confidence in its negotiations with China.

Noting that one of the prime foreign policy goals in an Obama administration would be to re-orient and re-energize U.S. engagement with East Asia, Medeiros said "we believe that the logic of providing for Taiwan legitimate defense needs, as outlined in the Taiwan Relations Act, gives Taiwan the confidence to approach cross-strait dynamics with greater confidence. It is with that logic that we support the recent package."
Schriver said McCain believes that diplomacy can be most effective tool and can have the best chance to succeed if Taiwan can negotiate with China from a position of strength and confidence.
"This is really about preserving Taiwan's latitude for maneuver -- preserving the ability of the people of Taiwan to make choices about their future," Schriver said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.117 to close at NT$32.697.
A total of US$883 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.580 and fluctuated between NT$32.556 and NT$32.724.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT donates books for children from remote areas

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) donated children's books Tuesday to support theRead for the Future" project promoted by a local foundation.
We are impressed by the efforts the CommonWealth Magazine Education Foundation has made to bring brooks to remote elementary schools in Taiwan, " said AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges in a press release.
The AIT hopes to provide students in remote areas with more extensive resources through this cooperation, he added.

A book presentation ceremony was held at Youmu Primary School in Taipei County earlier in the day, attended by Hodges, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, and CommonWealth Magazine Education Foundation Chairwoman Diane Ying.
At the event, the AIT presented about 300 easy-to-read English books to students and teachers for the American Shelf of theRead for the Futurebookmobiles, as part of the cooperation program.
Launched in 2004 by the foundation, theRead for the Future project includes three bookmobiles that circulate among 200 remote elementary schools in Taiwan and reach over 25,000 students.
The American Shelf serves as a platform for telling America's story through a variety of events and specialized print and non-print media on various aspects of American society and culture.
The American Shelf in theRead for the Futurebookmobiles is the second one established in Taiwan, after the one established at the Kaohsiung City Public Library.
Since 2000, over 400 cities around the world have become part of the growing network of the American Shelves and American Corners.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police chief vows to ensure Chinese official's safety

TEXT.P: National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Wang Cho-chiun on Tuesday promised to ensure the safety of a visiting Chinese official and condemned violence against him in Tainan City, southern Taiwan.

Wang ordered police authorities nationwide to reinforce security measures to protect the personal safety of Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), during the reminder of his stay in Taiwan.
Wang said that anyone caught illegally using violence and injuring others or damaging public property will be dealt with according to the law, regardless of his or her political affiliation.

NPA Deputy Director-General Yi Yung-jen acknowledged that Tainan City police had failed to adopt adequate security measures to protect Zhang and that the agency will investigate the incident and hold those in charge accountable.

Zhang fell to the ground after being chased and punched by a group of protesters mobilized by a Tainan City councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during a private tour of the Confucius Temple in Tainan City earlier Tuesday.
It was not immediately clear if Zhang fell because he lost his balance after being besieged by the protesters or if he was actually shoved to the ground.

Dozens of pro-Taiwan independence supporters chanted anti-China slogans to protest Zhang's appearance at the temple, and shouted at him to "get lost" and "go back to China" when they saw him walking alone.

One protester also jumped onto the hood of Zhang's car as he was being escorted from the site by a local official and a tour guide. The Chinese official was later taken to a hotel in Tainan City to rest.

Although three plainclothes policemen were present when Zhang was approached by the group of protesters, they did not try to stop the demonstration and none of the protesters were detained at the scene.
The National Police Agency also has ordered the Tainan City Police Bureau to thoroughly investigate the case.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22- member delegation to take part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.
The incident could have repercussions on a planned visit to Taiwan, slated for late October or early November, by ARATS President Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long-term care law should consider patients' family members: experts

TEXT.P: Scholars and representatives of non-governmental organizations demanded Tuesday that future legislation on Taiwan's Long-term Care Law take into consideration the needs of patients' family members, many of whom sacrifice their jobs to take care of the patients.

Chang Chin-fen, professor of National Taipei University's Department of Social Work, said at a public hearing that some people prefer looking after their ill family members instead of hiring caretakers, but they might have to give up their job as well as their labor insurance annuity, which is similar to social security for them when they grow old.
She said the future Long-term Care Law should not neglect these people, noting that they need professional training courses and a salary, like professional caretakers.

"If the law cannot guarantee the life and welfare of these people, it would be like the law punishes those who take responsibility for taking care of their family members, " said Chen Ying-rui, secretary-general of an alliance of family caretakers, adding that people who take care of ill family members also need respite care services.
They were speaking at a pubic hearing held by legislator Yang Li-huan of the ruling Kuomintang as preparation for drafting legislation for the Long-term Care Law.
In addition, scholars and non-governmental organization representatives noted that a gap in resources between cities and the countryside must be addressed before the law is enacted.

"Service stations should be established as a priority in remote areas of the countryside; otherwise, even if the law is enacted, people in need (in these regions) will not be able to benefit from it, " said Wu Yu-chin, secretary- general of the Alliance for Old People's Welfare Promotion, adding that capacities for community care services vary widely in Taiwan.

In response, government officials who also attended to the hearing agreed that it is necessary to set up a long-term care network before enacting the law, saying that it was the target of the Executive Yuan's 10-year plan.

Last year, the Executive Yuan approved a 10-year long-term care plan, in which it will invest a total of 81.7 billion NT dollars in 10 years to cope with problems of Taiwan's aging society. The plan is considered Taiwan's largest social welfare program for the elderly apart from the National Pension system, according to the Government Information Office.

President Ma Ying-jeou has also promised to implement long-term care insurance, enact the Long-term Care Law in four years, and integrate long-term care services and medical resources in communities to help elderly people "aging in place."

According to estimates by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, people over 65 in Taiwan, numbering currently 2.34 million, or 10.2 percent of the total population, will increase to 4.76 million in 2025, accounting for 20 percent of the population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to locate melamine-tainted baking ingredient

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation urged the government Monday to locate and make public the whereabouts of the full shipment of the melamine-tainted leavening agent ammonium bicarbonate imported from China.

After the discovery in Taiwan last month of melamine-contaminated milk powder and non-dairy creamer, it was also found that a total of 469 tons of ammonium bicarbonate imported by Taiwan's Sesoda Corp. from China was contaminated with the toxic chemical melamine.

The melamine content in a small portion of the imported ammonium bicarbonate was as high as 2,470 parts per million (ppm) -- more than 987 times the maximum permissible level, according to the foundation.

The foundation confirmed that some 384 tons of the melamine-tainted leavening agent had been distributed in domestic markets. It is believed to have been used in many baked products, such as Chinese deep-fried bread sticks, creamy custard buns (polo buns) , barbecue pork buns, puff, Chinese sticky rice crackers and Chinese wedding cakes, and as an additive to seaweed and squid, the foundation said.

About 3,055 of the 3,479 bags of the melamine tainted ammonium bicarbonate distributed in Taichung City have been seized by the city's Health Bureau, and the other 424 bags were used in paper production, according to a report released by the central city government Monday.

In light of the conflicting information provided by the media and the Department of Health on the volume of melamine-tainted ammonium bicarbonate that was sold, used and seized, the foundation urged that the government update the figures and make them available to the public.

The foundation also asked health agencies to immediately make clear information related to the whereabouts of the melamine-tainted baking ingredient, to provide, for example, a clearer picture on what products may contain the contaminated agent.

It added that the government should not try to hide the truth in an attepmt to avoid causing panic among consumers, but rather it should emulate King Car Food company's successfully handling of its melamine crisis. King Car removed all its melamine-tainted products from the market and made all information public shortly after eight of its products tested positive for melamine.

The foundation also suggested that the government work to gain an understanding of the manufacturing process of ammonium bicarbonate and figure out why the shipment to Taiwan was contaminated with melamine, a chemical used to make plastics or fertilizers that should never be used as a food additive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan official condemns violence against visiting Chinese academic

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Vice Chairman Chang Chun-hung strongly condemned Tuesday the violent treatment of visiting Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Vice President Zhang Mingqing by pro-Taiwan independence supporters in Tainan City earlier the same day.

The Chinese official, visiting in his private capacity as a scholar to attend a seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts, was chased and knocked to the ground by the protestors while he was touring the Confucius Temple in the southern city.
The dozens of protestors chanted anti-China slogans and shouted abuses at Zhang, telling him to "get lost" and "go back to China."
Chang condemned the protestors' actions, saying that it displayed the "barbarization of Taiwan's democracy."
"Democracy is Taiwan's biggest weapon, and if we lose that weapon, then all that is left to do is to travel down the road of surrender," he added.
Chang said that protests are a natural part of democratic societies, adding that it is acceptable for citizens to voice their opposition to China's military buildup.
"But the use of violence is cowardly and is tantamount to saying to the world that the result of Taiwan's democratization is barbarity," he claimed.
Noting that cross-Taiwan Strait relations have been on friendlier terms recently, Chang added that such "barbaric treatment" of a visiting academic can only undermine the nation's interests.
Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in the academic seminar in his capacity as dean of Xiamen University's school of journalism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese company to attain VCS validation for carbon asset trading

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese paper company is expected to receive the country's first "global validation" for its performance on carbon footprint management, in keeping with the government's efforts to comply with international standards on reducing carbon emission.

The company, Cheng Loong Corp., made the announcement Tuesday at a seminar held by the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taiwan on the United Kingdom 's experiences in carbon management and emission trading.

The company, with the assistance of a British consulting firm, is projected to attain the Voluntary Carbon Standard (VCS) certification for meeting criteria for carbon emission reduction and fuel efficiency by the end of October, said the company's president, Tsai Tong-ho.
It will become the first corporation in Taiwan entitled to exchange trade deals on the carbon market starting next year, he noted.
Tsai estimated that 200,000 tons of carbon assets can be accumulated within the validity length of the VCS on a market turnover of around US$1 million.
According to a report by the British research institute Ecosystem Marketplace, the trade volume of carbon assets is expected to surpass 150 million tons in 2008, which is 10 times higher than 2006.
VCS is a special project which provides the alternative for businesses of non- signatories to the Kyoto Protocol to voluntarily adhere to the regulations on carbon emission.
Taiwan is not a party to the protocol because it is not recognized as a sovereign state, due to opposition from mainland China, which considers the island one of its provinces.

DOC.HEADLINE: Change to Hanyu Pinyin to cost NT$1 billion at most: education chief

TEXT.P: The government's plan to replace Tongyong Pinyin with Hanyu Pinyin as the country's standard Mandarin romanization system will cost a maximum of NT$1 billion (US$30.69 million), Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng said Tuesday.

Asked about the issue during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Cheng dismissed as "incorrect" reports that the country would need to spend between NT$7 billion and NT$8 billion to fully implement the switch.
The Tongyong Pinyin system, used only in Taiwan, was adopted by the previous pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

Some believe that the DPP preferred Tongyong Pinyin to the widely used Hanyu Pinyin system because Hanyu Pinyin originated in China, but the DPP also justified Tongyong Pinyin by saying it was more adaptable to some of the other languages spoken in Taiwan, such as Hoklo and Hakka.
The new Kuomintang administration recently decided to change the romanization system to Hanyu Pinyin to bring Taiwan in line with international standards.
The plan was immediately opposed by the seven cities and counties ruled by the DPP, which claimed that the conversion would cost them NT$500 million.

Also during the hearing, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan explained that the romanization system is designed for people who are unfamiliar with Mandarin, and the main consideration in choosing a system should be the convenience of foreigners.
Since the United Nations has also adopted Hanyu Pinyin, Taiwan will have a problem bridging its gap with the world if it continues using Tongyong Pinyin, Liu contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recognizes SMEs

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou praised small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for their longstanding efforts in helping boost the country's economy by investing in Taiwan over the past few years.

Ma lauded these engines of Taiwan's economy during a ceremony held in Taipei City Monday to honor 18 Taiwanese SME entrepreneurs from home and abroad in recognition of their significant contribution to the country.

The president also commended the entrepreneurs for helping stabilize the country's economy, as Taiwan's 1.24 million SMEs account for 98 percent of all enterprises and 77 percent of the total job openings in the country.

Ma said that to improve Taiwan's economic environment, the Kuomintang (KMT) government has earmarked NT$50 billion (US$1.53 billion) since it was inaugurated May 20 this year to expand domestic demand.
Expressing confidence in the country's economy, the president said that the government also intends to earmark more than NT$100 billion next year for public works, Ma added.

The president reaffirmed that the government has worked out a plan to inject funds into the local stock market, whose benchmark index has plunged more than 4,100 points as of Monday since the government took office.
Ma acknowledged that the global financial crisis that has battered the local bourse has also negatively impacted the economy as a whole.

He said, however, that Taiwan's financial sector is still functioning normally, and that government authorities will do their utmost to map out measures to prevent the sectors from incurring losses as a result of the crisis.
As long as Taiwan steps up its risk control and crisis management, it will ride out the crisis, he added.

The 12 SMEs based in Taiwan which won the 17th National Outstanding SMEs Awards include Sheh Fung Screws Co. and Silicon Power Computer & Communication Inc. in the northern city of Taipei; FINETEK Co., System & Technology Corp. and Thermaltake Technology Co. in the northern county of Taipei; Longtek Scientific Co. in the northern city of Hsinchu; HEP Tech Co. and Yoke Industrial Corp. in the central city of Taichung; CVC Technologies, Inc. and Buffalo Machinery Co. in the central county of Taichung; Tung Yu Hydraulic Machinery Co. in the central county of Nantou; and Laser Tek Taiwan Co. in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The six SMEs based in foreign countries which garnered the 10th Outstanding Overseas Taiwanese SMEs Awards include Las Vegas-based Dental Implant Institute and Toronto-based Asian Legend Restaurant.

DOC.HEADLINE: China formally protests mobbing of its official

TEXT.P: China's quasi-official body in charge of handling exchanges with Taiwan filed a formal letter of protest with its counterpart in Taipei Tuesday, strongly condemning what they called " a barbaric action of violence" in which a Chinese official was beseiged by protesters in Tainan City.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation said the fax, received from its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , at 4 p.m. Tuesday, said that "a few people who are ignoring the majority's will in Taiwan are purposely attempting to destroy normal cross-strait exchanges."
Zhang Mingqing, deputy president of ARATS, was besieged by a group of anti-China protesters Tuesday and fell to the ground while visiting the Confucius Temple in Tainan City in southern Taiwan.

Based on footage shown on ETTV cable news, it appeared Zhang fell after being shouldered by Wang Ting-yu, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party Tainan City councilor, as Wang was turning his body toward the Chinese official.

The ARATS has requested that the SEF ask Taiwanese authorities to punish the instigators of the crowd that mobbed Zhang and to provide security to Zhang, hoping that such incidents will not occur again.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday as the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts in Tainan County in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism, Xiamen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan police help catch Japanese murder suspect

TEXT.P: Taiwan's criminal investigation police turned a Japanese murder suspect over to three police officers from Japan Tuesday after detaining him at a sushi bar in Taipei Oct. 9 in response to a request sent through Interpol.
Keiichi Noda, 58, was escorted by the three Japanese police officers back to Japan aboard a Japan Airlines flight to face charges of murder and robbery.

The man, who sports a shaved head, allegedly intruded into a private home in Japan's Kochi Prefecture on Sept. 19 and killed 70-year-old Toshiko Yano, the vice president of a financial company, and ran away with 10 million yen.

Japanese police believed that Noda was probably hiding in Taiwan because he left Osaka's Kansai International Airport on a Northwest Airlines flight bound for Taipei. They sought help from their Taiwanese counterparts through Interpol.

Although there is no judicial mutual assistance agreement between Taiwan and Japan, the Criminal Investigation Bureau still extended a helping hand and nabbed Noda at a sushi bar in one of Taipei's top Japanese restaurants.
According to police, when Noda was taken into custody, he had 150,000 yen with him. Asked where the remainder of the 10 million yen was, he said that he had spent it all.
Noda reportedly told police that his plan was to kill himself after blowing all the money he robbed from Yano on food, drinks and prostitutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan asks Malaysia to correct statement over cheese source

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) has asked the Malaysian government to correct a statement over the source of Malaysia-imported biscuits' cheese filling that was found with the industrial chemical melamine in late September, according to DOH spokesman Wang Je-chau late Monday.
Wang was referring to the issue involved with the recall of Regimen House Milk Sandwich Biscuits by Costco Wholesale Taiwan.
The biscuits were imported by Taiwan's Golden Kestrel Co. from Malaysia's Kee Wee Hup Kee Food Manufacture, Wang said.
According to Wang, a report by Malaysia's Sin Chew Daily cited Malaysia's Health Minister Liow Tiong Lai on Oct. 4 saying that the problematic biscuits were produced with Taiwan-made ingredients.
Liow also pointed out that the Malaysian food manufacturer Kee Wee Hup Kee was only responsible for packing and exporting the products, Wang said, citing the report.

However, Wang said investigations made by the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, and Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices in Malaysia and Singapore showed that the biscuits did not contain ingredients from Taiwan.

Wang said that Hong Kong's Joinfair Enterprises Co. purchased cheese powder for the biscuits' fillings from China-based Zengcheng Handyware Seasoning Co., and mailed or hand carried the ingredients to Malaysia's Kee Wee Hup Kee, which produced the biscuits with the cheese powder from China and other ingredients bought in Malaysia, and exported the product to Taiwan.

The Malaysian official's statement and Sin Chew Daily's report without verifications have harmed Taiwan's image, Wang said, adding that the DOH has written to the Malaysia Friendship and Trade Center in Taipei asking it to urge the Malaysian government to correct its statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panamanian ambassador welcomes Taiwanese investments in Panama

TEXT.P: The Panamanian ambassador to Taiwan, Julio Mock, on Tuesday encouraged Taiwanese entrepreneurs to increase their investments in Panama to reinforce the economic and comercial cooperation between the two nations.

During his "Panama: Yesterday and Today" speech given at the Institute of Latin American Studies in the University of Tamkang, Mock reiterated that economic, political and cultural ties between Taiwan and Panama have benefited both countries.

"Taiwan relies on Panama to distribute its merchandise to Latin America... thanks to the newly signed free trade agreement, the exportation of Panamanian beef to Taiwan has increased from 30 tons per year to 2,000 tons per year after the signing of the Taiwan-Panama Free Trade Agreement. This relationship is clearly one of mutual benefit", said Mock.
Mock noted that Panama is twice the size of Taiwan but yet it only has a population of 3.2 million compared to Taiwan's 23 million.

"The land is cheap and fertile for agricultural production. Considering Taiwan's successful experience in agriculture, we welcome Taiwanese investments in our country's agricultural sector. It would be a highly lucrative business", emphasized Mock.

Other investment opportunities mentioned by the ambassador were in the areas of energy, bio-energy and oil refineries, which are closely related to the country's future plans of expanding the Panama Canal.

When asked by a student about the possible threats of a newly built Nicaraguan trans-oceanic canal to Panama's economic development, Mock said: "Nicaragua is the poorest country in Central America, I seriously doubt they have the technological and monetary capacity to sustain such a massive project."

Mock reassured Taiwan that the diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Panama have been strengthened by the signing of the Taiwan-Panama FTA, adding that the friendship between the two nations surpasses any political interests.

Despite the seemingly close diplomatic and economical ties between Taiwan and Panama, in the past two decades, the Panamanian government has also welcomed a variety of Chinese investments directed at the development of the ports of Cristobal and Balboa, located accordingly in the Caribbean side and Pacific side of the Panama Canal.
It is the opinion of many scholars that the rapid increase of Chinese investments in Panama and the new leftist movement in Latin America might seriously damage Taiwan's ties with its Latin allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers challenge president on "no war" statement

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers expressed concern Tuesday over President Ma Ying-jeou's assurance that there will be "no war across the Taiwan Strait in the next four years, " saying China has never shown its good will toward Taiwan.
Stating his vision for the country's defense before top military leaders earlier in the day, Ma declared, "there will be no war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the next four years."
Ma also stressed, however, that Taiwan has to maintain a strong defense even if the country has no desire to go to war with the mainland.
DPP caucus whip Lai Ching-te and Legislator Yeh Yi-jin criticized the statement at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, wondering what the basis was for it.

China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan has increased from 400 in 2000 to 1,328 in 2008, the lawmakers said, a sign of China's lack of good will toward Taiwan over the past decade that led them to question Ma's declaration.

They asked whether Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, would be willing to display good will toward Taiwan on behalf of China during his upcoming visit to Taiwan and promise to dismantle the missiles.
They also wondered if President Ma would be willing to ask Chen to convey to Beijing a request to dismantle the missiles.

Speculating that Ma might have signed a "secret" agreement with China to back his peace pledge, the DPP legislative caucus demanded that any agreement signed by Taiwan and China affecting Taiwan's future would be required to be screened by the Legislative Yuan.
They also insisted that no cross-strait agreement could take effect without a public referendum.
Among the pacts that would be subject to such a requirement would be a peace agreement forged with China, a deal Ma has said he hopes to complete during his term in office.

Echoing the fears of his DPP colleagues that such a peace deal would be signed in secret, DPP lawmaker Gao Jyh-peng proposed to draft a bill of regulations on managing agreements signed by Taiwan and China that would formalize the legislature's role in approving such accords.

Gao was skeptical that Ma's so-called "peace accord" could really bring peace, saying that China had signed a "peace accord" with Tibet but still sent troops to crack down on democratic movements there.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT to hold Daniel Pearl Day of Music in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Daniel Pearl Day of Music will be held on Oct. 25 at the Taipei Artist Village (TAV), the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday in a press release.
The Daniel Pearl Day of Music is part of annual global effort to affirm the ideals of tolerance, friendship and our shared humanity,the AIT said.

With a full lineup of popular bands, the event will go from 2 p.m. to 9 p.m. Saturday at the venue located at No. 7 Beiping East Road near the Taipei Main Station, the AIT said, adding that the day-long concert will unite musicians and audience in the hopes of promotingHarmony for Humanity.

The Daniel Pearl Day of Music was established in 2002 to commemorate the life and work of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, who was murdered by extremists in Pakistan in 2002 in the line of duty.

Following his death, friends and musicians have hosted annual international concerts intended to promote cross-cultural understanding, overcome cultural and religious hatred, and encourage responsible and creative journalism as well as enrich peoples lives through music.
This event is co-sponsored by the artist village, Taiwan Foreign CorrespondentsClub, and Village Cafe.

Peopled interested in the concert are advised to visit the Web site http: //www.danielpearl.org.. For information about the local event in Taipei, they can contact Sean Scanlan at seanscanlan@gmail. com, or call the Village Cafe at 3393-7377 ext. 207.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior minister apologizes for harassment of Chinese official

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi apologized Tuesday for an incident in which a Chinese official was shoveled to the ground by a group of protesters in Tainan City earlier the same day, saying he would take full responsibility for the incident.
Liao said his ministry would launch an investigation into the incident to check whether law enforcement authorities had failed in their duties.

The interior minister also promised that police authorities nationwide will step up security measures to protect Zhang's personal safety and strictly hold those responsible for the incident accountable.

Earlier Tuesday, Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was chased and pushed to the ground by dozens of anti-China protesters while on a private tour to the Confucius Temple in the southern Taiwan city.

Three plainclothes policemen were present when Zhang was harassed and grabbed by emotional demonstrators, but they did not try to stop the violence and none of the protesters were detained at the scene.

Zhang, who suffered only a slight bruise, was sent back to a hotel in Tainan City to rest. Officials from the Interior Ministry, the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and the ruling Kuomintang all sent officials to show concern for Zhang.
According to Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng, Zhang has filed a formal complaint against the instigators of the incident with relevant authorities.

Meanwhile, Tainan prosecutors have taken the initiative to investigate the case, and those caught illegally using force against Zhang are likely to face charges of hampering freedom, assault and damaging property.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military finds possible remains of pilot of missing jet

TEXT.P: Fragmented human remains that may be from one of two missing pilots of a military fighter that disappeared off Taiwan's southwestern coast were found Tuesday, along with more debris from the aircraft, a high-ranking Air Force officer said in Taichung County.

Chang Chao-kuei, the political warfare chief of the Air Force's 427 Wing, added that DNA tests would be required to identify the collected remains, which were found in shallow reefs northeast of Nanwen islet in the Penghu Island chain.

Chang said family members of the missing officers were extremely disturbed emotionally when learning of the discovery. A mother couldn't stop crying and hoped that her son would return home alive, he said.
Chang further said that despite indications that fragments of the body of one of the pilots may have been found, the military still hoped that one of the two missing pilots had survived.
The IDF (indigenous defense fighter) disappeared from radar screens while on a bombing training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait Monday morning.
It took off from Chingchuangkang Airbase in Taichung County at 9: 15 a.m. and disappeared 30 minutes later near Huayu island in Penghu County, according to Air Force authorities.
The two officers aboard the plane, pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian-ting, have since remained unaccounted for.

IDFs, developed by Taiwan in the 1980s with assistance from the Unites States, together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the mainstay of Taiwan's second generation Air Force fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait forum at Chiayi university closed to public

TEXT.P: The cross-Taiwan Strait roundtable forum on communications and imaging arts to be held Wednesday on the campus of National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi County will be closed to the public, the university announced Tuesday.

The university originally welcomed all those interested to attend the forum, but the school authorities apparently changed their minds after seeing the head of the Chinese delegation being bullied in Tainan by pro-independence protesters, including a Tainan City councilor from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will be attending the forum in his capacity as dean of Xiamen University's school of journalism. The forum is a purely academic discussion and has nothing to do with politics," the university said.

Chung Cheng University officials said that a top-level meeting decided that to prevent protesters and hecklers from interrupting the forum, outsiders will not be allowed to attend the meeting, nor will they be permitted on the university's campus Wednesday.
Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in three academic seminars on Oct. 20, Oct. 22 and Oct. 24, respectively.
Since his arrival, he has been constantly followed by anti-China protesters.

During a visit to the Confucius Temple in Tainan Tuesday, he was besieged by a mob that jostled him to the ground and then later chased after him, with one protester striking a blow to the back of his head.
Another protester even jumped on the roof of his car as he was about to be driven away from the scene.

Nearly all sectors of Taiwan, including The Presidential Office, the Straits Exchange Foundation, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , KMT legislators, business leaders, and local chiefs of both the KMT and DPP, severely condemned the violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official files complaint with police over rough treatment

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese official said Tuesday that he has filed a formal complaint with police against those who harassed and jostled him to the ground earlier in the day during a visit to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City, southern Taiwan.
Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , told reporters Tuesday afternoon that he had taken the action following the incident.
"As a victim, I strongly condemn this act of violence and I have filed a complaint with law enforcement authorities," Zhang said.

Later the same day, Tainan City Police Bureau Commissioner Chen Fu-hsiang and Lin Chi-feng, an acting spokesman for the Tainan Prosecutors Office, both confirmed that Zhang had filed a complaint charging that he had been assaulted.
Zhang was besieged by dozens of pro-Taiwan independence supporters who shouted in his face and shoveled him to the ground as he was walking on the temple's grounds.

One protester even jumped onto the hood of Zhang's car and stamped on it with his feet as Zhang was being escorted from the site by a local official and a tour guide. The Chinese official was later taken to a hotel in Tainan City to rest.
The demonstrators may have been mobilized by Wang, and prosecutors later summoned Wang for questioning related to the incident.
Although three plainclothes policemen were on duty at the site, they did not stop the harassment and did not detain any of the aggressors at the scene.
With police authorities tightening security measures to protect his personal safety, Zhang has decided to continue his activities Wednesday in Kaohsiung City.

At the head of a 22-member delegation, Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day visit. He took part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts Monday in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC to launch alternative Suhua expressway plan next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's transportation minister said his ministry plans to present a new environmental impact assessment report for an alternative to the existing Suhua Highway next year, in the hope of solving eastern Taiwan's transportation bottleneck.

"(The MOTC) will present the required environmental impact assessment report in May or June next year, " said Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Mao Chi-kuo Tuesday, when questioned by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Fu Kun-chi, a strong advocate of the construction of an expressway in eastern Taiwan.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan also stressed at the legislature that his administration had no reason to postpone the road plan, but stressed environmental assessments needed to be conducted.
He said that eastern Taiwan's transportation problems could not be solved with a single means of transport, such as by increasing the frequency of scheduled train service.
When pressed on the new project's timetable, Mao also stressed that work on the roadway could not begin until completion of the environmental impact assessment panel's review process.
He noted however that if the environmental assessment went smoothly, construction on the roadway might start by the end of next year.

Legislator Fu echoed the premier's view that expanding train service could not solve eastern Taiwan's transportation bottlenecks, asserting that the railway system could only handle 20 percent of the traffic volume on the current roadway.

Fu said that a lack of convenient transportation to eastern Taiwan has led to high divorce and unemployment rates, as well as stagnation of trade in a region that is already among the poorest areas in the country.

The government originally designed an expressway connecting Suao in Yilan County and Hualien in Hualien County to replace the existing windy roadway that cuts through coastal mountains and is often blocked by landslides during heavy rains.

But the project, which would have required extensive drilling of tunnels, was highly controversial due to its potential impact on the surrounding ecosystem and was strongly opposed by environmentalists.

It was ultimately rejected last April by the environmental impact assessment panel under the Environmental Protection Administration, and environmentalists have described the new alternative road plan as "old wine in a new bottle."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ill-fated IDF fighter may have stalled before crash: Air Force officer

TEXT.P: An Air Force official said Tuesday that judging by the debris it left behind, an indigenous defense fighter (IDF) that disappeared Monday near the Penghu Island chain may have stalled before crashing into the sea.
The possible explanation of the crash was given by Shen Yi-feng, chief of staff of the Air Force's 427th Tactical Fighter Wing, who has coordinated the search mission for the jet fighter.
But Shen said Air Force Headquarters has formed an investigation task force to delve more deeply into the cause of the accident.

A search team consisting of Air Force, Navy and Coast Guard Administration (CGA) workers on Tuesday discovered 14 pieces of wreckage from the IDF that crashed in waters southwest of two islets in the Taiwan-held Penghu Island chain, some of them found on the islets themselves.

Earlier in the day, the search team also found three pieces of human flesh while scouring the area. The Armed Forces General Hospital in Penghu was trying to establish whether the fragmented remains belonged to either of the two Air Force pilots.
Two Navy ships and five CGA cutters were continuing to comb the waters where the plane is believed to have gone down.
The plane, operated by pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian- ting, disappeared from radar screens Monday morning while on a bombing training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait.
The IDF was developed in the 1980s by Taiwan's state-owned Aerospace Industry Development Corp. in cooperation with General Dynamics Corp. of the United States.
The IDFs, together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the backbone of Taiwan's Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan police director transferred after Chinese official besieged
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 21 (CNA) 10/21/08 23:10:26 (By Flor Wang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Tainan City Police Bureau Commissioner Chen Fu-hsiang was transferred by the National Police Agency (NPA) to take responsibility for an incident in which a Chinese official was shoved to the ground by protesters in the city Tuesday.
Chen was transferred to the post of deputy director-general of the National Highway Police Bureau, according to a statement released by the NPA.
NPA Director-General Wang Cho-chiun has submitted an application for his own punishment over the incident to the Ministry of the Interior.

Earlier Tuesday, Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was besieged by dozens of anti- China protesters and shoved to the ground while on a private tour to the Confucius Temple in the southern Taiwan city.
Three plainclothes policemen were present when the incident took place, but they apparently did not try to stop the violence and none of the protesters were detained at the scene.
Zhang, who suffered only a slight bruise, was sent back to a hotel in Tainan City to rest.
Officials from the Interior Ministry, the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and the ruling Kuomintang all sent officials to express their concern for Zhang.

Chen's transfer and disciplinary action against other policemen came after Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi apologized over the incident and vowed that his ministry would launch an investigation to determine if law enforcement authorities had failed in their duties.
The investigation showed that the Tainan City Police Bureau failed to respond quickly to Zhang's change of itinerary to prevent the incident, the statement said.
The NPA has asked police forces of five cities and counties in southern Taiwan to step up protection of Zhang's personal safety, the statement said.
According to Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng, Zhang has filed a formal complaint against the instigators of the incident with relevant authorities.
Meanwhile, Tainan prosecutors have decided to investigate the case, and those found to have illegally bullied Zhang are likely to face charges of hampering freedom, assault and damaging property.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official to cut short visit to Taiwan
