TEXT.P: A Chinese official who was besieged and shoved to the ground by protestors in Tainan City Tuesday has decided to cut short his visit to Taiwan by a day and return home from Kaohsiung Wednesday.

An official of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation said Zhang Mingqing, the vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , made the decision Tuesday afternoon, hours after he was heckled and chased around by a group of pro-independence protesters in Tainan City.
The official said SEF staff will see Zhang off at Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung Wednesday morning.

The Chinese official, who had been followed by anti-China protesters since arriving in Taiwan Oct. 19, was shoved to the ground amid a chaotic scene while visiting the Confucius Temple in the southern Taiwan city.
He suffered a bruise to his legs and was escorted to a hotel for a brief rest.
He condemned the instigators and pepetrators of the attack against him at a news conference later in the day.

"A civilized society which is ruled by law won't tolerate violence, " Zhang said, adding that he didn't believe the group of people who went after him represented the majority of Tainan City's people.
Branding himself a victim of violence, Zhang said this incident underlines the danger any Chinese tourist to Taiwan could face while visiting the island.
"I hope what I encountered in Taiwan will pave the way for better treatment of Chinese tourists as well as ARATS President Chen Yunlin," Zhang said.
He was referring to Chen's scheduled visit to Taiwan at the end of October or in early November.
Noting that the protesters were trying to spoil the thawing ties between Taiwan and China, Zhang said they were shooting their own feet by resorting to violence.
"They won't achieve their goal of stopping the peaceful development across the strait," Zhang said.

At the head of a 22-member delegation, Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day visit. He took part in an academic seminar at Taiwan National University of the Arts Monday in Taiwan County, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Zhang incident not to affect Chinese official's visit: spokeswoman

TEXT.P: The incident that saw a visiting Chinese official jostled to the ground by anti- China protesters will not affect the scheduled visit to Taiwan of Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, the Executive Yuan spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Soon after the incident, speculation arose that it might possibly affect Chen's planned visit at the end of October or early November, but Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih said the trip would not be affected.
Shih said that despite the lapse in security Tuesday, there would be tight security measures in place to ensure Chen's safety during his visit
The spokeswoman said the government denounced Tuesday's act of violence against Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Zhang was besieged by a group of emotional protesters during a visit earlier in the day to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City, a stronghold of the pro- independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Television footage showed Zhang being grabbed and shouted at by the protestors and then falling to the ground after being shoved, possibly inadvertently, by two of the protesters.
Shih said the Executive Yuan has dispatched Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang to visit Zhang after the incident.
Saying that the Taiwanese are a polite, hospitable and peace-loving people, Shih said the "irrational behavior was not in line with the expectations of Taiwan's people."
The Executive Yuan believes that no matter the circumstances, people should express their opinions in a peaceful and rational manner.
Shih admitted that the measures to provide security for Zhang, who is visiting Taiwan in his capacity as a scholar and not as vice president of ARATS, were not very tight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-submarine helicopter crashes in eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: An anti-submarine helicopter carrying five officers crashed in waters of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan on Tuesday, leaving one dead, two injured, and another two missing, according to a statement issued by the military.

Coast Guard Administration forces discovered the site where the S-70C helicopter crashed, 50 nautical miles from Hualien County's Shihti fishing port, and rescued two injured crew members while recuperating the body of a crew member who died in the crash.
The helicopter went missing Tuesday evening after taking off from Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, and the Coast Guard was called by the Air Force to search the crash site at 9:40 p.m.
The accident marked the second military tragedy in two days.
A Taiwanese-made indigenous defense fighter (IDF) went missing near the Taiwan- held Penghu Island chain Monday morning.
Fragmented human remains that may be from one of the aircraft's two missing pilots were found Tuesday, along with more debris from the aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court invalidates election of KMT lawmaker

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan District Court ruled Tuesday to annul the election of lawmaker Liao Cheng-ching of the ruling Kuomintang for his involvement in bribery in the legislative elections early this year.

Right after Liao won the Jan. 12 vote in his constituency, his rival, Kuo Jung- chung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, filed a complaint against him with prosecutors for alleged bribery, saying that his election should be annulled.
The court ruled that Liao bribed members of his clan and the heads of local borough, the smallest administrative units in Taiwan, in his Taoyuan County constituency.

A borough chief known only by his surname Liao admitted in court that he received three separate payments of NT$100,000 (US$3,077) from Liao Cheng-ching, in exchange for wielding his influence in the borough to vote in favor of Liao Cheng-ching.
In addition, several witnesses of the Liao clan also admitted that they took money from Liao Cheng-ching and that they were willing to accept the ruling of deferred prosecution.

The court also said in its ruling that Liao Cheng-ching commissioned a borough chief surnamed Chen to pass NT$30,000 to his counterparts to subsidize their phone and gasoline expenses in mobilizing voters.
Although other borough chiefs did not agree to cast their votes for Liao Cheng- ching, the court said that this did not change the fact that he was engaged in bribery.
Upon hearing the verdict, Liao said that he would appeal and that justice will vindicate him, adding that he has served in public office for four decades and has always abided by the law.
Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said that Liao's fate is not yet final.
CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yu said that only if the Taiwan High Court upholds the annulment of Liao's election on appeal, will the election body organize a by-election if needed.

He said that in line with Public Officials Election and Recall Law, regulations, if the election of a regional lawmaker is annulled, the election commission will have to conduct a by-election within three months after receiving the verdict.
For those whose remaining tenure is less than one year, however, no by-election is necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 22, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Chinese official leaves Taiwan early after incident

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese official who was jostled to the ground by protesters in the southern city of Tainan a day earlier cut short his stay and left Taiwan Wednesday.

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was escorted under tight security by police at Kaohsiung International Airport, where he was again followed by a group of protesters.

Seeing Zhang off at the airport, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung apologized to Zhang over the incident and expressed the hope that it would not affect ARATS President Chen Yunlin's visit to Taiwan.
Zhang told reporters shortly before his departure that he decided to return to China a day early because he was sore from a leg injury he suffered when he hit the ground during Tuesday's incident.
Also, Zhang said he would feel bad if his stay were to require the protection of a large police force, which would incur high social costs.

Zhang said he believes the protesters represented only a small minority of people in Taiwan and that they will not succeed in their attempt to sabotage cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and hamper the development of cross-strait relations.

Zhang said his stay in Tainan over the last three days has given him an unforgettable impression, not because of the violent incident, but because of the warmth extended to him by various sectors in Taiwan.
At the head of a 22-member delegation, Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday to take part in an academic conference held in Tainan in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.

During a visit to the Confucius Temple in the southern city Tuesday, Zhang was besieged by a group of emotional anti-China protesters and fell to the ground after being grabbed at and jostled by two of the demonstrators.
The incident led to the transfer of Tainan City Police Bureau Commissioner Chen Fu-hsiang, who was held responsible for the security lapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: All military aircraft grounded except patrol and search planes

TEXT.P: Taiwan has grounded all military aircraft, except for those on search and routine patrol missions, for safety checks after a jet fighter and anti- submarine helicopter crashed on consecutive days, the Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said Wednesday.

Chen told lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee that all military aircraft not on search and patrol missions have been grounded for three days and will not be allowed back in the air until they pass a new round of safety checks.
Chen said he felt "sorry, upset and extremely sad" over the crash of an anti- submarine helicopter off Taiwan's east coast Tuesday evening -- the second military tragedy in two days.
A Taiwanese-made indigenous defense fighter (IDF) went missing near the Taiwan- held Penghu Islands chain Monday morning.
"I offer my utmost apology to the country for the loss of the two military aircraft and the lives of the people aboard," Chen said.

The S-70C anti-submarine helicopter, carrying five officers, crashed in waters 62 nautical miles off Hualien County in eastern Taiwan around 6: 44 p.m. Tuesday, leaving one dead, two injured, and another two missing.

Helicopter captain Liu Shih-chen, who sustained serious but not life-threatening injuries, and head mechanic Tang Chih-hsun, who suffered cuts on his right leg, were airlifted from Hualien Armed Forces General Hospital by helicopter Wednesday morning to Tri-Service General Hospital in Taipei for emergency treatment.
As of press time, the Navy as well as the Coast Guard were still searching for co-pilot Ou Shih-wen and surveillance officer Huang Chi-sheng, who have gone missing since the crash.
The fifth crew member, surveillance petty officer Chu Chun-teh, was killed in the crash, and his body has been retrieved from the sea.

The pilot and co-pilot of the missing IDF remained unaccounted for as of noon Wednesday. Fragmented human remains that may be from one of the aircraft's two missing pilots were found Tuesday, along with more debris from the aircraft, according to the Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: British consultant to help creative entrepreneurs start businesses

TEXT.P: The British Council Taipei has invited a well-known creative industries consultant and trainer, David Parish, to share the secrets of starting up new businesses with potential creative industry entrepreneurs in Taiwan.

Although Taiwan's creative industries have become a "hot" sector, British Council Director Christine Skinner said it is time to consider the next step for Taiwan's creative industries and bring together creative passion and top business practices.

Creative industries are worth investing in, Skinner said at a news conference held Tuesday to promote a book by Parish and a series of events in which he will participate at the upcoming Taiwan International Creative and Industries Exhibition.
Architecture, design, music, films, literature, all of that adds to the quality of people's lives and adds to people's sense of pride,she added.

It is based on that belief that the British Council decided to translate Parish's book, titledT-Shirts and Suits: A Guide to The Business of Creativity, into a traditional-Chinese e-book that is free to download.

Describing the relationship between people who work in the creative industries and businessmen asrock stars versus their managers, Skinner said the book is not about taming artists into becoming business people.

It just demonstrates that actually developing business skills is just not that hard. It's fast and simple and artists can do it, Skinner said, calling the book practical and straightforward without stifling creativity.

Noting that the British Council has done lots of work in the area of creative industries and still wants to do more, Skinner said the sector can be absolutely beneficial for a place like Taiwan which is full of fabulous cultural industries and creative industries with a real interest in the arts, culture, design, and architecture.
We think this is the right kind of thing for Taiwan,she said.

Parish is a business adviser, trainer and management consultant who works with creative businesses. Over the past few years, he has also been working with the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization as the director of theSharing Best Practices in the Creative Industriesproject.
Parish will visit Taiwan from Oct. 23-28 to give a series of lectures on how to integrate creativity and business.
Founded in 1934 and operating in 109 countries and territories, the British Council is the U.K.s international cultural relations organization.

The British Council Taipei was established in 1996 to build a mutually beneficial relationship between people in the U.K. and Taiwan and to increase the appreciation among Taiwan's people of the U.K.'s creative ideas and achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Speaker welcomes handling incident through legal channels

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng lauded the decision by a Chinese official who was harassed and jostled to the ground by a group of protesters to file a complaint over the incident through legal channels.

Zhang Mingqing, the vice president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , filed a complaint with law enforcement authorities in the southern city of Tainan Tuesday after he was besieged by pro-independence protesters.
The group shouted in his face and shoved him to the ground during a visit to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City.
"Turning the incident into a legal case is a good way to handle the matter," Wang said.
Some opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators defended the protesters' action, with one calling it "a relatively lenient way of treating Zhang by the Taiwanese people."
But Wang said meeting the ARATS deputy head in a violent way was not conducive to creating a peaceful atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait.
"People from the two sides should show respect and courtesy to each other for the purposes of creating peace, prosperity and a bright future," Wang said.

Wang called on local citizens to reflect on their behavior and adjust it accordingly, saying that "it is the responsibility of the citizens of a democratic nation to treat every visitor from outside the country with courtesy."

On criticism of the abrupt removal of the Tainan City Police Department chief from his post Tuesday in the wake of the incident, Wang said Taiwan is a multicultural society where differing voices are tolerated.

"Some people may think that the National Police Agency was doing the right thing by stripping the Tainan police chief of his post quickly, " Wang said, adding that everybody should respect the decisions made by the executive authorities.
DPP supporters have argued that the NPA's decision to remove the Tainan police chief constituted political persecution.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday to attend a cross-strait academic forum in his capacity as dean of the School of Journalism and Communications of Xiamen University in China's southeastern province of Fujian.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural agency to promote natural cleaning agent

TEXT.P: A government-run agricultural research center in the eastern county of Taitung has decided to promote the planting and use of Chinese soapberries, a common cleaning agent in pre-industrial times, researchers said Wednesday.

Officials at the Taitung District Agricultural Research and Extension Station, an affiliate of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, explained that before soaps and other artificial cleaning agents were mass produced, people in rural areas in Taiwan tended to made "do-it-yourself" soaps from the fruit of the Chinese soapberry tree, or sapindus mukorossii gaerm.

Recent research indicates, however, that the fruit's shell, which contains the natural cleaning agent saponin, also has anti-viral and antibiotic properties, leading the station to encourage the wider planting of the Chinese soapberry as a new cash crop and promote its use as an ingredient in lotions, soaps, cosmetics, and biomedical products.
Staffers said the station will hold a public presentation on Oct. 25 to further explain the use of Chinese soapberry and present the applications developed at the station.

Many advocates of natural living in the West are already touting the soapberry as a natural replacement for chemical detergents, especially since it can be grown in sufficient quantities to satisfy strong demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority supports planned visit by China's top negotiator: survey

TEXT.P: A majority of people responding to a recent survey are in favor of the planned visit of a high-ranking Chinese official to Taiwan, despite strong opposition to the visit by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , pollsters said Wednesday.

According to the results of the survey conducted by Global Views Monthly, 50.3 percent of the respondents supported the upcoming visit by Chen Yunlin, president of China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , while 31.2 percent of respondents opposed it.
The survey was carried out Oct. 14-16 via telephone among 1,005 adults around Taiwan. It had a margin of error of plus/minus 3.1 percent.
Chen is expected to arrive in Taiwan in late October or early November for a second round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
Chen and Chiang last held talks in June in Beijing, during which they signed agreements on the launch of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights on weekends and the arrival of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Items on the agenda for the upcoming encounter are expected to include the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights and direct shipping links and the establishment of more direct cross-strait air routes.

When respondents were asked about their opinions on the upcoming talks and which agreements would benefit Taiwan, the most popular choice favored by 64.3 percent of respondents was an agreement on a cross-strait reporting system on food safety issues.

Some 62.8 percent cited the launch of cross-strait cargo charter services as being helpful, 61.9 percent thought the opening of direct shipping links would provide a boost, and 58.2 percent felt extending the weekend cross-strait charter services to all days of the week would be beneficial.

Another 57 percent of respondents thought an increase in the number of routes and flights included in the charter services would be helpful, 56.2 percent felt the opening of more direct cross-strait air routes would be beneficial, and 51.3 percent said the expansion of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan would help.

When respondents were asked which of the potential agreements would benefit themselves or their families or relatives, only an agreement on a cross-strait reporting system on food safety issues received majority support -- 56.9 percent.
None of the other choices were selected by a majority of respondents.

The DPP is scheduled to hold a demonstration in Taipei Oct. 25 ahead of Chen's visit to express its opposition to the "one China market, the downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty and an incompetent government."

The DPP has accused President Ma Ying-jeou of sacrificing Taiwan's sovereignty by adopting a "modus vivendi" approach that advocates a "diplomatic truce" with China and introducing a series of cross-strait liberalization measures since his May 20 inauguration.

The party is also dissatisfied with what it contends is the Ma administration's failure to take a tough stance toward China in dealing with the scare over melamine-tainted processed food and ingredients imported from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower, moving down 80.13 points, or 1.62 percent, Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, to close at 4,862.59.
Suffering a drop from gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 4,843.71 and fluctuated between 4,955.61 and 4,839.17.
A total of 2.59 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$47.04 billion (US$1.43 billion).

Consistent with market movements since Oct. 13 when falls in share prices in Taiwan were limited to 3.5 percent, the local bourse retreated less than other major Asian markets on a generally bearish day.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell nearly 5 percent while Japan's Nikkei 225 lost 6.79 percent.
But the loss-limiting provision has also meant that when market sentiment has been positive, the TAIEX has not rebounded by as much as other Asian bourses.

All eight major stock categories lost ground Wednesday, with construction issues falling the most at 2.9 percent. Cement stocks dropped 2.5 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both decreased 1.9 percent, banking and financial shares were down 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues declined 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues lost 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares declined 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,165 to 285, with 355 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$4.07 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Violent incident will deal a blow to Taiwan tourism: official

TEXT.P: The violent incident in which demonstrators jostled a visiting Chinese liaison official to the ground will surely tarnish Taiwan's international image and deal a blow to its tourism development, a ranking Ministry of Transportation and Communications official predicted Monday.

Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Oliver Yu said the violence will also have an unavoidably adverse impact on the progress of cross-strait negotiations on expanded air transport exchanges and the opening of shipping links.

Yu made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan, where he was questioned by several ruling Kuomintang legislators on how he felt when Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, fell to the ground as he was besieged by pro-independence protesters. Zhang fell as he was being grabbed at and jostled by the demonstrators during a visit to the Confucius Temple in the southern city of Tainan Tuesday.
Yu said he felt very regretful and disturbed when he saw the footage of the incident on TV.
"The Ministry of Transportation and Communications will double its efforts to secure the safety of international tourists and Chinese holidaymakers on sightseeing trips to Taiwan," Yu stressed.

Yu said that apart from touting the attractions of its natural scenery, good social customs and local culture, the country must strive to ensure the personal safety and security of visitors, in its tourism promotion efforts.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22-member delegation to take part in an academic conference in Tainan in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University in Fujian Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.293 to close at NT$32.990.
A total of US$1.126 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.697 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.990.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November fell 162 points to close at 4,656, with 113,984 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 164 points to finish at 4,611, with 336 contracts traded, with March, June and September futures all falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent.

March futures fell 165 points to close at 4,566, with 34 contract transactions, while June futures lost 164 points to finish at 4,542, with 20 contract transactions. September futures were down 159 points to close at 4,384, with 31 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,818 for November, 4,775 for December, 4,731 for March, 4,706 for June and 4,543 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 80.13 points to finish at 4,862.59, on turnover of NT$47.04 billion (US$1.43 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower, with November TF, December TE and TF, and September TE and TF all falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent.
November TE futures fell 6.75 points to close at 189.95, with 3,973 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 6.8 points to finish at 188.65, with 47 contract transactions.
September TE futures declined 6.7 percent to end at 185.65, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June

November TF futures were down 18 points, also limit down, to close at 501.6, with 3,330 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were down 18 points to finish at 497, with 25 contracts traded.

June TF futures fell 11 points to close at 511, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures lost 17.6 points to end at 489, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment among indigenous people rising: official

TEXT.P: The jobless rate among indigenous people in Taiwan has surpassed the national unemployment rate, due to the economic recession, the minister in charge of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) Wednesday.
Chang Jen-hsiang made the remark in an oral report to the Internal Administration Committee of the Legislative Yuan on the CIP's 2009 policies and budget allocations.
Citing the latest CIP statistics, Chang said the jobless rate among indigenous people was recorded at 4.26 percent last December, an increase of 0.26 percent compared to the year-earlier level.
This figure was higher than the national monthly unemployment rate of 4.14 percent in August, released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Chang noted.

The council has therefore taken steps to help aboriginal people obtain jobs, he said, adding that 1,500 work opportunities will be made available and vocational training programs will be offered to indigenous people.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to take action to narrow health insurance deficit next year

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Wednesday that measures such as raising the health charge on cigarettes and the insurance premiums of the wealthy will be needed next year to reduce the national health insurance program's growing deficit.
At a committee hearing in the Legislative Yuan, legislators expressed concern over the health insurance system's serious deficit as they reviewed the DOH's budget.

Acknowledging that the DOH needed to find ways to plug the gap, Yeh said he expected to increase the compulsory "health donation" imposed on each pack of cigarettes to NT$20 (US$0.60) from the current NT$10, and raise the premiums of high-income earners by the end of this year or early next year.

"Preparations are underway, but we will present the plan (to the Legislative Yuan) at an appropriate moment," Yeh said, adding that he preferred waiting until the domestic economic situation was less tense.
By increasing the so-called health tax, the Bureau of National Health Insurance would receive an estimated NT$16-18 billion in added revenues per year, Yeh said.

At present, an NT$11.8 tobacco tax is also levied on each pack of cigarettes, but while most of the health charge goes to the health insurance bureau, revenues from the tobacco tax are allocated to general government expenditures.

Yeh also said he plans to raise premiums paid by the wealthy while lowering those paid by underprivileged members of society, but did not provide any further details on the income levels at which such adjustments would kick in.

The Bureau of National Health Insurance warned Wednesday that with the insurance premium rate having been maintained at 4.55 percent in 2008, the bureau would run an accumulated deficit of about NT$32.6 billion for the year.
It had proposed raising the rate to 5.18 percent in April to keep the deficit from growing, but most legislators opposed the idea.
In addition, President Ma Ying-jeou promised during his campaign that premiums would not be raised before the country's economic growth rate increased.
Premiums have only been raised once --from 4.25 percent to 4.55 percent in 2002 -- since the system was put into effect in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chief calls for continued cross-strait exchanges

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung called for continued exchanges across the Taiwan Strait Wednesday, and apologized for an assault against a visiting Chinese official.

"I hope that normal cross-strait exchanges and a planned visit by ARATS President Chen Yunlin would not be affected by the isolated incident involving ARATS Vice President Zhang Mingqing in Taiwan, " Chiang told reporters following a nearly 30-minute meeting with Zhang at the Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan before Zhang's departure.

Zhang, who was pulled and pushed to the ground Tuesday by a group of anti-China protesters in Taiwan's southern Tainan City, cut short his visit by two days and flew back to Beijing Wednesday morning, saying he felt sore from the assault and did not want to cause local police any additional inconvenience and expenses in terms of providing extra protection for him.

According to Chiang, Zhang told him during the meeting that he was confident cross-strait relations would not be hobbled by the incident and added that he would handle two-way exchanges in a "business as usual" manner.

Zhang was besieged by dozens of pro-independence supporters led by a Tainan City councilor who shouted in his face and jostled him to the ground while he was touring the Confucius Temple in Tainan City, accompanied only by a local official and tour guide.

The demonstrators were mobilized by Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and prosecutors later summoned Wang for questioning regarding the incident.
Wang told a news conference later that day that the incident mainly resulted from Zhang's remarks shortly before his visit to the temple that "without Taiwan independence, there will not be war."

Zhang suffered minor injuries in his right leg and waist and had his injuries x-rayed at a hospital in Tainan. The Chinese official filed a charge of assault against his attackers with local law enforcement authorities Tuesday.

SEF and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) are quasi-official organizations representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively, in handling bilateral activities in the absence of government-to-government contact between the two sides.
The attack against Zhang came ahead of what will be a landmark visit to Taiwan by ARATS President Chen Yunlin later this month or early next month.
Chen serves as China's top negotiator with Taiwan and will be the highest ranking Chinese official to visit the island since the two sides began a dialogue in 1992.
He is slated to hold talks with Chiang on expanding regular direct flights and other two-way exchanges.

At a news conference Wednesday, members of the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) asked DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen to harshly punish the culprits and demanded that the law enforcement authorities investigate the case in depth and hold those responsible accountable.
They raised concerns that foreign tourists would be afraid to come to Taiwan in the face of the DPP supporters' rude behavior against Zhang, who visited Taiwan for an academic seminar.

As the head of a 22-member delegation, Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a four-day visit. He took part in a seminar Monday at Tainan National University of the Arts in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.
A group of about 200 anti-China protesters demonstrated outside the university, with one protester heckling him while he made a speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: China repatriates 13 criminal offenders, illegal migrants to Taiwan

TEXT.P: China repatriated 13 Taiwanese nationals, including six criminal offenders, Wednesday, handing them over to police officers from Taiwan at a wharf on the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Matsu, which is only several kilometers off the coast of China's Fujian province.
Chinese public security officers transported the 13 Taiwanese expatriates to Matsu by boat and turned them over to the Taiwanese police officers in accordance with the Kinmen Agreement.

Under the Kinmen Agreement signed in September 1990 between Taipei and Beijing, the two sides are obligated to repatriate fugitives, criminals, wanted suspects and those who illegally cross the other side's borders.

Six criminal investigation police dispatched by the National Police Agency checked the identities of the Taiwanese expatriates and body-searched them before escorting them back to Taiwan on an airplane.
According to the police officers, the six criminal offenders were all wanted on felony charges, while the other seven men all entered China illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourism operators cancel Taiwan trip due to Zhang incident

TEXT.P: Seven members of a Chinese delegation that was slated to attend the 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair have canceled their plans to attend the Oct. 31-Nov.3 event, citing safety concerns after an assault by anti-China protesters against a visiting Chinese official, the organizer said Wednesday.

Chang Shuo-lao, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association which organizes the annual fair, said he had received dozens of telephone calls from Chinese nationals over the last two days asking "whether Taiwan is safe and if they can come."

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, was besieged by a group of emotional pro-independence activists during a visit to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City in southern Taiwan Tuesday.

Television footage showed Zhang being grabbed and shouted at by the protesters and then falling to the ground after being shoved, possibly inadvertently, by two of the protesters. The incident caused Zhang to cut short his Taiwan visit.

Chang said the incident has impacted to a certain degree on the travel plans by Chinese tourists to Taiwan. However, he added, he believes China's National Tourism Administration Deputy Director Zhang Xiqin will attend the Taipei fair as scheduled.

The Zhang incident resulted in a drop in the number of the Chinese delegates to the travel fair to 290, with those who canceled including provincial officials in charge of tourism affairs, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to invest NT$3.7 billion in bid to raise employment rate

TEXT.P: In an effort to raise the employment rate amid the global economic downturn, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will invest NT$3.7 billion to implement a series of measures to help people find jobs, said CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan Wednesday.

"These short-term measures to boost employment are expected to help 30,000 jobless people," said Wang at a press conference, adding that the CLA will assess the economic situation to decide whether to expand the program.

Under the program, enterprises will be offered incentives to hire jobless Taiwanese workers. Enterprises that provide a job for an unemployed person who was without a job for three or more consecutive months will be eligible to apply, before March 2009, for a monthly subsidy of NT$10,000 over a six-month period.

In addition, local authorities that offer temporary jobs to underprivileged workers, in areas such as outdoor cleaning, tour guide services and community care services, will be eligible to a daily subvention of NT$800, or NT$17,600 per month, according to the CLA.
Enterprises approved by the CLA may also apply for a six-month subvention if they hire young first-time job seekers who have been unemployed for a long period of time, Wang said.

She urged non-governmental organizations to come up with plans to help jobless people find employment, saying that the CLA will offer subsidies to organizations that do so. Due to the current financial crisis in the United States, the stock market slump and other economic factors, the number of jobless people has increased to more than 464,000, according to CLA estimates.

The unemployment rate also reached 4.27 percent in September, marking the highest level in the past four years, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22 Navy officers disciplined over grounding of missile boat

TEXT.P: Twenty-two naval officers, including the commander of the Republic of China Navy, have been disciplined over the grounding of the Kuang Hua No. 6 Missile Speedboat off the coast of southern Taiwan in late September, Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min disclosed Wednesday.

Answering questions before the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee, Chen said that in a review report on the accident, the Ministry of National Defense concluded that human error was the direct cause of the boat's grounding off the coast of Chiayi County while it was taking part in the Han Kuang No. 24 Military Exercise.
As a result, the ministry penalized the 22 naval officers responsible for the accident in accordance with its penal code, he said.
The fast-attack missile boat ran aground Sept. 25 in bad weather. The 14 crewmen on board were rescued shortly after the mishap.
In the following days, rescue workers from the Navy removed the four Hsiung Feng anti-ship missiles, the navigation system and other important equipment from the vessel.

On Oct. 10, a salvage team of the Navy used two giant cranes to pull the 150-ton boat out of shallow waters and towed it to Chiayi County's Budai harbor for a preliminary welding job to repair the vessel before moving it to Kaohsiung harbor in southern Taiwan for an overhaul.
Although the hull of the boat appeared in a satisfactory condition, Navy frogmen who inspected the damage below water said they discovered five holes in the bottom of the vessel.

The missile boat is a prototype designed by the Navy under its Kuang Hua No. 6 Missile Speedboat Plan to phase out the 50-ton Seagull-Class missile boats. It is 34 meters long and 7.6 meters wide, with a top speed of 34 knots.

Under the Kuang Hua No. 6 plan, 30 boats will be built at a cost of about NT$400 million (US$12.29 million) each. The state-run Kaohsiung-based CSBC Corp. Taiwan -- the nation's largest shipbuilder -- began building the boats in November 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes for enhanced Taiwan-France relations

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he hopes relations between Taiwan and France will be enhanced with the help of Patrick Bonneville, the new director- general of the French Institute in Taipei.
Ma made the remarks in a meeting at the Presidential Office with Bonneville, who assumed his post in September.
Ma said Bonneville, who is very familiar with Asian affairs and speaks good Mandarin, will help facilitate the continued growth of the bilateral relations.
The president pointed out that the two countries have developed close trade relations and enjoy an annual bilateral trade volume of US$6 billion.

Taiwan and France also have close cultural interactions, he noted. Citing the popularity of the exhibition of French artist Jean-Francois Millet's works that ended in early September in Taiwan, Ma said French fine art is appreciated by many Taiwanese.
The two countries have also cooperated in the area of technology for many years, Ma said, noting that the French-made Mirage aircraft is the mainstay of Taiwan's air defense.

Bonneville said he viewed his posting to Taiwan as a great honor. The French government highly values its relations with Taiwan, as French businesses have invested substantially in Taiwan, which is the world's 15th largest economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP calls for participation in Saturday's mass protest rally

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on Wednesday called on the public to join an upcoming mass protest, which is being sponsored by the DPP, to make their views known to the government.
Tsai, at a news conference to promote the Oct. 25 demonstration, said the party has three questions for President Ma Ying-jeou.
The first question is "whether his promise that the future of Taiwan will be decided by Taiwan's 23 million people still counts, " she said.
The second is whether he defines Taiwan as an area or a sovereign independent country, Tsai said.

She was referring to Ma's remarks in a recent interview with a foreign media service that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have special relations, but not a state-to-state relationship. Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi later described the relations between Taiwan and the mainland as relations between the Taiwan area and the mainland area.

Finally, Tsai said, the party wants to know if the Ma administration intends to ask China to apologize and compensate Taiwan for exporting toxic foods, including melamine-contaminated dairy products, to the island, which caused a scare among the local people.

She noted that after the August 30 "People's Outcry" march against Ma administration's tilt towards China and the economic woes, the president commented that only 50,000 had joined the protest. This shows that the president has only "numbers" on his mind, she added.
The August march, sponsored by pro-independence civic group Taiwan Society, drew a far greater number of protesters than 50,000, according to the DPP estimate.
Although Ma said he hoped his performance would live up to the expectations of the people, the discrepancy between his actions and his promises has widened, Tsai claimed.

Also attending the news conference were former DPP chairmen Yao Chia-wen, Yu Shyi-kun, Su Cheng-chang and all the DPP central standing committee members. Two other former chairmen, Hsu Hsin-liang and Frank Hsieh, were absent.

The Ma administration should not allow China's top liaison official to come to Taiwan, otherwise the Taiwan people would "take substantial action to express their views on safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty," Su said.
Su was referring to a planned visit later this month or next month by Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
Meanwhile, the DPP decided after its central standing committee meeting Wednesday that Saturday's rally will not be extended to a night vigil.
The party will postpone the date for the vigil until Chen arrives in order to drive home its appeal, Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said.

Cheng said that the party will set a new date to hold the vigil, originally scheduled for Oct. 28-30, and the "safeguarding Taiwan" night rally that was slated for Oct. 31 in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to host largest travel fair in Asia

TEXT.P: The largest travel fair in Asia will open in Taipei Oct. 31 with the participation of 62 countries, in a bid to reinvigorate Taiwan's tourism industry, the organizers said Wednesday.

Stanley Yen, chairman of the organizing committee, said at a press conference Wednesday that this year a number of new exhibitors will join the Taipei International Travel Fair (Taipei ITF) , which will run through Nov. 3 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

"The inclusion of new participants, such as Singapore Airlines, Taiwan Tobacco Company and Slovenia, symbolizes the opportunities for development in Taiwan's tourism industry despite the global economical crisis," said Yen, a well-known hotelier.
According to a top tourism official, the fair this year is set to be a record- breaking event.

"Taipei ITF 2008 is the biggest and most important in the Asian travel and tourism industry, " said Janice Seh-jen Lai, head of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The participation of 62 countries showcasing their products at more than 1,200 booths will set a new record in the fair's 22-year history, she added.
Visitors to Taipei ITF 2008 will also have free access to the Cross-Strait Travel Fair, which focuses on travel on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to a spokesman for the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair to open Oct. 31

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair will open Oct. 31 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 1 for a four-day run.
According to the event's organizer, Taiwan Visitors Association, travel industry exhibitors from 62 countries will operate a record number of 1,206 stalls at the travel fair.
The exhibition will be divided into two parts -- an area for international exhibitors and an area for exhibitors from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
According to the organizer, many travel agencies and hotels will be offering big discounts -- from 33 percent to 50 percent -- to attract customers.
Admission to the exhibition will be NT$200, and those who buy 10 tickets or more at a time will be given a 20 percent discount.

Exhibitors at the annual travel fair include airlines, travel agencies, hotels, government tourism offices, land operators, cruise lines, bus operators, car rental companies, trade publications and other travel related organizations and enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign affairs minister departs for two west African countries

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco H. L. Ou left Taiwan Wednesday at the head of a delegation on a visit to The Gambia and Burkina Faso -- two of Taiwan's allies in West Africa.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release that during the visit, Ou will call on the presidents of the two countries and meet with other dignitaries there.
He will also review the execution and the results of Taiwan's cooperation projects with the countries before returning home Nov.4.

In addition, Ou will preside over the seventh meeting of the mixed commission of cooperation between Taiwan and Burkina Faso in its capital, Ouagadougou, and preside over an African regional working meeting.
He will also discuss cooperation projects between Taiwan and Burkina Faso in the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council to offer more temporary jobs to the unemployed

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan announced several employment stimulus measures Wednesday to help people in need and she urged companies to hire more jobless people.

In a letter sent to enterprises, Wang asked business owners to join the CLA's employment stimulus program to provide the jobless with employment opportunities at a time when the whole world is experiencing a financial squeeze and an economic downturn.

One of the measures is to increase the number of temporary jobs for unemployed members of underprivileged families, Wang said, disclosing that some 2,500 temporary jobs offered by the CAL in September had all been snapped up.

Wang said the CLA plans to provide an additional 6,000 temporary jobs in the public sector for a period of six months to one year. The measure is aimed at helping to provide some income to members of underprivileged families who have been unemployed for a long time, she explained.

Such short-term jobs will include street cleaning and tour guide and community services, and will offer a daily subsidy of NT$800 for 22 days in each month during the period from November this year to April next year, Wang said.

About 452,000 people were jobless in August, marking an unemployment rate of 4.1 percent, according to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS). The jobless rate for September rose further 4.27 percent.

At the same time, Wang said, the CLA will earmark NT$3.7 billion (US$113 million) to help at least 30,000 jobless people find employment. This project will go into effect immediately and will run until the end of June next year, she said.

Under another "Get to Work" plan by the CLA, companies that hire a Taiwanese worker who has been jobless for three or more consecutive months will be entitled to a CLA subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for a maximum period of six months, according to Wang. Some 10,000 people are expected to find placements in the initial stages of the plan, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF deputy chief in China to fix agenda for new round of talks

TEXT.P: The deputy head of Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body for engagement with China is currently in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen to work on an agenda for a second round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, a senior official confirmed Wednesday.

"Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), traveled to Shenzhen earlier in the day to negotiate the agenda for a second round of talks with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS)," said Liu Te-shun, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

As the topics to be discussed in the second round of the SEF-ARATS talks will include transportation and health issues, Liu said, both the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the Department of Health (DOH) have sent staff members to accompany Kao on his current visit.
Liu, however, would not reveal the level of the ARATS official with whom Kao is dealing, saying only the ARATS representative is at a level parallel to Kao's.

As to whether Kao will touch on the issue of the itinerary for the ARATS chief's planned visit to Taiwan to meet a second time since June with his SEF counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, Liu said Kao's talks will focus on the agenda for the Chiang-Chen meeting and will not touch on the schedule for Chen's visit.
According to Liu, Chen's Taiwan itinerary will be addressed during a preliminary round of consultations and the dates for the preliminary round of talks will be announced later.
Liu said Kao will return to Taipei in the next couple of days.

Despite an incident in which an ARATS deputy chief, Zhang Mingqing, was besieged and jostled to the ground by pro-independence activists during a visit to the southern Taiwan city of Tainan Tuesday, Chen Yunlin, China's top liaison with Taiwan, will visit Taiwan later this year as originally scheduled, officials from both sides of the Taiwan Strait confirmed Wednesday.
Zhang, who was visiting Taiwan as a journalism scholar, cut short his visit and returned to China Wednesday.

The weighted price index lost 80.13 points, or 1.62 percent, to close at 4,862.59 Wednesday.

The greenback was trading at NT$33.194 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.204 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 23, or the 25th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Government should support small & medium enterprises:consultant firm

TEXT.P: A human resource consultant company said Wednesday that given the global credit crisis, many enterprises in Taiwan may lay off staff after the Lunar New Year and that the government should focus its efforts on supporting small and medium enterprises.

Wu Rey-yin, CEO of 1111 Human Resource Bank, said that many enterprises are planning to cut staff to lower their operating costs. If the economic slowdown continues, layoffs may increase after the Lunar New Year, he added.
Unemployment for September reached 4.27 percent, and enterprises are cutting costs by slashing employee salaries, Wu said, adding that all this points to an economic slowdown.
Wu said that according to government statistics, small and medium business enterprises employed 77.12 percent of the workforce in Taiwan at the end of 2007.
Given this figure, he recommended that the government should focus its efforts on supporting these enterprises as a means of rescuing the economy.
In Taiwan, many employees tend to switch jobs and employers make staff changes during the Lunar New Year, which is when most enterprises give year-end bonuses.
