DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes for enhanced Taiwan-France relations

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he hopes relations between Taiwan and France will be enhanced with the help of Patrick Bonneville, the new director- general of the French Institute in Taipei.
Ma made the remarks in a meeting at the Presidential Office with Bonneville, who assumed his post in September.
Ma said Bonneville, who is very familiar with Asian affairs and speaks good Mandarin, will help facilitate the continued growth of the bilateral relations.
The president pointed out that the two countries have developed close trade relations and enjoy an annual bilateral trade volume of US$6 billion.

Taiwan and France also have close cultural interactions, he noted. Citing the popularity of the exhibition of French artist Jean-Francois Millet's works that ended in early September in Taiwan, Ma said French fine art is appreciated by many Taiwanese.
The two countries have also cooperated in the area of technology for many years, Ma said, noting that the French-made Mirage aircraft is the mainstay of Taiwan's air defense.

Bonneville said he viewed his posting to Taiwan as a great honor. The French government highly values its relations with Taiwan, as French businesses have invested substantially in Taiwan, which is the world's 15th largest economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign affairs minister departs for two west African countries

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco H. L. Ou left Taiwan Wednesday at the head of a delegation on a visit to The Gambia and Burkina Faso -- two of Taiwan's allies in West Africa.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said in a press release that during the visit, Ou will call on the presidents of the two countries and meet with other dignitaries there.
He will also review the execution and the results of Taiwan's cooperation projects with the countries before returning home Nov.4.

In addition, Ou will preside over the seventh meeting of the mixed commission of cooperation between Taiwan and Burkina Faso in its capital, Ouagadougou, and preside over an African regional working meeting.
He will also discuss cooperation projects between Taiwan and Burkina Faso in the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record number of Japan local governors visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that exchanges between Taiwan's and Japan's local governments are very close, noting that the number of Japanese governors visiting Taiwan so far this year has already reached a record high.

"To date, 12 Japanese local governors have visited or are scheduled to visit Taiwan this year, which is a record, " said Hsu Juei-hu, deputy secretary- general of the MOFA's Association of East Asian Relations, at a regular press briefing.
He added that several mayors and magistrates from Taipei, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi, Hualien and other cities and counties in Taiwan have also visited Japan this year.
Masanori Tanimoto, governor of Japan's Ishikawa Prefecture, and Wataru Aso, governor of Fukuoka, are slated to visit Taiwan Nov. 5-7 and Nov. 10-12, respectively, according to Hsu.
He also announced that the 33rd Taiwan-Japan economic and trade conference will be held Nov. 5-6 in Taipei, with more than 100 government officials from Japan and Taiwan set to attend.

Since 1976, the annual meeting has been held alternately in Tokyo and Taipei under the co-organization of the MOFA's Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's Interchange Association -- the two quasi-official organizations in charge of bilateral relations since Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

Asked about other aspects of exchanges between Taiwan and Japan, Hsu said the two countries have been discussing launching a working holiday visa program that would allow young people to supplement their travel through incidental employment.
"We've been engaged in talks with our Japanese counterparts on the issue and have begun discussions on the details of the plan," Hsu said.
"We should be seeing great results soon, and I hope that the deal can be sealed by the end of this year," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ridership on Kaohsiung MRT down on first of regular fares

TEXT.P: Ridership on the Kaohsiung MRT on Wednesday -- the first day of service at regular fares -- was down by 12,000 over the level for the previous day, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) said Thursday.
Fares on the southern port city's MRT had been reduced to NT$15 (US$0.45) for the Sept. 22-Oct. 21 period to celebrate the launch of service on the Orange Line on Sept. 14.
Passengers numbers for Wednesday reached 102,000 -- with 78,000 riders using the Red Line and 24,000 using the Orange Line -- down from Tuesday's total of 114,000, according to KRTC stats.
With the launch of regular fares Wednesday, the KRTC also began offering 15-percent discounts for passengers using I-Pass cards.

Huang Yi-chung, director of the KRTC's Public Affairs Department, said that the company decided to offer the discounted fare for I-Pass holders after taking both costs and ridership numbers into consideration.
He added that the KRTC will be looking particularly closely at what effect the discounted fare has on weekend passenger numbers following the launch of regular fare rates.
Huang also confirmed that although ridership was down by 12,000 on Wednesday, the KRTC's total revenue from ticket sales for the day was higher than during the period of discounted fares of NT$15.
The regular fare on the Red and Orange Lines is set at between NT$20-60 depending on the distance of the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's top negotiator with Taiwan may visit Taiwan Nov. 3: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has suggested that China's top negotiator with Taiwan arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for a five-day visit, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is expected to meet with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) for cross-strait talks during his visit, Lai said at a news conference.
Chen will be the highest-level Chinese official to visit Taiwan.

Chen, Chiang and their respective delegations are expected to discuss a wide range of topics, including food safety concerns related to China's export to Taiwan of substandard food products and ingredients that were tainted with the toxic industrial chemical melamine, according to Lai.

The much talked about Chiang-Chen meeting will be a follow-up to alandmark meeting in Beijing between the two in mid-June during which both sides reached an agreement on weekend cross-strait charter flights and the expansion of the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.306 to close at NT$33.296.
A total of US$1.613 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.990 and closed at the day's high of NT$33.408.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent for November, December, March, June and September.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 162 points to finish at 4,494, with 28,439 contracts traded. December futures declined 161 points to end at 4,450, with 310 contracts traded.

March futures fell 159 points to close at 4,407, with 22 contract transactions, while June futures lost 158 points to finish at 4,384, with 37 contract transactions. September futures were down 153 points to close at 4,231, with 31 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,656 for November, 4,611 for December, 4,566 for March, 4,542 for June and 4,384 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 132.08 points to finish at 4,730.51, on turnover of NT$25.73 billion (US$771.12 million).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower, with November TE and TF, December TE and TF, and September TF futures all falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent.

November TE futures fell 6.6 points to close at 183.25, with 598 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 6.6 points to finish at 182.05, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
November TF futures were down 17.4 points to close at 484.2, with 844 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were down 17.2 points to finish at 479.8, with 10 contracts traded.
September TF futures fell 17 points to close at 472, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices plunged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 132.08 points, or 2.71 percent, to close at 4,730.51.
Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 4,706.13 and reached a high of 4,730.51 during trading.
A total of 1.71 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$25.73 billion (US$771.12 million).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and banking and financial shares both at 3.3 percent, cement stocks and construction issues both at 3.2 percent, textile stocks at 2.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 2.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,341 to 159, with 245 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$428 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: National industrial federation promises 5,000 jobs

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) announced Thursday that it will try its best to provide 5,000 openings for the country's jobless to work for a maximum period of six months.

The commitment, announced by CNFI Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung, represented a favorable and immediate response to a package of employment stimulus measures put forward by Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan the day before.

One CLA program, dubbed "Get to work immediately, " invites privately run companies to hire Taiwanese workers who have been jobless for three or more consecutive months to work at their companies for a maximum period of six months.
These companies would then be entitled to a CLA subsidy of NT$10,000 per month for each newly hired worker.
The CLA is planning to help some 10,000 people find jobs under this program, according to Wang.
The CNFI chairman made the commitment during a luncheon with Wang and other CLA officials Thursday.

Speaking at the luncheon, the CLA minister quoted statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, indicating that some 464,000 people were jobless in September, marking an unemployment rate of 4.27 percent -- the highest for the past four years.

"The figures are alarmingly high and I appeal to all members of the public and private sectors -- management and workers alike -- to make concerted efforts to help the country survive the economic volatility triggered by the recent global economic storm," Wang said.

Also speaking at the luncheon, Chen said that the offer of a subsidy of NT$10,000 per worker per month was a sincere bid by the CLA to rev up employment, but it would not be the best policy to tackle the root of the country's economic woes.
"This trying time could also be an opportune time for the government to review its existing economic and labor policies and revise them accordingly," Chen suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to expand National Development Fund to stabilize economy

TEXT.P: The Cabinet decided Thursday to expand the size of the National Development Fund from NT$200 billion (US$6.01 billion) to NT$1 trillion to increase government investment in local businesses, in a bid to stabilize the country's economic situation.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said after a Cabinet meeting that the decision was made in light of the serious impact of the global financial crisis on Taiwan's economy.

Chen said the Cabinet is planning to obtain the additional NT$800 billion through a loan from the state-owned Chunghwa Post Co. and invest the fund in the manufacturing and service sectors to provide momentum to the economy.

In the future, the purposes of the National Development Fund will not be limited to venture capital investment and loans to businesses, but will expand to include participation in the capital increase, reorganization, merger and acquisition of businesses, Chen said.
He said the government is also considering the possibility of corporatizing the National Development Fund to make its operations more flexible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC wants to join international wetlands convention: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope Thursday that the Republic of China on Taiwan can become a contracting party to The Convention on Wetlands of International Importance.

The wetlands convention, also known as the Ramsar Convention, is an intergovernmental treaty signed in Iran in 1971 which provides a framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and wise use of wetlands and their resources. There are currently 158 signatory countries and areas to the convention.

In a written statement addressed to the opening of the Society of Wetland Scientists (SWS) Asia Chapter's 1st Asian Wetland Convention and Workshop being held in Taipei Oct. 23-26, Ma said that the ROC wants to join the convention in order to make a contribution to global ecological conservation efforts.

Noting that Taiwan is surrounded on all sides by water, has diverse topography, enjoys a rich ecology, and is home to extensive wetlands, Ma said that through the efforts of the Construction and Planning Agency under the Minister of the Interior, the government plans to set aside 75 areas as protected wetlands.

Besides promoting concrete conservation and management measures for the wetland areas, the government will also work to raise the general public's awareness of the importance of protecting these areas as well as increase the people's environmental consciousness.
Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Ramsar Convention, it has strongly supported its principles and regulations and is seeking to become a member, Ma said.

Interior Minister Liao Liao-yi said in a speech at the opening of the SWS conference that the 75 wetland areas to be set aside as protected areas together make up 1.23 percent of Taiwan's total land area.

Noting that the Construction and Planning Agency and related local government agencies have extensive experience in the management of wetlands, Liao said he hopes that Taiwan can share some of this experience and knowledge with the rest of the world during the conference.

The 1st Asian Wetland Convention and Workshop is being held at the National Taiwan University Hospital International Convention Center. The conference, whose theme is Asian Wetlands: Global Position, will cover four major topics, including ecological, economic and cultural significance of Asian wetlands; wetland technology and restoration; operation and management of wetlands; and global and local community participation and education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Offender asks DPP to punish him for harassing Chinese official

TEXT.P: The man who jumped onto the hood of a visiting Chinese official's car and fiercely stamped on it earlier in the week made a public apology Thursday for his rough behavior and asked the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to punish him.

The DPP member, identified as Lin Chin-shun, apologized for the problems and the damage to the public and party image caused by his behavior, and asked the DPP's Tainan city committee to penalize him.

Lin, however, declined to apologize to Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), who was visiting Tainan City in southern Taiwan that day. Lin insisted that Zhang was "an enemy."
Lin asserted that he will never give in to pressure and apologize to Zhang, saying that he was safeguarding Taiwan's independent sovereignty.
The case will be referred to and handled by the DPP's central authorities, said officials of the party's Tainan city branch.
Lin and Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu were questioned by prosecutors Tuesday after the incident.
The demonstrators were mobilized by Wang, who argued that they were angered by Zhang's remarks earlier Tuesday on Taiwan independence. Wang also rejected to apologize to Zhang.

Zhang filed a formal complaint with police against those who harassed him Tuesday during a private visit to the Confucius Temple in Tainan City. He was besieged by dozens of pro-Taiwan independence supporters who shouted in his face and jostled him to the ground as he was walking in the temple.
Zhang cut short his visit to Taiwan and returned to Beijing Wednesday.

Zhang arrived in Taiwan Sunday at the head of a 22-member delegation for a four- day visit. He took part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts Monday in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the school of journalism at Xiamen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan says it respects French court's ruling on Tahiti land dispute

TEXT.P: The government respects a recent ruling by a French court recognizing Taiwan's judicial role in a land dispute with China on the French Polynesian island of Tahiti, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
The government will continue pushing its plea for the return of the land to its original donor, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said.

At issue is a plot of land in Papeete, capital of Tahiti, which was donated by an overseas Chinese group to the Republic of China government before World War II for the purpose of building a consulate.

After France switched diplomatic recognition from the ROC to the People's Republic of China (PRC) in 1964, the ROC government, in an attempt to prevent Beijing from taking over the property, had the pro-Taipei donor file a lawsuit in Tahiti in 1978 to confirm its ownership of the property.
The PRC, which did not legally claim ownership of the piece of land until 2003, won the case in 2004.

Both the land's original donor and the ROC government appealed against the ruling in 2005, but Tahitian judicial authorities in 2006 challenged Taiwan's eligibility as an appellant on the grounds that the ROC's statehood is not recognized internationally.
The case, however, was later moved by the French supreme court to the appeals court in Paris after it became known that Beijing had tried to influence the case's proceedings in Tahiti.

According to a report filed by AFP from Paris Wednesday, the appeals court in Paris ruled last week that Taiwan's case could be heard "independent of the diplomatic situation" even given Taipei's status as a "Chinese state not recognized by the international community."

Guillaume Selnet, the lawyer representing the ROC government in the case, was quoted in the report as saying that the decision "formalizes the recognition of Taiwan by the French judicial authorities."
"If Taiwan can play a judicial role, it follows that the Republic of China must exist," Selnet said.
The ROC government has been struggling for international recognition since it lost a civil war in 1949 to the Chinese communists, which founded the PRC that year.

Over the past decades, the ROC government has lost most of its diplomatic allies to the PRC. Twenty-three countries now maintain diplomatic relations with the ROC, almost half of which are in Central America and the Caribbean region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rivers contribute to natural carbon sequestration mechanism: study

TEXT.P: A collaborative research project between Taiwan and Britain has found that rivers in the western Pacific region play a vital role in the land-to-sea transfer of organic carbon, with the rivers accounting for more than one-third of the total carbon transferred from land to sea, academic sources said Thursday.

Moreover, researchers said, the carbon-transferring efficacy may be amplified by the periodical onset of typhoons, as evidence indicates that over the past several decades, 77 percent to 92 percent of the organic carbon transferred to sea by riverine waters was done so during typhoon-induced floods.

In addition, the research also indirectly supports the hypothesis that forests contribute greatly to the capture of air-borne carbon particulates, as the results show that when trees and tree parts were washed down to the river by torrential rains, the carbon concentrations in the rivers would jump to much higher levels.

The project, co-led by Robert G. Hilton of University of Cambridge and Chen Hon- gey of National Taiwan University, surveyed the Li-wu River in eastern Taiwan in 2004 to determine the effect of typhoons on the fluctuations in the river's carbon concentrations.

By comparing the river sediments collected on typhoon days and on normal days, Chen said the researchers discovered that during the two typhoons in 2004, namely Mindulle in June and Aere in August, the concentrations of organic carbon originating from fossils and rocks remained at roughly the same levels, while concentrations of organic carbon originating from vegetation and soil increased tremendously.
The ratio of vegetation/soil-originating organic carbon to fossil/rock- originating organic carbon rose from 10:90 on normal days to 43:57 on days during typhoons, Chen said.
Furthermore, during torrential rains and floods, the carbon particles in the river may be sent directly to the ocean floors, where great amounts of carbon can be stored, according to Chen.
"The mechanism may help cut the amount of carbon in the air, and eventually reduce the global greenhouse effect," he added.
The results of the research project have been published in the Oct. 19 issue of Nature Geoscience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP Lu arrives in Mexico to attend BPW International Congress
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 22 (CNA) 10/23/08 18:10:38 (by Ramon Huang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu arrived in Mexico City early Tuesday morning to attend the upcoming 26th BPW International Congress.

Lu, heading a 14-member delegation of the Taiwan chapter of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, flew to the Mexican capital from San Francisco where she had made a short transit stop.
Chen Hsin-tung, Taiwan's representative to Mexico, and his wife as well as staff of the representative office were on hand to greet Lu and her delegation at the airport.
Chen expressed his respect and admiration for Lu's strenuous efforts to promote Taiwan's diplomacy as well as gender equality in the country since her term as vice president ended earlier this year.

Taiwan's representative office held a welcome dinner Tuesday evening at a club for Lu and her delegation, with organizers of the BPW conference and members of the Taiwan expatriate community attending.

The BPW International Congress is slated to be held Oct. 24-28 under the theme "Power to Make a Difference." It will feature several workshops addressing leadership development, successful strategies to enable women to gain economic independence, emerging issues for women in the 21st century, and a variety of other related topics.
Lu is scheduled to give a keynote speech titled "Letting Women Write History" on the second day of the conference.
The former vice president and her delegation will depart Mexico in separate groups on Oct. 28 and 29, making transit stops in Los Angeles en route back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: City gov't urged to enhance education for new immigrants' children

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Kuo-cheng urged the city government in southern Taiwan at a council session Thursday to provide more after-school tutoring to children of new immigrants.

Lin said more attention should be paid to this group of children as their population is growing and the children generally do not get sufficient help from their parents, who tend to have lower education and income levels compared to the general public.

In 2007, the city had 5,123 elementary and junior high school students who were born from marriages between Taiwanese citizens and foreign spouses, most of whom came from China and Southeast Asian countries.
The number of such students in the city was up by over 30 percent from the figure registered in 2005, Lin said.
He noted that 31 percent of children of new immigrants lived in the city's Chienchen and Hsiaokang districts, two industrial areas where most residents are wage laborers.

While new immigrants and their Taiwanese spouses tend to have lower education levels and income, they have a higher number of children, and it is common that their children do not receive proper learning assistance from their parents, Lin said.
Lin expressed his worries that without enough support in education, these children may suffer many setbacks in learning and may step on the wrong track in life.

Yen Chi-ping, a section chief of the city's Education Bureau, on Thursday promised to strengthen after-school education programs for new immigrants' children who appeared to be falling behind in their academic performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Key figure in diplomatic fraud scandal sentenced to jail

TEXT.P: A man convicted of being an accomplice in a diplomatic fraud case in which Taiwan was duped out of nearly US$30 million, was given a jail sentence of two years and four months Thursday.
Taipei District Court judges sentenced Wu Shih-Tsai, an ethnic Chinese man from Singapore, on convictions of forgery and making false accusations.

Wu was indicted on Sept. 5 on the charges by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office after it discovered that Wu provided the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) with false bank statement regarding the money, which was intended to help Taiwan build diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea.
The prosecutors said that Wu, after the exposure of the scandal in May this year, also falsely claimed that he had been threatened at gunpoint.

Wu and his partner Ching Chi Ju, who was commissioned by the MOFA in 2006 to help broker a deal for the establishment of diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea, allegedly embezzled the US$29.8 million intended as aid funds for the Pacific nation.
Wu could be convicted of embezzling the money after further overseas investigations are carried out, the judges said.
Wu was taken into custody by prosecutors in May and had been prohibited from leaving Taiwan, but Ching remains on the run.
Prosecutors said they are still investigating whether any former government officials, including former Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, were culpable in the case.

The scandal had resulted in the resignations of three senior government officials of the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, including Chiou; former Foreign Minister James Huang; and former Deputy Defense Minister Ko Chen-heng.

DOC.HEADLINE: President has not changed position on China missile threat: official

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has never given up on his demand for China to remove its missiles targeting Taiwan, in his work to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a Presidential Office official said Thursday.
Spokesman Wang Yu-chi dismissed as a "pseudo issue" a claim by former President Chen Shui-bian that Ma has abandoned his position on the Chinese missile threat.

In a statement issued earlier in the day, Chen accused Ma of "deliberately avoiding" any mention of the missile issue while speaking on the possibility of a cross-Taiwan Strait accord, in a recent interview with the India and Global Affairs quarterly.
Ma had previously said cross-strait peace talks would only be possible if China removes its more than 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture council announces fertilizer price cut

TEXT.P: The price of a type of fertilizer derived from petroleum will be cut by NT$50 (US$1.52) per 40-kg bag, effective Nov. 1, due to declining oil prices, Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung announced Thursday.

Chen had indicated on Monday that local urea prices might be reduced due to continued declines in oil prices in the world market, although the government promised that present fertilizer prices would be maintained through the end of the year when it imposed a price hike on May 30.

The prices of other kinds of fertilizers, however, will not be adjusted down for the time being, as international raw material prices have shown no sings of abating, Chen told reporters following a weekly Executive Yuan meeting.
Urea is the only chemical fertilizer derived from petroleum.
Following the May 30 price adjustment, a 40-kg bag of urea was priced at NT$520-NT$530, up from the previous level of about NT$360-NT$370.

In line with the Executive Yuan's efforts to promote Taiwan-made products, the COA will also sponsor a local farm products promotion fair in Taipei City on the coming weekend, featuring fruit, tea, flowers, liquor and vegetables, Chen said.

During the weekly Cabinet meeting, the Executive Yuan also approved a rural village renewal draft bill aimed at helping improve the livelihoods of some 600,000 families at more than 4,000 villages across the country.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the bill's projects will be included into the government's 12 mega-development program, with a fund of NT$150 billion (US$4.5 billion) set up to serve that end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global greenback shortage not to affect Taiwan: CEPD

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) gave the assurance Thursday that Taiwan's economy is not vulnerable to the recent global shortage of U.S. dollar liquidity.

During a press conference at the Executive Yuan, Chen Tain-jy reiterated that a lack of U.S. dollar liquidity will not compromise the nation's economy because Taiwan has large foreign exchange reserves and low external debts.

Chen noted that the depreciation of the Taiwan currency is caused by the withdrawal of U.S. capital from the country, emphasizing that the Central Bank of the Republic of China will intervene at the appropriate time to stabilize the market if the situation gets worse.

"A sharp fall of the U.S. stock market Wednesday and Argentina's foreign debt crisis fueled the existing global shortage of U.S. greenbacks, which in turn caused the Taiwan stock market to drop substantially," Chen explained.
According to Chen, the low U.S. dollar liquidity around the globe has hammered economies with high external debts, such as Argentina.

"A similar problem appeared during the 1997 Asian financial crisis. I am sure that fluctuating markets will stabilize now that the International Monetary Fund has taken the initiative to intervene in the matter," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC proposes Nov. 3 for start of 2nd top-level cross-strait meeting

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Minister Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday Taiwan has proposed that a historic meeting between top negotiators of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence on Nov. 3 in Taipei, under the principle of "equal status and dignity."

Lai said that the main issue of the second meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will be cross- strait transportation, which will include establishing direct shipping links and increasing the number of weekend direct chartered flights between Taiwan and mainland China.

Regular weekend flights were launched July 4, but the flights are considered not frequent or convenient enough, and the flight paths still must go through Hong Kong airspace, due to security concerns. Direct shipping links still do not exist.

"The commencement of direct shipping links and the increase in chartered flights with mainland China will not compromise the security of Taiwan," Lai told reporters at a press conference jointly held by the MAC and SEF Thursday. The issue of food safety will also be discussed, Lai said. Taiwan's public has been dismayed by imported melamine-adulterated milk products from China, which caused fears among local consumers and hurt local retailers, even those who do not use Chinese milk products.

Chiang, who also attended the press conference, pointed out that a deputy chairman level meeting will be held in Shenzhen, China on Oct. 27 to discuss the details and agenda items for Chen's visit to Taiwan.

Details of Chen's trip will be finalized in the Shenzhen meeting, he said. In addition, the MAC-proposed date of Nov. 3 for Chen's visit will need to be confirmed by the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits during the Shenzhen meeting, said Chiang.
Lai and Chiang also both guaranteed Chen's security. "Security will not be a problem during Chen's visit because enhanced security will be provided by Taiwan's National Security Bureau," Lai said.
ARATS Deputy President Zhang Mingqing was mobbed by protesters in southern Taiwan's Tainan City on Oct. 21, suffering minor injuries.
Lai and Chiang both condemned the violence on Zhang. "Freedom of speech most certainly should not include violent attacks," Lai said.

Chen's visit will be the first of its kind for the head of ARATS and is a reciprocal visit to the trip made by Chiang to Beijing in June in which the two sides signed landmark agreements on launching regular weekend flights and on allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Chen will be the highest ranking Chinese envoy to ever visit Taiwan since the two sides split at the end of a long civil war in 1949.

China, however, continues to see Taiwan as a province, not a separate country, and has threatened to attack if the island declares formal independence. Relations have improved under the new administration of Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou.

As for the sensitive issue of how Chen will address Ma - the title of "president" might be unacceptable to China as it does not consider Taiwan a country -, Lai would only say that Ma will meet Chen as the "president of the Republic of China, " Taiwan's formal name.

China does not deny the existence of the Republic of China, which once ruled mainland China before the civil war ended, but Beijing insists there is only one China, with Taiwan as a part of it. The SEF and its counterpart ARATS are quasi-official organizations that are responsible for handling cross-strait affairs in the absence of government to government relations.
SEF falls under the jurisdiction of MAC in Taiwan's Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP gets death threat against former president

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) received a letter containing a death threat against former President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, warning Chen not to attend an anti-China rally this weekend, according to DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang.
The letter, addressed to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, had a bullet enclosed with it, was signed "Mr. Wang" and was sent from Wuku township in Taipei County, Cheng told a news conference.
In the letter, "Mr. Wang" warned Chen not to take part in the protest march Saturday in Taipei City at the risk of losing his life, according to Cheng.

Meanwhile, the letter was transferred to the National Police Agency Director- General Wang Cho-chiun by DPP lawmaker Chai Trong-Rong, who said police authorities should track down who is behind the threat.

Saturday's demonstration is being organized by the DPP and several pro- independence groups to protest an upcoming visit by Chen Yunlin -- China's top liaison with Taiwan in his capacity as president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- who is expected to visit Taiwan in early November.

The DPP has said it will try to gather 1 million protesters to demonstrate against a host of issues, including China's tainted milk products, the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration so far, and Ma's steps to build closer ties with China.

Although some members of the DPP have openly objected to Chen Shui-bian's participation in the protest, the former president, who is the former head of the DPP, has insisted on taking part and promised to fully adhere to Tsai's instructions for protesters.

Some DPP leaders and members, however, are concerned that Chen Shui-bian's participation could taint the image of the party and the protest. The former president and his family members are deeply embroiled in a series of corruption and money-laundering allegations being investigated by the prosecution.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctor discourages eating contests

TEXT.P: A doctor of emergency medicine said Thursday that he does not encourage eating contests anywhere, as competitive eating is physically risky.

Chien Ting-kuo, an emergency medicine physician at Mackay Memorial Hospital, spelled out the warning in the wake of an incident Wednesday in which a graduate school student was believed to have choked to death in an eating contest.

Chien said an airway obstruction, such as food in the trachea, could cause a normal healthy person to fall unconscious in one minute. That person could die of cardiopulmonary arrest if he or she remains unconsciousness for 10 minutes, he added.
If the cardiopulmonary arrest lasts for more than four minutes, the patient, even if he or she recovers, is very likely to suffer permanent brain damage caused by a lack of oxygen, he warned.

A biotechnology graduate student at Dayeh University in the central county of Changhua on Wednesday won the first prize of NT$2,000 in an eating contest at his school by wolfing down two medium-sized steamed buns with layers of eggs and cheese in a few minutes.
The student, surnamed Chen, talked with his classmates briefly after winning the contest, then headed for the toilet, according to Huang Teh-hsiang, dean of student affairs at the university.
When he got to the door of the toilet, Chen began vomiting heavily then collapsed on the floor, Huang related. The student never recovered, he added.

The 23-year-old Chen was rushed by an ambulance to Yuan Sheng Hospital in the neighboring Yuanlin township, where he was given 20 doses of cardiotonic in an emergency effort that lasted 90 minutes, though he had been pronounced dead on arrival.

Doctors at Yuan Sheng Hospital concluded preliminarily that Chen choked to death because of an airway obstruction, although further examination, probably an autopsy, would be needed before the cause of death could be determined, according to Huang.

Huang said Chen's institute did not register with the university authorities before organizing the eating contest, adding that Dayeh University has already decided to totally ban similar eating contests on its campus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Black box of ill-fated IDF fighter recovered

TEXT.P: The flight recorder of an Air Force indigenous defense fighter (IDF) that crashed into the sea during a training mission Monday was recovered from waters near an uninhabited islet of the Penghu island chain off southwestern Taiwan Thursday after four days of intensive search.

"The flight recorder, commonly known as the black box, of the ill-fated IDF/1615 fighter was fished out of waters near Nanyen islet at 2 p.m.," said Col. Shen Yi-feng, chief of staff of the Air Force 427 Wing at the Chingchuankang air base in central Taiwan, who has been tasked with overseeing the search mission.

The black box will be sent back to Taiwan for military authorities and the original manufacturer of the plane -- Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) -- to conduct an extensive analysis to determine the cause of the crash, Shen said.
Over the past four days, 75 fragments of the crashed aircraft have been recovered, including a three-meter-long fragment of a tail fin of the fighter, he disclosed.

Also recovered were several pieces of human remains which have been sent to the Armed Forces General Hospital in Penghu to establish whether they belonged to either of the two Air Force pilots aboard the jet fighter, Shen added.
The plane, operated by pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian- ting, disappeared from radar screens Monday morning while on a bombing training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait.

The IDFs, also known as Ching-kuo jet fighters in memory of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, was developed in the 1980s by the AIDC in cooperation with General Dynamics Corp. of the United States. The IDFs, together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the backbone of Taiwan's Air Force.
Monday's incident was the fifth mishap involving IDF jet fighters since the model was commissioned into service in 1988.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boost employment amid high joblessness

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will come up with an employment promotion program for 2009-2012 in the hope of keeping the country's unemployment rate at 3.9 percent or lower, CEPD Deputy Chairman Shan Gee said Thursday.

Shan made the announcement after the Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Wednesday reported that September's unemployment rate hit a four-year high of 4.27 percent for the same month and the figure represented a 0.13 percentage point increase over the previous month.

The unemployment rate averaged 3.96 percent over the first nine months of this year, marking a 0.04 percentage point increse over the same period of last year and a three-year high for the same period, the reported revealed.
"It is a grave problem we must tackle first, " Shan said.

He added that funding for the 2009-2012 employment promotion program has been allocated in the government's budget plan for next year and is expected to be implemented on a long term and consistent basis.
In the meantime, the government's employment stimulation plan for the second half of this year is expected to generate thousands of jobs, said Shan.

The plan, which is aimed at expanding domestic demand, calls for launch of many construction projects initiated by the government. Around NT$58.3 billion earmarked for the projects eventually will be delivered to local governments.
Shan added that some 14,000 job openings are expected to be created in November and December after the local governments begin to award construction contracts.

To boost short term employment, the government has also asked various government agencies to come up with feasible programs, Shan said, adding that the Council of Labor Affairs has raised an employment promotion proposal as a result.

To implement those programs, however, the government will need to find funding sources, according to Shan, who added that only the employment stimulus programs initiated by the Council of Labor Affairs call for a budget of NT$3 billion.
Shan added that government will commission the DGBAS to study budget issues.

He said wage subsidies will be included in the planned short-term employment promotion programs. He noted that when the jobless rate reached 5 percent in 2003 and 2004, the Ministry of Economic Affairs provided wage subsidies to small and medium-sized enterprises so they can pay their employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protected Formosan salmon survive September typhoons

TEXT.P: The Shei-Pa National Park Administration Center's efforts to conserve the rare Formosan Landlocked Salmon allowed most of the fish to survive two typhoons in September, the center's deputy director-general Peng Mao-hsiung said Thursday.

Peng said the number of the rare salmon species, which is designated as a national treasure, dropped from 5,321 to 3,629 after Typhoon Sinlaku and Jiangmi slammed Taiwan last month with strong winds and torrential rains.
The rate of loss of the fish after the typhoons was registered at about 30 percent, lower than the minimum 50 percent registered after each typhoon in the past, Peng said.

The fish is also known as "cherry blossom hook salmon" because of its hooked nose and cherry blossom-shaped spots. It is found mainly in Cijiawan River in the national park in central Taiwan, the southernmost line for salmon of the northern hemisphere.
Peng said most of the salmon washed away in rivers swollen by rains in the two typhoons were small ones less than 15 cm in length.

"This was probably because they were not strong enough to swim against the pull of the raging river, " Peng said, adding that they may have been flushed downriver or injured by sand and stones in the water.
According to Peng, the center has spent many years working to improve the construction of 26 debris dams in the national park to ensure a smooth passage for the salmon to swim upriver to breed.
The debris dams were built decades ago to protect a reservoir in the national park by trapping sand and gravel, but this has also hampered the salmon's upstream movement.
The center also planted trees along the river to improve the water quality in the salmon's habitat, as trees help to prevent sand and soil from slipping into the river.
The endangered salmon was designated as a rare creature by the Taiwan government in 1984.
The administration center began its efforts to conserve the fish in 1992 when the national park was established, and the number of salmon was recorded then at about 600, according to Peng.
Peng said the center will release nearly one thousand salmon fry, which were spawned artificially, into the stream next March to test their adaptation to the natural environment.
He said he hoped that the conservation efforts would be expanded in the future and that the species would be allowed to inhabit the national park permanently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weekend cross-strait charter flights to be expanded to daily service

TEXT.P: The goal of transforming the current nonstop weekend cross-strait charter flights into daily services will make the agenda of an upcoming high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Thursday.

"Significant progress will be made on increasing the number of flights and destinations as well as on devising straighter flight routes in cross-strait aviation services, in the wake of the upcoming talks, " said Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo.

Mao made the remarks after Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan announced earlier in the day that China's top liaison with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, is expected to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for high-level consultations with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung, on promotion of bilateral ties.
Chen, president of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will be the highest-ranking Chinese envoy ever to visit Taiwan.

Establishing direct sea and air links will be a priority topic in the Taipei round of the Chiang-Chen talks, a follow-up to the first such meeting in Beijing in mid-June during which two landmark accords were forged to pave the way for the opening of direct weekend charter flights and an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan.
Mao said the second Chiang-Chen meeting will discuss the possibility of turning the weekend charter flights into daily services, with more flights, more destinations and shorter flight routes.
According to the agreement reached in the Beijing talks, Taiwan allows a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourist arrivals per day.
Over the past three months, the actual tourist arrivals have fallen far short of the targeted number.
Mao said the government has adjusted downward its target to 1,000 Chinese tourists per day before the end of this year.

Despite a decline in the load factor of the weekend charter flights at one point, the rate rebounded to 94 percent last week, thanks to an increase in the number of Chinese tourist arrivals, Mao said. A total of 3,400 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan last week -- an average of roughly 500 a day.

At present, only 36 direct cross-strait charter flights are available from Friday through Monday. The limited number of such flights has discouraged potential Chinese tourists, Mao said, adding that increasing the number of charters is imperative to attracting more Chinese holidaymakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP gets death threat against former president

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) received a letter containing a death threat against former President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, warning Chen not to attend an anti-China rally this weekend, according to DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang.

Saturday's demonstration is being organized by the DPP and several pro- independence groups to protest an upcoming visit by Chen Yunlin -- China's top liaison with Taiwan in his capacity as president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- who is expected to visit Taiwan in early November.

The DPP has said it will try to gather 1 million protesters to demonstrate against a host of issues, including China's tainted milk products, the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration so far, and Ma's steps to build closer ties with China.

If the cardiopulmonary arrest lasts for more than four minutes, the patient, even if he or she recovers, is very likely to suffer permanent brain damage caused by a lack of oxygen, he warned.

A biotechnology graduate student at Dayeh University in the central county of Changhua on Wednesday won the first prize of NT$2,000 in an eating contest at his school by wolfing down two medium-sized steamed buns with layers of eggs and cheese in a few minutes.
The student, surnamed Chen, talked with his classmates briefly after winning the contest, then headed for the toilet, according to Huang Teh-hsiang, dean of student affairs at the university.
When he got to the door of the toilet, Chen began vomiting heavily then collapsed on the floor, Huang related. The student never recovered, he added.

The 23-year-old Chen was rushed by an ambulance to Yuan Sheng Hospital in the neighboring Yuanlin township, where he was given 20 doses of cardiotonic in an emergency effort that lasted 90 minutes, though he had been pronounced dead on arrival.

Doctors at Yuan Sheng Hospital concluded preliminarily that Chen choked to death because of an airway obstruction, although further examination, probably an autopsy, would be needed before the cause of death could be determined, according to Huang.

Huang said Chen's institute did not register with the university authorities before organizing the eating contest, adding that Dayeh University has already decided to totally ban similar eating contests on its campus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Black box of ill-fated IDF fighter recovered

TEXT.P: The flight recorder of an Air Force indigenous defense fighter (IDF) that crashed into the sea during a training mission Monday was recovered from waters near an uninhabited islet of the Penghu island chain off southwestern Taiwan Thursday after four days of intensive search.

"The flight recorder, commonly known as the black box, of the ill-fated IDF/1615 fighter was fished out of waters near Nanyen islet at 2 p.m.," said Col. Shen Yi-feng, chief of staff of the Air Force 427 Wing at the Chingchuankang air base in central Taiwan, who has been tasked with overseeing the search mission.

The black box will be sent back to Taiwan for military authorities and the original manufacturer of the plane -- Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) -- to conduct an extensive analysis to determine the cause of the crash, Shen said.
Over the past four days, 75 fragments of the crashed aircraft have been recovered, including a three-meter-long fragment of a tail fin of the fighter, he disclosed.

Also recovered were several pieces of human remains which have been sent to the Armed Forces General Hospital in Penghu to establish whether they belonged to either of the two Air Force pilots aboard the jet fighter, Shen added.
The plane, operated by pilot Capt. Ku Chih-bin and co-pilot Capt. Chen Jian- ting, disappeared from radar screens Monday morning while on a bombing training mission over Penghu in the Taiwan Strait.

The IDFs, also known as Ching-kuo jet fighters in memory of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, was developed in the 1980s by the AIDC in cooperation with General Dynamics Corp. of the United States. The IDFs, together with U.S.-built F-16s and French-made Mirage 2000-5s, form the backbone of Taiwan's Air Force.
Monday's incident was the fifth mishap involving IDF jet fighters since the model was commissioned into service in 1988.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boost employment amid high joblessness

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will come up with an employment promotion program for 2009-2012 in the hope of keeping the country's unemployment rate at 3.9 percent or lower, CEPD Deputy Chairman Shan Gee said Thursday.

Shan made the announcement after the Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Wednesday reported that September's unemployment rate hit a four-year high of 4.27 percent for the same month and the figure represented a 0.13 percentage point increase over the previous month.

The unemployment rate averaged 3.96 percent over the first nine months of this year, marking a 0.04 percentage point increse over the same period of last year and a three-year high for the same period, the reported revealed.
"It is a grave problem we must tackle first, " Shan said.

He added that funding for the 2009-2012 employment promotion program has been allocated in the government's budget plan for next year and is expected to be implemented on a long term and consistent basis.
In the meantime, the government's employment stimulation plan for the second half of this year is expected to generate thousands of jobs, said Shan.

The plan, which is aimed at expanding domestic demand, calls for launch of many construction projects initiated by the government. Around NT$58.3 billion earmarked for the projects eventually will be delivered to local governments.
Shan added that some 14,000 job openings are expected to be created in November and December after the local governments begin to award construction contracts.

To boost short term employment, the government has also asked various government agencies to come up with feasible programs, Shan said, adding that the Council of Labor Affairs has raised an employment promotion proposal as a result.

To implement those programs, however, the government will need to find funding sources, according to Shan, who added that only the employment stimulus programs initiated by the Council of Labor Affairs call for a budget of NT$3 billion.
Shan added that government will commission the DGBAS to study budget issues.

He said wage subsidies will be included in the planned short-term employment promotion programs. He noted that when the jobless rate reached 5 percent in 2003 and 2004, the Ministry of Economic Affairs provided wage subsidies to small and medium-sized enterprises so they can pay their employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protected Formosan salmon survive September typhoons

TEXT.P: The Shei-Pa National Park Administration Center's efforts to conserve the rare Formosan Landlocked Salmon allowed most of the fish to survive two typhoons in September, the center's deputy director-general Peng Mao-hsiung said Thursday.

Peng said the number of the rare salmon species, which is designated as a national treasure, dropped from 5,321 to 3,629 after Typhoon Sinlaku and Jiangmi slammed Taiwan last month with strong winds and torrential rains.
The rate of loss of the fish after the typhoons was registered at about 30 percent, lower than the minimum 50 percent registered after each typhoon in the past, Peng said.

The fish is also known as "cherry blossom hook salmon" because of its hooked nose and cherry blossom-shaped spots. It is found mainly in Cijiawan River in the national park in central Taiwan, the southernmost line for salmon of the northern hemisphere.
Peng said most of the salmon washed away in rivers swollen by rains in the two typhoons were small ones less than 15 cm in length.

"This was probably because they were not strong enough to swim against the pull of the raging river, " Peng said, adding that they may have been flushed downriver or injured by sand and stones in the water.
According to Peng, the center has spent many years working to improve the construction of 26 debris dams in the national park to ensure a smooth passage for the salmon to swim upriver to breed.
The debris dams were built decades ago to protect a reservoir in the national park by trapping sand and gravel, but this has also hampered the salmon's upstream movement.
The center also planted trees along the river to improve the water quality in the salmon's habitat, as trees help to prevent sand and soil from slipping into the river.
The endangered salmon was designated as a rare creature by the Taiwan government in 1984.
The administration center began its efforts to conserve the fish in 1992 when the national park was established, and the number of salmon was recorded then at about 600, according to Peng.
Peng said the center will release nearly one thousand salmon fry, which were spawned artificially, into the stream next March to test their adaptation to the natural environment.
He said he hoped that the conservation efforts would be expanded in the future and that the species would be allowed to inhabit the national park permanently.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weekend cross-strait charter flights to be expanded to daily service

TEXT.P: The goal of transforming the current nonstop weekend cross-strait charter flights into daily services will make the agenda of an upcoming high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Thursday.

"Significant progress will be made on increasing the number of flights and destinations as well as on devising straighter flight routes in cross-strait aviation services, in the wake of the upcoming talks, " said Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo.

Mao made the remarks after Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan announced earlier in the day that China's top liaison with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, is expected to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for high-level consultations with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung, on promotion of bilateral ties.
Chen, president of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will be the highest-ranking Chinese envoy ever to visit Taiwan.

Establishing direct sea and air links will be a priority topic in the Taipei round of the Chiang-Chen talks, a follow-up to the first such meeting in Beijing in mid-June during which two landmark accords were forged to pave the way for the opening of direct weekend charter flights and an increase in Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan.
Mao said the second Chiang-Chen meeting will discuss the possibility of turning the weekend charter flights into daily services, with more flights, more destinations and shorter flight routes.
According to the agreement reached in the Beijing talks, Taiwan allows a maximum of 3,000 Chinese tourist arrivals per day.
Over the past three months, the actual tourist arrivals have fallen far short of the targeted number.
Mao said the government has adjusted downward its target to 1,000 Chinese tourists per day before the end of this year.

Despite a decline in the load factor of the weekend charter flights at one point, the rate rebounded to 94 percent last week, thanks to an increase in the number of Chinese tourist arrivals, Mao said. A total of 3,400 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan last week -- an average of roughly 500 a day.

At present, only 36 direct cross-strait charter flights are available from Friday through Monday. The limited number of such flights has discouraged potential Chinese tourists, Mao said, adding that increasing the number of charters is imperative to attracting more Chinese holidaymakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export orders from China continue downward streak

TEXT.P: Export orders from China and Hong Kong continued to decline in September for a second straight month, signaling a bad omen for the country's economic prospects, officials said Thursday.
According to figures released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), Taiwan companies received US$31.79 billion worth of orders from around the world in September, up 2.82 percent year-on-year.

But orders from China and Hong Kong, which combine to form Taiwan's largest export outlet, totaled only US$7.549 billion, marking a whopping 10.79 percent plunge from the year-earlier level. The drop followed a 8.86 percent fall in August. In July, the annual growth rate already narrowed to less than 2 percent.

Export orders from Taiwan's second largest market-- the United States -- also fell 2.29 percent year-on-year in September to US$7.389 billion, while orders from its third biggest market -- Europe -- registered a 14.94 percent annual increase to US$6.594 billion.

As the results of an MOEA survey of local enterprises showed that respondents foreseeing grimmer trade picture for October outnumber optimistic ones by nearly 14 percent, ministry officials said export orders may continue shrinking in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Friday, moving down 131.38 points at 4,599.13 on a turnover of NT$3.97 billion (US$119.23 million).
The weighted price index lost 132.08 points, or 2.71 percent, to close at 4,730.51 Thursday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.337 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.041 from Thursday.
