DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 24, or the 26th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: President prays for peace for country at Buddhism function

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou attended a Buddhist Dharma function held at the National Taiwan University Stadium in Taipei Friday to pray for peace and good fortune for the country.
At the ceremony organized by the Chief Sun Buddhism Temple, Ma prayed for blessings from above to help him in holding the country together in peace amid global economic volatility.

The Chief Sun Temple's founder, 94-year-old Master Baiyun, decided to hold the three-day national prayer gathering which kicked off Friday in a bid to strengthen the nation's confidence in meeting challenges at home and abroad, according to the sponsors.
It marks the first time that the temple located in Guanmiao, Tainan County has organized such an activity in Taipei City.
Friday's ceremony drew hundreds of Buddhists and non-Buddhists, including prominent political figures, such as President Ma and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.
Former Control Yuan President Chen Lu-an and Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng, both of whom are devout Buddhists, also attended the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan sent to foster family in Brazil

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese-Brazilian orphan who was returned to his Brazilian grandmother in a high-profile international custody battle four years ago has been sent to a foster family, a Taiwanese charity organization that has maintained contact with the boy said Thursday.

According to Chinjen Austin Ou, director of the Taiwan Catholic Mission Foundation, Iruan Wu Ergui has been in foster care since July this year because of his elderly grandmother's poor financial situation.
The foster family provides much better education and living conditions for the boy, said Ou, who has visited Iruan twice a year over the past four years.
Ou said he tried to contact Iruan's Taiwanese uncle, Wu Huo-yen, to inform him of the boy's status but was unable to reach him.
Iruan -- better known in Taiwan by his Chinese name Wu Yi-hua -- was born out of wedlock to a Brazilian mother and a Taiwanese father, Wu Teng-shu, in 1995 in Brazil.
The mother died in 1998, and the child's grandmother -- Rosa Leocadia Silva Ergui -- was named as the boy's guardian with Wu Teng-shu's approval.
In 2001, the father took the boy back to Taiwan for a short visit to his hometown of Chieting, Kaohsiung County but died unexpectedly during his stay there.
The boy's uncle then decided to take the boy and refused to let him go.

The boy's grandmother filed a lawsuit to regain custody of the boy, and Taiwan's supreme court ruled in 2003 that Iruan should return to his rightful guardian. Iruan eventually returned to Brazil in February 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Nearly half of stores sell cigarettes to minors: consumers group

TEXT.P: Nearly half of all stores recently inspected by the Consumers' Foundation were found to be illegally selling cigarettes to minors, foundation officials said Friday.

For the purposes of the inspection, teenagers under 18 dressed in senior high school uniforms were sent by the foundation to 235 stores around Taiwan to try to buy cigarettes, according to Hsieh Tien-jen, acting chairman of the foundation.
A total of 111, or 47.2 percent, of the stores sold cigarettes to the minors, Hsieh said.

Among the 147 convenient stores inspected, 22.4 percent failed to comply with the ban on the sale of cigarettes to minors, compared with 42.3 percent in a similar inspection conducted last year, Hsieh said.
While 19 percent of 7-Eleven stores inspected broke the law, 22.6 percent of FamilyMart stores violated the ban, and 31.5 percent of Ok Mart and Hi-Life stores failed to comply, he said.
Hsieh noted that an amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act set to come into effect on Jan. 1, 2009 will raise the fine for sellers violating the ban from NT$15,000 to NT$50,000.
He urged sellers to strengthen the education of their workers in this regard.

Meanwhile, Yu Kai-hsiung, secretary-general of the foundation, called the public's attention to the fact that one-third of young people who smoke are likely to die of smoking-related diseases in the future.
He added that 90 percent of adult smokers came into contact with cigarettes before the age of 19.

Furthermore, he continued, cigarettes are extremely inexpensive in Taiwan, being sold for as little as NT$50 (US$1.50) a pack, which makes them much more easily accessible to youth than in other countries where they are sold at NT$100-NT$200 per pack, Yu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two protected birds released back into wild on Kinmen

TEXT.P: Two birds listed as protected in Taiwan that were wounded and weak when they were caught on Kinmen earlier this month were released back into the wild on the Taiwan-held outlying island Friday.

A European Hobby caught in Hubao, Little Kinmen on Oct. 11 was injured, weak and weighed just 150 grams. It was released back into the wild in good condition and weighing 200 grams by Kinmen National Park Administration (KNPA) zoologists.
Meanwhile, a Common Kingfisher which was wounded and weak when it was caught in Chungshan Forest Oct. 20 was also released in good health.
The release of the two birds was one of the activities of a training workshop held by the KNPA Friday on care for injured wildlife. A total of 50 volunteers took part in the workshop.
The Kinmen National Park is best known among Taiwan's seven national parks for its good habitat for wild birds and busy birdwatching activities year round.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mainland officials have seen what has happened in Taiwan: SEF

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Friday that whether or not Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will visit central and southern Taiwan depends on the outcome of a meeting slated for Oct. 27 in the Chinese city of Shenzen.
"They have seen what has happened in Taiwan," he added.
Chiang was referring to the incident where ARATS Deputy President Zhang Mingqing was mobbed by protesters in southern Taiwan's Tainan City on Oct. 21, suffering minor injuries.

A deputy chairman level meeting is to be held in Shenzhen to discuss the details and agenda of Chen's upcoming visit to Taiwan. The details of Chen's trip will be finalized in the meeting, according to Chiang.
Chiang added that "the Mainland Affairs Council-proposed date of Nov. 3 for Chen's visit will need to be confirmed by ARATS during the Shenzhen meeting."
Chiang pointed out that this is Chen's first ever trip to Taiwan and that he hopes Chen will be able to visit many places during his stay.
"Chen is interested in seeing more of Taiwan, but they have also seen what has happened in Taiwan," he added.

Chen's visit comes after a trip made by Chiang to Beijing in June during which the two sides signed landmark agreements on launching regular weekend cross- strait flights and on allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Chen will be the highest ranking Chinese envoy to visit Taiwan since the two sides split at end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese Nobel laureate elected as head of int'l scientific group

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh was elected Thursday as the next president of the France-based International Council for Scientific Union (ICSU), according to Wong Chi-huei, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute.

Wong said that Lee, who is currently visiting the African country of Mozambique for the ICSU's annual assembly has accepted the new post at the urging of those in domestic and international academic circles.

Lee won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986 along with Hungarian-Canadian John Polanyi and American Dudley Herschbach. He is also an academician at the Academia Sinica, where he served as president from January 1994 to October 2006.
Lee will assume his new post at the ICSU in 2011, Wong said.

Lee, who was the first Taiwanese person to win the Nobel Prize, will become the first Taiwanese to assume the presidency of the ICSU, which is one of the most important international scientific institutes in the world in which Taiwan has participated, Wong said.
The scientific union's members include 114 national scientific bodies and 29 international scientific unions.

Headquartered in Paris, the ICSU holds annual assemblies on different issues in different places each year, Wong said, adding that its influence on international academic circles is like that of the United Nations on the world, Wong said.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Lee's winning of the election is a great honor for Taiwan, according to Vanessa Yea-ping Shih, minister of Government Information Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices plunged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 150.89 points, or 3.18 percent, to close at 4,579.62.
Finishing lower for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4599.13 and fluctuated between 4603.56 and 4,579.62 during trading.
A total of 1.65 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$25.68 billion (US$768.86 million).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares all moving down the most at 3.4 percent. Cement stocks and foodstuff issues both declined 3.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares and construction issues both dropped 3.2 percent, and textile stocks were down 3.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,296 to 145, with 275 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$828 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official to push for film courses in elementary, junior high schools
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/08 15:59:13 (by Tsai Hsiao-ying and Jian Chen)

TEXT.P: A visiting Taiwan official said here Thursday that his film promotion department will try to persuade Taiwan's Ministry of Education to include movie courses in elementary and junior high school curriculums.

Frank J. K. Chen, director of the Department of Motion Pictures under the Cabinet-level Government Information Office, said that the initiative will raise the Taiwan public's awareness of the importance of film education and foster a greater interest in movies.
"Movie culture requires cultivation at an early age, " Chen said, noting that film classes begin at the elementary school level in France.
Chen is currently heading a delegation of Taiwan theater operators on a visit to France to learn more about the European country's film industry development as well as digital projection technology.
He said that the French government's policy of support for its motion picture industry can serve as a model for Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the visit has helped theater operators in Chen's delegation better understand the French attitude toward culture and re-think their own social responsibilities and the social significance of movie theaters, said Shin Kong Cineplex manager Luo Min-wen, one of the members of the delegation.
She noted that Taiwan's theater operators only take box office revenue into consideration and do not care about contributing to culture.
The country's film venues are restricted in the selection of films available by distributors as well, Kuo said, in contrast to France where a wide diversity of movies are shown in cinemas.
Members of the delegation expressed the view that digital projection will become the trend of the future and that an upgrading of facilities in Taiwan theaters will be needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier gives assurances on visiting Chinese official's safety

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan gave assurances Friday that the personal safety of China's top negotiator with Taiwan will be secured when he visits Taiwan next month.

The National Security Bureau, with the support of other police units, will be mainly responsible for securing the safety of Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), during his stay, Liu said at the Legislative Yuan.

In response to concerns over the safety of Chen and his delegation raised by People First Party Legislator Lin Cheng-er, Liu stressed that he has on many occasions assured that there will be no safety and security loopholes during Chen's visit in Taiwan, which is expected to take place between Nov. 3-7.
Lin asked Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi whether the government is ready to provide airtight personal protection for Chen and his group.
"Absolutely," Liao answered.
Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Tsao Er-chung asked whether and when President Ma Ying-jeou will be meeting with Chen during the ARATS president's forthcoming visit.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan responded that the time for the meeting had yet to be decided but was expected to be worked out in the coming days by officials from the two intermediary bodies representing Taiwan and China in the negotiations -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's ARATS.

The legislators expressed concern about Chen's safety while in Taiwan after ARATS Deputy President Zhang Mingqing was mobbed by protesters in southern Taiwan's Tainan City on Oct. 21, suffering minor injuries.
MAC has proposed that the historic meeting between Chen and his counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, take place in Taipei under the principle of "equal status and dignity."

Chen, Chiang and their respective delegations are expected to discuss a wide range of topics, including food safety concerns related to China's tainted food exports, the establishment of direct shipping and cargo charter links and increasing the number of nonstop passenger charter flights on weekends between Taiwan and China, according to Lai.

The much talked about Chiang-Chen meeting will be a follow-up to a landmark meeting in Beijing between the two in mid-June during which both sides reached an agreement on weekend cross-strait charter flights and the expansion of the number of Chinese tourists allowed to visit Taiwan.

Regular weekend flights were launched July 4, but some believe the flights are not frequent enough and inconvenient because they still must pass through Hong Kong airspace due to security concerns before heading to their final destinations.
Direct shipping links still do not exist.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent for November.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 157 points to finish at 4,337, with 31,754 contracts traded. December futures declined 155 points to end at 4,295, with 188 contracts traded.

March futures fell 154 points to close at 4,253, with 10 contract transactions, while June futures lost 153 points to finish at 4,231, with seven contract transactions. September futures were down 148 points to close at 4,083, with 23 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,494 for November, 4,450 for December, 4,407 for March, 4,384 for June and 4,231 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 150.89 points to finish at 4,579.62, on turnover of NT$25.68 billion (US$768.86 million).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower, with November TE and TF futures and December TE and TF futures all falling by the maximum allowable 3.5 percent.

November TE futures fell 6.4 points to close at 176.85, with 727 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 6.35 points to finish at 175.7, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

November TF futures were down 16.8 points to close at 467.4, with 740 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were down 16.6 points to finish at 463.2, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers urge DPP to cancel Saturday rally

TEXT.P: Several ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers on Friday urged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to cancel its planned protest rally against the government slated for Saturday, describing the rally as "propping up the corrupt (former President) Chen Shui-bian."
The rally, being co-sponsored by the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union, will target "the one China market, the downgrading of Taiwan's sovereignty, and an incompetent government."

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, KMT caucus whip Kuo Su-chun pointed out that the DPP has been unwilling to separate itself from the former president, who is being investigated for money laundering and corruption, or to ask him not to participate in the rally.

Instead, the DPP "would rather walk hand-in-hand with this former president who deprived Taiwan of its dignity, " she said, adding that the party nevertheless still insists on calling itself the party of conscience and reform.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Tsao Erh-chang pointed to the irony of the DPP holding a rally to protest incompetent government when "former President Chen is the most incompetent of them all, " a fact over which DPP Chairman Tsai Ing-wen has "feigned ignorance."

The KMT legislators' calls for the rally to be canceled came in response to remarks by DPP legislators, including Twu Shiing-jer and Su Cheng-ching, at the same legislative session in which they urged citizens to take part in the rally to voice their dissatisfaction with the current government.

Twu accused the government of being aloof and caring more about whether China's top negotiator will come to Taiwan than about the fact that three out of four people have lost confidence in the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: New mindset needed for competitive gaming industry: Taichung mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 24 (CNA) 10/24/08 16:31:12 (By Semy Chen and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu told Macau media that the views of Taiwan's people will have to change drastically before the country can establish a gaming industry that is competitive.

In an interview published Friday in the Macao Daily News which was seen here, Hu said that leading gambing centers such as Las Vegas now focus on more than just gambing, offering a wide variety of other leisure and entertainment options for visitors that allow for more diversified development.

As for whether Taiwan can become an international gaming center, Hu said that although investors from Las Vegas and Macao have expressed interest in the Chen- nan recreational area in Taichung County as a potential center, authorities have no intention at the present time of establishing such an industry there.
Therefore, Hu said, he has not actively sought investors, adding that he doesn't think a gaming industry will be set up anywhere else in Taiwan in the near term.

Hu also talked about the launch of direct charter flights between Taichung and Xiamen, China, in July this year, expressing the hope that Taichung and Macau can actively work together to expand flights between the two destinations to increase their respective tourism industries.

Noting that the four cities and counties of central Taiwan have a combined population of more than 6 million as well as plenty of tourist attractions while Macao continues to develop its own unique tourism resources, Hu said that there is a lot of potential for expansion of flight services between the two destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expansion of cross-strait charters could keep businessmen at home

TEXT.P: Most Taiwanese business owners with operations in China have little choice but to live in China, but that could change if the cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services were more convenient, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The results revealed that if the weekend cross-strait charter services, currently operated between Friday and Monday, were extended to every day of the week, 42.6 percent of China-based Taiwanese business owners would choose to live in Taiwan, while 53.7 percent would still live in China.
The survey results were based on 1,227 valid questionnaires received from business class passengers on weekend cross-strait charter flights between Sept. 5-8.
According to Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, the results show that Taiwanese entrepreneurs doing business in China do not necessarily have to live in China in the future.
The change would help decrease the incidence of infidelity that is very prevalent among Taiwanese businesspeople who live separately from their spouses, Mao said.
Asked if the extension of the cross-strait charter services would increase their intention to invest in Taiwan, 74.8 percent of respondents gave a positive answer.

Another 18.3 percent of respondents said it would not help. Among the reasons mentioned were Taiwan's high labor and land costs, the severe industrial exodus from Taiwan and an unwillingness to change the status quo.
As to whether the extension would raise their desire to invest in China, 56.2 percent of respondents believed it would help, while 20.8 percent did not think it would lead to any changes.
The weekend cross-strait charter flight services were launched on July 4 this year.

During upcoming talks set for early November in Taipei, representatives of Taiwan and China are expected to discuss the possibilities of extending the services to all days of the week, increasing the number of routes and flights included in the charter services, and opening more direct nonstop cross-strait air routes.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.116 to close at NT$33.412.
A total of US$1.113 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.296 and fluctuated between NT$33.280 and NT$33.463.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT launches contest on democracy

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Friday launched the Taiwan portion of a worldwide contest aimed at enhancing the global dialogue on democracy.
The competition, called "Democracy Video Challenge, " asks budding filmmakers, democracy advocates, and the general public to create video clips that complete the phrase, "Democracy is..."

Scott Robinson, director of the AIT's American Culture Center, told a news conference that the AIT will set up a panel of judges to choose three semifinalists from the videos submitted in Taiwan to be judged in the United States.
The Taiwanese entries will compete with others in the region.

Seven winning videos will be chosen -- one each from Sub- Saharan Africa, East Asia and the Pacific, Europe, the Near East and North Africa, South and Central Asia, and the Western Hemisphere, as well as one anonymous video.

Using YouTube as the video platform for the challenge, the winning videos will be selected from 21 finalists by global online voting. The winners will be granted an all-expenses paid trip to Washington D.C., New York and Hollywood, where gala screenings of the winning videos will be held.
Their work will also get exposure as filmmakers and people in the U.S. film and television industry will be able to see it.

"We expect this competition will be well received and lively in Taiwan, not only because of Taiwan's vibrant democracy, but also because of Taiwan's creativity in filmmaking, " Thomas Hodges, AIT's Chief of Public Affairs Section, said at the news conference.

Lin Wen-chen, president of the non-government Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, said at the same occasion that he hopes this event will remind and encourage more people in Taiwan to care about democracy.
"Speaking of democracy and human rights, I find many of the young generation take them for granted, " Lin said. "But it takes much effort to protect democracy and human rights."
The AIT will hold a screening in Taiwan next March to recognize the three videos representing Taiwan, along with other video submissions, Robinson said.
For guidelines, rules and more information about the video challenge, the AIT advised people interested to visit the Web site http://www.ideochallenge.america.gov.

Taiwan partners of the challenge include the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, Council for Cultural Affairs, Chinese Taipei Film Archive, Taiwan Film and Culture Association, SPOT Taipei Film House, and National Taiwan University of the Arts.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington. Editem/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum launches Asian art show in Chiayi County

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei has launched a special exhibition in southern Taiwan on Asian art and culture to herald the establishment of the museum's southern branch, scheduled for completion in 2011.
The exhibition, titled "Exploring Asia: Episode One of the National Palace Museum's Southern Branch, " is being held in Chiayi Performing Arts Center in Chiayi County's Minsyong township.

The 117 items displayed encompass six different Asian art themes -- Buddhist sculptures, religious scriptures, fabrics and textiles, blue and white porcelains, tea cultures and traditions, and Western trends in Asian art, according to National Palace Museum director Chou Kung-shin.

Chou said most museums in Taiwan focus on Chinese-oriented art and cultures, but this special exhibition will allow Taiwanese people to learn more about treasured works from greater Asia, which will be the emphasis of the museum's southern branch when it opens.

Visitors will see the world's only Dragon Sutra manuscript written in Tibetan, which was completed in 1669 under the reign of Qing Dynasty Emperor Kangxi, as well as many precious Buddhist sculptures made in ancient India, an executive of the museum said.
They will also learn from many ancient artifacts about how western aesthetics infiltrated Asian art and how Asian cultures were viewed by western eyes, the executive said.
The exhibition will run through Jan. 4, 2009, and admission is free for visitors until Oct. 31, the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACIO launches Australia film festival

TEXT.P: The 4th Australia Film Festival opened Friday, featuring seven movies the event's organizer hopes will give Taiwanese audiences a better understanding of the country and strengthen bilateral cooperation and exchanges in film education and production.

Speaking at an opening reception to launch the "Australia Film Showcase, " Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) Representative Alice Cawte said she hoped people in Taiwan would take this opportunity to get to know more about Australia.
"Movies serve as an important medium to know the culture and lifestyle of one place, just as the movie Cape No. 7 does for people to get to know Taiwan," Cawte said.
"Through these movies, the audience in Taiwan will be able to better understand the multi-cultures as well as the delight, anger, sorrow and happiness of Australia," she added.

Previously held in 2002, 2005, and 2007, this year's Australia Film Showcase features seven Australian-made films, including the family dramas Clubland, Home Song Stories, Romulus My Father, and Peaches, family film Hildegarde, romantic comedy The Wog Boy, and the award-winning Yolngu Boy, which presents a sympathetic look at an Indigenous youth struggling to find his place in the world.
Organized by the ACIO and co-organized by the Taipei City Government's Department of Culture Affairs, the festival will run until Oct. 31 at Leofoo Cineplex in Taipei.
For more information on the movies and screening times, the ACIO advised people interested to visit www.australia.org.tw or www.leofoo.com.tw.
The ACIO functions as the de facto Australian embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged not to recognize Chinese medical credentials

TEXT.P: Members of Taiwan's medical sector voiced firm and clear opposition Friday to the government administration's plans to recognize Chinese academic credentials.

In a public hearing on the impact of recognizing Chinese academic credentials on Taiwan's medical sector, sponsored by three opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators, delegates representing six medical professionals' groups unanimously opposed President Ma Ying-jeou's plans to recognize Chinese academic credentials and recruit Chinese students beginning next year.

Shih Hsien-yen, chairman of the Taiwan Medical Association, said China's medical education systems are notoriously chaotic and its medical school students normally do not get much internship training before becoming a doctor.

Such facts prove that Chinese medical practitioners, as well as Taiwanese citizens who have received medical education in China and earned medical credentials there, will not be able to provide quality medical services to Taiwanese patients, Shih said.

Tseng Hsiu-yi, a director with the National Union of Nurses' Associations, said the influx of Chinese medical personnel into Taiwan and the return of Taiwanese students who have earned medical credentials in China, would certainly lead to the quality of Taiwan's medical and nursing care being compromised.

In response to Shih and Tseng's remarks, Shih Mei-chun, an official with the Bureau of Medical Affairs under Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH), reassured the group that while the government plans to recognize Chinese academic credentials, the DOH's stance is to keep Taiwan's doors closed to all Chinese academic credentials issued by China's medical sector, based on consideration of Taiwanese people's health and welfare.

Also speaking at the public hearing, Wang Ming-yuan, an official with the Education Ministry's Department of Higher Education, said the ministry will respect the opinions of the DOH and local medical professionals when planning to hire medical professionals from China or Taiwanese people who have obtained medical credentials issued by Chinese medical institutes.

Lin Kuang-chi, a department chief of the Ministry of Examination, said although according to the stipulations of the World Trade Organization's (WTO) General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) , Taiwan may not be able to recognize Chinese academic credentials WITHOUT allowing Chinese citizens who have passed examinations in Taiwan to obtain Taiwanese professional licenses, the WTO will still respect the ways member countries deal with its own regulations applied within the countries.
Besides, Lin said, only Taiwanese citizens who are Republic of China ID card holders are eligible to sit tests in Taiwan for professional licenses.
His remarks indicate that even if Taiwan recognizes Chinese academic credentials, mainland Chinese would still need to obtain professional licenses in Taiwan in order to work in their profession.
"Chinese people will not be able to apply to sit tests in Taiwan for professional licenses because they are not ROC citizens, "Lin added.
President Ma told a group of visiting Chinese scholars in September that Taiwan will recognize Chinese academic credentials and recruit Chinese students from next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to meet Chinese official based on 'reciprocity, dignity'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he will receive Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in his capacity as president of the Republic of China when Chen visits Taiwan early next month.

During an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Ma said that he and Chen "certainly will meet face-to-face," and that the issue of how both sides will address each other will be handled according to the principles of "reciprocity and dignity."

Chen is tentatively scheduled to arrive in Taipei Nov. 3 for a five-day visit at the invitation of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- the counterpart of ARATS -- for a second round of talks with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.
They last met in Beijing in June.

The president said that Chen's visit to Taiwan provides an important symbolism of reciprocity and dignity, meaning that although both sides of the Taiwan Strait do not recognize each other at this stage, they can at least refrain from denying each other.

"Both sides can use pragmatic and flexible ways to resolve our differences," Ma said. "There is no need to create difficulties in certain areas to obstruct the badly needed exchanges between the two sides."

Citing an example, Ma said when the Red Cross societies of Taiwan and China were to sign the Kinmen Agreement in 1990 to repatriate fugitives, criminals and illegal migrants from each other's side, the two sides could not agree on whether to use the ROC or Western calendar.
The issue was finally resolved after both sides agreed to write down only the month and date while leaving the space for the year blank.

Another example, according to Ma, was that the direct weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China began in July smoothly after both sides agreed to define the air routes they served as "special routes," defusing the dispute as to whether they were domestic or international air routes.
Ma pointed out that the results of all local opinion surveys showed that the people are supportive of Chen's visit to Taiwan.

"I don't think the (opposition) Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would object to his visit either," he said, adding that Chen's second round of talks with Chiang will result in greater convenience for DPP members who need to go to China.

Commenting on the Oct. 21 incident in which Chen's deputy, Zhang Mingqing, was besieged and jostled to the ground by pro-independence protesters while visiting the Confucian Temple in Tainan, southern Taiwan, the president said that the government must severely condemn violence and not allow such incidents to happen again.
"We will especially not allow such things to occur while Chen Yunlin is visiting Taiwan. We will absolutely see to that," he said.

"Isn't it self-contradictory for (the activists in) Taiwan to urge China to renounce the use force against Taiwan and repeatedly criticize China for being unwilling to give up use the use of force, while they themselves apply violence to a visitor from China?" Ma asked.
He stressed that Taiwan has an obligation to protect the safety of all people who enter its borders, whether they are from the Chinese mainland or elsewhere.

At the end of the first meeting between Chiang and Chen in Beijing June 12-13, they signed agreements to launch weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China and expand Chinese tourists' access to Taiwan.

In their forthcoming second round of talks in Taipei, they are expected to discuss direct air routes and the opening of more airports for the current weekend charter flights, as well as direct cargo flights, direct maritime links, and a framework for cooperation on food safety.
Chen will become the highest-ranking official of the People's Republic of China to have ever set foot in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plans to help Pacific allies cope with waste disposal problem

TEXT.P: Taiwan is working to broaden the scope of its aid to its Pacific allies, from medical and agricultural technical assistance to environmental areas such as garbage disposal, officials of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Friday.

Following a ministerial forum between Taiwan and its six Pacific allies in July last year, the EPA assigned several teams of experts to make on-site assessments of the environmental situation in the island countries, before drafting cooperation plans.

Wu Yi-lin, a senior environmental specialist at the Greenhouse Gas Office under the EPA, told the Central News Agency that for the people of the Pacific islands, the problem of garbage disposal seems to be more pressing than rising sea levels.

"The world is focused on the problem of rising sea levels as it is an index of global climate change, but they (the people living on the Pacific islands) think that waste disposal is a more urgent matter," Wu said.
Most of the Pacific island countries are atolls and have little land for waste dumps, he noted.
"They fear that they might be submerged, not by the sea, but by trash," he added.

Liang Yeon-fong, director of the EPA International Affairs Office and one of the experts who conducted on-site assessments in the Solomon Islands, Marshall Islands, Palau and Nauru, told the CNA that garbage disposal is indeed a common worry among Taiwan's Pacific allies.
He said the problem can impact significantly on the economy of some countries, particularly those that depend on tourism, as tourists are usually repelled by a dirty, disorderly environment.
These Pacific countries have only simple and crude waste dumps, and sometimes garbage is piled up in the open, Liang said.
To solve the waste disposal problem, Taiwan's Pacific allies need not only money but also technical assistance and personnel training, he said.

According to Liang, the Solomon Islands wanted a waste incinerator, but considering the technical expertise needed to maintain and operate such a facility, the EPA thought this would not be a practical solution to the waste disposal problem there.

The evaluation teams reported that the Solomon Islands once obtained an incinerator for medical waste, but within three months the equipment broke down because it was not operated correctly, and it has not been in use since due to a lack of funds and expertise to repair it.

Noting that most of the waste in the Pacific island countries is biodegradable material such as fruit skins and pits, Liang said that collection is the main problem, as there are insufficient garbage trucks and public trash cans in those countries.
He suggested that degradable garbage can be used as organic fertilizers, a practice that is already being observed by some Taiwanese agricultural missions there.

In a report presented to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) which controls Taiwan's foreign aid budget, the EPA suggested donating garbage trucks to the Pacific allies and helping them to establish recycling systems.
The EPA has no budget for foreign aid, but can provide technical assistance and manpower to Taiwan's allies.
Liang urged that the MOFA integrate environmental protection into its foreign assistance program, which so far has been focused on medical services and agricultural technical aid.
"After all, Taiwan has expertise in waste reduction and recycling," he said.
EPA statistics show that Taiwan's recycling rate was 38.7 percent in 2007 -- thanks to a waste classification policy implemented in 2006 -- which compares well with other developed countries.
Among Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies, six, namely Palau, Tuvalu, the Marshall Islands, Solomon Islands, Kiribati and Nauru, are located in the Asia-Pacifica region.

In Sep. 2006, the First Summit of Taiwan and Pacific Allies took place in Palau and the Palau Declaration on coastal management was signed. The declaration encouraged these countries to make a solid commitment to the protection and sustainable management of coastal areas and the ocean. It was signed by former President Chen Shui-bian and leaders of the six Pacific countries.

In 2007, a Taiwan-Pacific Allies Environment Ministers Meeting was held in Taipei, with representatives agreeing to develop cooperation plans and action for environmental protection, intensify interactions between their countries, and support plans for technology transfer.
That same year, the Second Summit of Taiwan and Pacific Allies, which was held in the Marshall Islands, focused on cooperation in the areas of medicine, sanitation, and environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't makes no concessions on diplomatic, defense fronts: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday his administration, while seeking to improve relations with China, has not done anything harmful to the country's sovereignty and dignity since its inauguration.
"I have stood firm on both the diplomatic and defense fronts, " Ma said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Speaking a day before the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and several pro-independence groups hold a protest rally against Ma's administration and China in Taipei, Ma said he supports the expression of opinions in a legal manner and even agreed with one of the rally's themes -- opposing substandard or toxic foodstuffs from China.

"The appeal against the substandard products from China is the government's policy, " Ma said. "It is a national consensus to stave off imports of contaminated foodstuffs or dangerous products into Taiwan."

Ma noted that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has condemned Chinese companies' shipments of melamine-tainted milk products and food ingredients to Taiwan and demanded that they apologize and compensate local victims.

He also said the Strais Exchange Foundation -- a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties -- is working to establish a mechanism to seek compensation from China.

The president took issue, however, with the rally's goal of "protecting Taiwan's sovereign status, " which is based on opposition criticism that Ma's administration is tilting excessively toward China.
He described the slogan as empty rhetoric by a handful of people and stressed that his administration has achieved things that the previous DPP administration pursued but failed to accomplish.

He insisted that his government had not made any concessions on Taiwan's sovereignty to realize those goals, such as agreements to open nonstop direct weekend cross-srait charter flights between Taiwan and China and expand opportunities for Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

The protest rally comes just two weeks before China's point man on Taiwan, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin, is to arrive in Taiwan to negotiate further transportation links between the two sides and discuss food safety issues and joint crime-fighting efforts.
Although the protest may voice opposition to Chen's visit, Ma said the results of all public opinion surveys show that a majority of local people are giving it a thumbs-up.
"I think even the DPP itself would not oppose his visit because the issues to be addressed during his visit are related to DPP members and supporters," Ma said.
When the DPP was in power, Ma recalled, the DPP also pushed for the establishment of direct air links to facilitate the cross-strait travel of local businessmen who have operations in China.

On the DPP's criticism that Taiwan's sovereign status is threatened under Ma's administration, Ma asserted that to date, he has not seen a single thing the government is doing that could be detrimental to the country's sovereignty.

On the contrary, Ma said, his administration's consolidation of relations with the country's diplomatic allies, completion of an arms procurement deal with the United States, and reduction of tensions in the Taiwan Strait, all will solidify, not weaken, Taiwan's sovereign status.
"What I'm doing or have done is all based on the concept of contributing to Taiwan and its people and has never flinched on diplomatic and national defense stances," Ma said.

With a conciliatory approach, Ma went on, his administration has succeeded in purchasing weapons systems from the United States to beef up Taiwan's defense capability while reviving the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and reducing cross-strait tensions.

"All these developments are in the interest of the United States and Japan, two of Taiwan's most important trading partners," Ma said, adding that the scenario is also in the interests of Taiwan and China and meets international expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Development fund expanded for long-term investment: economic planner

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's plan to expand the National Development Fund (NDF) is aimed at increasing the government's long-term investment in potentially successful local enterprises to help them improve the quality of corporate management, in an effort to stabilize the local economy, the country's top economic planner said Thursday.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks to allay public concerns that the government's NDF expansion plan was initiated for the purpose of bailing out trouble enterprises and rescuing the stock market.
Chen made the comment after announcing the Cabinet's decision earlier in the day to expand the size of the fund from NT$200 billion (US$6.01 billion) to NT$1 trillion to give momentum to the economy.

Chen said, however, that the additional funds will also be used to invest in private enterprises that are facing liquidity problem because of global financial crisis but still have sound fundamentals and promising future.

He said that to his knowledge, a bailout occurs when a company that fails to pay interest to its creditor banks eventually strikes a deal for a solution with the help of the Ministry of Economic Affairs. The National Development Fund has nothing to do with this process, he added.
Chen said that the Cabinet plans to expand the fund's functions to include a role in corporate capital increase, reconstructions, mergers and acquisitions.

He said that the fund would continue to focus its investments primarily in the manufacturing sector and the service industry. Although the banking system is part of the service industry, the government prefers not to invest NDF money in the banking industry, according to Chen.
As the government has stakes in more than 50 percent of Taiwan's financial institutions, most of the county's banks enjoy high liquidity, Chen noted.
If financial institutions want to engage in corporate mergers, they have the capability to do so on their own, Chen said, adding that it would be better if the government did not step in.

The top economic planner also said the government will establish a cross-agency mechanism to govern the NDF assessment and decision-making process which will be handled by the board of directors. The NDF board of directors will decide on the eligibility of companies that apply for NDF funds for purposes such as corporate recapitalization and reconstruction, he added.

The board of directors will assess applications not only on the basis on "venture capital" investment programs, but will also take into consideration other plans for strategic industrial investment, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: President clarifies 'two areas' concept, reaffirms mutual non-denial

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday the Republic of China is a sovereign state and defined relations across the Taiwan Strait as a special relationship.

He also stressed that conceptualizing Taiwan and mainland China as "two areas" was not his invention, but believed the framework offered a way for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to sidestep sovereignty questions in pursuing closer ties as long as each side did not deny the other's existence.
Ma said consultations between the two sides' intermediary bodies have been conducted under such a "mutual non-denial" framework.

Elaborating on the issue during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Ma said although a total of 171 countries worldwide have recognized the People's Republic of China as a state, Taiwan cannot do so, because if Taiwan were to recognize the PRC, it would be "recognizing the existence of another country on its own territory."

Ma was referring to the fact that the territory of the Republic of China, as defined in the country's Constitution, covers not only Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu where its jurisdiction reaches, but also the Chinese mainland, overlapping with the territorial area claimed by the PRC.
"It is impossible for the two sides to recognize each other, but they can achieve mutual non-denial," Ma said.
Ma first put forth in August the concept that ties between Taiwan and the mainland are a type of "special relations" and ruled out the possibility that they could be links "between two states."

Such a concept, in which Taiwan and the mainland are referred to as "areas, " drew strong protests from the opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, which accused Ma of downgrading Taiwan's status from a sovereign state to a "region" similar to Tibet and Xinjiang.
Ma, however, asserted during the interview that the policy has not changed the status of the Republic of China as a sovereign state or his status as the president of the Republic of China.

According to Ma, the "two areas" concept is not his own invention but could be dated back to 1991, when then President Lee Teng-hui announced the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion to acknowledge the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are under separate rule.

The move symbolized that the communist regime established on Oct. 1, 1949 in China is no longer considered by the ROC as a "rebellious group, " but "a governing authority that has de facto rule of the mainland," Ma said.
Over the past 17 years, several other concepts have been put forth by the country's leaders to try to define cross-strait relations, but none has been proven feasible, he said.
These include the "special state-to-state relations" proposed by Lee in 1999, and the "one country on either side" theory raised by then President Chen Shui- bian in 2002, Ma noted.

In particular, Chen's statement sparked U.S. concerns that Taiwan was trying to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally, indicating that such a statement was unhelpful to Taiwan's effort to assert its sovereignty, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Modularly-assembled' target drugs developed by medical researchers

TEXT.P: Medical researchers at National Cheng Kung University Hospital have found a new way to produce target drugs that allows physicians to build an optimal combination of "targeting" and "curing" elements based on the characteristics of the cancer under focus, the Tainan-based hospital announced Friday.

Introducing the idea of "smart ammunition, " the researchers explained that a "modularly-assembled" target drug is similar to a smart missile that is made of a targeting unit that can best seek the target under given conditions -- whether it should be heat- seeking, infra-red targeting, or radar guidance -- and an ammunition compartment that can deliver the greatest damage to the designated target -- whether it should be standard, armor-piercing or incendiary.

Shieh Dar-bin, an oral disease expert at the hospital, said that individual patients may develop different variances of a cancer, which possess unique cell surface antigens, and show specific conditions that require customized therapy to induce the best curative effects.
To target cancer cells, physicians have to select a targeting module, or "moiety, " that recognizes the given type of antigen, Shieh said.
To kill the tumorous cells, the physician should select a curing agent that can most efficiently destroy them according to the patients' condition.
"These factors may not be easily predetermined in the laboratory or the production line," Shieh noted.
"What we do is to allow greater flexibility for physicians in terms of selecting and using the drugs that can best heal their patients," Shieh said.

For example, Shieh said, if there are 10 existing targeting modules and 10 available curing agents, a facility capable of combining modularly-assembled target drugs would be able to produce 100 different combinations of drugs.
And the physicians who have placed the orders can then apply the tailor-made drugs to their patient, added Shieh.

According to the hospital, the new target drugs have passed animal testing, and it has applied for permission to test the modular approach on humans. With luck, the therapy could be available in hospitals in five years, Shieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shipping links conducive to fruit exports to China: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the establishment of direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait would facilitate Taiwan's fruit exports to China because it would reduce delivery times considerably.

Speaking in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Ma said that forging cross-strait maritime links will be one of the topics to be addressed during a top-level cross-strait meeting to be held in Taipei early next month.

Ma was referring to a much-anticipated meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

According to Ma, the opening of direct cross-strait shipping services will shorten transportation times to less than half of the eight days it currently takes to navigate to China via indirect routes.

"Once direct shipping services are available, Taiwan-grown fruit can reach the Chinese mainland in just four days or even in 10 hours, " Ma said, adding that the shortened delivery time will not only help cut transportation costs but will also be conducive to preserving fruit freshness and prolonging its shelf life.
Besides fruit growers, the local aquaculture industry will also benefit from the establishment of direct cross-strait shipping links, he said.
Noting that many locally farmed fish species have enjoyed growing popularity in China, Ma said fishery exports to China could increase further with the opening of direct shipping services.

Chen Yunlin, China's point man on Taiwan, is expected to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 to meet with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on a broad range of topics, from maritime links and the expansion of the existing weekend direct charter flights and Chinese tourist arrivals, to the opening of cargo charter flights, new flight routes, and food safety issues.

Ma said that following the Taipei round of the Chiang-Chen talks, cross-strait travel may be further eased, with Taiwan allowing the minimum number of members of each Chinese tour group to be cut from the current 10 to five or even fewer to attract more Chinese tourist arrivals.
Many Chinese citizens have expressed interest in backpacking in Taiwan, according to travel sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bakeries in southern Taiwan struggling to survive

TEXT.P: Bakeries in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, urged the government Friday to grant them business tax exemptions or reductions because many of them are on the brink of collapse.

Wang Chia-jung, president of the Pingtung County Bakery Association, told reporters that 26 of the 220 bakery shops in Pingtung County had shut down, while many others were struggling to survive after suffering two serious blows as a result of contaminated material and ingredients imported from China.
Wang said that reports about the melamine-tainted milk power supplied by Chinese dairy product companies in mid-September had caused the bakeries to lose 50 percent of their business.

To make the situation worse, it was reported last week that a bread raising agent, ammonium bicarbonate, imported by Taiwan from China also was also found to contain the toxic chemical melamine, he added.

As a result, many of these bakeries that used to sell at least 200 pineapple buns -- their mainstay product -- a day now cannot sell even one bun, although they have given the public the assurance that they used yeast, not ammonium bicarbonate, as the raising agent in the pineapple buns, Wang said.

"These shops have lost 90 percent of their business and are unable to cope with the hardship any more. Some of them do not even have the money to pay their membership fees to the association. They need a helping hand from the government," he urged.

Pingtung County's Deputy Magistrate Chung Chia-pin and his wife tried to support the bakeries at a bread-making demonstration by eating some of the pineapple buns and puff pastries to drive home the point that the products were not made with ammonium bicarbonate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU professor elected as RSC fellow

TEXT.P: A professor from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan has been elected a fellow of the U.K.-based Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC) , becoming the only fellow of the society whose expertise is not in the field of chemistry, the university said Thursday in a statement.

Professor Yu-cheng Lin has established a Micro-Electro-Mechanical System (MEMS) laboratory dedicated to developing nanotechnology and MEMS in the areas of biotechnology and medicine. The laboratory's research lies in the application of micronano-particle synthesis, electricity, magnetism and thermodynamics in molecular biology, the statement said.

Lin graduated from NCKU's Department of Mechanical Engineering in 1985 and earned a doctoral degree in 1996 in the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

Established in 1841, the RSC -- an international association headquartered in London -- is devoted to advancing the chemical sciences. As the largest academic chemistry institution in Europe, the society now has 46,000 members from around the world.
NCKU, which is considered to be one of Taiwan's top five higher education institutions, has long been famous for its medicine and mechanical engineering departments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chan blazes through to semis in Taipei

TEXT.P: Top-seeded Chan Yung-jan from Taiwan continued her rampage through the draw at the 2008 OEC Taipei Ladies Open Friday, while the comeback of a former top-five player from Japan hit a roadblock.
Chan, who had expected a tough battle against seventh-seeded Jessica Moore of Australia, relentlessly subdued her opponent 6-0, 6-0 in 40 minutes, yielding a mere 16 points in the 12 games.
With the victory, Chan advanced to the semifinals of the US$100,000 tournament being played at the Taipei Arena, where she will face Corinna Dentoni of Italy.

Chan admitted that she was surprised at the ease of her victory because Moore is known for her tenacity and dangerous forehand, but the Taiwanese world No. 74 said she was able to neutralize the Australian's weapon by playing points at a faster pace and forcing her opponent into making repeated errors.

The 19-year-old, who has lost only five games in the first three matches of the tournament, said she wasn't sure what to expect from the mercurial Dentoni, but hoped to continue her winning ways and win her first singles trophy of the year.
Dentoni reached the semifinals by edging past 38-year-old Kimiko Date-Krumm 5-7, 7-5, 7-6 (4).
Date-Krumm reached a career-high singles ranking of fourth in the world in May 1995 but retired at the end of 1996 at the age of 26 while still playing at a very high level.
She later said she hated the game her lost two years on tour because she didn't enjoy traveling the world and being alone.
But married and with a different outlook, the Japanese veteran decided this year to mount a comeback and her appearance in Taipei was her first outside of Japan in her return to competitive tennis.

Taiwan's other remaining hopeful in the tournment was eliminated Friday, as Chang Kai-chen lost to sixth-seeded Jarmila Gajdosova of Slovakia 6-4, 6-2. The Slovakian will play Japan's Kumiko Iijima in Saturday's other semifinal.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun reached the semifinal of the US$125,000 Challenger-level Samsung Securities Open in Seoul by winning two matches Friday.
Forced to play twice after his scheduled match was rained out Thursday, Lu first defeated Kristian Pless of Denmark 7-6 (11), 6-1 and then topped Bjorn Phau of Germany 7-6 (6), 7-5.

World No. 65 Lu, who climbed to the highest ranking of his career after winning a US$125,000 challenger in Uzbekistan last week, will next face South Korea's Lee Hyung-taik, a former top-50 player who has breezed through the first three rounds of the Seoul event, losing only 10 games in three matches.
Lu has a 1-2 record lifetime against the Korean.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man arrested for threatening former president's life

TEXT.P: Taipei City police arrested a man in Taipei County Friday night for sending an intimidating letter, along with a bullet, to threaten the life of former President Chen Shui-bian.
According to the First Police Office in Taipei's Zhongzheng District, the 47 -year-old man, identified by his surname Kang, was taken into custody in Taipei County's Yonghe City.

Police officers on duty said that the man mailed the letter and the bullet to Chen in care of Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, warning the former president not to join the Oct. 25 protest march by DPP members and supporters to express their dissatisfaction with the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou and his Cabinet.

Although Kang sent the letter in the name of his former boss who had fired him not long ago, police still tracked him down and verified him as the writer of the letter by checking his handwriting, the officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agreement on cargo charters to be signed in new round of talks: SEF

TEXT.P: An agreement on cargo charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be among the four accords to be signed during the second round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks, a senior official said Friday.
Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the other three agreements will be on direct shipping and postal links as well as on food safety.
Kao is scheduled to travel to Shenzhen in southern China next Monday for apreparatory meeting with the SEF's counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Asked whether ARATS President Chen Yunlin will arrive in Taiwan Nov.3 for the meeting, Kao said that was the date proposed by the SEF, but that "Beijing has yet to give a formal response."
Kao, who held talks with the ARATS in Shenzhen Thursday on the agenda for the meeting, said both sides are now "close to" setting up the agenda for the second meeting.
On the air links agreement, Kao said that the issue will include more charter flights and flight destinations, straighter flight routes, and cargo charter flights.
He also said that at least two destinations in China -- Shanghai and Guangdong -- will be designated for cargo charter flights.
He said direct postal links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been limited in the past to ordinary or registered mail, and will be expanded to include parcel post and express mail.
In addition, both sides will strike an initial agreement on the issue of food safety, though it was not included on the agenda until late, he said.
The recent discovery of melamine-contaminated milk products and food ingredients from China has given rise to problems in some sectors of Taiwan's food industry and caused a scare among consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT securing of Ketagalan Blvd. restricts freedom of speech: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) securing the right to use Ketagalan Boulvard or the plaza in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei during a top Chinese envoy's visit to Taiwan in early November is tantamount to restricting local residents' freedom of speech, an opposition leader said Friday.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen was referring to the KMT's registration with Taipei City police authorities for use of Ketagalan Blvd. in the first week of November when Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will visit Taiwan.

"We don't know the purpose of the KMT's registration for use of Ketagalan Blvd., but it seems to me that the KMT was trying to restrict freedom of speech during Chen's visit, " Tsai told a news conference during which she also explained the main goals of a mass rally to be staged by the party at Ketagalan Blvd. Saturday.
The DPP is collaborating with another opposition party -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and several pro-independence groups to organize mass marches through five parts of Taipei.

Participants in those parades will then gather at Ketagalan Blvd. in front of the Presidential Office to voice their opposition to what they call the current KMT government's China-leaning policy and China's shipments of toxic or substandard foodstuffs to Taiwan.
Tsai said it is clear that the DPP's mass rally at Ketagalan Blvd. is to express its opinions on issues of public concern and voice its protest against the government's pandering to China.
In contrast, she said, the KMT's control of the site in early November is apparently aimed at restricting fredom of speech and freedom of expression.
With the right to use the plaza falling into the hands of the KMT, opposition parties and supporters will be unable to stage anti-government or anti-China activities there during Chen's visit.

Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the party looks forward to atract up to 500,000 people to join the marches whose main goals include pushing China to apologize for shipping melamine-tainted milk products and food ingredients to Taiwan and compensate local victims and pushing President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to apologize for what he calls its many wrong policies.
