DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 25, or the 27th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five- yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.
2001: Government agencies mobilizes over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
'Modularly-assembled' target drugs developed by medical researchers

TEXT.P: Medical researchers at National Cheng Kung University Hospital have found a new way to produce target drugs that allows physicians to build an optimal combination of "targeting" and "curing" elements based on the characteristics of the cancer under focus, the Tainan-based hospital announced Friday.

Introducing the idea of "smart ammunition, " the researchers explained that a "modularly-assembled" target drug is similar to a smart missile that is made of a targeting unit that can best seek the target under given conditions -- whether it should be heat- seeking, infra-red targeting, or radar guidance -- and an ammunition compartment that can deliver the greatest damage to the designated target -- whether it should be standard, armor-piercing or incendiary.

Shieh Dar-bin, an oral disease expert at the hospital, said that individual patients may develop different variances of a cancer, which possess unique cell surface antigens, and show specific conditions that require customized therapy to induce the best curative effects.
To target cancer cells, physicians have to select a targeting module, or "moiety, " that recognizes the given type of antigen, Shieh said.
To kill the tumorous cells, the physician should select a curing agent that can most efficiently destroy them according to the patients' condition.
"These factors may not be easily predetermined in the laboratory or the production line," Shieh noted.
"What we do is to allow greater flexibility for physicians in terms of selecting and using the drugs that can best heal their patients," Shieh said.

For example, Shieh said, if there are 10 existing targeting modules and 10 available curing agents, a facility capable of combining modularly-assembled target drugs would be able to produce 100 different combinations of drugs.
And the physicians who have placed the orders can then apply the tailor-made drugs to their patient, added Shieh.

According to the hospital, the new target drugs have passed animal testing, and it has applied for permission to test the modular approach on humans. With luck, the therapy could be available in hospitals in five years, Shieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shipping links conducive to fruit exports to China: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the establishment of direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait would facilitate Taiwan's fruit exports to China because it would reduce delivery times considerably.

Speaking in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Ma said that forging cross-strait maritime links will be one of the topics to be addressed during a top-level cross-strait meeting to be held in Taipei early next month.

Ma was referring to a much-anticipated meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

According to Ma, the opening of direct cross-strait shipping services will shorten transportation times to less than half of the eight days it currently takes to navigate to China via indirect routes.

"Once direct shipping services are available, Taiwan-grown fruit can reach the Chinese mainland in just four days or even in 10 hours, " Ma said, adding that the shortened delivery time will not only help cut transportation costs but will also be conducive to preserving fruit freshness and prolonging its shelf life.
Besides fruit growers, the local aquaculture industry will also benefit from the establishment of direct cross-strait shipping links, he said.
Noting that many locally farmed fish species have enjoyed growing popularity in China, Ma said fishery exports to China could increase further with the opening of direct shipping services.

Chen Yunlin, China's point man on Taiwan, is expected to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 to meet with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on a broad range of topics, from maritime links and the expansion of the existing weekend direct charter flights and Chinese tourist arrivals, to the opening of cargo charter flights, new flight routes, and food safety issues.

Ma said that following the Taipei round of the Chiang-Chen talks, cross-strait travel may be further eased, with Taiwan allowing the minimum number of members of each Chinese tour group to be cut from the current 10 to five or even fewer to attract more Chinese tourist arrivals.
Many Chinese citizens have expressed interest in backpacking in Taiwan, according to travel sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bakeries in southern Taiwan struggling to survive

TEXT.P: Bakeries in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, urged the government Friday to grant them business tax exemptions or reductions because many of them are on the brink of collapse.

Wang Chia-jung, president of the Pingtung County Bakery Association, told reporters that 26 of the 220 bakery shops in Pingtung County had shut down, while many others were struggling to survive after suffering two serious blows as a result of contaminated material and ingredients imported from China.
Wang said that reports about the melamine-tainted milk power supplied by Chinese dairy product companies in mid-September had caused the bakeries to lose 50 percent of their business.

To make the situation worse, it was reported last week that a bread raising agent, ammonium bicarbonate, imported by Taiwan from China also was also found to contain the toxic chemical melamine, he added.

As a result, many of these bakeries that used to sell at least 200 pineapple buns -- their mainstay product -- a day now cannot sell even one bun, although they have given the public the assurance that they used yeast, not ammonium bicarbonate, as the raising agent in the pineapple buns, Wang said.

"These shops have lost 90 percent of their business and are unable to cope with the hardship any more. Some of them do not even have the money to pay their membership fees to the association. They need a helping hand from the government," he urged.

Pingtung County's Deputy Magistrate Chung Chia-pin and his wife tried to support the bakeries at a bread-making demonstration by eating some of the pineapple buns and puff pastries to drive home the point that the products were not made with ammonium bicarbonate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agreement on cargo charters to be signed in new round of talks: SEF

TEXT.P: An agreement on cargo charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be among the four accords to be signed during the second round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks, a senior official said Friday.
Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the other three agreements will be on direct shipping and postal links as well as on food safety.
Kao is scheduled to travel to Shenzhen in southern China next Monday for a preparatory meeting with the SEF's counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Asked whether ARATS President Chen Yunlin will arrive in Taiwan Nov.3 for the meeting, Kao said that was the date proposed by the SEF, but that "Beijing has yet to give a formal response."
Kao, who held talks with the ARATS in Shenzhen Thursday on the agenda for the meeting, said both sides are now "close to" setting up the agenda for the second meeting.
On the air links agreement, Kao said that the issue will include more charter flights and flight destinations, straighter flight routes, and cargo charter flights.
He also said that at least two destinations in China -- Shanghai and Guangdong -- will be designated for cargo charter flights.
He said direct postal links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been limited in the past to ordinary or registered mail, and will be expanded to include parcel post and express mail.
In addition, both sides will strike an initial agreement on the issue of food safety, though it was not included on the agenda until late, he said.
The recent discovery of melamine-contaminated milk products and food ingredients from China has given rise to problems in some sectors of Taiwan's food industry and caused a scare among consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT securing of Ketagalan Blvd. restricts freedom of speech: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) securing the right to use Ketagalan Boulvard or the plaza in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei during a top Chinese envoy's visit to Taiwan in early November is tantamount to restricting local residents' freedom of speech, an opposition leader said Friday.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen was referring to the KMT's registration with Taipei City police authorities for use of Ketagalan Blvd. in the first week of November when Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will visit Taiwan.

"We don't know the purpose of the KMT's registration for use of Ketagalan Blvd., but it seems to me that the KMT was trying to restrict freedom of speech during Chen's visit, " Tsai told a news conference during which she also explained the main goals of a mass rally to be staged by the party at Ketagalan Blvd. Saturday.
The DPP is collaborating with another opposition party -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and several pro-independence groups to organize mass marches through five parts of Taipei.

Participants in those parades will then gather at Ketagalan Blvd. in front of the Presidential Office to voice their opposition to what they call the current KMT government's China-leaning policy and China's shipments of toxic or substandard foodstuffs to Taiwan.
Tsai said it is clear that the DPP's mass rally at Ketagalan Blvd. is to express its opinions on issues of public concern and voice its protest against the government's pandering to China.
In contrast, she said, the KMT's control of the site in early November is apparently aimed at restricting fredom of speech and freedom of expression.
With the right to use the plaza falling into the hands of the KMT, opposition parties and supporters will be unable to stage anti-government or anti-China activities there during Chen's visit.

Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the party looks forward to atract up to 500,000 people to join the marches whose main goals include pushing China to apologize for shipping melamine-tainted milk products and food ingredients to Taiwan and compensate local victims and pushing President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to apologize for what he calls its many wrong policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president calls for cross-strait government-to-government talks

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui proposed Saturday that Taiwan abandon the model in which dialogue with China is conducted through a civic intermediary and seek to enter official government-to-government talks with Beijing.

Lee criticized the Kuomintang (KMT) administration led by President Ma Ying- jeou as "losing touch with political reality" for sticking to this model, arguing that the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , with its limited authority, is incapable of handling the complex political, economic, social and security issues across the Taiwan Strait.

Established as a civic organization in 1991 during Lee's presidency, the SEF was authorized by the government to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties with China and to negotiate various technical matters with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

While the functions of the SEF and ARATS almost came to a standstill during the eight-year leadership of former President Chen Shui-bian from the pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party, the groups have restored their roles in cross-strait relations since Ma's inauguration on May 20 this year.

Following talks in June in Beijing -- the first encounter after a hiatus of almost 10 years -- SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin are expected to meet again in early November in Taipei.
Lee, however, said the SEF's role in cross-strait relations "should now come to an end."

"The SEF's existence is not only redundant but also exposes the government's ignorance of the structural change in cross-strait exchanges and fails to highlight the state-to-state relations between Taiwan and China, " Lee said while addressing a forum on Taiwan's sovereignty and security held by Taiwan Advocates, a think tank that Lee established in 2001.
Lee insisted that Taiwan and China should be placed on an equal footing before entering negotiations, and that Taiwan must not downgrade its own status as a sovereign state.

Lee accused the Ma administration of adopting various "de-sovereignization" moves over the past five months, one of which has been reopening talks with China based on what Lee said was the "non-existent" "1992 consensus," which Ma claims allows the two sides to agree to disagree on the meaning of "one China."

On Ma's move to define the relations between Taiwan and China as those between "two areas, " Lee described it as a "mistaken policy" that will revert cross- strait ties to a kind of "domestic relations," tantamount to the past "civil war state" between the KMT and the Chinese communists.

During a time when Beijing is widely recognized internationally as the rightful government representing China, Ma's "two areas" concept will only justify Beijing's sovereignty claim over Taiwan, and lead to the downfall of the Republic of China, Lee said.

According to Lee, after the constitutional reforms of 1991, the jurisdiction of the ROC Constitution was restricted to the Taiwan area, and the ROC has also recognized the legitimacy of the People's Republic of China government in China.

In addition, the introduction of popular presidential elections in Taiwan through 1992 constitutional reforms has allowed the ROC government to obtain the mandate of Taiwan's people, meaning the government in Taiwan has nothing to do with the people in mainland China, Lee said.

He stressed cross-strait ties have been defined as a kind of "state-to-state relations" since 1991 and that the "Republic of China on Taiwan" is an independent sovereign state, not the "Taiwan area" as Ma has called it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City to promote World Games in Hong Kong

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government will hold a news conference in Hong Kong Saturday afternoon to promote the 2009 World Games, scheduled for next July, and a warm- up event that will start Oct. 28, a local official said late Friday.

Hsu Ming-chun, director-general of the city's Information Office, said Games representatives will introduce the event to Hong Kong's people at the news conference, which will take place at the New World Center in Hong Kong's Kowloon area.
Athletes from different sports will also display their skills in rhythmic gymnastics, tug-of-war and dancesport, to give people in Hong Kong a taste of what the World Games will be like, Hsu said.
Well-known Taiwanese pop singer Jolin Tsai will also join the promotional event, she added.

To be held in the southern port city from July 16-26 next year, the World Games will feature 36 sports not featured in the Olympic Games, divided into six categories: artistic and dance sports, ball sports, martial arts, precision sports, strength sports, and trend sports.
The event is expected to draw 5,200 athletes from more than 90 countries and many additional visitors to the city to boost local tourism.
A warm-up competition to be held in Kaohsiung from Oct. 28 to Nov. 8 will see athletes compete in four sports -- boules, korfball, water skiing, and gymnastics.

The World Games gymnastics events focus on different apparatus and skills than those featured in Olympic competition, spanning aerobic, acrobatic and rhythmic gymnastics as well as tumbling and trampoline events.

Hsu, who is also an executive of the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC) in charge of the event, said the promotion, following Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's previous trip to Hong Kong Oct. 19, is part of efforts of the KOC and the Kaohsiung City government to increase the event's international profile.
Another promotional delegation will visit Japan to introduce the Games there.
Toyo Ito, the Japanese architect who designed the the main stadium for the World Games, will join next month's public relations event, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's office workers burned by global financial meltdown: survey

TEXT.P: The impact of the global financial meltdown has been increasingly visible in Taiwan, with a recent survey suggesting that nearly two-thirds (65.7 percent) of local office employees have sustained losses in stock market or mutual fund investments.

The online poll released Saturday by the 104 Job Bank showed that among the money-losing workers, 12 percent sustained losses of several hundreds of thousands of Taiwan dollars while 2.2 percent reported losses of over NT$1 million.

According to the survey, 24.1 percent of those who lost more than NT$100,000 (US$2,990) due to the financial storm work in the investment, financial consulting services and insurance sectors, 18.3 percent work in the electronics and information sectors, and 14.9 percent are in construction.

Those losses may be impacting consumer spending. The survey found that respondents budgeted an average of NT$2,112 to spend during this year's department store anniversary sales, down from last year, although some retailers have reported brisk sales during their sale periods.

Over 46 percent of respondents said they would spend less during the anniversary sales than last year, while 33 percent said they would spend the same amount, while 20.6 percent said they planned to spend more this year.
104 Job Bank researchers concluded that people were restraining their spending urges because of the rising prices of commodities and a global economic recession.

As to the 20.6 percent of respondents who intended to spend more during the department store sales this year, the researchers said they were "trying to save money by taking advantage of preferential discounts" offered by the retailers.
The survey was conducted between Sept. 30 and Oct. 4 among 104 Job Bank members. A total of 3,919 valid samples were collected, and the survey's margin of error was plus or minus 1.57 percent.

On Wednesday, the government released statistics showing the unemployment rate was 4.27 percent in September, 0.13 percentage points higher than a month earlier. Some 12,000 more people were without jobs.
The average monthly unemployment rate over the first nine months of 2008 was 3.96 percent, 0.04 percentage points higher than the same period last year, the government figures showed.

Ryan Wu, chief operating officer of Internet-based 1111 Job Bank, said the rising jobless rate reflected the spread of the global financial crisis and credit crunch to industrial and commercial sectors around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President promotes Taiwan agricultural products

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou touted the positive impact direct shipping links with China will have on agricultural exports at an agriculture product promotion event Saturday.
Taiwan and China are tentatively scheduled to hold a second round of talks in early November, with the establishment of direct shipping links one of the items on the agenda.
The president suggested that opening direct shipping links with China would benefit agricultural exports by reducing their delivery time to well below the current eight days.
"Once direct shipping services are available, Taiwan-grown fruit can reach the Chinese mainland in just four days or even in 10 hours," he said.
The shortened delivery time will not only help cut transportation costs but will also be conducive to preserving fruit freshness and prolonging its shelf life, the president indicated.

At Saturday's event, Ma also showed his own appreciation for local produce, buying bananas, oranges, and flowers to show his support for local farmers. He said he "loves Taiwan farm products, " and always eats a banana after each meal.

Direct shipping links will be just one of the topics on the agenda when Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , meet in early November.
Food safety issues and the creation of direct cargo charter flights will also be discussed.
The two secured agreements on direct weekend charter flights and expanding the number of Chinese nationals allowed to visit Taiwan during their first round of talks in Beijing in mid-June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier spends big to promote Taiwan produce

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan headed to the Songshan Tobacco Plant Culture Park in Taipei City Saturday morning to attend an event held by the Council of Agriculture (COA) to promote locally-grown produce.

At the event, Liu spent nearly NT$80,000 (US$2,400) purchasing a variety of Taiwan-grown agricultural products, including NT$30,000 on 50 boxes of dragon fruit and NT$17,500 on 50 bottles of Malasun millet wine produced in Sinyi Township in the southern county of Nantou.
The premier said he bought so much to share the wonderful Taiwan- made products with his friends.
He urged citizens around Taiwan to purchase more locally-grown produce to help the country's agricultural sector thrive.

Also accompanying Liu on his visit were Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih and COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung, who each also spent thousands of New Taiwan dollars purchasing a variety of local fruits and vegetables and other produce.

Earlier the same morning, President Ma Ying-jeou also visited the COA-sponsored activity to tout Taiwan agricultural goods and make some purchases, including bananas, oranges and flowers, to encourage the country's citizens to purchase Taiwan-grown produce.

Ma said at the event that establishing direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links -- one of the items to be discussed when Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin visits Taiwan early next month to meet with Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung -- will benefit Taiwan's agricultural exports by reducing the shipping time to China to as little as ten hours from the current eight days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office prefers SEF-ARATS model for cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office has rejected former President Lee Teng-hui's proposal for Taiwan to start government-to-government talks with China rather than negotiating through quasi-official bodies.

Spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Saturday the office respects Lee's opinion but thinks the existing model in which talks are conducted through Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) is "the best arrangement at the current stage."

In a speech delivered to a forum held by Taiwan Advocates earlier the same day, Lee said such a model should be scrapped because the SEF, with its limited authority, is incapable of handling the complex political, economic, social and security issues across the Taiwan Strait.
Instead, Lee said, Taipei should seek to enter government-to-government talks with Beijing to highlight Taiwan's status as a sovereign state.

On Lee's denial of the existence of the "1992 consensus" between Taiwan and China, Wang pointed out that the consensus was confirmed by Chinese President Hu Jintao during a conversation with U.S. President George W. Bush on March 26.

Also, the existence of such a consensus, which allows the two sides to agree to disagree on the definition of "one China," was what made possible a series of negotiations between the SEF and the ARATS in the 1990s, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Police College celebrates 63rd anniversary

TEXT.P: Taiwan Police College (TPC) marked its 63rd anniversary Saturday by holding a celebration ceremony and a series of activities under the theme of "steadiness, self-confidence, excellence, and growth."
Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi was on hand at the ceremony to offer his congratulations.

Speaking at the ceremony, Chen Lien-chen, the new president of TPC, said that the educational goal of the college is to teach future law enforcement and disaster rescue workers the professional skills they will need for their job, as well as cultivate the spirit of the democratic rule of law and teach them to think independently when performing their duties.

The series of activities, held on the campus drill ground and open to the general public, included displays by students of the skills they have learned at the college, including judo and taekwondo, as well as performances by various student groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice President promotes Taichung suncakes

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew attended a "suncake festival" held at Taichung Park in the central Taiwan city Saturday to mark the 100th anniversary of the park's Mid-Lake Pavilion.
Accompanied by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Siew promoted Taichung suncakes at the event, calling them the "pride of Taiwan."
Through Hu's promotional eforts, Taichung suncakes have become internationally renowned, the vice president said, urging people to buy more of the tasty product to support local producers.
For his part, Hu said that despite the tough economic times recently, Taichung's baked goods industry has maintained strong sales and its leading position domestically.
Also on hand to perform at the event was singer Ma Nien-hsien, who had a supporting role in the Taiwan box-office hit "Cape No. 7."
The festival featured several activities, including a do-it-yourself suncake booth where parents and their children had the opportunity to have some fun trying their hand at making the local pastry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Philharmonic Orchestra to perform Beethoven in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Taipei Philharmonic Orchestra (TPO) , led by renowned German conductor Andreas Delfs, will perform several of Beethoven's works in a performance next week, the orchestra announced Saturday.

The concert, which will take place on Oct. 28 at Zhongshan Hall in Taipei, will feature Beethoven's Leonore Overture No. 3, Op. 72a, the Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor, Op. 37, and Symphony No. 3 "Eroica" in E flat major, Op. 55.

Chen Hung-kuan, a reputed American musician originating from Taiwan who now teaches at the Shanghai Conservatory, will also perform on the piano, and 28 hearing-impaired children will perform Beethoven's Ode to Joy with tambourines and recorders, the orchestra said at a press conference.
Ticket prices for the show, titled "Invisible Heroes," range from NT$500 (US$15) to NT$2,000.
Delfs, now the TPO's guest conductor, described the group as a "rare orchestra that plays for love and passion for the music (instead of for money)."
Having served as general music director of Hannover's symphony orchestra and opera company in Germany, he is currently the music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra in the United States.
In addition, two performances conducted by Delfs featuring Austrian composer and conductor Gustav Mahler's symphonies will be staged on Nov. 21 and 23, the TPO said.

The TPO was founded in 1985 by a group of enthusiastic musicians and came under the direction of the late American maestro Henry Mazer, who came from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and stayed with the TPO for over 18 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's ITRI to promote cross-strait industrial cooperation

TEXT.P: Promoting industrial cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be one of the top priorities of the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in the next few years, ITRI President Johnsee Lee said Saturday.

The new strategy has been developed as part of the government's push for closer economic ties with China and to help raise the technological levels of local industries in which Taiwan is currently lagging and make it easier for them to gain an international presence.

The institute's three-year program to achieve the goal intends to promote cross- strait exchanges in the first year, engage in consultations in the second year, and open cross-strait cooperation plans in the third year, Lee said in an interview with local media at the institute.

He noted that the first activity the institute has organized to boost Taiwan- China industrial exchanges will be a symposium on cross-strait Chinese herbal medicine cooperation slated for early December.
That will be followed by a series of seminars on topics such as medicinal herbs, medical development and research, and clinical experiments, Lee added.

In addition to organizing cross-strait workshops and seminars, Lee said that the two sides will also conduct talks on issues concerning intellectual property protection and standardization of electronic products like memory cards, communication devices and electric cells.
ITRI is a national research organization conceived to strengthen Taiwan's technological competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chan ousted by determined Italian foe in OEC Taipei Ladies Open

TEXT.P: In sizing up Italian Corinna Dentoni a day before their semifinal match, Taiwan's Chan Yung-jan said her opponent was unpredictable and could play at a very high or very low level.

Much to her regret, the world No. 74 faced Dentoni at her best Saturday in the semifinal of the US$100,000 2008 OEC Taipei Ladies Open, and aside from an early break, could never find a formula to rattle her much-lower ranked foe, falling 6-4, 6-1.

"She was very consistent and she never had a letdown that allowed me to put pressure on her," a disappointed Chan said after the match. "I also couldn't take advantage of the break point opportunities I had."
Chan jumped to a 2-0 lead in the first set, seemingly on her way to another convincing win over a lower ranked foe, after having lost only five games in her first three matches in the tournament.

But Dentoni fought back to break Chan in the fourth game and broke her again in the 10th game to clinch the set, helped by a bit of luck when her shot on set point clipped the net and fell over for a winner.

Chan had three break points in the opening game of the second set as she appeared set to reverse the Italian's momentum. Dentoni ran off the next five points to win the game, however, and the 19-year-old Taiwanese was never really in the match after that.
Winning only her second match against a top 100 opponent this year, the unseeded Dentoni performed well above her ranking of 171 in eliminating the tournament's top seed.

Full of confidence after knocking off former world No. 4 Kimiko Date-Krumm on Friday, even if Date was 12 years past her prime, Dentoni was consistently able to keep the ball in play during long rallies.
She varied her pace and shot selection, mixing an occasional drop shot with deep forehands to frustate Chan, who grew impatient in the second set and made a flurry of errors going for quick winners.
"She was really hard to predict because she hit flat balls and balls with spin. I tried to change the rhythm, but it didn't work, " Chan said.
Dentoni said she was thrilled to reach the final in defeating Chan, the second highest ranked opponent the Italian had beaten in her career.

She attributed her excellent showing this week to playing outside of Europe, where she can become easily distracted, and finally getting used to a new grip that her coach suggested that she try about a year ago.
In Sunday's final, Dentoni will face sixth-seed Jarmila Gajdosova of Slovakia, who topped Japan's Kumiko Iijima in the day's other semifinal, 6-2, 6-2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition rally protests president's cross-strait policies

TEXT.P: Waving banners reading "protect Taiwan, down with Ma Ying-jeou" and shouting "oppose toxic products, protect sovereignty," hundreds of thousands of people joined a rally Saturday organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to denounce President Ma Ying-jeou's approach toward China.

Rally participants marched through five parts of Taipei before gathering at Ketagalan Blvd. in front of the Presidential Office to protest, among other things, the Ma administration's conciliatory policy toward China and Beijing's shipments of toxic or substandard foodstuffs to Taiwan.
The weak economy was also on the minds of the protesters.
"Taiwan's economy is facing harsh times and the government could not do anything, " said Liu Tse-jun, a pregnant mother, who brought her three children with her to join the protest.
"I am doing what I can for Taiwan by joining this rally. The government had done nothing about the tainted milk from China," added Pai Fu-tang, a 40-year-old man from southern Taiwan.

The protest comes less than two weeks before China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yun-lin, arrives in Taiwan for talks on food safety issues and expanded cross-strait transportation and air cargo links.

Banners reading "we are anti-communist, we object to Chen Yunlin's visit" reflected protesters' views that the trip was not in Taiwan's interest, especially at a time when the country is struggling with a sluggish economy.

The DPP called on Ma to apologize for what it described as the president's incorrect cross-strait policy, accusing him of leaning toward China, and also called on Premier Liu Chao-shiuan to take responsibility for "government incompetence" by resigning.

Former President Chen Shui-bian, who has put the DPP in an awkward position with his outspoken counterattacks against suspicions that he and his family were engaged in corruption and money-laundering, joined the march and was cheered on by a crowd of protesters.
Chen, however, did not make any public remarks.

No immediate estimates of turnout at the rally were available, but the DPP, opposition party the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and other pro-Taiwan independence groups that joined together in organizing the mass rally hoped to attract 500,000 participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County holds milk cow festival to support dairy industry

TEXT.P: Changhua County in central Taiwan opened a milk cow festival Saturday as part of efforts to show support for the local dairy industry, an official of the county's Department of Agriculture said Saturday.

The two-day annual event was expected to help increase consumption of milk and other dairy products in the winter, which is usually the peak season for milk production but the low season for milk consumption.
The festival, held in a cereal barn in the county's Fusing township, was organized by the department and the farmers' association of the township, where most of the county's milk cows are raised.
The festival displayed photos and video clips on the milk production process and development of the county's dairy industry to show how milk is produced and how milk cows are raised.
There was also a series of events giving children the chance to roll up milk rice balls or paint cutouts shaped like cows.
The farm also provided children with empty milk cartons to draw on and compete to see who could come up with the most creative design.

The first day's activities also included a milk drinking contest, which, instead of asking participants to drink as much milk as they could, invited them to make funny faces after downing the beverage, the official said.

Changhua County is one of Taiwan's most important milk production centers. It has a total of 102 milk farmers who raise 21,700 milk cows that produce about 65,000 tons of milk every year, about one-fifth of Taiwan's total production..
Milk farms can be found in each of the county's 26 townships, and many of them have existed for more than 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protest march in Taipei attracts foreigners' attention

TEXT.P: Many foreigners joined Saturday's protest march held by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to show support for the demonstration's positions and experience the atmosphere of a local political rally.

Maddalena, an Italian who has been in Taiwan for the last four years studying Chinese philosophy, told the Central News Agency that demonstrations in Taiwan are quite different from those in her native land, where protests against educational reform took place recently.

"Most of the protesters in Italy are young and intellectual, while here we can see many middle-aged and elderly people, " she said in fluent Mandarin, noting that the rallies generally have peaceful atmospheres.
Some foreigners who participated in the protest march were sympathetic to its positions and demands.

A Japanese who works in Taiwan said he joined the rally to express opposition against China, as Japan and Taiwan both have had to deal with unsafe food imports from their giant neighbor and the economic threat posed by China, which has drawn considerable investment from Japanese enterprises.

He noted, however, that in Japan, protest marches are generally organized by nongovernmental associations, and people rally spontaneously, while most marchers in Taiwan seem to be mobilized by political parties.
Kathryn, an Australian who has studied in Taipei for two months, said it would be best for Taiwan to remain independent from China to safeguard its precious democracy.

The DPP organized the "oppose China, protect Taiwan" rally to oppose substandard Chinese products, the one-China market, and the recognition of Chinese diplomas and criticize what it describes as the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) government's incompetence.

The rally is the second to have been organized against the KMT administration since it took office May 20, following an Aug. 30 march that demanded that the government defend Taiwan's sovereignty and the people's livelihood. The Aug.30 protest was organized by several pro-independence groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head wants to debate President Ma on sovereignty issue

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairwoman said Saturday she was willing to conduct a public debate and dialogue with President Ma Ying-jeou on national sovereignty issues and the country's cross-Taiwan Strait policy.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Tsai Ing-wen criticized Ma for his "opaque" handling of cross-Taiwan Strait issues in response to the president's accusation the previous day that the DPP was deliberately manipulating the sovereignty issue as part of the Oct. 25 protest march.
"If the people did not actually feel it, it would not be possible to manipulate the sovereignty issue, " Tsai responded.

Speaking to CNA Friday, Ma questioned why the DPP was denouncing the Kuomintang government, which took power May 20, for "surrendering" and "selling Taiwan" to China after it managed to achieve the long-awaited goal of opening the doors wider to transportation, commercial and postal cross-strait exchanges.

He noted that Tsai failed to accomplish the opening of the so-called "three- links" across the strait during her tenure as the chairwoman of the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council from 2000 to 2004.

Taiwan began exchanges with China on a small scale in 2001 when the DPP government opened two outlying islands -- Kinmen and Matsu -- to direct transportation links to China after the two sides had closed their doors to each other for nearly 40 years.
But it only stuck deals on nonstop flights between Taiwan proper and China on specific holidays.
Tsai rebutted Ma's criticism by saying the DPP had done nothing to harm Taiwan's sovereignty during its rule.

She said the DPP never accepted the "one-China" principle and the so-called "1992 Consensus" -- an understanding reached in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to provide their own interpretation of what "one China" actually represents.

Tsai argued that the DPP managed to stabilize cross-strait relations during its eight-year rule based on the condition that Taiwan's sovereignty was not harmed and that Taiwan did not give its sovereignty away.

The DPP chairwoman charged that Ma's approach to the sovereignty issue was even worse than the "one China, respective interpretations" consensus the KMT had upheld because it was closer to Beijing's "one-China" principle.
Tsai also suggested that when cross-strait policy has implications for the country's sovereignty, it should be approved by a national referendum before it can take effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to help with orphan drugs research

TEXT.P: The government and local charities should help with research and development of orphan drugs that are needed to treat rare diseases, also known as orphan diseases, an Academia Sinica academinician urged Saturday.

Chen Chien-jen, an epidemiologist who served as Department of Health minister from 2003-2005, made the pitch in a speech delivered at a ceremony marking the 80th founding anniversary of Academia Sinica, the country's top academic institution.
Noting that the development of orphan drugs is usually prohibitively expensive and unprofitable, Chen said only a few pharmaceutical companies are willing to develop them.

To encourage private sector investment, Chen said, relevant government agencies and local charitable organizations should play active supporting roles in promoting research and development in the field.

In his speech titled "environment, gene and human diseases," Chen said that genes are decisive factors in human diseases. But good health habits and avoidance of exposure to harmful substances in the environment can help reduce the incidence of disease.
Equally important in disease prevention and control is to step up scientific research on the causes of diseases, diagnostic methods and treatments, Chen said.

Touching on Taiwan's medical research, Chen said that as modern medical research emphasizes human rights and research ethics, researchers need to spend more energy on communicating with patients involved in experiments and protecting their privacy as well as the health and safety of those who are assigned to the control team in the new drug or treatment research project.

Thanks to the competence of local research teams and active participation by patients and ordinary citizens, Chen said many of Taiwan's medical or epidemiological research projects have proceeded smoothly.

As to the recent controversy over melamine contamination standards, Chen said Taiwan should set its own test standards rather than following those adopted by the World Health Organization or the European Union because major Western countries, such as the United States and EU countries, are unlikely to import milk or milk products from China.
Since the amounts of Chinese-made dairy products consumed by local people are different from those by Americans or Europeans, Chen said Taiwan should craft its own melamine contamination standards.
"The government is obligated to protect public health and impose strict food safety monitoring and control regulations," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office promises reforms in response to DPP protest

TEXT.P: The government will review its operations and make necessary reform to resolve public grievances, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Saturday.

Wang made the remarks after tens of thousands of opposition supporters marched through downtown Taipei earlier that day to protest the Kuomintang administration's growing ties with China, where a tainted milk powder scandal has fueled fresh distrust toward Beijing among local citizens.

In the strongest display of opposition to President Ma Ying-jeou since his inauguration May 20, demonstrators also demanded that Ma reshuffle the Cabinet immediately and apologize for his failure to deliver on his campaign promise to improve the economy.
The street protest was organized by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and major pro- independence groups.

Acknowledging that the demonstrators' appeals are the government's policy goals, Wang said that probably, insufficient government efforts, coupled with the ongoing global financial turmoil, have added to people's hardships and thus fueled public discontent.

"The government will make a thorough review and do whatever it can to meet the public's demand and expectations," Wang said, adding that the administration is more than willing to make all necessary reforms.

Responding to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's call for a debate with Ma on sovereignty issue, Wang said Ma hopes to meet Tsai to discuss issues regarding prevention of violence and corruption and major economic topics.
Despite its previous failed attempts to invite Tsai for face-to-face talks with Ma, Wang said the Presidential Office will continue its efforts to arrange for a Ma-Tsai meeting.

As protesting China's shipments of melamine-tainted milk products and other food ingredients was also a major appeal of the protest march, Wang said food safety is a priority item on the agenda for an upcoming meeting between the top leaders of the quasi-official intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Wang was referring to a meeting in Taipei early next month between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
Wang said the SEF and ARATS have forged a direct communication mechanism for food safety concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition rally protests president's cross-strait policies

TEXT.P: Waving banners reading "protect Taiwan, down with Ma Ying-jeou" and shouting "oppose toxic products, protect sovereignty," hundreds of thousands of people joined a rally Saturday organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to denounce President Ma Ying-jeou's approach toward China.

Rally participants marched through five parts of Taipei before gathering at Ketagalan Blvd. in front of the Presidential Office to protest, among other things, the Ma administration's conciliatory policy toward China and Beijing's shipments of toxic or substandard foodstuffs to Taiwan.
The weak economy was also on the minds of the protesters.
"Taiwan's economy is facing harsh times and the government could not do anything, " said Liu Tse-jun, a pregnant mother, who brought her three children with her to join the protest.
"I am doing what I can for Taiwan by joining this rally. The government had done nothing about the tainted milk from China," added Pai Fu-tang, a 40-year-old man from southern Taiwan.

The protest comes less than two weeks before China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yun-lin, arrives in Taiwan for talks on food safety issues and expanded cross-strait transportation and air cargo links.

Banners reading "we are anti-communist, we object to Chen Yunlin's visit" reflected protesters' views that the trip was not in Taiwan's interest, especially at a time when the country is struggling with a sluggish economy.

The DPP called on Ma to apologize for what it described as the president's incorrect cross-strait policy, accusing him of leaning toward China, and also called on Premier Liu Chao-shiuan to take responsibility for "government incompetence" by resigning.

Former President Chen Shui-bian, who has put the DPP in an awkward position with his outspoken counterattacks against suspicions that he and his family were engaged in corruption and money-laundering, joined the march and was cheered on by a crowd of protesters.
Chen, however, did not make any public remarks.

No immediate estimates of turnout at the rally were available, but the DPP, opposition party the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and other pro-Taiwan independence groups that joined together in organizing the mass rally hoped to attract 500,000 participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County holds milk cow festival to support dairy industry

TEXT.P: Changhua County in central Taiwan opened a milk cow festival Saturday as part of efforts to show support for the local dairy industry, an official of the county's Department of Agriculture said Saturday.

The two-day annual event was expected to help increase consumption of milk and other dairy products in the winter, which is usually the peak season for milk production but the low season for milk consumption.
The festival, held in a cereal barn in the county's Fusing township, was organized by the department and the farmers' association of the township, where most of the county's milk cows are raised.
The festival displayed photos and video clips on the milk production process and development of the county's dairy industry to show how milk is produced and how milk cows are raised.
There was also a series of events giving children the chance to roll up milk rice balls or paint cutouts shaped like cows.
The farm also provided children with empty milk cartons to draw on and compete to see who could come up with the most creative design.

The first day's activities also included a milk drinking contest, which, instead of asking participants to drink as much milk as they could, invited them to make funny faces after downing the beverage, the official said.

Changhua County is one of Taiwan's most important milk production centers. It has a total of 102 milk farmers who raise 21,700 milk cows that produce about 65,000 tons of milk every year, about one-fifth of Taiwan's total production..
Milk farms can be found in each of the county's 26 townships, and many of them have existed for more than 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 26, or the 28th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."
