DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply lower Tuesday, moving down 206.34 points at 4,160.53 on a turnover of NT$4.28 billion (US$127.77 million).
The weighted price index lost 212.75 points, or 4.64 percent, to close at 4,366.80 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.615 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.118 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 28, or the 30th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic indicators in September paint gloomy picture: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading economic indicators are pointing to a recession as the total indicator monitoring score fell to 12 points, a level not seen since December 2001, according to a report released Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The indicators also flashed a blue light for the month, a sign that the economy is heading toward recession, after signaling a slowdown a month earlier with a yellow-blue light.
It was the second blue light to appear this year after first appearing in July, said Hung Jui-bin, director-general of the CEPD's Economic Research Department.

The CEPD uses five colors to measure domestic economic health, with "red" indicating serious overheating, "yellow-red" for slight overheating, "green" for steady growth, "yellow-blue" for a slowdown and "blue" for recession.
The composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economy's outlook in the coming three months -- stood at 106.4 in September, down 0.3 percent from the month-earlier level.

The index has now fallen 11 consecutive months since last November, the CEPD said, attributing the September decline to drops in three leading indicators -- the stock market index, export orders, and semiconductor shipments.
Meanwhile, the index of coincident indicators, which reflects current economic activity, registered 109 in September, down 0.7 percent from August.
The decline was mainly caused by fall-offs in industrial production index, manufacturing sales, and exports, according to the report.

Hung attributed the recession to a continuing slowdown in the financial, manufacturing, consumption and export sectors and warned that the domino effect of the U.S. financial storm and economic slowdown was so powerful that Taiwan's economy would not be immune to its impact.

If there were any bright spots in September, Hung said, it was that crude oil prices and prices of staple raw materials were dropping in the international market, which is expected to drive inflation lower, Hung said.
The official also forecast that the economy would begin to recover in the second half of next year, as previous cycles of economic decline or contraction had lasted 12-15 months.
Hung suggested that the recession may soon reach bottom because the monitoring indicators have dropped for several months in a row.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beitou elementary school students to get spa treatment

TEXT.P: Stressed-out students at a Beitou elementary school will now be able to put their best foot forward after a hot spring foot spa was opened on school grounds Monday.

The hot spring pool, in which students will be able to dip their feet and which will also serve as a teaching facility, is the unique perk now being offered at Hushan Elementary School in Taipei City's Beitou district, one of Taiwan's best- known hot spring centers.

According to the school's principal, Her Yi-chun, the school's outdoor hot spring pool -- the first ever at a school in Taiwan -- was the result of test hot spring water wells drilled by the city's Department of Economic Development in the area in 2007.
School authorities noticed that hot spring water regularly bubbled up to the surface through the small test well drilled on the school's grounds and decided to investigate further.

They discovered that 100 tons a day of 40-degree Celsius water from a carbonic spring with fairly neutral PH readings rose to the surface every day, Her said, and decided to turn it into a place for students, teachers and residents of the community to relax.

Taipei City Education Department Director Wu Ching-shan, who presided over Monday's opening of the hot spring pool, praised the school staff's idea and joined a group of schoolchildren in bathing his feet in the pool.
Wu said the foot spa would be open to the public on holidays, in addition to the school's students, teachers and staff workers.
Beitou is located north of Taipei City's center and has long attracted visitors, dating back to when Japan ruled Taiwan, to its hot springs and spas.

DOC.HEADLINE: More dengue fever cases reported in Kaohsiung City

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has stepped up efforts to contain the spread of dengue fever as 28 new cases were reported in certain parts of the southern port city last week, a local health official said Monday.

"Twenty-eight more indigenous dengue fever cases were reported in the city last week alone, bringing the total cases to 186 so far this year, " said Ho Chi- kung, director of the municipal Department of Health.

As an annual national sports meet is being held in the city and a warm-up event for the 2009 World Games will also open in Kaohsiung Tuesday, Ho said the city government's dengue fever-fighting team has heightened its alert and stepped up preventive operations, including epidemiological surveys, environmental cleanups and emergency disinfection.
According to Ho, this year's dengue fever situation is far more complicated than before.

In the past, the outbreak in the city was usually caused by a single strain of the virus, but this year, he said, two types of the virus originating in four different countries -- Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines and Cambodia -- were detected in cases reported in the city.
Making epidemic control even more challenging is that the four different strains penetrated different districts of the city, Ho said.

For instance, dengue fever cases reported in the city's Nantzu district were mainly caused by a Type 1 virus originating in Thailand, Ho said, with 14 boroughs in the district affected by the epidemic.

But except for Jenchang borough, which was still being closely monitored, the epidemic had been brought under control in all other boroughs, with no new cases reported in those areas for more than six weeks.

A single case reported in Fenghua borough in Kushan district was caused by a Type II strain originating in the Philippines, Ho said, adding that no new case of this strain has been reported for more than four weeks.

Meanwhile, the Type II Cambodian strain mainly affects Chienchen district and neighboring Kaohsiung County's Fengshan City, and the cases reported in the city's Lingya district were mainly caused by the Type I Vietnamese strain of the virus, Ho said.

He suspected that the Cambodian and Vietnamese strains spread to neighboring areas in Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County in August, and although the outbreak was later contained, some remnants of the virus were able to spread into Chienchen and Lingya districts, causing the infection to reach a peak last week.
With intensive preventive efforts, Ho said the epidemic will be gradually subsiding in the coming one week or two.
The potentially deadly dengue fever is a mosquito-borne disease which is manifested by a sudden onset of severe headache, muscle and joint pains, a fever, and rashes.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's apology marks belated justice: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Tuesday described as a "belated justice" China's apology over the export of a shipment of melamine-tainted milk powder to Taiwan.
Liu, who openly demanded such an apology Oct. 7, said he believes the goodwill gesture by China will help create a favorable atmosphere for the upcoming negotiations between the two sides.
To help the victims claim compensation from the China, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is accepting registration by the affected parties, Liu said.

Taiwan was informed by China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on Sept. 12 that 25 tons of Sanlu-brand milk powder imported from China in June as an ingredient for food manufacturing was adulterated with melamine, after Sanlu recalled 700 tons of tainted milk powder linked to kidney- related diseases being suffered by young children.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-Taiwan Strait affairs in the absence of official ties.
In its latest letter to the SEF Monday, the ARATS said the case has been proven to be a food safety incident and offered an apology to Taiwanese consumers and businesses affected by the problem.

The move came ahead of talks slated for early November in Taipei between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin, in which the establishment of a cross-strait reporting system for food safety issues will be discussed.

Chen's planned visit is strongly opposed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which is dissatisfied with what it contends is the Kuomintang administration's failure to take a tough stance toward China in dealing with the scare over melamine-tainted milk products and ingredients imported from China.
To voice its protest against the upcoming Chiang-Chen talks, the DPP held a massive demonstration in Taipei Saturday that the party claimed to have drawn 600,000 participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOH bans all protein powder imported from China

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Tuesday a ban on another China-made food ingredient, protein powder, which was found to contain low levels of the toxic chemical melamine.

The protein powder is the fourth food item imported from China that has been banned in Taiwan since a food scare broke out in Sept. following the discovery that milk powder, creamers and ammonium bicarbonate from China had been contaminated with melamine.
"To protect consumers' safety and rights, all imports of the China-made protein powder will be banned from today," said DOH Deputy Minister Cheng Shou-hsia at a press conference.

According to Cheng, the tainted protein powder was found during random examinations conducted by local health bureaus in the past few days. Six of the 13 samples selected tested positive for the toxic chemical at levels of 1.9 to 5.03 ppm (part per million) , he disclosed.
The DOH has instructed the importers to recall product and has directed local health bureaus to seize all of it, he said.
Of the 704 tons of protein powder imported this year, 393 tons were from China, 261 tons of which was imported by four local companies and found to be contaminated with melamine, Cheng said.

The four enterprises imported the tainted ingredient from two companies, Dalian Greensnow Egg Products Development Co., Ltd. and Jilin Jinyi Egg Co., Ltd., located in Jilin and Liaoning provinces in northeastern China, according to Cheng.
To ensure food safety, all China-made protein powder, even if it tests negative for melamine, will be recalled, he stressed.
Protein powder is a food additive used in the production of ham, vegetarian ham, tempura and cakes, Cheng said, adding that it constitutes about one percent of the content of such foods.
He further indicated that the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis under the DOH has tested 40 samples of those food products, and the melamine tests were all negative.
Melamine has been found in imports of dairy products, creamers and vegetable- based proteins from China in the past weeks.
Under the DOH's current regulations, foods testing positive for melamine with the use of the LC-MS/MS technique (liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry) are not allowed on the market.
Melamine, an industrial material, was added by Chinese food producers to diluted milk to falsely elevate protein levels.
The practice has led to four deaths and sickened tens of thousands of children in China who were fed with baby formula made with contaminated milk.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's bid to interact with ASEAN a test of cross-strait ties: MOFA

TEXT.P: How China responds to Taiwan's efforts to establish relations with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is worth observing, as it will indicate Beijing's stance on Taiwan's campaign for more international space, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Victor Yu, director-general of the MOFAs Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that as the establishment of closer relations between Taiwan and the ASEAN countries depends on Beijing, it is a good opportunity to test the improving relations between Taiwan and China.

We have to use appropriate channels to let the Chinese leaders understand that Taiwans efforts to promote relations with the ASEAN is crucial and will provide a better foundation for the countrys survival and sustainable development," Yu said.
"If Beijing no longer has political concerns, it should show some goodwill on the issue, and we will see exactly how much goodwill it has toward Taiwan,he added.

Besides seeking better relations with China under President Ma Ying-jeou's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy, the Kuomintang administration has been stepping up efforts since it took office May 20 for Taiwan to actively participate in the integration of the Asia Pacific region and ASEAN.

Taiwan's foreign ministry decided on Oct. 17 to establish a think tank to develop strategies to promote relations with ASEAN countries, a decision made after a two-day coordination meeting of the ministry's newly formed task force on relations with ASEAN.
Yu said the task force will hopefully be in full operation by next January.

Taiwan fears its trade-dependent economy could be marginalized if it is not included in a regional free trade zone being negotiated, which would include the ASEAN countries, China, South Korea and Japan.

China will make its own evaluation of Taiwan's efforts to participation in the ASEAN, Yu said, adding that he believes that in the future both sides will put the issue on the agenda of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, given that it involves Taiwan's international space.

Noting that Taiwan has a lot to contribute to ASEAN, Yu said that the country's current mission is to establish a "systematic link" with the regional group to promote bilateral and multi-lateral relations.

Asked what name should be used in Taiwan's bid to participate in the ASEAN, Yu said although it is too early to discuss that matter, "as long as there is political goodwill, such a technical issue can be resolved."
Established in Thailand in 1967, ASEAN is made up of 10 member countries -- Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.
Its objectives, apart from promoting regional peace, include the acceleration of economic growth, social progress and cultural development among its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA confident about future ties with Palau

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Palau and Taiwan will remain solid and strong no matter which candidate wins Palau's upcoming presidential election because both candidates are friendly toward Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

After the first round of voting on Sept. 23, the two runners-up, incumbent Vice President Elias Camsek Chin and Johnson Toribiong, former Palau ambassador to Taiwan, will face each other in the Nov. 4 runoff for the presidency.

"Both candidates are good friends of Taiwan and therefore our relations with Palau will not be affected by the outcome of the election," said Victor Yu, director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
He added that Taiwan and Palau share close and substantial relations, citing as an example the fact that Taiwanese visitors make up one third of the total tourist arrivals in Palau.

According to Yu, the final result of Palaus presidential election is expected on Nov. 11 after all the votes, including absentee ballots, have been counted. The new president will be sworn in next January.
Taiwan and Palau established diplomatic relations in 1999 and the Pacific island remains one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plan for integration of Taichung city, county in final stages: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan said Tuesday that the plan to integrate Taichung city and county and upgrade their status to that of a special municipality is now in the final stages.

Liu made the remarks in response to a query on the issue by Legislator Chi Kuo- tung of the ruling Kuomintang who said he had already heard Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi's views on the integration plan.

According Chi, the interior minister said that the integration plan is a complicated political process involving several issues such as the terms of the magistrate and mayor and the status of village and township chiefs in the proposed special municipality.
Liao was quoted as having said that all of these issues would have to be dealt with in accordance with the law and public opinion.

Premier Liu said at Tuesday's interpellation session that after the plan is presented to the president and vice president for their input, it will be sent to all the relevant legislative committees and civic groups for discussion, after which time the details of the plan will be announced to the public.
He added that the process of integrating Taichung city and county and upgrading their status to a special municipality will "definitely be completed."

DOC.HEADLINE: Major Kaohsiung hotels buck trend with increased profits: mayor

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Tuesday that the increased profits of the southern port city's major international tourist and business hotels despite the tough economic times is a reflection of the city's high-quality low-priced tourism resources.

Speaking in a municipal government meeting attended by Kaohsiung Tourism Association Honorary President Lin Fu-nan, Chen said that the city's four major international hotels together increased their occupancy between January and August by 6,442 room bookings compared to the same period a year earlier.
The mayor noted that Kaohsiung has been the only city in Taiwan to achieve growth in this regard this year, attesting to its draw as a tourist destination.

During the meeting, Lin affirmed the municipal government's efforts at boosting Kaohsiung's tourism industry. However, he added that more could be done, noting that 250 of the city's smaller hotels still have an average occupancy rate of less than 50 percent.

Bureau of Redevelopment Director Liu Hsin-cheng said the fact that Kaohsiung's major international hotels have been able to boost their revenue is both the result of the city's attractive tourist resources as well as the municipal government's efforts, in cooperation with local tourism operators, to promote Kaohsiung tourism abroad.

He noted that the rate of growth in revenues of the four international tourist and business hotels in Kaohsiung ranked 1st, 3rd, 5th, and 6th, respectively, among all major hotels in Taiwan for the January-August period this year.

Their ability to buck the general trend of declining revenue amid tough economic conditions clearly illustrates the positive results of the efforts made by the municipal government's tourism promotion delegations sent to various overseas destinations, including Japan and Singapore, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head demands China's compensation over tainted food products

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen demanded Tuesday that China compensate Taiwan consumers and companies for the problems caused by its export of tainted milk products to the country, and that the Chinese government issue a formal apology over the food scare.

The apology offered Monday by China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) to Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was not sincere and the Chinese government should publicly apologize and put forward feasible measures to compensate Taiwan's consumers and businesses hit by the scare over melamine-tainted milk powder and other food items, said Tsai.

The melamine contamination in Taiwan was first detected in mid-September in a Chinese brand of milk powder and since then the list of similarly tainted food items has expanded, causing panic and outrage among local consumers.

Fielding questions from DPP lawmakers at a legislative meeting, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said he would accept the ARATS' apology, although he was not very satisfied with the way China has handled the issue.
"The ARATS should have apologized sooner," he contended.
The premier said he was confident that ARATS President Chen Yunlin would personally apologize to the Taiwan people over the issue when he arrives in the country next week.

During his visit to Taiwan from Nov. 3-7., Chen will hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Ping-kun, on the expansion of cross- Taiwan Strait tourism and travel exchanges as a follow-up to their historic meeting in Beijing in June.

According to Liu, the issue of melamine-tainted food products from China will be discussed in the coming ARATS-SEF meeting, and the SEF will ask, on behalf of the Taiwan people, for compensation from "the Chinese government and (culpable) companies."

DOC.HEADLINE: American evangelist Franklin Graham to preach in Taipei

TEXT.P: Franklin Graham, son of renowned American evangelist Billy Graham, will host a four-day evangelistic conference at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei between Oct. 30 and Nov. 2.
The Taipei Franklin Graham Festival is expected to attract over a quarter of a million people from around Taiwan, the event preparation committee said Tuesday.
Franklin Graham, born in 1952, is the president and CEO of both the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association and the international Christian relief organization Samaritan's Purse.
He will talk to local audiences about the political, economic and social problems that are disrupting society from the standpoint of religious faith, members of the committee said.

They noted that Graham hopes to convey the message of "new life, new hope" in Taiwan at a time when society's spirits have been dampened by rising unemployment, surging consumer prices and an economic slowdown triggered by the global financial crisis.
Billy Graham, who will turn 90 on Nov. 7, hosted a five-day evangelistic roadshow in late October 1975 in Taipei, drawing more than 200,000 people.

Acclaimed as the most famous contemporary evangelist who has had a personal audience with every sitting U.S. president since Harry Truman, Billy Graham has preached to more than 200 million people in 185 countries around the world.
Franklin Graham, who has taken over his father's evangelical duties, is scheduled to visit President Ma Ying-jeou at the Presidential Office Thursday before the conference begins.
He will pray for the president and invite him, as well as Premier Liu Chao- shiuan and other Cabinet members, to attend the evangelistic conference, the preparation committee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent for November and December.

TAIEX Index futures for November gained 282 points to finish at 4,316, with 161,939 contracts traded, while December futures increased 267 points to close at 4,262, with 1,559 contracts changing hands.
March futures advanced 268 points to close at 4,224, with 62 contract transactions, while June futures increased 258 points to finish at 4,193, with 89 contract transactions.
September futures gained 260 points to close at 4,058, with 32 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,034 for November, 3,995 for December, 3,956 for March, 3,935 for June, and 3,798 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 33.1 points to finish at 4,399.97, on turnover of NT$71.99 billion (US$2.14 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were both higher.
November TE futures rose 11.5 points to close at 176, with 6,364 contracts traded, while December TE futures increased 10.05 points to finish at 173.5, with 105 contract transactions.
June TE futures fell 4.7 points to finish at 158.8, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and September.
November TF futures gained 15.4 points to finish at 450.2, with 6,658 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures increased 19.2 points to finish at 450, with 74 contracts traded.
September TF futures fell 29.6 points to finish at 394.2 points, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to uphold dignity in reception of Chinese official

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan promised Tuesday that the government will uphold the country's dignity and interests in its reception of China's top negotiator with Taiwan, who is scheduled to visit Taipei in early November.

Liu said that while he has no plan to meet with Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the details of President Ma Ying-jeou's planned meeting with Chen will be made public after they are finalized.
Liu ruled out the possibility for the meeting to take place at the Grand Hotel where Chen will be staying, stressing that President Ma will be "receiving" Chen, not "paying him a call."
Liu said the government hopes Chen will call Ma "president, " but has prepared for other possible scenarios to make sure Ma's status is not downgraded in the meeting.
The premier made the remarks when asked about the issue during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen will be in Taipei Nov. 3-7 to hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, to discuss issues ranging from extending the weekend cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services to every day of the week and opening direct cross-strait shipping links to establishing a reporting system on food safety issues.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which believes the talks will lead to the sacrificing of Taiwan's sovereignty, is strongly against Chen's visit.
In addition to holding a massive rally to protest the visit on Saturday, the DPP is also planning to hold various demonstrations during Chen's stay in Taiwan.
The DPP plans, for example, to have supporters set up national flags on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to assert Taiwan's sovereignty.
On this matter, Liu said the government will allow the public to freely express their opinions and will not remove the national flags set up by protesters.
On the other hand, tight security measures will be imposed to prevent any possible outbreak of violence, Liu said.
During his visit to the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan last week, ARATS Vice President Zhang Mingqing was jostled to the ground by protesters, forcing him to cut short his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices edge higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging up 33.1 points to close at 4,399.97.
Rebounding after four consecutive losing sessions, the local bourse opened at 4,160.53 and fluctuated between 4,425.9 and 4,110.09.
A total of 4.33 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$71.99 billion (US$2.14 billion), the second highest single-day amount in the month of October.

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with Paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent. Machinery and electronics shares moved up 1.3 percent, textile stocks rose 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues were up 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 0.4 percent.
The other three major stock categories lost ground, with cement issue dropping the most at 2.1 percent. Construction stocks lost 1.7 percent, and banking and financial shares fell 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 884 to 487, with 363 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$16.07 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, decreasing NT$0.059 to close at NT$33.438.
A total of US$1.69 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.497 and fluctuated between NT$33.357 and NT$33.638.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor to promote tourism in South Korea

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu announced Tuesday that she will head for South Korea Wednesday on a tourism promotion visit.
Speaking at a meeting with city officials, Chen said she hoped the visit could help create more business opportunities for Kaohsiung City's tourism sector.

South Korean tourists made about 21,000 visits to the port city in southern Taiwan in the first nine months of this year, up from the previous year's level of 16,000, the mayor said, citing statistics compiled by the city government.
Chen said that on her mission to drive those numbers higher, she plans to tout the city to over 120 South Korean travel agencies and pay a visit to Busan City Mayor Hur Nam-sik.

The mayor, accompanied by the city's economic affairs and tourism bureau chiefs, will fly a charter operated by Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines from the Kaohsiung International Airport to South Korea's Incheon International Airport outside Seoul.
Chen has already visited Japan, Singapore and Hong Kong on tourism promotion missions this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan modern art masters exhibition to open in Maryland Saturday

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring a trio of renowned modern artists from Taiwan is set to kick off Saturday at Towson University's Asian Arts Gallery in the U.S. state of Maryland.
The "Taiwan's Three Masters of Modern Art" exhibition, which will run through Dec. 13, is being co-sponsored by the ROC government's Council for Cultural Affairs and the Maryland State Arts Council.
More than 30 recent works on paper, wood and lacquer of the artists Liao Shiou- ping, Ling Shi-chi and Chu Wei-bor will be on display.

The three artists, who broke with Taiwanese art tradition and embraced the avant-garde movement of the 1960s, have developed uniquely individual styles through years of exploration and innovation, according to an organizer of the event.
The organizer said that the works to be exhibited clearly illustrate the artist trio's "unceasing vigor in trying to surpass themselves."
The opening reception for the exhibition will be held Saturday from 3 p.m.-5 p.m. at the Asian Arts Gallery, Center for the Arts. Admission to the reception and exhibition is free of charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: President recognizes ARATS apology for melamine scandal

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou positively acknowledged Tuesday an apology from China's quasi-official intermediary body handling Taiwan affairs over the shipment of melamine-tainted milk powder to Taiwan.
"The apology is good and worthy of recognition, though it indeed came a bit late, " Ma said while meeting with top leaders of seven of Taiwan's largest industrial and commercial associations.

Ma was referring to an official letter of apology from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) sent to its Taiwanese counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, the day before, in which it apologized to the people of Taiwan for the "food safety incident."
Noting that the ARATS' promise to have the unscrupulous milk powder supplier punished was not enough, Ma said Taiwanese victims were entitled to claim compensation from China.
The SEF has set up a mechanism to assist local consumers and companies harmed by the melamine incident in seeking compensation, Ma said.

ARATS informed the SEF Sept. 12 that 25 tons of Sanlu-brand milk powder imported from China in June as an ingredient used in food processing was adulterated with melamine, after Sanlu recalled 700 tons of the tainted milk powder linked to kidney-related diseases suffered by tens of thousands of young children in China.
Melamine is an industrial chemical used to make plastics and banned as a food additive.
Ma told the senior business executives that maintaining peace with China is in Taiwan's best interest.
"We need not instigate conflicts to seek sympathy and should instead use peaceful means to resolve cross-strait disputes, " Ma said.
Unfortunately, Ma said, some recent incidents, including the melamine scare, have cast clouds on relations with China.
He said if Chinese authorities had offered an apology earlier over the melamine scare, Taiwan's people would have felt differently about the situation.

The letter of apology came just over a week before ARATS President Chen Yunlin visits Taiwan. Chen, as China's top point man on Taiwan, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Nov.3 for a five-day visit, during which he is expected to meet with Ma.

Acknowledging that many practical cross-strait issues need to be addressed, such as protection of Taiwanese investors in China, Ma said his administration will exercise prudence in engagements with China and will avoid any rash moves.

The business leaders wno met with Ma included Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Chang Pin-chao, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China and Chang Chiung-chang, secretary-general of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: 77th lineal descendant of Confucius dies in Taipei

TEXT.P: Kung Te-cheng, the 77th direct lineal descendant of Confucius, died Tuesday at the age of 89 in a hospital in Taipei County.
According to the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in the county's Sindian City, Kung checked into the hospital on Oct. 20 after developing pneumonia with a complication of sepsis.

Although doctors placed him in an intensive care unit and tried to use medicine and a respiratory device to stabilize his condition, he died of heart and lung failure at 10: 50 a.m. Tuesday, a hospital spokesman said.
Kung is survived by his wife of 72 years, Sun Chi-fang, son Wei-ning, daughters Wei-er and Wei-lai, five grandchildren and a great grandson.

As the head of the main line of Confucius' offspring around the world, Kung had served as the presiding official since 1935 at the annual ceremonies held by the central government on Sept. 28, Confucius' birthday, to honor the great Chinese sage.

Kung served in many important positions. He was a member of the National Assembly from 1946 to 1991 and helped draft the 1947 Constitution. From 1956 to 1964 he was director of the National Palace Museum in Taipei, overseeing the treasures transported from mainland China to Taiwan during the civil war with the communists. He was also a senior adviser to four successive presidents of the Republic of China from 1948 to 2000.

He served as the president of the Examination Yuan for nine years between 1984 and 1993. In recent years, he held professorships at National Taiwan University, Fu Jen Catholic University and Soochow University.

As Kung's first son Wei-yi, the 78th lineal descendant, died in 1989, his first grandson Tsui-chang -- the 79th lineal descendant -- born in 1975, has now become the head of the main line of the Confucian offspring and will serve as the sacrificial official in future Confucian ceremonies. .
Kung's great-grandson Yu-jen, the 80th lineal descendant, was born in Taipei on Jan. 1, 2006.

Confucius was born in 551 B.C. in the state of Lu -- now the Shandong province of China. He died at 73. His teachings have become the cornerstone of traditional Chinese culture and have greatly influenced other Asian countries as well.

In 1952, the Republic of China government in Taipei designated Confucius' birthday as Teachers' Day in recognition of his great achievements as a teacher. The Confucian temples around Taiwan and in other countries all hold sacrificial rituals on this day every year in honor of the highly respected sage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang-Chen talks to focus on non-political issues: President Ma

TEXT.P: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou stressed Tuesday that the upcoming talks between quasi-official bodies representing Taiwan and China would not address political issues.

Ma stated that the high-profile talks, to take place in Taipei in early November, will focus on "technical and functional problems, " which if not properly addressed would make it difficult to normalize bilateral economic ties.

He said the talks would cover issues such as opening new air routes and more destinations across the Taiwan Strait, extending direct weekend charter flights to weekdays, establishing direct shipping links and postal exchanges, and developing a framework to deal with food safety issues.
Ma made the remarks during his meeting at the Presidential Office with leaders of seven major industrial and commercial associations in the country.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for a five-day visit for a second round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) .

The visit was opposed by pro-independence activists who held a large-scale protest march in Taipei City Oct. 25 to voice their discontent with what they believe is Ma's conciliatory policy toward China.
But Ma said he expected the visit of Chen, the highest ranking Chinese official ever to visit Taiwan, to drive cross-Taiwan Strait relations to a new stage, he said.

Ma stressed that once transportation between Taiwan and China becomes more convenient, the business and cultural sectors will be able to adapt the new traffic model to benefit their own exchanges with China.
Such interactions extend far beyond the government's influence, the president said, and he urged the public to avoid politicizing all aspects of exchanges with China.

The seven industrial and commercial association leaders who called on Ma to show their support for his policy included Chen Wu-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Chang Pin-chao, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China; and Chang Chiung-chang, secretary- general of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

The other four were Lee Cheng-chia, chairman of the Taiwan Federation of Industry; Lin Ping-pin, chairman of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises; Chen Fu-hsiung, vice chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association; and Lai Cheng-yi, chairman of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan business groups welcome Chinese top negotiator's visit

TEXT.P: Seven Taiwanese industrial and commercial associations on Tuesday jointly expressed their support for the upcoming historic meeting between top negotiators of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, stressing that cross-strait interactions will be in the interests of Taiwans development and lead to a harmonious bilateral relationship.

In the statement on the upcoming meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman, and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, chairman of the Association of Relations Across Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the associations urged the government to maximize Taiwanese people's interests in negotiations under the principles of equality, dignity and mutual benefit, in order to foster an advantageous environment for the countrys economic revitalization.

They also stated that through bilateral exchanges, Taiwans food safety can be ensured, referring to the recent scandal over Chinas melamine-contaminated milk products, which were imported to Taiwan, causing consumer panic and hurting local food businesses.
The two sides can also discuss the global financial crisis, the groups said.

(The government) should consider how to enhance bilateral cooperation in the fields of economic cooperation and trade, in order to mitigate the impact (of the global financial crisis) on Taiwan, Preston W. Chen, chairman of the Taipei- based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), said at a press conference.
According to Chen, China has become one of Taiwans most important trade partners, as Taiwan ranks among the top five countries that invest the most in China.
China is also Taiwan's largest export market and second-largest source of imports.
Roscher Lin, president of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, said he hoped that the issue of Taiwan businessmens investment in China will be discussed.
He said Chinese authorities should apply the same regulations, such as stipulations concerning taxes, to Taiwanese investors as to Chinese people.

Chen added that Taiwanese industrial and commercial associations are also hoping Taiwanese SMEs can have access to more Chinese capital to help their businesses grow and cope with increasing production costs.
Lin explained that domestic banks seem to have decreased loans to enterprises, which have a strong need for capital.

He said that the amount of loans that banks give to enterprises is in accordance with enterprisesturnover. Under the pressure of the global economic downturn, their turnover has declined, which has led to more difficulties getting loans from banks, he said.
Chen Yunlin is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Nov. 3 for a five-day visit, leading a 60-member delegation, including financial officials and leaders of major banks in China.

During his stay in Taiwan, Chen will meet his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang, and is expected to sign four agreements, including aCross-Taiwan Strait Air Links Agreementand other deals on direct shipping and postal links and food safety.
Two seminars focusing on the global financial crisis will also be held between Chinese and Taiwanese financial officials and experts.

The seven associations that made the joint statement Tuesday were: the CNFI, National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Taiwan Federation of Industry, Taiwan Electrical and Electronic ManufacturersAssociation and Council for Industrial and Commercial Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to host Asia's second largest documentary festival

TEXT.P: Asia's second largest documentary festival will kick off in Taichung at the end of October, showcasing over 130 domestic as well as international film productions, including 18 from Taiwan.

The biennial Taiwan International Documentary Festival, which will open on Oct. 31 in the central Taiwanese city, has attracted some 115 overseas works from 34 countries this year for screenings and competitions in various categories.

"The works reflect the directors' concerns over 21st Century issues, such as the environment and marginalized groups, " Dr. Ava Hsueh, director of the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in Taichung, said at a news conference Tuesday.

One of the entries includes a documentary project "Invisibles", which is coordinated by German filmmaker Wim Wenders and comprised of five sections of films shot by directors from Spain, Peru and Germany aimed at making harsh situations faced by marginalized and underprivileged groups better known to the world.
Wenders himself chose to record stories of rape victims to highlight the problem of domestic violence in Congo.

The festival comes as a homegrown Taiwanese film "Cape No. 7" has taken the box office by storm - generating a record 440 million NT dollars in ticket sales so far. However, it is not a documentary and will not be included in the festival.

The story of love and humor celebrates what Taiwan is all about and has made local audiences regain enthusiasm in the local film industry, despite the sector being in a relatively quiet stage since its heydays in the '70s and '80s when it was considered the Hollywood of Chinese-speaking societies.

Hsueh said that the festival will not only serve as a platform for documentary makers to exchange ideas, but also help the museum with its initiative to expand its documentary database for research and public use.
"It will also allow viewers to gain different perspectives on the world through the filmmakers' lenses, " Hsueh said.
International filmmakers are expected to make appearances during after-screening gatherings, along with workshops and forums on documentaries held throughout the nine-day event.
Hsueh noted that this is Taiwan's first time cooperating with Asian and European film festival organizers to recommend awarded films to be shown at one another's events.

Meanwhile, the festival will also feature productions of local themes, including six documentaries from the series "Doc Taichung II: Taichung Through Different Eyes, " which are chosen as one of the two opening films at the festival.
The Doc Taichung II selection records the city's various aspects and civic activities, such as doctors' care for children, and the elderly's nostalgia of the past.
"A film festival has a tight connection with the locality, " Hsueh said, stressing that the event has made a point of focusing on the city.
Of the 18 Taiwanese works to be screened, four are running for awards in the international categories.

"Heat Sun, " for instance, records the sad fates of Taiwanese soldiers recruited to fight the Pacific War under the Japanese Occupation but were treated as prisoners of war when the war ended. They nevertheless show great vitality despite their suffering.
The documentary will represent Taiwan in the "International Competition - Feature Length" category.
Among the venues where the films will be rolling are the museum and the Cultural Affairs Bureau of Taichung City.
Free shuttle bus services to the film festival venues will be available at the Taichung Station on the Taiwan High Speed Rail.
The festival will close on Nov. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi County magistrate detained over suspicions of graft

TEXT.P: Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen was taken into custody by prosecutors Tuesday on suspicions he engaged in graft by leaking confidential information to help a businessman win a tender worth more than NT$650 million.
The Chiayi District Court granted the Chiayi Prosecutors Office's request to take Chen into custody out of concern that he could tamper with evidence in the case.
It said also he was eligible to be detained because the crime he was suspected of committing carries a sentence of more than five years in prison.
A panel of three judges made the decision, reversing a ruling by the same court on Oct. 4, when Chen was released on NT$3 million (US$89,652) bail.
Building contractor Lai Wen-cheng, who was released on NT$1.5 million bail on Oct. 4 in the same case, was also detained as requested by prosecutors.
Chen, a rising political star of the Democratic Progressive Party, is suspected of leaking to Lai the reserve price for a tender for a sewage system to be constructed in rural Minsyong township.
According to investigators who tapped Chen's phone last year after Chen's office tendered the sewage system, Chen called Lai to visit him at the magistrate's Taipei residence in May 2007.

Lai phoned his staff to rewrite his company's bidding price immediately after leaving Chen's residence and eventually won the contract with a bid of NT$654 million, or NT$200,000 less than the reserve price, prosecutors alleged in their request to the court to detain Chen.
As prosecutors believed Chen was the only one who knew the reserve price of the tender, they had investigators search the magistrate's office and Lai's company on Oct. 3 and sought their detention.
Chen denied any wrongdoing in the bidding process, and the Chiayi District Court rejected prosecutors' detention request on Oct. 4.
The ruling was thrown out by the Tainan Branch of the Taiwan High Court on Oct. 21 after prosecutors appealed the original ruling, which led to Tuesday's second hearing of the request.
Chen was escorted away from the court by sheriffs after the court announced its ruling, which stunned Chen's wife Liao Shui-hui and many of his supporters and drove them to tears in the court room.

Although his status as the county's magistrate won't be affected unless he is indicted and found guilty, his job at the county government will be assumed by Deputy Magistrate Huang Kui-nan while he is in custody.

DPP Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan described the case as political persecution. The party resolved on Oct. 8 that Chen was innocent of the allegations and warned prosecutors not to allow political partisanship to interfere with the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Not fast nor slow in promoting cross-strait ties: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the government's approach to improving relations with China is "neither too fast nor too slow, " and would not harm Taiwan's national dignity and sovereignty.

Ma defended the government's China policy at a meeting with leaders of seven industrial and commercial associations at the Presidential Office, responding to critics who argue that the administration is tilting too closely toward Beijing at the cost of the country's sovereignty.
The president insisted to the entrepreneurs that Taiwan and China stand as equals in their negotiations and that the problem of Taiwan being belittled does not exist.
As the president of the Republic of China, Ma said he will definitely make the safety and happiness of 23 million Taiwanese people his top priority.
"I grew up on Taiwanese rice and Taiwanese water, " he said, in expressing his determination to fight for Taiwan's interests.

With some suggesting that the government is opening the doors to China too quickly, while others believing the liberalizing moves have come too slowly, Ma said he understands that different people have different opinions.
Those seeing the development of ties with China as proceeding too quickly feel that way because there was no progress on the issue over the past eight years, Ma argued.
The president recalled, however, that late Formosa Plastics Group founder Wang Yung-ching once complained that the government walked too slowly.
"We will go neither fast nor slow" and will satisfy the needs of different sectors in the country, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei health officials find meat in vegetarian products

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Taipei City government said Tuesday that they had examined 35 vegetarian products sold on the market and found that six of them contained beef, pork or chicken.
The officials said that the six substandard vegetarian products, which constituted 17.1 percent of the samples examined, were not packaged and that consumers had no way of knowing their contents.

These food products were sold as vegetarian fish balls, vegetarian pork meatballs -- also known as Lion's head -- and various other vegetarian meatballs, but actually they contained animal ingredients, probably with the purpose to enhance their flavor, the officials added.

Chiang Yu-mei, director of the Food and Drug Division of the city government's health department, said that from July 1 next year, all vegetarian food manufacturers and stores must comply with a certification system designed to protect the rights of Taiwan's more than 2 million vegetarians.

She explained that the packages of the vegetarian products must label clearly to which of the five classes they belong: purely vegetarian, vegetarian with eggs, vegetarian with dairy products, vegetarian with eggs and dairy products, or vegetarian without animal content.

A package marked "purely vegetarian" means that it does not contain animal products or any of the five herbs that are considered as non-vegetarian -- onions, garlic, Chinese chives, shallots and leeks -- because, according to Buddhist scriptures, they excite the senses.

Those who do not comply with the certification system will be liable to fines of between NT$30,000 (US$895) and NT$150,000. If the description does not match the contents, or if the products are found to contain animal ingredients, their manufacturers will be fined between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000, Chiang warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Straits Exchange Foundation elects directors

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , founded in 1991 to deal with China in the absence of official ties, elected 49 directors Tuesday, four more than currently sit on the foundation's board.

Speaking after the new directors were elected in an extra-ordinary meeting of the foundation's board, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said the increase in the numbers of directors was necessary in light of the foundation's more prominent role.

In anticipation of more frequent exchanges between the foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , Chiang said the number of seats for government officials on the board was increased from 12 to 16.
The seats for business leaders who are mainly founders of the foundation and are eager to tap the Chinese market has been increased from 24 to 28.
But the number of seats reserved for social leaders decreased from three to two, and the number of seats for political parties fell from four to three.
Chiang said the elected directors will meet next month to elect a new chairman.
The foundation, which is preparing for talks in Taiwan with its Chinese counterparts early next week, was sidelined for nearly eight years under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian.
It was brought back into the limelight after the Kuomintang was swept to power to act as Taiwan's intermediary with China in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of improving ties with Beijing.
Chiang will meet ARATS President Chen Yunlin on Oct. 4 and the two are expected to sign four agreements on direct postal and shipping links, food safety issues, and expanding air links a day later.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to help Taiwan's food sector tap halal market

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) indicated Tuesday that it will help Taiwan's food industry tap into the multi-billion dollar halal food market in Muslim countries.

TAITRA executives said they have invited six managers of reputed food companies and supermarket chains from the United Arab Emirates, Malaysia and Indonesia to visit the 2008 Kaohsiung Food Show Nov. 6-9.

These companies include Indonesia's fresh produce importer Salitrosa Ausasia and two of Malaysia's supermarket chains -- Village Grocer and Bintang -- as well as two Dubai-based food importers: J.M. Foods and Dufoods Trading Co. -- a subsidiary of the Ibrahim Al Zarooni Group of the United Arab Emirates.

The TAITRA will also hold a Halal Food Market and Business Opportunities Conference on Nov. 6 at the Kaohsiung Business Exhibition Center, the site of the Kaohsiung Food Show. The keynote speaker will be J.S. Rajan, general manager of J.M. LLC Co. in Dubai, the TAITRA executives said.

A similar conference will be held Nov. 20 at the Taipei International Convention Center, with Norman Rajen Bin Abdullah, veteran manager of Malaysia's Mydin supermarket chain, and Edward Tjandrakusuma, general manager of Indonesia's Sinar Supermarket, slated to be the speakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agricultural tourism to be promoted at Taipei ITF 2008

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will promote Taiwan's agricultural tourism at the upcoming 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair, Stanley Yen, chairman of the organizing committee, announced Tuesday.

The COA will present three separate pavilions to illustrate the theme of "Enjoy life, experience happiness" at the 2008 ITF Taipei, which will open Oct. 31 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 1 for a four-day run.
They will showcase recreational farming, agri-flavored delicacies and country liquors, said COA deputy chief Wang Chen-teng at a press conference held in the Taipei International Convention Center.
According to Wang the COA has been trying to develop overseas travel markets to gain more opportunities for Taiwan's agricultural tourism.

The COA's primary goal is to attract tourists from Chinese speaking countries in the Asian-Pacific region due to the similarities in language, culture and eating habits, but this is only the first step of a marketing campaign to promote agricultural tourism internationally, Wang said.

The 62 countries showcasing their products at more than 1,200 booths will be the most in the fair's 22-year history, making it the largest and most important travel fair in Asia. It is estimated that more than 190,000 people will attend the event this year.

"The annual travel fair will include exhibitors from airlines, travel agencies, hotels, cruise lines, government tourist offices, land operators, bus operators, car rental companies, trade publications and other travel related enterprises, " said Yen, a prominent hotelier.
"It symbolizes the opportunities for development in Taiwan's tourism industry despite the global economical crisis."
Admission to the exhibition will cost NT$200 (US$6). A 20 percent discount will be given to those who purchase 10 or more tickets at the same time.
According to a spokesman for the event, visitors to 2008 Taipei ITF will also have free access to the Cross-Strait Travel Fair, which focuses on travel in Taiwan and China.
The promotion of the tourism industry is a key element in the Taiwanese government's efforts to combat the economic downturn that has gripped the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Czech Republic holds national day celebration

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based representative office of the Czech Republic held a national day reception Tuesday to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the countrys independence from the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

The independent Republic of Czechoslovakia was formed in 1918, following the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire after World War I. In an 1948 coup detat, Czechoslovakia became a communist ruled state and on Jan. 1, 1993, the country peacefully split into its constituent states, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Jaroslav Dolecek, representative of the Czech Economic and Cultural Office in Taiwan, said at the function that putting behind the 40 years of totalitarian communist rule,the people of the Czech Republic now live in a free and smoothly functioning democratic society and enjoy a thriving economy with rapid growth in exports, a strong inflow of foreign capital and relatively low unemployment.
Many people might be surprised to learn of the many things that Czechs have discovered or invented, such as contact lenses, polarography, the screw propeller, the wordrobotand so on, Dolecek said.

He added that in that context, the best way to describe the East European country is through Victor Hugo's words:There is no such thing as a little country. The greatness of a people is no more determined by their number than the greatness of a man is determined by his height.
Although Taiwan and the Czech Republic do not have diplomatic relations, Dolecek said that the two countries still share very good and close relations.
In the spirit of mutual benefit and reciprocity, bilateral exchange and cooperation between Taiwan and the Czech Republic in such fields as trade, tourism and science is constantly growing, he said.
Speaking at the function, Vice Foreign Minister Javier Hou said that both Taiwan and Czech started the process of democratization at roughly the same time.
Former Czech President Vaclav Havel led the non-violentVelvet Revolutionthat brought down communism in 1989, just two years after Taiwan lifted martial law.
Our shared beliefs have paved the way for strong bilateral cooperation and exchange, Hou said.They have also encouraged reciprocal visits between senior-level officials and parliamentarians.

Noting that Taiwanese also have experience in fighting communism and pursuing democracy and freedom, Hou said Taiwan can therefore share in the joy felt over Czechs joining the European Union in 2004.
He added that Taiwan would also one day become a more active participant in the international community.
Next year the Czech Republic will hold the EU presidency, which I suppose is dream come true for you, Hou said.Becoming more involved in the international community is a dream of our own as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: Not fast nor slow in promoting cross-strait ties: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the government's approach to improving relations with China is "neither too fast nor too slow, " and would not harm Taiwan's national dignity and sovereignty.

Ma defended the government's China policy at a meeting with leaders of seven industrial and commercial associations at the Presidential Office, responding to critics who argue that the administration is tilting too closely toward Beijing at the cost of the country's sovereignty.
The president insisted to the entrepreneurs that Taiwan and China stand as equals in their negotiations and that the problem of Taiwan being belittled does not exist.
As the president of the Republic of China, Ma said he will definitely make the safety and happiness of 23 million Taiwanese people his top priority.
"I grew up on Taiwanese rice and Taiwanese water, " he said, in expressing his determination to fight for Taiwan's interests.

With some suggesting that the government is opening the doors to China too quickly, while others believing the liberalizing moves have come too slowly, Ma said he understands that different people have different opinions.
Those seeing the development of ties with China as proceeding too quickly feel that way because there was no progress on the issue over the past eight years, Ma argued.
The president recalled, however, that late Formosa Plastics Group founder Wang Yung-ching once complained that the government walked too slowly.
"We will go neither fast nor slow" and will satisfy the needs of different sectors in the country, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei health officials find meat in vegetarian products

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Taipei City government said Tuesday that they had examined 35 vegetarian products sold on the market and found that six of them contained beef, pork or chicken.
The officials said that the six substandard vegetarian products, which constituted 17.1 percent of the samples examined, were not packaged and that consumers had no way of knowing their contents.

These food products were sold as vegetarian fish balls, vegetarian pork meatballs -- also known as Lion's head -- and various other vegetarian meatballs, but actually they contained animal ingredients, probably with the purpose to enhance their flavor, the officials added.

Chiang Yu-mei, director of the Food and Drug Division of the city government's health department, said that from July 1 next year, all vegetarian food manufacturers and stores must comply with a certification system designed to protect the rights of Taiwan's more than 2 million vegetarians.

She explained that the packages of the vegetarian products must label clearly to which of the five classes they belong: purely vegetarian, vegetarian with eggs, vegetarian with dairy products, vegetarian with eggs and dairy products, or vegetarian without animal content.

A package marked "purely vegetarian" means that it does not contain animal products or any of the five herbs that are considered as non-vegetarian -- onions, garlic, Chinese chives, shallots and leeks -- because, according to Buddhist scriptures, they excite the senses.

Those who do not comply with the certification system will be liable to fines of between NT$30,000 (US$895) and NT$150,000. If the description does not match the contents, or if the products are found to contain animal ingredients, their manufacturers will be fined between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000, Chiang warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Straits Exchange Foundation elects directors

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , founded in 1991 to deal with China in the absence of official ties, elected 49 directors Tuesday, four more than currently sit on the foundation's board.

Speaking after the new directors were elected in an extra-ordinary meeting of the foundation's board, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said the increase in the numbers of directors was necessary in light of the foundation's more prominent role.

In anticipation of more frequent exchanges between the foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , Chiang said the number of seats for government officials on the board was increased from 12 to 16.
The seats for business leaders who are mainly founders of the foundation and are eager to tap the Chinese market has been increased from 24 to 28.
But the number of seats reserved for social leaders decreased from three to two, and the number of seats for political parties fell from four to three.
Chiang said the elected directors will meet next month to elect a new chairman.
The foundation, which is preparing for talks in Taiwan with its Chinese counterparts early next week, was sidelined for nearly eight years under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian.
It was brought back into the limelight after the Kuomintang was swept to power to act as Taiwan's intermediary with China in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of improving ties with Beijing.
Chiang will meet ARATS President Chen Yunlin on Oct. 4 and the two are expected to sign four agreements on direct postal and shipping links, food safety issues, and expanding air links a day later.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to help Taiwan's food sector tap halal market

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) indicated Tuesday that it will help Taiwan's food industry tap into the multi-billion dollar halal food market in Muslim countries.

TAITRA executives said they have invited six managers of reputed food companies and supermarket chains from the United Arab Emirates, Malaysia and Indonesia to visit the 2008 Kaohsiung Food Show Nov. 6-9.

These companies include Indonesia's fresh produce importer Salitrosa Ausasia and two of Malaysia's supermarket chains -- Village Grocer and Bintang -- as well as two Dubai-based food importers: J.M. Foods and Dufoods Trading Co. -- a subsidiary of the Ibrahim Al Zarooni Group of the United Arab Emirates.

The TAITRA will also hold a Halal Food Market and Business Opportunities Conference on Nov. 6 at the Kaohsiung Business Exhibition Center, the site of the Kaohsiung Food Show. The keynote speaker will be J.S. Rajan, general manager of J.M. LLC Co. in Dubai, the TAITRA executives said.

A similar conference will be held Nov. 20 at the Taipei International Convention Center, with Norman Rajen Bin Abdullah, veteran manager of Malaysia's Mydin supermarket chain, and Edward Tjandrakusuma, general manager of Indonesia's Sinar Supermarket, slated to be the speakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese agricultural tourism to be promoted at Taipei ITF 2008

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will promote Taiwan's agricultural tourism at the upcoming 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair, Stanley Yen, chairman of the organizing committee, announced Tuesday.

The COA will present three separate pavilions to illustrate the theme of "Enjoy life, experience happiness" at the 2008 ITF Taipei, which will open Oct. 31 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 1 for a four-day run.
They will showcase recreational farming, agri-flavored delicacies and country liquors, said COA deputy chief Wang Chen-teng at a press conference held in the Taipei International Convention Center.
According to Wang the COA has been trying to develop overseas travel markets to gain more opportunities for Taiwan's agricultural tourism.

The COA's primary goal is to attract tourists from Chinese speaking countries in the Asian-Pacific region due to the similarities in language, culture and eating habits, but this is only the first step of a marketing campaign to promote agricultural tourism internationally, Wang said.

The 62 countries showcasing their products at more than 1,200 booths will be the most in the fair's 22-year history, making it the largest and most important travel fair in Asia. It is estimated that more than 190,000 people will attend the event this year.

"The annual travel fair will include exhibitors from airlines, travel agencies, hotels, cruise lines, government tourist offices, land operators, bus operators, car rental companies, trade publications and other travel related enterprises, " said Yen, a prominent hotelier.
"It symbolizes the opportunities for development in Taiwan's tourism industry despite the global economical crisis."
Admission to the exhibition will cost NT$200 (US$6). A 20 percent discount will be given to those who purchase 10 or more tickets at the same time.
According to a spokesman for the event, visitors to 2008 Taipei ITF will also have free access to the Cross-Strait Travel Fair, which focuses on travel in Taiwan and China.
The promotion of the tourism industry is a key element in the Taiwanese government's efforts to combat the economic downturn that has gripped the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. welcomes continuation of cross-strait dialogue
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 28 (CNA) 10/29/08 11:33:24 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States welcomes continued efforts by Taiwan and China to try to resolve their differences through dialogue, a U.S. State Department official said Tuesday.

Referring to the upcoming visit to Taiwan by China's top negotiator, the official from the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs said that Washington has always encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to seek a peaceful resolution of their dispute through dialogue.
The U.S. government is pleased to see progress in cross-strait relations, he said.

Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will be in Taipei Nov. 3-7 to hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, to discuss issues ranging from extending the weekend charter flight services between Taiwan and China to every day of the week and opening direct shipping links to establishing a reporting system on food safety issues.
The meeting will be the second of its kind since cross-strait dialogue was resumed in June after a hiatus of almost 10 years.
During their first encounter in Beijing, Chiang and Chen signed agreements on the launch of weekend charter flights and the arrival of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi County magistrate detained over suspicions of graft

TEXT.P: Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen was taken into custody by prosecutors Tuesday on suspicions he engaged in graft by leaking confidential information to help a businessman win a tender worth more than NT$650 million.
The Chiayi District Court granted the Chiayi Prosecutors Office's request to take Chen into custody out of concern that he could tamper with evidence in the case.
It said also he was eligible to be detained because the crime he was suspected of committing carries a sentence of more than five years in prison.
A panel of three judges made the decision, reversing a ruling by the same court on Oct. 4, when Chen was released on NT$3 million (US$89,652) bail.
Building contractor Lai Wen-cheng, who was released on NT$1.5 million bail on Oct. 4 in the same case, was also detained as requested by prosecutors.
Chen, a rising political star of the Democratic Progressive Party, is suspected of leaking to Lai the reserve price for a tender for a sewage system to be constructed in rural Minsyong township.
According to investigators who tapped Chen's phone last year after Chen's office tendered the sewage system, Chen called Lai to visit him at the magistrate's Taipei residence in May 2007.

Lai phoned his staff to rewrite his company's bidding price immediately after leaving Chen's residence and eventually won the contract with a bid of NT$654 million, or NT$200,000 less than the reserve price, prosecutors alleged in their request to the court to detain Chen.
As prosecutors believed Chen was the only one who knew the reserve price of the tender, they had investigators search the magistrate's office and Lai's company on Oct. 3 and sought their detention.
Chen denied any wrongdoing in the bidding process, and the Chiayi District Court rejected prosecutors' detention request on Oct. 4.
The ruling was thrown out by the Tainan Branch of the Taiwan High Court on Oct. 21 after prosecutors appealed the original ruling, which led to Tuesday's second hearing of the request.
Chen was escorted away from the court by sheriffs after the court announced its ruling, which stunned Chen's wife Liao Shui-hui and many of his supporters and drove them to tears in the court room.

Although his status as the county's magistrate won't be affected unless he is indicted and found guilty, his job at the county government will be assumed by Deputy Magistrate Huang Kui-nan while he is in custody.

DPP Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan described the case as political persecution. The party resolved on Oct. 8 that Chen was innocent of the allegations and warned prosecutors not to allow political partisanship to interfere with the case.
