DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-chief of Hsinchu Science Park detained over corruption suspicions

TEXT.P: The former chief of Hsinchu Science Park, James J. Lee, was taken into custody by prosecutors Wednesday over his possible links to the former first family's alleged money-laundering activities.

The Taipei District Court granted the request from prosecutors at the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office on the grounds that he had very likely engaged in corruption, which is a felony, and might tamper with evidence unless brought into custody.
The prosecutors requested Lee's detention after questioning him and his wife Feng Chao-ching for five hours Tuesday.
The two were interrogated after Special Investigation Division investigators conducted simultaneous searches of four sites, including Lee's residences in Taipei and Yilan City.
The case stemmed from the prosecutors' investigation into alleged money- laundering by the family members of former President Chen Shui-bian.

An anonymous official familiar with the case said that investigators found that a development company controlled by Jeffrey Koo, founder of the ChinaTrust Group, wired large sums of funds to the overseas bank accounts opened by two proxies of the first family after its land in Longtan, Taoyuan County, was purchased by the Hsinchu Science Park in February, 2004.

The official said the investigators suspected that the funds, which ended up in the first family's overseas bank accounts, were kickbacks offered by Koo's firm for the land deal, which was sealed at what investigators claimed to be unreasonably high prices during Lee's term as chief of Hsinchu Science Park.

Prosecutors in charge of the case refused to divulge whether Lee was detained because of his links to the ex-first family's alleged financial manipulations, saying only that he was suspected of steering undue profit toward Koo's firm.

A pro-independence activist, Lee went into exile in the United States when Taiwan was ruled by the Kuomintang, and returned to Taiwan to serve as the vice environment minister when the Democratic Progressive Party took power in 2000.
He was named as chief of the Hsinchu Science Park in October, 2001, and retired from that post after the KMT administration assumed office in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 29, or the first day of the tenth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators call for immediate cuts in utility prices

TEXT.P: Lawmakers on the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee demanded Wednesday that the government immediately reduce electricity and natural gas prices or face a boycott of the screening of their budget for the coming fiscal year.

Legislators across party lines passed a resolution at a meeting Wednesday, demanding that prices of household liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), natural gas, fuel oil and electricity be adjusted downward to reflect the decline in the prices of crude oil and basic commodities in the international market since hitting highs in early July.

Announcing the resolution, KMT Legislator Chiu Ching-chun, who chaired Wednesday's committee meeting, said the committe will suspend screening of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' 2009 budget until the ministry proposes a detailed price reduction plan.

Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Monday that natural gas prices in Taiwan could fall in November because of falling crude oil prices over the past two months, but indicated there was little room for cuts in electricity prices.

Yiin said power prices would likely remain close to their current levels because the previous price hikes in July and October only covered half the amount needed to cover the state-run Taiwan Power Company's losses.
Taipower estimated that it will still suffer an operating deficit of NT$100 billion this year, despite the two price increases.
The power company is expected to sustain a further deficit of NT$150 billion next year if power prices are not adjusted further by then to reflect actual costs, Yiin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Pompe disease screening key to better prognosis: study

TEXT.P: Taiwanese medical researchers have developed a new method to screen newborn babies for Pompe disease, enabling accurate early detection and efficient treatment that can greatly improve survival rates, academic sources said Wednesday.

With the help of "Myozym" -- a new drug developed by Chen Yuan- tsong of Academia Sinica -- babies suffering from the rare genetic disorder can be treated before they are one-month old and can recuperate to near-full faculties.
Pompe disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II, is caused by the deficiency in an enzyme called "acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA)" that is needed to break down glycogen.

Without the enzyme, glycogen accumulates in organs and muscles and gradually damages their functions. In the worst cases, infants with the illness will die from respiratory or cardiac complications before the age of one.

The incidence of Pompe disease is estimated at one in every 35,000 to 40,000 newborns, according to National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) , one of the institutions that participated in the project.

Hwu Wuh-liang, director of NTUH's Medical Genetics Department and a co-author of the scientific paper, said their search for an earlier detection method was sparked by disappointing clinical results with Myozym after it was approved for sale that did not live up to results obtained during the testing stage.
"We suspected the reason for the poor performance was that the treatments tended to start as late as half a year after birth, " Hwu said.
As a result, Hwu, Chen, and other researchers from Taiwan and the United States turned their attention to developing a new detection method that could spot Pompe disease earlier.

Compared to the conventional screening method that spots the syndrome between three to six months after birth, Hwu said that among all 132,538 newborns screened between October 2005 and March 2007, the new method successfully isolated four baby patients before they were a month old.

Along with three other patients, the four newborns were treated with Myozym as early as possible, Hwu noted. After receiving treatment every two weeks for more than a year, the seven newborn patients have grown healthily and their organ functions are almost as good as normal, Hwu said.
The results, which have been published in the science journal Pediatrics, have made possible the wider application of Pompe disease screening among Taiwan's newborns, said Hwu.
Beginning next year, he said, almost all newborns can undergo the test at a cost of NT$200 (about US$6).

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office mum on APEC envoy appointment

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office would not confirm reports Wednesday that former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien will be appointed by President Ma Ying-jeou to attend the 2008 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders summit in Peru next month.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi had no comment on reports by two major Chinese-language dailies Wednesday speculating that Chien, who was Taiwan's foreign minister between 1990 and 1996, would attend the APEC summit meeting on behalf of the president.
"We will make an announcement at an opportune time on who will represent President Ma in attending the summit meeting," Wang noted.

The United Daily News reported that if Chien is appointed by Ma to attend the 2008 APEC summit meeting, to be held in Lima, Peru Nov. 22-23, he would be the highest-ranking former Republic of China (Taiwan) official to attend the APEC leaders gathering.

His participation would mark a "significant development" in Taiwan's relations with China since Ma took office in May, the daily said. Ma has adopted a policy of "diplomatic detente" to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Because of Beijing's opposition, ROC presidents have been barred from the APEC unofficial leadership summit meeting since the country became a member of the regional grouping in 1991 under the moniker "Chinese Taipei."
Ma said during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency last week that "we will do whatever we can to raise the level of our representation at the APEC leadership summit."
In recent days, former Vice President Lien Chan has also been named as a possible envoy to the forum.

Taiwan was represented by prominent business leaders in the important regional meetings over the last two years -- by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, respectively.

Chien, 73, has also served as speaker of Taiwan's now-defunct National Assembly and chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development. He also taught Ma when Ma was a student at National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators call for immediate cuts in utility prices

TEXT.P: Lawmakers on the Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee demanded Wednesday that the government immediately reduce electricity and natural gas prices or face a boycott of the screening of their budget for the coming fiscal year.

Legislators across party lines passed a resolution at a meeting Wednesday, demanding that prices of household liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), natural gas, fuel oil and electricity be adjusted downward to reflect the decline in the prices of crude oil and basic commodities in the international market since hitting highs in early July.

Announcing the resolution, KMT Legislator Chiu Ching-chun, who chaired Wednesday's committee meeting, said the committee will suspend screening of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' 2009 budget until the ministry proposes a detailed price reduction plan.

Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Monday that natural gas prices in Taiwan could fall in November because of falling crude oil prices over the past two months, but indicated there was little room for cuts in electricity prices.

Yiin said power prices would likely remain close to their current levels because the previous price hikes in July and October only covered half the amount needed to cover the state-run Taiwan Power Company's losses.

Taipower generates much of its electricity from thermal coal, and Yiin said a rise in international coal prices from NT$2,280 per ton on July 1 to NT$3,938 in October, made it difficult to cut power rates to users.
Yiin's remarks appeared to fly in the face of reality, as spot coal prices in the international market have been on the decline since reaching a peak at the beginning of July.
But a Taipower spokeswoman told the Central News Agency that Yiin was actually conveying the utility's average coal costs.

She said that the lower prices in the first half of 2008 still reflected the long-term coal contracts Taipower had signed in 2007, while rising prices in international markets in 2008 were only being reflected in purchases made in recent months, leading to a rise in average costs.
The spokeswoman said with market prices highly volatile, Taipower to date has only signed long-term contracts for 12 percent of its coal needs in 2009.

She added that while spot prices on some coal markets have fallen well below US$100 per ton, large vendors have been unwilling to sign one-year supply contracts at those prices, leaving next year's cost picture uncertain.
Taipower estimates that it will still suffer an operating deficit of NT$100 billion this year, despite the two price increases.
The power company is expected to sustain a further deficit of NT$150 billion next year if power prices are not adjusted further by then to reflect actual costs, Yiin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ratio of businesses offering on-the-job training down: survey

TEXT.P: The percentage of businesses offering on-the-job training has declined significantly since last year amid tough economic times, according to the results of a survey released by 1111 Job Bank Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by the online employment services provider during the latter half of this month, revealed that only 61.33 percent of businesses offer on-the-job training, down from 85.65 percent in a similar survey last year.

Among the businesses taking part in the survey, 66.1 percent said they are in favor of providing assistance to their employees for on-the-job training, down slightly from 70.45 percent last year, while 28.95 percent said they have no opinion as they consider job skills training a personal decision.

Only 4.95 percent of the respondents said they do not support providing assistance for such training, with the main reasons mentioned being concerns about work load, waste of company resources and inability to offer overtime.
By sector, businesses in the information technology and real estate industries were the most likely to offer on-the-job training to employees.

Ryan Wu, chief operating officer of 1111 Job Bank, said the percentage of businesses in the IT and real estate sectors offering on-the-job training is so high because skilled employees are at the core of these businesses' profitability.

The survey on the effects of the economic downturn on businesses' attitudes toward providing on-the-job training was conducted online between Oct. 15-28, with a total of 525 valid samples being collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drug rehab center offers violin class to inmates

TEXT.P: A violin concert was held at the Taichung Drug Abuser Treatment Center Wednesday, where 20 former drug abusers entertained center officials, their peers and visiting relatives by playing four musical compositions.
The visiting relatives of the inmates, including a 90-year-old grandmother, were all moved by their performances.
The inmates have attended a three-month violin class that the center sponsored as one of the programs devised to help the drug abusers kick their habit while continuing to grow mentally.

"It takes patience and perseverance to get rid of addiction, but abstention will be easier or more pleasant if the center can help the inmates rediscover the value of their lives during the rehab process," said Chou Hui-huang, director of the center.
One of the inmates said that by learning to play the violin, he has become more settled internally and has gained a clearer sense of his life's direction.
In addition to violin class, the center has had many other classes and programs in place to help the inmates weather tests and challenges, Chou said.

The classes and programs include religion groups, martial art classes, gardening and greening programs, a computer maintenance class, an Aboriginal dancing class, a mind exploration and improvement program and an experience sharing class, according to Chou.
The Taichung Drug Abuser Treatment Center, one of the government-funded rehab centers in Taiwan, was established Jan. 1, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to further demonstrate against Chinese negotiator's visit

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a series of demonstrations next week against the visit of China's top negotiator with Taiwan, after holding a massive anti-China rally last Saturday, a party official said Wednesday.

The planned demonstrations will include a vigil, an encircling-the-city protest and simultaneous rallies around Taiwan, said Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information.

There will also be protests targeted specifically at separate meetings to be held by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and President Ma Ying-jeou with Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, Cheng said.
He said the DPP will make sure the demonstrations are peaceful and non-violent when encouraging the public to express their opposition to the "Chiang-Chen meeting" and "Ma-Chen meeting."

Chen, president of the Beijing-based semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is scheduled to lead a delegation to Taipei Nov. 3-7 to discuss with the SEF issues ranging from extending the weekend charter flight services between Taiwan and China to every day of the week and opening direct shipping links to establishing a reporting system on food safety issues.

The DPP believes the talks will lead to the sacrificing of Taiwan's sovereignty and is strongly against Chen's visit. The party is also dissatisfied with what it claims is the Kuomintang administration's conciliatory attitude in dealing with the scare over melamine-tainted milk products and ingredients imported from China.
The upcoming demonstrations will be follow-ups of a march held by the DPP in Taipei Saturday, which the party claims drew 600,000 participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.5 million Citizen Digital Certificate cards issued to date: MOI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior announced Wednesday that the number of Citizen Digital Certificate cards issued to date has surpassed the 1.5 million mark.

The card -- an electronic identity card with security features in the form of a contact microprocessor 'smart' chip card -- is the basis for an e-government initiative that links all government agencies through networking and provides convenient and versatile services to citizens, the ministry said in a press release.
A total of 1,548 different types of government applications can now be made using the CDC card, which citizens have used over 20 million times since its launch in 2003, according to the ministry.

The government began accepting applications for CDC cards on Apr. 30, 2003, and it completed the integration of all 374 household registration offices around Taiwan into the system by June of the following year, the ministry said.

The card can now be used for a wide range of services, including income tax submission, vehicle registration, labor insurance and pension matters, driver's license application, and household registration, to name a few, according to the ministry.
The ministry said that the issuance of more than 1.5 million cards illustrates the concrete achievements of the government's promotion of the e-government services initiative.

It said that the services offered under the CDC card program will be expanded and that it is currently in consultation with various government agencies to join the program, adding that the expanded services will attract even more citizens to apply for the CDC card in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.143 to close at NT$33.295.
A total of US$1.535 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.318 and fluctuated between NT$33.216 and NT$33.450.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices edge lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for November fell 28 points to close at 4,288, with 170,104 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 30 points to finish at 4,231, with 1,537 contracts traded.

March futures fell 38 points to close at 4,186, with 68 contract transactions, while June futures lost 24 points to finish at 4,169, with 141 contract transactions. September futures were down 29 points to close at 4,029, with 31 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,316 for November, 4,261 for December, 4,224 for March, 4,193 for June and 4,058 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index moved up 6.55 points to finish at 4,406.52, on turnover of NT$79.74 billion (US$2.39 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

November TE futures fell 1.5 points to close at 174.5, with 6,175 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 1.25 points to finish at 172.25, with 220 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
November TF futures were up 7.6 points to close at 458.6, with 4,765 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures were up 4.4 points to finish at 454.4, with 52 contracts traded.
March TF futures increased 11 points to close at 464.4, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices close marginally higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.55 points to close at 4,406.52.
Finishing higher for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 4,622.55 after the Dow surged 10 percent overnight, but then retreated, falling as low as 4,395.61.
A total of 4.52 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$79.74 billion (US$2.39 billion), the highest of any session in October.

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1.2 percent and banking and financial shares increased 1.1 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.2 percent. Cement stocks declined 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 0.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares dropped 0.1 percent, and foodstuff issues were down 0.03 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 768 to 624, with 409 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$4.42 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film director donates earnings to help needy indigenous families

TEXT.P: Taiwanese director Wei Te-sheng, whose romantic comedy "Cape No. 7" has taken box offices by storm, has donated funds raised from an auction of props used in the film to a local charity to help impoverished aboriginal families.

Wei, along with actors and actresses in the film, donated NT$1.82 million (US$54,675.99) to the Christian charity World Vision Taiwan Tuesday. The charity will use the funds to help needy aboriginal families in central Taiwan and the southern county of Pingtung, where the movie was made.
The donated funds were raised from an Oct. 3-20 online auction of props used in the film.

The film, Wei's first full-length motion picture, is still being screened in movie theaters around Taiwan, with box office earnings already surpassing NT$400 million -- the second highest in Taiwan, next to the NT$775 million for the Hollywood Blockbuster "Titanic".

The film tells two interrelated stories. One is a love story about a Japanese man leaving his Taiwanese girlfriend at the end of World War II when Japan gave up its colonial rule of the island. The other is about the dreams of a group of young, amateur Taiwanese musicians.
"Cape No. 7" won the Best Narrative Film at the 2008 Louis Vuitton Hawaii International Film Festival on Oct. 15.

According to information posted on the festival's Web site, an international jury screened 150 entries from 36 countries based on the Hawaii film festival's mandate "to entertain, enlighten and empower."

Taiwan's Government Information Office officials noted recently that in addition to receiving a cash award of NT$100,000, Wei will be entitled to a government subsidy to cover 20 percent of the movie's NT$50 million budget, due to the success of the film.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to launch text-message parking query system

TEXT.P: Taipei City Parking Management Office in collaboration with Chunghwa Telecom will launch Nov. 1 a new parking query system that will help drivers locate the three parking lots closest to their vehicles with a simple text message, an official said Wednesday.

To provide the service, the city and Chunghwa Telecom have collaborated on a mobile phone positioning system that will link a system identifying the location of the cell phone user's vehicle with computerized information on nearby parking lots, according to Chien Pai-chang, an official at the office's operation department.
Drivers who are Chunghwa Telecom subscribers only need to send a text message to "55145" to get parking information, Chien said.

Once the text message is sent, Chunghwa Telecom will determine the phone's location based on the strength of the cell phone's signal received by its base stations and then transmit that information to the Parking Management Office's computer system.
The office's computer will then search for parking lots in the area and the number of empty spaces left and text that information automatically to the driver.
The process takes around two minutes and costs NT$2.3 per request, Chien said.
Taipei City will also continue with its instant parking query system, which enables drivers to obtain information on public parking spaces available in the city by telephone, according to Chien.
Under that system, Chunghwa Telecom mobile subscribers can dial "55145" to make voice queries on parking fees and open parking spaces.

Some users had complained that the voice service was not convenient enough and that cell phone inquiries were expensive, Chien said, which prompted the office to expand the query system's functions and convenience.
Non-Chunghwa Telecom cell phone subscribers or local telephone users can dial (02) 2726-9600 ext. 2 to make similar queries as well, Chien added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign tourist arrivals on rise: tourism bureau

TEXT.P: Although a violent incident might impact Chinese tourists' willingness to visit Taiwan, tourist arrivals from many parts of the world have been on the rise this year, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said Wednesday.

"Except for Japan, numbers of tourist arrivals from European and Southeast Asian countries as well as the United States and South Korea have been increasing this year, " Lai told a legislative committee meeting screening the bureau's 2009 budget.
"It is clear evidence that the government is not only setting its sights on China in its tourism expansion efforts," she asserted.

Lai acknowledged that an incident last week in which a visiting Chinese official was besieged by local protesters might affect the willingness of Chinese tourists to visit, but said most visitors from China had a good impression of Taiwan and its people's hospitality.

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was harassed and jostled to the ground by a group of anti-China protesters Oct. 21 while on a private visit to the Confucius Temple in southern Taiwan's Tainan City.

As a result of the incident, seven Chinese representatives who were slated to attend the 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair from Oct. 31 - Nov. 3 canceled their trip to Taiwan out of fear for their personal safety, she said.

However, a total of more than 290 Chinese people, a figure higher than last year's level, have applied to take part in this year's international travel fair at the Taipei World Trade Center, Lai said.

Meanwhile, ARATS President Chen Yunlin will arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for a five- day visit and will hold talks with Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on the expansion of two-way exchanges on travel, tourism and food security as a follow-up to their historic meeting in Beijing in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan investor confidence hits record low: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investor confidence plunged to a record low in the third quarter of 2008, as pessimism prevailed amid the global financial crisis, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by asset management firm JF Taiwan Limited.

The results show that Taiwan's investor confidence index stood at 81.8 in October, a 23.3 percent decline compared to July when the survey was last conducted and marking the lowest level since the survey was launched in July 2004.
An index below 100 is indicative of pessimism, while one above 100 is indicative of optimism.

All six components of the index declined in October, with the largest drop-off coming in respondents' outlook on the possibility of "one's own investment portfolio appreciating in the next six months," which fell 28.9 percent to 69.8.
The possibility of "Taiwan's economic environment" improving posted the second largest fall, declining 28.21 percent from three months earlier to reach a record low of 69.3.
Also hitting a record low level was the possibility of an "increase in the Taiex, " which registered 89.9 in October, down 21.3 percent from July.

While the "possibility for a better investment market environment and atmosphere" dropped 26.6 percent to 81.4, the possibility for "a better global economic environment" lost 15.2 percent to stand at 70.8.
The possibility for a "better political environment and cross-Taiwan Strait relations" decreased 19.8 percent to 109.5, making it the only indicator that still remained above the median value of 100.

The results ran parallel to those of a similar survey conducted in Hong Kong, in which the Hong Kong investor confidence index plummeted 20.2 percent to 95 in September, marking the first time the index has dropped below 100 since the survey was launched in July 2006 in Hong Kong.

Investor confidence in other areas, such as the possibilities for better employment opportunities, higher commodity prices, higher property prices and increases in income, also declined significantly in both Taiwan and Hong Kong, all hitting record lows.

While the prospect for better employment opportunities and higher property prices nosedived by around 60 percent in both Taiwan and Hong Kong, the outlook for higher commodity prices plunged by 50.7 percent in Taiwan and 32.6 percent in Hong Kong thanks to the ease in inflationary pressures.
Meanwhile, 58.8 percent of Taiwanese investors surveyed thought the measures put forth recently by governments worldwide would help boost investor confidence.
Approximately 40 percent of respondents were upbeat that the global economic downturn would touch bottom within one year, while 30 percent believed it would touch bottom in between one and two years.

The Taiwan survey was conducted via telephone Oct. 13-19 among 1,079 investors aged 20 and above. The Hong Kong survey was carried out via face-to-face interviews in late September among 500 investors aged 21-60.

DOC.HEADLINE: Black-faced spoonbill season begins in Tainan County

TEXT.P: The southern county of Tainan has entered its black-faced spoonbill season, with 638 of the endangered birds having flown south as of Wednesday to winter in the county's wetlands, a local official said that same day.
This year's first black-faced spoonbill was observed in the southern county Oct. 1, according to the official at the county's Department of Agriculture.

The birds migrate from northern China and the border between North and South Korea to the wetlands near the Tzengwen River's estuary in Tainan county's Chigu township every October and stay through the following April.
According to the official, the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan designated a protection zone in the wetlands in 2002 for the conservation of the species.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said the wetlands have many other attractions waiting to be discovered and the county government has tried to preserve the topography in order to retain more creatures there.
The county government has improved its management of the wetlands and held promotional activities to invite the public's support for its preservation efforts, Su said.

The local government established the Black-Faced Spoonbill Conservation and Management Center near the wetlands three years ago to carry out research on the endangered species, which is viewed as an environmental indicator, Su said.

The number of migrating spoonbills to Tainan County increased from nearly 300 in 1997 to 1,013 early this year, which was close to half of the world's 2,065 spoonbills recorded in the latest global census released this January, the official said.
The total number of migrating spoonbills to Tainan county this year is expected to increase from the current figure, but it is difficult to predict the exact number, the official said.
The county will hold its annual black-faced spoonbill conservation festival on a date not yet decided, to allow the public to learn more about the rare bird and the wetlands' resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food safety to feature prominently in Chiang-Chen meeting

TEXT.P: Food safety will be a major topic of discussion when Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), meets with his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin early next month, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Wednesday.

Yeh told reporters that Chiang and Chen, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , are expected to sign an agreement under which both sides of the Taiwan Strait will establish a mechanism to ensure food safety.
Chen is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Nov. 3 for a five-day visit at the invitation of Chiang for a second round of talks between them. They last met in Beijing in June.

Yeh pointed out that there is already a dialogue channel between the Cabinet- level DOH and the Ministry of Health of China, and that health officials from the two sides have already reached consensus on the text of the agreement to be finalized and signed at the meeting.

According to Yeh, under the proposed food safety mechanism, China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine should strictly enforce the same standards for food exports to Taiwan, the United States, Europe and Japan.
In addition, he added, the DOH will set up a food and drug administration to stop the import of all substandard food products from China at Taiwan's borders.
The mechanism will allow for compensation to those who have suffered harm and losses due to toxic and substandard food imports from China, Yeh said.

Taiwan's food sector has suffered a series of blows as a result of the importation of melamine-tainted food products, including milk power, protein powder and ammonium bicarbonate -- a bread raising agent -- from China.
Many coffee shops and bakeries have complained that the melamine scare has caused them to lose up to 50 percent of their business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former vice president to attend APEC leaders summit on behalf of Ma

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office announced Wednesday that former Vice President Lien Chan will attend the 2008 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum leaders summit in Peru next month on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.

Lien would be the highest-ranking former Republic of China official ever to attend an APEC leaders summit, and his participation will be seen by some as a symbol of progress in Taiwan's relations with China following Ma's inauguration on May 20.

Ma has adopted a policy of "diplomatic detente" to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait that critics contend will not reverse China's efforts to prevent Taiwan from participating in the international community.

Because of Beijing's opposition, ROC presidents have been barred from the APEC leaders summit meeting since the country became a member of the regional grouping in 1991 under the moniker "Chinese Taipei."
Ma said during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency last week that "we will do whatever we can to raise the level of our representation at the APEC leadership summit."

Taiwan was represented at the first APEC leaders summit, held in Seattle in 1993, by Vincent Siew, then chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development. Siew is now vice president.

In 2001, then President Chen Shui-bian proposed to send former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to attend the APEC leaders summit to be held in Shanghai. Taiwan boycotted that gathering after Chen's proposal was rejected.
Taiwan was represented by prominent business leaders in the last two APEC forums -- by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, respectively.

Lien, 72, who earned a Ph.D. in political science from the University of Chicago, was the Republic of China vice president between 1996 and 2000 and chairman of the now ruling Kuomintang in 2000-2005.
The 2008 APEC summit meeting is slated to be held in Lima, Peru Nov. 22-23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top China negotiator's visit a milestone for cross-strait ties: SEF

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency Wednesday that the upcoming visit by mainland China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin is a "milestone" in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
"Mainland China official Chen Yunlin's visit to Taipei is a milestone in cross- strait relations and will serve to brightly polish Taiwan's plaque," said Chiang.
However, Chiang stressed that "hospitality and courtesy to guests will need to be observed, as it is the means to win mainland China's respect for Taiwan."
In addition, it is important to pay Chen respect as the international community will be watching this historic meeting in Taiwan, Chiang said.

"We ourselves also need to polish the plaque of Taiwan sovereignty by strengthening our economy and ensuring that the government is corrupt-free. We should not let protests ruin this plaque and make us the laughing stock of the world," said Chiang.
The five-day visit is scheduled to begin on Nov. 3. Chen will be the highest- ranking Chinese official to visit Taiwan since the two sides split at the end of a civil war in 1949.

Chiang's comments reflected concerns over the opposition's strong objections to Chen's visit. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held a rally which was attended by tens of thousands of people in Taipei on Oct. 25. Protesters voiced discontent over the visit and Ma's opening-up policies toward China.
Just last week, ARATS Deputy President Zhang Mingqing was slightly injured when he was mobbed by protesters in Tainan City in southern Taiwan.
The DPP and pro-independence activists are planning further protest activities to coincide with Chen's visit.
Apparently due to worries about Chen's safety and to avoid any chance of protesters mobbing Chen, Chiang said Chen will not do any sightseeing in Taiwan.
"Chen's visit to Taiwan will be purely for negotiations and that no other visits to Taiwan tourist sites will be included due to security reasons," said Chiang.
He noted that Chen's itinerary originally included visits to central and southern Taiwan, but those visits have been canceled due to the mobbing of ARATS Deputy President Zhang.

The landmark meeting between Chiang and Chen will cover issues such as opening new air routes and more destinations across the Taiwan Strait, extending direct weekend charter flights to weekdays, establishing direct shipping links and postal exchanges, and developing a framework to deal with food safety issues, Chiang said, adding that cross- strait direct air cargo transport will be included in negotiations on chartered flights.
Chiang indicated there was a high likelihood that agreements on these issues will be signed.
"The details for these agreements have all been settled in previous cross-strait negotiations and the visit by Chen is to sign these agreements," Chiang said.
Chiang noted that as part of plans to improve future cross-strait ties, the two sides will also sign a memorandum of understanding, or MOU, regarding financial and banking issues.

Chiang expressed hopes that the upcoming meeting between him and Chen in Taipei will be able to lay the ground works for financial opening. If so, Taiwan's banks will be able to set up subsidiaries in mainland China and vice-versa.
"Attracting mainland China investment, in addition to tourists, will be important issues in future cross-strait cooperation, " noted Chiang.
Given the current global credit crisis, Chiang said the two sides should also discuss ways to cope with the negative effects of the crisis.

The addition of financial issues in the upcoming cross-strait meetings is requested by Chen, with the aim of initiating cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China to counter the global credit crisis.
"European countries are uniting to counter the snowballing woes. Both sides of the strait should work together as one on this particular issue," said Chiang.
The modes for future cross-strait dialogues will also be set out by these meetings between the heads of SEF and ARATS, Chiang indicated.
"In addition, Taiwan and mainland China, by engaging in cross-strait dialogue, serves to improve regional stability", according to Chiang.
He also stressed that there are no under-the-table dealings whatsoever by SEF and ARATS, addressing a concern raised by the opposition DPP.
SEF is a quasi-official body responsible for handling cross-strait affairs. Its counterpart in mainland China is ARATS.
Since Ma Ying-jeou took office as president, Chiang and Chen have already met once in Beijing in June 2008. Chen's visit to Taiwan will be the first ever trip for a president of ARATS to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Councilor under prosecutor's probe for harassing Chinese official

TEXT.P: The case involving seven Tainan City residents charged with allegedly mobbing a visiting Chinese official was handed over to prosecutors Wednesday for further investigation, according to a spokesman for the city police department.

Wang Ting-yu, a Tainan City councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was among the seven suspects, the spokesman said. Two of them failed to report to the police for an initial investigation.

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, was besieged and jostled to the ground by a group of anti-China protesters on a private tour to the city's Confucius Temple on Oct. 21.
One protester even jumped onto the hood of Zhang's car and stamped on it with his feet as Zhang was being escorted away from the site by a local official and a tour guide.
Wang, who allegedly mobilized the protesters to the scene, was charged with hindering personal freedom, assault and eroding public order.
Tainan City police authorities are still trying to identify two other suspects who were seen pushing and attacking Zhang in a video footage held by police as evidence, the spokesman said.
Zhang filed a formal complaint with police against those who harassed him following the incident. He cut short his visit and returned to Beijing the next day.

At the head of a 22-member delegation, Zhang arrived in Taiwan Oct. 19 for a four-day visit. He took part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts on Oct. 20 in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the School of Journalism at Xiamen University in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: China working to expand citizens' eligibility to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 29 (CNA) 10/29/08 21:15:15 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office said Wednesday that the relevant agencies are currently working on the issue of expanding the range of Chinese citizens eligible to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing visits.

Speaking at a regular press briefing, spokesman Yang Yi said that the agencies are considering an expansion of the number of Chinese provinces whose citizens are eligible to travel to Taiwan and also an increase in the number of travel agencies authorized to arrange tour groups to Taiwan.

Yang pointed out that Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office, had already announced in Xiamen in early September that the number of provinces and travel agencies would be significantly increased in the future.
As to the scope of the expansion of eligibility for Taiwan travel, China's National Tourism Office will make announcement after a decision has been reached, Yang said.

According to recent media reports, the relevant agencies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have reached a consensus on increasing the number of provinces whose citizens are eligible to travel to Taiwan from the current 13 to 19, and the number of authorized travel agencies from 33 to 60.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't has no plans to trim foreign labor force: minister

TEXT.P: The government has no plans at this time to cut back on the number of foreign workers in Taiwan's labor-intensive sectors to help create job opportunities for local people, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Wednesday.

Yiin admitted that the Council of Labor Affairs had recently discussed, on unofficial occasions, the idea of slashing the number of foreign workers in Taiwan, but he said Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has ruled out that possibility at a time when local businesses are experiencing difficulties amid sagging economic conditions across the globe.

Foreign laborers are usually placed in dangerous, labor-intensive or night-shift jobs that Taiwanese workers are not willing to do, and represent a significant work force in Taiwan companies, he said.
Against such a background, Yiin said, his ministry is opposed to the idea of replacing foreign workers with Taiwanese workers to help Taiwan's industry better cope with rising operating costs.
There are more than 300,000 foreign workers in Taiwan, most of whom are from Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges France's support for Taiwan's participation in U.N.

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed the hope Wednesday that France will help Taiwan participate in United Nations specialized agencies, when France takes over the rotating chairmanship of the European Union (EU) in the second half of this year.
Liu made the remarks in a meeting with Patrick Bonneville, the new director- general of the French Institute in Taipei.

Responding to Liu's appeal, Bonneville noted that in September the EU expressed its support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in U.N. specialized agencies, and he emphasized that France and the EU support the peaceful progress of cross- Taiwan Strait relations and regional stability.
On the topic of the economy, Bonneville said some French businesspeople view Taiwan as a springboard for investment in China and Hong Kong.
Liu responded that French investors are smart and that the Taiwan government will like to be their partner in business and to contribute to strengthening the Asian economy.
He said he hoped that Taiwan and France will share information on the world's financial crisis so as to better cope with the global problem.

Liu told Bonneville that Taiwan's economic development remains promising and that the government has introduced a series of stimulus measures such as fully insuring deposits in local banks, asking banks to support local firms, and bringing on stream a series of public construction projects.
Taiwan and France have maintained good relations, the premier noted, adding that he is confident Bonneville's rich experience and knowledge of Asian affairs will help to enhance the ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Immigration agency to sponsor seminar on human trafficking

TEXT.P: An international seminar on the prevention of human trafficking will open in Taipei Thursday for brainstorming on enhancing the efficiency of anti-human trafficking operations, a senior official said Wednesday.

A U.S. prosecutor in charge of human trafficking cases, James Felte, has been invited to give tips on the investigation and prevention of trafficking in persons, particularly women and children, said Chien Tai-lang, deputy minister of the interior.

Non-government organizations representatives, including Panadda Changmanee of Vietnam's Oxfam Quebec International and Navauth Ya of CARAM Cambodia, will also deliver keynote speeches at the seminar to share experiences in the prevention of and crackdown on human trafficking, Chien said.

Since the United Nations issued the Protocol on the Prevention, Prohibition and Punishment of Trafficking in Persons in 2003, all U.N. member countries are required to take effective steps to prevent human trafficking and penalize offenders, as well as to protect victims of relevant crimes.

As a member of the global village, Taiwan has mounted concerted efforts to prevent and clamp down on human trafficking in recent years, even though it is not a U.N. member, said Chien who concurrently serves as acting director-general of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior.

With its prosperous economy, Chien said, Taiwan has become a major importing country of migrant workers and female marriage immigrants from Southeast Asia in recent years. Against this backdrop, Taiwan has also become a major destination or transit stop in human trafficking operations, he added.

To grapple with this situation, Chien said, the NIA has placed emphasis on the protection of those who have fallen victim to human trafficking crimes. Among other initiatives, he said, a three-year program has been launched this year to set up 11 shelters for human trafficking victims and will offer them psychological counseling, legal aid and medical care during their stay at the shelters, as well as provide them with financial aid for repatriation.

Noting that the immigration law incorporates a special chapter on human trafficking prevention, Chien said the government will further legislate a special act to strictly regulate prevention and investigation of and crackdown on human trafficking.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS Memorial Hall top sightseeing spot in Taipei city

TEXT.P: The National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei attracted the most visitors from at home and abroad in the period Jan.-Aug. this year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Taipei City government.
The hall, which was built in memory of the late President Chiang Kai-shek after his death in 1975, was visited by an average of 16,000 people a day during the eight-month period, the figures showed.

The second most popular site was the National Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall, which commemorates the founding father of the Republic of China, with an average of 13,000 visitors a day, while the Taipei Zoo, with 9,000 daily visitors, was in third place.

However, the biggest attraction for foreign tourists was the night markets, which drew 63 out of every 100 foreign visitors to Taiwan in the Jan-Aug period. The National Palace Museum, which attracted 45 out of every 100 foreign tourists to see its exquisite cultural treasures, was in second place among such visitors.
The third biggest attraction for visitors from overseas was the skyscraper Taipei 101, with 39 out of every 100 foreign visitors going to see the landmark building.
Among the privately run sightseeing spots, the Taipei 101 observation deck was the most popular, drawing around 3,000 visitors per day.
As for historic sites and buildings, Lungshan Temple in Taipei's Wanhua District was number one, attracting an average of 5,000 visitors daily during the eight- month period.
Meanwhile, the figures showed that Taipei city had the highest number of tourism hotels in Taiwan, totaling 33 as of the end of August.
The occupancy rate of the city's international hotels was 71.09 percent, second only to Kenting hotels in Pingtung county.
Other hotels in Taipei recorded an occupancy rate of 72.59 percent during the eight-month period, with Hsinchu the only area that surpassed that rate.
The room rates for international tourist hotels in Taipei averaged NT$4,075 (US$122) per day, the third highest price in Taiwan after the Lalu in Nantou and the Hotel Royal Chiao Hsi in Yilan.
The average room rate for other hotels in Taipei was NT$2,032 per day, about 10 percent less than the average room rate for tourist hotels countrywide, which was recorded at NT$2,252.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan scientist invents world's first chlorophyll organic battery

TEXT.P: A scientist in Taiwan has invented the world's first chlorophyll organic battery that can supply electricity within 10 seconds of being wetted with water, beverages or even urine.

Chungpin Hovering Liao, a professor at the Graduate School of Electro-Optic and Material Science of National Formosa University in central Taiwan's Yunlin County, told a news conference Wednesday that the battery, when wetted, can provide electricity for two days to a week.
While the strength of the battery is about half that of an ordinary battery, its storage capacity is more than that of Japan's water-powered fuel cells, he said.

The production cost of the chlorophyll organic battery is very cheap -- about NT$1 to NT$2 (US$.03 to US$.06) , Liao said, adding that the battery contains no toxic substances and will not pose an environmental hazard, even if discarded at will.
The professor disclosed that he is in the process of applying for patent in Taiwan, the United States and other countries for the new invention and expects to see mass production in the near future.

Liao, 49, received a B.S. degree in nuclear engineering from National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu, Taiwan, in 1982. He earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in plasma science and fusion technology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of the United States in 1989 and 1992, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official optimistic about tourist arrivals to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese tourism official said Wednesday that he believes larger numbers of Chinese tourists will visit Taiwan when the conditions are right.

Zhang Xiqin, China's National Tourism Administration deputy director who also serves as head of the non-official Cross-Strait Tourism Association, said many more Chinese sightseers would visit Taiwan once the current problems, such as insufficient airplane seats and too few flight destinations between the two sides, have been resolved.

Zhang made the comments on arrival at Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan at the head of a delegation of more than 290 members who will attend the 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair from Oct. 31-Nov. 3.

He also brushed aside concerns on Taiwan's part that a recent violent incident involving a visiting Chinese scholar might deter Chinese tourists from coming to the island, saying that it has only been three months since Taiwan opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists, and that it will take time for things to improve.
Zhang, who is on his fifth visit to Taiwan, said that each time he is touched by the Taiwan people's hospitality.
He said his delegation's participation in the Taiwan travel fair is particularly important this year because of the developments in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

"It is important to take part in this year's Taipei International Travel Fair -- the first since Taiwan's wider opening in July to tourists from China -- because it marks a genuine start to enhanced two-way tourism exchanges," he said.

Apart from allowing people in Taiwan to gain a better understanding of China's tourism, Zhang said, the main goal this time around is to give Chinese tourism operators a chance to acquire more in-depth knowledge of Taiwan and help bring more Chinese tourists to the island.

Zhang's trip to Taiwan comes a few days ahead of a visit by China's top cross- strait liaison officer, Chen Yunlin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, who is slated to arrive Nov. 3 for a five-day visit.

Chen will hold talks with Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on travel and tourism exchanges between Taiwan and China as well as food security cooperation, in a follow-up to their landmark meeting in Beijing in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paphiopedilum orchid show opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Paphiopedilum orchids -- better known as Lady's Slipper Orchids -- opened Wednesday at the Taipei Botanical Garden and will run until Nov. 23.

The exhibition, jointly sponsored by the National Museum of Natural Sciences and the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, is putting more than 190 pots of Lady's Slipper Orchids on display, including many that have won awards in various competitions.

According to Kao Chi-ching, general-secretary of the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, the orchids on display include the original species, the single-flower type, the multiflora type and the standard type.
The lady slipper orchids are also known in the United States as moccasin flowers, because of their resemblance to a shoe or moccasin.

The orchids are in the subfamily Cypripedioidea. They are so named because of the flowers' slipper-shaped pouches. The pouch can trap insects in order to force them to climb up past the staminode, behind which they collect or deposit pollinia.

Lady's Slipper orchids originated in the tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia, including southern China, but over-collecting has caused the flowers to become rare and endangered in their original habitats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Choice of ex-VP for APEC summit marks progress in cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Lien Chan's attendance at this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Peru next month will symbolize significant progress in relations across the Taiwan Strait, a diplomatic official said Wednesday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Henry Chen made the remarks after the Presidential Office announced earlier in the day that Lien Chan has been chosen to attend the 2008 APEC summit on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Lien would be the highest-ranking former official of the Republic of China ever to attend an APEC informal leadership meeting.
Because of Beijing's opposition, ROC presidents have been barred from the annual APEC summit and have been forced instead to name a proxy to attend.

Noting that APEC is one of the most important multilateral international organizations that Taiwan managed to join as a full member, Chen said Lien's attendance at the forum's annual summit will mark a positive development in cross-strait relations.

With a Ph.D. in political science from the University of Chicago, Lien has rich experience in international affairs. He held many important government posts, including minister of foreign affairs, Taiwan governor and premier, before serving as vice president from 1996 through 2000.
Given his political stature, Lien is widely seen as the most appropriate person to represent Ma at the annual APEC summit, which will take place in the Peruvian capital of Lima Nov.22-23, Chen added.
In 2005, Lien made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing in his capacity as chairman of then-opposition Kuomintang, becoming the first opposition leader from Taiwan to ever visit China.

During that visit, he met with Chinese President Hu Jintao for wide-ranging talks and laid the groundwork for the establishment of a dialogue platform for the KMT and its former civil war enemy -- the Communist Party of China.

In a statement issued after learning of Ma's decision to name him as his proxy for the upcoming APEC summit, Lien said he will be honored to serve as the president's surrogate at such an important international conference.

At a time when the world is facing a credit crunch and economic turmoil, Lien said, he will share his views and experiences with top leaders from APEC member economies to tackle challenges and promote mutual cooperation.
"I'll do whatever I can to fulfill my duty," he added in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sovereignty-related pact should be put to referendum: DPP

TEXT.P: All agreements signed between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies across the Taiwan Strait should be approved by the Legislative Yuan and any bilateral dealings involving national sovereignty should be put to referendum, the country's main opposition party said Wednesday.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made the pitch in a five-point statement issued just a few days before Nov. 3 when China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart in his capacity as president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

In its statement, the DPP also demanded that the arrangement for Chen's meeting with Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung should follow the protocol and practices usually observed in state-to-state conferences or engagements, in order to uphold Taiwan's sovereign status and dignity.

Since the upcoming Chiang-Chen talks will take place within the framework of the institutionalized SEF-ARATS engagement mechanism, the statement said, Chen would be the People's Republic of China's representative who should not engage in any political activities other than talks with SEF officials during his stay and his itinerary should be kept open and subject to popular and media supervision.
Moreover, the statement urged President Ma Ying-jeou to reiterate that Taiwan's future is up to the decision of its 23 million people.

The statement also demanded that Ma ask Chen during their meeting in Taipei to push the Chinese government to apologize to the people of Taiwan for its military threat and diplomatic suppression against Taiwan over the past decades and to promise to dismantle its missiles targeting at Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday, moving up 41.99 points at 4,448.51 on a turnover of NT$3 billion (US$90.1 million).
The weighted price index gained 6.55 points, or 0.15 percent, to close at 4,406.52 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.041 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.254 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 30, or the second day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."
