DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's key interest rates lowered further by 0.25 basis points

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China further lowered Taiwan's key interest rates by 0.25 basis points Thursday in an emergency measure to boost the country's economy that has shown signals of a recession.

The latest reduction -- the second of its kind this month -- marked the discount rate down further to 3 percent, the rate on accommodations with collateral to 3.375 percent and the rate on accommodations without collateral to 5.25 percent.

The Central Bank said in a statement that while inflationary pressure has eased following the fall in global oil and commodity prices, the risk of an economic downturn is escalating due to sluggish business activities.
The situation is reflected in Taiwan's unsatisfactory performance in terms of exports, industrial production, consumption and employment over the past few months, the Central Bank said.

According to a report released Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Taiwan's leading economic indicators flashed a blue light for September, a sign that the economy is heading toward recession, after signaling a slowdown a month earlier with a yellow-blue light.
It was the second blue light to appear this year after the first one in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan scientist invents world's first chlorophyll organic battery

TEXT.P: A scientist in Taiwan has invented the world's first chlorophyll organic battery that can supply electricity within 10 seconds of being wetted with water, beverages or even urine.

Chungpin Hovering Liao, a professor at the Graduate School of Electro-Optic and Material Science of National Formosa University in central Taiwan's Yunlin County, told a news conference Wednesday that the battery, when wetted, can provide electricity for two days to a week.
While the strength of the battery is about half that of an ordinary battery, its storage capacity is more than that of Japan's water-powered fuel cells, he said.

The production cost of the chlorophyll organic battery is very cheap -- about NT$1 to NT$2 (US$.03 to US$.06) , Liao said, adding that the battery contains no toxic substances and will not pose an environmental hazard, even if discarded at will.
The professor disclosed that he is in the process of applying for patent in Taiwan, the United States and other countries for the new invention and expects to see mass production in the near future.

Liao, 49, received a B.S. degree in nuclear engineering from National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu, Taiwan, in 1982. He earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in plasma science and fusion technology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of the United States in 1989 and 1992, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official optimistic about tourist arrivals to Taiwan

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese tourism official said Wednesday that he believes larger numbers of Chinese tourists will visit Taiwan when the conditions are right.

Zhang Xiqin, China's National Tourism Administration deputy director who also serves as head of the non-official Cross-Strait Tourism Association, said many more Chinese sightseers would visit Taiwan once the current problems, such as insufficient airplane seats and too few flight destinations between the two sides, have been resolved.

Zhang made the comments on arrival at Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan at the head of a delegation of more than 290 members who will attend the 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair from Oct. 31-Nov. 3.

He also brushed aside concerns on Taiwan's part that a recent violent incident involving a visiting Chinese scholar might deter Chinese tourists from coming to the island, saying that it has only been three months since Taiwan opened its doors wider to Chinese tourists, and that it will take time for things to improve.
Zhang, who is on his fifth visit to Taiwan, said that each time he is touched by the Taiwan people's hospitality.
He said his delegation's participation in the Taiwan travel fair is particularly important this year because of the developments in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

"It is important to take part in this year's Taipei International Travel Fair -- the first since Taiwan's wider opening in July to tourists from China -- because it marks a genuine start to enhanced two-way tourism exchanges," he said.

Apart from allowing people in Taiwan to gain a better understanding of China's tourism, Zhang said, the main goal this time around is to give Chinese tourism operators a chance to acquire more in-depth knowledge of Taiwan and help bring more Chinese tourists to the island.

Zhang's trip to Taiwan comes a few days ahead of a visit by China's top cross- strait liaison officer, Chen Yunlin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, who is slated to arrive Nov. 3 for a five-day visit.

Chen will hold talks with Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on travel and tourism exchanges between Taiwan and China as well as food security cooperation, in a follow-up to their landmark meeting in Beijing in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paphiopedilum orchid show opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: An exhibition of Paphiopedilum orchids -- better known as Lady's Slipper Orchids -- opened Wednesday at the Taipei Botanical Garden and will run until Nov. 23.

The exhibition, jointly sponsored by the National Museum of Natural Sciences and the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, is putting more than 190 pots of Lady's Slipper Orchids on display, including many that have won awards in various competitions.

According to Kao Chi-ching, general-secretary of the Taiwan Paphiopedilum Society, the orchids on display include the original species, the single-flower type, the multiflora type and the standard type.
The lady slipper orchids are also known in the United States as moccasin flowers, because of their resemblance to a shoe or moccasin.

The orchids are in the subfamily Cypripedioidea. They are so named because of the flowers' slipper-shaped pouches. The pouch can trap insects in order to force them to climb up past the staminode, behind which they collect or deposit pollinia.

Lady's Slipper orchids originated in the tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia, including southern China, but over-collecting has caused the flowers to become rare and endangered in their original habitats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Choice of ex-VP for APEC summit marks progress in cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Lien Chan's attendance at this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Peru next month will symbolize significant progress in relations across the Taiwan Strait, a diplomatic official said Wednesday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Henry Chen made the remarks after the Presidential Office announced earlier in the day that Lien Chan has been chosen to attend the 2008 APEC summit on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Lien would be the highest-ranking former official of the Republic of China ever to attend an APEC informal leadership meeting.
Because of Beijing's opposition, ROC presidents have been barred from the annual APEC summit and have been forced instead to name a proxy to attend.

Noting that APEC is one of the most important multilateral international organizations that Taiwan managed to join as a full member, Chen said Lien's attendance at the forum's annual summit will mark a positive development in cross-strait relations.

With a Ph.D. in political science from the University of Chicago, Lien has rich experience in international affairs. He held many important government posts, including minister of foreign affairs, Taiwan governor and premier, before serving as vice president from 1996 through 2000.
Given his political stature, Lien is widely seen as the most appropriate person to represent Ma at the annual APEC summit, which will take place in the Peruvian capital of Lima Nov.22-23, Chen added.
In 2005, Lien made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing in his capacity as chairman of then-opposition Kuomintang, becoming the first opposition leader from Taiwan to ever visit China.

During that visit, he met with Chinese President Hu Jintao for wide-ranging talks and laid the groundwork for the establishment of a dialogue platform for the KMT and its former civil war enemy -- the Communist Party of China.

In a statement issued after learning of Ma's decision to name him as his proxy for the upcoming APEC summit, Lien said he will be honored to serve as the president's surrogate at such an important international conference.

At a time when the world is facing a credit crunch and economic turmoil, Lien said, he will share his views and experiences with top leaders from APEC member economies to tackle challenges and promote mutual cooperation.
"I'll do whatever I can to fulfill my duty," he added in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sovereignty-related pact should be put to referendum: DPP

TEXT.P: All agreements signed between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies across the Taiwan Strait should be approved by the Legislative Yuan and any bilateral dealings involving national sovereignty should be put to referendum, the country's main opposition party said Wednesday.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made the pitch in a five-point statement issued just a few days before Nov. 3 when China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart in his capacity as president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

In its statement, the DPP also demanded that the arrangement for Chen's meeting with Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung should follow the protocol and practices usually observed in state-to-state conferences or engagements, in order to uphold Taiwan's sovereign status and dignity.

Since the upcoming Chiang-Chen talks will take place within the framework of the institutionalized SEF-ARATS engagement mechanism, the statement said, Chen would be the People's Republic of China's representative who should not engage in any political activities other than talks with SEF officials during his stay and his itinerary should be kept open and subject to popular and media supervision.
Moreover, the statement urged President Ma Ying-jeou to reiterate that Taiwan's future is up to the decision of its 23 million people.

The statement also demanded that Ma ask Chen during their meeting in Taipei to push the Chinese government to apologize to the people of Taiwan for its military threat and diplomatic suppression against Taiwan over the past decades and to promise to dismantle its missiles targeting at Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan eyes financial cooperation agreement with China

TEXT.P: Financial officials from Taiwan and China will meet for the first time in Taipei next week to discuss various cross-Taiwan Strait financial issues, including the signing of a memorandum of understanding for cooperation on financial regulation and supervision, officials said Thursday.

After the discussion, officials from the two sides are expected to meet again in China by the end of the year to speed up the signing of the agreement, said the officials from the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).

The upcoming meeting will also touch on the possible relaxation of investment restrictions on Chinese qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) in Taiwan and the issue of allowing financial institutions on both sides to set up branches in each other's territories, the FSC officials said.

According to Fu Don-cheng, a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, participants in the meeting will include the heads of several Chinese financial institutions and Chinese officials in charge of the regulation and supervision of banking, insurance and securities operations.

The Cabinet decided in July to allow QDII from China to invest in Taiwan's stock market. However, without an MOU with China, the policy would only be able to attract a maximum 3 percent of Chinese QDII, which would represent a combined investment of NT$33.8 billion.
Also, the government hopes that the offices opened by seven Taiwanese banks in China could be upgraded to bank branches.

The financial talks will take place on the sidelines of negotiations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , the two quasi- official intermediary bodies representing the respective governments in dealing with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

The highlight of the upcoming negotiations, to be headed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin, will be the possible signing of agreements on cross-strait air services, shipping links, mail services and food safety.

Fu noted that the planned agreement on air services will cover the opening of more direct cross-strait air routes, extension of the weekend charter flight services to every day of the week, and the launch of cargo charter flight services.

As far as the air route issue is concerned, the two sides are expected to finalize a new route that would allow the cross-strait charter flights to skip a detour through Hong Kong's or Macau's air space, as they are currently required to do, Fu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese liaison official to meet president after signing pacts: MAC

TEXT.P: China's top cross-strait liaison officer Chen Yunlin will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou after Chen concludes his meeting and signs several agreements with his counterpart in Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , according to the head of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Thursday.

MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan made the disclosure in a briefing at the Legislative Yuan on the upcoming second meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Chen, President of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
"The main purpose of Chen's historic five-day visit to Taiwan is to sign agreements between the SEF and ARATS," Lai said..
As far as the current plan goes, in the first two days, Chen will focus largely on the meetings and negotiations with the SEF, Lai stressed.
However, "when the signing of the agreements is completed, arrangements will be made for Chen to meet President Ma and to visit tourist sites," according to Lai.
The first meeting between Chiang and Chen was in June last year when they signed landmark agreements on direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights and expanded tourism links between the two sides.
When Chen arrives on Nov. 3, he will become the highest level Chinese official ever to visit Taiwan.
The second Chiang-Chen meeting is aimed at negotiating and signing agreements between Taiwan and China on expanded direct charter flights, shipping and postal links and food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices rise sharply on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 277.12 points, or 6.28 percent, to close at 4,683.64.

Finishing higher for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 4448.51 and rose as high as 4,684.11. A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$67.7 billion (US$2.06 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 6.9 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 6.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and construction issues both increased 6.6 percent, textile stocks were up 6.5 percent, cement stocks grew 6.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 6.1 percent, and foodstuff issues gained 4.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,348 to 194, with 278 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$735 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent for November, December, March, June and September.

TAIEX Index futures for November gained 300 points to finish at 4,594, with 71,639 contracts traded, while December futures increased 296 points to close at 4,531, with 1,981 contracts changing hands.
March futures advanced 293 points to close at 4,479, with 24 contract transactions, while June futures increased 289 points to finish at 4,421, with five contract transactions.
September futures gained 282 points to close at 4,311, with 22 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,294 for November, 4,235 for December, 4,186 for March, 4,132 for June, and 4,029 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 277.12 points to finish at 4,683.64, on turnover of NT$67.7 billion (US$2.06 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were both higher, with TE and TF futures for November and December both surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent.
November TE futures rose 12.15 points to close at 186.25, with 2,081 contracts traded, while December TE futures increased 12.05 points to finish at 184.3, with 196 contract transactions.
September TE futures advanced 11.85 points to finish at 182.95, with eight contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

November TF futures gained 32 points to finish at 491, with 1,833 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures increased 31.8 points to finish at 486.2, with 120 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reaffirms commitment to upholding national sovereignty

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Thursday his commitment to upholding national sovereignty, in the latest effort to clarify an allegation by the opposition that his administration is tilting excessively toward Beijing.
Ma said that as president of the Republic of China, he has always attached top priority to "the country's sovereignty, Taiwan's dignity and the people's security."
The president made the remarks while receiving a group of Taiwanese veteran representatives, days before a planned visit to Taiwan by mainland China's top cross-strait negotiator.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will be in Taipei Nov. 3-7 to hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung. They are likely to sign agreements on cross-strait air services, shipping links, mail services and food safety.

Concerned that the negotiations could lead to a compromise of Taiwan's sovereignty, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is strongly against the meeting and will hold a series of protests during Chen's visit to demonstrate its position.

Also Thursday, Ma stressed during a separate meeting with John Chad Hapner, national commander of the U.S. veterans service organization American Veterans, that Taipei will definitely "stand firm on its position" when negotiating with Beijing.
Ma stated that over the past few months since his inauguration, he has been working to restore mutual trust with the United States and improve relations with China.
His administration is also trying to promote cross-strait peace and normalize cross-strait economic ties so as to sustain Taiwan's development, he added.
The president said Taiwan is grateful to Washington for its recent decision to sell Taiwan a series of weapons systems and will continue its security cooperation with the U.S. government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors seeking jail term for councilor on assault charges

TEXT.P: Prosecutors are seeking a 14-month jail sentence for Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu who has been indicted on charges of public intimidation and assault of a visiting Chinese official, the Tainan Prosecutors Office said Thursday in a statement.
Seven suspects, including Wang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), were indicted in the case.
Wang allegedly mobilized the protesters who later mobbed the Chinese official, and was charged by prosecutors with hindering personal freedom, assault and eroding public order.

The Tainan Prosecutors Office made the announcement after it concluded the investigation earlier the same day. The case was transferred to the prosecutors office the day before by the Tainan city police.

Zhang Mingqing, vice president of China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), fell as he was being besieged and jostled by a group of anti-China protesters while he was on a private tour of Tainan City's Confucius Temple on Oct. 21.

Prosecutors are also seeking an eight-month jail term for a protester, identified by the surname Lin, who jumped onto the hood of Zhang's car and stamped on it as Zhang was being escorted away from the site, said a spokesman for the Tainan Prosecutors Office.
Zhang pressed a formal complaint with Tainan city police against those who harassed him later that day. He cut short his visit and returned to Beijing the next day.

Zhang headed a 22-member delegation to Taiwan Oct. 19 for a four-day visit, during which he took part in an academic seminar at Tainan National University of the Arts in Tainan County, in his capacity as dean of the School of Journalism at Xiamen University.
Meanwhile, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, China's top liaison with Taiwan, will arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3 for a five-day visit.
Police nationwide have been asked to tighten security to provide full protection for Chen and prevent any similar incidents from occurring during his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: No Taiwanese casualties in Pakistan earthquake: MOFA

TEXT.P: So far no Taiwanese people have been reported injured or killed in the magnitude 6.4 earthquake that devastated Pakistan this week, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

The 6.4-magnitude earthquake that hit Pakistans Baluchistan, 400 miles southwest of Islamabad, before dawn on Wednesday, has killed at least 200 people, injured hundreds and made at least 20,000 homeless.

"As of now, there are no Taiwanese citizens injured or killed in this earthquake that took place in Pakistan, said Ali Yang, deputy director-general of the MOFAs Department of West Asian Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
"We would like to express our consolation and condolences to the victims,Yang added.

He said the foreign ministry is still gathering information and evaluating the situation to see if any assistance from Taiwan is necessary. Yang said the ministry will not rule out the possibility of working with civil organizations in disaster relieve efforts.

Pakistan's government and the World Health Organization are sending resources and supplies to the areas devastated by the earthquake. Officials believe that the total number of deaths may still rise, as many remained trapped under rubble.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to meet with China's top negotiator on panda issue

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday he will meet with China's top negotiator on Taiwan to discuss the issue of pandas during the latter's upcoming visit to the island next week.

Speaking at a Taipei City Council meeting on food safety management and investment in businesses, Hau said he will meet with Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, for a brief discussion during Chen's visit from Nov. 3-7.
"We'll meet mainly for talks on the two giant pandas that China has promised as gifts to Taiwan -- known as 'Tuan Tuan' and 'Yuan Yuan,'" Hau noted.

Taipei city and several other cities in Taiwan have competed to host the two giant pandas, which China wants to loan to Taiwan. Hau and Taipei city government officials even paid a visit to Shanghai in June to forge a pact on exchanges related to rare animal conservation, including swapping animals as gifts and sharing know-how in animal raising and reproduction.
Chen has said that he will not bring pandas with him in his upcoming visit to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Lien Sheng-wen, a member of the ruling Kuomintang's policy-making Central Standing Committee, who doubles as chairman of the Taipei EasyCard Corp., said at the Taipei City Council meeting that he has no idea whether Chen will take time during his visit in Taipei to ride Taipei's subway system, the MRT.
"As far as I know, the usage of EasyCard or similar electronic ticketing systems are much wider in China than in Taiwan," Lien said.
Meanwhile, Hau said that it's not against the law for people who plan to demonstrate during Chen's visit to wear whatever they like, including clothes made of the national flag.
"However, the demonstrators will be dealt with in accordance with the law if their behavior violates the Assembly and Parade Law, " Hau said.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which believes Chen's visit to Taiwan and talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , will lead to the erosion of Taiwan's sovereignty, plans to hold various demonstrations during Chen's visit, including a sit-in outside the Grand Hotel, where Chen is expected to stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bakeries sue importer of toxic milk powder

TEXT.P: Several bakeries filed a lawsuit Wednesday against New Tai Milk Products Co., seeking compensation for the financial losses they suffered as a result of the company's import and sale of melamine-contaminated milk powder from China.

Representatives of the bakeries, accompanied by Taiwan Solidarity Union Secretary-General Lin Jhi-jia, filed a civil lawsuit with the Taipei District Court in the first legal action ever brought by local bakeries against the importer of dairy products.

One of the bakery representatives, Ho Kuan-ching, said that since the melamine scandal surfaced more than a month ago, there has been no goodwill action from the Taoyuan County-based New Tai -- the Taiwan subsidiary of the New Zealand dairy giant Fonterra.
New Tai is known to have imported 25 tons of the melamine-tainted milk powder from China's Sanlu Group, one of that country's largest manufacturers of dairy products.
New Tai has made no move to compensate local bakeries for their losses, except to say that the Sanlu Group should be held accountable for the melamine incident, according to Ho.

Ho said that it was beyond her understanding why New Tai had not sought compensation from Sanlu. The lawsuit by the bakeries was filed with the purpose of pressing the Taiwanese importer to seek compensation from the Chinese manufacturer, she added.

She said the bakeries are seeking compensation for financial losses incurred over a period of more than one month. However, New Tai offered to pay only NT$50,000 in compensation to each of the bakeries, an amount that Ho said is unacceptable because it does not even cover operating costs for a single day.
The maximum financial losses suffered by each bakery over the period probably exceeds NT$500,000, Ho estimated, adding that numerous bakeries have fallen victim to the scandal.

She also said that although the government plans to provide subsidies to bakeries with a business turnover of less than NT$5 million, those that qualify for the subsidy have yet to be informed of their eligibility and those with a turnover of more than NT$5 million have complained that their right to compensation was ignored.

According to Lin, the lawsuit was a last resort, as the bakeries had no other options. He also urged the government to formulate and adopt compensation or indemnity measures in order to help the affected bakeries tide over their financial woes.

The government, as the gatekeeper of food imports, was partly to blame for the toxic milk scandal, and should grant national compensation to businesses that suffered losses as result of the incident, he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.496 to close at NT$32.799.
A total of US$3.329 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.145 and fluctuated between NT$32.713 and NT$33.335.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan horseshoe crab population decreasing: survey

TEXT.P: The population of horseshoe crabs in Kinmen -- Taiwan's only remaining habitat for both baby and adult horseshoe crabs -- has been on the decline since 2003, indicating that human activities have been gradually threatening the existence of the species, biologists reported Thursday.
The other habitat -- on the outlying Penghu islands -- will host only adult horseshoe crabs, according to the marine biologists who have surveyed the species for years.
They urged the government to take swift action to conserve the ancient species, as its habitats in Taiwan have all been destroyed due to over-exploitation years ago.
The species is found in Taiwan on the outlying islands of Kinmen, which lies closer to China's southeast coast than to Taiwan proper, and on the Penghu archipelago in the Taiwan Strait.

The horseshoe crab is sometimes nicknamed the "living fossil" because the species has existed on Earth for some 400 million years and has remained in its present form for 200 million years. Although it called a crab, the arthropod is more closely related to its land-based counterparts, such as spiders and scorpions.

Even though the species is not listed as endangered, its numbers in North America, Europe, Japan, and Taiwan have been significantly reduced in recent years. Part of the reason is that medical researchers have found valuable substances in the blood of horseshoe crabs, which can be used to develop new drugs.

Chen Chang-po, a research fellow of Academia Sinica's Biodiversity Center, said that following the destruction of the habitats in the main Taiwan area, he and other biologists helped to organize surveys to monitor the remaining horseshoe crab habitats in Penghu and Kinmen.

In the surveys, they found that baby horseshoe crabs will only appear at the intertidal zones along the coastline of the Kinmen islets, while adult horseshoe crabs will frequent both Penghu and Kinmen.
The facts suggested that, were the Kinmen habitats to be threatened, the entire population of horseshoe crabs would be in great danger because of the loss of an important breeding ground, said Chen.

Based on surveys conducted between 2003 to 2007, the population of baby horseshoe crabs in Kinmen has decreased, Chen said, adding that this indicated the need for government intervention to better preserve the species.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT holds mock U.S. presidential debate to enhance understanding

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Thursday held a mock debate featuring local university students on the upcoming U.S. presidential election, to encourage Taiwanese people to have a better understanding of the issues and process of the election.
This debate is being held to encourage a better understanding of the U.S. and the issues, Scott Robinson, director of the AITs American Culture Center, said at the event.
This is really intended as an educational exercise to stimulate debates about U.S. issues rather than advocate for or against a particular candidate,Robinson added.

In addition to students from National Chengchi University (NCCU) debating as Team Obama and National Tsinghua University (NTHU) as Team McCain, participants included panelists at the debate Stacey Tsai, AIT Public Affairs Officer; Ming Lee, professor of the NCCUs Department of Diplomacy; and Yen Chen-shen, professor of the NTHU s Department of General Studies.

The debaters challenged each other on various of issues, such as the economy, foreign policy and U.S. domestic policy in the 90-minute competition. The audience was then asked to cast a virtual ballot for the team with the better performance.
Despite that the performance between the two teams was neck-to-neck, Team Obama won by a small margin of votes and left the event with a NT$ 10,000 (US$ 305) check.

Commenting on their performance, Robinson lauded the students knowledge about U.S. elections and said that he was really impressed by their performance in the debate, especially in the wildcard question part where each team confronted each other back and forth.
I think they were well-prepared. Considering none of them is a native speaker, but they talked about tough policies. I think its pretty amazing,he said.
Chang Su-hau, who is in his fifth year at the NCCUs Department of Diplomacy, said he enjoyed the process from the beginning to the end because he likes challenges and enjoys speaking to the public.

What I learned from the debate is that it takes a lot of effort and confidence to speak in public about your ideas, Chang said, adding thatit is not easy to be a politician and try to persuade somebody who doesnt believe that much in you.

The aspiring diplomat from the winning team who speaks native-speaker-like English said that although he has never lived in a foreign country for more than a year, he tried to talk to the audience in a charismatic way and with fluency.
Yvonne Tyan, a senior from NTHUs Department of General Studies, said that even though her team lost the debate, they did their best and it was a great learning experience.
I think its fun. We can learn a lot from their attitude and experience. Its an awesome experience,she said.

Computer-science major Stanley Ho, a sophomore from the NTHU representing John McCain, said that he thinks McCain, if elected as the next U.S. president, will be more supportive of Taiwan against China. However, Ho said that he is a supporter of Barack Obama because the world needs a new face and change.
The AIT functions as a de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.63 million have received free flu shots under inoculation program

TEXT.P: Some 1.63 million Taiwanese people have received free flu shots this month under an annual government-funded flu inoculation program targeting vulnerable groups, an official of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Thursday.

The target of this year's program, which began on Oct. 1, includes senior citizens aged 65 and older, residents and workers of nursing homes, children between the ages of six months and three years, and first through fourth graders at elementary schools.

Also targeted are patients suffering from rare diseases, serious illnesses or injuries, disease prevention and control personnel at medical and health care institutions, workers in the poultry and livestock industries, and animal disease control and prevention personnel.
CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said Thursday that it is estimated that at least 3 million people are entitled to receive the flu shots.
Since the launch of the program, the inoculation rate was the highest among members of the disease prevention and control personnel at medical and health institutions at 67 percent.
In comprison, only 41 percent of elderly citizens and those with serious diseases or injuries have received flu shots.
Flu outbreaks normally peak in late November and gradually tail off after the Lunar New Year holiday, which usually falls in February.
As it takes around two weeks for the vaccine to produce an immunity, Lin advised people to get vaccinated before the end of October.
Lin said the CDC has purchased 3.2 million doses of flu vaccine to meet this year's demand.
If there are doses left over by Nov. 30 when the program expires, they will be available to other citizens from Dec. 1, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: President buys necessities for poor children in online charity drive

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou purchased a shipment of daily necessities online and had them delivered by express service to disadvantaged children, in a show of support for a charity drive launched Wednesday by the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families, according to the fund's Chief Executive Officer Wang Ming-jen.
The drive was initiated by PChome Online, one of the nation's leading Internet portals, in cooperation with the children's fund and the home delivery service President Transnet.

Under the program, all the basic necessities required by the fund's 22 centers around the country are available on PChome's Web site, which allows the public to purchase and donate basic items to those in need.
All purchased items will be delivered within 24 hours to designated centers, and the centers will swiftly deliver the donations to disadvantaged children, Wang said.

The drive was launched with Ma's order that included toothpaste, toothbrushes, shower gel, rice, toilet paper and facial tissues, all of which were to be delivered to the fund's centers within one day.
Wang said most of children receiving aid from the fund are from poor families and they are reliant on charity for their livelihood and education until they can become independent.
Wang expressed the hope that the charity drive will help to alleviate the dire financial situation of disadvantaged families, which has been exacerbated by rising consumer prices.
The fund currently provides aid to about 40,000 children in Taiwan and nearly 36,000 in foreign countries, and has helped 170,944 people come off the poverty line and live independently.
Vincent Hsieh, PChome's chief operating officer, said he is proud of the Web portal's staff who initiated the online charity drive -- the first of its kind in Taiwan.

Huang Chien-li, general manager of President Transnet, said his company is committed to participating in the drive and will guarantee delivery of all donations to the fund's centers, no matter how difficult the route.
He emphasized that delivery will be free during the first month of the charity drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: More convenient transport links to keep businessmen at home

TEXT.P: More convenient cross-Taiwan Strait transport links will encourage Taiwanese business owners with operations in China keep their operational bases and homes in Taiwan, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.
Mao said if cross-strait charter flight services were more convenient -- with added numbers of flights and destinations -- the impact would not only be economical.
"It would also have a positive influence on social development across the strait, leading more Taiwanese business owners to become more willing to keep their roots at home in Taiwan," Mao said.

China is Taiwan's number one destination for foreign direct investment and around 1 million Taiwanese business people and their families are believed to be living in mainland China, mostly in coastal cities such as Shanghai.

Before weekend cross-strait charter flights were launched on July 4 this year, the only non-stop flights available were on a handful of holidays each year, making it necessary for Taiwanese investors to move to the mainland.

The weekend flight services were launched following an agreement signed by Taiwan and China's top negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), respectively.

The agreements were signed in mid-June after the two quasi-official intermediary bodies in charge of negotiations in the absence of formal government-to-government relations resumed top-level cross-strait dialogues which were suspended in 1999.
Chen is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Nov. 3 for a five-day visit as a reciprocal gesture for Chiang's visit to Beijing in June.

During the planned meeting in Taipei, Chiang, Chen and representatives from the two sides are expected to cover issues such as opening new air routes and more destinations across the Taiwan Strait, extending direct weekend charter flights to weekdays, establishing direct shipping links and postal exchanges, and developing a framework to deal with food safety issues. Agreement on these issues are also expected to be signed.

Although regular weekend flights have been launched, some believe the flights are not frequent enough and are inconvenient because they must pass through Hong Kong airspace, due to security concerns, before heading to their final destinations.
The number of routes are also not considered sufficient.

Mao quoted the results of a recent poll conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as indicating that about 45 percent of China- based Taiwanese business owners would choose to live in Taiwan if the weekend cross-strait charter services, currently operated between Friday and Monday, were extended to every day of the week.

In comparison, Mao said, only 3 percent of the Taiwanese business owners said they would move their business operation nerve centers from Taiwan to China if there were more convenient cross-strait transport links, which would enable them and their families to remain in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Mao said, if direct shipping links, which still do not exist at present, are opened in the near future, time for a one-way trip by ship from Taiwan to the Chinese mainland will be reduced by one to four days -- a prospect that would make Taiwan's agricultural exports to China more competitive, by shortening delivery time and ensuring freshness.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP criticizes indictment of councilor for harassing Beijing official

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accused Tainan prosecutors Thursday of staging a show to appease China, prior to a visit by a key figure from Beijing, with the indictment of a city councilor on charges of harassing a visiting Chinese official last week.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang made the charge at the party's headquarters in Taipei after Tainan prosecutors announced earlier the same day that they would seek a sentence of 14 months in jail for Tainan City Councilor Wang Ting-yu of the DPP for harassing Zhang Mingqing -- vice president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- in public last week.

Zhang fell to the ground as he was being besieged and jostled by a group of anti-China protesters, allegedly mobilized by Wang, while Zhang was touring Tainan City's Confucius Temple on Oct. 21 in southern Taiwan.

Prosecutors charged Wang with assault, hindering personal freedom and eroding public order. A total of seven people, including Wang, were indicted in the case, which was transferred by the Tainan city police to Tainan prosecutors Wednesday.

Cheng criticized the prosecutors' swift indictment, saying that the "speedy" handling of the case was to "appease" China ahead of an imminent visit by ARATS President Chen Yunlin -- China's top negotiator with Taiwan -- from Nov. 3-7.
"Political considerations might be behind the swift indictment, " Cheng alleged.

Prosecutors are also seeking an eight-month jail term for a protester, identified by the surname Lin, who jumped onto the hood of Zhang's car and stamped on it as Zhang was being escorted away from the site by a local official and a tour guide.

In a statement issued later Thursday, the Tainan Prosecutors Office rejected the DPP's accusation and stressed that the indictment was not politically motivated and that there was no interference in the case by any superior official or government agency.
Prosecutors were able to quickly wrap up the investigation into the case because of the solid evidence available, the Tainan Prosecutors Office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever haul of ketamine seized at Taoyuan airport

TEXT.P: More than 156 kg of ketamine -- the largest haul ever seized at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport -- was discovered earlier this week at the country's main gateway, airport police authorities said Thursday in a statement.
According to airport police authorities, airport security inspectors detected the category-three drug when X-raying cargo that had been mailed through the airport's express delivery service centers.

The drug was discovered in three batches, with the first two batches totaling 105.2 kg seized Tuesday at one courier center and the third, of 51.45 kg, discovered Wednesday at a different center, airport police said. The drugs were wrapped in small aluminum bags.
Two suspects were apprehended in Taipei and Taoyuan counties in northern Taiwan, while a third was captured in Pingtung County in the south of the country.
The case was turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mainland official's apology welcomed and helpful to Chen meeting: SEF

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said that the apology by China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin over imported melamine-tainted products Thursday will help smooth the way for Chen's upcoming visit here, but Chiang insisted that Taiwan still wants to be compensated for economic losses suffered.

"The mainland's top negotiator Chen Yunlin has publicly apologized to Taiwan's people for the tainted milk incident. I welcome it because it will help the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting in Taipei," Chiang told reporters at a news conference.

Chen, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, said this morning in Beijing during a press conference that the tainted milk incident is a huge breach of food safety. It has caused great harm to the health of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said.
"I feel very sad. I am hereby apologizing to the people in Taiwan," Chen said.

Having heard Chen's open apology, Chiang responded: "Taiwan's people not only require an apology. We demand compensation as well. However, Chen's apology will help to smooth the process for the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting."
On Monday, ARATS had faxed a formal letter of apology to SEF over the issue.

"What is important in the future is that both sides of the strait have to work together to prevent similar incidents from re-occurring, " Chiang said, pointing out that measures that will allow a quick response between mainland China and Taiwan need to be established.
Chen also told the news conference that he is disappointed that he will not be able to visit Chiayi County in central Taiwan to see the famous mountain Alishan.

Chen's itinerary had originally included a trip to Chiayi County but due to the fact that earlier on Oct. 21, ARATS deputy president Zhang Mingqing was mobbed by protestors in Tainan City in southern Taiwan, Chen's visits to central and southern Taiwan were canceled.

"He is expressing his true emotions. He is a hearty man, like most people from northeastern mainland China", said Chiang. "I am sure that as long as both sides of the Taiwan Strait could just sit down and talk, we could actually work out many problems, " Chiang added.
Chen will be the highest ranking mainland Chinese official to set foot on Taiwan since the two sides split at the end of a civil war in 1949.
The upcoming meeting will be the second meeting between Chiang and Chen since their first meeting in Beijing in June of 2007.

The purpose of Chen's visit to Taiwan is to sign landmark agreements, including on expanding direct chartered flights, launching shipping and postal links as well as setting up a mechanism to deal with food safety issues between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russia's Pichuzhkina takes center stage with four golds

TEXT.P: Russia has proved itself once again as the world best in rhythmic gymnastics, as 17 year-old Natalia Pichuzhkina made a clean sweep of the gold medals in that category of the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games Pre-event Series Wednesday.
Rhythmic gymnastics was the first of five gymnastics events in the 12-day warm- up games that opened at the Kaohsiung Arena Tuesday.

On Tuesday, Pichuzhkina won two gold medals in the rope and hoop events with skillful artistic performances that highlighted the beauty and power of her movements. The next day, the young woman snagged another two gold medals, as she won the judges' hearts in the club and ribbon competitions.
Pichuzhkina, the gold medalist in the clubs and group events at the 2006 European Youth Championship, scored 16.75 in the clubs contest Wednesday -- the highest score in the warm-up games so far.

Looked tired but excited, Pichuzhkina expressed satisfaction with her performance in the past two days. She said, however, that she made some minor mistakes during the competitions, but vowed to continue to improve her performance.

Pichuzhkina said she hopes to compete in the Olympics some day. In Russia, one must be the very best in order to qualify for the national Olympic team, she said. Russia was the gold medal winner in the rhythmic gymnastics event at the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games in August.
Although the World Games showcases non-Olympic events, it features rhythmic gymnastics as an individual competition. In the Olympics, it is a team event. Pichuzhkina left for home Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait mechanism on fishery disputes, relief urged

TEXT.P: Participants in a cross-Taiwan Strait academic forum on conservation of fishery resources called unanimously Thursday for the establishment of a mechanism to resolve cross-strait fishery disputes and provide relief to fishermen operating in the strait.

Forum attendees, including academics from National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) , researchers from the Fujian Marine Research Institute and from the Kinmen Fisheries Research Institute, also called for closer fishery cooperation between Taiwan and China so that sustainable fishery resources in the strait can be maintained.

Speaking at the forum, Liao Cheng-hsin, director of the NTOU's Department of Environmental Biology and Fisheries Science, said the fishery sectors from both sides already maintain very close ties because they share the Taiwan Strait as their major fishing ground.
Because of these close ties, Liao said, a mechanism for fishery disputes across the strait and the protection of fishermen from both sides should be established in order for development to continue.

Huang Shifong, chairman of the Fujian Deep Sea Fisheries Association, suggested that the fishery sectors from the two sides should cooperate more closely and should build a common fishery management body so that they can learn from and complement each other.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng pointed out in his opening address that Taiwan and China are separated only by a narrow strait, and said this makes both countries responsible for conserving fishery resources in the strait and protecting the maritime environment.
"Nothing constructive will be achieved if the efforts are made by one side only," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust 10-year-old fake NT$50 coin factory

TEXT.P: A makeshift factory that specialized in counterfeiting NT$50 (US$1.53) coins for the past 10 years has been discovered and manufacturing stopped in the southern county of Kaohsiung, with its owner arrested, police announced Thursday.

The 61-year-old owner, identified only by his family name Lin, told police he had been producing the fake NT$50 coins for a decade, injecting more that 500,000 fake coins, with a total face value of over NT$20 million, into the local market.

Acting on a tip-off, a law enforcement team of officers from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and police bureaus in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and neighboring Tainan County, raided the factory in Kaohsiung County's Luchu township Wednesday and seized its owner and a large number of finished and unfinished fake NT$50 coins, as well as counterfeiting machines and other equipment.

According to a CIB spokesman, Lin sold the fake coins to downstream accomplices who then laundered the money through retail market channels, night markets, convenience stores and automatic vending machines.
As the amounts were not large and no coin verification machines are available on the local market, the operation was not detected until recently, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese gymnast welcomes experience gained in pre-event

TEXT.P: Taiwanese gymnast Yu Pei-lung, who won two bronze medals at the 2009 World Games Pre-event Series, said Wednesday that she hopes the experience gained in the warm-up event will better prepare her for next July's World Games.

The two bronze medals that Yu won for her Chinese Taipei team were in the hoop event Tuesday with a score of 14.975 for a routine with high degree of difficulty, and in clubs with a score of 15.025 Wednesday.
Yu said that compared with Tuesday's performance, she was more relaxed on the second day, and was pleased to win the second bronze medal.
Yu, a student at National Taiwan Normal University, is a member of Taiwan's rhythmic gymnastics training team for next year's World Games.

She will vie with Wang Yi-chieh, another Taiwanese gymnast who also competed in the two-day rhythmic gymnastics warm-up events, for the only representative place in the World Games rhythmic gymanastics category.
Wang placed fourth in the qualifying rounds of the two-day competition's four events--rope, hoop, clubs, and ribbon.

Having competed three times in the Pacific Rim Gymnastics Championship, Yu said each international competition helps her, but added that competing in Taiwan and being watched by compatriots in the pre-event spurred her to better performances.

Though welcoming the experience gained in international competitions, Yu said that she is worried about her future development as she has had less time to practice since she entered university and has had difficulty finding a proper practice venue.
The rising Taiwanese star in the field of rhythmic gymnastics also said it was stressful to learn that there are more and more gymnasts than ever before in competition.
Nevertheless, Yu expressed hope that she will be able to compete in the World Games and give a performance that will bring honor to her country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vaccines for riemerella anatipestifer infection pass animal test

TEXT.P: Virologists at a government-run laboratory have completed animal testing on vaccines against three separate types of riemerella anatipestifer (RA) infection, a common communicable disease in poultry in Taiwan, officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Thursday.

The officials reported that RA-infection is highly lethal, with a mortality rate as high as 75 percent, and that it is impossible to develop a standard vaccine that can induce immunity against all serotypes of the bacterium.
In addition, they noted, the RA bacterium has 21 serotypes, although six serotypes -- RA-1, RA-2, RA-6, RA-8, RA-10 and RA-11 -- have been the most prevalent ones in recent years.

The fact that scientists have to deal with multiple serotypes individually further complicates the process of RA vaccine development, said the officials, adding that after four years, only vaccines for RA-1, RA-2 and RA-6 have been made.
The serotype, or serovar, is a sub-species classification that groups micro- organisms or viruses of the same species into different categories according to their cell surface antigens.

Chao Parn-hwa, director of the COA's Animal Health Research Institute, said that some 38 million head of poultry are consumed annually in Taiwan, representing a market value of NT$8 billion (about US$ 244 million) . To reduce losses resulting from RA infection, he went on, the institute began the vaccine development in 2004 with the help of several other Taiwanese universities.

Last year, after the vaccines were produced from inactivated bacteria, the project team began animal experiments on some 5,000 ducks and geese on three farms in the central counties of Yunlin and Chiayi, said Chao, adding that the results have been promising.

Chao said the institute will soon submit an application for mass production to the central health authority and that once permission has been granted, the institute will transfer the related technologies to private pharmaceutical companies for mass production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't promoting first law targeting human trafficking: official

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior is pushing for the passage of the country's first comprehensive law specifically targeting human trafficking, which would impose stricter punishment against offenders, an official said Thursday.

Speaking at an international conference, Deputy Interior Minister Lai Fong-wei said that enacting such a law would demonstrate the government's resolve to combat the crime and is part of its efforts to curb the serious crime.
Taiwan currently has laws and regulations addressing the issue, but the law mentioned by Lai will become the country's first to specifically address human trafficking offenses.

Offenders caught exploiting trafficked victims by forcing them to work, for instance, will be sentenced to up to seven years in prison based on the new law. Civil servants found guilty of such a crime will receive a punishment that is one and half times harsher than that of a regular citizen, if the law is enacted.
Lai said the draft law is expected to clear the legislative floor by the end of the current legislative session.

According to the ministry's National Immigration Agency (NIA) , Taiwan is one of the major importing countries of migrant workers and marriage immigrants from Southeast Asia. Against this background, human trafficking rings have exploited such channels to smuggle in Southeast Asian women, who are forced into prostitution or other illegal work. Mainland Chinese women are also smuggled here to work as prostitutes.

Taiwan's police has tracked down 275 cases of suspected human trafficking from January 2007 to September this year, with 190 cases involving sexual exploitation and 85 involving labor exploitation, according to NIA statistics.

Lai noted that with the establishment of an inter-agency meeting earlier this year, the ministry is stepping up its anti- human trafficking efforts with an allocation of NT$390 million (US$11.93 million) for the 2008-2010 period, in a bid to strengthen what he described as the "3P" measures.
The "3P" measures refer to prevention of the crime, prosecution of the perpetrators and protection for the victims.
In terms of protection, the government can grant trafficking victims work and temporary residency permits, according to Chieh Li-kung, vice director-general of the NIA.
Meanwhile, Chieh stressed that the cross-border pattern of human trafficking highlights the importance of setting up international cooperation networks to efficiently respond to the crime.

American Institute in Taiwan director Stephen M. Young said at the conference that the United States applauds and supports Taiwan's efforts and is committed to working with Taiwan on this global problem.
He said, however, there is still more for Taiwan to do, such as standardizing implementation of victim protection and strengthening coordination across agencies.

Another problem Taiwan faces, which is apparent to people who live here, is the insufficient implementation of laws. Many organized prostitution facilities, for example, are allowed to operate behind closed doors, while police authorities only crack down on prostitutes who are street walkers.

Human trafficking, which generates unlawful profits worth US$ 31.6 billion every year worldwide, is considered the second biggest type of crime next to drug trafficking, according to the International Labour Organization, a United Nations agency.

Around 12.3 million people are victims of forced labor around the world at present, with 2.4 million of them trafficked for the purposes of sexual and labor exploitation, as well as removal of human organs for lucrative transplant operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP application to rally outside Grand Hotel rejected

TEXT.P: An application filed by an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) city councilor to stage rallies next week on roads leading to the Grand Hotel to heckle China's top negotiator with Taiwan was rejected by the Taipei Municipal Police Department Thursday.

DPP Taipei City Councilor Chuang Jui-hsiung, who filed the application, said it is "ridiculous" that the police rejected the rally application on the grounds that permission to use the roads has already been applied for by the Taipei City Chapter of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) during a Nov. 3-7 visit by China's top liaison officer with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

The areas for which the KMT have applied for use Nov. 3-7 include the uphill side of the road leading to the Grand Hotel and the Grand Hotel Park, while the areas that Chuang has applied for are the downhill side of the road leading to the hotel and part of the nearby Bei An Road, the Taipei Police Department said.

Since KMT followers will gather on the KMT-reserved roads while Chen and his group were planning to gather on the other side of the roads, an undesirable conflict would probably occur, given the proximity of the two sides, the police said.
In addition to rallies, the DPP followers have also planned to fire whistling rockets to "prevent Chen Yunlin from sleeping at night."

Noting that tens of thousands of DPP members and followers took to the streets Oct. 25 for a "safeguarding Taiwan" rally that took place near the Presidential Office peacefully, Chuang described the Taipei police as "lacking a sense of humor" in their handling of Chen Yunlin's visit to the city.
Chen Yunlin's deputy, ARATS vice president Zhang Mingqing, was mobbed by angry protesters during a visit to the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan last week, forcing him to cut short his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed reactions in Chiayi to top Chinese negotiator's remarks

TEXT.P: A decision by China's top negotiator with Taiwan to stay away from central and southern Taiwan during his upcoming visit to the country drew mixed reactions Thursday in Chiayi, southern Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), apologized at a news conference in Beijing earlier in the day for Chinese exports of melamine-contaminated dairy products and food ingredients to Taiwan.
He also noted that he promised to visit Chiayi when he met several residents of the southern city in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province last month.

"I now have to apologize, " said Chen, his voice breaking with apparent emotion, adding that "because of the arrangement of the itinerary, I will be unable to visit central and southern Taiwan during my visit Nov. 3-7."
Chiayi Councilor Chen Wen-lin of the ruling Kuomintang said he met the ARATS chief Sept. 24 when he visited the tulou (earth building) in Zhangzhou, listed as a world heritage site.

After learning that Chen Yunlin was to visit Taiwan in October, he and other members of his tour group invited the official to visit Chiayi to see the famous Mt. Ali and taste steamed rice with turkey, a Chiayi delicacy.
Chen Wen-lin said he regretted that Chen Yunlin would not visit Chiayi and expressed hope that the public would not "over politicize" his visit.
"Those who visit Taiwan should be treated as guests. If he can travel to central and southern Taiwan, he will also gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan's freedom and democracy," Chen Wen-lin said.
"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not confront each other forever, but should gradually ease the tensions," he added.

Although he has welcomed Chen Yunlin's visit, however, others obviously have very different views, with a bronze statue of the late President Chiang Kai-shek that stands in a park in Chiayi County defaced with characters that read "Chen Yunlin get out."

Chen Yunlin's decision to stay out of central and southern Taiwan during his visit is due to safety reasons, following an ugly incident Oct. 21 in which Zhang Mingquing, a deputy of Chen Yunlin, fell to the ground after being jostled by protesters while he was visiting the Confucius Temple in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wider range agreed upon for direct hiring of Indonesian workers

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Indonesia reached consensus on a variety of issues in a recent Taiwan-Indonesia labor affairs conference, including an agreement to allow direct hiring of Indonesian laborers in all relevant industries, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs said Thursday.

The conference, held in Taipei Oct. 29, was attended by officials from both sides and presided over by the council's Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan and Mohammed Jumhur Hidayat, director-general of Indonesia's National Agency for the Placement and Protection of Indonesian Overseas Workers.
The consensus will allow Indonesia to join other foreign labor source countries that have agreed to apply the direct hiring system to better protect their overseas workers' rights, the official said.

Taiwan's government set up the Direct Hiring Service Center in December 2007 to help local people find foreign caretakers, with the main objective of streamlining the process of hiring foreign caregivers and protecting foreign laborers from being exploited by employment agencies.
The measure allows foreign laborers to find jobs in Taiwan without having to go through labor brokers either in their own countries or in Taiwan.
For Indonesian workers in Taiwan, the measure is currently only applicable for those in caregiving, who account for 90 percent of the 120,000 Indonesian workers in Taiwan, the official said.
The consensus reached Wednesday will benefit the remaining 10 percent of Indonesian workers in the manufacturing and construction industries, the official added.
The two sides also agreed to shorten the application time and to simplify process of direct hiring services, the official went on.

In addition to the direct hiring measure, Taiwan and Indonesia also agreed on exchanges of information on training of family caregivers in the hope of improving the standards of Indonesian caregivers, with the exchanges to be carried out within one month.

Indonesia also promised control its employment agencies, which have a high rate of absconding laborers, and will establish a mechanism within one month to cover Taiwan's expenses in finding, detaining, and deporting absconding Indonesian workers, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves draft bill on Taoyuan aviation park development

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Thursday a draft package of regulations governing the development of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and surrounding areas with the aim of stimulating local economic growth.

"The draft package is designed to facilitate the development of an aviation city revolving around the airport to meet the demand of both aviation services and local economic development, " said Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which the package was reviewed and approved.

Noting that the Taoyuan aviation city project is one of the 12 "i-Taiwan" programs touted by President Ma Ying-jeou when he was on the campaign trail for the presidency, Liu said a state-owned airport company will be established in accordance with the new package, which he said will allow for the introduction of entrepreneurial skills to airport management.
He added that the raft of regulations will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval in the near future.
"If the bill clears the legislative floor by the end of this year, the proposed state-run airport company will be inaugurated in 2010," Liu explained.

Highlights of the bill include tax breaks for the new airport company, which will not face business tax on airport service charges and other revenues, while airport buildings will be exempt from housing tax and all airport land plots will be exempt from land tax.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said the Taoyuan aviation city development project symbolizes the government's resolve to catch up with other major countries, including those in the Asia-Pacific region, which are also developing their major international airports into logistics centers.

"Our project covers two sectors -- the Taoyuan airport park and the aviation city in its vicinity, " Mao noted, adding that the ultimate goal is simultaneous development of the airport and its surrounding regions.

While enjoying tax breaks, the airport company will be required to offer part of its profits to the Taoyuan county government for local development projects and to financially support the country's money-losing airports.

As to who will be eligible to bid for development projects in the airport park and aviation city, Mao said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will be responsible for all planning work and that local governments will also be allowed to take part in the projects.
Operators in the manufacturing and service sectors are also welcome to invest in the development projects to make the country's main gateway into a locomotive for industrial and economic growth.
The draft bill contains 46 articles in nine chapters that include general operation guidelines, program planning and revisions, airport park management and aviation city development and construction.

According to the regulations, the park and aviation city will be granted privileges similar to free trade ports, which enjoy greater flexibility in hiring foreign laborers and local workers than regular businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sex workers appeal for abolition of penalties for streetwalkers

TEXT.P: A group of streetwalkers and prostitutes' rights activists demonstrated in front of the Executive Yuan building Thursday, appealing for the abolishment of a regulation that punishes streetwalkers but not their clients.

A spokeswoman for the Taipei-based Collective of Sex Workers and Supporters (COSWAS) said the group organized the demonstration to highlight its appeal because a "consensus conference" commissioned by the Executive Yuan will take place in November to discuss whether prostitutes should be exempt from punishment.
Taiwan's legal system only punishes prostitutes, not their patrons, and mainly targets women who walk the streets looking for customers rather than women who work in bars or clubs.

For years, the COSWAS and other prostitutes' rights activists have been pushing for the scrapping of Article 80 of the Social Order Management Act which only mandates punitive measures for the prostitutes, while allowing the men who pay for their services to get off scot-free.

At a time when the world is engulfed in serious financial turmoil and credit crunch, the COSWAS spokeswoman said, domestic jobless rates are skyrocketing, adding to the economic harships for underprivileged families.

Noting that the some 100,000 sex workers in Taiwan face a constant struggle to support themselves and their families, she added that the government should abolish the unfair law and legalize prostitution.
If the sex trade were to be legalized, better management could be introduced to provide better protection for sex workers, most of whom are socially underprivileged, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 31, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.
