Mainland Chinese women are also smuggled here to work as prostitutes.

Taiwan's police has tracked down 275 cases of suspected human trafficking from January 2007 to September this year, with 190 cases involving sexual exploitation and 85 involving labor exploitation, according to NIA statistics.

Lai noted that with the establishment of an inter-agency meeting earlier this year, the ministry is stepping up its anti- human trafficking efforts with an allocation of NT$390 million (US$11.93 million) for the 2008-2010 period, in a bid to strengthen what he described as the "3P" measures.
The "3P" measures refer to prevention of the crime, prosecution of the perpetrators and protection for the victims.
In terms of protection, the government can grant trafficking victims work and temporary residency permits, according to Chieh Li-kung, vice director-general of the NIA.
Meanwhile, Chieh stressed that the cross-border pattern of human trafficking highlights the importance of setting up international cooperation networks to efficiently respond to the crime.

American Institute in Taiwan director Stephen M. Young said at the conference that the United States applauds and supports Taiwan's efforts and is committed to working with Taiwan on this global problem.
He said, however, there is still more for Taiwan to do, such as standardizing implementation of victim protection and strengthening coordination across agencies.

Another problem Taiwan faces, which is apparent to people who live here, is the insufficient implementation of laws. Many organized prostitution facilities, for example, are allowed to operate behind closed doors, while police authorities only crack down on prostitutes who are street walkers.

Human trafficking, which generates unlawful profits worth US$ 31.6 billion every year worldwide, is considered the second biggest type of crime next to drug trafficking, according to the International Labour Organization, a United Nations agency.

Around 12.3 million people are victims of forced labor around the world at present, with 2.4 million of them trafficked for the purposes of sexual and labor exploitation, as well as removal of human organs for lucrative transplant operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP application to rally outside Grand Hotel rejected

TEXT.P: An application filed by an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) city councilor to stage rallies next week on roads leading to the Grand Hotel to heckle China's top negotiator with Taiwan was rejected by the Taipei Municipal Police Department Thursday.

DPP Taipei City Councilor Chuang Jui-hsiung, who filed the application, said it is "ridiculous" that the police rejected the rally application on the grounds that permission to use the roads has already been applied for by the Taipei City Chapter of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) during a Nov. 3-7 visit by China's top liaison officer with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

The areas for which the KMT have applied for use Nov. 3-7 include the uphill side of the road leading to the Grand Hotel and the Grand Hotel Park, while the areas that Chuang has applied for are the downhill side of the road leading to the hotel and part of the nearby Bei An Road, the Taipei Police Department said.

Since KMT followers will gather on the KMT-reserved roads while Chen and his group were planning to gather on the other side of the roads, an undesirable conflict would probably occur, given the proximity of the two sides, the police said.
In addition to rallies, the DPP followers have also planned to fire whistling rockets to "prevent Chen Yunlin from sleeping at night."

Noting that tens of thousands of DPP members and followers took to the streets Oct. 25 for a "safeguarding Taiwan" rally that took place near the Presidential Office peacefully, Chuang described the Taipei police as "lacking a sense of humor" in their handling of Chen Yunlin's visit to the city.
Chen Yunlin's deputy, ARATS vice president Zhang Mingqing, was mobbed by angry protesters during a visit to the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan last week, forcing him to cut short his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed reactions in Chiayi to top Chinese negotiator's remarks

TEXT.P: A decision by China's top negotiator with Taiwan to stay away from central and southern Taiwan during his upcoming visit to the country drew mixed reactions Thursday in Chiayi, southern Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), apologized at a news conference in Beijing earlier in the day for Chinese exports of melamine-contaminated dairy products and food ingredients to Taiwan.
He also noted that he promised to visit Chiayi when he met several residents of the southern city in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province last month.

"I now have to apologize, " said Chen, his voice breaking with apparent emotion, adding that "because of the arrangement of the itinerary, I will be unable to visit central and southern Taiwan during my visit Nov. 3-7."
Chiayi Councilor Chen Wen-lin of the ruling Kuomintang said he met the ARATS chief Sept. 24 when he visited the tulou (earth building) in Zhangzhou, listed as a world heritage site.

After learning that Chen Yunlin was to visit Taiwan in October, he and other members of his tour group invited the official to visit Chiayi to see the famous Mt. Ali and taste steamed rice with turkey, a Chiayi delicacy.
Chen Wen-lin said he regretted that Chen Yunlin would not visit Chiayi and expressed hope that the public would not "over politicize" his visit.
"Those who visit Taiwan should be treated as guests. If he can travel to central and southern Taiwan, he will also gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan's freedom and democracy," Chen Wen-lin said.
"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not confront each other forever, but should gradually ease the tensions," he added.

Although he has welcomed Chen Yunlin's visit, however, others obviously have very different views, with a bronze statue of the late President Chiang Kai-shek that stands in a park in Chiayi County defaced with characters that read "Chen Yunlin get out."

Chen Yunlin's decision to stay out of central and southern Taiwan during his visit is due to safety reasons, following an ugly incident Oct. 21 in which Zhang Mingquing, a deputy of Chen Yunlin, fell to the ground after being jostled by protesters while he was visiting the Confucius Temple in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wider range agreed upon for direct hiring of Indonesian workers

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Indonesia reached consensus on a variety of issues in a recent Taiwan-Indonesia labor affairs conference, including an agreement to allow direct hiring of Indonesian laborers in all relevant industries, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs said Thursday.

The conference, held in Taipei Oct. 29, was attended by officials from both sides and presided over by the council's Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan and Mohammed Jumhur Hidayat, director-general of Indonesia's National Agency for the Placement and Protection of Indonesian Overseas Workers.
The consensus will allow Indonesia to join other foreign labor source countries that have agreed to apply the direct hiring system to better protect their overseas workers' rights, the official said.

Taiwan's government set up the Direct Hiring Service Center in December 2007 to help local people find foreign caretakers, with the main objective of streamlining the process of hiring foreign caregivers and protecting foreign laborers from being exploited by employment agencies.
The measure allows foreign laborers to find jobs in Taiwan without having to go through labor brokers either in their own countries or in Taiwan.
For Indonesian workers in Taiwan, the measure is currently only applicable for those in caregiving, who account for 90 percent of the 120,000 Indonesian workers in Taiwan, the official said.
The consensus reached Wednesday will benefit the remaining 10 percent of Indonesian workers in the manufacturing and construction industries, the official added.
The two sides also agreed to shorten the application time and to simplify process of direct hiring services, the official went on.

In addition to the direct hiring measure, Taiwan and Indonesia also agreed on exchanges of information on training of family caregivers in the hope of improving the standards of Indonesian caregivers, with the exchanges to be carried out within one month.

Indonesia also promised control its employment agencies, which have a high rate of absconding laborers, and will establish a mechanism within one month to cover Taiwan's expenses in finding, detaining, and deporting absconding Indonesian workers, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet approves draft bill on Taoyuan aviation park development

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Thursday a draft package of regulations governing the development of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and surrounding areas with the aim of stimulating local economic growth.

"The draft package is designed to facilitate the development of an aviation city revolving around the airport to meet the demand of both aviation services and local economic development, " said Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at a weekly Cabinet meeting in which the package was reviewed and approved.

Noting that the Taoyuan aviation city project is one of the 12 "i-Taiwan" programs touted by President Ma Ying-jeou when he was on the campaign trail for the presidency, Liu said a state-owned airport company will be established in accordance with the new package, which he said will allow for the introduction of entrepreneurial skills to airport management.
He added that the raft of regulations will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval in the near future.
"If the bill clears the legislative floor by the end of this year, the proposed state-run airport company will be inaugurated in 2010," Liu explained.

Highlights of the bill include tax breaks for the new airport company, which will not face business tax on airport service charges and other revenues, while airport buildings will be exempt from housing tax and all airport land plots will be exempt from land tax.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said the Taoyuan aviation city development project symbolizes the government's resolve to catch up with other major countries, including those in the Asia-Pacific region, which are also developing their major international airports into logistics centers.

"Our project covers two sectors -- the Taoyuan airport park and the aviation city in its vicinity, " Mao noted, adding that the ultimate goal is simultaneous development of the airport and its surrounding regions.

While enjoying tax breaks, the airport company will be required to offer part of its profits to the Taoyuan county government for local development projects and to financially support the country's money-losing airports.

As to who will be eligible to bid for development projects in the airport park and aviation city, Mao said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will be responsible for all planning work and that local governments will also be allowed to take part in the projects.
Operators in the manufacturing and service sectors are also welcome to invest in the development projects to make the country's main gateway into a locomotive for industrial and economic growth.
The draft bill contains 46 articles in nine chapters that include general operation guidelines, program planning and revisions, airport park management and aviation city development and construction.

According to the regulations, the park and aviation city will be granted privileges similar to free trade ports, which enjoy greater flexibility in hiring foreign laborers and local workers than regular businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sex workers appeal for abolition of penalties for streetwalkers

TEXT.P: A group of streetwalkers and prostitutes' rights activists demonstrated in front of the Executive Yuan building Thursday, appealing for the abolishment of a regulation that punishes streetwalkers but not their clients.

A spokeswoman for the Taipei-based Collective of Sex Workers and Supporters (COSWAS) said the group organized the demonstration to highlight its appeal because a "consensus conference" commissioned by the Executive Yuan will take place in November to discuss whether prostitutes should be exempt from punishment.
Taiwan's legal system only punishes prostitutes, not their patrons, and mainly targets women who walk the streets looking for customers rather than women who work in bars or clubs.

For years, the COSWAS and other prostitutes' rights activists have been pushing for the scrapping of Article 80 of the Social Order Management Act which only mandates punitive measures for the prostitutes, while allowing the men who pay for their services to get off scot-free.

At a time when the world is engulfed in serious financial turmoil and credit crunch, the COSWAS spokeswoman said, domestic jobless rates are skyrocketing, adding to the economic harships for underprivileged families.

Noting that the some 100,000 sex workers in Taiwan face a constant struggle to support themselves and their families, she added that the government should abolish the unfair law and legalize prostitution.
If the sex trade were to be legalized, better management could be introduced to provide better protection for sex workers, most of whom are socially underprivileged, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Oct. 31, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday, moving up 24.11 points at 4,707.75 on a turnover of NT$3.91 billion (US$119.21 million).
The weighted price index gained 277.12 points, or 6.28 percent, to close at 4,683.64 Thursday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.652 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.147 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 31, or the third day of the 10th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai- shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two- member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."
