DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. looks forward to Ex-ROC vice president's APEC participation
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/08 13:22:03 (By Chiehyu Lin, Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States looks forward to former Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan's participation in an upcoming informal leadership summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a U.S. State Department official said Thursday.

The official, however, declined to comment on whether the participation of Lien -- the highest-ranking former ROC official ever to attend an APEC leadership meeting -- symbolizes a breakthrough for Taiwan and progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Lien will attend this year's Nov. 22-23 summit in Lima, Peru, on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admits both Taiwan and China as members. Due to China's opposition, Taiwan's president is barred from attending the annual informal leadership meeting in person and instead has to name a special envoy who attends on his behalf.

Taiwan was represented at the first APEC leaders summit, held in Seattle in 1993, by Vincent Siew, then-chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development. Siew is now vice president.
In the last two APEC forums, Taiwan was represented by prominent business leaders -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, respectively.

Also Thursday, Randy Schriver, a former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, told CNA in Washington that he is pleased to see Lien's participation in the next summit.
Schriver said he hopes the United States -- the host of the 2010 APEC forum -- will invite Ma to attend that event in person.
His view echoed that of Douglas Paal, former Taipei Office director of the American Institute in Taiwan, who has proposed that Ma seek to participate in the APEC summit under a "proper" title.

Paal, currently vice president of the U.S.-based Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, predicted during a visit to Taiwan earlier this month that Ma's participation in the summit could be possible in the coming two to three years thanks to his efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations through a "modus vivendi" approach that advocates a "diplomatic truce" with China.
According to Paal, Ma's approach has received good responses from China, as seen in the postponement of Paraguay's plan to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former national security chief detained on suspicions of corruption

TEXT.P: Former National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen was detained and held incommunicado Friday on suspicions of defrauding half a million U.S. dollars in the name of promoting diplomacy.

After a two-month investigation, prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office summoned Chiou and five other witnesses in the wee hours of Friday for questioning on suspicion that he defrauded US$500,000 from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) earmarked for a diplomacy promotion effort known as the An Ya Project and sought Chiou's detention afterward.
Their request was granted by the Taipei District Court Friday.

According to MOFA officials, after the An Ya Project was executed, Chiou, then secretary general of the National Security Council, wrote a letter to the MOFA, demanding that the ministry appropriate US$500,000 for him to facilitate the progress of the An Ya Project.

The MOFA issued several traveler's checks for the amount under the instruction of then-Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau and the checks were submitted to Chiou's office by one of Kau's secretaries, the Taipei District Court said in its ruling.
Chiou's scheme cam to light when part of those checks were cashed by him at a casino overseas, according to the ruling.
He took the money in the name of facilitating the progress of "secret diplomacy" in which former President Chen Shui-bian is said to have engaged during his tenure.
The prosecutors searched six locations Friday before questioning Chiou and said that the search had yielded evidence.
The Taipei District Court granted the prosecutors' request to have Chiou detained incommunicado out of concern that he could tamper with evidence.
The other five people were released after questioning.

Chiou stepped down in disgrace as vice premier only two weeks before he was due to finish his term May 20 in the wake of a diplomatic bungle in which Taiwan was defrauded of US$29.8 million while seeking to forge official ties with Papua New Guinea in 2006.

Several media outlets quoted Control Yuan member Hung Chao-nan as alleging several days ago that Chiou handed US$10 million in cash to the president of a Latin American country when Chen was visiting that country, with which Taiwan maintains formal diplomatic relations. Hung did not identify the country in question.
Chiou denied Hung's allegation.
Chiou's case was a spin-off of the prosecutors' efforts to sort out other details involving Chen and his family's alleged money laundering via overseas bank accounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA Airways to resume Taipei-Paris passenger flights in January

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second-largest international air carrier, Eva Airways, is scheduled to resume Taipei-Paris passenger flights from January in view of lower oil prices, a corporate source said Friday.

From Jan. 21, EVA will offer three weekly passenger flights, on Monday, Friday and Sunday, departing from Taipei for Paris, while the returning flights will depart from Paris for Taipei every Monday, Thursday and Saturday, according to the EVA official.

EVA suspended its passenger flight operations on the Taipei-Paris route last November after deficits caused by soaring oil prices. In addition to higher fuel prices, expensive costs for flying over Russian airspace also led the carrier to call a halt to the Taipei-Paris route, the official said.

EVA will be using new Boeing 777-300ERs on the route, which will save up to 20 percent of the fuel consumed by the Boeing 747-400s that were used on the route prior to November 2007, said the official.
The flights will still fly over Russia's Siberia flight zone, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
TSU demands compensation from ARATS head over melamine scandal

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) performed a protest skit outside a Taipei City hotel Friday to demand that Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin offer compensation for the scandal over melamine-contaminated food imported from China.
Chen and his delegation are expected to stay at the hotel during a visit to Taiwan slated to kick off Monday.

The TSU demanded compensation following a verbal apology to Taiwan by the ARATS head in Beijing a day earlier. Chen's apology came in the wake of a written apology issued by the association on Monday.
TSU Secretary-General Lin Jhi-jia said the imports of melamine-tainted milk powder from China has caused serious harm to Taiwan's baking industry.
He said the protest skit was staged because Taiwan's "patience has come to an end" regarding tainted food products from China.

The head of the tiny pro-independence party said Chen must offer "concrete compensation" for the harm caused by the scandal, otherwise the TSU will call for the Taiwanese people to "ask him to eat tainted pie."

Lin said the next step will be to urge all sectors of Taiwanese society to voice a formal protest to Chen, adding that the party has people ready to follow the ARATS head and his delegation around and protest during their visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier: Cross-strait flights are "special air route"

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said in a television interview Thursday that "relations between Taiwan and China are neither domestic nor international and that therefore, cross-Taiwan Strait direct flights are very special air routes."
Liu made the remarks in an interview with China Television on an upcoming landmark visit to Taiwan by Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin.

When asked if China and Taiwan see eye to eye on the issue, Liu responded that "if both sides of the Taiwan Strait had no consensus on the issue, then there would be no negotiations at all, let alone the signing of agreements."

Chen is slated to visit Taiwan Nov. 3-7 to sign a raft of agreements, including those on expanding direct chartered flights and launching shipping and postal links, as well as setting up a mechanism to deal with cross-strait food safety issues.
"The direct chartered flights between Taiwan and China are considered to be a special air route that is neither domestic nor international. It is a cross- strait air route," said Liu.

Chen will be the highest-ranking Chinese official to set foot on Taiwan since the end of the civil war in 1949. The meeting will be the second meeting between Chen and Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung since their first meeting in Beijing in June 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Import ban on Chinese agricultural products to remain: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the government has no plans to lift its import ban on 830 Chinese agricultural products as he pledged to protect the interests of Taiwanese farmers.

Raising the issue while receiving representatives of the agricultural, fishing and livestock sectors, Ma noted that Taiwan has over the past eight years opened its market to a total of 1,417 Chinese agricultural products, with 37 percent remaining forbidden.
"The government is very careful (about further opening the market) to protect Taiwanese farmers and fishermen from any damage, " Ma said.
He added that the interests of Taiwan and its people are his administration's top concern.

For example, he said, the establishment of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links -- an issue to be addressed during upcoming negotiations between Taiwan and China -- will be favorable to the development of Taiwan's agricultural and fishing sectors because it will facilitate Taiwanese exports to China.

Ma predicted that after the shipping links are launched, Taiwan's agricultural and fish exports to China will rise by 20 percent, increasing the income of local farmers and fishermen by 10 percent to 15 percent.

Chen Yunlin, who as president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits acts as Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan, will be in Taipei Nov. 3-7 to hold talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.
Besides a pact on direct cross-strait shipping, the two sides are also expected to seal agreements on cross-strait air services, mail services and food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP urges Taiwanese to treat ARATS head with courtesy
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/08 15:00:37 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu said in Los Angeles Thursday that the Taiwanese should treat Chen Yunlin, head of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), with the same common courtesy they would extend to any other visitor.

Lu made the remarks during a transit stop in the southern California city en route to Taiwan from a visit to Mexico City, where she attended the 26th annual conference of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women that took place Oct. 24-28.

On the ARATS head's upcoming visit to Taiwan, Lu said the public should treat him with the utmost kindest and friendliness to let him understand what Taiwan is really like. Chen is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Nov. 3.

"I believe there is no reason for our Democratic Progressive Party compatriots to feel too nervous or tense" about Chen's visit, Lu said, pointing out that "although we are not a great power, we are a democratic country and we are the masters of Taiwan," Lu said.
"We should bury the hatchet and let the other side of the Taiwan Strait clearly understand that the Republic of China on Taiwan is not a part of the People's Republic of China," Lu said.

The former vice president, who was slated to board a flight back to Taiwan Friday, said she will closely monitor developments regarding Chen's visit over the coming days but will not meet with him during his stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health surcharge on cigarettes to be increased to NT$20

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has passed a draft amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention and Control Act, increasing the health and welfare surcharge on cigarettes to NT$20 per pack from the existing NT$10 and expanding non-smoking areas in public spaces, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Friday.
Under the revisions, non-smoking areas will be extended to schools at senior- high level or below, medical institutions, government units and offices for use by three persons or above.

Those who violate the regulations will face a maximum fine of NT$10,000 (US$305) and those who provide smoking paraphernalia such as ashtrays in non-smoking areas or who fail to set up no-smoking signs in smoking-prohibited places will be subjected to a maximum fine of NT$50,000, the official said.
The revisions will take effect Jan. 11 next year after being ratified by the legislature, the official went on.
The revisions are designed in accordance with regulations set forth by the World Health Organization to increase prices in an effort to reduce tobacco consumption, the official said.

Taiwan spends about NT$45 billion annually on health insurance to cover medical treatment of diseases related to smoking, the official said, adding that the new measure raising tobacco prices will be beneficial to public health.
He noted that prices of tobacco products in Taiwan are still lower than that in some other countries.

Refusing to support the increase of health surcharge, Taiwan's tobacco industry association said that without supplementary measures, the considerable increase in health surcharge will trigger more serious smuggling of tobacco products and will cause the government's tax revenues to shrink.
However, DOH Deputy Minister Cheng Shou-hsia said the country's health surcharge revenue on cigarettes will increase from NT$20 billion to NT$38 billion after the amendments take effect next year.

The increased revenue will be used as subsidies for medical treatment for the disadvantaged, including those with rare diseases or financial difficulties and those living in remote areas where medical resources are insufficient, Cheng said.

Meanwhile, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan instructed the DOH at Thursday's weekly Cabinet meeting, in which the revisions were passed, to communicate with the ruling Kuomintang and opposition Democratic Progressive Party to come up with effective measures against hording and smuggling of tobacco products.
Cheng said there will always be people protesting against the increase of tobacco health tax no matter when the increase is proposed.

He emphasized that the revisions will increase Taiwan's tobacco health surcharge, currently about 32 percent of the price of a pack of cigarettes, to slightly over 50 percent, which is still much lower than the 66 percent -80 percent in some other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pork off menu at Kaohsiung World Games warm-up event

TEXT.P: Out of respect for the dietary requirements of Muslim athletes and referees, pork is not being served during the 2009 World Games Pre-event Series, the event organizer said Friday.

The arrangements, including food, accommodation and transport, for the warm-up event follow next July's World Games standards, said Hsu Cho-Chuan, chief executive of the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee, which is in charge of the event.

Beef, chicken and vegetarian options are being offered to around 500 participants from 37 countries who are eating in various district offices and schools that have been pressed into service as eateries for the event, Hsu said.

Hsu added that the athletes and referees have been accommodated in 250 rooms in nine hotels around the city. They also receive lunch and dinner vouchers worth NT$250 (US$7.6) each from the organizer, with breakfast provided by the hotels.

The warm-up competition, which kicked off Oct. 28 in the southern port city, sees athletes competing in four sports -- water skiing, gymnastics, boules and korfball, with the assistance of around 1,000 volunteers who are helping with such logistics as translation and directions.

Set to take place in Kaohsiung July 16-26 next year, the World Games will feature 36 sports not featured in the Olympic Games, divided into six categories: artistic and dance sports, ball sports, martial arts, precision sports, strength sports and trend sports.

Hsu noted that the government will not construct a World Games athletes village but will instead provide athletes with accommodation and food in places close to the event venues for their convenience.
The event is expected to attract 4,500 athletes from around 100 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent for June.

TAIEX Index futures for November gained 250 points to finish at 4,844, with 171,585 contracts traded, while December futures increased 263 points to close at 4,794, with 1,647 contracts changing hands.
March futures advanced 245 points to close at 4,724, with 100 contract transactions, while June futures rose 309 points to finish at 4,730, with 64 contract transactions.
September futures gained 259 points to close at 4,570, with 73 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,594 for November, 4,531 for December, 4,479 for March, 4,421 for June, and 4,311 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 187.02 points to finish at 4,870.66, on turnover of NT$86.78 billion (US$2.64 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher, with TF futures for November and December both surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent.
November TE futures rose 6.25 points to close at 192.5, with 6,465 contracts traded, while December TE futures increased 5.2 points to finish at 189.5, with 214 contract transactions.
September TE futures lost 5.05 points to finish at 178, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.
November TF futures gained 34.2 points to finish at 525.2, with 3,534 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures increased 34 points to finish at 520.2, with 110 contracts traded.

March TF futures advanced 25 points to end at 521.4, with two contracts traded, while September TF futures grew 16.8 points to close at 496, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businesses in China back 2nd Chiang-Chen meeting

TEXT.P: Representatives of the associations of Taiwanese doing business or maintaining business operations in China are scheduled to gather in Taipei City Saturday to openly support the holding of talks with China in Taipei next week.

Chang Han-wen, president of the Association of Taiwan Invested Enterprises on the Mainland, said Friday that in addition to throwing their support behind the meeting, they will also urge the Kuomintang administration to quickly deliver on its campaign promises to open direct postal, business and transportation links with China.
One of the priorities, Chang said, will be to extend the weekend nonstop cross- strait charter flights that already exist to every day of the week by the end of the year.
"We also urge that financial institutions from each side be allowed to set up branches on the other side so that Taiwanese businesses in China can get financing," Chang said.

Taiwan and China's top negotiators -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- are scheduled to meet in Taipei next week to follow up on their meeting in Beijing in mid-June this year.
When Chen Yunlin arrives in Taipei Nov. 3 for a five-day historic visit, he will be the highest ranking People's Republic of China official to have ever visited Taiwan.

During the planned meeting, Taiwan and China are expected to cover issues such as opening new air routes and more destinations across the Taiwan Strait, extending direct weekend charter flights to weekdays, establishing direct shipping links and postal exchanges, and developing a framework to deal with food safety issues.
Four agreements on those issues are expected to be signed.

According to Chang, 12 representatives of Taiwanese businesses in China will gather at the Grand Hotel Nov. 3 to welcome Chen Yunlin's arrival in Taiwan and will attend the welcoming dinner at the hotel to be hosted by the SEF in honor of Chen.

The representatives are also scheduled to host a luncheon together with other Taiwanese industrial and business groups to honor Chen Yunlin and accompanying ARATS officials at the Grand Hotel Nov. 6, Chang added.

China is Taiwan's number one destination for foreign direct investment and around 1 million Taiwanese businesspeople and their families are believed to be living there, mostly in coastal cities such as Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP urges expats to help in normalization of U.S.-Taiwan ties
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 30 (CNA) 10/31/08 17:23:52 (By Chu Lu-seng and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Annette Lu urged Taiwanese expatriates in the United States Thursday to work together to assist Taiwan-U.S. relations in moving toward normalization.

Lu made the call during a stopover in Los Angeles en route back to Taiwan from her visit to Mexico City to attend the 26th annual conference of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women held Oct. 24-28.

Noting that next year will mark the 30th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act, Lu called for Taiwan expatriates with influence in the U.S. to reflect on what areas of Taiwan-U.S. ties have seen progress over the past three decades and what areas could be improved upon.

Pointing out that "the Taiwan of 30 years ago and Taiwan 30 years later are completely different, " the former vice president asked "with U.S. policy toward Taiwan at the time extending to today, how could it be that the policy would not need to be revised?"

After attending a welcoming party hosted by Taiwanese female expatriates at a hotel in the suburbs of L.A., Lu headed to Los Angeles International Airport for an early Friday morning flight back to Taiwan.
Lu and her delegation are scheduled to arrive at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the wee hours of Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: Taiwan people want to send message of peace to Chinese official

TEXT.P: The ruling party Kuomintang's Secretary General Wu Den-yi said in a press conference Friday that many people from central and southern Taiwan regret that China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin will not be able to visit their areas due to security concerns during his upcoming visit, and would like to send him a message of peace.
Wu said the residents would like to hold a seminar in Taipei during Chen's visit next week "to tell him that Taiwan people love peace."

According to Wu, people from Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County, Tainan County, Tainan City and Chiayi City would like to come to Taipei to hold the seminar. These people say that this upcoming meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, is "very much to the benefit of Taiwan."

"Taiwan people are very friendly and hospitable. We do not want the international community nor the people from mainland China to think that we are brutal in nature. We would like to send a message to Chen, to tell him that Taiwan people love peace", said Wu.

Sources from the ruling party Kuomintang (KMT) also said yesterday that ARATS President Chen, in addition to meeting SEF Chairman Chiang, will also meet with KMT heavyweights such as former vice-president Lien Chan, KMT Chairman Wu Poh- hsiung and People's First Party Chairman James Soong.

ARATS President Chen will be the highest ranking mainland Chinese official to visit Taiwan since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait split at the end of a civil war in 1949. The upcoming meeting between Chiang and Chen will be the second meeting between the two since their first meeting in Beijing in June 2007.

Chen is scheduled to visit Taiwan from Nov. 3 to 7 to sign landmark agreements, including on expanding direct chartered flights, launching shipping and postal links as well as setting up a mechanism to deal with food safety issues between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan joins Japan's project to upgrade Subaru Telescope

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top academic and science research institute, signed a memorandum of understanding with the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ) Friday to collaborate in optical and infrared wavelength astronomy and on the development of a new camera for the Subaru Telescope.

Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong and Paul Ho, director of the preparatory office of the planned Academia Sinica Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics (IAA) , sealed the new partnership in Toyko, Japan, according to a statement from Academia Sinica.
Subaru, built and first operated by the NAOJ in 1991, is an 8.2-meter optical infrared telescope situated at the summit of Nauna Kea of Hawaii, the United States.
It is the NAOJ's flagship telescope and one of the largest and most advanced optical telescopes in the world.
According to the statement, the NAOJ proposed to build a new camera, called Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) in 2006, a next generation very wide-field camera for the telescope.

Its targeted field of view is 1.5 degrees in diameter, giving it almost 10 times the field of view and survey speed of the existing prime focus camera (Suprime- Cam) on the telescope, while maintaining the equivalent image quality necessary for weak lensing survey.

The camera's development began in 2007, and it is scheduled to be completed in 2012. When built, it will be the world's largest CCD camera, composed of 120 8 -million-pixel CCD chips, the statement said.
The IAA was invited to develop certain special parts and components for the sophisticated camera and to join scientific observatory projects involving the state-of-the-art device.

The NAOJ, a member of Japan's inter-university research agency National Institutes of Natural Sciences, is a core Japanese national institute for astronomy and is widely acknowledged as having some of the world's most advanced observatory facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.K. establish parliamentary group to boost relations

TEXT.P: The establishment of the Taiwan-United Kingdom parliamentary group serves as an excellent channel for the two countries to further promote bilateral relations and exchanges, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday.

"It is such a good thing that we established the Taiwan-U.K. parliamentary association because in this way, we can promote diplomacy in a more relaxed manner and by building up interpersonal relationships (among legislators), Liu said at the inauguration of the Legislative Yuan's "Taiwan-U.K. Parliamentary Communication Association.
"Parliamentary diplomacy can serve as the mainstay of our national diplomatic work and provides a strong and firm support for it," he added.

Noting that the U.K. has one of the oldest multi-party democratic systems in the world, Liu said this parliamentary group is a platform for legislators from both sides to learn from each other and further promote bilateral relations on the foundations of strong economic, educational, cultural and scientific exchanges.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who also serves as the honorary chairman of the association, said the establishment of the parliamentary group isall that one could wish forbecause it can complement the government's diplomatic efforts.

Speaking at the same occasion, Michael Reilly, director of the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taiwan, noted that just over two years ago, the Select Committee of Foreign Affairs in the U.K. House of Commons published an extensive report on Britain's relations with China and Taiwan, in which it suggested that Taiwan and the U.K. should have closer links.

In its conclusions it stressed that the growth and development of democracy in Taiwan is of the greatest importance, and it recommended the British government should increase its contacts with Taiwan at a political level,Reilly said.
"In particular, it recommended that we should work to increase the links between elected representatives of Taiwan and those of the U.K.," Reilly added.
The top British representative to Taiwan said he hopes this association will be more than just a friendship group and be a platform for the two countries to work together.

He said the U.K. and Taiwan -- in common with many other developed countries -- face many shared challenges including tackling global warming, resisting protectionism, combating the spread of infectious diseases, and ensuring social justice.
TheTaiwan-U.K. Parliamentary Communication Associationis the 30th such group set up by the Legislative Yuan with counterparts from other countries.
Initiated by Kuomintang Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, who serves as the chairman of the association, the group has 57 members and is still growing.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.201 to close at NT$33.000.
A total of US$1.13 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.799 and fluctuated between NT$32.652 and NT$33.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices rise sharply on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 187.02 points, or 3.99 percent, to close at 4,870.66.

Finishing higher for the fourth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,707.75 and fluctuated between 4,911.8 and 4,659.67. A total of 4.77 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$86.78 billion (US$2.64 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 6.6 percent. Cement stocks advanced 6.5 percent, construction issues rose 6.1 percent, paper and pulp issues increased 5.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 5.2 percent, foodstuff issues grew 5.1 percent, textile stocks gained 4.2 percent, and machinery and electronics shares advanced 3.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 976 to 515, with 325 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.42 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu enters coastal fishing season

TEXT.P: On the Penghu Islands off southwest Taiwan, the strong chilly sea wind from the northeast has replaced the gentle summer southerly breeze. The beginning of the Penghu coastal fishing season has arrived.

Recently more and more enthusiastic anglers were spotted standing on rocks along the coasts of the Penghu archipelago, concentrating attention on the fishing pole in their hands and enjoying the fun of fishing on the seashore.
Lu Hung-chih, the founder and chairman of the Penghu Islands Rocks Fishing Association, touted Friday that the archipelago, which is located in the Taiwan Strait, is a heaven of rock fishing.
There are perfect spots for seashore fishing everywhere in Penghu which is a group of 90 islets that houses many fishing grounds in the Taiwan Strait.
Anglers in Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Taichung on the west coast of Taiwan proper were often seen sailing at night to remote islets off Penghu for fishing, he added.

The seasons of autumn and winter are regarded as the best time for rock fishing in Penghu, Lu said, because migratory fish usually gather near seashores in the cold seasons when the strong northeasterly wind blows.
"It is like schools of fish waiting for you to angle, instead of the fishers waiting for the fish, " said Lu, who developed the interest in rock fishing when he was a junior high school student.

On the downside, amateur anglers threaten the islets' beautiful ecologic environment by using fish bait mixed with chemical raw materials and the garbage they leave behind -- including plastic bottles and empty plastic lunch boxes, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA pledges full cooperation with probe of former security chief

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that it will cooperate fully with the investigation of a former national security chief who was detained on suspicion of defrauding the ministry of half a million U.S. dollars in the name of promoting diplomacy.
However, the MOFA declined to release any specific details of the case.
The Foreign Ministry will not comment on this specific case but will give full cooperation in the investigation, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said in response to reporters' questions.

Former National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen was detained Thursday and held incommunicado on suspicion of corruption in connection with the "An Ya Project, " the content of which has not be made public.
Chiou's case was a spin-off of prosecutors' efforts to sort out the details of allegations against former President Chen Shui-bian and his family of laundering money via overseas bank accounts.

Henry Chen said the Chiou case was one of the many in which standard procedure was not followed and that other such instances are being currently being investigated, but he refused to give any further details.

However, he stressed, this was why Foreign Minister Francisco H.L Ou insisted, upon taking office on May 20, that all diplomatic work should "return to being carried out under standard procedure and in accordance with the system."

No such thing ever happened before 2000 under the Kuomintang administration, as diplomatic work was conducted using professional standards, " the MOFA spokesman said. "We have to return to diplomatic professionalism and respect that."

According to a decision by the Taipei District Court, after the An Ya Project was closed, Chiou, then secretary general of the National Security Council, wrote a letter to the MOFA, asking the ministry to allocate US$500,000 to him to continue the project.

The MOFA issued several travelers' checks to him for the requested amount at the instruction of then-Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau, stated the Court in its decision to detain Chu, adding that the Chiou case came to light when he cashed some of the checks at a casino overseas.

Chiou stepped down in disgrace as vice premier in early May -- two weeks before his term expired -- amid a scandal over a diplomatic bungle in which Taiwan was defrauded of US$29.8 million while seeking to forge official ties with Papua New Guinea in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stronger APEC presence marks better cross-strait ties: SEF

TEXT.P: China's acceptance of former Vice President Lien Chan as Taiwan's representative at this year's informal leadership summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum is an important sign of improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Friday.

Lien, who will attend the Nov. 22-23 summit in Lima, Peru on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou, will be the highest-ranking former Republic of China official ever allowed to take part in the annual event.
Chiang pointed out that in the past when cross-strait relations were tense, Taiwan was subjected to obvious suppression by China in its participation in APEC.
The situation, however, has changed following the easing of tensions between the two sides, as seen in the example of Lien, he said.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admits both Taiwan and China as members. Due to China's opposition, Taiwan's president is barred from attending the leadership meeting in person and instead has to name a special envoy to attend on his behalf.
Chiang, who was then chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, attended the 1998 and 1999 summits on behalf of then President Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese tourists likely to visit Taiwan soon: Beijing official

TEXT.P: Larger numbers of Chinese tourists are likely to sightsee in Taiwan after flying across the Taiwan Strait becomes more convenient, a visiting Chinese official said Friday.

Speaking in Taipei, China's National Tourism Administration deputy director, Zhang Xiqin, brushed aside Taiwan's concern that the number of Chinese tourists coming here has remained low after the two sides agreed in June to allow up to 3,000 Chinese nationals a day to visit Taiwan.

Only 20,000 Chinese tourists have visited Taiwan since the agreement took effect in mid-July, but Zhang said he was more concerned that Taiwan's tourism facilities might not be able to accommodate the coming influx of Chinese tourists.
He asserted that large numbers of Chinese tourists will come to Taiwan soon as long as more flights and routes are established across the Taiwan Strait.

Zhang, who also serves as head of the non-official Cross-Strait Tourism Association, made the comments after presiding over the opening of the 2008 Taipei International Travel Fair at the Taipei World Trade Center with Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai, who also heads the Taiwan Strait Tourism and Travel Association.

He arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to attend this year's Taipei International Travel Fair, which runs until Nov. 3, at the head of a 290-member delegation composed of tourism officials and representatives from 31 provinces.

Zhang's trip to Taiwan came a few days ahead of a visit by China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, president of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, who is slated to arrive Nov. 3 for a five-day visit.

Chen will hold talks with Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on travel and tourism exchanges between Taiwan and China as well as food security cooperation, in a follow-up to their landmark meeting in Beijing in June.
For her part, Lai said all of Taiwan's sectors are paying a high degree of attention to Chen's visit to Taiwan next week and welcomed his visit.
She assured Taiwan's people that cross-Taiwan Strait travel and tourism will become more economical after more flights and routes are created.

DOC.HEADLINE: New cross-strait talks to usher in fresh tourism era: MOTC head

TEXT.P: The second meeting between top negotiators of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait scheduled for Nov. 3 will mark a new era for Taiwan's tourism, as more direct links between Taiwan and China will be established, the head of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.

MOTC Minister Mao Chi-kuo said at the opening ceremony of the Taipei International Travel Fair 2008 (Taipei ITF 2008) that amid an economic downturn, the tourism industry in Taiwan is still seeing growth this year and it will head into a new era, as relations between Taiwan and China reach a milestone with more direct air and sea links between the two sides.

Mao was referring to an upcoming meeting between Taiwan and China's top cross- strait negotiators, in which the two sides are expected to sign agreements on broadening their tourism and transportation links.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will head a delegation of around 60 people on a historic visit to Taiwan Nov. 3-7 to meet with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation. They are slated to sign four agreements, including a "Cross-Taiwan Strait Air Links Agreement" and accords on direct shipping and postal links.
Chen will be the highest ranking official from the People's Republic of China to visit Taiwan since the two sides split in 1949 after a civil war.

Speaking at the opening of the travel fair, Stanley Yen, director of the Taipei ITF Organizing Committee, said that the direct links between Taiwan and China will bring a complete change for travelers coming to Asia.

"Now that travelers from Europe and from the United States can easily include both Taiwan and China on their itinerary, this will officially put Taiwan on the road to becoming a regional transportation hub," Yen said.
According to Yen, Taipei ITF 2008 set new records this year with exhibitors from 62 countries and regions around the world occupying a total of 1,206 booths.
The fair was divided into six major exhibition areas -- each with its own unique features -- namely Europe, America, Africa, the Middle East, the Asia-Pacific Region, and Taiwan.

Noting that the Taipei ITF, which each year attracts huge crowds, has become the greatest tourism exhibition in Asia, Vice Premier Paul Chiu said that Taiwan is definitely worth visiting, as it has diverse cultures, beautiful scenery and most important of all -- the friendliest people.
The Taipei ITF, is in its 16th year, was organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association under the supervision of the MOTC.

According to the organizers, the most heavily represented countries and regions at the fair this year are Japan with 69 booths, Malaysia with 25, South Korea with 20, the U.S. with 14, Hong Kong with 12, and Macau also with 12.

Visitors are advised to make use of the Taipei ITF Web site to obtain the latest information about the fair, plan where to go, and compare prices before heading to the Taipei World Trade Center venue, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to help long-term jobless

TEXT.P: An advocacy group for the unemployed urged the government Friday to do more for those without jobs at a time of rising unemployment, especially people who have been without work for more than six months.

According to the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan, 144,000 people at the end of September had been jobless for more than six months, 20,000 more than at the same time last year.
Among them, 66,000 were classified as long-term jobless, meaning they had been without work for more than a year.

The Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has long had diverse measures to promote job creation for the long-term jobless, including subsidizing private businesses to hire those who have been unemployed for more than five months.
The bureau also provides them with training to gain new skills that will better meet the demands of the labor market, a council official said.

But Son Yu-lian, secretary-general of the Taiwan Labor Front, criticized the measures, saying that most long-term jobless are middle-aged or older, and that vocational training has only a limited effect, as some basic skills, such as word processing, present technical challenges.

He also suggested that the Taiwan's persistently high jobless rate indicated that unemployment in the country not only consisted of cyclical unemployment caused by the global economic downturn but also of structural employment.
Structural unemployment occurs when job seekers' skills do not match employer demands in the labor market, generally because of structural changes in the economy.
Son was also skeptical about a newly introduced CLA measure to subsidize businesses for six months that hire workers who have been unemployed for more than three months.

The measures seem to be able to help many people, especially employers who need short-term manpower, but the structural problem cannot be solved with short-term subsidies,he said, predicting that the unemployment rate will remain high until next year.

He suggested that the government create long-term job opportunities in the area of public service, such as tour guides and traffic conductors, and extend the period during which those without work are eligible for unemployment benefits.
Currently, people who lose their jobs can apply for unemployment benefits, equal to 60 percent of the average monthly insured wage under the labor insurance program, for up to six months.
According to the DGBAS, the unemployment rate climbed to 4.27 percent in September, marking the highest level for the same period in the past four years, with 464,000 people out of work.

The global economic downturn has been blamed for the high unemployment rate, as 31 percent of the jobless, or 145,000 people, have lost their jobs due to business closings or downsizing, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: First batch of ARATS officials due to arrive Friday evening

TEXT.P: The first batch of officials from China's quasi-official intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Friday evening to make preparations for the cross- strait high-level dialogue slated to begin in Taipei next week.

The ARATS officials, including: Zheng Lizhong and Li Bingcai, two ARATS vice presidents; Li Yafei, secretary general; and Wang Xiaobing, deputy secretary general, departed from Beijing Capital International Airport around 3:30 p.m., aboard a cross-strait weekend nonstop charter flight operated by the Taipei- based China Airlines (CAL).

They are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at 7: 45 p.m. When ARATS President Chen Yunlin arrives in Taipei Nov. 3, he will be the highest-ranking Chinese official ever to visit Taiwan after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait separated in 1949 after a bloody civil war.

Chen is slated to meet with his Taiwanese counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), during his historic five-day visit in Taipei as a follow-up to the two men's first meeting in Beijing in mid-June.

During the first Chiang-Chen meeting in Beijing, which resumed the cross-strait high-level dialogue that was suspended in 1999, they agreed on the launch of cross-strait nonstop weekend charter flights and the wider opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-smoking group welcomes hike in tobacco tax, but urges more

TEXT.P: The anti-smoking group John Tung Foundation approves of the Cabinet's plan to increase taxes on cigarettes and expand non-smoking areas in public spaces, but more needs to be done in Taiwan to reduce smoking, especially among youngsters, a foundation official said Friday.

Lin Ching-li, the foundation's tobacco hazard prevention section chief, was referring to a draft amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention and Control Act passed by the Cabinet Thursday to increase the health and welfare surcharge on cigarettes to NT$20 per pack from the existing NT$10.
The amendment also included extending non-smoking areas to schools at the senior-high level or below, medical institutions, government units, and offices used by three or more people.
The revisions will take effect Jan. 11 next year after being ratified by the legislature, according to an official of the Department of Health Friday.

According to Lin, the revisions are in accordance with the World Health Organization's recommendation to create non-smoking environments and raise tobacco prices - which it believes are the two most effective measures to reduce tobacco consumption and smoking among young people.
It is rare for a government to promote the two measures simultaneously, Lin said, praising the Executive Yuan for passing the revisions.
A World Bank report in 1999 showed that tobacco consumption is reduced by 4-8 percent and smoking by youngsters by 10 percent if tobacco prices are increased by 10 percent, Lin said.

What is considered a reasonable price for tobacco products in Taiwan should range between NT$80 and NT$100 per pack, based on international pricing levels, and Taiwan's national personal average income of US$15,000 a year, Lin said.
But Taiwan's tobacco prices are still among the lowest in the world, said Lin. During the past two decades, Taiwan has only increased its cigarette prices from NT$45 to NT$60 per pack.
In that same period, New York has raised its tobacco prices from NT$60 to NT$280, and Hong Kong from NT$45 to NT$125, Lin noted.

Hong Kong started actively increasing health surcharges on cigarettes in 1983 and now a pack of tobacco sold there has a surcharge of more than NT$70, Lin said. The effort has successfully reduced the area's smoking rate from 23 percent in 1982 to 14 percent in 2005, according to Lin.
There is still room for Taiwan's government to increase tobacco tax and prices to prevent the island from turning into a haven for tobacco dumping, she said.

According to statistics compiled by the Department of Health, about 23 percent of Taiwan's population are smokers, with the smoking rate of men higher than that of women - 49 percent compared to 5 percent. Meanwhile, one out of 10 people aged below 18 are smokers.
In Taiwan, the legal age for smoking is 18, which means many teenagers are smoking illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu will benefit from cross-strait pacts: vice minister

TEXT.P: The Cross-Taiwan Strait talks to be held next week in Taipei will greatly benefit the outlying Penghu Islands, Vice Minister of the Interior Lai Fong-wei said Friday.
Lai, who served as the offshore county's magistrate from 1997-2005, made the remarks in a published letter to the editor of the local newspaper, Penghu Times.

Although talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) from Nov. 3-7 will focus on the opening of direct shipping links and the expansion of air services between the two sides, Lai said, the negotiations will also benefit the Penghu Islands.

If a shorter route is established between Taiwan's Taoyuan International Airport and Shanghai airports, this would boost the appeal of the island group to more Chinese tourists because of Penghu's location, he said.
The Penghu Islands are located in the Taiwan Strait -- some 140 km south east of mainland China.

A straighter route between Taipei and Shanghai could help reduce the flying time by 62 minutes to 82 minutes, and as much as NT$3 billion (US$915 million) could be saved in carriers' operating costs and travelers' expenditure, Lai said.

In terms of cross-strait cargo shipping, he said, this could help to bring down consumer product prices in Penghu because staple commodities, construction materials and daily necessities could be imported directly from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local groups to launch movement to 'safeguard Taiwan'

TEXT.P: Local pro-Taiwan independence groups announced Friday that they will launch a "Safeguard Taiwan Week" movement starting Nov. 3 in opposition to the visit of China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin.
"Our appeals are to safeguard (the country's) sovereignty and protect Taiwan, " Lo Chih-cheng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Society, one of the organizing groups, said at a news conference.

The series of activities, which will continue until Nov. 7 when Chen Yunlin, the president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is scheduled to leave the island, "would demonstrate Taiwan's public opinion," Lo contended.
The groups called upon Taiwan's people to stand up and make their voices heard by the international community.

The organizers suggested five ways to show support for Taiwan and object to Chen's visit, such as wearing clothes with protest slogans or joining the vigil held by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and other local pro- independence groups.
They also encouraged people to phone, fax or e-mail the Grand Hotel, where Chen will stay during his landmark visit, to protest the more than 1,000 missiles China has targeted at Taiwan.
Balloons reading "Taiwan is my country" will be distributed in venues such as Taipei Railway Station and at exits of the city's major metro stations.

Chen's delegation will meet with their counterparts from the quasi-official Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation to sign agreements on the expansion of chartered passenger flights between Taiwan and China, the launch of direct shipping and postal links and the establishment of a mechanism to deal with food safety issues.

Chen's visit has proven controversial, with the DPP and pro-independence groups looking to take advantage of it to vent their doubts over closer ties with China and protest Beijing's threat to use force against Taiwan if it were to declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: New cancer drug released to private maker for R&D: source

TEXT.P: A promising new drug that can inhibit cancer development has been transferred from its developers, two universities in Taiwan, to a multinational pharmaceutical company, which will continue research and development on the medication, academic sources reported Friday.

According to National Taiwan University (NTU) in Taipei and National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan, the drug -- an inhibitor against integrin protein "alpha-nu-beta-3 (\v]3) " -- will be released to the Taiwanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Anchen Pharmaceuticals under an agreement signed Oct. 30 in Taipei.

Chuang Woei-jer, a professor of medicine at NCKU, explained that the integrin alpha-nu-beta-3 adheres one cell to another, which can inadvertently trigger angiogenesis -- a process whereby cancer cells encourage the growth of extra blood vessels to acquire additional nutrition.

By inhibiting the alpha-nu-beta-3, Chuang said, the drug -- dubbed "alpha-nu- beta-3 disintegrin" -- can effectively suppress angiogenesis and the activity of osteoclasts -- a kind of cell that destroys bone cells.
When osteoclasts are over-excited, they can lead a cancer to metastasize to the bones.
Once angiogenesis and osteoclasts are moderated, the tumorous cells will lose their vitality and become more susceptible to the curative powers of other drugs, Chuang said.
Fu Wen-mei, a professor of medicine at NTU, said the new drug can be used to treat cancer's metastasis to the bones, macular degeneration, and osteoporosis.
Potential annual sales of the drug have been estimated at no less than NT$30 billion (about US$910 million), Fu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH foresees better management of medicine herb imports from China

TEXT.P: Taiwan will take steps to ensure the safety of Chinese medicine herbs imported from China, as soon as the two sides forge a food-safety agreement that is expected to stem the inflow of substandard food products from the mainland, an official at Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

Food safety is one of major issues on the agenda of the upcoming talks between Chiang Pin-kun, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yun-ling, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, when the two meet in Taipei in early November.
The issue took center stage with the exposure last month of a toxic milk power incident in China that swiftly expanded into global concern over China-produced substandard food products.

Lin Yi-hsin, chairman of the DOH Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy, said that once the two sides seal the food safety agreement, the committee will seek quality certification of all medicine herbs imported from China.
Taiwan consumes more than 10,000 tons of medicine herbs, which are used not only in traditional Chinese medical treatment, but also as culinary ingredients due to their health benefits.

While 90 percent of these herbs, in a wide variety, are imported from China, it has been difficult for the Taiwanese health authorities to control the quality because there has been no clear channel between the two sides for the management of herbal medicine, Lin admitted.

The quality of China-produced medicine herbs on the Taiwan market at present is mixed, the official said, adding that quite often such imports are found to contain toxic substances like aflatoxin and heavy metals.
However, the problem will be addressed if the two sides sign the agreement on food safety, Lin said, explaining that Chinese medicine herbs are categorized as food products.

Lin noted that the DOH committee has been making efforts over the past years to promote the management of Chinese medicine ingredients. It recently completed work on the proper labeling of these products, and is currently working to set standards on the permissible levels of toxic substances in medicine herbs, he said.
The committee will later concentrate on ensuring the safety of medicine herb sources in China, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't approves NT$10 billion to create new temporary jobs

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved an NT$10 billion (US$303 million) plan Friday that will create temporary jobs and help people in need, beginning Nov. 1, the Executive Yuan said in a statement released Friday.

The plan will create an estimated 46,000 short-term jobs for unemployed workers by the end of this year, the Executive Yuan said, and provide another 56,000 temporary placements for the jobless in the first half of 2009.

Some NT$3.1 billion of the funds for the program have been earmarked from this year's government budget, while the remaining NT$6 billion will be part of the government's spending for next year, the statement said.
Short-term jobs offered in the program will mainly be in the public sector, including street cleaning, community services and river inspection.
The measure is part of the government's efforts to boost employment at a time when the jobless rate is rising due to the global economic downturn.
Unemployment rose to a four-year high in September at 4.27 percent, with 464,000 people out of work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign business associations welcome talks with China

TEXT.P: Three major foreign trade and business groups issued a joint statement Friday welcoming next week's talks between Taiwan and China in Taipei.

In their joint statement, the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei, and the Japanese Chamber of Commerce & Industry Taipei called for substantial progress in the negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), from Nov. 3-7.

The upcoming negotiations between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies will provide a landmark opportunity for the two sides to remove the long-term obstacles between them and are set to benefit Taiwan greatly because they will help boost Taiwan's interaction with one of the world's fast-growing powerhouses, they said.

If a breakthrough could be made on the extension of the current cross-strait weekend passenger charter flights to every day of the week and in the opening of direct air cargo services and shipping links, it would definitely help rebuild the confidence of both Taiwanese and foreign companies, the statement said.

The three major foreign business associations also asserted that foreign enterprises will station more workers in Taiwan if they can dispatch personnel from Taiwan to China in a more convenient and efficient manner.

In a bid to maintain fair market competition, they also expressed the hope that foreign shippers could also be included in the direct shipping program to help them reduce operating costs and boost efficiency.
They said they are looking forward to enhanced cooperation between Taiwan and China in personnel exchanges, cargo transportation and capital movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three special permits to be issued to attract qualified foreigners

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved a visa program aimed at attracting highly qualified foreign personnel to come to Taiwan for academic exchanges, employment or investment, a government economic planner said Friday.

"Under the program, three special cards -- an academic and commercial travel card, an employment pass and a 'plum blossom' permanent residency card -- will be issued from next year to attract outstanding foreign professionals," said San Gee, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

According to San, the CEPD-proposed special visa program emulates the United States' green card, the European Union's blue card, South Korea's IT card, gold card and science card in loosening restrictions on the entry of highly qualified foreign personnel to make them more willing to come to Taiwan to share professional expertise or invest in local industries.

"Under the program, procedures for persons of international repute and senior professionals to apply for entry and residency will be simplified in line with the global trend of attracting outstanding talent," San added.

He further explained that international heavyweights in their fields who want to enter Taiwan for purposes other than work will be issued "academic and commercial travel cards" valid for up to three years, with no limit on the number of visits and eligible to stay for a maximum of 30 days on each visit.

Highly qualified foreign personnel intending to take a job in Taiwan will be issued a "four-in-one" card known as an "employment pass, " which incorporates a visa, work permit, alien resident's certificate and re-entry permit, San said.
For those intending to immigrate to Taiwan based on their professional expertise or investment, "plum blossom" permanent residency cards will be issued, San said.
The Ministry of the Interior will flesh out detailed regulations covering application procedures, required documents and qualifications, the CEPD official added.

Meanwhile, a CEPD proposal to exempt graduates of the world's top 100 universities from a requirement that they must have two years of experience before they can work in Taiwan has not yet been approved by the Executive Yuan.

"In light of the current high domestic unemployment rate, the Cabinet has demanded that the CEPD come up with more extensive complementary measures before opening the door wider to graduates of world famous universities, in order not to affect local college graduates' job opportunities," San said.

In his view, he said, it would be regrettable that a new graduate from Harvard University would be denied the opportunity to work in Taiwan simply because he or she failed to meet the work experience requirement.
"If Taiwan wants to upgrade its service industry, it should take bold steps to ease restrictions regarding the hiring of highly qualified immigrant workers," San added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS advance team arrives in preparation for historic meeting

TEXT.P: A 20-member advance team from China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) arrived in Taipei Friday in preparation for the landmark visit of ARATS' head to Taiwan next week.

Zheng Lizhong, an ARATS vice president who headed the advance team, said the upcoming meeting in Taipei between ARATS President Chen Yulin and his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, will mark a historic step forward in the development of cross-strait relations.
Zheng said his team's main mission is to make sure Chen's visit to Taiwan proceeds smoothly.

Chen is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Nov. 3 for a five-day visit during which he will sign four agreements with Chiang on the establishment of direct postal and shipping links, expansion of direct flight services, and installation of a permanent mechanism to deal with food safety concerns.
Zheng said the advance team will meet with SEF staff to iron out technical details regarding the Chiang-Chen meeting and the agreements they will sign on that occasion.
Members of the ARATS advance team include resident ARATS Vice President Li Bingcai and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei.
